title: Wheels Turn Slowly at 'Hub'
description: By next summer, the intersection of Fordham Road and Third and Park Avenues will be a transportation hub designed to spur economic growth in one of the largest shopping districts in the Bronx. But local merchants are questioning whether the promise of economic growth on Fordham Road is worth what they say has been a loss of business.

title: Help When College Seems an Ocean Away
description: If a mother's love were enough to get a teen-ager into college, Alexandra St. Juste, 17, would surely be bound next fall for New York University, her dream school, where she plans to study computers.

title: Terror Aloft, Death at Sea
description: Officials in the Comoro Islands were left to wonder last week at the motives of terrorists who seized an Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 767 in flight and forced its crew to keep flying until it ran out of fuel and ditched at sea within sight of tourists on an Indian Ocean beach.

title: Trouble Spots On the Road
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Child Labor in the 1990's
description: This time of year makes me think of a teen-ager I once met who knew the world of child labor like Huck Finn knew the river. He thought holidays were awful. Halloween is bad, he told me, and Thanksgiving weekend is worse.

title: Klansman Who Espoused Hate Now Urges an End to Bigotry
description: I'M not a hero. I did wrong. I fouled up big-time.''

title: Deals and Discounts
description: FLY-DRIVE IN SOUTH AFRICA African Travel Inc., a Glendale, Calif., tour operator, is offering eight-night packages for travelers who want to explore South Africa on their own. For $1,999 a person, double occupancy, there's round-trip air fare from New York or Miami to Johannesburg or Cape Town, eight-day car rental with unlimited mileage and all insurance and taxes, and eight nights in various Holiday Inn Garden Court hotels (predeparture booking required) throughout South Africa. Two children or a third adult sharing the room are $1,399 extra. Available through May. For information, call (800) 421-8907.

title: For Songwriters Who Want to Say More Than 'Shooby Dooby Do'
description: FEW can doubt that much of popular music is lyrically challenged. Remember ''Chicago,'' Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young's counterculture call to arms? ''We can CHANGE the world/Ree-uh-RAY-EEE-ANGE the world . . .'' Really profound -- plus it rhymes.

title: Self-Love Makes This World Go Round
description: THERE'S A REASON Noel Coward's work keeps being rediscovered after passing through periodic eclipses during which it's called trivial. His best comedies are not only models of dramatic construction but also too full of slippery wit, elegant put-downs and, most important, unflagging high spirits to go underappreciated for very long.

title: Wealthy, Helped by Wall St., New Find Ways to Escape Tax on Profits
description: Last spring, Wall Street bankers made an irresistible sales pitch to Eli Broad, the billionaire home builder and co-founder of the booming SunAmerica insurance empire.

description: The Muirhead is gone, but the restaurant's name is internationally known, thanks to a concoction called pecan pumpkin butter.

description: A Musical Evening in Brooklyn

title: Little Bug, Big Bang
description: IT TOOK THE European Space Agency 10 years and $7 billion to produce Ariane 5, a giant rocket capable of hurling a pair of three-ton satellites into orbit with each launch and intended to give Europe overwhelming supremacy in the commercial space business.

title: Roadside Icon Promotes Herself and City's Image
description: If ever a city's eccentricities could be turned into flesh, the fame-hungry, appearance-obsessed, publicity-driven spirit of Los Angeles is embodied in the form of Angelyne, the billboard queen.

title: 1854 West End Theater Reopens
description: A historic London theater that has been derelict for 8 years and has not seen a live theater performance for 57, reopened last month in the West End, following a $25 million restoration project. The theater, the Lyceum, on Wellington Street on the edge of Covent Garden, was built in 1854; it closed as a theater in 1939 when it was bought by the London County Council for demolition to make way for an approach road to Waterloo Bridge. World War II intervened and the plan was dropped. After the war it became a dance hall.

description: IMAGININGS OF SAND

title: Tom Clancy
description: Tom Clancy is working with Gen. Fred Franks Jr. on a nonfiction book about the gulf war, to be published in the spring.

title: Care at the Playground
description: YOUR children's favorite playground may not just offer fun and games. It could also make them sick. That's the warning issued this fall by the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission. Beware, they say, of school, day care, park and community playground equipment made of metal or wood with lead-based paint that may now be peeling, chipping and turning into dust.

title: The Ailey Company's Men Make Their Presence Felt
description: DANCE IS A WOMAN, THE SAYING goes. But not necessarily. And not this December at City Center, where the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performs in a four-week season that opens on Wednesday. This year, the range of talents and experience among the male dancers is especially impressive. There are hot newcomers like Jeffrey Gerodias and Amos J. Machanic Jr., who recently moved up from the Ailey junior company, and there is a veteran artist of nuanced subtlety like Dudley Williams, who has performed with the company for 32 years. But those names are just a start. Here are five other dancers who represent the dynamism of the Ailey men. JENNIFER DUNNING

title: Prospects for Change, Not Hope
description: IN the five years since Yugoslavia entered its spiral of ethnic barbarism, outside diplomats have often laid much of the blame at the feet of two ambitious men: Presidents Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and Franjo Tudjman of Croatia. Each built his own political fortune on a base of nationalist passions that he stirred up among his countrymen when Communism collapsed.

title: Solved! Prof. Plum and Cohorts in the Clear
description: A British law clerk who whiled away his time on World War II fire patrol in England dreaming up a board version of a popular parlor game died in such obscurity two years ago, it was learned last week, that not even Colonel Mustard or Miss Scarlet had a clue.

title: The Many Forms of Beloved Holly
description: HOLLY may be on many gardeners' minds at this time of year. Although it is too early to think about buying the berried branches for holiday decoration, the subject surely is worthy of consideration as part of providing premium landscape evergreens.

title: In-Room Treats
description: To the Editor: I wish to respond to Ann Ross, who wrote a letter of enthusiasm about the ''Scottish Treats'' (Oct. 20) accorded her on a trip abroad. Namely ''a tray with an electric pot to heat water, tea bags, instant coffee, sugar, milk and packets of biscuits or cookies.''

title: Three Days of the Concorde
description: It promised the drama of a space shuttle launch, and fittingly, it was a mechanical glitch that delayed the 9 A.M. liftoff of British Airlines' half-size Concorde at the southern end of Times Square last Sunday.

title: Looking At The Same Old Song
description: CAN A SINGER IN A nonmusical role actually ''belt'' a performance? Judging from the intensity Barbra Streisand brings to her starring role in her new film, ''The Mirror Has Two Faces,'' which begins as a screwball romantic comedy and reaches a crescendo of impassioned self-adoration, the answer is yes. Bing Crosby crooned his nonsinging roles, Frank Sinatra swung them, and Elvis Presley rocked his. But the difference between singing and acting is the difference between an ethereal dream and a workout at the gym.

title: A Doctor in the House
description: THE fine old house on West 94th Street has been cut up to fit three families. Its excellent bones are hidden behind sheetrock; its inlaid floors are pierced by a hulking metal spiral staircase; its elegant entrance hallway walls are blanketed with tiny-flower-sprigged pastel wallpaper.

title: The Meadowlands: Swamped by Development
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hartford School Program, Help for Anxious Parents
description: For most of the four years since Carmen Cuevas moved here from Puerto Rico, homework time was riddled with anxiety. With only broken English and a high school equivalency diploma, Ms. Cuevas found many of her children's questions difficult to answer.

title: GUN PLAY
description: 1. Concealed weapons are legal in 31 states, but justifiable use remains a sticky question. 2. Dave Bresnahan, a Utah state legislator, is the newest poster boy. In October he fired his (legal) pistol at two hit-and-run-driving suspects as they fled on foot; now he faces six months in jail. Why? The laws allow for self-defense, not vigilantism. 3. The N.R.A. is pro-Bresnahan, but some gun supporters are wary. After the perps were caught (by someone else), he pulled out a hot-pepper gun and warned, ''Sit down ... we have ways of making you.'' 4. As debate rages, Dead Serious Inc., a group in Texas, is keeping things lively with this prickly offer: It will pay $5,000 to any member who ''kills somebody in accordance with the law.''

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Davis and Riley Win Titles
description: Erin Davis and Jonathon Riley extended their undefeated cross-country seasons yesterday with victories in the Footlocker Northeast Regional High School Championship at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. The top eight boys and top eight girls qualified for the national championship to be held on Dec. 14 in San Diego, Calif.

title: Road for the Senate's Leader Is Expected to Be Tortuous
description: Trent Lott is all the things that most Republican senators want in a leader.

title: For Baronial Splendor, Try Tarrytown
description: RUINED castles like Tintagel or problematic Camelot can inspire romantic yearnings, but now a restored 20th-century castle (erstwhile Axe Castle) perched on a hill in Westchester might fulfill them all. Although this turreted structure with its soaring fortress-like stone walls may seem forbidding, the welcome inside is warm and plush. Dine in the Oak Room and sit in baronial splendor near the massive fireplace; admire the carved-stone mantle, the 17th-century French paneling, the burnished sideboard, the tapestries -- all on a scale to suit a time larger than ours. In daylight, the enclosed veranda provides views seemingly to Cincinnati. Diners wanting a drink before or after a meal will find the bar smart and congenial.

title: A New Antagonist for AIDS
description: In the 1980's, as gay white men downtown waged their highly public fight against AIDS, church leaders uptown in Harlem shook their heads disapprovingly. ''Ministers up here just figured it was divine retribution for sinful behavior,'' recalls Dr. Preston R. Washington, the pastor of Memorial Baptist Church on West 115th Street.

description: INDEPENDENT SPIRIT

description: SHIP leaves port. Ship hits iceberg. Ship goes down, taking more than 1,500 passengers with it. This is a musical?

description: A Roman Catholic priest and a church employee on their way to deposit $6,000 from the collection basket in a Queens bank were robbed last week by two men armed with automatic weapons.

title: Keeping The Crowd On Its Toes
description: COMING out of the opening-night performance of the New York City Ballet on Tuesday, Isaac Mizrahi felt like dancing.

title: How Crazy Was Zelda?
description: By the time these letters were written, f. scott fitzgerald had been struggling for years to find the right approach to his wife Zelda's recurrent mental illness. She started to show signs of serious disturbance in the late 1920's, and in November 1930 she began a 15-month stay at the Prangins Clinic in Switzerland. Three months after her release, she had a relapse, and Fitzgerald contacted Dr. Jonathan Slocum, owner of a posh clinic, Craig House, in Beacon, N.Y.

description: The day after the war crimes tribunal in The Hague handed down its first sentence, there was a feeling in this town today that for some of the people killed in the Bosnian war justice may have at least begun.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: I found all of Andrew Sullivan's article ''When Plagues End'' (Nov. 10) interesting and some of it profoundly insightful, but a sense of class privilege lingers between the lines. What, for example, are these ''circuit'' parties that he speaks of? Who has the time and money to spend on these things? (I have never heard of them. Perhaps I have been too busy running from the doctor's office to the drugstore.)

title: Riding the Bull for a Day
description: AT 7:15 A.M., MICHAEL P. DICARLO STEPS OUT OF HIS CONDOMINIUM AND, UNDER A MURKY SKY, finds his partner, G. Ross Forbes Jr., waiting to start the one-mile walk up Beacon Hill to Boston's financial district. By 7:45, when they enter the gleaming office tower at 75 State Street, heels are already clicking across the marble floors. It's Wednesday, Sept. 11, and Wall Street is purring along -- its stocks soaring ever higher -- in defiance of the odds, history and perhaps logic itself.

title: So Travolta Is Avant-Garde?
description: For 25 years, Jonas Mekas's Anthology Film Archives has functioned as a sanctuary for classic and avant-garde films. On any given evening, you could almost expect the ghost of Lionel Barrymore to materialize in the lobby of the red-brick film fortress on Second Avenue and strike up a conversation with a black-clad film maker looking for funds to finish a magnum opus that no one will ever see.

title: A Warning on Dangers Of Smoking Heroin
description: Heroin users call it ''chasing the dragon,'' a fanciful euphemism for inhaling burning heroin fumes in a ritual evocative of Asian opium dens.

title: Schulberg Tackling Fitzgerald Play Anew
description: IN a rambling house overlooking the water in Quiogue, a sleepy hamlet tucked between Westhampton and Quogue, Budd Schulberg, one of the only living links to F. Scott Fitzgerald, talked about ''The Disenchanted,'' his fictional tale of their cataclysmic collaboration on a film script.

title: The Devils Lose as Brodeur Does Not Play
description: Jacques Lemaire, the Devils coach who seems to revel in keeping his players off guard while demanding unyielding loyalty to his grind-it-out system, threw a doozy at the Devils tonight, when he chose to start the rookie goaltender Mike Dunham instead of the experienced Martin Brodeur against the Western Conference's No. 1 team, the Colorado Avalanche.

title: When a Landfill Is Too Full
description: WITH its cover of dead leaves, the hill that rises alongside Route 7 in southern New Milford looks much like the any of nearby hills that dot the landscape. Reaching 160 feet at its peak, it spreads over 75 acres in the industrial-commercial stretch of town, a place that might seem suited for skiing or sledding in the months ahead.

title: Mistaken Man
description: ''We don't want to offend Native Americans,'' says Stephen McNallen, the president of the 500-strong Asatru Folk Assembly. ''Because, really, we have a lot in common with them.'' Like: a craving for the same skeleton. Recently, during a Federal court hearing, the California-based Asatru -- a Euro-American ''tribe'' that seriously embraces pre-Christian pagan religion -- made a bid for the 9,300-year-old Kennewick Man, unearthed last summer in Kennewick, Wash. A coalition of Native Americans is already trying to wrest the bones away from archaeologists to rebury them. The Asatru, who contend that the skeleton may belong to a Caucasian who migrated from Europe via the ancient Bering land bridge, want to bury it, too -- their way. ''We'd call upon the gods,'' says McNallen. ''We'd dip a branch in mead.''

title: Builders Are Taking Part of Financial Risk
description: WHEN the building boom of the 1980's turned into the bust of the 1990's, the construction companies that prospered putting up high-rise office towers had to scramble to find work. Some turned to interior work, while others focused on the public sector, building schools, hospitals and other medical facilities.

title: Ambitious Serb Takes On His Less Telegenic Twin
description: Zoran Djindjic, in his trademark black turtleneck and light brown tweed jacket, stepped onto the balcony of the opposition headquarters overlooking Terazije Square and raised his arms triumphantly to the cheering crowd of 100,000.

title: In Prosecutor's Rise and Fall, a Story of Ambition, Deceit and Shame
description: When Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. put a gun in his mouth and pulled the trigger in a $20 room on a neon strip here, it was almost the cliche ending to an ambitious man's rise and fall.

title: An Indian-Style Gem Takes On a New Role
description: In a neighborhood chockablock with architectural gems, the teak-trimmed house at 7 East 10th Street makes its brick and brownstone brethren look like drably appointed poor cousins. The Lockwood de Forest house, an explosion of intricately carved flowers, elephants and birds, is one of Greenwich Village's most eye-grabbing buildings and the only ''Indian style'' row house in the city. Architectural historians say it may be the only one of its kind in North America.

When he married Elizabeth Hart in 1856, he turned the wedding into an advertising opportunity, trimming the six-foot-tall wedding cake with sugar pistols and rifles and topping it off with a rearing colt.

title: What's to Be Done About John Brown?
description: EDWARD DeLISLE thinks it's unconscionable that Torrington doesn't do more to memorialize its most famous native son, John Brown. After all, the abolitionist's martyrdom on a Virginia gallows was the kindling that ignited the Civil War and eventually ended slavery. It's a lost opportunity, said Mr. DeLisle, who lives about a mile from Brown's birthplace.

title: After the Dustbuster, a Clean Sweep
description: GENERAL MOTORS may still be the Goliath of Detroit, but it had long seemed powerless to fend off mini-van attacks from the auto industry's Davids. While Chrysler remained the king of small vans and other companies offered competitive models, G.M. struggled to come up with a mini-van that could hold its own in the surging market.

title: Military Cuts Benefit McGuire and Fort Dix
description: In the Pentagon's post-cold war campaign to streamline domestic military operations, one base's loss is often another's gain. For McGuire Air Force Base in Wrightstown, a shift in the missions of Barksdale Air Force Base in Louisiana and Symore-Johnson Air Force Base in North Carolina has meant an influx of 32 KC-10 refueling planes and about 1,000 pilots, mechanics and other personnel, said Lieut. Steve Lygren, a spokesman for McGuire.

title: Death as a Friend
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin was the last great american catholic leader of the Second Vatican Council era. The words that describe that epic period -- open, forward-looking, moderate, collegial -- described him. Cardinal Bernardin, who rose rapidly to national leadership and who was at the center of almost every major development in American Catholicism for three decades, was perfectly suited to the era.

title: Aging Schools Facing Problems From Air Pollution
description: THE discovery of molds and fungi growing in damp areas of a Stamford elementary school this fall was the latest sign to state health and education officials that Connecticut's aging school buildings -- and some adjacent playgrounds -- may be hazardous to children's health.

title: Continental Aplomb
description: YOU can eat in the finest restaurant in the world, and it might not handle as large a crowd with as much grace and skill,'' a lawyer says about a recent dinner for 25 that he attended at Stephen's Cafe.

title: France's Newest Belle de Jour
description: THERE IS A WEB SITE ON the Internet devoted to French actresses who are, naturellement, young and beautiful. The site is called Belles de Jour and, with the sleeper success of her film ''A Single Girl,'' Virginie Ledoyen -- beautiful, and just turned 20 -- has landed on it. Her entry comes complete with a filmography (she has a small part in another French film opening soon, ''La Ceremonie''), biographical data (she was a child model for Lacoste) and a link to a photograph of her in a black bra.

title: Trades to Remember: Biggest Deals on the Big Board
description: WHEN John T. Dorrance 3d, grandson of the founder of Campbell Soup, sold $720 million of the company's stock in October, it was the seventh-biggest trade ever on the New York Stock Exchange. But it was hardly typical of these giant deals.

title: The New Fowler's
description: WE ALL KNOW how the word peccadillo is now often used: as a minimization, or dismissal as insignificant, of a brief, secret extramarital affair by a politician. In the synonymy of political sin, it is more than an indiscretion and much less than a zipper problem. And yet all our major dictionaries shy from this current meaning, preferring the more general ''trivial offense,'' ''trifling fault'' or ''minor sin.''

title: U.S. and China Spin A Tale of Warmth
description: Only in the precarious relationship between the United States and China could a meeting that resolves no differences be termed a success by both sides. But that was the official spin Sunday in Manila when Bill Clinton sat down with President Jiang Zemin while on his trip to Asia to confer with the area's leaders on economic matters. When the meeting ended, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang had agreed to exchange state visits -- but not until a year from now -- and they got nowhere on human rights and arms proliferation.

description: Allowing voters to register on Election Day has helped make Maine's voter turnout the best in the nation, but some critics question whether the end justifies the means.

title: To Expand, a Club Goes Underground
description: One fortuitous inch has made it possible for the Princeton Club at 15 West 43d Street to significantly expand its athletic space -- into the building next door -- raising prospects, club officials said, for recruiting and retaining younger members.

title: The Numbers Support Gulf War Syndrome Claims
description: Since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, veterans have complained of intestinal problems, joint pain, skin rashes, chronic fatigue, memory loss and a host of other symptoms that have collectively become known as Gulf War Syndrome. But until now, it was not clear that they were suffering those ailments in any larger number than troops who did not serve in the gulf.

description: THE biggest news of the holiday season is being made by the Eglevsky Ballet, which, under the direction of Jane Miller Gifford, will dance a new old edition of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: A Memorial for Savio
description: A memorial for Mario Savio, a student leader of the Free Speech Movement at the University of California at Berkeley in the 1960's, will be held at noon on Dec. 8 in the Pauley Ballroom on the Berkeley campus. Listed among the speakers are several people who played significant roles in the Free Speech Movement, including his widow, Lynne Hollander, Bettina Aptheker and Michael Rossman. Prof. Reggie Zelnik, chairman of the history department at the university, is also scheduled to speak. Mr. Savio, a teacher at Sonoma State University, died on Nov. 6 at 53.

title: Despite Good Record, Some Safety Concerns
description: WHILE offering room for a crowd, mini-vans are often considered ideal family vehicles because they are fairly large and stable and have many safety features. Indeed, mini-vans have a generally good safety record, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which receives money from insurers to study ways to make cars more crashworthy.

title: State's Littlest College Survives on Ukraine Connection
description: UNDER the facade of a handsome Tudor building, across a wide expanse of lawn flecked with the yellows and reds of fallen leaves, a group of young men enjoy some time away from their books as they practice kicking, dribbling and shooting soccer balls into a net. A familiar autumnal image of a Connecticut campus, perhaps, yet one that would have been unimaginable only a few years ago.

title: O'Bannon's Low Profile a Reluctant Look
description: Ed O'Bannon was as visible and familiar here as a palm tree, a part of the cool, soothing scenery and a towering fixture in the Los Angeles area.

title: The Sun Sets on the Cichlids
description: DARWIN'S DREAMPOND

title: You See Puppies, She Sees Coats
description: 101 Dalmatians

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SERPENT ON THE ROCK

title: You See Puppies, She Sees Coats
description: Star Trek: First Contact

title: Immigrants Again Renew Sunset Park
description: THE history of the Sunset Park community of Brooklyn is a tale of the effect of waves of immigration on community life. In the 1990's, the tale is being retold with new twists.

title: French Air Shuttle Doubles Its Flights
description: Shuttle service between Paris and three major regional cities has increased on Air Inter Europe, the state-owned French airline company. The Navette (shuttle) from Paris Orly airport serves Toulouse and Marseilles every 30 minutes at peak periods, and every hour in between; and Nice every hour. The new schedule offers twice as many flights as Air Inter's previous schedules.

title: A Public Voice for Hispanic Interests
description: LAST year, Fernando Betancourt, 37, was appointed the first executive director of the Connecticut Latino and Puerto Rican Affairs Commission, newly created by the General Assembly.

title: Baseball, History and the Future Clash in a City Park
description: River Bank Park by the Passaic River has served the people of the Ironbound neighborhood of Newark since the early 1900's. Residents like Nancy Zak have jogged on its track, wandered under its sycamore trees and watched children play ball on its emerald expanses.

title: The Essence Of Her Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Dorian S. May, Fotis G. Hasiotis
description: Dorian Sue May, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph E. May of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married last evening to Fotis George Hasiotis, the son of Nefelle and Menelaus Hasiotis of Trumbull, Conn. Cantor David Benedict performed an interfaith ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York.

title: Performers With Style, Timeliness
description: PLEASE don't call the performers who do their solo shows at Real Art Ways performance artists. And avoid the term avant garde, Will K. Wilkins implores.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: Sullivan goes too far too fast. He speaks with the hope of those who have recently tested positive. He speaks with a relatively intact immune system. And he speaks from a place of privilege. The new drug therapies may provide a momentary reprieve, maybe more, but they are not a cure.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture is omitted from some copies of the Travel section today at the bottom of the Practical Traveler column about holiday gifts on page 4. As noted in the caption, the picture would have shown a license plate game in ''Kids Travel Book.''

title: Collectors' Favorites at Antiquarius
description: WHEN the Christmas antiques show in Greenwich called Antiquarius opens on Friday, prestigious American and English antiques dealers will be there as usual, but ''Greenwich Collections'' will also be part of the show. That exhibition -- curated by Derek Ostergard, associate director of the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, and Sandra Joys, director of Christie's education program, will honor Greenwich residents and their collections. ''We're not letting the cat out of the bag,'' Sandra Joys said. ''But what is collected and why will be unveiled.''

title: 15 Suburban Families Try Mini-Vans On for Size
description: IN the 1950's, 60's and 70's it would have been hard to imagine the suburbs without the station wagon. From the Ford Country Squire to the Oldsmobile Vista Cruiser, with or without a rack on the roof and fake wood on the sides, the wagon was the epitome of family transportation.

title: At F.D.A., Kessler Leaves a Negative Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: The State of Disunion
description: THIS month is a three-year anniversary for Paula Doremus, one consumed by regret for the past, uneasiness for the future.

title: THE DISSENT OF MAN
description: Regarding your Sunday item ''The Dissent of Man'' (Nov. 10): During my seminary studies on Genesis, a professor pointed out the contradiction between the creation date of 4004 B.C., based on a literal interpretation of Genesis by the Irish cleric James Ussher, and the scientific evidence that the earth is billions of years old. One student, still devoted to a literal reading of Scripture, quickly replied, ''God can create old rocks if He wants to.''

title: The Equalizer
description: My first car was a brand-new 1969 midnight blue Malibu convertible loaded with power windows, power door locks, air-conditioning and a left-foot accelerator. This last option really wasn't an option. Without it, I would have been reduced to sitting in the driveway and playing with the windows. Eighteen months earlier, I became totally paralyzed after breaking my neck in a high-school wrestling class. By the summer of 1969, I had defied the experts who had said I would never move again, but I needed crutches, and my right foot wasn't strong enough to step on the gas. So my parents bought an accelerator that could be positioned to the left of the brake.

title: For Kin of Some Jet Crash Victims, Not Hearing Last Tape Is Too Much to Bear
description: Susan Smith says she knows there are people who might not understand why she wants to hear the tape of the final terrifying minutes of the Valujet flight that caught fire and crashed in the Everglades in May, killing her 24-year-old son, Jay, and the other 109 on board. According to a transcript of the tape, which has been released, the passengers were screaming that the plane was on fire.

title: Coping With the Season
description: How do you deal with the frenzy of the Christmas season?

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: Drugs do not end epidemics. Plagues abate because of changes in human behavior, living conditions, hygiene, resistance to infection or microbial ecology. In part, this requires persistent, global educational efforts in disease prevention. Because such efforts will not be wholly successful, we also need to understand why most people who are exposed to H.I.V. do not become infected. It is not widely appreciated, for example, that the great majority of health care workers stuck by H.I.V.contaminated needles do not develop AIDS. They mount an initial immune response to the virus that prevents persistent viral infection. The same is true of African women who can resist infection after exposure.

title: Life in the Spotlight, Death in Disgrace
description: An unexceptional child of New Jersey's modest suburbs, Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. quickly learned the importance of appearances. An ordinary baseball catch, people recalled, would be turned into a freeze-frame performance. He rose to become a feared prosecutor in Somerset County, known for his swaggering assault on drug dealers. He capitalized on the attention and craved more.

title: Country Inn Style, Old-Fashioned Menu
description: IN Washington Depot, an old house overlooking the Shepaug River is now home to the G. W.Tavern, in space formerly occupied by the Bee Brook restaurant. To evoke a tavern mode while avoiding a cutesy faux-antique look isn't easy but G. W. Tavern has managed to do so with a landscape mural of soft colors (reminiscent of the work of 18th- and 19th-century itinerant artists) that wraps around the walls of the entrance hall and main dining room.

title: On the T.W.A. Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprises Brighten Holiday Music Programs
description: DESPITE the preponderance of traditional works like Handel's ''Messiah'' and carols, the music scene for the holiday season holds a few surprises.

title: Playoff Equation for Giants and Eagles: Just Don't Lose
description: There are no more scenarios. No more waiting. Or wondering. It has come down to this: If the Giants beat the struggling Philadelphia Eagles at Veterans Stadium today, they keep their extremely slim playoff hopes alive. If they lose, they will be playing the rest of the season for pride. It is that simple.

title: The Battle of Gramercy Park: Chapter 2
description: WE last visited Gramercy Park through a conceit; we pretended to have tumbled into an Edith Wharton novel. How else to explain the increasingly vicious and expensive battle between Sharen Statler Benenson, the elegant and imperious chairwoman of the board of trustees of the city's only private park, and O. Aldon James Jr., the energetic and wickedly clever president of the National Arts Club, whose front door faces the park.

title: History in a Hurry
description: EUROPE

title: Five Stars to Play at Emelin Theater Benefit
description: ON Tuesday at 8 P.M. the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck is giving itself a gala 25th-anniversary benefit with a stellar gathering on its stage. The recital has Isaac Stern and Yefim Bronfman playing Prokofiev's F minor Violin and Piano Sonata, and the cellist Lynn Harrell will join Mr. Bronfman for the ''Fantasiestucke,'' Op. 88, by Schumann.

title: Long-Distance Runner
description: This was not my first campaign. In 1995 I ran for the State Assembly in the Eighth District, getting nearly 2,000 votes and the endorsement of The Courier-Post because of my ''vast knowledge of the issues'' and ''willingness to consider alternatives to the usual stopgap measures.'' My campaign budget was $22.50, spent on printer paper, postage and gas to get to a few public forums. Since several newspapers printed my ''10-Point Plan to Restructure New Jersey Public Schools for the 21st Century,'' I decided not to print fliers. I considered the campaign a success; my Libertarian Party colleagues were ecstatic, especially since the news media have traditionally ignored serious third-party candidates.

title: Tackling Football In Full Gear At Early Age
description: THOUGH baseball may be considered the national pastime, don't tell that to the devotees of football. For these die-hards, the pro football season, which culminates in the Super Bowl at the end of January, is not long enough. Nor is the college season, which ends with the bowl games on New Year's Day, nor the high school season, which is coming to a close now.

title: Solution to Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: SNOWIKAZE
description: In the endless quest to keep orthopedic surgeons busy, Aspen is turning to the ultimate adrenaline rush: speed. Starting next month, the Colorado resort will open what officials claim is the nation's first ''citizen'' speed skiing courses: a variety of steep, carefully groomed runs that will let helmet-wearing patrons blitz downhill at 65 miles per hour. Dave Bellack, general counsel for the Aspen Skiing Company, says the course is specially designed -- no bumps, no obstacles -- to ''minimize catastrophic injury.'' (Thanks!) Still, signing a liability waiver and passing a skills test will be mandatory. ''When you're going that fast,'' says Bellack, ''you can't just stand up and yell, 'Yahoooo!' ''

title: A Show Where Automobiles Are Taking the High Road
description: OVER the course of 20 years, Terry and Eva Herndon of Carlisle, Mass., have amassed a collection focused entirely on representations of the car in art. More than 80 works in a variety of media have been assembled into a traveling exhibition, ''Art From the Driver's Seat: Americans and Their Cars.'' It is currently parked at the Hudson River Museum here, and it is a great ride.

title: Hopping to Who Knows Where
description: THOUSANDS of Long Islanders, including me, will be up in the air this weekend, flying toward or away from their families according to taste.

title: You're Under Arrest
description: O.K., you're innocent. They always say that. It wasn't you, you say, who was walking down the street drinking that beer, relieving yourself against the wall, scalping those tickets to the United States Open or smoking that joint in Washington Square Park.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: The fact that protease inhibitors have had profoundly beneficial effects for many persons with AIDS is cause for celebration and, perhaps, even hope. Nevertheless, an enormous amount of research still needs to be done, and predictions of victory are still years away.

title: How Cars Lost Their Character
description: DURING the late middle ages in Europe, before nation states developed, artists commonly moved, with little regard for borders, from one noble court to the next in search of patrons. The constant migration of artists trying to please aristocrats who had strikingly similar tastes produced what is known as the International style.

title: Affirmative Action Battle Moves to Courts
description: Opponents of affirmative action were jubilant on Election Day when California voters handily passed a citizens' initiative, Proposition 209, that banned all programs involving race and sex preferences run by the state.

title: Success Comes to Trotter Trainer After Two Decades
description: IT has taken Joe Guarino a lifetime to become an instant success in harness racing. With a resume like that, a sense of humor helps.

title: If They Only Had a Home . . .
description: When the final curtain fell last Sunday on ''My Child,'' a musical at the Queens Family Theater, the actors headed for the parking lot, their heads low, their suitcases packed. For the third time in five years, the theater group is homeless.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 3 with a review of ''The Architect of Desire: Beauty and Danger in the Stanford White Family,'' by Suzannah Lessard, misspelled the surname of a partner in White's architectural firm. He was William Rutherford Mead, not Meade.

title: China Tries to Claim Tibet, Disney ... All of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Beating the Odds Is Nothing New
description: ROBI DANIELS, of West Hartford, leaned forward, pumped his arms faster and powered up the final hill of a five-mile road race in Wallingford one recent Saturday. Cheering on 14-year-old Robi from the sidelines was his coach, Donald Chaffee, of Newington.

description: The Emotional Brain

title: A Guide to the Goofs of Wall Street's Wizards
description: EVERYBODY makes a blunder at work now and then, but when a Wall Street stock analyst does, investors can lose millions.

description: GRAND armies are not always what it takes to make an impressive showing on the mutual fund battlefield.

title: Classical Briefs
description: ARGENTO: SONG CYCLES; VAUGHAN WILLIAMS: VOCAL WORKS

title: Guidelines for Using Supplemental Room Heaters Safely
description: EVERY year there are more than 50,000 fires reported to fire departments. Ninety percent of these fires occur in one- and two-family homes, and more than 4,000 people die in these fires. Twenty-two percent of the residential fires were caused by careless use of supplemental room heaters, like wood- or coal-burning stoves, kerosene heaters and electrical heaters.

title: No Headline
description: ''The simple fact is that anyone sitting on a big pot of money today probably isn't paying capital gains taxes. And the Government can adopt rule after rule after rule -- but the people who will get stuck paying capital gains taxes will be the ordinary investors who own mutual funds.''

title: Classical Briefs
description: ROSSINI: 'TANCREDI'

title: Sin of Omission
description: In this age of shifting moral ground, when a 7-year-old's chaste kiss raises political and ethical hackles, our friend recounts a modern tale of behavioral confusion. Because she works for a large company and because this incident rises to some dubious blushing heights, let us merely call our friend Joel.

title: Arkansas Plans to Execute Three Murderers on the Same Night
description: Three convicted murderers have been scheduled for death on the same night next January in what will be the second triple execution in the United States since the Supreme Court authorized a resumption of capital punishment 20 years ago.

title: Go Ahead, Make My Day
description: CLINT EASTWOOD

title: Miss Simmons, Mr. Kyd-Rebenburg
description: Lesley Simmons, a corporate lawyer in Paris, and Georg Kyd-Rebenburg, a sales and marketing director in Vienna, were married on Friday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey performed the ceremony.

title: A Career Finally Clicks, and the Challenges Begin
description: AFTER a failed career and a fiery accident, Donna Hartley has finally seen the dust settle in her life. But that doesn't mean it's time to rest. Now, this 49-year-old single mother faces a whole new challenge as she seeks financial security for herself and her 16-month-old daughter.

title: FRANKENCATS
description: Frankencats'' must have been written by a cat hater (Sunday, Nov. 10). These supposedly ''genetic feline mutations'' (the Bengal, La Perm and the Sphynx) happen to be just as loving as your everyday tabby. Many cats are, in fact, mutations, but so what? That's not rare these days. We own a 2-year-old Bengal who is no wilder than a ''normal cat.''

title: INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: I wonder if even you realize how good Andrew Sullivan's article on the AIDS epidemic is. It deserves publication in book form, making it permanently available.

title: Catherine Foxley, Laurence Cohen
description: Catherine Burns Foxley, a daughter of Mrs. Kenneth W. Washburn of Providence, R.I., and William C. Foxley of La Jolla, Calif., was married last evening to Laurence Greg Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Cohen of Denver. The Rev. Robert J. Robbins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, in which Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel participated, at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: No Trespassing
description: THE BOOK OF YAAK

title: Dominicans Now Have A New Kind Of Leader
description: When his 12-hour work day at the National Palace is over, this country's new President does not always head home. He is just as likely to make a late-night, unannounced visit to a poor neighborhood, market or hospital, just to see what is going on and what he can do.

title: AN EYE FOR THE ID
description: Regarding Peter Marks's article ''An Eye for the Id'' (Nov. 10), about the stage director Scott Elliott: The next time you hear someone say I'm difficult, bet him $1,000 that he can't name a single incident where I have caused a problem. You'll make yourself some easy money.

title: God's Playbook
description: In my 25 years of sportswriting, I have found that nothing inspires the cynicism in my journalistic peers -- an admittedly skeptical lot -- as much as the athlete or coach who has ''found God'' or who tells post-game interviewers that his belief in God made victory possible.

title: 2 Ex-Workers Charge Bias At the Statue of Liberty
description: Anthony Washington said he surged with ''pride and dignity'' when he was appointed a National Park Service ranger at the Statue of Liberty.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Tea for Few

title: The $13,900 Model (No, It's Not a Car)
description: WHAT La Cornue, a chrome and stainless-steel stove from France you can park in your kitchen (sticker price $13,900) that is featured in the Williams-Sonoma cookware catalogue. And yes, that's Williams-Sonoma (800-541-2233), not Neiman Marcus. So far, four have been ordered.

title: Loft Conversions Bloom North of Chicago's Loop
description: NEARLY seven-and-a-half years after a fire destroyed what was supposed to be the first large-scale, largely residential loft conversion in this city's trendy art gallery district, development of living quarters has returned to the River North neighborhood, just across the Chicago River from the Loop business district.

title: Cajun Cooking to Satisfy Many Palates
description: THE friendly voice on the telephone at Cooking With Jazz suggested we bring a hearty appetite. It was the voice of Steven Van Gelder, the enthusiastic chef and owner of this small Cajun spot in Whitestone, Queens.

title: Fighting Crime With Education
description: An alarming increase in the number of youths aged 10 to 17 who are arrested for violent crimes in the United States has many state officials pushing tougher laws, trying more youths in adult courts and locking them up with adult prisoners. But few states are making equally strong efforts to keep youthful offenders from returning to prison once they are released. One sensible approach is to use education as an antidote to juvenile crime.

title: Hefty Pickings in Hong Kong
description: PROPELLED by a spectacular rally in Hong Kong stocks, two Hong Kong funds have jumped to the highest ranks in the list of one-year leaders among international stock funds.

title: Prime Time Grapples Over the Human Soul
description: WE ARE NOW, officially, a country of cynics. If this television season has told us anything -- and television always plays back society's bedrock assumptions -- it is that suspicion defines the national character. Here are the attitudes that the best, smartest new shows have been built on: politicians are spun out of public relations images, money is everything, cops are crooked.

title: Corrections
description: A New Yorkers & Co. article last Sunday, about The Amsterdam News, omitted the attribution for its designation as the nation's oldest continuously published black newspaper. That is what The Amsterdam News considers itself. Three other black newspapers -- The Philadelphia Tribune, founded in 1884; The Baltimore Afro-American, 1892, and The Chicago Defender, 1905 -- say they have published continuously and longer. The Amsterdam News was founded in 1909.

title: Not an Altered Show, But a Separate Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Plunging Down River
description: IT is not often that anyone puts his life in the hands of a total stranger who admits to being a smuggler, a heavy drinker and a daredevil willing to navigate a treacherous river on the blackest of nights to slip an illicit cargo past the police. But this may be necessary for anyone interested in a wild ride up the Daning River in the Three Gorges area of central China.

title: A Cornered Fugitive Ends It All
description: Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. talked tough almost to the end.

title: Broccoli Rape Teams With Pizza and Pasta
description: BROCCOLI RAPE is an underrated vegetable. Italians and Chinese use it a great deal, but Americans have tended to overlook it because of its bitter taste, which some people find off-putting. Also known as stem broccoli, broccoli rabe or rapini, it looks like a flowering head of broccoli, but it is more closely related to the turnip family.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Simpson Keeps to His Story
description: O. J. Simpson absorbed blow after blow on the witness stand last week, repeatedly denying accusations that he was a liar and murderer but unable to explain how blood got on his property and how he cut his hand.

title: Q. & A.
description: Disclosing A Negative Report

title: Florida's Big Dreams Are Shattered
description: Blitzed and battered, Danny Wuerffel had a Heisman Trophy coronation deteriorate all around him this afternoon. Florida State came within one victory of a second national championship in four seasons by bullying Wuerffel with a relentless defensive effort and surviving the desperate comeback of the top-ranked Florida Gators in a 24-21 victory.

title: Taking to Task A Report on Zen
description: How very disappointing! The story about the Empty Hand Zendo in Rye (''For a Foray Into Zen: Be Ready to Listen,'' Sept. 29) had so many errors and inaccuracies.

title: Dr. Brookman and Ms. Shepard
description: Jennifer Beth Shepard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Shepard of Dix Hills, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Frederick Roy Brookman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Brookman of Southampton, L.I. Rabbi Robert Benjamin performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: How the Hispanic Community Helps Itself
description: SIX years ago, Charles Gonzalez went into a meeting of the Westchester Hispanic Chamber of Commerce as a guest and walked out as an officer of the organization.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday about comparison shopping for cold remedies misstated the prices for a large box of Kleenex. At Bigelow's Pharmacy, on the Avenue of the Americas near Eighth Street, the price was $1.89; at Love's, on Madison Avenue near 88th Steet, $1.99; at D'Agostino, at University Place near 11th Street, $2.19; at Duane Reade, on Seventh Avenue near 28th Street, $1.49.

title: In Fight Over Cleaners, Neighbors Lead by a Nose
description: After detecting excessively high levels of a harmful cleaning solvent in several apartments above a dry-cleaning plant in TriBeCa, city officials shut the business last week calling it ''detrimental to the life and health of residents.''

title: Needier Than Ever
description: The children, the sick, the elderly and the poor, who make up the most defenseless elements of New York City's population, have suffered brutal blows from cutbacks in government services in recent years. Though the city's economy has picked up a bit, the financing of programs for people in distress has not been restored to its old levels. The signs of trouble are as visible as the homeless in the streets, the abandoned buildings and the abused children in the headlines. Public-minded citizens find themselves wanting to help but wondering whether it is possible to make a difference in the lives of others.

title: Ms. Rifkind, Mr. Brandenburger
description: Barbara Rifkind, the general manager of the world-language division of Addison Wesley Longman, an educational publisher in White Plains, is to be married today to Adam M. Brandenburger, a professor of business strategy at the Harvard Business School in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Daniel Alder is to perform the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York.

title: Consultants: The Other Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Vacation Apparently No Cure For 'Song'
description: Unbridled's Song, the star-crossed hero of the Kentucky Derby, tried to erase the tensions and trauma and sore feet of his troubled spring when he went to the races yesterday for the first time in four months. But he may also have lost his dynamite speed, as he showed when he ran second to Pacific Fleet in an allowance race at Aqueduct.

title: Plant a Black Walnut (for Your Grandchildren)
description: I like to spend Thanksgiving at the family farm in Maryland, walking the fields of stubbled cornstalks and being careful not to trample the newly planted winter wheat. The air is rich with a good kind of decay -- of fallen oak leaves and black walnuts.

title: Another Loss to Miami Costs Syracuse Millions
description: After eight consecutive victories, Syracuse finds itself with a deflating season bookended in defeat. Today's familiar tormentor was Miami, and the humbling 38-31 loss was particularly costly to the Orangemen, both in the Big East standing and in the pocketbook.

title: Finding Art in the Artifacts of the Masses
description: NOT SO LONG AGO THE letters P.C. stood unequivocally for political correctness. But in certain quarters of the art world at least, this may be changing. Walking through ''A/Drift,'' the hip, alternately stimulating and grating exhibition at the Center for Curatorial Studies Museum at Bard College here, it seems that P.C. may soon denote another art-world obsession: popular culture.

title: The Charms of Japan's Little Edo
description: THE seasoned vendor with unruly white eyebrows and a towel around his head grunted thanks as I paid for a beat-up, backpack-like basket used for carrying tea. Strapping it around my shoulders, I pushed through the flea market crowds at Narita-san Temple -- eyeing piles of old silk kimonos, rows of hand-wrought farm tools, a 1950's Columbia record player here, a perfectly preserved navy officer's uniform there -- until I found my companions for the day and my reason for going to the city of Kawagoe 10 years ago: the Kongoh family, lost in thought over a display of antique tea bowls.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-20

title: The House Can Make You Sick
description: DO you have a sore throat, runny nose or watery, itchy eyes? Are you sneezing, coughing or wheezing? Does your head ache? Feeling tired and irritable? You may have picked up a bug from a friend, family member or co-worker. Or you may have gotten sick from your house.

title: Corrections
description: Article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about protests at Rockefeller University by an animal-rights group, In Defense of Animals, misstated the group's position. In Defense of Animals believes that cats used in a current research project at the university can feel the effects of experiments performed on them because while the process they undergo, decerebration, severs the spine from the brain, it leaves much of the brain's sensory reception intact.

title: Ms. O'Loughlin And Mr. Moses
description: Noreen O'Loughlin, a marketing executive, was married yesterday to Robert Moses, a publisher. The Rev. Samuel W. Edleman performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I.

title: RUSHING AWAY FROM TAXES: The Capital Gains Bypass -- A special report.; Wealthy, Helped by Wall St., New Find Ways to Escape Tax on Profits
description: Last spring, Wall Street bankers made an irresistible sales pitch to Eli Broad, the billionaire home builder and co-founder of the booming SunAmerica insurance empire.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: Sullivan proclaims that new medicines already change AIDS from a death sentence to an illness that can be controlled. It is a frightening process to take on new hope when one has been in a predictable losing battle with early death. But Sullivan proposes just that. His courageous article leads the way.
