description: THE ENVIRONMENT

title: A 'Vicious' Roman a Clef
description: Amanda Craig's troubles started last summer, when galleys of her third novel -- ''A Vicious Circle,'' a satire of London's contemporary literary scene -- began circulating among reviewers. ''It's about things that are little known to outsiders,'' she says. ''Like how much log-rolling there is, the way that venom is the elixir of success. I wanted to hold a mirror up and show them their own ugly snouts. But I didn't mean for anybody to take it personally!''

title: Quality Transplants Available Closer to Home
description: To the Editor:

title: The Childless Feel Left Out When Parents Get a Lift
description: SCOTT WENZEL considers himself very much a family man. So why isn't he getting along with today's family-friendly workplace?

title: Ode to Althea
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Vermont-Bound Skiers Get One More Train
description: Starting tomorrow, Amtrak, with financial assistance from Vermont, is scheduled to add a second daily train into the state's ski areas. Augmenting the service along the Connecticut River provided by the Vermonter, the Ethan Allen Express will leave Penn Station in New York seven afternoons a week to travel up the Hudson River to Whitehall, N.Y., and then east to Rutland, Vt. Rutland provides access to Killington and Pico in Killington, Okemo Mountain in Ludlow, Sugarbush in Warren and Stowe Mountain. These resorts expect to provide transfers from the station either for a separate fee or as part of a package. As an example, a ride to Killington costs $10 for a round trip. The return train will also operate daily, but at varied hours.

title: Mighty Casey Has Labor Peace
description: Three weeks after they resoundingly rejected a new labor agreement their chief negotiator negotiated, Major League Baseball's club owners even more resoundingly ratified the very same agreement last week. The agreement, which the players union executive board will vote on this week, insures labor peace for at least the next four years in a sport whose past quarter century has been wracked by strikes and lockouts.

title: Generation Gap
description: THE GATES

title: H.M.O. System Needn't Reduce Quality of Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Uninsured Among Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Single Women's Battle With Landlord Is Down to the Wire
description: A new college graduate from Detroit, Mary Ann Aitken thought herself lucky in 1989 when she got a tiny single-room apartment for $55 a week at Leo House, a century-old Chelsea hotel whose safety, cleanliness and sense of community made it the word-of-mouth choice for single women without a lot of money. Now when she thinks about her seven years there, she weeps.

title: Bit of Boston's Jewish Pride Is Revived
description: In its popular image, Beacon Hill has always been a place of Anglo-Saxon privilege, where Boston Brahmins lived in the splendor of elegant brick townhouses around Louisburg Square.

title: U.S. Takes Hard Look at Saudis With Bombing and Shah in Mind
description: The bombing in Saudi Arabia last June that killed 19 Americans not only confirmed that the United States had woefully inadequate intelligence about the aggressive opposition within Saudi Arabia. It also underlined how American ties to the Saudi royal family are inhibiting Washington from solving the intelligence problem.

title: Comic-Strip Gaul In a Paris Museum
description: Asterix the Gaul, the French comic-strip hero whose adventures, translated into 77 languages, have made him the most popular French protagonist ever, is the theme of an exhibition at the Musee National des Arts et Traditions Populaires in Paris that runs through April 21.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: IN BETHLEHEM

title: Men of Letters
description: THE CORRESPONDENCE

title: Still a Glenn Miller Fan
description: SAM CASALE believes in miracles.

title: A Shoe Company Finds White Plains Fits Its Needs
description: WHEN the Nine West Group, the women's shoe company, announced last month that, after trying on different styles for the better part of a year, it had found the perfect fit for its new corporate headquarters here, the sighs of relief were palpable.

title: Geneva
description: Geneva is popularly a city of bankers and diplomats, people who prefer to conduct their business behind closed doors. Yet any visitor to the city cannot help being struck by the sheer range of possibilities outdoors, including walks along Lake Geneva, trips to the old villages and pleasant countryside immediately outside the city or to the nearby Jura Mountains (with their excellent cross-country skiing), and of course the Alps. The Cointrin Airport, with its excellent rail and road connections, is the gateway to a good deal of Europe's prime skiing, not just in Switzerland, but also France.

title: Holiday Windows for the Id in All of Us
description: ANYONE wondering whether Christmas cynicism has reached an all-time high should head over to the holiday windows at BARNEYS NEW YORK on Madison Avenue at 61st Street, where one and all can bare their dreams and woes to that famous bearded man . . . Sigmund Freud.

title: Biggish Night
description: ''Oh, nurse!'' From his table in the New York Friars Club, Freddie Roman, the club's tanned, friendly ''dean,'' flags down a waitress. ''Gentlemen, jump in,'' he urges, grabbing a pig-in-a-blanket. ''This is the greatest hors d'ouevre in the history of hors d'oeuvres.''

title: It's a Mummy, It's in Maine and After a Furor, It's Still for Sale
description: Nonesuch House Antiques is ''a weird shop,'' its owner, Terry R. Lewis, admits.

title: Chefs' Talents Benefit the Hungry
description: PEOPLE who feed people for a living are on a mission to end hunger in Westchester County -- even if they have never seen a hungry person themselves.

title: Tennessee Professor Finds Fliers Denying the Holocaust Vexing
description: Benjamin S. Austin is a sleuth on the trail of offenders who may well have committed no crime. It is the crime they deny or minimize that offends him: the Holocaust.

title: DUUUUDES! THE AUDIT
description: Your Sunday feature, ''Duuuudes! The Audit'' (Nov. 10), about the No. 1 party school in the country, accurately depicts a segment of student life that is self-indulgent and irresponsible.

title: Surfing for Information? Here's Where to Click
description: You can find out almost anything you want on the Internet these days, so it should come as no surprise that you can find out almost anything about New Jersey as well. The executive branch of the state government introduced its home page on the World Wide Web in January after about 40 other states had already done so. In October, officials said the Web sites for Governor Whitman and 19 state departments had been averaging 38,000 visits a day.

title: Despite Marijuana Furor, 8 Users Get Drug From the Government
description: The passage of voter initiatives in California and Arizona allowing the medical use of marijuana has caused renewed interest in a little-known Government program at the University of Mississippi that supplies marijuana for medicinal purposes to eight people across the country.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Deeper in Debt

title: 'Charity' That Helps Givers Attracts I.R.S. Auditors
description: One prominent lawyer calls it ''the chutzpah trust.'' To the Internal Revenue Service, it is a red flag likely to produce an audit and a long court fight. But for wealthy investors, at least for a few years, it was a remarkable way to avoid capital gains taxes.

title: Gingrich Ethics Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: A France Bites Dog Story
description: Beneath the surface calm of all the planning at NATO headquarters for the new force in Bosnia, the halls are alive with whispers about who is going to blink first in the American-French standoff over how to revamp NATO's command structure. It's worth understanding this quiet little tug of war, because its outcome will deeply impact U.S.-NATO and U.S.-French relations. As one German diplomat remarked to me: ''You Americans and French are both up a tree. You both need a ladder to get down.'' That may be true, I told him, but there is one big difference between us: It's America's tree. And if push comes to shove, it's France that will be leaving without the aid of a ladder.

title: Puppet for Hire
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Saudis Have Royal Voice In Washington Embassy
description: When the Senate Intelligence Committee held a closed-door session last summer about the bombing of an American military housing complex in Saudi Arabia, it heard from an unusual witness: the Ambassador from Saudi Arabia.

title: BEDROOM HAIR
description: How wonderful to find the undone look for hair made official in your magazine. Not only do I have the right kind of hair (long, straight, impossible), I possess what must be the ultimate styling tool to create effortless bedroom hair -- a 6-week-old baby.

title: Credit Tyson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Korean-American Church Wins a Reprieve
description: For many Sundays, the congregation at the Eunhae Presbyterian Church had uttered a special prayer: save our church.

title: A Greenwich Chorus Is Reborn
description: THE hectic schedule of Paul F. Mueller, the new conductor of the Greenwich Choral Society, could be likened to whirlwind tour. ''This has been one of the busiest falls I've ever had,'' said Mr. Mueller, who sat at the piano in the rehearsal room at Christ Church in Greenwich, working out an arrangement before the singers arrived.

title: The Czarist Fascination With British Art
description: BECAUSE American history was once so entwined with England's, Americans often think that Anglophilia is peculiar to the United States. But a spectacular and luxurious exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art shows that there was an epoch when Russia was intensely smitten with things British. Catherine the Great, who was Empress of Russia from 1762 to 1796, began the vogue for British art there and she stimulated those in the nobility who continued to accumulate works into the 19th century. Much of the fruit of this enthusiasm wound up at the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg from which comes ''British Art Treasures From Russian Imperial Collections in the Hermitage.''

title: The A.A.R.P. and Legal Help
description: Re: ''For Lawyers, A.A.R.P.'s Seal'' (Spending It, Nov. 17):

title: A Getaway At the Tip of Africa
description: AMONG the latest visitors to discover the pleasures of False Bay, at the tip of Africa, are jackass penguins, which soar out of the Indian Ocean water and, with a Charlie Chaplin tramp walk, scurry up Boulders Beach to nest in the thick, sloping brush behind the ivory sand.

title: Keeping It Out of Court: When Mediation Works
description: WHEN Irene and Norman Katz decided it was time to split up their 26-year marriage, they feared the divorce process.

title: Herbert L. Rothbart, 59, Research Director
description: Dr. Herbert L. Rothbart, the regional director of research for the United States Department of Agriculture, died on Nov. 18 at Temple University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 59 and lived in Flourtown, Pa.

title: The Symptoms of Internet Addiction
description: NOT long ago, in a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in Texas, a 17-year-old boy was weathering withdrawal at its worst. His body shuddered with convulsions. He hurled tables and chairs around the hospital.

title: Rolling and Wrapping: An Old Trade for a Current Vogue
description: Long before the current cigar vogue, the tabaqueros of Union City have been quietly rolling their own. At the Galileo Cigar Company, La Isla Cigars and Boquilla/Havana, aging Cubans who fled the island practice a delicate craft handed down to most of them as children. At La Isla, passers-by can gaze through the plate glass at the small brigade of tobacco rollers who work for Berto Ale as they pile cured and shredded filler atop a binder leaf, roll, then wedge the crude cylinders into fluted trays to be pressed for half an hour. The wrapper is then applied -- smooth and round at one end and twisted, then snipped off, at the other.

title: From Pumping Gas to High-Octane Rental
description: A 22-story, $45 million luxury rental building is to rise at the corner of 33d Street and First Avenue, where last week workers began to demolish a Mobil gas station.

title: New Price Index Expected to Be Pushed to Reflect Buying
description: A panel appointed by Congress is expected to recommend next week that the Government create a new price gauge that would more accurately reflect inflation -- a move that would result in less generous increases in Social Security payments and other benefits, which would also help lower the deficit, officials said.

title: Nancy Saltsman and James Sheed
description: THERE are some people who can walk through heavy rain or sleet in beautiful tweeds and suede loafers and somehow remain impervious to splashes, stains or wilting of any kind. James Bond is one. James Sheed is another.

title: Smoking Heroin Is Linked To Neurological Ailment
description: Heroin users call it ''chasing the dragon,'' a fanciful euphemism for inhaling burning heroin fumes in a ritual evocative of Asian opium dens.

title: Robert Graves's Love Poems
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shaman for Urban Rites
description: Shortly before the tribute to the Beaver Moon was to begin last Sunday, the shaman had just begun to turn down the light inside the tea garden when a member of her ceremonial circle let out a deep, soul-cleansing sigh.

title: Station Manager Inspires Riders to Keep Place Clean
description: To the Editor:

title: A Small Hotel, a Mock Battleship and the Titanic
description: The Pabst Hotel

title: Hawn in Her Golden Years: Forever Blond, Forever Smart
description: IT'S A RARE MOMENT. Goldie Hawn, sitting on the terrace outside her office, is kvetching. She has had to cancel a family holiday trip to Aspen, Colo., because the backup goalie on her son's hockey team has suddenly quit and Wyatt, 10, has to stay home to tend goal.

title: Cornrows Are a Crossover Hit
description: SUSAN KARTEN, an Upper West Side lawyer, thought her daughter's obsession with cornrows was just a passing fancy. But fashionable 8-year-old Ruby had other ideas. She experimented with a single braid, but ''Ruby was determined,'' said her mother, who took her daughter to Afrigenix on West 72d Street for the full treatment. Ruby wanted to turn heads as one of the first white students at Public School 99 to sport cornrows.

title: How Much Is That Doggie in the Theater?
description: BY now, thousands of children have seen the remake of Disney's ''101 Dalmatians,'' which opened on Wednesday, and thousands more will do so in the coming weeks. When they walk out of the theater, more than a few will undoubtedly ask the question that many parents knew was coming: ''Can I have a Dalmatian puppy?''

title: Simple Gifts, Pieced Together With Care
description: IN the golden age of Amish quilts, 1860 to 1950, the women who made them would say that their intention was to help the community keep warm. But this explanation wouldn't hold up in court. There are far easier ways to make a blanket than these quilts. ''Lit From Within: Amish Quilts of Lancaster County,'' at the Zimmerli Art Museum here, includes 34 antique quilts from Lancaster County, Pa., that dazzle and at the same time suggest other reasons for their creation.

title: Sad State of Tunnel Art Suggests a Lack of Will
description: To the Editor:

title: DUUUUDES! THE AUDIT
description: Your item raised a serious issue. Boo-Boo and Turbo, the college students at Florida State University, are binge drinkers.

title: Ellen Katz and Daniel Halberstam
description: Ellen Katz, a law clerk to Associate Justice David H. Souter of the United States Supreme Court, was married last evening to Daniel Halberstam, an attorney adviser to the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission in Washington. Rabbi Alan Lucas performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I.

title: How the Internet Threatens Bliss
description: WITH national statistics reporting that one out of three marriages fail, and Long Island data suggesting an even grimmer one out of two marriages self-destruct, matrimonial lawyers have long warned that alcohol and debt are among the leading accelerants that spark divorce. Now add a third incendiary: Internet addiction.

title: Uncle Sam, the Pension Pest
description: CHIEF executives and other senior executives routinely inveigh against Government interference in their pay. But, on the evidence, they ought to be cheering on the Government.

title: New York Has Troubles, But It Isn't Disaster City
description: ARGUE IF YOU LIKE, BUT in the opinion of at least one major director, New York City no longer measures up as a location for the big disaster movie. Not that individual scenes of appalling violence and brutality don't film beautifully here. But for those post-apocalyptic epics in smoldering slag heaps with tilting stalagmites for buildings and crazed hordes stomping themselves to death on the sidewalks, better go to Los Angeles.

title: Trojans Finally Top Irish In Overtime
description: One coach is miniature (Lou Holtz) and one coach is overweight (John Robinson), but now this odd couple will have something to talk about if they end up together in the unemployment line.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE GOOD ENOUGH CATHOLIC

title: 'Dadetown' to Benefit Film Makers
description: INDEPENDENT film making will be celebrated Friday when the Westchester Arts Council presents a one-time screening of ''Dadetown,'' a film by the late Russ Hexter. The event, which will take place at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College at 6 P.M., will benefit the council's new fund-raising effort on behalf of independent film makers.

title: I.R.A.'s Political Wing Still Hopes to Join Talks
description: Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, has pledged to continue working for peace in Northern Ireland, despite Britain's virtual rejection of the party's latest proposal to gain a seat at peace talks.

title: The Life Cycle of the Louse
description: Every year as fall chills into winter comes another boom time for the insect scientists call Pediculus humanus capitis and the rest of us know as head lice. Pat Richel, the nurse at Brayton Elementary Schoo in Summit, said: ''We haven't had a case yet, but I expect them.'' As usual, Ms. Richel checked all the students at the beginning of the year and sent information to their homes.

title: An Anti-Abortion Killer Kills Himself
description: Two years ago, John Salvi, a 24-year-old anti-abortion campaigner, shot to death two receptionists and wounded five others at two abortion clinics in Brookline, a suburb of Boston. He was convicted of murder last March and sentenced to two life terms without parole.

title: Jets Fans Know How To Suffer
description: THE record for consecutive games played in the National Football League is 282, set by Jim Marshall from 1960 through 1979. However, Jim Marshall was paid for his labors, and the defensive lineman also had the frequent pleasure of slamming opposing quarterbacks to the frozen tundra of Minnesota.

title: French as a Weapon
description: It's not the pain but the pleasure of exile -- the mutilating pleasure of cutting yourself off from everything closest to you -- that is the force behind SLANDER (University of Nebraska, paper, $14), a deceptively delicate novel by Linda Le. Like the author, the protagonist is a young Vietnamese writer who lives in France. She's estranged from her homeland but far from cozy in her adopted culture: ''French has become her only language, her tool, her weapon. The weapon she uses against her family, against the Country. Thanks to that weapon, she will always be alone. She's a meteque, a dirty foreigner, who writes in French.'' What could be the jumping-off point for a predictable analysis of post-colonial isolation becomes something more intimate as the protagonist probes the way she has willfully distanced herself from her family. Told by her vain, vapid mother that she's the product of an extramarital affair, she must decide which father to claim: the loving, beaten-down cuckold she grew up with or the unknown foreigner who came to Vietnam with the war and left behind an illegitimate child. Looking for some sort of direction, she contacts the one relative as alienated as she is: her uncle, packed off to an asylum by the family after an incestuous affair with his sister. The writer and the all-too-sane madman alternate their stories in self-conscious yet often lovely first-person narratives, translated here by Esther Allen. Reminiscent of Marguerite Duras's novel ''The Lover,'' Ms. Le's book offers proof that alienation, in the right hands, can be exquisite. Jennifer Howard

title: A Renaissance Gives Phoenix More to Savor
description: UNTIL about five years ago, the dining scene in Phoenix and neighboring Scottsdale was dominated by splashy resort hotels. Smaller, independent restaurants had a tough time competing with the golf-package Goliaths, which had the overwhelming advantage of corporate support to keep them afloat. Residents and visitors seemed content with the conservative status quo.

title: Not a Bad Guy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Surviving to Recount The 'Ultimate Betrayal'
description: Just listening to the tales of sexual torment and horror that Carolyn Wilson Spence and her five children have suffered is enough to make your heart ache with pain and your head fill with anger.

title: Rare 'No' on Liquor License
description: The State Liquor Authority has decided not to grant a liquor license to a new bar at the corner of Avenue A and St. Marks Place, a move that has delighted neighborhood advocates who contend that the night life in the area has got out of hand.

title: Hispanic Residents of Mt. Kisco Say They're Being Harassed
description: Around midnight, Mount Kisco police and building inspectors raided the gray clapboard house at 71 Maple Avenue, roused the 25 Hispanic laborers who lived there, photographed them in their beds, ordered them to pack and told them they could spend the night on the floor of a community center across the street.

title: Big Wolves Aren't So Bad in Japan
description: GRANDMA has made a tasty hors d'oeuvre, or, more accurately, has been a tasty hors d'oeuvre, and the wolf's fangs drool saliva as he gobbles up Little Red Riding Hood. Then, as the wolf naps, the hunter shows up and cuts open the wolf's stomach with scissors to liberate Grandma and Little Red Riding Hood, who observes cheerfully: ''Oh, I was so surprised. Mr. Wolf ate me so suddenly.'' The hunter inserts some rocks and sews Mr. Wolf back up, so that when the wolf wakes he totters off with a stomach ache that perhaps has taught him a lesson.

title: More Than a Chip Off the Building Block
description: TRAMMELL CROW spent four decades becoming the nation's leading real estate developer. But in the late 1980's, everything he had achieved was imperiled by perhaps the worst real estate crash of modern times.

title: 150 Years of Helping Shape a Nation's Taste
description: IN A BUSINESS NOT KNOWN FOR longevity, the oldest art gallery in the country has good reason this month to celebrate a century and a half of continuous operation. Situated cozily down the block from the Frick Collection, a favored former client, Knoedler & Company, on East 70th Street, is marking the occasion with a choice selection of works that have passed through its ledgers over the decades. Among the standouts in the exhibition, titled ''The Rise of the Art World in America: Knoedler at 150,'' are John Singleton Copley's ''Watson and the Shark,'' Thomas Eakins's ''Music'' and a moody portrait called ''The Plum'' from the deft brush of Edouard Manet.

title: An Actor Whose Face Offers Real-Life Lessons
description: Lance Henriksen: actor's actor, the American Max von Sydow, the scariest voice in show business, a slayer of rattlesnakes. Mention him to anyone who has worked with the 55-year-old star of ''Millennium,'' and the stories -- legends, really -- come pouring out.

title: The Many Forms of the Much-Beloved Holly
description: HOLLY could be on many gardeners' minds at this time of year. Although it is too early to think about buying the berried branches for holiday decoration, the subject surely is worthy of consideration as part of providing premium landscape evergreens.

title: Whale Watching Made Easy
description: I AM no great game tracker. I've been on enough safaris to know that my job is to sit in the back of the Land Rover and shut up, except to go ''Oooh'' when someone else spots the lions. I have caused enough false alarms to contemplate writing a book of my experiences: ''A Guide to South African Tree Stumps and Termite Mounds That Resemble Large Mammals.''

title: You See Puppies, She Sees Coats
description: The Crucible

title: Concern for Rail Safety Follows a Bridge Accident
description: When An Amtrak train ran off the tracks in Secaucus, N. J., last weekend, it raised concern about a whole class of bridges and renewed a debate over making all railroad bridges safer.

title: Edgar J. Boell, 90, A Biologist at Yale
description: Edgar John Boell, a longtime biology and zoology professor at Yale University, died on Nov. 10 in Venice, Fla., after a long illness. He was 90 and had moved to Venice from Connecticut some years ago.

title: Why There's Egg On Your Interface
description: RECENTLY, I tried to boil some water and turned on the wrong burner. A minor mishap, until you consider that I've done this thousands of times in the 20 years I've owned my stove.

title: Small World, Big Returns
description: More global and foreign mutual funds are turning their sights on small companies. But can global small-stock portfolios return more than domestic ones, and do so with less risk?

title: Ms. Rybak, Mr. Shelengian
description: Constance Ann Rybak, a music teacher, was married yesterday to Richard Shelengian, an operations systems analyst. The Rev. Anoushavan Tanielian, Vicar General of the Armenian Prelacy, performed the ceremony at St. Sarkis Armenian Apostolic Church in Douglaston, Queens.

description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea R. Massar, Jeremiah Cassidy
description: Andrea Robin Massar was married yesterday to Jeremiah Joseph Cassidy at the Roger Sherman Inn in New Canaan, Conn. Paul D. Shaperio, a retired judge of the Stamford Probate Court, officiated.

title: Customs Search
description: To the Editor: While going through Customs on Oct. 4 on returning alone from Jamaica, I was pulled aside by a Customs officer who began searching my luggage and asking me personal questions. Many of the questions focused on my husband (who was unable to travel with me): Why wasn't he traveling with me? Where does he work?

title: Target the Tube
description: ALTHOUGH THE country seems again to be clamoring for ''campaign finance reform,'' it will not happen until we stop trying to repeal a fact of life: money talks. Instead of struggling to shut up money we should be making speech cheaper. And since the most decisive political speech is delivered by television, that is not as hard as it sounds.

title: Strangers in a Strange Land
description: THE LAND OF GREEN PLUMS

title: A Soccer Mom Who Is Proud to Be One
description: WHEN Deborah Slaner Larkin of Pelham, an advocate of sports for girls, hears ''soccer mom,'' she cringes. The term, she says, does not do justice to those who are making a difference in their daughters' lives.

title: The Fat-Enabling Culture: Society Made Me Eat It!
description: COLOSSAL buckets of buttered popcorn (20 cups, 1,600 calories) are standard at the movies, but where oh where did that half-gallon of soda (800 calories) at the 7-Eleven come from? Or the pound-plus steaks served at restaurants? Or that half-pound mall staple, the cinnamon bun (670 calories)?

title: Puerto Rico Is Putting Priority on Tourism
description: TOURISM has long been important to Puerto Rico's economy, but it has never been more vital or as much of a priority as now. Determined to attract even more than last year's 4.1 million tourists, including almost 2.3 million Americans, the island is adding thousands of hotel rooms, sprucing up the airport and every day is cleaning beaches that Puerto Rican officials boast are now among the most spotless in the Caribbean.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Horizontal Woman

title: New Curriculum From Albany: the Irish Potato Famine, or One View of It
description: One of the most heated debates in the New York State Legislature this year had nothing to do with the state's ballooning budget gap, its welfare and crime policies or any of the other day-to-day affairs of state government.

title: Would-Be Briton Fights Government Inhospitality
description: Anyone competing to see who has the best story about being hassled while trying to get a new passport should not invite Mohamed al-Fayed into the conversation.

title: What's That Ringing Sound? Just the Overture to Handbell Season
description: Ring, Christmas bells,

title: From the Edge of Experience, a New Sound
description: DEATH, SEX AND ETERNITY: in his short life and in his art, the French Canadian composer Claude Vivier was a man diving, often recklessly, into the ultimate. His music was a sequence of messages from a dangerous existence, from an excess that he relished not for sensual enjoyment but to gain the energy to create. He felt he had to go beyond the limits, farther and farther. And from the edge of experience he began to bring back, in the years leading up to his death in 1983, a new sound.

description: In the Eye of the Storm: An Art of Conscience, 1930-1970

title: Levittown Division Wins Class 2 in a Thriller
description: LEVITTOWN DIVISION (10-0-1) took a commanding 21-8 halftime lead, fell behind late in the fourth quarter but stunned BELLPORT (9-2) in the last seven seconds to win the Class 2 Long Island championship by a score of 31-28 last night at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Birds And Battles In Boer Country
description: THE crowned cranes are nesting again in Wakkerstroom Marsh. And nature tourism has re-energized this once-declining region of cattle ranches in Mpumalanga, formerly Eastern Transvaal, South Africa.

title: A Poetry That Matters
description: ''AN ODD PLANET, AND THOSE ON IT ARE ODD, TOO,'' Wislawa Szymborska WRITES in her poem ''The People on the Bridge,'' and, indeed, for her the world has grown a lot stranger, a lot more welcoming, intrusive and unmanageable since she won the 1996 Nobel Prize in Literature two months ago. While poets around the world rejoiced that the prize had gone to a splendid practitioner of their art, and most of Poland celebrated the award's having gone to a writer widely admired in her own country, news agencies scrambled to find out who she was. Szymborska, meanwhile, retreated to Zakopane, a small town in the mountains, valiantly trying to hold off the onslaught and to think about her Nobel acceptance speech, which she is to deliver in Stockholm this week.

title: Homey, Elegant, Rustic But Always East 20's
description: AJA **

title: Holiday Gifts For the Road
description: IT'S the gift-buying time of year, and with it comes a crop of new items to appeal to travelers. Two suggestions rank high for people deserving major gifts. They are a cellular phone for a car, with a year's worth of service, or a palm-sized camcorder. They are recommended with one caveat: both are favorites with thieves. But a woman or older person who drives long distances alone will feel safer with the phone, and the small camcorders are becoming almost as ubiquitous as still cameras.

title: Childs Takes Full Charge Down Stretch
description: The Knicks' first and last option -- Get Out of Patrick's Way and Pray -- was shelved for the moment. In their bid to resemble a team of promise rather than one that is problematic, the Knicks tried something novel: They put the ball in the hands of Chris Childs.

title: Private Zoo's Creatures Great, Small And Exotic
description: Like a modern-day Noah, Henry Wallace has ranged far afield to fill his modern-day menagerie.

title: Use of D.H. Is Still a Wedge Dividing the Leagues
description: Representatives of the owners and the players have not signed their new agreement; they have not even drafted it in formal contract language, and the players' executive board will not ratify it until this week at its meetings in Puerto Rico. That means there is still time to make a change.

title: On Trail of Fossils? Take an Open Mind
description: A RECENT fossil find in Cheshire raises the possibility that the state's central valley could be where to find answers to questions about a mass extinction of most of the earth's plants and animals 202 million years ago or the evolution of the first mammals, birds and reptiles.

title: N.J. Transit Adds Officers To Buses
description: Passengers on New Jersey Transit's 177 bus routes in Essex County may have recently noticed the unfamiliar, but comforting sight of a uniformed law enforcement officer on board.

title: Star of the Past Is Charged With Stealing Small Town's Hope for the Future
description: Three years ago this small village embraced a plan by Denny McLain, baseball's last 30-game winner, to resuscitate an ailing meat packing plant that had provided livelihoods to people here for generations.

title: Diversity Stokes a Planned Community
description: SINCE the founding of the Jackson Heights Beautification Group eight years ago, Maire Breen, a 36-year resident of the Queens community told a visitor the other day, the streets are cleaner, graffiti is almost nonexistent and flowers and trees have been planted everywhere.

title: Adding Reading to the Health Care Plan
description: ON the premise that you must feed children's minds as well as their bodies, Fair Haven Community Health Center is giving books to its youngest patients to foster a love of reading and help prepare them for school. A quieter waiting room is an added bonus.

title: The World Is His Canvas, And His Inspiration
description: STANDING IN A MONTREAL hotel lobby recently, Robert Lepage was amused to discover that his wallet contained only Italian lire. The 38-year-old director and performer had just returned home to Canada from the European tour of ''Elsinore,'' his one-man version of ''Hamlet.'' As usual, he was existing on several continents at once: ''I guess I'm still partly in Palermo,'' he said with a smile.

title: BEDROOM HAIR
description: Mary Tannen's ''Bedroom Hair'' (Nov. 10) brought back a memory from a summer in the 1980's, when I went swimming in salt water and then picked up my daughter at a riding stable. I had not showered after the swim, and my hair (long at the time) got coated with dust from the riding ring. I put it in a ponytail, then wrapped the tail around the elastic band. I laughed, realizing that my hair stayed in place without bobby pins.

title: On, Dilbert! On, Dogbert! On, Dave!
description: IT'S the holiday season -- a time when many employees become depressed by the merry office decorations that obscure the one thing they really need in their lives: an unobstructed view of their ''Dilbert'' cartoons.

title: John O. Williams -- Saxophonist, 91
description: John O. Williams, a jazz saxophonist and composer, died on Nov. 24at the Westminster Thurber Community nursing home in Columbus, Ohio. He was 91.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: NAKED SLEEPER

title: Underneath Wrapping, An Array of Surprises
description: Chris Childs was sick of worrying about his leg injury. He was even more sick of losing. So in the first half of yesterday's game against the Sacramento Kings, Childs reached down, pulled off the protective wrap that covered his right leg and threw it away.

title: Mickey Levine, an Advocate For Veterans, Is Dead at 83
description: Mickey Levine, a lifelong advocate for social and political rights who helped to organize the American Veterans Committee, died on Nov. 22 at his home in North Miami Beach. He was 83 and had lived for many years in and near Manhattan.

title: No Offense Was Intended
description: To the Editor:

title: BREAKING GLASS
description: I was greatly moved by Jonathan Rosen's Lives column ''Breaking Glass'' (Nov. 10). Kristallnacht should be remembered by the world. What better way to mark this date than with something as life affirming as a wedding?

title: Advertising Is Meant To Inform, to Enhance
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Porter Jr., 35, A Jazz Saxophonist Aided by Clinton
description: Art Porter Jr., a saxophonist known for his work in jazz, rhythm-and-blues and pop music, died Nov. 23 in a boating accident in Bangkok, Thailand. He was 35.

title: Just Shut Up and Hire
description: R. ROOSEVELT THOMAS JR., a senior research fellow at the American Institute for Managing Diversity, used to believe that prejudice could be eradicated in corporate America. Now, he has a more practical goal: Make even prejudiced people promote talented women and members of minorities whether they like them or not.

title: Riverboat Gambling With Government
description: IN THE STATE OF THE UNION ADDRESS THAT KICKED OFF his re-election campaign, President Clinton declared, ''The era of Big Government is over.'' Now, as he ponders his second inaugural, he is undoubtedly aware of three contradictions. Together, they frame a choice: whether to continue or end a scandal that is far less visible than recent titillations -- but ultimately more important.

title: In China, Letting a Hundred Films Wither
description: COME OVER A RISE ON THE DUSTY DIRT road west of this small industrial town near Hangzhou, and the scene of the crime suddenly appears: an antique city reflected in a dark lake, built to replicate the waterfront of mid-19th-century Canton, where opium dens and teahouses were the languorous backdrop of a coarser era.

title: Stars Barred
description: Angering many white conservatives in his own party last week, Republican Gov. David Beasley called for the removal of the Confederate Battle flag that flies over the South Carolina State Capitol. If the state legislature approves the plan, the flag would be relocated to a Confederate memorial on the Statehouse grounds. Governor Beasley, who had supported leaving the flag on the Statehouse when he was elected two years ago, said his mind was changed by torchings of black churches, a drive-by shooting of black men by two white men with Klan ties and other racial incidents.

title: Corrections
description: The View column on Nov. 10, about specialized adult day care in Greenburgh, misstated the year in which a client, Diane Williams, was born. It was 1932, not 1939.

title: Station Now Glossy but Wet
description: During last Tuesday's downpour, some subway riders splashed undaunted through the puddles inside the station at 96th Street and Lexington Avenue. Others, concerned about slipping on the slick tiles, treaded more gingerly.

title: It May Have Been Flashy in 1952
description: In Las Vegas, if you aren't flashy enough, you're history. The Sands Hotel, built in 1952, clearly wasn't making the grade lately, and last week what flash remained was reduced to a 30-foot pile of broken dreams. Coming soon: a $1.8 billion, 6,000-room ''Venetian-themed'' resort. The world can hardly wait.

title: Development Plan Raises Concern
description: DOES a behemoth belong in Tuckahoe? A developer's proposal to build a 53,000-square-foot supermarket, 90 residential apartments and a recreation complex on 8.5 acres straddling the Bronx River here has hit a nerve in this village of 6,500 people.

title: Labor Dept. Workers Glad To Vacate 'Shabby' Site
description: To the Editor:

title: 500 Bulbs, 2 Reindeer, 2 Off-Duty Policemen: It's Christmas
description: Some towns are serious about Christmas, but few more so than Belleville, where high-watt displays of Santa, Elves and Wise Men beckon from every street.

title: Which Came First, Tall or Smart?
description: FROM LUCY

title: The Future Is Now
description: The Jets' second season starts today, 10 months after the start of the great overhaul that quickly dissolved into a 1-11 record. In a way, this could also be the start of 1997.

title: Smooth Taking
description: AT A BREAKFAST IN THE RAINBOW ROOM this fall, 10 middle-aged finalists (nine women and one man) who had been using Ethocyn for six months on the right side of their faces only, and had succeeded in becoming noticeably smoother on that side, proudly displayed their asymmetry and awaited the announcement of the winner of this year's Ethocyn spokesmodel of the year contest.

title: Supplies and Demand
description: We've all heard the stories: A worker uses company time for personal reasons, or absconds with company property. Maybe it's a few pens or pencils, but occasionally it's something bigger, like a laptop computer. Now we'd like to hear your stories. Do your co-workers take outrageous liberties at work? How does your company react? Send your best tales to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Linda S. Johns, George L. Gibson
description: Linda Suzanne Johns, the director of publicity and promotions at Rodale Books in Emmaus, Pa., was married yesterday to George Langdon Gibson, the president of Walker Publishing in New York. The Rev. Gilbert Miller, a Congregational minister, officiated in Hallowell, Me., at the home of Diana and George W. Gibson, the bridegroom's parents.

title: Ready-Made Genius
description: DUCHAMP

title: Death Penalty Rejected in Park Slope Murder Case
description: After four months of deliberation, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn has announced that he will not seek the death penalty for a 32-year-old man accused of robbing and killing the owner of a news stand in Park Slope.

title: Corrections
description: The table of contents on page 4 of The Times Book Review today misspells the surname of the reviewer of ''Europe: A History,'' by Norman Davies. He is Theodore K. Rabb, not Raab.

title: Giving Is Receiving
description: Nobody ever does what I tell them to.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Special Prosecutors' Inquiries Have Led to Doubts About Their Usefulness
description: After Watergate, the idea of having prosecutors who were independent of the White House look into allegations of high-level wrongdoing seemed an obvious, even compelling, innovation.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: TRIBECA

title: Success Brings End To Magazine Plan
description: FIVE years ago, with New Rochelle in a budget crunch, subscriptions to every magazine in the public library were threatened with cancellation. But a resident's idea, which was embraced by many others, saved the periodical collection.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: A Glimpse of River Park in Limbo
description: Scattered among the rotting piers and derelict sheds of the Hudson River shoreline are unmistakable signs of life. After decades of forced separation, Manhattan residents have a reason to venture across the West Side Highway, lured by a handful of renovated piers and an asphalt esplanade that stretches from 14th Street to the Battery. But these modest improvements are just a tease, no-frills amenities that the state's Hudson River Park Conservancy has cobbled together with money it receives from parking lots and other businesses still using the waterfront.

title: A Bit Mad In the Mud: A Rumble For Rugby
description: It was muddy and chilly, and their request for bleachers, television platforms and tents had been ignored by park officials. But for the men and women who pride themselves on camaraderie, derring-do and a high tolerance for ale, nothing could spoil yesterday's rugby tournament in Central Park.

title: Surrendering to an Itch
description: TALES OF MENDELE

title: Melissa Z. Grey, Kevin A. Jones
description: Melissa Zane Grey, a daughter of Mrs. Robert H. Fetherston of Farmington, Conn., and the late Romer Zane Grey Jr., was married yesterday to Kevin Arthur Jones, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Evan Jones of Portsmouth, N.H. The Rev. James V. Hickey performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick in Farmington.

title: Doorman Style: Uptown Shop Acts Downtown
description: At the Hermes shop at 11 East 57th Street, Dixieland provides the soundtrack for Bob Schmidt, the store's sixtyish doorman, elegantly clad in Hermes bow tie, black beret and tailored black overcoat. He opens the door, greets the shoppers, wishes them well. Sometimes, he says, he does even more.

title: Snakes That Play Nice
description: Lightening up today's minimalist fashion scene, some women are wearing whimsical toy snakes and boas as cuddly scarves. They are a far cry from the macho men who strut about in the summer with pet pythons around their shoulders. The wearer of an apple-green stuffed snake, upper right, bought hers at the Central Park Zoo shop for $10. A popular boa comes from F. A. O. Schwarz, for $160, and its furry fabric is cut in a circle to coil around necks and arms. All the snakes have contrasting-color bellies, just like the real thing.

title: Berkeley Carroll School Is No 900-Pound Gorilla
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Towns Say, 'Let It Snow. We're Insured.'
description: Last winter, Woodbridge suffered through a record-high 78 inches of snow, which used up 15,000 tons of salt (triple the normal amount) and $1.2 million in expenses (more than double the $550,000 annual snow budget). So this year, they decided to do something about it.

title: Storm Center
description: JUST back from Toronto, Diane Ravitch was in no mood to talk. ''I've been raked across the coals at a conference,'' she said. ''I think I need to lay low for a while.''

title: It's a Schwinn!
description: No Hands

title: The Hardest-Working Students in Show Biz
description: JAMES BROWN has become the subject of academic study at the New School for Social Research, and this classroom work has inspired a free concert on Tuesday night.

title: Clean Air Goals May Change
description: The Clean Air Act tells the Environmental Protection Agency to periodically review its definition of how pure the air must be to protect the public's health.

title: When One Could Live By One's Wit
description: IN A WORLD WITHOUT STANDARDS OF CONDUCT, the only humiliation an ambitious man may still manage to achieve is intellectual. I should know: while playing a party game called Famous Authors, in the company of some authors who might almost qualify and others who desperately wished to, I loudly and confidently identified a photograph of E. M. Forster as Gertrude Stein. To this day, whenever I see either name in print, the hot blush of wounded vanity, not to mention the explosive laughter of the litterateurs in attendance, rushes back to me from that Upper West Side salon.

title: Breaking the Hebron Deadlock
description: Nearly two months after Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat committed themselves to ending the impasse over the withdrawal of most Israeli forces from the West Bank city of Hebron, there are signs of progress on this difficult issue. In recent days, the Israeli Prime Minister has dropped his insistence that Mr. Arafat provide a written guarantee that Israeli troops in Hebron remain free to pursue terrorists into Palestinian-controlled areas of the city. It is now up to Mr. Arafat to withdraw some of his conditions so the future of Hebron can be settled quickly.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WATERSHED

title: His Words Add Music To the Music
description: FOR THE FIRST TIME IN ITS VENERABLE history, Carnegie Hall will be the setting for a centennial tribute to a lyricist. No one would be more surprised and humbled by this achievement than the honoree himself: Ira Gershwin. He would have probably been embarrassed, only later allowing himself to feel satisfaction and finally acceptance.

title: Paul Dowd, 60, A Researcher Of Vitamins
description: Dr. Paul Dowd, a researcher in organic chemistry known for his investigation of the mechanics acting in various vitamins, died on Nov. 21 at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. He was 60 and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: University Helping Blacks to Graduate
description: The University of Virginia, once known for its Confederate flag-waving football fans, is being recognized for its success in retaining and graduating black undergraduates.

title: At Weddings, Klezmer Rocks, Thanks to One-Man Bands
description: If you close your eyes and ignore the accent, you might imagine dreadlocks, perhaps long sideburns or at least a tattoo. If you see the equipment, you think techno. And if you see the effect they have on a dance floor, you're struck by their ability to make people move.

title: Sugar and Spice
description: THERE IS SOMETHING SUBSTANTIAL, ENDURING and perhaps a little frightening about the dark side of sweetness. In a dessert, the interplay of sweet and savory delivers something a lot more satisfying than what mere sugar can provide.

title: Cold Turkey In Turkey. Right.
description: PERHAPS no habit is more instantly associated with Turks than smoking. When Benjamin Disraeli visited Constantinople he wrote that one of his favorite pastimes was ''to repose on voluptuous ottomans and smoke superb pipes.'' Herman Melville reported that the city streets were lined with cafes where ''Turks sit smoking like conjurers.'' In 1841, a diplomatic crisis between France and the Ottoman Empire erupted when the French Ambassador demanded a formal apology for not having been offered the honor of smoking with the Sultan during a visit to the royal palace.

title: All for a Cause
description: Events in support of the New York City Ballet, an organization that helps the disabled and protection for journalists around the world.

title: Water Main Fails, Causing Gas Leak in S.I.
description: A 20-inch water main ruptured on Staten Island before dawn yesterday, causing a gas leak, which was quickly contained, and flooded the basements of 10 homes and businesses in the Mariners Park section.

title: Rocking With Springsteen Yields Money for Charities
description: The three charities benefiting from Bruce Springsteen's three-night return to his musical roots last week do not know exactly how much money the performances by the Jersey Shore's most famous rocker will generate. But although the total receipts have not yet been tallied, the publicity alone is worth more than the concert proceeds, said Rose Mikolon, development director of the Women's Center of Monmouth County in Hazlet Township.

title: Storm Is Able to Rebound From Debacle in Opener
description: Normally, it is football players who can use a week's worth of practice to recover from a stunning defeat. The six days between games can be used for mental adjustment and physical improvement. Basketball teams usually don't have that luxury. Fortunately, for St. John's, it did.

title: A Handmade Tale
description: IF LUMPS OF CLAY CAN BE SAID TO HAVE LIVES, THEN WALLACE AND Gromit -- an obsessed, oblivious inventor and his silent, deeply skeptical dog -- surely possess thrilling ones. So far, they have battled a cyberdog, outwitted a felonious penguin, even built a spaceship for a cheese-tasting expedition to the moon, all exploits that have netted them prestigious awards (including two Academy Awards) and a following in Britain. Now American audiences will be exposed to Wallace and Gromit's hilarious eccentricities: their latest short film, ''A Close Shave,'' has just been released on video here and will debut on PBS this Wednesday. The film, their third, dispels any lingering notion that stop-frame animation is the homely stepsister of hand- and computer-drawn techniques. And it demonstrates for the public why Nick Park, a director at Aardman Animations and the genius from whose mind Wallace and Gromit sprang, deserves the praise that people in his industry have heaped on him for years.

title: When Fame Glows Bright, It's Hard to Be Tortured
description: THREE YEARS AGO, ADAM Duritz, the singer and songwriter of Counting Crows, was thrust into celebrity on the strength of his band's first album, ''August and Everything After,'' which went platinum faster than Nirvana's major-label debut, ''Nevermind.'' The band's folk-rock-influenced songs were tuneful, if not ground-breaking, and Mr. Duritz's tormented, dreadlocked mien seemed to match his literate, angst-ridden lyrics.

title: Behind the Scenes at the Track, the Rink, the Field
description: The Meadowlands sports complex, one of the world's largest entertainment centers, opened 20 years ago on a 750-acre site that once was swamp. Since then, it has drawn millions to its stadium, racetrack and arena for football, soccer, hockey, horse racing and popular entertainment. Pope John Paul II celebrated Mass there; the Grateful Dead recreated the 60's.

title: Martial Arts Schools Grow as Way of Life
description: A SIGN in the Westchester Academy of Self-Defense in New Rochelle reads: ''I come to you with only karate. My hands are empty, but I fear no man. Should I be forced to defend myself, my honor, or my principles, should it be a matter of right or wrong, life or death, then here are my weapons, my empty hands.''

title: Itzhak Perlman Discusses Child Prodigies and Handicap Access
description: IN the movie ''Shine,'' a teacher warns a young musician to watch out for the Rach 3: ''It's dangerous!'' The Rach 3 is not a pterodactyl, it's Rachmaninoff's treacherously difficult Piano Concerto, No. 3. In this movie based on the Australian child prodigy David Helfgott, the young musician has a breakdown and spends years in a mental institution after tackling the Rach 3.

title: STRICTER AIR RULES COULD PLACE FOCUS ON THE MIDWEST
description: The Clinton Administration's new proposal to tighten national air quality standards for smog and soot may offer an opportunity for some regions of the country that have struggled for years to bring their cities into compliance with the existing clean-air goals.

title: You See Puppies, She Sees Coats
description: Jingle All the Way

title: A Beginning Stripped of Awe
description: A JEALOUS mother sends her stepson to a certain death. A patriarch turns his wife into a courtesan. Daughters drug their father and sleep with him. A father binds his son and prepares to kill him. Brothers sell their young sibling into slavery. And throughout, there looms another father, who tests, demands, condemns and honors his callous, loving, conniving and vicious children.

title: A War Crimes Sentence
description: Drazen Erdemovic, a former soldier in the Bosnian Serb army, was sentenced last week to 10 years in prison; he is the first person to be convicted by an international war crimes tribunal since the trials conducted in Nuremburg and Tokyo after World War II. The international tribunal on war crimes in the former Yugoslavia had accepted a guilty plea from Mr. Erdemovic for his part in the massacre of Muslim civilians near Srebrenica in 1995.

title: Blacks See Texaco Victory As a Start
description: WHEN Sil Chambers walks through the halls of Texaco Inc. these days, co-workers cheer. When he enters his office, the phone rings off the hook with well-wishers. Successful in a racial discrimination lawsuit against his employer, Mr. Chambers is hopeful now that he and five other black plaintiffs can finally look forward to an opening of some of the doors they claimed have been shut to them.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Can Sitcom Make It With L.I. Setting?
description: EXCEPT for the notorious Amy Fisher trilogy a few years back, Long Island has not figured importantly as a location for prime-time television shows.

title: Sallie S. Han, Jason Antrosio
description: Sallie Sugine Han, a daughter of Young Ja Han and Dr. Kwang Soo Han of Hillsdale, N.J., was married yesterday to Jason Elia Antrosio, a son of Gail Antrosio and the Rev. David Antrosio of Willowvale, South Africa. The bridegroom's father, a minister of the Foursquare Church in Willowvale, performed the ceremony at the Palisadium, a restaurant in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Four Young Men, Crooning Into Adulthood
description: IT'S the story that had to be told,'' Brooks Arthur said. That's because he lived it. And ''Crooners,'' at the Forum Theater Group here, is that story as told by Mr. Arthur, with the help of Bob Booker.

title: Kings Plaza at the Crossroads
description: WHILE Santa Claus was around the corner looking a little bored in his big green chair, Lisa Bocchino moved inside a tomb of cookie piles, wearing her own costume of an orange apron and orange baseball cap and doling out chocolate chip, old-fashioned, oatmeal and butterscotch cookies to the traffic of customers coming her way.

title: Margaret McCann, M.A. Rutherfurd
description: Margaret Anne McCann, a daughter of Judith K. McCann and John P. McCann Jr., both of South Salem, N.Y., was married on Wednesday to Morton Alan Rutherfurd, a son of Georgette and Guy Rutherfurd of New York. Assistant Justice Anita R. Florio of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the Colony Club.

title: The Product Tie-Ins From Hell
description: DO the Perp Walk -- in Bruno Magli Shoes.''

title: India Beauty Pageant
description: To the Editor:

title: SKI LIFT
description: Hitch your wardrbe to a sport: Outdoor gear for city and country.

title: The Ambivalent Hall of Famer
description: THREE DAYS BEFORE HER 53d birthday, Joni Mitchell had the eerie experience of confronting the spitting image of her younger self on a downtown stage.

title: American Letters, African Voices
description: SOMETIME in the middle of the 18th century, a slave, newly captured on the west coast of Africa, found himself on board a Dutch slave ship bound for Barbados. Once a week, he would note later, the master of this strange ship would stand before the assembled crew and their captives, holding a magical object in his hands. This talisman -- powerful and mysterious, whispered to be the repository of all knowledge and possessed of great ceremonial value -- revealed its secrets by speaking through the lips of the master. The slave marveled at the sublimity of this sorcery. After one such oracular display, he followed his master to the object's hiding place, and, stealthily and with the greatest trepidation, seized it in both hands. In his autobiography, published in 1770, he describes what happened next: ''When nobody saw me, I opened it, and put my ear down close upon it, in great hopes that it would say something to me; but I was sorry, and greatly disappointed, when I found that it would not speak. This thought immediately presented itself to me, that every body and every thing despised me because I was black.''

title: So Maybe It Wasn't the Economy
description: ECONOMIC statistics are thrust into the news every day, with a portentious exactitude that can send Wall Street soaring or reeling, influence Government policy, even sway elections. Did consumer prices rise one-tenth of a percent more than was expected? Was economic growth a half percentage point less than people had been hoping?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 3 about a bookstore closing in New Rochelle misstated the surname of an author who gave a reading there. He is William Melvin Kelley, not Kennedy.

title: Ms. Amelkin And Mr. Cahn
description: Elizabeth F. Amelkin, a teacher, and Jordan M. Cahn, a banker, were married last evening in Palm Beach, Fla. Cantor David Feuer performed the ceremony at the Breakers.

title: Wary Support for Pataki Welfare Plan
description: A SWEEPING proposal by Gov. George E. Pataki to revise the state's welfare system by cutting benefits and widening work programs is gaining cautious support from Republican elected officials on Long Island.

title: Tower Offers Rooms for Long Stays in New York
description: An appropriate adjective for the Phillips Club, a 96-unit residential hotel that is scheduled to open today near Lincoln Center in Manhattan, is discreet. An easy-to-miss sign announces its existence in a new 26-story glass and brick condominium tower next to a Pottery Barn. The rooms, which range from snug studios to spacious three bedroom suites, are almost self-consciously quiet in soothing Giorgio Armani shades of beige, white, cream and taupe.

title: Emily Greenberg, Brett M. Topel
description: Emily Beth Greenberg, a daughter of Ellen and Dr. Stephen Greenberg of Dix Hills, L.I., was married last evening to Brett Michael Topel, the son of Audrey and Dr. Melvyn Topel, also of Dix Hills. Rabbi Howard Buechler performed the ceremony at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LATER DAYS AT HIGHBURY

title: 'Old Dog' Watson Has Some Bite and Some Bucks
description: If the first nine holes of the Skins Game today certified anything, it is that:

title: When Merchants Were Family
description: THEY are mostly all gone now -- vanished with the years and changes in suburban life styles. They were the small merchants who served our community and became part of the fabric that a family weaves over a lifetime. Of course, it's easy to throw stones at giants, and the huge shopping centers that have replaced our neighbors are a perfect target. It is, however, true that as I move through my town, I wonder if a mall can give a cookie to a fretful toddler in a shopping-cart or seek out a needed part for an out-of-date lawn mower.

title: Ms. Kurdova, Mr. MacLennan
description: Natalia Kurdova, the daughter of Svetlana F. Ruba of Moscow, was married on Friday to Thomas Stewart MacLennan, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. MacLennan of Princeton, N.J. A civil-marriage officiant performed the ceremony at the Palace of Weddings in Moscow.

title: Testing for a Lyme Disease Vaccine
description: THIS summer, one by one, Terry Buckley's three young children contracted Lyme disease. Kacey, 5, and Evan, 6, had the bull's-eye rash, while Graham, 8, became sluggish and said his leg ached. After a course of antibiotics, all returned to good health. Mrs. Buckley's husband, Greg, had Lyme disease a few summers ago, as did her mother, who lives with the family in Guilford. Of the family's four cats, two dogs and three horses, only the Arabian mare seems to have become infected. Though the horse tested negative, the veterinarian recommended she too be medicated.

title: Joanna Handelman, Jeffrey Nadler
description: Joanna Beth Handelman, the daughter of Janet and David Handelman of Los Angeles, was married last evening to Jeffrey Neil Nadler, a son of Marilyn Nadler of Glendale, Queens, and Dr. Harvey Nadler of Manhattan. Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich officiated at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: Darkness Visible
description: THE TENTH CIRCLE OF HELL

title: Milbury Yells, Islanders Rally, but Everyone Loses
description: Hockey coaches, angry at referees, have been known to wave a pair of eyeglasses in their direction to protest judgment. Mike Milbury of the Islanders added a high-tech twist to this tradition tonight.

title: Shooting Deer in a Barrel?
description: GROWING UP in small-town South Jersey, I never heard the words ''deer problem'' until decades later, when I was working in upstate New York. One winter day, a normally mild-mannered colleague trudged in, fuming about his near-death highway experience. The previous night, a deer had bounded from the woods and onto the hood of his car. Deer and car were totaled.

title: Brazilian Spot Offers Variety and Quantity
description: AT the new Green Field restaurant in Farmingdale the food is Brazilian, the owner is Korean and the servers are South American and Portuguese.

title: For Love Of Holly
description: HOLLY may be on many gardeners' minds at this time of year. Although it is too early to think about buying the berried branches for holiday decoration, the subject surely is worthy of consideration as part of providing premium landscape evergreens.

title: Web Offers an Outlet For Charitable Impulses
description: The spirit -- and reality -- of giving has a strong presence on the World Wide Web this holiday season.

title: Stocks Tumble in Japan
description: Stocks traded sharply lower here this afternoon after a quiet morning session. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 345.67 points, or 1.64 percent, to 20,674.69. On Friday, the Nikkei lost 15.18 points.

description: THE people who pioneer each new generation of computing technology have not traditionally been the same people who invent the next generation beyond it.

title: Defenders Against Death Penalty Construct Cases for Compassion
description: By the time the defense lawyers got the case, everything seemed just about over except the question of punishment. Prosecutors had a videotaped confession from the defendant, plus evidence that appeared incriminating, like hair and clothing. The following day, a grand jury would indict him for attempted rape, robbery and first-degree murder.

title: Koji Kobayashi, 89; Built NEC of Japan Into an Electronics Leader
description: Koji Kobayashi, an industrial visionary who built the NEC Corporation of Japan into a leader in the world electronics industry, died on Saturday in a hospital in Tokyo. He was 89 years old.

title: Tiny Tim, Singer, Dies at 64; Flirted, Chastely, With Fame
description: Tiny Tim, whose quavery falsetto and ukulele made ''Tiptoe Through the Tulips With Me'' a novelty hit in 1968, died on Saturday night at the Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis. He was 64 and had lived in Minneapolis for the past year.

title: A Healthy Start To Key Season In Retail Sales
description: American shoppers, apparently feeling more flush than during last year's holiday season, hit the malls over the weekend with a vigor not seen in the last few years, retail executives and mall operators said yesterday.

title: Historical Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: President vs. Press
description: Here's a constructive suggestion to Erskine Bowles, new White House chief of staff, to help Bill Clinton be a better President in his second term: Bring back the regular, wide-open, televised news conference.

title: Canton's Biggest Employer Is Out of Step, and That's Fine With Him
description: In the weeks before the election, leaders of the Dole campaign in Stark County privately admitted that their candidate did not have a prayer here, and by the morning of Nov. 5, even the longtime Republican Congressman Ralph Regula, a cautious man, was saying for the record that Bill Clinton would win.

title: Jewish Council Under Scrutiny Is Known for Political Clout
description: For years, politicians from Presidents to City Council members have believed they could win tens of thousands of Orthodox Jewish votes if they captured the support of just one group: the Council of Jewish Organizations of Borough Park, a collective of social service agencies.

title: Rangers Zoom to Other End for a Change
description: The current Rangers can't beat every team every night by running and gunning and going full speed. Despite the talent at the high end of their roster, these Rangers are not young enough or vigorous enough to gamble and forecheck and pounce upon every foe in its own zone. Sometimes, this will backfire.

title: Asian Nations Resist The West's Pressure On Human Rights : Burma's Bid For ASEAN Membership Reaffirmed
description: SINGAPORE  By avoiding a decision on when Burma will join the Association of South East Asian Nations, leaders of the group want to show that they will not give in to pressure from the West on the issue of human rights, analysts said Sunday.

title: Accord Reported on Japan Phone Breakup
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's largest telecommunications company, has reached an agreement with the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications on breaking up into three companies, a Japanese newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported today.

title: Which Side Are We On?
description: A Communist tyrant, humiliated in elections, annuls the results. When huge crowds demonstrate against his corrupt rule, he silences press and television coverage of the protests. And through the crisis no senior official of the United States Government deplores the tyrant's suppression of democracy and freedom.

title: A Warm Holiday Ritual
description: December's arrival, and the start of another holiday season, also marks the beginning of a vital local exercise in sharing -- the eighth annual New York Cares coat drive.

title: Pigs, for 'Personal Use'
description: How many pigs are too many? David Kraly is building a pig farm on 18 acres he just bought in a rural but decidedly residential area of Hamilton Township. His lawyer says he plans to raise between 50 and 100 pigs. But Mr. Kraly's neighbors complained that the farm would smell bad. So tonight, Hamilton's Township Committee will introduce an ordinance to limit the pig population to three ''for personal use'' on parcels in the same zoning class as Mr. Kraly's.

title: Mrs. Bissell to Seek Leniency
description: The lawyer for Barbara Bissell, the widow of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., plans to meet with Federal prosecutors tomorrow to ask them to request a lighter sentence for Mrs. Bissell in return for the help she gave the authorities in their search for her husband.

description: A woman and her 11-month-old son died when a fast-moving fire engulfed their apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, fire officials said. Three housemates, who were critically injured, survived by jumping out the windows of their third-story apartment.

description: Roche Laboratories in Nutley, N.J., has formally named various units of Lowe Group in New York to introduce Xenical, an anti-obesity drug, with direct marketing and other advertising. Billings were estimated to be as much as $50 million.

description: If Giants Coach Dan Reeves is going to read a poem to his team now, it had better be by Edgar Allan Poe.

description: A partial list for this week.

title: Mother and Baby Die in Brooklyn Fire
description: A woman and her 11-month-old son died early yesterday morning when a fast-moving fire engulfed their apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, fire officials said. Three housemates, who were critically injured, survived by jumping out the windows of their third-story apartment.

title: Challenge to Bid for Funeral Home Operator Is Allowed to Proceed
description: The Loewen Group said today that a Texas court had dismissed a lawsuit filed by the Service Corporation International that sought to stop an antitrust challenge of its $3.2 billion hostile takeover bid for Loewen, the second-largest operator of funeral homes in the United States.

title: Okinawa Copter Base May Move Out to Sea
description: The United States and Japan announced today that an American military helicopter base in Okinawa would be transferred onto a huge offshore platform as a way to reduce the noise and danger caused by American military operations on the southern Japanese island.

description: Hakeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets was admitted to a hospital yesterday after having an irregular heartbeat for the second time in less than two weeks.

description: To the Editor:

description: At this point the only question left for Neil O'Donnell to ask himself is: ''Was it worth it?''

description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the auction of a 52-week bill on Thursday.

title: Doctor Can Practice Again
description: A West Milford physician whose prescriptions may have contributed to the deaths of two patients has been allowed to resume practicing medicine by the state Board of Medical Examiners, The A.P. reported yesterday.

title: McDonald's Ranks As the No. 1 Brand
description: The McDonald's Corporation has been ranked the No. 1 brand in the world in a book from the Interbrand Group, a corporate-identity consultancy owned by Omnicom Group.

title: As Arts Prizes Multiply, So Do Doubts on Value
description: Pick a night, any night. Somewhere in Manhattan, someone is giving an award for artistic achievement, often more than one. New York, according to the city's Office of Cultural Affairs, is now host to more prize ceremonies than any other American city.

title: Scaled-Down Aid: Perils Lurk in Plans for Zaire
description: In the last three weeks, plans for an international force to help Rwandan refugees in Zaire have shrunk drastically.

title: Bowl Alliance Raises The Stakes Too High
description: Even if the bowl alliance produces a clear resolution to the college football season, this past weekend demonstrated that it has a flaw serious enough to put it out of business. It is just too top-heavy. At a time when college presidents are emphasizing fiscal responsibility in their entertainment divisions, the brave new world created by the bowls exposes an industry with financial rewards that are spiraling out of sight.

title: At Heart of Dispute, Tires by the Acre
description: Rhode Island's biggest environmental hazard isn't some faulty waste-water treatment plant, careless laboratory or reckless factory. Rather, the state's Department of Environmental Management says, it is a pile of old tires in a Providence suburb.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: In Pickpocket's Stash, a Peek at Life in 60's
description: The year was 1960. Chubby Checker was doing the Twist, that good-looking Senator Jack Kennedy was headed for the White House, and Carmen Bilbao, a 20-year-old student at New York University, walked to a movie in Times Square. ''It was a better time,'' she now recalls. ''I thought it was safe.''

title: East Timor Conflict Requires a Referendum
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Relies on Big Donors for 1997 Race
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aggressive style of raising funds for his re-election has produced an unusually high reliance on big givers: the average contribution to his campaign is $1,122. That is nearly eight times the size of his leading competitor's and is the highest average in the eight-year history of the city's tighter restrictions on campaign contributions.

title: Jan Behr, 85, Conductor at the Met
description: Jan Behr, who conducted nearly 150 performances at the Metropolitan Opera, died on Nov. 21 at his home in Lakewood, N.J. He was 85, and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: 160 NATIONS MEET TO WEIGH REVISION OF COPYRIGHT LAW
description: Copyright laws are under technological siege. Intended to insure both a financial return to those who create everything from poetry to computer software and reasonable public access to such material, the current laws may be unequal to the task.

title: 'Nutcracker' As a Big Bag Of Goodies For All
description: Two holiday traditions converged on Friday. The day after Thanksgiving is legendary, or even notorious, as one of the busiest shopping days of the year. Friday night was also when the New York City Ballet opened its annual run of ''The Nutcracker'' at the New York State Theater.

title: Defining TV's And Computers For a Future of High Definition
description: The agreement reached last week on a standard for the next generation of television sets is unleashing a consumer electronics revolution that will in time affect almost everyone in the country. It will also pit some of the world's largest corporations against each other in the competition to draw the blueprints for this future.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: No Headline
description: This brings back a part of my life I had almost forgotten. -- MARIA CORREA, on the return of a wallet she lost to a Times Square pickpocket more than 30 years ago. $(B6:2$)

title: No Cameras in Court? No Problem
description: At the O. J. Simpson civil trial last Tuesday, Mr. Simpson was questioned about his famous suicide note, written on the day of the televised Bronco chase. In the note, he asked to be remembered as ''the real O. J.''

title: Bridge
description: The record number of victories in the Blue Ribbon Pair Championships is four, shared by Larry N. Cohen and Bob Hamman. Cohen, who relocated from Little Falls, N.J., to Boca Raton, Fla., earlier this month, won for the first time in 1981 when he was 22. He almost won a fifth on Thursday at the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals in San Francisco as he and his partner, David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., finished just three match points behind Bob Blanchard and Jim Krekorian of Manhattan.

title: Staying the Course In the Heart of Ohio
description: ''Duty'' has been a driving force for W. R. Timken Jr. as he heads the Timken bearing and steel company and the Timken family, both institutions in Stark County, Ohio.

description: The record number of victories in the Blue Ribbon Pair Championships is four, shared by Larry N. Cohen and Bob Hamman. title: Kennedy Is Back on Top of the P.S.A.L.
description: Kennedy Coach Jerry Horowitz admitted he would have been inconsolable if his Knights had lost yesterday's Public Schools Athletic League championship game at Columbia's Wien Stadium.

title: Frustration Boils Over For Giant With a Mouth
description: Giants cornerback Phillippi Sparks is already a very good player. Someday he could be great. But if he does not tone down his on-field rhetoric, he will become tagged as a whiner.

title: Miriam Goldberg, College Professor, 80
description: Miriam Levin Goldberg, who studied underachievement by gifted youths and taught at Teachers College of Columbia University, died on Nov. 21 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 80 and lived in the Bronx.

title: Peru Imprisons an Ex-General After He Linked Army to Blast
description: A retired Peruvian general is being held in prison, after alleging in a television interview that an infamous military death squad had been reactivated and was responsible for a recent bombing.

title: The Silver Move Sets Pace
description: It was difficult to sight next May's Kentucky Derby yesterday through the rain and mud and fog at Aqueduct, but the 2-year-old colt named The Silver Move got the clearest look when he outran Jules to win the Remsen Stakes by 4 1/2 lengths.

title: How to Tame Smith? Overtime
description: In the battle of the backups this afternoon, Colts quarterback Paul Justin, playing for the injured Jim Harbaugh, kept a couple of things in mind: don't try to be a hero and don't do anything ''stupid'' to lose the game.

title: Nets' 'W' Also Stands for Williams
description: It would take getting as grimy as a mud flat, but Jayson Williams didn't care. He was thinking of his backyard, his to plant and help grow.

title: Death at an Early Age
description: Two-thirds of the boys who reach the age of 15 in Harlem can expect to die in young or mid-adulthood -- that is, before they reach the age of 65.

title: Plea for the 'Transgendered'
