description: People who do not identify with the sex they were born into are lobbying Rutgers University for protection against discrimination and harassment, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Kansas City to Restore Grandeur of Train Station
description: From the outside, the gray limestone walls and granite entryways of this city's train station look untouched by time, still as sturdy as in World War II, when half the nation's soldiers passed through its cavernous halls.

title: A New Romania: Neither Communist Nor Godless
description: In a ceremony resplendent with the glittering robes and miters of Romanian Orthodox bishops in a site resonating with historic significance, Romania's new President today pledged a new start for his troubled country.

title: Cultural Tradition and Law Collide in Middle America
description: The proud father of six was beaming on Nov. 9 when more than 100 fellow Iraqi refugees crowded into his house and the house next door for the wedding of his two eldest daughters.

title: Film Studio Gets A New President
description: Columbia Pictures said yesterday that it had named Amy Pascal, the president of production at Turner Pictures, as its new president. Ms. Pascal replaces Lisa Henson, who left this fall.

title: A special vest can take the place of hand-held pumps for breast-feeding mothers.
description: BOTTLE feeding is a chore faced by virtually all parents, even those who prefer that their babies have breast milk. Since the mother cannot always be available, many women use a pump to extract milk and fill bottles for later meals.

title: A Lane for the Heavy-Laden
description: The New Jersey Turnpike will have an extra lane starting on Wednesday, but during rush hours, only vehicles carrying three or more people will be able to use it. The northbound lane of the outer roadway from Interchange 11 in Woodbridge to Interchange 14 in Newark will be open only to such vehicles from 6 A.M. to 9 A.M. The southbound lane will be similarly restricted from 4 P.M. to 7 P.M. Turnpike officials say that motorists who use the lane should be able to shave five minutes off their commute.

title: Accounts
description: * Transitions Optical, Tampa, Fla., a joint venture of PPG Industries and Essilor International, to Media That Works, Cincinnati, to handle national and spot media buying on its account, with billings estimated at $30 million. Those duties had been handled by Focus Media, Santa Monica, Calif. The St. George Group, Pittsburgh, continues to handle the creative, media planning and print buying portions of the account.

title: Equity Offerings for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Bleak Serbian Mining Region May Decide Milosevic's Fate
description: After almost two weeks of street protests in major Serbian cities against the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic, he appeared today to be losing patience, hinting that he might be about to crush them. But many Serbs say his fate will ultimately be determined in this bleak southeastern mining region.

title: Fresh Start On a Farm After Streets Of Zambia
description: Once the dirt road passes the big vegetable farms near Landless Corner and becomes the private highway of suicidal chickens and car-chasing cows, the huts take on the personalities of their owners. One thatched roof is so neat that it is fussy, another has a layered look, a third is a mess of slipping straw.

title: Sierra Leone a Triumph of Peacemaking by Africans
description: The signing of a peace agreement here this weekend ending a five-year civil war in Sierra Leone stands in stark contrast to much of what the world is accustomed to hearing from Africa these days.

title: Who, me? Print a leaked document? A proper newspaper wouldn't dream of that.
description: THE scoop was something any normal newspaper would have been proud of, or so you might have thought. On Nov. 26, The Mirror, one of Britain's down-market tabloids, found itself the recipient of the journalistic equivalent of manna from heaven: leaked copies of large portions of the Government's 1997 budget, which was due to be presented to Parliament the next day.

title: Zaire Envoy Called Home; French Town Furious
description: Zaire recalled its Ambassador to France today after thousands of people in the southern French city of Menton rallied to demand that he be charged in the deaths of two schoolboys in a traffic accident.

title: Stop It at the Source
description: To the Editor:

title: Informix's new product is trying to seize market share from its major data base software rival.
description: THE Informix Corporation will move tomorrow to try to take market share from the Oracle Corporation, its leading rival in data base software, when it begins shipping its Universal Server.

title: Trial Balloon For Bratton: What's Next?
description: LET us face it. The prospect of William J. Bratton running for mayor is nothing short of tantalizing. For New Yorkers, it's intriguing because they always love a contentious campaign. But for Mr. Bratton?

title: DEFICIT ESTIMATES OF THE TWO SIDES ARE EDGING CLOSER
description: The Republican leaders in Congress are reducing their estimate of the growth of the deficit, bringing them much closer to the White House's figures, officials from both sides say, even before they begin budget negotiations in earnest. The new projection not only reduces the size of the problem facing the White House and Congress but also narrows the differences between them.

title: Wind and Rain Create Long Waits For Holiday Travel
description: Wind gusts and heavy rain turned the end of the holiday weekend into an agonizing wait for many commuters, some of whom waited hours to creep past road accidents or for flights to take off or land.

title: Officer Accused of Assault
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was arrested early yesterday morning at a diner in Bethpage, L.I., and charged with assaulting a patron and kicking out one of the diner's doors, the police said.

title: Insistent Safir Still Has Plans For Officers In Caribbean
description: Refusing to let go of a pet project that has become tangled in a thicket of political and diplomatic sensitivities, Police Commissioner Howard Safir suggested yesterday that he had not yet given up hope of stationing several New York City police officers in the Dominican Republic to help track fugitives there.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actress BLAIR BROWN has long been an admirer of the Dr. Seuss books, so when she was invited to read from the work of Theodor Seuss Geisel at a benefit tonight, she replied, ''Sign me up.''

title: For Peace in Ireland, End Emergency Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Disappearing Reforms in Mexico
description: Only last July, President Ernesto Zedillo proudly advertised a bold series of electoral reforms in Mexico, negotiated by the country's main political parties under his sponsorship. These promised, for the first time, to allow opposition parties to compete for votes on equal terms, beginning with next year's nationwide congressional elections.

title: Idries Shah, 72, Indian-Born Writer Of Books on Sufism
description: Idries Shah, an India-born author whose books about the varieties of Islamic mysticism known as Sufism have been widely published in the West, died on Nov. 23 in London. He was 72. He moved to Britain in the mid-1950's but traveled widely.

title: Orioles Lose 'Voice,' and Hear an Outcry
description: With the departure of the Baltimore Orioles' popular radio announcer after an apparent contract dispute, many residents are wondering who is to blame for this loss to the city.

title: Strong Weekend for Kmart in Manhattan
description: The plan was to get New Yorkers to embrace the idea of Corning Ware, clothes inspired by a former Charlie's Angel and all the other suburban sundries offered by the Kmart Corporation, which opened two stores this fall in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Global Copyright Accords Sought for Information Age

title: TV: Evolving Window on the World
description: Since the primordial days of experimental television in the 1920's and early 1930's, through the early broadcast era and into the computer age, the medium has evolved from a hobbyist's plaything into the world's window on itself. At the same time, this ubiquitous tube has undergone constant, if gradual, change in its ability to show detail, in the technology that makes it flicker, and in the shape of the images it presents.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When it comes to taking action to fight AIDS, NATASHA RICHARDSON does not find that simply writing a check is enough.

title: A Cool, Calm Couples Collects Title at Skins
description: This was pure desert theater, a gauzy flashback to the Palm Springs that was the Hollywood celebrity getaway of the 30's, 40's and 50's. Four marquee guys in cashmere, batting golf balls around on a Sunday morning in the shadow of the San Jacinto Mountains, making money.

title: Charging Inmates for Care Raises Issue of Health Risk
description: A 60 percent drop in the number of New Jersey prison inmates seeking medical care has raised questions of whether the state went too far earlier this year when it began charging prisoners $5 for each visit to the doctor.

title: Transplant Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Must Help Colombia Stop Drug Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Mezzo Does Battle With Zeffirelli's 'Carmen,' and Wins
description: The mezzo-soprano Denyce Graves has not only taken over the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Bizet's ''Carmen,'' she has taken over the whole show. And more power to her.

title: Mara Palmer, Interior Decorator, 77
description: Mara Palmer, an interior decorator who worked on yachts and offices as well as private homes in the United States and Europe, died on Nov. 20 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 77.

title: Shakespeare in Action
description: When the lights went down in the theater where we recently saw the new version of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' my husband was reminded of the first time he saw the Franco Zeffirelli film of the play. What reminded him was not the play, but the screen, which looked like something had been thrown at it.

title: Kodak Hopes Demand for Digital Images Will Sell Film
description: Robert M. Unterberger, president of the Eastman Kodak Company's two-year-old Digital and Applied Imaging Division, loves telling the story. It seems his wife, Mary Ann, wanted their daughter Kathy to pick out a sweater as a birthday gift. But the Unterbergers live in Rochester and Kathy lives in Austin, Tex.

title: John Williamson, 44, Nets Star in the 1970's
description: John Williamson, an electrifying guard who teamed with Julius Erving to help the New York Nets win two American Basketball Association championships in the 1970's -- while enhancing the image of the struggling league in the process -- died Saturday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 44.

title: Wry Tales From Ragmen and Hipsters With Attitude
description: Oscar Brown Jr.'s act falls comfortably at the intersection of jazz singing, comedy, theater and politics; it's the product of the Beat 1950's. Mr. Brown's classic album ''Sin and Soul'' (Columbia), from 1960, has recently been reissued, and on Saturday afternoon at the Langston Hughes Auditorium at the Schomburg Center in Harlem he turned in a set that relied on the music from the album. It was a set that gradually revealed Mr. Brown to be an astonishingly gifted and imaginative performer who brings a comprehensive worldview to the stage.

title: The City's Temporary Windfall
description: This fall has been the first time in many years that New York City has not experienced a budget crisis, filled with warnings about the need for more cuts in services. Thanks to an uptick in the city's economy, which was propelled by the boom on Wall Street, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has been able to announce $450 million in unexpected tax revenues that can be used to buy new textbooks for schools and put the overall budget on a sounder footing. Mr. Giuliani is putting his windfall to good use. But he cannot afford to divert himself from the path of austerity he has been following.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Familiar Faces In Ambitious Movies
description: Even when television movies get away from the standard porridge of diseases of the week or women who, for one reason or another, are positively terrified, the results can be disheartening. Two ambitious projects take a nose dive on this week's schedule.

title: Driving Teen-Agers Away From Drugs
description: While campaigning for re-election, President Clinton proposed drug tests for teen-agers who apply for driver's licenses. Republicans quickly labeled his proposal an election-year gimmick, but his advisers say he is serious. Whatever Mr. Clinton's motives, the proposal seems flawed on a purely practical level and may even raise questions of civil liberties.

title: Willingness to Transcend The Trappings of History
description: At their worst, the canon wars -- all those debates about great books, great art and great civilizations -- reduce themselves to competing forms of narcissism: a war of wills between those who have had the right for years to insist that art be shaped in their image and those who wish to claim that right for the future.

title: Broadcasters and Producers Make Time for Children
description: Jim Steyer, a man with a hard-earned reputation as a crusader on behalf of children's educational television, will announce today that he has taken on a new identity -- as a businessman intent on profiting from children's television.

title: State Defends Utilities' Break
description: New Jersey's treasurer said the planned elimination of the utility tax that now provides at least $685 million a year to local governments will not wreak havoc on municipal budgets -- at least not next year, The A.P. reported yesterday.

title: Layaway Plan Helps Finance a New Generation of P.C.S. Wireless Services
description: When Sprint Spectrum wanted huge amounts of sophisticated electronic equipment to build a new national wireless telephone network, it went to the telecommunications equipment titans Lucent Technologies and Northern Telecom Ltd. Little surprise there.

title: Blind Users Add Access On the Web
description: Cathy Murtha had never used a computer until early last year. As a busy mother of three children, she had not discovered a need for a computer and did not even know how to turn one on.

title: Soaps Heroine Spurns Script, and Plot Thickens
description: It was a case of life imitating art imitating life.

title: Brown Passes Into Disaster Zone
description: IN the years when Bill Parcells was coaching the Giants, he would often say, ''Around here, everything is euphoria or disaster.'' It still is.

title: Elegant Gift Books to Admire and Even Read
description: ''The possession of a book becomes a substitute for reading it,'' complained the novelist Anthony Burgess 30 years ago, apparently lamenting a common human failing. Although he no doubt spoke the truth, the surprising fact remains that certain books do not insist on being read. Mere possession serves their needs, provided you admire their handsome exteriors and maybe every so often crack them open to consult their contents.

title: Red Storm Stays Alive In N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: After losing in the first round for four consecutive years, St. John's advanced to the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's soccer tournament yesterday with a 2-1 victory over George Mason. The game-winner was a controversial goal with 11 seconds left in a game played in wind and rain at Adelphi University.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING

title: A Very Private Actor On a Very Private Author
description: The eyelids droop languorously; the lips purse; the wrist goes limp. He sashays down a curving staircase in an elegant silk dressing gown. It is Noel Coward deconstructed, Coward without the facade of heterosexuality. And it is Frank Langella, back on Broadway in Coward's ''Present Laughter'' at the Walter Kerr Theater, playing Garry Essendine, Coward's alter ego, man of the theater, feckless lover and something of a spoiled child in a 6-foot-3-inch body.

title: Throw Away Evil Atlas
description: To the Editor:

title: Rift in NATO Over Control Is Delaying Restructuring
description: Disagreement over a French demand that the United States cede control of a major NATO command in Naples to the Europeans has forced allied foreign ministers to delay plans to approve a major post-cold-war military reorganization next week, NATO diplomats said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about Wall Street strategies for minimizing capital gains tax liability misspelled the surname of a financial adviser who was quoted on the strategy of selling a business to an employee stock ownership plan. He is Francois de Visscher, not de Vissher.

title: Chess
description: Sometimes there are questions about the psychology of a game that cannot be definitively answered unless one of the players stands forth and bares his or her soul. And that's not likely when you realize that most of what grandmasters say ostensibly for the public is really intended just to set up future opponents.

title: Neutrino Hunters Cast Nets Far and Deep
description: FROM the hinterlands of Siberia to the Ionian Sea, and from mountain ranges in the United States, Japan and Europe to the South Pole, physicists are casting their nets in hopes of landing a bountiful catch of neutrinos from the Sun and stars.

title: Merrill Lynch Names Investment Banking Chief as President
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that Herbert M. Allison Jr. would become president and chief operating officer on April 15, making him the likely eventual successor to David H. Komansky as head of the biggest American securities company.

title: Brodeur Back In Goal Tonight
description: Devils goalie Martin Brodeur has had his troubles lately, but Coach Jacques Lemaire said yesterday that he would start Brodeur tonight when the streaking Florida Panthers visit the Devils. Brodeur's ego was slightly bruised when Lemaire benched him in Saturday's game against Colorado.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Women's Tournament

title: In Spain, They Have a Way To Clear A.T.M.'s at Night
description: Antonio Oliveros was getting tired of stepping over condoms and an occasional sleeping prostitute when he arrived for work as assistant manager at a Barclays Bank branch here.

title: Leonardo on Disk: Deal of the 16th Century
description: EVEN if you have to miss the current exhibition centered on the Codex Leceister, the early 16th-century manuscript by Leonardo da Vinci that Bill Gates bought in November 1994 for $30.8 million dollars, Mr. Gates has a deal for you. For about $50, his privately owned Corbis Corporation will sell you the entire manuscript and throw in the Mona Lisa. You also get a lot more, so on volume alone, it is a pretty good deal, and unlike Mr. Gates's fragile copy, yours comes in digital form on a sturdy CD-ROM. The Windows version is available now; a Macintosh edition should appear around Christmas.

title: Hong Kong Legislature
description: To the Editor:

title: A Strong Start for the Trade Panel
description: When President Clinton pushed the 1994 global free-trade accord through a reluctant Congress, opponents predicted that new mechanisms for adjudicating trade disputes might force changes in American environmental laws and other statutes. Two years' experience since then under the World Trade Organization, which conducts its biennial meeting among trade ministers next week in Singapore, suggests otherwise. If anything, evidence is mounting that judicial panels established to resolve trade conflicts are working firmly to America's advantage.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the opening of an international treaty conference on copyright protections misstated the academic title of Pamela Samuelson, who wrote a law review article on the United States' treaty proposal. She is a professor, not a visiting professor, at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: 'Express Delivery' Parcel Delivers a Speedy Arrest
description: They looked like Airborne Express deliverymen and they were even driving one of the company's trucks. But as soon as they had delivered their heavy package to a Brooklyn car repair shop, the two men arrested the worker who had signed for it.

title: No Headline
description: ''Of course, though, that woman over there, she's a millionaire. There's another millionaire! There's a millionaire in that pickup that just drove by. And look! Here comes a millionaire walking into my restaurant right now!''

title: TV Aims Few Shows At a Teen-Age Audience
description: Whether it is with the decibel level of their music or the style of their clothing, teen-agers clamor to be seen, heard, noticed.

title: Currency Talks Snag on German Demand
description: European Union finance ministers resolved most differences today over a pact to require low budget deficits after the switch to a single currency, but an important disagreement remained.

title: FALCON BUILDING STOCK SURGES ON TALK OF SALE
description: Shares of Falcon Building Products Inc. rose 13 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of construction and home-improvement products, said it was exploring a sale. Falcon Building, based in Chicago, said it was looking at strategic alternatives to enhance shareholder value, including the sale of the company or its individual businesses. The company said it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company and the Smith Barney Inc. unit of Travelers Group to provide financial advice. Shares of Falcon Building jumped $1.625 yesterday, to $14, giving the company a market capitalization of $280 million.

title: Jay Kramer, 80, Chairman Of New York's Labor Board
description: Jay Kramer, who was chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board under five Governors and used his position as a relentless cudgel against labor racketeers, died on Sunday at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. Mr. Kramer, who also lived in Great Neck, L.I., was 80.

title: Belarus Leader Aims at Russian Reunification
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korea Car Exports Jumped 70% Last Month
description: South Korean auto exports rose 70 percent in November from a year earlier, to a record 155,388 vehicles, the auto companies said yesterday. Domestic sales were up 14.4 percent, to 151,088, because of aggressive marketing, which included financing packages, they said.

title: Danone Buys Remainder Of French Food Venture
description: Groupe Danone said yesterday that it had bought from Groupe St. Louis a 34.5 percent stake in their jointly held Panzalim prepared foods venture for 2.9 billion French francs ($555.9 million). St. Louis, a Paris-based paper and sugar producer with sales of 35.3 billion francs ($6.75 billion) last year, sold the stake because it wanted to reduce its retail business and raise cash for expanding in food production. Panzalim, Europe's third-largest maker of pasta and frozen meals after Nestle S.A. and Unilever P.L.C., will now be totally owned by Danone. Panzalim, created in 1994, will have sales of about 8.4 billion francs this year. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Chrysler's November Sales Up Only 1.4%
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that its sales rose 1.4 percent last month, in line with analysts' expectations.

title: Economists Say Japan Is in Another Slump
description: Japan's economy probably shrank in the July-September period from the previous quarter as private demand slowed and the Government's emergency spending packages dried up, economists said yesterday.

title: Panthers Are Bracing For 49er Showdown
description: In only their second season, the Carolina Panthers are 9-4 and in a position to win the National Football Conference West division and make the playoffs. If they do, they will become the first expansion team to do so in only two seasons.

title: A Raise in '97? Coyly, Albany Leaders Turn the Unspeakable to the Barely Deniable
description: The state's two most powerful legislators said today that they would be ''shocked'' and ''surprised'' if the Legislature voted to increase its salary this year. But both men quickly conceded that it might still happen.

title: Russia and NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Charged With Counterfeiting in Columbia University Office
description: On most days, Columbia University's little printing office in the basement of the Journalism Building in Morningside Heights is busy making up faculty reports, newsletters for students, staff announcements from the administration and other routine printed materials.

title: Newark Ex-Police Director Receives a 2 1/2-Year Term
description: The man who served as Newark's top police official for five years and once promised to ''wipe out all corruption'' in the department was sentenced today to 30 months in prison for using thousands of dollars from a police account for vacations and gifts to his wife and girlfriends.

title: Havel Has Surgery for Lung Cancer; Prognosis 'Good'
description: President Vaclav Havel was operated on for lung cancer today and had a malignant tumor excised from his right lung, and half of the lung was removed, his doctors said.

title: Computing Computing's True Cost
description: CORPORATE computer managers have known it for years, but most individual personal computer buyers learn it the hard way: the purchase price of a new PC is just the tip of the iceberg.

title: Bitter Battle for Teamsters' Leadership in New York
description: Ten supporters of Ron Carey, the teamsters' president who is running for re-election, were handing out fliers outside a United Parcel Service building in Manhattan on a recent morning when a black van with tinted windows drove up.

title: After Four Heartbreaks, Can Navy Win?
description: If Navy does not beat Army this year. . . .

title: Patterns
description: Feraud Woos Younger Client

title: A Bad Deal For Baseball
description: Major League Baseball's labor agreement promises fans a five-year respite from the tiresome battles between players and owners. But that promise may be hard to keep, because the new pact addresses an economic problem that may not exist while it ignores a governing crisis that imperils the game.

title: Peter F. Bronfman, Industrialist, Dies at 67
description: Peter F. Bronfman, who with his brother, Edward, created one of the most powerful and secretive corporate empires in North America, died on Sunday at his home in Toronto. He was 67.

title: One Mosque's Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Young & Rubicam Dismisses Employees
description: Six junior-level employees in various departments at Young & Rubicam New York have been dismissed for circulating an electronic message that contained material deemed to be racially offensive.

title: Fear of a Virus, and Fear Itself, Stun a Resort Town
description: For decades hippies, artists and nature lovers from around the world have been drawn to the crystalline waters, virgin forests and vast wilderness of this quiet resort town in the southern Andes Mountains of Patagonia.

title: Giuliani Signs A Bill Tying Public Money To Debates
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who refused to debate in the last mayoral campaign unless the other candidates met his terms, signed a law yesterday that will require candidates for mayor, comptroller and public advocate to take part in debates if they receive public campaign money.

title: A Partner At Goldman Leaves for $50 Million
description: What does it take to get a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company to resign his lucrative post? Even more money.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 23 about new rules aimed at the Nasdaq stock market referred incorrectly to a rule that a limit order -- an order to buy or sell shares at a specified price -- must be disclosed immediately when its price is better than the market price. The Securities and Exchange Commission did not delay the rule. But it did say that until April 10 it would not enforce a part of the rule requiring disclosure of the limit order within 30 seconds.

title: Church Aide Avoids Jail After Bishop Speaks Up
description: The woman stood before a judge in Brooklyn yesterday and admitted in a barely audible voice that she had stolen $1.2 million from the Roman Catholic church -- money that law enforcement authorities say she used to buy boats and cars, finance college expenses for her sons and pay for vacations to Las Vegas, Nev., and points abroad.

title: British Asset Manager To Sell Its Swiss Bank
description: The British investment manager Mercury Asset Management said yesterday that it would sell its Swiss private bank Mercury Bank A.G. to the Luxembourg-based Safra Republic Holdings S.A. for about 250 million Swiss francs ($192 million) cash. In a joint statement, Safra said its flagship private bank, Republic National Bank of New York, would make the acquisition.

title: Self-Inflicted Wounds
description: Imagine a New York City couple with a learning-impaired child in public school. The couple appear at a federally mandated evaluation hearing to discuss a plan for the child's education. But there is an unexpected glitch -- a member of the evaluation committee fails to show up. When the parents threaten to sue the city, the Board of Education eventually awards them a private-school education, at public expense.

title: Speed Record Quest Halted
description: An international race to break the land speed record this year has apparently ended with the withdrawal of the last major contender from competition, a jet-powered British car called the Thrust SSC.

title: AFRICAN OFFICIALS SHIFT ALLEGIANCE ON U.N.'S TOP POST
description: In a move that could signal a swift end to the candidacy of Boutros Boutros-Ghali for a second term as United Nations Secretary General, Africans have been released from their pledge to stand behind him in the face of American opposition and are now free to nominate other Africans in order to save the seat for that region.

title: Mount Zion Calls on More Than Basketball to Make It the Best Ever
description: It's game night for the Mount Zion Christian Academy Mighty Warriors. So all rise.

title: Must Be Finicky
description: Things to avoid:

title: Cubs Sign Dunston
description: SHAWON DUNSTON decided to return to the Chicago Cubs after one season with San Francisco, agreeing yesterday to a one-year, $2 million contract. The 33-year-old shortstop had spent his 11-year major league career with the Cubs until signing with the Giants on Jan. 8. (AP)

title: Canada Air Acts To Defer Debt
description: Canadian Airlines International Ltd. said today that it planned to defer more than half of its debt and lease payments due in the next six months.

title: Powell Says He Had No Evidence Of Toxic Chemicals in Gulf War
description: While insisting that he knew of no evidence showing that American troops had been exposed to chemical or biological weapons during the Persian Gulf war, Gen. Colin L. Powell said today that he supported a wide-ranging Government investigation to ''get to the bottom'' of the mysterious illnesses reported by thousands of gulf war veterans.

title: AS ZYCON TAKEOVER IS ANNOUNCED, SHARES SOAR 28%
description: The Zycon Corporation, a maker of printed circuit boards, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., based in Dallas, for $180 million. Zycon, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said Hicks would pay $16.25 for each Zycon share outstanding. Shares of Zycon surged 28 percent yesterday, rising $3.50, to $16 a share. Zycon, which had sales of $180.9 million in 1995, said principal shareholders representing 60 percent of the shares outstanding backed the deal.

title: Rye Man Indicted in Double Murder May Face Death Penalty
description: A Rye man who won $17.5 million in the state lottery six years ago was indicted in Westchester County yesterday on charges that could make him liable for the death penalty in the fatal shootings of a pregnant woman and her father-in-law in front of their sprawling Chappaqua home.

title: Con G. Cholakis, 66, Judge Who Made Key Ruling in Pataki Race
description: Judge Con G. Cholakis of Federal District Court in Albany, a Republican appointee who dismayed the party's hierarchy in 1994 when he reinstated a Libertarian competitor in George E. Pataki's run for governor, died on Sunday at his home in North Greenbush, a suburb of Troy, N.Y. He was 66.

title: Business Is Booming At McDonnell Douglas
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Beat but Taking Off
description: The first three decades of the century might as well be prehistory for jazz listeners. While a debate over the racial, stylistic and geographic origins of jazz keeps on cooking among academics and historians, the average fan has been denied easy access to the tussle because the recordings themselves are rarely, if ever, reissued. But the condition is changing.

title: Fatal Crash Stops Traffic
description: Rush hour traffic on the westbound lanes of Route 280 came to a halt for three hours yesterday because of a fatal accident in West Orange, the police said. Traffic was backed up for several miles until the lanes were reopened at 6:35 P.M., said Trooper Joseph Lettieri of the state police. At least three cars were involved in the accident, he said.

title: Break in Main Under Lake Halts Water For 85,000
description: A water main buried under a lake in a Westchester County park here broke early this morning, leaving 85,000 people in New Rochelle, Eastchester and Pelham without water.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Newark Chief Sentenced

title: It's Foley's Turn As the Jets Turn On Themselves
description: The virtual disintegration of the Jets' passing game and of the hopes it brought for the season were underlined today when the young Glenn Foley was nominated to mop up at quarterback while Neil O'Donnell's season ended.

title: Downtown Post Offices Are Moving Out, Aggrieving Many Communities
description: This city of 6,500, nestled in the pine-draped mountains of south-central Montana, has long struggled to keep its historic Main Street thriving despite strip mall development and the pullout of a major railroad.

title: Chic Scales the Heights, or Walks the Dog
description: When Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue put snowboarding clothes in their store windows a few weeks ago, it was a clear sign that serious activewear had entered the mainstream. It's no longer just for athletes. It's fashion.

title: Nuclear Byproduct Cleanses Stubborn Smokestack Pollutants
description: THE stubborn stability of many of the pollutants coming out of industrial smokestacks makes it hard to keep them from getting into the air. But a team of British researchers reports that these volatile organic compounds appear to break down easily in the presence of a catalyst made from a byproduct of the nuclear industry: uranium oxide.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Schundler to Light Menorah
description: As a Federal appeal is pending on the constitutionality of installing religious symbols at City Hall, Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City has scheduled a menorah lighting ceremony in front of the building at sundown on Thursday.

title: SAMSUNG SIGNS CONTRACT TO SUPPLY MONITORS TO I.B.M.
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, a unit of Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it had recently signed a long-term contract to supply monitors for personal computers to the International Business Machines Corporation. A Samsung official confirmed reports of the deal that appeared in Korean newspapers but declined to disclose the value of the contract. Reuters, however, reported that Samsung had agreed to supply five million monitors, worth $2 billion, to I.B.M. over three years.

title: The Price of Dumping Boutros-Ghali
description: The way in which the United States has seen fit to get rid of Boutros Boutros-Ghali is deeply humiliating -- for both the Administration and the United Nations -- as well as for a man who has served the institution much better than most recent Secretaries General.

title: We're Performers, Please Ignore Us
description: Close your eyes and try to imagine a Mazzy Star concert. It doesn't take much effort. All you have to envision is blackness and nearly immobile silhouettes. On Sunday night at the Supper Club, Mazzy Star, along with its opening act, Sparklehorse, took a minimalist's look at rock conventions, constructing songs out of torpor and inertia.

title: Amro Bars Comment On an Expansion
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V., a leading Dutch bank, declined yesterday to comment on a report in a trade publication that it had held discussions about acquiring Weiss, Peck & Greer L.L.C.

title: Olajuwon Released From Hospital
description: Hakeem Olajuwon and the Houston Rockets were feeling much better yesterday, after his irregular heartbeat was corrected and he was released from the hospital.

title: Astros Sign Fernandez, Listach and Spiers
description: Pitcher SID FERNANDEZ, coming off four injury-shortened seasons, agreed yesterday to a one-year contract with the Houston Astros, who also signed infielder PAT LISTACH and re-signed BILL SPIERS.

title: Publishers Customize the News and Trim Costs, Too
description: From the outside, the only difference between the newspaper that lands on Jerry Pennington's driveway each Saturday morning and the ones most of his neighbors get is the yellow plastic wrapper. Inside the wrapper, however, is a special weekend business section that represents the first steps in The Austin American-Statesman's experiment in tailoring the familiar daily paper to the tastes, and someday maybe even the pocketbook, of every reader.

title: Banner Ads On Internet Attract Users
description: One particularly popular activity in the realm of interactive media, apart from downloading photographs of Teri Hatcher, has been banner-bashing.

title: France Says Key Arrest Uncovers Basque Plot
description: Basque separatist guerrillas fighting against Spain have long kept a low profile in southwestern France, slipping betweeen countries like ordinary travelers crossing the Pyrenees. But the rebels have been so angered by a recent crackdown on their activities in France that they have begun planning reprisal attacks on French targets, the French and Spanish police say.

title: For Ballet Theater, New Homes at Arts Center in Newark and at City Center
description: American Ballet Theater has been selected as a principal affiliate of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, the $180 million Newark theater-and-restaurant complex that is to open next fall. The announcement was made yesterday by the center.

title: Very Smart Fruit Flies Yield Clues To the Molecular Basis of Memory
description: IN bottles lining a wall of a Long Island laboratory there are swarms of fruit flies with an unusual ability. They have been endowed with a gene that gives them photographic memory.

title: JOHN ALDEN TO SELL ANNUITY BUSINESS TO SUNAMERICA
description: The John Alden Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its annuity operations to SunAmerica Inc. for about $240 million in cash. SunAmerica would acquire all the common stock of the John Alden Life Insurance Company of New York and the reinsurance of the annuity block of the John Alden Life Insurance Company. John Alden Financial, based in Miami, said it would use about $175 million to $200 million of the proceeds to buy back stock and pay down debt. The company also said the deal would allow it to strengthen its health care insurance business. SunAmerica, a financial services concern based in Los Angeles, said the acquired annuity business would immediately begin adding to the company's earnings.

title: Girardi's Agent Expects Deal With Yanks Soon
description: Joe Girardi progressed from being a pariah to being a prince with the Yankees last season, and now the valuable catcher is about to become a fixture in New York. His agent said yesterday that he was ''very close'' to agreeing on a contract with the World Series champions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALISTAIR COOKE, the courtly 88-year-old former host of ''Masterpiece Theater'' on public television, has uncharacteristically stirred a controversy over remarks he made about rape.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about growth of the number of awards in the arts misidentified one prize and its recipient this year and misstated its amount. The award is the Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, not the Lillian Gish Prize for Distinction in the Arts. It went this year to the stage director Robert Wilson; Ingmar Bergman won last year. The prize consists of a silver medallion and $200,000 this year, not $250,000.

title: The Knicks Now Regard Heat as a Worthy Rival
description: Patrick Ewing and John Starks still speak fondly of Pat Riley, but in the future they plan to pass up on the group hugs. Their former coach is no longer the captain of a cruise ship with a broken compass.

title: No Headline
description: Cold Batteries

title: Oil Spill Closes Grade School
description: Three hundred students were evacuated from an elementary school yesterday morning when a pipe burst in the school's boiler room and more than 1,000 gallons of heating oil gushed out.

title: Mexican President Dismisses Embattled Attorney General
description: President Ernesto Zedillo dismissed Attorney General Antonio Lozano Gracia and most of his team today, replacing Mr. Lozano with a leading human rights lawyer. The President acted to put an end to an embarrassing series of missteps by top justice officials, senior Mexican officials said.

title: Girl, 12, Is Killed by Train
description: A 12-year-old Perth Amboy girl died yesterday after being struck by a train, officials said. The girl, Michele Hinkley, was walking along the tracks with two other girls about a mile north of the Perth Amboy station, said Ken Miller, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit.

title: Treasury Securities Dip in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities stumbled yesterday, after new economic data failed to provide the incentive needed to keep last week's rally going.

title: Looking Past Fear of AIDS To See a Child
description: MICHAEL had been in New York for about a month, but it was time to leave for the peaceful reaches of rural Virginia. He didn't touch the shiny aluminum trays of Chinese food laid out before him and his family like a real New York send-off. He cried like a baby at times, which is all right, since he is one. His parents, Wayne and Dianne, barely had time to eat. They took turns cradling him, stroking his soft face or playfully dangling a pacifier close to his tiny, grasping hands.

title: Mandatory Ads Violate Rights, Fruit Growers Tell Supreme Court
description: It is settled ground at the Supreme Court that businesses have a First Amendment right, within limits, to advertise their products. An unusual free-speech case argued before the Court today presented the Justices with the other side of the advertising coin: whether businesses have a constitutional right to decline to participate in a Government-required advertising program intended to bolster the health of an entire industry.

title: Mets Release 2 Pitchers
description: The Mets announced yesterday that two right-handed pitchers, DOUG HENRY and MIKE FYHRIE, had cleared waivers and were released by the club.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: The Most Social of Wild Canids Struggles for Survival
description: THE African wild dog, one of the rarest and most quirkily beautiful mammals in the world, has more aliases than a member of the F.B.I. witness protection program, and all of them are confusing. Take the name African wild dog: it sounds like an abandoned pet gone bad. A related name, ''African hunting dog,'' is hardly better. The creature is indeed a superb hunter, but here, too, the phrase suffers from its human connotation, the whiff of English hounds out on an afternoon fox chase.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Keating S.& L. Conviction

title: VW Promotes A Key Figure In G.M. Fight
description: Ignoring an ultimatum from the General Motors Corporation, Volkswagen A.G. has promoted a former G.M. executive who G.M. had demanded be dismissed in the legal dispute between the two companies.

title: Mehl Joins Indy League
description: The Indy Racing League, the sanctioning body formed by the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, will begin its second year of competition with Leo Mehl, the former head of Goodyear's racing division, as its vice president and executive director.

title: Calligraphy Is Reflected In a Premiere
description: As part of Chamber Music Society Two, an initiative to support emerging artists, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented the Brentano String Quartet in a program at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. Though only in its fourth season, this quartet -- Mark Steinberg and Serena Canin, violinists; Misha Amory, violist, and Michael Kannen, cellist -- is already a first-class ensemble.

title: Town of Empty Pockets Finds Manna in Lottery
description: ''We're your typical little West Texas town, struggling real hard not to fade away,'' says Bill Brzezinski, the proprietor of the Silver Star Cafe on Highway 180 here. ''Everything depends on oil, cows and cotton, and the oil's all but gone, the cattle market is way down, and the cotton crop's been terrible the last three years now.''

title: Rape Victim Is Angered After Talking To NBC Show
description: The producers of ''Dateline NBC'' call Karen Pomer the heroine of an hourlong special report tomorrow night, but she is accusing the program of misrepresenting facts and exaggerating the racial aspects of a rape she endured a year ago.

title: A Budapest Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Roadway Death Toll Is 18
description: Eighteen people were killed on New Jersey roads from Wednesday through Sunday, the highest Thanksgiving weekend death toll in 15 years, officials said. Four people were killed on those days last year.

title: Letters Show How Indonesian Donor Family Lobbied Clinton
description: Mochtar Riady, an Indonesian businessman with longstanding ties to President Clinton, recommends to the President that the United States normalize ties to Vietnam and pursue trade with China.

title: A Fatal Fire, a Girl in Prison, And a Tangle of Justice Issues
description: Ev eryone the judge, psychiatrists, her friends and her lawyers -- agrees that Donna Ratliff needs someone to talk to.

title: Under Cuban Ferns, A Very Small Frog
description: FORGET Japan or Silicon Valley: the latest word in miniaturization may well be from Cuba, where a frog the size of a fingernail has been discovered on a remote mountainside.

title: Seeking Reasons For Disease Genes
description: FATE may be cruel or indifferent but geneticists believe there are often good reasons for bad genes. Genes that cause diseases like cystic fibrosis are so common, some say, as to suggest they must confer, either now or at some time in the past, a powerful compensating advantage.

title: New Agency Sought By Bausch & Lomb
description: Citing creative differences, the eye-wear division of Bausch & Lomb said yesterday that it had mutually parted ways with Bartle Bogle Hegarty in London, which had handled the worldwide Ray-Ban sunglasses account for six months. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Woman Spared Prison In Theft From Diocese
description: After the Bishop of the Brooklyn diocese asked the court to show mercy, a former employee of the Roman Catholic Church was spared a prison sentence despite admitting that she had stolen $1.2 million from her employer.

title: Don't Censor Atlas, However Odious Its Origin
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Films, Facts Get Some Assistance
description: Movie studios are drawn increasingly to fact-based dramas. And the blurred and sometimes controversial line between fact and fiction is evident in three new films: ''The Crucible'' and ''Shine,'' which opened in recent weeks, and ''The People vs. Larry Flynt,'' which opens later this month.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SAFEWAY INC., Pleasanton, Calif., a multiregional food retailer, acquired an additional 13.6 percent of SSI Equity Associates L.P. for $124.9 million, increasing its stake in the company to 74.1 percent.

title: Riley's Back In New York, And This Time He's in First
description: Pat Riley has the Knicks exactly where he wants them -- trailing his Miami Heat in the standing. And when Riley returns to Madison Square Garden tonight, it will be another reminder that he is still someone whom the Knicks have to deal with.

title: Man Is Guilty of Murder in Death of Firefighter in Garage
description: A man who admitted accidentally starting a fire in an illegal garage in Brooklyn was convicted yesterday of murder in the death of a firefighter who was killed as he searched the garage for possible victims.

title: The Return Of the Old Sprinter
description: JESSE OWENS on one leg could have beaten him in a race, he said. ''But, I wasn't the only one,'' recalled Marty Glickman. Yet Glickman believed that he, and not Owens, ought to have run in the 400-meter relay in the 1936 Berlin Olympics. And Owens, who had already won three gold medals, had agreed, though when Owens expressed it to a coach of the United States track team, he was admonished. ''You'll do as you're told,'' said Dean Cromwell.

title: Nuclear Agency to Reorganize for Rapid Action
description: The chairwoman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission acknowledged today that shutdowns imposed by her agency on nuclear power plants in Connecticut and elsewhere in recent years might never have been necessary had the agency spotted their problems early enough. She said the commission would be reorganized to enable inspectors to spot such problems, and senior managers to order corrective action, more quickly.

title: Hanspard Wins Award
description: Statistically, BYRON HANSPARD was not even the best running back in his conference this season. But Doak Walker award voters looked past the numbers, and yesterday the Texas Tech junior was honored as the best running back in college football.

title: JUDGE THROWS OUT KEATING'S VERDICT
description: Charles H. Keating Jr., whom Government officials once characterized as the most notorious swindler in the savings and loan crisis, had his last remaining criminal conviction thrown out by a Federal judge today.

title: When Sherlock Got His Quirks
description: It was a late summer evening in 1889 when Sir Arthur Conan Doyle sat down to dinner at the Langham Hotel in London with an American publishing agent who had come to commission new works of fiction for Lippincott's monthly magazine.

title: Rwandans Confront a Time to Heal
description: Five months ago, when Gaspar Ngumigize came home from a Hutu refugee camp in Burundi, he found a Tutsi family living in his two-room house along a dirt path here.

title: Jammed Belgrade Radio Defies the Buzz of Power
description: Bumbling along behind the 100,000 or so protesters who circle the city center each afternoon in Belgrade, his head buried inside the hood of his thick yellow parka and his hands fumbling with a tape recorder, a mobile phone and a walkie-talkie, was a portly and disheveled radio reporter.

title: New Flat Rate Creates Surge In Use of America Online
description: Computer users eager to take advantage of America Online Inc.'s new flat-rate pricing plan overwhelmed the system yesterday, causing widespread busy signals across the nation as subscribers tried in vain to dial into the on-line service's computers.

title: Publish Rules for Harlem Worship (and Beyond)
description: To the Editor:

title: Editor Is Named for Columbia Journalism Review
description: Marshall Loeb, former editor of Fortune magazine and a radio commentator and writer on investing, has been named editor of The Columbia Journalism Review.

title: The Business of WBIS Is Utterly Byzantine
description: A game of ''Find the Yankees on TV'' is under way. One hundred games are guaranteed next season on the MSG Network, but confusion exists over whether MSG will show 50 others, whether WPIX-TV/Channel 11 will get them again, whether the newborn WBIS-TV/Channel 31 will grab them, or whether the stations will split them.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL TO CUT 800 JOBS IN REVAMPING
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation plans to cut 800 jobs, or nearly 6 percent of its work force, by the end of next year. Some 400 people have already been told they will lose their jobs, and the rest will leave next year as part of a reorganization plan that includes selling bad loans, shutting lending offices and replacing old computer systems. Great Western, one of the nation's largest savings and loan associations, said it would take one-time pretax charges of $115 million to $130 million to cover the cost of the job cuts and the effect of selling $300 million in bad mortgages. The company, based in Chatsworth, Calif., announced the impending cuts in September, but the company's shares fell 50 cents yesterday, to $30.625, apparently because investors expected deeper reductions.

title: If You Read This History, Then You're a Part of It
description: A HISTORY OF READING

title: Game Plan For Giants: Dust Off Resumes
description: Now the guessing about the future of Dan Reeves will intensify at warp speed. The Giants' coach is not the only one wondering about his future.

title: China's Military Stumbles Even as Its Power Grows
description: As Chinese and Russian warplanes performed ear-splitting acrobatics at China's first international air show recently, Su Bichun was working inside the exhibition hall trying to sell to any willing buyer a supersonic cruise missile system that the Chinese Army does not want, possibly because it does not work.

title: Why Sharpen TV Image for Dull Content?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Rally, but So Far Only for the Big Stocks
description: The raging bull market that has pushed the Dow Jones industrial average past 6,500 points has turned into an exclusive affair: While large stocks are leaping up, smaller companies are seeing their shares go nowhere.

title: A Hospital Chaplain Helps the Disfigured Beneath the Skin
description: The Rev. Carolyn Yard can remember staring at the 4-year-old boy's hideous, dripping wounds, and his whispering to her, in a tiny voice, what had happened.

title: Mexico's Closing of Five Ports Pushes Up Prices of Crude Oil
description: Crude oil prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after Mexico closed five big ports because of bad weather, a move that threatened to disrupt exports to the United States.

title: Log Cabin in New York
description: Poor Emma Lazarus, said the Senator, she never really understood.

title: Mr. Clinton's Welfare Challenge
description: President Clinton's vow to ''fix'' the welfare law within days of signing it became almost impossible to honor when the Republicans retained control of Congress. The Administration's fallback position is to ask Congress for modest amendments that would restore about $13 billion of the $50 billion in scheduled Federal cuts over the next five years.

title: Gillies's No. 9 Finds Place Amid The Rafters
description: He gave opponents the cold shoulder and gave his less rugged teammates a shoulder to lean on, or, when necessary, to hide behind.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Heineken Division Picks Joint Venture
description: Heineken Latin America and Caribbean in Miami, a unit of Heineken N.V., has named a joint venture of Upmarket Illustra in San Francisco and Burkhardt & Partners in New York to handle the creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $10 million over three years. Those duties had been handled on a project basis by Upmarket, which is headed by Robert Gordon.

title: Memorial Service Is Set for the Missing T.W.A. Crash Victims
description: Trans World Airlines is planning a memorial service tomorrow for the 15 victims of the Flight 800 crash whose remains have not been recovered.

title: Trends Conspire Against the Yearbook
description: The DeSoto, the yearbook at the University of Memphis, has survived two world wars, a depression and endless changes in academic fashion since it began publishing in 1916 for the first graduating class at what was called West Tennessee Normal School.

title: Dow Corning Offers Plan To End Suits
description: A year and a half after it turned to bankruptcy court to avoid drowning in a tidal wave of lawsuits over breast implants, the Dow Corning Corporation proposed today to set aside $3 billion to pay all creditors, including up to $2 billion for injury claims linked to silicone implants.

title: Poland, a Paradise for Car Thieves, Seeks Means to Fight Underworld
description: PARIS  It is said that cars stolen in Germany are soon in Poland, but now the refrain is "stolen in Poland, soon somewhere further east."

title: Sydney M. Pozer, Left Behind In 'Great Escape,' Dies at 78
description: Sydney M. Pozer, a Canadian gunner who survived the crash landing of a burning British bomber in World War II to become one of the prisoners who conspired against their German captors to organize the mass breakout known as the Great Escape, died on Friday at his home in Prince George, British Columbia. He would have turned 79 today.

title: It's Grading Time for Schools
description: It's that time of year again, when the prospect of report cards makes hearts tremble -- the hearts of school administrators, that is. Today, the State Department of Education was expected to issue report cards on 2,200 public schools, grading them on attendance, teacher-student ratios, per-pupil costs and student achievement. This is the sixth time the report cards have been compiled, and the second time they have been issued since a law was passed requiring that the reports be produced annually, in a consistent form that enables administrators to make comparisons from year to year.

title: Gulf War Illness Findings Aren't Unexpected
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Card Company Halts Marketing Project for Now
description: Giving way to a legal attack by Mastercard and Visa, Advanta said yesterday that it had temporarily agreed to stop marketing a credit card linked to American Express's frequent-flier program.

title: Green Picks Johnstone
description: BARRY GREEN, the Indy-car team owner who won the 1995 Indianapolis 500 with JACQUES VILLENEUVE as his driver, announced yesterday that PARKER JOHNSTONE, 35, would be the team's driver for the 1997 season on the Championship Auto Racing Teams Indy-car series.

title: Interleague Play Requires a January Vote
description: Historic interleague play looms on baseball's horizon, but it won't officially become part of baseball's landscape until the players vote on the plan, and they won't do that until next month.

title: Simmons to Help Sell A Subscriber Gauge
description: Two research companies said yesterday that they would team up to sell a magazine subscriber measurement system named Smart Media. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Study the Results
description: To the Editor:

title: The Voice of a Boy, The Power of a Man
description: If the truth be told, most countertenors sound like males singing in strained falsetto. Not David Daniels, who made his New York recital debut on Monday night at the Walter Reade Theater as part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series. In range and color, Mr. Daniels has the voice of a boy soprano, clear and beautifully produced, yet projected with the virility and lung power of an adult. His thrilling sound probably comes closer to what the celebrated operatic castrati of Handel's day were like than most of the power mezzos who sing the castrati roles today.

title: An Ape Showing Humans What Humanity Is
description: THE WOMAN AND THE APE

title: Judge Is Asked to Quit in Prudential Suit
description: A lawyer representing Prudential Insurance policyholders requested yesterday that a Federal judge step down from presiding over a dispute between the insurer and policyholders, saying that the judge improperly met in private with the company's chairman.

title: Raven Is Investigated
description: The National Football League is investigating whether JON STARK, a rookie quarterback for the Baltimore Ravens, has associated with gamblers. Stark has been placed on administrative leave with pay after meeting with Commissioner PAUL TAGLIABUE on Nov. 25. ''There's no information at this time that he bet on any games,'' GREG AIELLO, an N.F.L. spokesman, said yesterday.

title: Boy, 12, Returns Unhurt 6 Days After Kidnapping
description: A 12-year-old boy who was kidnapped at gunpoint last Wednesday from his Connecticut home was found unharmed early this morning in Queens by law-enforcement officials and returned to his home in Meriden, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: State to Oversee Financially Ailing Miami
description: Gov. Lawton Chiles today decided to appoint a state oversight board to help the City of Miami solve its budget crisis but stopped short of a state takeover of the city's finances.

title: Brodeur Puts a Stop To Devils' Doldrums
description: Martin Brodeur had something to prove to himself and his coach tonight. After losing three games in a row and being denied a chance to play against his boyhood idol by Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire, Brodeur proved in remarkable fashion how good a goaltender he is.

title: 2 Rival Senate Leaders Are Chosen Again
description: Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi was re-elected as majority leader today, pledging to cooperate with the Democratic minority and the White House, to run a tighter and more organized legislative ship and to restore the Senate to a decidedly less taxing work schedule.

title: PANEL SAYS ERRORS IN INFLATION DATA DRAIN U.S. BUDGET
description: An independent commission appointed by Congress will report on Wednesday that the Government is overstating the inflation rate by 1.1 percentage points, costing it billions of dollars in inflated Social Security and other benefits payments. The commission will call on Congress and the Clinton Administration to solve the problem.

title: INSIDE
description: Plan for Sidewalk Structures

title: G.M. Has a 2d Poor Month As Sales Are Down 11.9%
description: The General Motors Corporation reported dismal auto sales today for the second month in a row, even as many other auto makers announced gains in their November sales.

title: Lucas Varity Starts Trimming: 13 Businesses and 3,000 Jobs
description: Lucas Varity P.L.C. said today that it would sell 13 businesses, take a charge of $420 million and cut 3,000 jobs as part of a two-year streamlining.

title: In the Changed Landscape of Recruiting, Academic and Corporate Worlds Merge
description: For many years, the Ford Motor Company has drawn new employees from more than 400 of the nation's best colleges in an annual rite of spring that is as ambitious a recruiting effort as anything corporate America has produced. And very soon, that broad-based approach will be as obsolete as the Edsel.

title: Meredith Dandy, Just Not That 'Dandy'
description: That was Don Meredith in the boyswear department of Kmart on lower Broadway yesterday morning, surrounded by tykes' Knick and Ranger jackets, wasn't it?

title: MARVEL CLEARED TO BORROW FROM CREDIT LINE
description: The Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. said yesterday that a group of its lenders had approved a waiver that would allow the company to borrow the remaining $15 million from its existing credit line. The financially troubled comic book publisher said it would continue meeting with the lender group, which is led by Chase Manhattan Bank, in an effort to reorganize its current credit line. The company hopes to secure an additional $130 million for investments and working capital in connection with Andrews Group Inc.'s proposal to invest new equity in Marvel and to make Toy Biz Inc. a Marvel unit. Marvel shares fell to $2.50 each on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: McDonnell Joins Boeing to Build Wide-Body Jets
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Boeing Company, whose commercial aircraft businesses have been headed in opposite directions, said yesterday that they had reached a cooperative agreement that would benefit them both.

title: Have-Nots Need Stake In Mexico, Envoy Says
description: One of James R. Jones's most sobering experiences as United States Ambassador here, he says, was a conversation in Tijuana with a cluster of young, unemployed Mexican men waiting for nightfall so they could climb the steel fence along the border.

title: Mr. Pataki Picks a Judge
description: In his most important judicial appointment thus far, Gov. George Pataki has nominated Richard Wesley, a well-regarded New York State Appellate Division judge, to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court. While we do not share Judge Wesley's views on the death penalty, and have some qualms about the process by which he was selected, the Governor has made a respectable choice.

title: Maker of Fake Medals Gets Maximum Fine
description: A Federal judge imposed the harshest possible penalty today on a Long Island company that sold bogus Medals of Honor, citing letters from veterans who expressed outrage that a medal meant to reward extraordinary valor on the battlefield had been sold to people who had never even served in the military.

title: Former Officer Gets 5-Month Prison Term
description: A former police officer from the corruption-plagued 30th Precinct in Harlem was sentenced to five months in prison yesterday, even though his lawyer argued that the officer learned to perform illegal acts from a superior in the precinct.

title: The Martini: Stirred, Shaken or Eaten
description: THIS is the age of the mutant martini. Drinks called martinis now have sake and cucumber in them. Or cranberry juice. Or creme de cacao and a chocolate kiss. Whatever happened to your basic gin with vermouth?

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Public or Private Health?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''Record companies used to be very good at predicting the tastes of record buyers, but their ears are clouding up a little bit.''

title: The Sparring Begins For Bowe and Golota
description: Riddick Bowe says he knows why he took such a beating from Andrew Golota in their July 11 brawl-marred heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Between them, STEVEN SPIELBERG and KATE CAPSHAW now have seven children -- the youngest, DESTRY ALLYN SPIELBERG, was born on Sunday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The baby girl weighed 7 pounds 12 ounces.

title: The Moon May Have Water, And Many New Possibilities
description: Scientists think they have detected water on the Moon, and suddenly visions of people living in lunar colonies and stopping off there to refuel on the way to Mars seem a little less farfetched.

title: Messinger, in Caribbean, Widens Campaign Vistas
description: With a year to go until the New York mayoral election, Ruth W. Messinger spent Thanksgiving weekend on the campaign trail -- but it took her nowhere near New York. Instead, Ms. Messinger headed for the Dominican Republic and Haiti for four days of official meetings, news conferences and honorary dinners.

title: Portraits of Mt. Kisco
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Affirms Special Status of Catholic Schools
description: The Supreme Court of Canada has ruled that the provincial government of Ontario need not finance non-Catholic religious schools even though for more than a century it has paid for schools run by the Roman Catholic Church.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Spicy Stew Of Beef, Eggplant And Onion
description: In Louisiana, you would be served eggplant and shrimp creole. But many liberties have been taken with this dish, starting with the eggplant, which has been broiled rather than fried. The flavors take nicely to a little ground beef, but ground pork would be equally welcome.

title: Whose Town Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: CALGON CARBON BUYS ADVANCED SEPARATION
description: The Calgon Carbon Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Advanced Separation Technologies Inc. from the Florida Progress Corporation and the Potomac Capital Investment Corporation for $70 million. Advanced Separation makes mixture-separating processing systems used in producing lysine and corn syrup. The company has annual sales of $30 million. The Pittsburgh-based Calgon Carbon produces untreated acid-washed carbons for use in manufacturing, pollution control and making charcoal. It had sales of $291.9 million last year. Florida Progress is a utility based in St. Petersburg, Fla. Potomac Capital Investment is a unit of the Washington-based Potomac Electric Power Company.

title: Time of Troubles in Algeria
description: With its constitutional referendum last week, the Algerian Government went far toward finishing the wrecking job on democracy it began nearly five years ago. The new Constitution outlaws Islamic parties, strips power from the Parliament and allows the president to rule by decree. The Government said it had been approved by 86 percent of Algerians, but no independent verification of the vote was allowed.

title: Columbia Counterfeiting Suspects: Modest Jobs, Heavy Debts
description: As investigators try to determine the extent of a counterfeiting scheme at Columbia University, court records suggest that those arrested in the case so far lived modestly and worked at jobs with moderate salaries, but that several had large debts, mainly for student loans.

title: Homeowners In Nassau Threaten Suit Over Taxes
description: Citing studies showing that Nassau County's property tax system overcharges homeowners in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, a coalition of civil rights groups today gave county officials 60 days to rectify the situation.

title: Giuliani and City Council Haggle Over Superstores
description: The Giuliani administration worked intensively with City Council officials yesterday to end their stalemate over suburban-style megastores, with the main sticking point appearing to be the Council's authority to approve or reject such stores.

title: Financier Makes Gift to Russian Business School
description: George Soros, the Hungarian-born investor who amassed a fortune through currency speculation, has guaranteed $1 million to help create a new home for a fledgling American-style business school at the University of St. Petersburg in Russia.

title: A Mongolian Moment: No Gas and the Camel's Lost
description: A man named Sad rode his motorbike up to the only gas pump in this dusty little town one recent afternoon, but he could see from the way the other herdsmen were standing around that there wasn't much pumping going on.

title: Delta and Continental Reported to Be Discussing a Merger
description: Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines are holding talks about a possible merger, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: Standoff in Serbia Is Nearing the Brink
description: The Serbian President and the opposition groups that have marched against his Government by the tens of thousands in the last two weeks edged closer to deploying the remaining weapons in their arsenals.

title: Plan to Improve Courts Includes Separating Domestic Violence Cases
description: At the end of a year scarred by complaints over the criminal justice system's handling of domestic violence cases, New York State's top judge announced yesterday that in 1997, each borough will have special courts with handpicked, trained judges to oversee such cases.

title: Army or Navy To Go to Bowl
description: The winner of Saturday's Army-Navy football game will be invited to the Independence Bowl, officials for the New Year's Eve game said today.

title: 3 Former Archer Daniels Officers Indicted on Price-Fixing Charges
description: A Federal grand jury indicted three former officers of the Archer Daniels Midland Company yesterday -- including an executive who worked for almost three years as an undercover Government informant in the case -- on charges that they conspired with competitors to fix the prices of a feed additive.

title: Documents Show Government's Concern : Was Duke of Windsor A Nazi Sympathizer?
description: The release of wartime documents in Britain on Tuesday revealed the extent to which the government was concerned about the possible Nazi sympathies of the Duke of Windsor and fears that Germany would try to put him back on the throne.

title: Rush Hour Train Derails
description: A New Jersey Transit train on the single-track line between Gladstone and Summit derailed during rush hour yesterday evening, injuring no one but delaying more than 1,000 commuters for over an hour. The four-car train, heading eastbound with 50 passengers, had pulled onto a side track just east of Murray Hill station in New Providence to let a westbound train pass, said Penny Bassett-Hackett, a spokeswoman for the railroad. When the eastbound train pulled back onto the main track, one wheel of its lead car derailed, she said.

title: Valujet Planes Flying Half-Full
description: Valujet Inc. reported today that its planes were less than half full in November, typically one of the busiest times for air travel in the United States.

title: Juvenile Delinquents?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Up
description: This was a good foreign-policy week for both Mickey Mouse and Ronald McDonald.

title: Files Say Justice Marshall Aided F.B.I. in 50's
description: Thurgood Marshall, the late Supreme Court Justice and a towering figure in the nation's civil rights movement, provided occasional confidential information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation about developments in the civil rights community, according to recently released documents.

title: A Democratic Offensive on Campaign Finance
description: Demanding prompt action on campaign finance legislation despite Republican diffidence, Senate Democrats tried today to make up in statistics and indignation what they lacked in votes.

title: Japanese Economy Grows, but Just Barely
description: Japan's economy showed signs that it had resumed growing in the third quarter, contrary to expectations for a second consecutive contraction, but the growth was tepid and economists said that more trouble lay ahead.

title: The Teamsters' Fateful Choice
description: When Ron Carey was elected president of the teamsters' union five years ago, he pledged to end 40 years of corruption that had seen four of the union's recent presidents jailed or indicted. He promised no more organized crime, no more concessionary contracts and no more local bosses who fatten their bank accounts at members' expense.

title: WQXR Marks 60th Year With a Series on Its Past
description: WQXR, New York City's only classical-music radio station, is celebrating its 60th anniversary this month with a ''Moments of Memory'' series highlighting live broadcasts and interviews of the past. Among these vignettes, being broadcast through Dec. 21, are Morton Gould in one of his last broadcasts; Kurt Masur, after being appointed music director of the New York Philharmonic, commenting on his aspirations for the orchestra; the soprano Renata Tebaldi marveling at the fervor of her fans years after her retirement, and comments by Leontyne Price, Benny Goodman and Erich Leinsdorf.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Electric appliances come alive to sell their G.M. sibling, the EV1.
description: COMMON household appliances are the stars of a spectacular spot that signals the start of ambitious efforts intended to create interest in an uncommon car.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: 'Team' Seems to Be a Foreign Word to These Knicks
description: First, his streaking team took the inside away from the Knicks, then it made off with their desire. But afterward, Pat Riley refused to ridicule his former franchise, insisting after the Miami Heat's 99-75 victory last night that the Knicks were still one of the most talented teams in the league.

title: Questions on Estrogen Therapy and Alcohol
description: ABOUT 25 percent of postmenopausal women in the United States take estrogen replacement therapy because of evidence that it prevents osteoporosis and heart disease. Even more of these women feel free to have a drink now and then because of research showing that it, too, may protect against heart disease.

title: My, What Big Morals Our Fairy Tales Weave
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Prevail in Should-Win Situation
description: A struggling team was in town. The Islanders were defending home ice. For the last few years, the Islanders were not expected to win these encounters.

title: New X-Ray Method Helps Find Appendicitis
description: IN about one in five appendectomies performed in this country, the appendix turns out to be normal. And another one patient in five has appendicitis but is sent home with the condition undiagnosed. A chief factor in both situations is the imprecision of standard pre-operative diagnostic tests.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOYCE MILTON, a historian who has written books about Charlie Chaplin, Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, and Charles and Anne Morrow Lindbergh, is moving forward in time with her newest subject: Hillary Rodham Clinton. The biography is scheduled to be published by William Morrow & Company in 1998.

title: Crisp, Rich Words For Cookie Bakers
description: COOKIE makers will rejoice because their favorite sweet morsels have at last been given their own cookbooks.

title: Official Admits Taking Trees
description: As Jersey City's recycling director, Thomas Killeen worked to make the city a greener place. But Mr. Killeen apparently could not resist making his own yard greener at the taxpayers' expense.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ELAN UNIT WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL OF MUSCLE-SPASMS DRUG
description: The Elan Corporation, based in Dublin, said its United States subsidiary Athena Neurosciences Inc. had won approval from the Food and Drug Administration for its new muscle-spasms drug. The drug, Zanaflex, is the first oral treatment for the condition approved by the F.D.A. in more than 20 years, Elan said. Elan's American depository receipts rose $1.25 to close at $30.625 in Nasdaq stock trading.

title: Empty Coffin: Months After Flight 800, Vigil for a Son
description: For most of the world, the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 is a mystery frozen in metal wreckage hidden away in an old hangar. But in Anne Allen's family, as with others devastated by the crash, the tragedy ricochets like a scream in an echo chamber, picking up force with each bounce.
