title: 2 Die as Terrorist Bomb Rips Train at a Paris Station
description: A powerful explosion ripped apart one car of a packed commuter train pulling into a Paris rail station at the height of the evening rush hour tonight, killing two passengers and critically wounding seven in what President Jacques Chirac condemned as ''an act of barbarity and terrorism.''

title: Crew Seeks Money to Fix Computers
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that the most pressing technology need is not more computers but enough funds to fix existing ones and to train teachers to use them.

title: Cultivating The Art Of the Melange
description: FOR the record, Jessica Hagedorn issued this warning before the scheduled interview: ''It's not really 'Lunch With.' It's 'Merienda With.' ''

title: Personal Health
description: BREAST cancer is the second-leading cause of cancer deaths in women, after lung cancer, and the disease women worry about most. The best current weapon for preventing breast cancer deaths is early detection: finding and treating the disease before it has a chance to spread. The earlier the cancer is found, the higher the cure rate, and the technique best able to detect these early cancers in women who seem otherwise healthy is periodic X-rays of the breasts, or screening mammography.

title: News Instead of Cartoons
description: If you can't beat 'em, run a different race, CBS has decided.

title: No Private Offers For Banco di Napoli
description: Mediocredito Centrale S.p.A., which is owned by the Italian Treasury, is the only bank that has offered to buy the Treasury's 60 percent stake in Banco di Napoli S.p.A., the Treasury said yesterday.

title: Applied Graphics To Buy Spot Link
description: Applied Graphics Technologies in New York has agreed to acquire the assets of Spot Link Inc. in Wilmington, Ohio, from the Western International Media Corporation, a media services unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. To acquire Spot Link, Applied Graphics will give Interpublic 539,683 shares of its common stock, worth $11.7 million at the close of trading yesterday.

title: Justices Weigh Rights of States In Gun Control
description: The Clinton Administration struggled today to convince the Supreme Court that the Brady gun control law does not trample on the constitutional principles of state sovereignty in requiring local law-enforcement officials to conduct background checks of prospective gun purchasers.

title: Replacing Fat With Prunes and Apples
description: FOR many years, chefs specializing in spa food have used fruit purees to replace some or all of the fat in cakes and other baked goods. Prune puree is a favorite for chocolate cakes. Now, Sun sweet Growers in California have introduced Lighter Bake, a prune-and-apple puree designed to be used as a fat replacement in baking. It is not very sweet and does not distort a recipe.

title: Clinton Declines to Take Sides on Campaign Against Prosecutor
description: President Clinton today declined to say whether he approved of James Carville's proposed campaign against Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, seeming to leave the door open for his former chief strategist to proceed.

title: CARTER-WALLACE REJECTS $928 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: Carter-Wallace Inc. said yesterday that its biggest shareholder had rejected a sweetened $928 million buyout offer from the Los Angeles financier Marvin Davis. Mr. Davis, through his closely held Davis Companies, raised his bid for Carter-Wallace to $20 a share last month, an increase of $2 a share, or $93 million. But Carter-Wallace, whose products include Arrid Extra Dry deodorant and Trojan condoms, said that the CPI Development Corporation, which owns a majority of its stock, had indicated it had ''no interest'' in selling to Mr. Davis. Therefore, Carter-Wallace said, it would not take any further action on the Davis proposal. Carter-Wallace stock closed unchanged yesterday at $15.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: LOCTITE IN MERGER TALKS WITH POTENTIAL BIDDER
description: The Loctite Corporation is in talks with a potential buyer that it did not identify, which could bring in a higher bid for the adhesive maker than the $1.22 billion offered by its biggest shareholder. Representatives of Loctite and its investment banker, Dillon, Read & Company, met with the chief executive of the potential bidder, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Two weeks ago Loctite rejected a $57.75-a-share bid from Henkel K.G.a.A. of Germany as too low and said it would seek a higher bid from others. Loctite shares rose $1.125, to $60.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Henkel, which already owns 35 percent of Loctite, started a tender offer on Nov. 6 to pay $57.75 in cash for each share it does not already own.

title: Maurice B. Mitchell, 81, Leader Of a College and Public Radio
description: Maurice B. Mitchell, who never finished college yet rose to lead the University of Denver in a decade as chancellor as well as holding leadership positions at Encyclopedia Britannica and National Public Radio, died on Saturday at the Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: St. John's Keeps Its Balance
description: For a half, this was a game straight from the peach-basket era, eerily reminiscent for St. John's of a 1992 visit here. Yet the result was much more pleasant for the Red Storm this time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ex-Archer Daniels Officers Indicted by Federal Jury

title: A.C. Nielsen Reaches Deal To Halt Discount Practices
description: The A. C. Nielsen Company reached an agreement today with the European Commission to end pricing practices that Nielsen's archrival, Information Resources Inc., said had thwarted competition.

title: Passing Problems? Brown Shrugs
description: Dave Brown is among the first to admit that the Giants need to add better players if they are going to be a playoff contender any season soon. But whether the quarterback position needs improvement is something others must decide.

title: The Dow Falls 79.01 Points In Late Selloff
description: With concern rising that rallies in the dollar and bonds might be stalling, stocks quavered and then tumbled late yesterday as the General Motors Corporation reported poor auto sales for November.

title: No Cookie's Sweeter Than One That's Handed Down
description: DELICIOUSNESS doesn't change over time. Consider cookies, which are one of the first pleasures to signal the coming of the end-of-year holidays.

title: HAWAII JUDGE ENDS GAY-MARRIAGE BAN
description: A Circuit Court judge in Honolulu ruled yesterday that lawyers for the state had failed to show any compelling reason for the existing ban on gay and lesbian unions. Calling the ban unconstitutional, the judge ordered the state to stop denying marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

title: U.S. Director Is Voted Out
description: For 31 years, Ollan Cassell has ruled track and field in the United States. In that span, despite the heroics of such athletes as Carl Lewis, Michael Johnson, Edwin Moses, Florence Griffith Joyner and Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the sport that is so important in the rest of the world has been reduced to almost an athletic afterthought here.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of a Basque separatist by the French police misspelled the given name of the French Interior Minister. He is Jean-Louis Debre, not Jean Luis.

title: Mediterranean Command at Stake : U.S. Tries to Fend Off Paris on a NATO Post
description: BRUSSELS  The United States has started wielding a combination of carrots and sticks to isolate France over its challenge to the American hold on the job of NATO commander in the Mediterranean, according to European officials at allied headquarters in Belgium.

title: Playing Modern Detective In the Gunpowder Plot
description: While writers as diverse as John le Carre and V. S. Naipaul journey to exotic places in search of material, Antonia Fraser habitually goes to the reading room of the British Museum, where she is surrounded by her research (and sometimes by her mother, daughters and other members of her family of writers, the literary Longfords). For Lady Antonia there is also a sense of adventure, despite the quietude and the archival aspect of her creativity.

title: Europe's Call For Rights In Cuba Lets U.S. Off Hook
description: The European Union's vote on Monday urging Cuba to improve its policies on human rights and political freedoms has cleared the way for President Clinton to waive once again the most controversial part of a new law intended to punish foreign companies that use confiscated American property in Cuba, Administration officials said today.

title: Cowboys Hit Hard: Lett Suspended One Year for Drug Use
description: Two weeks of speculation ended for Dallas Cowboys tackle Leon Lett yesterday when the National Football League suspended him for one year without pay for failing his most recent drug test. It was Lett's second suspension for violating the N.F.L.'s drug policy in the last 13 months.

title: International gift-giving may be a worthwhile business practice, but there can be pitfalls.
description: IT'S global gift-giving time for corporate travelers who want to maintain a warm relationship with key foreign contacts. Whatever the recipient's religion -- maybe Buddhist rather than Christian -- the holidays are an excuse to celebrate the new year and say ''thank you.''

title: Some Expansion and Contraction
description: Who would have thought five years ago that an expansion team in Miami would reach the Stanley Cup finals in its third season and have the best record in the National Hockey League in its fourth?

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: OVERHEARD on a jet during the safety briefing at takeoff, between a father and his 5-year-old son:

title: China Turns the Tables
description: Two years ago, the Clinton Administration caved in to China when it agreed not to link the two countries' trade relations to Beijing's violations of human rights. Today, with its threats of economic retaliation against the Walt Disney Company over a film about the Dalai Lama, China is exercising a form of ''reverse linkage.''

title: Anne Schwerner, Civil Rights Worker's Mother, 84
description: Anne Schwerner, a retired New York teacher and the mother of Michael H. Schwerner, a 24-year-old civil-rights worker killed by Ku Klux Klansmen near Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964, died on Friday at a nursing home in Kettering, Ohio. A former resident of Pelham, N.Y., she was 84.

title: A. Martin Macy, 70, Aviation Executive And a Consultant
description: A. Martin Macy, a retired pilot, aviation consultant and executive with regional airline associations in Washington, died on Thursday at his home in Houston, where he had moved last year. He was 70 and also kept homes in Washington and Antigua.

title: Parisians Brace for Tightened Security
description: The bombing at a rail station cast a pall of gloom over the city tonight as Parisians resigned themselves to the possibility of a new wave of terror.

title: Lawmaker's House Is Linked to Drug Sales
description: The police said today that a house in Albany that was used to distribute as much as $25,000 in heroin a week is owned by an Assemblywoman from the Bronx.

title: ISIS PHARMACEUTICALS STOCK RISES AFTER BIG PAYMENT
description: Shares of Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc. rose 10 percent yesterday after the drug maker said it had received a milestone payment from Boehringer Ingelheim about its genetic treatment for Crohn's disease. The company, which is based in Carlsbad, Calif., said Boehringer bought $10 million of Isis stock for $24.47 a share. Isis stock rose $1.625 to close at $18.375 on the Nasdaq stock market. The treatment is based on Isis 2302, which uses certain proteins as weapons to fight inflammatory diseases. The company has conducted clinical trials on Isis 2302 for use in treating kidney transplant rejection and ulcerative colitis.

title: For Record Industry, All Signs Are Gloomy
description: ''I'm going to keep making money,'' the top-selling rapper Snoop Doggy Dogg boasts on his new album. He may be the only person in the music industry feeling that optimistic. The business is in one of the most perplexing crises it has faced in decades.

title: Building Is Booming and California Lawyers Are Massing on State Line
description: It happened first in California 15 years ago: a housing boom touched off a litigation boom as legions of lawyers filed lawsuits accusing builders of shoddy workmanship.

title: Restless Tribute to Human Resilience
description: ''I thought you say you take pictures of physical damage,'' the disfigured Japanese woman says in broken English to the American war photographer in one of the opening scenes of Robert Lepage's visually stunning epic-length dramatic work, ''The Seven Streams of the River Ota.'' With her back to the audience, she implores the G.I. to record what the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima has done not only to her surroundings, but also to her.

title: Gingrich Sees Improved Relations Between Congress and Clinton
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich predicted tonight that the mission of the re-elected Republican majority in the House would shift to ''implementation,'' from confrontation, starting with President Clinton's proposed budget.

title: As Hanukkah Approaches, Olive Oil Takes Center Stage
description: HANUKKAH, which begins tomorrow evening, is as much a celebration of the olive as it is of the miracle of the oil that lasted eight days.

title: Special Courts for Boroughs
description: New York State's top judge said each borough would soon have handpicked, trained judges to oversee domestic violence cases. Page B1.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ISI AUTOMATION, Detroit, a maker of material handling products and automation systems, has been acquired by Norgren, a unit of IMI P.L.C. of London. IMI said it was paying $150 million.

title: Dan Flavin, 63, Sculptor Of Fluorescent Light, Dies
description: Dan Flavin, a leading Minimalist sculptor known for working with fluorescent lights, died on Friday at a hospital in Riverhead, L.I. He was 63 and had homes in Wainscott, L.I., and Garrison, N.Y.

title: Racal, ITT Industries In British Radio Bid
description: Racal Electronics P.L.C. said yesterday that it would team up with its main rival, ITT Industries, to bid for a delayed $:2 billion ($3.4 billion) British Defense Ministry radio contract. Racal, a British military and telecommunications company, announced a joint venture with the United States company, which means there is just one bidder to build the next-generation Bowman radio network for the British Army.

title: Remembering Justice Wilentz
description: Friends, relatives and associates of Robert N. Wilentz gathered yesterday at the State Supreme Court, where he presided for 17 years, and remembered him as a hard-working and compassionate jurist.

title: In Case Tied to Mexico, Witness From Citibank Is Called a Liar
description: A banker convicted of money-laundering in 1994 has asked for a new trial, asserting that a Citibank executive who testified as an expert witness for the prosecution lied on the witness stand.

title: Deutsche Telekom Sells Additional Shares
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said yesterday that it had sold an additional 90 million shares, bringing the total number sold in its initial public offering to 713.7 million, or 26 percent of the company. The German phone giant raised $11.5 billion in Europe's largest privatization when it went public on Nov. 18.

title: U.S. Warns Serbia Against Crushing Protests
description: In the face of opposition demonstrations by tens of thousands of Serbs this week, the United States today stepped up its criticism of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and warned that a crackdown on the protesters could doom the country's hopes to be freed of economic and political sanctions.

title: Drug Fines Will Fight AIDS
description: About $1 million in fines collected from people convicted of drug offenses will be given to drug treatment centers to help slow the spread of AIDS, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday. The money will be given to 25 agencies to treat 845 intravenous drug users and their sex partners, the Governor said. Currently, the state spends $31 million a year on treatment programs.

title: I.B.M. TO EXPAND DISK-DRIVE MANUFACTURING CAPACITY
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it planned to spend $440 million to expand its worldwide manufacturing capacity for disk drives and other components, including a new factory in Thailand. I.B.M., one of the world's largest producers of computer components, said the new plans bring the total investment announced for its Storage Systems division this year to $1.32 billion. A portion of the new investment will be used to build a disk-drive plant in Prachin Buri, Thailand, I.B.M. said. The factory will produce 2.5-inch drives used in portable computers.

title: Seeking That 'Special Aura'
description: ''Payback,'' an ABC television movie, is a tense crime drama starring Mary Tyler Moore and Edward Asner. The network has been planning to show it early next year, promoting it as a fruitful on-screen reunion of the two former lead actors of the classic ''Mary Tyler Moore Show.''

title: Yankees Give Girardi a 2-Year Deal
description: Joe Girardi's voice dripped with emotion yesterday as he spoke about signing a two-year, $5.5 million contract with the Yankees and about remaining in New York. Even Girardi conceded that in one amazing year he went from unwanted to untouchable.

title: With Its Drug Binge Over, Cali Seeks Salvation in Old Values
description: The abundance of plastic surgeons still recalls the fast money that flooded this second-string city, nerve center of the world's $150 billion annual trade in illegal drugs.

title: Expanded Inquiry Is Ordered in Death of Killer
description: With the parents of John C. Salvi 3d charging that prison officials ignored their son's mental condition, Gov. William F. Weld has ordered that the routine investigation into Mr. Salvi's apparent suicide be expanded to include a thorough examination of his medical needs while in prison.

title: Cadwell Davis Loses Three J.& J. Brands
description: The personal products division of Johnson & Johnson has moved the North American accounts of three feminine-hygiene brands from Cadwell Davis Partners in New York to two other Johnson & Johnson roster agencies. Combined billings were estimated at $28 million to $30 million.

title: Utility Regulator Will Retire
description: The legal battle over whether Edward H. Salmon should be allowed to keep his job as a Commissioner of the Board of Public Utilities ended yesterday when he agreed to retire at the end of the year and pay a $2,500 fine.

title: Student Says Vomiting on Painting Was an Artistic Act
description: When a museumgoer vomited on a Mondrian masterwork at the Museum of Modern Art in New York last month, museum officials called it ''an unfortunate incident'' and said the young man involved had apparently not done anything deliberate to harm the painting.

title: TCI is ready to have another one of its calves tomorrow.
description: AT the headquarters of Tele-Communications Inc. in Englewood, Colo., the senior executives have coined a folksy phrase for the way they build up and spin off fledgling businesses: They call it calving.

title: Help Wanted in East Zaire as Rebels Try to Govern
description: A local man wearing a frayed but clean shirt and tie was riding a battered bicycle around the streets of this once prosperous tourist town, looking for work in the newly liberated province of North Kivu.

title: When Public Business Goes Private
description: As for-profit and nonprofit organizations increasingly displace government agencies in running public programs -- from education to prisons to welfare -- watchdog journalism is facing a new and little-noted challenge.

title: Hospital Leasing Deal Endangers the Indigent
description: To the Editor:

title: New 'Furniture' and, Finally, Toilets Planned for City Streets
description: Many of the structures moored to New York City's sidewalks bear the wounds of an urban habitat, from the array of jerry-built newsstands slathered with grime to bus shelters that look as if they have been set upon by marauders. And the one streetside amenity that many residents crave, a clean public toilet, is usually nowhere to be seen.

title: Stephanopoulos Plans to Teach at Columbia
description: After five years of swimming through a perpetual seminar in politics and policy as a senior adviser to Bill Clinton, George Stephanopoulos has accepted a place as a visiting professor of political science at Columbia University, the first post of the multimedia career he intends to pursue upon leaving the White House at year's end.

title: A Cool Persona: Enigmatic, Ageless
description: THE true test of a classic is the amount of reinterpretation, and even abuse, it can take. Shakespeare has absorbed a female Richard II, played by Fiona Shaw. ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' under Peter Sellars's direction, looked right at home in a 20th-century diner. And the martini, austerest of all the great cocktails, has managed to retain its dignity even when assaulted by tiny pickles, garlic cloves, chocolate liqueurs and, in one truly bizarre variation proposed in the 1950's (the ''dillytini''), a string bean marinated in dill vinegar.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 29.35 points, or 0.14 percent, at 20,659.91. On Tuesday, the Nikkei fell 44.13 points.

title: The Mall Pall
description: The figures are in. Peter Jennings reported the good news on Monday night. Shoppers spent 12 percent more at malls on Thanksgiving weekend this year than they did in '95. Given the primacy of malls in American life, you'd think there would be more celebration of their ongoing 40th anniversary. It was in 1956 that the first enclosed shopping center, Southdale, opened in Edina, a suburb of Minneapolis.

title: Saying Home Sweet Home In Joyous Song and Dance
description: For most of us who grew up in the 1940's and 50's, MGM musicals were passports to magic. With an inexpensive ticket to some glorious movie palace, we could step from our own humble homes into a world of dazzling color, bustling with beautiful women and dashing men, none of whom had the slightest difficulty breaking into an enchanting song or fabulous dance. Hollywood gave us our Emerald City month after month. More than anyone else, the wizard responsible for these sumptuous illusions was the producer Arthur Freed.

title: Mentor Wins Brutal Game Over Pupil
description: PAT RILEY did not inherit Jeff Van Gundy but he surely claimed him for his staff five years ago. The respect is so great that Van Gundy will still rave about Riley, even though Riley is now officially the opposition and still has his rule against ever helping a member of the other team up from the floor.

title: Federal Prosecutors Stay Silent On Leniency for Bissell's Widow
description: Federal prosecutors in New Jersey refused to say yesterday whether leniency was being considered for the widow of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the former Somerset County Prosecutor who killed himself on Nov. 26 after fleeing the authorities.

title: Plutonium Disposal Option Meets Cost Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Pack May Miss Game vs. Knicks
description: Nets point guard Robert Pack missed practice today after coming down with flu symptoms, making it uncertain whether he can play against the rival Knicks Wednesday night in the Meadowlands.

title: PATAKI ANNOUNCES FIRST NOMINATION TO HIGHEST COURT
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who has repeatedly criticized the state's highest court as soft on crime, announced his first nomination to the Court of Appeals today, choosing a pro-death-penalty Republican with a reputation for supporting prosecutors and interpreting laws narrowly.

title: A New Era at the California Capitol, Or the Same Old Gridlock Instead?
description: There was much optimistic talk of a new legislative era among Democrats in Sacramento on Monday as their party formally took back control of the California Assembly and, in a historic first move, elected to the Speakership one of their number, Cruz Bustamante of Fresno, the first Hispanic lawmaker to head the chamber.

title: TNT Gets 1998 Games
description: TNT yesterday acquired the cable television rights to the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan, from CBS Sports and will show about 50 hours. TNT will pay CBS an estimated $10 million and give CBS generous time to show Olympic promotions, while CBS will keep all revenues from advertising sold on both networks. ''Anytime you give the viewer more quality Olympic programming, it's a win-win,'' said SEAN McMANUS, the president of CBS Sports.

title: Girl Falling From Platform Critically Injures Young Boy
description: A 5-year-old Bronx boy who was walking with his mother was critically injured yesterday afternoon when he was struck by a 16-year-old girl who had jumped, slipped or been pushed off an elevated subway platform, the police said.

title: Harrods Owner Wants British Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprint Spectrum Shrinks Wireless Rollout
description: Sprint Spectrum, which owns more Federal licenses for advanced wireless voice and data networks than any of its competitors, has lowered its estimate, for a second time, of the number of cities in which it will provide personal communications services by the end of the year.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE agreement last week to transfer majority ownership of Chateau d'Yquem to a French conglomerate could mean the end of control by a family that has held it since the Middle Ages.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For more than 20 years, ROBERT BEASER, a composer and the chairman of composition at the Juilliard School, has had a mission: ''to write classical music that is more communicative than contemporary music, which can be rather hard sledding,'' he said yesterday. But little did he figure that a favorite television character of his 4-year-old twins, Big Bird of ''Sesame Street,'' would be a messenger.

title: Screws Tightened on Serbian Opposition
description: The Serbian President and opposition groups that have marched against his Government by the tens of thousands in the last two weeks edged closer tonight to deploying the last weapons in their arsenals.

title: DIME BANCORP TO BUY BFS BANCORP FOR $92 MILLION
description: Dime Bancorp Inc., the sixth-largest savings bank in the United States, agreed to acquire the New York- based BFS Bancorp Inc. for $92 million. BFS has five branches in New York and $643 million in assets. Dime, also based in New York, said the acquisition would add to earnings immediately, as it plans to slash BFS's costs by 40 percent. Dime also plans to buy back up to 5 percent of its stock and to sell $1.2 billion in mortgage-backed securities. The three actions will add to earnings, improve profit margins and reduce Dime's exposure to losses tied to changes in interest rates, James Large, Dime's chairman, said in a statement.

title: Charles Bressler, 70, Tenor and Teacher
description: Charles F. Bressler, a tenor who appeared in numerous recital, oratorio and opera performances in New York City and around the world, died on Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: American Topics : Short Takes
description: Karla Chapman, an eighth-grade student in Pikeville, Kentucky, has been suspended from school for wearing black lipstick, which the principal said was a distraction. Karla's parents, Michael and Connie Chapman, protested angrily outside the school, and Michael now faces charges of terroristic threatening and abuse of a teacher, to which he pleaded not guilty. "What would your child's cosmetics have to do with her education?" he asked. Principal Rosa Wolfe said Karla, 13, could return if she gives up the lipstick. Karla says she will do so if the charges against her parents are dropped. There the matter stands.

title: Big or Small, Martini Glass Is a Hot Item
description: WHAT'S going into them is anybody's guess, but martini glasses are flying out of stores and showrooms.

title: A Justice Rooted in Small-Town Life and Values: Richard Carl Wesley
description: During the O. J. Simpson case, when Justice Richard C. Wesley was out jogging near his home in upstate New York, he made it clear to a friend that he disapproved of what he considered Judge Lance A. Ito's permissiveness.

title: An Account of Rape And Its Aftermath
description: Television news magazines, perhaps to justify their obsession with stories involving violence and sex, often tag on some edifying message to their audience-grabbing tales. Tonight, ''Dateline'' offers a woman's account of being raped as prelude to a report on her campaign to increase her local police department's sensitivity to the crime.

title: I.B.M.'s Issue Draws Interest From Investors
description: I.B.M. entered the debt markets in a big way yesterday, offering an issue of 100-year bonds that featured attractive returns relative to Government securities. Combined with a lower dollar, that pushed Treasuries off their early highs to finish mixed.

title: Wake Forest and Kentucky Both Roll to Early Victories
description: It is billed as the Great Eight Festival, a title based more on the past than the present. In truth, only four of the teams that traveled to the United Center for four games over two days have the chance to be great. The others are just hoping to be good.

title: Fixing the Scales for Measuring Inflation: In Politics, It's Not an Easy Thing
description: Say the owners of a grocery store discovered that the scales they used to weigh produce were out of whack and that their profits were down because they were undercharging for fruits and vegetables. The first thing the grocers would do would be to fix their scales.

title: German Output Falls 2d Consecutive Month
description: Germany's industrial output fell 1.8 percent in October from September, according to provisional figures released yesterday by the Economics Ministry. The fall marks the second consecutive month-on-month slide in German output, after a fall of six-tenths of 1 percent in September. Production had been rising gently for most of the year.

title: Food Notes
description: A Scandinavian Holiday Boutique

title: Garden Is No Eden for Knicks So Far
description: The struggling Knicks may need a burglar alarm to protect their home court.

title: A tract close to the airport, too noisy for houses, becomes the hot industrial site near Indianapolis.
description: ON a site the size of seven football fields, a developer has started preparing the land for a distribution center in Plainfield, an industrial boomtown six miles west of Indianapolis.

title: Jets Will Go With Foley And Hope for the Best
description: Why do the Jets plan to start third-stringer Glenn Foley at quarterback for the last three games of the season? Why not, his teammates say.

title: O, Shakespeare
description: To the Editor:

title: Detroit TV Station Deal
description: The Granite Broadcasting Corporation has agreed to acquire WXON-TV, the Detroit affiliate of the Warner Brothers network owned by Time Warner Inc., for $175 million in cash. The seller is WXON-TV Inc. The move gives Granite, which already owns nine network-affiliated television stations, its first presence in a top 10 market. Granite is based in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column in some editions of Business Day on Tuesday about the planned sale of Silcorp Ltd. gas stations and convenience stores in Michigan to Clark Refining and Marketing Inc. gave an outdated name for the parent company of Clark. It is the Trizec Hahn Corporation, which changed its name from the Horsham Corporation last month.

title: Albert Carretta, 88, Official Who Ended Ban on 'Free' in Ads
description: Albert A. Carretta, who as a member of the Federal Trade Commission wrote a 1953 decision allowing businesses to advertise ''free'' goods along with merchandise for sale, died of a heart attack on Saturday while visiting a son in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 88 and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: U.S. Helping More to Leave Kurd Enclave In North Iraq
description: Nearly three months after its military and relief effort collapsed in northern Iraq, the United States today began evacuating 4,000 to 5,000 Kurds and other Iraqis who had worked for private organizations in the northern Kurdish enclave once protected by the United States and its allies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Aug. 8 about a family on Long Island that raises free-range organic chickens misspelled the name of a commercial chicken producer. It is Perdue Farms, not Purdue. A spokesman for Perdue pointed out the error in a letter dated Oct. 1. This correction was further delayed because of an editing lapse. The letter's discussion of other disputed points in the article appears today on page C11.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Unions Reject United Way
description: If William P. Shuber, the Bergen County Executive and a board member of the United Way, does not want to give county employees a raise this year, then union officials do not want their members giving to the United Way. About 1,500 county workers have been working without a contract since last Dec. 31.

title: Devils Aiming to Rise Above Peers
description: The Devils shut down the top team in the National Hockey League on Tuesday night. Now comes the difficult task: six games against teams with losing records.

title: Lazarus's 'Masses'
description: To the Editor:

title: Jayhawk Rally Pushes No. 1 Past Former No. 1
description: The Great Eight Festival might as well have been called the Great Two tonight as top-ranked Kansas took on Cincinnati, the preseason No. 1 team, in the best matchup of the young college basketball season.

title: S.&L.'s Post Loss After Insurance Fund Fee
description: The United States savings and loan industry posted a loss of $505 million in the third quarter after paying a one-time fee to replenish its deposit insurance fund, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.

title: Judge in Bomb Inquiry Has Made a Career of Fighting Terrorism
description: Jean-Louis Bruguiere, one of the three French investigating magistrates named today to lead the inquiry into the latest bombing in Paris, has plenty of reason to travel with an armored car and bodyguards.

title: Japan Proposes Agency To Oversee Its Banks
description: Japan is planning to establish an agency in April 1998 to supervise and inspect the nation's banks, the Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said yesterday. The move would take away part of the Finance Ministry's role of supervising the financial industry, leaving intact the authority over brokerage firms. The ministry's other main roles are collecting taxes and allocating the nation's budget among other ministries and agencies.

title: POP
description: A Salsa Star Who Delivers

title: Carl F. Grillo, 41, Executive Director For Liberal Party
description: Carl F. Grillo, the secretary and executive director of the Liberal Party of New York State, died on Tuesday night at the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center. Mr. Grillo, who lived in Dongan Hills on Staten Island, was 41.

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Tonight 8 P.M.

title: Kunstler's Widow Sues Over Use of Firm's Name
description: The widow of William M. Kunstler sued his associate, Ronald L. Kuby, yesterday to prevent him from using Mr. Kunstler's name to promote his new law practice.

title: Spirited Holiday Stockings
description: IT'S that time of year when everyone is in a giving mood. But in a city crowded with competing benefits, people in the business of receiving for good causes have to be especially creative. One of the most fashionable ways to attract munificence is to commission designers and local celebrities to make clever objects that can be displayed, auctioned, raffled off or otherwise turned into cash.

title: The Hard Part: Fixing the Errant Price Index
description: A lot of Americans, according to the commission appointed by Congress to examine how the Government measures inflation, have been getting away with murder for decades. They have been paying less in taxes and receiving more in benefits than Congress ever intended. The catch, the panel of experts headed by Michael J. Boskin, a Stanford economist who was President George Bush's chief economic adviser, is that we have seen the enemy and it is almost all of us.

title: Guatemalan Foes Renounce Use of Arms, Ending 35-Year War
description: The Guatemalan Government and rebel leaders formally renounced the use of arms today, ending an armed conflict that has claimed more than 100,000 lives over 35 years.

title: Westinghouse Sets Bonneville Payment
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay $6 million to the bankrupt Bonneville Pacific Corporation to remove itself as a defendant in a civil suit filed by Bonneville's trustee against numerous companies.

title: New Donaldson Fund Raises $3 Billion
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette has raised $3 billion for its new buyout fund, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II, according to people familiar with the firm.

title: Man Is Charged With Fraud After a Claim for $5 Million
description: Anthony Robinson sued New York City for $5 million in 1994, saying he had broken his leg after tripping on a large crack in a garbage-strewn Harlem sidewalk.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Clarkson

title: Learning Self-Discipline
description: To The Home Section:

title: Metromedia Says Its President Has Resigned
description: Metromedia International Group Inc., the entertainment and communications conglomerate headed by the billionaire John W. Kluge, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, John D. Phillips, had resigned.

title: Older Role Models
description: To The Home Section:

title: A Tale of Stock Promotion, Regulation and the Internet
description: Peter A. Usinger was incensed. He was using the Internet, as he often does, to check up on a little company he had bought stock in called Omnigene Diagnostics Inc.

title: G.I. Charm Overcomes Anxieties In Hungary
description: The prospect of thousands of American soldiers setting up base camp in this tiny village that does not rate a dot on most maps sent dizzying visions through many minds here. On one hand there were dreams of instant wealth from the world's richest army, on the other worries about a dive in moral standards as free-wheeling G.I.'s behaved as depicted in Hollywood movies.

title: Helping Janet Reno
description: Like the young woman in the commercial who snapped ''Mother, I'd rather do it myself,'' Attorney General Janet Reno has informed Congress that she needs no independent counsel to investigate charges that President Clinton took millions in foreign payoffs for political favors.

title: Butler to Return With Dodgers
description: Outfielder BRETT BUTLER, whose comeback from cancer last September lasted just five games before he suffered a broken left hand when hit by a pitch, agreed yesterday to a one-year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Bridge
description: Two players from the New York City region, Zia Mahmood of Manhattan and Michael Rosenberg of Tuckahoe, N.Y., completed a rare double in San Francisco Sunday at the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Lithuania Has No Right To Keep Jewish Archive
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Victims: Flight 800 Memorial
description: These 15 victims from Flight 800, whose names were given by T.W.A., are still missing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP., Seal Beach, Calif., said its shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of its aerospace and military businesses to Boeing Co. for approximately $3.2 billion. As part of the transaction, Rockwell is spinning off its $10.4 billion commercial-electronics business to its shareholders.

title: HUNTSMAN CHEMICAL BID FOR REXENE IS WITHDRAWN
description: The Huntsman Chemical Corporation said yesterday that an agreement to buy the Rexene Corporation for $16 a share, or $302 million, fell apart because of what Huntsman, based in Salt Lake City, called Rexene's unreasonable conditions. Dallas-based Rexene objected to the transaction being a one-step merger rather than a tender offer, Huntsman said, and presented ''outrageous'' terms, including a fee of $100 million if the transaction was not completed. Both are petrochemical companies. Separately, a group led by Guy P. Wyser-Pratte and Spear Leeds & Kellogg, a New York securities firm, proposed four nominees for the Rexene board and want the number of directors reduced so the four would be a majority. Together, Mr. Wyser-Pratte and Spear Leeds own about 10 percent of Rexene's shares and want the company to be sold.

title: Gain for Same-Sex Parents, at Least
description: The ruling was about same-sex marriage. But in what some are calling the biggest show trial yet on homosexuals as parents, the deciding factor was the issue of whether same-sex couples make good moms and dads.

title: Supreme Court Debates State Bans on Multiparty Candidates
description: New York voters take for granted the fact that candidates can appear on the ballot as the nominees of more than one party at a time. But such fusion tickets are an anomaly elsewhere in the country, in fact are prohibited in most states, and the Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether those prohibitions violate the First Amendment rights of free speech and association.

title: Delta Jet Stranded on Runway by Landing Gear Trouble Ties Up La Guardia
description: A Delta Air Lines jet with a landing gear problem was stranded on a runway at La Guardia airport for more than six hours yesterday, leaving the airport with just one working runway, which delayed hundreds of flights and forced some to land at other airports.

title: 1,800 French Soldiers Join Bomb Patrols
description: French police officers, reinforced by 1,800 soldiers, appeared in high-visibility patrols at airports and train stations in Paris and other cities today after an explosion in a rush-hour commuter train on Tuesday night that killed two people and left at least 70 wounded.

title: Complex Plumbing, Complex License
description: To the Editor:

title: Hazards Strategy Praised
description: An environmental group praised New Jersey yesterday for doing a better job than most in keeping track of toxic chemicals and reducing the likelihood of accidents.

title: A New Way to Look at Prices
description: A commission of outside economists appointed by Congress reported yesterday that the Government's measure of inflation overestimates the impact of price increases by more than one percentage point a year. That might sound boringly technical. But the impact on the Federal budget would be huge. With one stroke of the pen, Congress could knock $50 billion off the deficit in 2002, about a third of its projected level. Over 10 years, the adjustment could reduce deficits by $500 billion -- without forcing a single vote on spending cuts or tax hikes.

title: Doyle Manuscript Sold For $519,500 at Auction
description: An autograph manuscript of ''The Sign of Four,'' Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's second Sherlock Holmes story, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's to an anonymous American collector for $519,500, far more than the auction house had estimated.

title: As Zuzu Can Attest, Americans Love Hopeful Ring of 'It's a Wonderful Life'
description: They clutch her hands. They weep. They share with her the sorrows of their lives, all the while seeking her assurance that everything will be all right. To them, she is not Karolyn Grimes, a middle-age woman living in Kansas, but Zuzu Bailey, only 6 and living in the make-believe town of Bedford Falls.

title: Plant Was Town's 'Golden Goose'
description: For this small community of old farms, white clapboard churches, saltboxes and ranch homes, the Connecticut Yankee power plant has long paid the bills.

title: For Germans, Guilt Isn't Enough
description: Among the foreign countries that Americans know, I've noticed that my native Germany is named more often than many. When I moved to Washington this fall, I was struck by the omnipresence of things German on television.

title: Do Korean Men Still Beat Their Wives? Definitely
description: Asked if he has beaten his wife, Lee Un Kee straightened himself in indignation and the warm sparkle suddenly left his eyes, leaving them as chilly and harsh as the wind gusting through this farming village.

title: A Step Toward the Other Side of Waiting
description: Stacie Patton watches and waits.

title: Embarrassed, France Halts Thomson Sale
description: The French Government, bowing to a wave of Gallic pride touched off by its attempt to sell Thomson S.A., the heavily indebted, state-owned electronics company, to French and South Korean investors, temporarily suspended the entire plan today.

title: Stocks Stagger a Bit, With Dow Off 19.75
description: Stocks stumbled in a volatile day of trading yesterday as a selloff of some of the better-performing stocks of the year sent the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks down for a second consecutive day.

title: U.S. Launches Second Craft to Study Mars
description: An American spacecraft is on its way to Mars and a planned landing there on the next Fourth of July, when it should deliver the first remotely controlled roving vehicle designed to traverse the landscape of another planet.

title: Labor-Pact Road Still Has Bumps
description: The rain that fell on Dorado Beach today was not accompanied by thunder, but rumbles were heard and felt nevertheless. They served notice that the brave new era of labor peace in baseball has not yet dawned.

title: An Additional Title For Wren at Omnicom
description: John Wren, president of Omnicom Group, the parent of agencies like BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide, was named yesterday to the additional position of chief executive, effective Jan. 1. Bruce Crawford, 67, chairman and chief executive at Omnicom, will continue as chairman.

title: New Leader for Breeders' Cup
description: The Breeders' Cup underwent a change of command yesterday when JAMES E. BASSETT 3D retired as president after nine years and was succeeded by his executive director, D. G. VAN CLIEF JR.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lighter Sentence Is Requested As Reward for Bissell's Wife
description: Federal prosecutors in New Jersey asked yesterday that the wife of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the former Somerset County prosecutor who killed himself last week rather than face a prison term, receive a lighter sentence than Federal guidelines recommend.

title: Jewish Treasures, Suitable for Mailing
description: MENTION postcards to most people and they think of those wish-you-were-here photographs of snowy Alps or palm-freckled beaches that thicken the mail just when you do not want to be told that someone else is far away from the office and having fun.

title: Test Scores in Poor Districts Still Lagging, Officials Say
description: Statewide test results released today show that high school students in New Jersey's 30 poorest school districts continue to score substantially lower than their wealthier, suburban counterparts on the standardized tests needed to graduate.

title: Rangers Make A Fine Point By the Buzzer
description: When a hockey team is slumping, it sometimes loses games it should win. That happened to the Rangers more than once during November, when they plunged toward the bottom of the National Hockey League.

title: Giuliani and Council Hit an Angry Impasse on Superstores
description: Negotiations between the Giuliani administration and the City Council on a plan to allow warehouse-style stores to open in manufacturing areas broke down amid bitter recriminations last night, raising the possibility that the plan might be delayed for months.

title: To Zairians, President Becomes Irrelevant
description: Since the beginning of a crisis six weeks ago, when a rebel force began capturing cities along Zaire's eastern border, no subject has caused more speculation among Zairians than when their longtime President will return home and what he will do to reverse the situation when he gets here.

description: Singing and Swinging,

title: McGee Stays With Cardinals
description: WILLIE McGEE will be staying with the St. Louis Cardinals after agreeing yesterday to a $1 million, one-year contract. He had a $500,000 base salary last season and earned a $100,000 bonus for appearing in 90 or more games.

title: Bonds Hurt By Strength In Economy
description: The bond market was hurt yesterday by a report showing continued pockets of strength in the economy and by a Federal Reserve decision to refrain from coming to market to buy Treasury securities for its own account.

title: A Mouse Is Charred In a Dryer?
description: The minds of choreographers are mysterious indeed. What could Bob Eisen have had in mind in ''Memfigen,'' in which a gaunt, old-looking man in swim trunks gasped and groaned his way through lopsided push-ups and belly flops as his dancers watched from the side? And what was Michelle Spencer thinking of as she lingeringly described the charred body of a mouse caught in her laundry dryer? Not the audience, it seemed, then and throughout the dismal ''Split Stream'' program the two presented on Sunday afternoon at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: Bristol-Myers Stock Split
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company will split its stock 2 for 1 and raise its quarterly dividend by one cent a share on a presplit basis. The new dividend of 76 cents a share will be paid Feb. 1 to stock of record Jan. 3. Stockholders will be paid one share for each share held at Feb. 7. The stock will be distributed Feb. 28. The stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $113.375, down $1.875 a share.

title: Put Israel on Notice
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was 1940 and like thousands of couples before them and since, ETHEL STONE, a student at Barnard College, and her beau, SAMUEL J. LeFRAK, would meet in the lobby of Barnard Hall, the building that is the heart of the school. More precisely, they would rendezvous ''on Jake,'' as the brass plaque in the lobby dedicated to Jacob Schiff, the donor of the hall, is known.

title: GT INTERACTIVE STOCK DIVES ON EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The shares of the GT Interactive Software Corporation plunged 37.6 percent yesterday after it warned that delays in products tied to the hot-selling Nintendo 64 would result in fourth-quarter sales of $115 million to $125 million -- below analysts' expectations of $150 million. Shares of GT Interactive, the maker of Mortal Kombat 3 and Doom II games for PC's, dropped $4.75 to $7.875 in Nasdaq trading of 8.2 million shares. Overall sales of PC games have dropped amid a rise in popularity of video game consoles, which attach to television sets. Nintendo said last month that United States sales of its new Nintendo 64 game systems were four times higher than expected.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There's a new spot on the remote control for TONY GUIDA, who has been a television newsman on WCBS-TV and WNBC-TV for 25 years. He will become the lead anchor for WBIS-TV/Channel 31, the new television station owned by the ITT Corporation and Dow Jones & Company. The station was the home of WNYC-TV, the public broadcasting station. Starting in January, WBIS will offer business, sports and entertainment programming 24 hours a day and Mr. Guida will make his debut then. He was on vacation in Europe yesterday. NADINE BROZAN

title: The New Parents Tour Children's Orphanage
description: GUANGZHOU, China  "This is the happiest U.S. government office you'll ever see," said the American consular official despite the fact that several members of his audience were bawling at the top of their lungs.

title: Carlton Communications Posts 20% Leap in Profit
description: Carlton Communications P.L.C. said yesterday that its full-year pretax profit rose nearly 20 percent, in line with expectations, after growth in its video and film production and editing units offset slower television broadcasting operating profit.

title: Fielder Fine-Tunes His Plea
description: Cecil Fielder, the Yankees' prodigious home run hitter, clarified last night the trade demand he delivered to the team last week.

title: South African Constitution Is Approved By High Court
description: A new constitution renouncing the racism of the past and guaranteeing equal rights in South Africa was finally approved today by this nation's highest court, clearing the way for President Nelson Mandela to sign the document into law.

title: BEL-TRONICS TO ACQUIRE CINCINNATI MICROWAVE
description: Cincinnati Microwave Inc., a struggling maker of radar detectors, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Bel-Tronics Ltd. USA, a privately held competitor based in Covington, Ga., for an undisclosed amount of stock. The transaction would result in a publicly traded company in which Bel-Tronics would own a 60 percent stake and Cincinnati Microwave, 40 percent. Last month, Cincinnati Microwave reported its 11th consecutive quarterly loss. Shares of Cincinnati Microwave rose 50 cents, to $1.75, in Nasdaq trading. Cincinnati Microwave currently has a market value of about $30 million. The company had revenues of $79.3 million last year.

description: AIRFRAME

title: Milton Sapirstein, 81, Professor And Researcher in Psychiatry
description: Milton R. Sapirstein, an emeritus clinical professor of psychiatry who was associated with Mount Sinai Medical Center for nearly five decades, died last Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital North. He lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and would have turned 82 on Saturday.

title: N.F.L. Needs Quick Action In Drug Bans
description: TWO weeks ago tomorrow, the Friday before the Cowboys were to lose at Giants Stadium, the word was on the street. And three days before the Cowboys were to dominate the Redskins on Thanksgiving, the word was in headlines in The Fort Worth Star-Telegram: Leon Lett had tested positive for drugs.

title: The Holocaust Children Who Did Not Grow Up
description: It might be a large family album or a school yearbook: snapshots of children, 2,500 of them, in sailor suits and holiday frocks, posing at the beach, in backyards and on playgrounds with parents, brothers and sisters and chums. Clearly, they do not know what awaits them.

title: There Are Good Reasons For a Wedding At the Airport
description: The reasons Delta Air Lines and Continental Airlines, which are discussing a possible merger, might make a good fit are readily apparent. Their route networks, for example, would mesh well.

title: People
description: * Judy Hu, senior vice president and strategic planning director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Troy, Mich., a unit of MacManus Group, left to join a client, the North American operations of the General Motors Corp., Warren, Mich., in the new position of director for advertising resources management.

title: U.N. LEADER HALTS BID FOR NEW TERM BUT DOES NOT QUIT
description: Moving a step closer to withdrawing from the race for Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali said today that he was suspending his candidacy for re-election ''for the time being'' but not dropping out completely.

title: No Headline
description: ''Everyone understands the nature of the game. The West is being moved out and China is taking over.''

title: The Makings of a Sitcom
description: Handel's ''Agrippina'' is losing the rarity status it had in 1985, when Newell Jenkins presented a concert reading at one of his Clarion Concerts. The work has since had several European stagings, a Washington Opera production and performances at the Mannes College of Music, where the Oxford Early Opera gave a modern-dress version two years ago. Now Mannes's own period-instrument ensemble, the Mannes Camerata, is presenting ''Agrippina'' at the Cloister Theater at Riverside Church through Friday.

title: As Tradition Demands, the Berwick (Pa.) Bulldogs Keep Winning
description: The state championship game is this week, and people are leaving lucky pennies on the Catman's grave.

title: Bass Sees Profit Jump; Plans to Add 7,000 Jobs
description: Bass P.L.C., the British brewer and hotel company, said yesterday that it had a 12 percent increase in pretax profit in the year that ended on Sept. 30. The pretax profit of $:671 million ($1.1 billion) was up from $:599 million a year earlier. Sales for the year rose 12.5 percent, to $:5.11 billion.

title: Granada Sells George V To Saudi Prince
description: Granada Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold the Hotel George V in Paris to Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia for $:104 million ($171 million), the second sale from the Exclusive portfolio that Granada acquired last January. The Hotel George V posted an operating loss of $:200,000 in the year ended Jan. 31

title: Japanese Ex-Aide Is Accused Of Taking $530,000 in Bribes
description: In a move that could bolster support for Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's reforms, the police today arrested a former Deputy Health Minister suspected of taking about $530,000 in bribes.

title: Serbia Vows Not to Crush Protests, U.S. Says
description: Serbia's Foreign Minister says his Government will not use force to repress anti-government protests, the State Department said today.

description: Baseball

title: Natural Gas Prices Increase For Second Consecutive Day
description: Natural gas prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday for the second consecutive session amid expectations that a report would show inventories fell last week just as more cold weather is set to raise demand.

title: Recital Is Canceled
description: The pianist Helene Grimaud has postponed her all-Brahms recital scheduled for Saturday at Alice Tully Hall because of illness. The new date is Feb. 15, and tickets for this week will be honored on that date. For information or refunds: (212) 721-6500.

title: From Bad to Worse: Going Is Slow as Repairs Begin on the Gowanus
description: In the five years that he has been commuting on the Gowanus Expressway, John Jennings has always allowed an extra half-hour for the congestion on what some consider the worst road in America. Yesterday, he needed closer to an hour.

title: Pentagon Says Gulf War Data Seem to Be Lost
description: Military logs for an eight-day period in which thousands of American troops might have been exposed to nerve gas and other Iraqi chemical weapons shortly after the Persian Gulf war in 1991 appear to have been removed or lost and cannot be located despite an exhaustive search, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Schuss and Crash: Injured Street Out for Season
description: Picabo Street, the spirited and talented American skier who has won the women's World Cup downhill overall title the last two years, fell during a training run today and tore ligaments in her left knee. She will be out of racing for the rest of the 1996-97 season.

title: Samuel Brownstein, 87, Guide Through S.A.T. Maze, Dies
description: Samuel C. Brownstein, who liked teaching so much that he began teaching when he was in grade school and continued long after he retired as a teacher, died on Monday at the home of his daughter in Waban, Mass. He was 87 and best known as the man who guided millions of high school seniors through the treacherous terrain of the Scholastic Aptitude Test as the co-author of ''Barron's How to Prepare for the S.A.T.''

title: Traffic Sails in New Lanes
description: The New Jersey Turnpike's new high occupancy vehicle lanes were a grand success during their first morning rush yesterday, officials said. Lynn Fleeger, a spokeswoman for the Turnpike Authority, said 1,464 cars, vans and buses -- more than the agency had projected -- used the lane between 6 and 9 A.M. They accounted for more than 5 percent of the overall traffic between Woodbridge and Newark. About a third of the users were buses.

title: Agency, After an Outcry, Changes Citizenship Plan
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service announced a change in procedures for background checks today after Republican accusations that it had allowed convicted criminals to become citizens.

title: Man Jailed After Saying on TV That He Had Sex With Girl, 14
description: A New Hampshire man who admitted on the ''Sally Jessy Raphael'' talk show that he fathered a child with a 14-year-old girl was charged with statutory rape yesterday after the police in Dover, N.H., viewed a videotape of the program.

title: 2 Crime Busters for New Orleans
description: For the last two years, New York City officials from the Mayor on down have proclaimed that their crime-fighting strategy is the solution to runaway big-city homicide rates.

description: Advertisers including United Airlines and Volvo Cars of North America were among those singled out for criticism yesterday when the Center for Science in the Public Interest presented its 12th annual Harlan Page Hubbard Lemon Awards.

title: Singapore Airlines Is Looking at Indonesia
description: Singapore Airlines Ltd. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy a stake in P.T. Sempati Airlines, one of Indonesia's two international carriers. ''Discussions have taken place with Sempati on an equity-based relationship, and these discussions are continuing,'' a Singapore Airlines spokesman said in a statement.

title: Something to Whine About
description: Adam Duritz got overexcited when Counting Crows played its current single, ''Angels of the Silences,'' as the second song of its set at the Beacon Theater on Monday night. He jumped, then fell backward as he landed, spraining his right knee. ''That was stupid,'' he said. For the rest of the concert, he hobbled around the stage or sat and sang; midway through, he went offstage to have his leg taped.

title: Figurines Gain Diversity
description: In the beginning, the holi day figurines 16 almost life-size motorized carolers, skaters and sledders cavorting in turn-of-the-century costume in front of the Christmas tree in Monument Square -- all were white.

title: Silence Heals, Doctors Tell Raspy Clinton
description: President Clinton's doctors today ordered Mr. Clinton not to talk for three or four days, to rest his famously overworked vocal cords in hopes of recovering his voice.

title: AXEL SPRINGER TO BUY STAKE IN AMERICA ONLINE UNIT
description: America Online Inc. said yesterday that the German newspaper publisher Axel Springer Verlag A.G. will acquire a 10 percent stake in AOL Germany for an undisclosed amount. AOL Germany is a unit of AOL Europe, a partnership between America Online and the German media company Bertelsmann A.G. In exchange for the stock, AOL Europe will gain access to some of the 40 newspapers and magazines that Springer publishes. Springer will also provide content and market support for the Internet service. America Online, based in Dulles, Va., said AOL Europe had more than 300,000 subscribers and would expand soon to Austria, Switzerland and Sweden. Shares of America Online rose $2.625, or 7 percent, to $40.125.

description: The Nets would not allow the Knicks to make them part of their 12-step program to recapture their self-esteem.

title: Escapees From Jets' Elba Leave Lewis Puzzled
description: With remarkable candor, Mo Lewis wondered aloud today why players who leave the Jets blossom elsewhere while those who stay, as he put it, ''burn themselves out trying to play hard and come up with the short end of the stick.''

title: Mutual Mistrust and Caution On Revising an Inflation Index
description: Trying to determine whether it is politically realistic to use a proposed change in the way the Government measures inflation to help erase the deficit, Republicans and Democrats tried today to tease out assurances of bipartisan cooperation on an issue that holds clear perils for both sides.

description: Faced with high operating costs and rising competition from other electricity sources, the owners of a Connecticut nuclear power plant with one of the best longterm performance records in the nuclear industry decided yesterday to shut it down permanently.

title: Troops Join Police Patrols After Deadly Train Blast : Paris Fears New Terror Attacks
description: PARIS  As the government deployed nearly 2,000 troops Wednesday to prevent further terrorist attacks, indications emerged that Algerian Islamic fundamentalists whose presence in the country had already been suspected set off the deadly bomb on a suburban train the day before.

title: Crew Wants National Standards To Be Used in New York Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew proposed yesterday that New York City adopt national education standards that would change what schoolchildren are expected to learn and how their achievements would be measured.

title: Stock Option Trading High
description: Trading in stock options this year has hit a record high, an industry trade group reported yesterday. The Options Industry Council said that through November, 180,693,189 options contracts had been traded on United States exchanges. With a month of trading left in the year, the total tops the annual record of 174,380,236 contracts set in 1995. A stock option is the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell 100 shares of a stock at a predetermined price on or before a fixed date.

title: Who Copied Whom? Ruling Implies Neither
description: In the latest round of a legal battle that has become something of a curiosity in the entertainment world, a Federal Court judge has denied a claim by Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber that Ray Repp, an obscure American composer of liturgical music, stole a song from his 1969 musical, ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat.''

That was clear on Tuesday night when the company, now in its 25th year under the direction of Tina Ramirez, opened a two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater. Two new productions showed the troupe's increased choreographic sophistication, and the entire evening revealed that the dancers had acquired fine stage presences.

title: Facing Cuts, Head of Police Resigns Post
description: Angered by lawmakers who wanted to cut his pay and pension benefits, the Suffolk County Police Commissioner announced late Tuesday that he would retire at the end of the year.

description: The chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc., one of the nation's largest cable television operators, has fired the first salvo in what could become a battle with cable programmers.

title: 2 Women and Infant, Held 3 Days by Kidnappers, Are Freed
description: Two Brooklyn sisters and a 6-week-old boy were freed late Tuesday after being held hostage for three days in an attempt to collect a $20,000 debt from the women's brother, the police said.

title: U.S. Charges Filed in Killing Of Policeman
description: Two men accused of being members of a violent robbery gang known as the Park Avenue Boys have been indicted on Federal charges in the March killing of a Bronx police officer, a case that led to a political showdown over whether the gunman should face the death penalty.

title: The Garden and Radio City are squaring off over the market for Christmas musicals.
description: CAN the Rockettes pass the Scrooge test? The battle for Christmas is intensifying at two legendary Manhattan showcases, Madison Square Garden and the Radio City Music Hall. The Garden is mounting a new $4 million advertising and marketing campaign for its three-year-old holiday musical, ''A Christmas Carol,'' escalating its challenge to the lucrative 63-year-old Christmas spectacular at Radio City.

title: De La Hoya-Whitaker in Works

But first, each must win fights next month against different opponents, Whitaker's promoter, DINO DUVA, said yesterday. Then they will meet in Las Vegas, Nev., in May for Whitaker's 147-pound World Boxing Council belt.

title: Atlanta Symphony Settles After a 10-Week Strike
description: After a strike lasting just over 10 weeks, the musicians and management of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra have agreed on a labor contract that guarantees the players an 8 percent salary increase over four years and gives them a greater say in questions of tenure review, seating and tour planning.

title: VIACOM BUYS 50 PERCENT STAKE IN UPN NETWORK
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it had exercised its option to buy a 50 percent stake in the United Paramount Network from BHC Communications Inc. for about $160 million. The price represents half the $320 million or so that BHC has invested in the last two to three years in the network, known as UPN. BHC is 76 percent owned by Chris-Craft Industries. UPN will give Viacom, based in New York, another outlet for its programs. UPN said its 152 affiliate stations reach about 92 percent of United States households. Viacom will jointly own and operate UPN with BHC when the deal is completed on Jan. 15. UPN lost $129.3 million in 1995 and $95.8 million in the first nine months of this year. BHC, based in New York, has eight television stations.

description: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday sued the Colgate-Palmolive Company and its agency, Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, contending that they deliberately copied a television commercial for Crest toothpaste that P.& G. has run since 1989.

description: The Labor Minister said today that the passenger-service staff of Canadian Airlines International Ltd. would be forced to vote on the company's proposed rescue plan, which is opposed by their union.

description: The world's major nations have increasingly subordinated human rights in foreign policy, overlooking abuses to promote trade or to reflect political calculations, Human Rights Watch said today in an annual report.
