title: BRE-X IS CLOSE TO SELLING GOLD STAKE TO BARRICK
description: Bre-X Minerals Ltd. said yesterday that it was close to an agreement to sell a 75 percent stake in its Indonesian gold property to the Barrick Gold Corporation.. Negotiations could be completed as early as next week, Bre-X said. An agreement would give Bre-X as much as $4.35 billion and give Barrick, North America's largest gold-mining company, a majority stake in the Busang deposit on Borneo, which Bre-X said contains 57 million ounces of gold. Placer Dome and the Teck Corporation, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and the Denver-based Newmont Gold Corporation have also said they were interested in bidding on the gold field. Analysts said Barrick would probably be allowed to purchase the 75 percent stake.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the International Briefs column of Business Day on Tuesday about a planned sale of Mercury Bank A.G. of Switzerland to Safra Republic Holdings S.A. misidentified the Safra unit involved. It is Republic National Bank of New York (Suisse) S.A., a Swiss-based private-client bank, not Republic National Bank of New York, a unit based in the United States.

title: Mastercard's 'Smart Card' Builds Support
description: Seven financial giants, including Wells Fargo, Chase Manhattan and Dean Witter, Discover, have agreed to market the Mondex electronic-cash product in the United States.

title: Thomas Chosen Top Metro Player
description: JEFF THOMAS of Plainfield West Golf Club in New Jersey was awarded the Metropolitan Golf Association's player of the year award at the association's annual meeting and banquet last night at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.

title: How About Some Coffee Tables With Your Tomes?
description: THAT master of brainstorms, Kramer, from the television show ''Seinfeld,'' once thought up an ingenious way to simplify the custom of displaying lavish picture books on coffee tables. He hit on an idea with legs: making a coffeetable book about coffee tables (itself a good idea) and equipping the book with legs of its own. And on the show, at least, he got a publisher.

title: An equipment delay hurts Northern Telecom's stock and reinforces a reputation to live down.
description: WHEN Sprint Spectrum announced on Tuesday that it would not meet its target for introducing advanced wireless voice and data services around the country, the stock of its owners, the Sprint Corporation and three large cable television companies, took only a glancing blow.

title: Thomson's Bidder Is Stunned; Daewoo Registers 'Outrage' : France Backs Out Of Deal to Rescue Electronics Giant
description: PARIS  In a stunning about-face, France abruptly canceled on Wednesday the planned sale of Thomson SA, the state-owned electronics company, whose privatization has been the centerpiece of President Jacques Chirac's ambitious plan to restructure the French defense industry.

title: Doctor Charged With Murdering Cancer Patient
description: A doctor who injected a terminally ill cancer patient with a lethal dose of drugs has been charged with first-degree murder. He could face the death penalty if a jury decides he intentionally killed the man to end his suffering.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three well-known Washington personages, ROBERT B. REICH, the Secretary of Labor; KWEISI MFUME, the president and chief executive of the N.A.A.C.P., and TED KOPPEL, the anchor of ''Nightline'' on ABC-TV, were honored at a luncheon at the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown yesterday. They had been singled out by Women of Washington, an 1,100- member networking organization, for their support of women's issues.

title: Loan Debtor Liquidated By Japanese Court
description: The Osaka District Court announced yesterday that it had liquidated a real estate development company that borrowed more than 26.6 billion yen ($235 million) from Japan's insolvent housing lenders, according to Teikoku Data Bank, a financial research company.

title: Service Mourns Jet Crash's Missing
description: Out on the great green lawn of Pinelawn Memorial Park here today, brisk winds stung the faces of those who had come to mourn 15 victims lost in the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800. Although 230 people died in all, these 15 have never been found, and the December air served as a cold reminder of the time that had passed since that fateful muggy night in July.

title: At a Coffee Table, Stirring Thought
description: DON'T judge a book by its cover, the saying goes. But in this season of gift-giving -- when time is short, lists are long and publishers unleash an avalanche of gift books in alluring jackets -- superficial attractions count. (Perhaps that's why style books are popular. They are the hand-held equivalent of a Calgon bath.)

title: A Plea in Baby's Death
description: A 30-year-old Atlantic City man who had shaken his 3-month-old son to stop him from crying pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he murdered the baby, prosecutors said.

title: A Sterile NATO Quarrel
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is bogged down in a sterile squabble between the United States and France over which nation will designate future commanders for the alliance's Southern Command, based in Naples. Washington is right to insist that an American admiral hold this job, which includes control over the United States Sixth Fleet. But the Clinton Administration should move quickly to break the impasse by supporting a French officer for a comparably high-level position.

title: Trees Sprouting Coats and Hats
description: DIG out the bed. Extricate the Exercycle. Buying a freestanding coat tree before holiday visitors arrive is a lot less expensive than having an architect draw up plans for new closets.

title: New Lift Ride Eases Safety Concerns on Slopes
description: The importance of a smooth and worry-free lift ride tends to be overlooked by skiers and snowboarders who have never known the grind of boot-hacking their way up a slope. But dependable lifts at ski areas are like subways to a city: When they run smoothly, no one notices. When something goes radically wrong, people don't forget.

title: Violence Disrupts Prison
description: Racial gang violence is the latest problem at the Hudson County Correctional Facility, where a partial lockdown has been imposed until tensions cool. Until then, officials said yesterday, inmates will be allowed out of their cells only for meals and showers. An inmate was stabbed and three others were injured in a melee Sunday between members of the Latin Kings, a Hispanic gang and the Five Percenters, a black gang, said Michele Dupey, a spokeswoman for the county. The week before, another inmate was stabbed and four others were hurt in a gang fight, she said.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN MAY SEEK BUYER FOR MASTERCRAFT
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that it was considering selling its Mastercraft Group, which makes upholstery fabric. The recent modernization of Mastercraft's looms, Collins said, should help the unit grow and keep costs low. Mastercraft accounted for $213.5 million of Collins & Aikman's $1.07 billion in sales in the nine months ended on Oct. 26. Collins, based in Charlotte, N.C., said the sale of the unit, based in Spindale, N.C., would let it focus on automotive textiles and plastic-trim products.

title: Clinton Still Studying Choices For National Security Team
description: After weeks of deliberations on what the White House termed President Clinton's ''first and most urgent task'' after re-election, the President is still wrestling with the choices for his national security team in a process that has left his own Government on edge and even drawn the attention of foreign capitals.

title: Cowboys Sign Childress for Line
description: The Dallas Cowboys signed a five-time Pro Bowl tackle, RAY CHILDRESS, yesterday to shore up their defensive line following the drug suspension of LEON LETT.

title: Exports Help German Economy, But Growth Eased in 3d Quarter
description: Soaring exports fueled German economic growth in the third quarter, the Government said today, although the expansion slowed from the second quarter.

title: Judge Throws Out Changes In Rules for Credit Unions
description: A Federal judge today struck down new Federal rules designed to make it easier for credit unions to expand .

title: Mr. Carville Calms Down
description: President Clinton must have been embarrassed by his press secretary's statement that the President couldn't get James Carville to pipe down. So yesterday Mr. Carville did his old boss a favor and began backing away from his plan to launch an advertising campaign against Kenneth Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Norwegian Oil Concern to Buy Kuwaiti Unit for $1.23 Billion
description: Saga Petroleum A.S., moving to raise its daily oil production about 36 percent, said today that it had agreed to acquire Santa Fe Exploration (U.K) Ltd. for $1.23 billion from the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation.

title: Rejection Of 'Star Wars' Not Political, Inquiry Says
description: An independent panel of experts today rebutted Republican charges that the nation's intelligence agencies deliberately played down the nuclear threat to the United States.

title: Malls and Stores Find New Outlets In Cyberspace
description: WITH the busiest shopping weekend of the year receding into memory, so, too, perhaps, is the romantic notion that holiday shopping is a wholly magical event. But these days the weary consumer can take solace in a new alternative to crowded department stores and the persistent shortage of parking spaces: ''cybershopping'' on the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday, with an article about a housing boom in Nevada that has led to a sharp increase in litigation against contractors, misspelled the given name of a man shown inspecting damage to a residential development and misstated his occupation. He is Steven Doze, not Seven, a construction consultant, not a lawyer.

title: One Hand Protects, Another Destroys
description: Hunting for pheasant on a wild bluff above the Columbia River early last month , John Hough says he turned to face an approaching helicopter and caught a lungfull of chemical spray. Mr. Hough became dizzy and nauseated, he said, his throat and chest burning.

title: Ford Reports Vehicle Sales Dropped 2.2% in November
description: The Ford Motor Company reported today that its sales fell 2.2 percent in November, as the final tally of monthly auto sales showed that American companies had lost ground to Japanese and European competitors.

title: BAXTER IN STOCK SWAP FOR RESEARCH MEDICAL
description: Baxter International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Research Medical Inc. in a stock swap valued at $236 million, or $23.50 a share, to expand into products for minimally invasive heart surgery. The acquisition steps up Baxter's efforts to concentrate on late-stage cardiovascular disease. Research Medical is one of the nation's largest makers of cannulae, or tubes used to transfer a patient's blood to a heart-lung machine during open-heart surgery, and cardioplegia products, used to limit damage to heart muscle. Shares of Research Medical rose $2.766, to $22.766, in Nasdaq trading. Separately, Baxter said it expected to close the previously announced purchase of Immuno International A.G. in two to six weeks.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a recent trip to the Dominican Republic by Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, misstated the title of Sal F. Albanese, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for mayor. He is a City Councilman, not a State Assemblyman.

title: Teen-Ager Charged In L.I. Double Killing
description: A teen-ager has been charged in the bludgeoning death of his father and his father's girlfriend after a fight spurred by the youth's refusal to run an errand, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: China Already Entrenched As a Hong Kong Capitalist
description: A few years ago, a mottled brown granite office building in the central business district here changed hands. Along with the $493.5 million sales price paid by the new owners -- an assemblage of mainland Chinese investors -- came a tidy $17.8 million sales commission to an unknown real estate company called Sunshine Properties.

title: INSIDE
description: South African Milestone

title: From a Lawmakers' Group, An Old Fund-Raising Lesson
description: The National Foundation for Women Legislators has a membership of fast-rising female politicians and a high-minded mission: ''to provide strategic resources for women to be strong and effective state legislators.''

description: $11.1 Million for a Sargent

title: A 'Technical' Ruse
description: The Boskin Commission's conclusion that the Government has been overstating the inflation rate by 1.1 percent raises some fundamental questions about the purpose of cost-of-living adjustments in benefit programs.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

With variations on familiar carols, rediscovered obscurities and new seasonal tunes, the holidays nurture creativity mixed with calculation; by now, there is hardly a niche left unsung. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times sift through some of this year's more notable offerings. (Compact disks range in price from $14.95 to $16.95.)

title: Babrak Karmal, Afghanistan's Ex-President, Dies at 67
description: Babrak Karmal, the Soviet-backed Communist who led Afghanistan's Government from from 1979 until he resigned in 1986, died on Sunday at the Kremlin hospital in Moscow, the Interfax news agency in Moscow reported yesterday. He was 67 and had spent most of his time after he stepped down living quietly in Russia, under Soviet pressure.

title: Yankees Are All Business With Leyritz and Fielder
description: On a day Cecil Fielder continued squawking about his uncertain future with the Yankees, Jim Leyritz discovered that he no longer has a future with the Yankees.

description: 'Art/Language'

title: California Offers Swap for Stand of Redwoods
description: The Federal Government and the State of California today offered oil and gas fields, timberland and other property worth at least $380 million in return for a grove of Northern California redwoods that is the largest old-growth forest of its kind left in private hands.

title: A Bipartisan Voice: William Sebastian Cohen
description: The country first noticed William S. Cohen in July 1974, when he announced that he would vote to recommend the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon. ''By acts or acquiescence,'' the freshman House Republican declared, President Nixon ''allowed the rule of law and the Constitution to slip under the boot of indifference and arrogance and abuse.''

title: Swaying With Schumann and Prokofiev
description: It is not easy to throw yourself into, say, Bach, but both Schumann and Prokofiev offer a musician the pleasures of exuberant identification, of getting mixed up with the notes and producing something that sways or staggers according to spontaneous personal impulse. That could be one answer to the riddle of Yefim Bronfman's pairing of these composers in his current series at Alice Tully Hall. Another could be just that he loves playing them.

title: Poppe Tyson Pulls Stock Offering
description: The Poppe Tyson unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, which specializes in interactive communications, said yesterday that it had postponed an initial public offering of stock because of what it said were ''unfavorable market conditions.''

title: Why the Brady Law Is Constitutional
description: This week, the Supreme Court heard arguments that the Brady law violates states' rights. The law imposes a five-day waiting period on handgun purchases to allow checks of criminal records. While most law enforcement organizations support the law, some county sheriffs oppose a provision that requires them to do the background checks. They object, as Justice Antonin Scalia puts it, that the Brady law ''makes the states dance like marionettes on the fingers of the Federal Government.''

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Two Deaths

title: The King Recovers From Defeat
description: IT turned out that even for King Richard of North Carolina, who campaigned in his familiar feather-dominated cowboy hat and snakeskin boots and with stump speeches of about five minutes in duration, political office was not a divine right.

title: Man Reports Murder of Wife and Mother-in-Law and Then Kills Himself
description: A man who called 911 at 10:24 A.M. yesterday from Staten Island got right to the point: he had killed his wife and mother-in-law in his home and was on his way to Great Kills Park to end his life.

title: RJR NABISCO EXPECTS 'BARN BURNER' OF A FOURTH QUARTER
description: The chief executive of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, Steven Goldstone, said yesterday that the company's fourth quarter was going to be ''a barn burner,'' confirming speculation that the financial picture of the company was looking up. At a meeting of Boston-area chief executives, Mr. Goldstone said that RJR had a very good year so far, but that the fourth quarter was going to be even better.

title: Pope's Talk With Anglican Leader Appears to Stall
description: As they prayed together this evening in a small chapel on one of Rome's hills, Pope John Paul II and the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, head of the world's Anglican community, tried hard to cast a harmonious glow over one of the most contentious dialogues in the Christian world.

title: A Compromise On Encryption Exports Seems To Unravel
description: A compromise between the computer industry and the Clinton Administration that would relax export controls for data-scrambling technology is in danger of collapsing as a growing number of American companies are rejecting it.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Currents column in The Home Section yesterday misstated the dates for the show and sale of gold and silver jewelry at the American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street. It began on Thursday and will continue through Sunday. Hours will be 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. today and to 6 P.M. on Saturday and Sunday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A judge yesterday denied WOODY ALLEN'S request to order MIA FARROW to grant him more access to two of their children.

title: Karamazovs, Yes, Brothers, No
description: They sing. They dance. They perform Bach minuets while juggling flashlights.

title: New Deals Announced At Interpublic
description: Units of the Interpublic Group of Companies announced yesterday that they had made acquisitions in public relations and interactive marketing and formed a media services agency in Europe.

title: National Semiconductor Surges on Profit Report
description: A quarter after reporting a $207.6 million loss, the National Semiconductor Corporation returned to profitability today, reporting earnings that were a few cents above Wall Street analysts' estimates.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Pallbearer

title: Democratic Challengers Meet in Forum to Speak Against Giuliani
description: In an early preview of next year's mayoral race, four Democrats seeking to challenge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared together for the first time in the campaign last night, portraying the incumbent as a contentious and polarizing city executive and repeatedly asserting that Mr. Giuliani could be defeated.

title: Bunker's Contents Described
description: The Pentagon said today that the nerve gas sarin and other chemical weapons had definitely been stored at an Iraqi ammunition depot that was destroyed by American troops in March 1991, an event that may have exposed thousands of soldiers to a cloud of the deadly chemicals.

title: Serene Carols to Upbeat Rap: Pop CD's for the Season -- Vanessa Williams
description: THE annual flurry of holiday albums has turned into a blizzard, as performers aim to provide something for every mood: festive and frazzled, sweet and skeptical, scattered and calm, cozy and forlorn. With variations on familiar carols, rediscovered obscurities and new seasonal tunes, the holidays nurture creativity mixed with calculation; by now, there is hardly a niche left unsung. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times sift through some of this year's more notable offerings. (Compact disks range in price from $14.95 to $16.95.)

title: C.I.A. Chief Disciplines Official for Disclosure
description: In one of his last acts as Director of Central Intelligence, John M. Deutch today revoked the security clearance of a senior State Department official who revealed a dark secret of the Central Intelligence Agency to a member of Congress, who then told the world about it.

title: It Takes More Than Standards
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's proposal for new and tougher standards for New York City's schools is sound. The new approach would discard rote learning techniques and emphasize logic and analysis. It also calls for systemwide performance standards that would bring order to the instructional process -- and allow easy comparison among schools and districts. But after seven chancellors in 12 years, each of whom junked his predecessor's ideas, principals and teachers have become immune to new initiatives. Curriculum proposals have been collecting dust in offices all over the city. Dr. Crew will need to work hard to save his challenging ideas from the same fate.

title: Taiwan, Snubbed by South Africa, Ends Aid and Recalls Envoy
description: Taiwan said today that it was canceling all aid to South Africa, suspending most treaties and recalling its ambassador. The move, announced by Taiwan's Foreign Minister, John Chang, follows South Africa's decision to transfer diplomatic relations from Taipei to Beijing in 1997.

title: Airline Set To Pull Plug On Signs After Suit
description: Turn off the lights; the neon's over pending appeal, anyway.

title: New Publisher at Boston Globe
description: William O. Taylor will step down as publisher of The Boston Globe in April, and his place will be taken by his younger cousin, Benjamin B. Taylor, the newspaper announced yesterday.

title: Caray Back for 53d Season
description: The Hall of Famer HARRY CARAY will return for his 53d season behind the microphone doing Chicago Cubs play-by-play. Caray will begin his 15th year with the Cubs on WGN-TV and WGN-AM radio next season, the stations said yesterday. (AP)

title: Of a Woman's Body as Both Subject and Object
description: Using her nude body as ''visual territory,'' the performance artist Carolee Schneemann has for some 30 years danced on the edge of the mainstream art world, producing bizarre, provocative imagery that runs a gamut of corporeal experience.

title: Moderation on the Skids: Big and Bad Are Back
description: IN the no-nonsense 90's, we were all supposed to grow up, get sensible and atone for the excesses of the 80's. And we did. For a while. Now six years of moderation have taken their toll. We're tired of low-fat foods. We're sick of fish and bored with frozen yogurt. Aren't we entitled to time off from good behavior?

title: John Vassall, 71, Spy at Heart Of Scandal That Shook Britain
description: John Vassall, the high-living, low-level British Admiralty clerk whose exposure as a Soviet spy in 1962 created the first of the sex scandals that helped end the political career of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, died in London on Nov. 18, his lawyer said yesterday. He was 71.

title: Newmont in $2 Billion Bid for Santa Fe Gold
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation announced an unsolicited bid yesterday of $2 billion in stock for the Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corporation, a move that could set off a bidding war in the rapidly consolidating mining industry as other companies seek to enter the fray.

title: Restaurants
description: If someone had asked you, 20 years ago, to stake your fortune on future tastes, could you possibly have imagined that Americans would develop a passion for raw fish in seaweed? Asked to choose between the austerity of Japanese cuisine and the robust cooking of Korea, I would have bet on Korea. But sushi is now sold in supermarkets, while Korean cooking remains a mystery to most of America. Mirezi (it is pronounced mee-ray-ZHEE) may change that.

title: Inaugural Tribute to King
description: President Clinton's second inauguration, although smaller and briefer than the affair four years ago, will reflect the fact that it coincides with Martin Luther King Day by featuring gospel music and a performance by a daughter of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the White House said today.

title: Experienced Player Who Shuns Spotlight: Anthony Lake
description: In his four years as President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake has shunned the public spotlight as few of his predecessors have, shaping the Administration's foreign policy with discretion, if not secrecy. Today Mr. Clinton nominated him as Director of Central Intelligence, a job in which discretion is a premium and in which the intellectual rigor ascribed to him will be sorely tested.

title: After Saudi Base Bombing, A Split Over Fixing Blame
description: On the morning of June 25, the final day of his year's duty in Saudi Arabia as commander of the Air Force fighters enforcing the no-flight zone over southern Iraq, Brig. Gen. Terryl J. Schwalier, a rising young star in the military hierarchy, sat down to write his end-of-tour report.

title: The N.A.S.D. expels Stratton Oakmont, ordering repayment
description: STRATTON OAKMONT, R.I.P.?

title: Injury to Street Hurts Struggling U.S. Team
description: Picabo Street, the two-time World Cup downhill racer who attacks a ski slope like a bird after prey, is relegated to a hotel bed now.

title: Widows Sue Bullet Maker
description: Two of the women widowed when a former postal worker killed four men at the Montclair Post Office in March 1995 are suing the companies that made and sold the Black Talon hollow-point bullets used by the killer, The Associated Press reported. The same bullets were used by Colin Ferguson when he killed six people and wounded 19 aboard a Long Island Rail Road train in 1993. A Federal judge in New York dismissed a suit against the manufacturer of the bullets, Winchester Ammunition, and its parent company, the Olin Corporation. In 1993, Winchester said it would sell the bullets only to law enforcement agencies.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another member of a Presidential family, SUSAN EISENHOWER, acted more the gracious hostess than the honored guest at a luncheon yesterday given by the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute. The occasion was the publication by Farrar, Straus & Giroux of her book, ''Mrs. Ike,'' a memoir about her grandmother Mamie Eisenhower.

title: AMERICA ONLINE SWITCHES ON FEE FOR ITS FLAT-RATE PLAN
description: America Online Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to obtain customers' consent before switching them to its new flat-rate plan. The agreement resulted from negotiations with 19 states and will be adopted nationwide. The Internet service provider will also give retroactive refunds to all customers who ask to switch back to their old plan before April 10. America Online, which is based in Dulles, Va., received a complaint letter from 17 state attorneys general on Nov. 18 after it said it would automatically move subscribers on Dec. 1 to its new flat fee of $19.95 a month. The switch would occur unless customers chose another pricing option.

title: Environmental Group Rates L.I. Sound Cleanup Efforts
description: In the regional effort to clean up Long Island Sound, Connecticut is doing the most, while Long Island communities are lagging, an environmental group said today. The efforts in Westchester County and New York City ranked in the middle.

title: Lansbury as Santa's Neglected, Determined Wife
description: Anyone who thought for a minute that the end of the 12-year run of ''Murder, She Wrote'' on CBS was a cue for Angela Lansbury to slip quietly into well-heeled retirement just doesn't know Miss Lansbury. With more than 50 years of performing behind her, on stage, screen and television, the actress is back, exuding more energy and charm than ever in ''Mrs. Santa Claus'' on Sunday.

description: With charm and movie star good looks, George I. Norman Jr., a millionaire financier, played among the big names of Hollywood, keeping Rocky Mountain society agog in the era of bell-bottoms and turtlenecks.

description: Family Workshop

description: Nicole Eisenman

description: To the Editor:

title: Bomb Suspect to Use Lawyer at 2d Trial
description: This time, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef will let a real lawyer do the lawyering.

title: 2 Michael Jordans and a dash of Spike Lee could add up to a successful public service campaign.
description: IF a humorous new television commercial for the United Negro College Fund were a feature film, it might be titled ''Here Comes Mr. Jordan -- and Mr. Jordan'' or ''The Files on Michael Jordan'' or even ''The Two Mr. Jordans.''

title: The Message From Hawaii
description: This week's historic decision by a trial judge in Hawaii paving the way for that state's recognition of same-sex marriages is a breakthrough for fairness. It obviously does not settle the heated national debate over same-sex marriages. But those who have not yet closed their minds on the issue owe it to themselves to read Circuit Judge Kevin Chang's calm dissection of some of the more popular arguments against awarding homosexuals the important benefits that flow from civil marriages.

title: Distinctive Views of Dancers
description: Generalizations about the dance world are guaranteed to drop by the wayside tomorrow and Sunday afternoon when five marvelously offbeat dance films from Canada, Russia and the United States will be screened at the Walter Reade Theater. The Film Society of Lincoln Center has joined forces with the 40-year-old Dance Films Association for the first time to present the association's annual Dance on Camera Festival.

title: Court Rules New York City May Cancel Agency's Welfare Contracts
description: Reversing a lower court ruling, a Federal appeals court yesterday cleared the way for New York City to cancel a series of city contracts with a nonprofit agency that is at the heart of a Federal investigation into the city's procurement process.

title: Heroes on Skis, Courageous and Cold
description: The inspiring documentary ''Fire on the Mountain'' describes the bracing exploits of the 10th Mountain Division of the United States Army, an elite ski corps that came into being just before the United States entered World War II. The hearty outdoorsmen recruited for this mission proved to be lifelong athletes, looking fit and healthy in their 70's and 80's as they reminisce about their adventures, wartime and otherwise. As this film by Beth Gage and George Gage makes clear, they have certainly left their mark.

title: How Controls Are Applied
description: Rent control applies to apartments in buildings constructed before Feb. 1, 1947, in which the tenant or an authorized successor has been in continuous occupancy since before June 30, 1971 -- the date when vacancy decontrol for rent-controlled apartments took effect.

title: Serene Carols to Upbeat Rap: Pop CD's for the Season -- Various Artists
description: THE annual flurry of holiday albums has turned into a blizzard, as performers aim to provide something for every mood: festive and frazzled, sweet and skeptical, scattered and calm, cozy and forlorn. With variations on familiar carols, rediscovered obscurities and new seasonal tunes, the holidays nurture creativity mixed with calculation; by now, there is hardly a niche left unsung. Below, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times sift through some of this year's more notable offerings. (Compact disks range in price from $14.95 to $16.95.)

title: Giants Are Still Feeling Toomer's Injury Exit
description: Speed kills, or at the very least it scares the daylights out of people. That is why Amani Toomer may have been the Giants' best weapon. On punt returns, some of his runs were so powerful, so dramatic and so fast that players on opposing teams knew there would be little room for error.

title: Six Top Area Teams Will Vie at the Garden
description: Two years ago, when the best high school basketball teams in the metropolitan area played a preseason doubleheader at Fordham with such stars as Stephon Marbury and Shaheen Holloway, tickets were being sold in the parking lot. Last year, when the one-day extravaganza was expanded to six teams and moved to Madison Square Garden, it drew almost 8,000 spectators in a snowstorm so bad that the Knicks game that night was postponed.

title: Census Tests New Category To Identify Racial Groups
description: A new study by the Census Bureau has found that very few people would classify themselves as multiracial if given the opportunity to do so. The finding has bolstered the position of representatives of minorities who have been cool to the idea of adding the classification to the Government's list of officially recognized racial and ethnic categories.

title: In Schools, Cautious Praise for Crew's Plan
description: At Public School 119 in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, nearly a quarter of the faces in each classroom change during the school year, as a stream of children moving into the neighborhood take over the desks of those who have moved out.

title: Wider Limits Planned for Trading Halts
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday proposed a small change in the circuit breakers that would halt trading in all stock markets in the United States if share prices plunged. The change would make the circuit breakers less restrictive than they are now, but far tighter than they were when they were introduced in 1988.

title: Schwarzkopf Says He Doubts That Chemicals Caused Illnesses
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of American forces in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, said today that he did not believe that Iraqi chemical weapons had anything to do with the mysterious health problems reported by thousands of veterans of the war.

title: Alou Gets Extension
description: A day after successful treatment for an enlarged prostate gland, Montreal Expos Manager FELIPE ALOU was given a two-year contract extension through 2000. Alou agreed to manage the club through 1999 with a personal services clause for 2000.

title: Touch of Tarnish on Sutton Place Image
description: As prices have risen steadily for apartments along Fifth and Park Avenues, in TriBeCa, in Greenwich Village and on the side streets of Carnegie Hill, many of the city's brokers report that prices are flat along Sutton Place.

title: Thomas Makes a Big Splash in the Big East
description: It was evident from his first trip down the lane that Tim Thomas of Villanova would not need a learner's permit to drive in the Big East.

title: INSIDE
description: Encryption Deal Unraveling

title: Alger Hiss Is Eulogized as a Man of Civility and Sophistication
description: Hundreds of friends and admirers of Alger Hiss gathered yesterday in a church in lower Manhattan, to remember him not as a cause or a symbol but as a man of generosity and wisdom who loved poetry, books, wine and, above all, his many friends.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Heckes

title: Loctite Accepts Bid by Henkel
description: Henkel K.G.a.A., the giant German maker of chemicals and detergents, said yesterday that its sweetened bid of $61 a share had been accepted by the Loctite Corporation, making it likely that Henkel would gain control of the American adhesives company. Loctite is based in Rocky Hill, Conn.

title: U.S. Productivity Declined in 3d Quarter
description: Productivity, which measures the time, effort and cost of providing goods and services, fell a revised three-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, the first decline since late last year, the Labor Department reported today. The same report contained indications of a rise in labor costs.

title: SERB CHIEF SHOWS SIGNS OF YIELDING ON ELECTION ISSUE
description: In the face of continuing large demonstrations protesting the annulment of local elections won by opposition parties, President Slobodan Milosevic today made several concessions, and there were hints he might reconsider the election decision.

title: No Headline
description: ''I'm a very political animal.''

title: $25 and Under
description: Cafe Fes is a Moroccan restaurant, but it feels as much French as it does North African. Maybe that's because, like many Americans, I first tasted North African food in France, and Cafe Fes displays its French side proudly.

title: A Patriarch's Revenge On a World of Philistines
description: Meet Isaac Geldhart (Ron Rifkin), an autocratic publishing magnate whose Olympian literary standards are so rigid that he scornfully refuses to publish a novel called ''Rising Tide'' whose probable success could rescue his distinguished house from bankruptcy. The derisive term Isaac uses to dismiss the novel and its ilk is ''slicko hipster'' fiction. He sees the book as only one more disposable item in the swamp of modern culture, which he spittingly denounces as a ''carcinogenic pile of trash.''

title: Nominations Have Made C.I.A. Chief Odd Man Out
description: When the game of musical chairs stopped at the White House this morning, John M. Deutch, the Director of Central Intelligence, was the last man standing.

title: A Pep Talk Snaps Holik Out of Slump
description: A conversation with Coach Jacques Lemaire helped to end Bobby Holik's scoring slump. Holik scored his first goal in 13 games tonight to give the Devils a 2-1 victory over the Calgary Flames at Continental Arena.

title: Safir Defends Plan To Pursue Fugitives
description: Trying to salvage his plan to station two detectives in the Dominican Republic to track fugitives, Police Commissioner Howard Safir blamed drug traffickers in that Caribbean country yesterday for inciting opposition to his plan, and then criticized Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger for opposing him.

title: Disappearing, Reappearing, Still Smiling
description: THE smile is a little glazed; the eyes are ringed in dark circles; the voice is worn at the edges. David Copperfield, the millionaire magician, seems both tired and wired in his Broadway debut, like an airline attendant at the end of a red-eye flight. There's that same scary, vigilant friendliness of someone who has performed the same tasks so many times that they come automatically, but who knows he can't turn off the charm until the plane has landed.

description: Stung by reports of worsening human rights abuses in the areas it controls, the Palestinian Authority has announced an official inquiry into the death of a prisoner who was shot by a guard in the West Bank town of Jericho this week.

title: Seeing 3 Images in One Face
description: For more than a decade, the Japanese photographer and performance artist Yasumasa Morimura has been creating a strange devotional art: insinuating himself into other artist's pictures and under other people's skins. In the mid-1980's, his color photographs included remakes of van Gogh's self-portraits, with Mr. Morimura in the starring role. By 1991, when he had his first solo show in New York, he had graduated to elaborate photographic reprises of large multi-figure paintings by Goya, Bruegel, Rembrandt and Rossetti in which each character, thanks to computer splicing, was again Mr. Morimura, carefully made up, costumed and posed.

description: For nine months, the gruesome rumors circulated through the club scene like an echo. Andre (Angel) Melendez, 25, a fixture on the downtown party circuit known for his flamboyant costume with full-size feather-covered wings, was missing.

title: When Everyone Sings, Just for the Joy of It
description: IT falls to Edward Norton to get the ball rolling. Mr. Norton, the savvy new actor who made such a strong impression this year in ''Primal Fear'' and the soon-to-be released ''The People vs. Larry Flynt,'' is the first person in Woody Allen's new musical comedy to throw caution to the winds, open his mouth and let go. As the film begins with enchanting glimpses of Central Park in springtime, Mr. Norton begins singing ''Just You, Just Me,'' and the moment comes as a complete shock. The shock is that it works so well.

description: In most school districts in New Jersey, the test results of high school juniors change little from one year to the next. The top schools usually stay on top, give or take a change in ranking of one or two places, and the same schools rank at the bottom.

description: Plans for SUGAR RAY LEONARD's comeback bout unraveled yesterday when regulators sought to bar his promoter and the fight's casino and television sponsors pulled out.

description: BERTRAND RUSSELL

title: Writing a Crime
description: The controversy about Asian fund-raising for President Clinton's re-election campaign has taken a strange turn. An American reporter who wrote about alleged efforts to raise money in Taiwan has been charged there with criminal libel.

title: Cabinet Renewal
description: President Clinton has selected a sound if largely familiar national security team for his second term, making some history while he was at it. Madeleine Albright promises to be an articulate defender of American interests and principles as Secretary of State. Senator William Cohen, a moderate Republican selected to be Secretary of Defense, has long championed sensible Pentagon budgets and restraint in the use of American military force. They are likely to bring adjustments but no drastic changes in American foreign policy.

title: Chelios Signs Big Contract
description: CHRIS CHELIOS, a three-time winner of the Norris Trophy as the National Hockey League's top defenseman, signed a three-year contract extension yesterday with the Chicago Blackhawks. The new deal is worth $3.5 million per season. (AP)

title: Tunnel as Nightmare (Worse Than the Usual)
description: ''Daylight'' is a disaster film that assembles the Holland Tunnel (imploding), unlucky travelers (assorted), Sylvester Stallone (very, very brave) and a dog, all united by cruel fate for a stressful two-hour adventure beneath the Hudson River. It will seem suspenseful only to those who wonder whether Mr. Stallone can get the dog out alive.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS FOR WEEK 14
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M. GAMES

title: Independent Inquiry Needed on Gulf Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Isles Take Best Shots But Still Fall Short
description: When they played the Florida Panthers here three weeks ago, the Islanders felt good about earning a tie. Tonight, emboldened by three victories in their last four games, they fully expected to win.

title: A Trusted Adviser, and a Friend: Samuel Richard Berger
description: Of the four newly chosen members of his national security team, President Clinton hugged only one before the cameras today: Samuel R. Berger, the rumpled, shaggy-browed lawyer Mr. Clinton named as national security adviser.

title: Casey Returns to Boston As Calipari's Top Dog
description: There was the 59-year-old Don Casey, in his common guy's sportcoat, being embraced by the black-leather, sunglasses-wearing Hollywood star.

title: New Millenium Now Begins, Warily
description: Accepting an 11th-hour demand by the owners that extended the interleague experiment to a second season but deflated expected elation, the players' executive board unanimously ratified the new collective bargaining agreement today, ending the longest labor dispute in baseball history.

title: A Show of Support for Hendrick
description: The reaction of the Nascar community yesterday to the indictment on Wednesday of Rick Hendrick, one of the sport's leading car owners, was divided into three parts: support for Hendrick's record and character as an owner; refusal to comment on the substance of the charges against him, since they have nothing to do with racing, and a feeling that the timing of the announcement was unfair to Hendrick and Terry Labonte, his championship-winning driver.

title: CONRAIL AND CSX FILE LAWSUIT AGAINST NORFOLK SOUTHERN
description: Conrail Inc. and the CSX Corporation sued the Norfolk Southern Corporation yesterday, contending that Norfolk Southern illegally tried to break up their proposed $8.7 billion merger. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Philadelphia, requests a jury trial and seeks unspecified punitive damages. ''Norfolk Southern has flooded the marketplace with false and misleading information concerning both the CSX-Conrail merger and its conditional hostile tender offer,'' Conrail and CSX said in a joint statement. Norfolk Southern, which has made a $10 billion hostile bid for Conrail, called the lawsuit frivolous. ''If they really believe that Norfolk Southern is not serious about buying Conrail, then they should remove the barriers they put up,'' Bob Fort, a spokesman for Norfolk Southern, said.

title: G.O.P. Leader Urges Ending Of Rent Rules
description: Staking out a position at one end of what promises to be a pitched battle, the Republican leader of the State Senate yesterday proposed to do away with almost all rent regulation by mid-1999.

title: On Learning Chinese
description: To the Editor:

title: National Security Team Must Fill in the Blanks
description: President Clinton has addressed a pair of pressing political needs in selecting his new national security team.

title: Prosecutors Seek to Keep Unabom Trial In New Jersey
description: Federal prosecutors in Newark contended last night that the New Jersey murder trial of the Unabom suspect Theodore J. Kaczynski should not be moved to California. They said that if his lawyers were concerned about a speedy trial, the Government was willing to begin the proceedings in New Jersey next June, instead of in California next November, as now planned.

title: A Tribute Through Movement
description: ''He's still here,'' Judith Jamison said of Alvin Ailey, who died in 1989. ''He's still here as long as the contribution he made to us is still here.''

description: To the Editor:

description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions that are to close soon in Manhattan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WEYERHAEUSER CO., Tacoma, Wash., the forest products company, formed a $400 million partnership with UBS Asset Management Inc. to buy pine-forest land in the Southern Hemisphere.

title: GULFMARK TO SPIN OFF SOME ASSETS AND SELL THE REST
description: Gulfmark International Inc. said yesterday that it planned to spin off to its stockholders all the assets of its marine energy transportation business. The oil services company, based in Houston, said that after the spinoff it would sell its remaining assets to Energy Ventures Inc. for about $107 million in stock. Gulfmark stockholders will receive 0.6995 Energy Venture share for each of their shares. Gulfmark's shares jumped $5, to $59, on the Nasdaq stock market. Energy Ventures stock slipped 12.5 cents, to $48.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2 Bell Units Back Away From TV Plan
description: Bell Atlantic and Nynex, which announced a $22 billion merger last April, are retreating from a key part of their strategy to expand into television, according to people familiar with the two regional Bell companies.

title: Chrysler to Raise Its Dividend and Shift Top Management
description: With brisk sales of Jeeps and mini-vans producing a torrent of cash, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it would raise its quarterly dividend, buy back more stock, and make management changes aimed at rewarding some of the executives responsible for the company's success.

title: Thinking Defensively Has Boosted Rangers
description: With three minutes left in overtime Wednesday night, Ranger goalie Mike Richter left his net to chase a puck. But he tripped over the side of the cage, causing a chain reaction of collisions behind the net involving himself, defenseman Jeff Beukeboom and Philadelphia's Shjon Podein.

title: What Can I Do?
description: In central Indiana, a conservative Republican member of Congress is proposing to his constituents an answer to a question constantly put to themselves by Americans horrified by the ever-increasing oppression through which the Communist Chinese Government rules its own country and occupied Tibet.

title: ALBRIGHT TO HEAD STATE DEPT.; REPUBLICAN IN TOP DEFENSE JOB
description: President Clinton today announced his selection of Madeleine K. Albright to be Secretary of State as he introduced a national security team for his second term that also includes a prominent Republican to head the Defense Department.

title: N.T.T. Agrees to Split Into 3 Separate Units
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the world's largest telephone company, will be broken into three separate units under a plan announced today that would redraw the future of telecommunications in Japan.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Quilty's is one of those beautifully plain spaces, all white on white with wainscoting on the walls and understated lights, that look as if they had been there forever, waiting to be discovered. In fact, it is new, recently replacing the dark Ahnell.

title: Boys and Girls Clubs In Project With Coke
description: The Boys and Girls Clubs of America and the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that they would join in efforts to raise $60 million over the next decade for a youth-development program sponsored by the clubs.

title: False Rape Charge Admitted
description: A woman who claimed that she was raped by a male inmate at the Union County Jail in February admitted in court yesterday that the sex was consensual, officials said. The woman, Alveda Torrado, 32, of Elizabeth, pleaded guilty to false swearing and criminal contempt, telling Judge Walter R. Barisonek that she fled to Puerto Rico in March to avoid appearing before a grand jury, said Edward M. Neafsey, the Acting County Prosecutor. She could be sentenced to six months in the county jail, Mr. Neafsey said. The jail has since taken steps to avoid further contact between male and female inmates, he said.

title: Mathematician Is Honored
description: Yakov Sinai, a Princeton University mathematics professor, has been a pioneer in revealing unusual examples of chaos in the real world and applying his insights to solve scientific problems, according to his colleagues. Last week, Dr. Sinai, 61, was awarded the Wolf Foundation Prize for Mathematics. He will share the $100,000 prize, one of the top honors in a discipline not eligible for a Nobel Prize, with Joseph B. Keller of Stanford University. They were honored for their individual lifetime achievements in mathematical physics.

title: With No Tailpipe But Much Fanfare, A New Car Arrives
description: With all the klieg-light hoopla and hype of a Hollywood premiere, the first electric car to be mass-produced in this country in modern times went on sale here today, a sleek, whisper-quiet little two-seater packed with state-of-the-art batteries and the nation's hopes for an end to tailpipe pollution and heavy dependence on foreign oil.

description: ''Losing Chase'' was shown on the Showtime cable channel on Aug. 18. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Aug. 16. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Cooling Riley's Momentum Becomes a Knick Challenge
description: When they last met, Alonzo Mourning drove by Patrick Ewing as if he were a cardboard cutout. Pat Riley clapped his hands till they stung and the Miami Heat recorded a stunning blowout victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Talmudic Quandary for a Shul: Growth or Intimacy
description: When the wandering Jews of congregation B'nai Jeshurun carry their Torahs from a borrowed church to their renovated synagogue on Sunday, after five and a half years away, they will be returning to a home that is far too small to hold them.

title: Security as You Shop
description: At the Bridgewater Commons mall, security guards are patrolling the vast parking area on horseback to be able to see over cars and to intimidate would-be thieves. At Garden State Plaza, where a woman escaped a kidnapping attempt on Saturday, plainclothes detectives from the Bergen County Prosecutor's Office are assisting uniformed Paramus officers. And in Jersey City, extra police patrol the Newport Centre and Hudson malls, paid with Urban Enterprise Zone money.

title: A Plan for Saving Billions in Budgets
description: A prominent organization that studies government finances said yesterday that New York City and New York State could save up to $15 billion a year if they abandoned a range of antiquated practices that the rest of the nation had long discarded or never adopted.

title: Selection for Secretary of State Is Praised by Helms and Others
description: After an uneven first term of learning how to manage foreign policy, President Clinton got good reviews today for selecting his Administration's most effective public voice, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief delegate to the United Nations, to be the first female Secretary of State.

title: Troubled Tie: France Hears Alarming Echoes of Colonial Past From Algeria
description: Like a festering wound that will not heal, Algeria still torments France, a former colonial master and its enemy in a long and bitter war of liberation.

title: ANCHOR GAMING IS CONSIDERING A SALE OR MERGER
description: The shares of Anchor Gaming rose 12 percent yesterday after the company said it was considering a sale or merger and had hired Morgan Stanley & Company as a financial adviser. Anchor Gaming, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev., makes casino games, including the popular Wheel of Gold slot game, and operates gambling halls. Anchor's stock has fallen 35 percent from a 52-week high of $71 on July 8, amid concern that the company could lose business to new competitors. Stuart Linde, an analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company in New York, said the company could be sold for more than $700 million, or $55 to $60 a share. Possible suitors include Casino Data Systems and Alliance Gaming, he said. Anchor Gaming's shares rose $5, to $46, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Fire Empties Rockefeller Center Restaurant
description: A fire erupted last night in the kitchen of a restaurant in Rockefeller Center, injuring seven people, hurling gas and smoke 33 stories up through the ducts and causing a minor explosion in a top-floor equipment room, Fire Department officials said.

title: Keep in Mind
description: ''RAFFERTY RESCUES THE MOON,'' a theater production based on a Celtic fairy tale, combining songs, humor and imagery to tell the story of Rafferty, a boy who leaves his treehouse in Ireland to rescue the moon, which has been swallowed by the Great Fish. A panicky poet and a bombastic bat help out. Saturdays, through Dec. 21, at 2 P.M. Tickets: $7. At Synchronicity Space, 55 Mercer Street, SoHo. Reservations: (212) 941-8685.

title: Prisoner Flees Hospital
description: A 19-year-old Newark man escaped from police custody yesterday while awaiting the results of a chest X-ray at University Hospital, the authorities said. The man, Kurvan Rankin, had been arrested hours earlier near an elementary school with 22 vials of cocaine. Mr. Rankin told the police that he had tuberculosis and was taken to the hospital, where he was placed under the guard of a policeman. Later in the morning, the officer noticed that he was gone, said Detective Dan Collins, a Newark police spokesman. Mr. Rankin is not considered dangerous, he said.

Historians later demonstrated the correctness of Mr. Whitsitt's view that the practice had not begun until the 17th century, but the furor over his beliefs had long since cost him his job.

Shareholders of Barefoot, which provides lawn-care services and is based in Worthington, Ohio, will be able to choose either cash or Servicemaster shares. Selling the military and aerospace business, which had revenue of $5.9 billion last year, might bring Hughes $8 billion, analysts said. title: HADCO AGREES TO DEAL FOR RIVAL MAKER OF CIRCUIT BOARDS
description: The Hadco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a rival maker of printed circuit boards, the Zycon Corporation, for $18 a share in cash, or about $205 million. Zycon, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it had ended the agreement announced Monday, under which it would have been acquired by an affiliate of the Dallas buyout firm of Hicks Muse Tate & Furst for $16.25 a share. Zycon said principal shareholders that own about 60 percent of its stock had agreed to the Hadco offer. Zycon shares's rose $1.625 each, to $17.625, on the Nasdaq stock market, while Hadco shares rose $1.6875, to $47.125. Hadco is based in Salem, N.H.

description: Two days after Boutros Boutros-Ghali put his candidacy for a second term as Secretary General on hold, African nations today began nominating alternative candidates.

title: Top Driver Suspended
description: WALTER CASE JR., the leading driver at Yonkers Raceway, was suspended yesterday after failing a drug test. The New York State Racing and Wagering Board suspended Case, 35, for an indefinite period. It was the third drug-related suspension for the driver, who has 534 victories this year, including 334 at Yonkers.

title: Censorship Follies, Town by Town
description: I had to go to the library to find a map detailed enough to show Cortland, Ohio, which, it turned out, is a small town in the northeastern corner of the state. There's not much there by big-city standards: 6,000 people and no movie theaters. But there is one courageous high school teacher who went to battle to keep his school board from banning my book.

title: Water on the Moon, Pie in the Sky
description: On Feb. 10, 1910, a visionary young graduate student at Clark University recorded a wildly improbable prediction in his journal: that the presence of ice on the Moon would allow human explorers an opportunity for autonomy off Earth. That student was Robert H. Goddard, the father of practical rocketry.

title: Vibrant Tales In Small Book On Queens
description: MORTY SKLAR lugged a carton filled with copies of his latest book down 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights, where the most visible literary competition was a Jehovah's Witness holding copies of ''Awake'' in outstretched hands. There used to be a small bookstore in his Queens neighborhood, but it closed down the same month his anthology, ''Patchwork of Dreams,'' was published.

description: Robert C. Rosenberg, a senior partner in the law firm of Hawkins, Delafield & Wood who counseled state and municipal agencies, public authorities and bond underwriters throughout the country and overseas, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Rosenberg, who lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was 54.

description: THE soreness was evident in Brad Otton's voice.

title: Henry Siegel, 86, Who Solved Mysteries as Medical Examiner
description: Dr. Henry Siegel, an eclectic medical sleuth who was a deputy chief medical examiner in New York City in the 1960's and chief medical examiner for Westchester County in the 1970's, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Plantation, Fla. He was 86.

title: 16 Years for Gang Leader
description: The leader of a drug-selling gang that terrorized an Atlantic City housing project was sentenced yesterday to 188 months, or nearly 16 years, in Federal prison, prosecutors said. Hanif Abdullah, the gang leader, had pleaded guilty in February to racketeering and trying to murder a member of a rival gang. The gang, known as the Abdullahs, controlled the Shore Park housing project, said Dick Lavinthal, a spokesman for the United States Attorney's Office in Newark. Twenty-one other members of the gang have been convicted of various offenses.

title: Louis M. Brown, 87, Lawyer Who Emphasized Prevention
description: Louis Morris Brown, a lawyer and legal scholar who formulated preventive law as an academic discipline and a practitioner's specialization, died on Sept. 12 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 87.

title: MAGNA BUYS ASSETS OF CARADON ROLINEX FOR $32 MILLION
description: Magna International Inc., an auto-parts concern based in Markham, Ontario, said yesterday that it had purchased the assets of a British parts company, Caradon Rolinex P.L.C., for $:20 million, or more than $32 million. Magna said Caradon had annual sales of about $129 million and supplied products for Rover, Volvo and Honda vehicles. Magna indicated that other possible acquisitions were in the works in North America and Europe.

description: Girls outnumbered boys by at least 2 to 1 at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. But Gwen Stefani of No Doubt enlisted the boys to sing by themselves. ''I'm just a girl,'' they shouted, making her laugh.

title: Most Expensive Senate Race
description: The recent Senate campaign reached new levels of expense as well as nastiness: the candidates spent a state record of $16 million between them, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Senator-elect Robert G. Torricelli spent nearly $8.9 million, while his Republican opponent, Richard A. Zimmer, spent more than $7.6 million, records filed with the Federal Election Commission showed.

title: Police Give Details in Killing Of Flamboyant Club Denizen
description: After sifting through the gossip and innuendo of the club world for months, detectives investigating the slaying of a young clubgoer said yesterday that one of the killers had given them details of the murder, which he said was committed with a pillow.

But in choosing a work that has been played famously well in the past, Mr. Zimmermann was making it difficult to distinguish himself. That he did was to the credit of this accomplished 31-year-old artist.
