title: The Miracle Backlash
description: In our media culture of spin and counter-spin, every hype is followed by a fall. No sooner is anyone from a film director (Quentin Tarantino) to a war hero (Colin Powell) elevated to the Pantheon than a backlash sets in. This ruthless phenomenon spares no one -- not even people with AIDS.

title: CSX Begins a 2d Tender Offer for Conrail
description: The CSX Corporation said today that it had begun a second tender offer to extend its holdings to 40 percent of Conrail Inc., which would complete the cash portion of its proposed $8.73 billion acquisition.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage, and Off column of Weekend yesterday about the shortage of Off Broadway theaters misidentified the show produced by David Stone. It is ''The Batting Cage,'' a comedy by Joan Ackerman, not ''Bunny Bunny.''

title: Hitchcock Traded To the Padres
description: The San Diego Padres acquired the left-hander STERLING HITCHCOCK from the Seattle Mariners yesterday for the right-hander SCOTT SANDERS.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Reading Needs More 'Rithmetic From the City
description: To the Editor:

title: Kelly Asks a Judge for More Freedom
description: Alex Kelly's lawyer asked the judge in his rape case today to change the terms of his $1 million bond so he could leave home alone to work with inner-city teen-agers and return to college. Mr. Kelly is currently restricted to his Darien home 24 hours a day unless he is accompanied by one of his parents.

title: Commerce Resumes but Pain Continues
description: The Record Shack on 125th Street is not so different from what it once was. The vintage vinyl records are stacked neatly in their bins once again and Aretha Franklin's thunder drifts out past the plate glass window into the street, demanding that shoppers stop, come in, browse awhile.

title: November Labor Data Weak; Jobless Rate Edges Up to 5.4%
description: A Government report showing a lackluster job market in November reassured investors today that inflation was not a threat and helped to blunt a stock market dive prompted by remarks made Thursday night by the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: High Court To Take Up Land Dispute
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a long-running territorial dispute between the Federal Government and Alaska over ownership of parts of the seabed and offshore lands along the state's northeast coast, in an area rich in wildlife as well as oil and natural gas.

title: A Buried Message Loudly Heard
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board since 1987, has long since learned that his every phrase will be transmitted instantaneously to stock and bond traders worldwide and that his merest inflection can send markets stampeding.

title: Special Education Procedures Must Be Improved
description: To the Editor:

title: Birds Galore, Pursued by Flocks of Flying Birders
description: It's 3:30 A.M. In the thick fog, four grown men have a dead tree surrounded and are holding tape recorders up to it, each one pumping a different hoot up into the empty branches, hoping for a reply. A cold drizzle runs down their necks.

title: Occupation of a Nuclear Plant Signals Russian Labor's Anger
description: More than a dozen employees at St. Petersburg's nuclear power plant took over the control room on Thursday and threatened to shut down the plant that provides most of the city's power unless they received months' worth of back pay. This morning 400 of their colleagues joined the protest, and announced a hunger strike. Federal officials rushed to the scene to assess the hazard.

title: Ban Extended on Affirmative Action Measure
description: A Federal judge today temporarily barred the University of California from enforcing the provisions of Proposition 209, the voter initiative approved last month that would end the state's affirmative action programs.

title: NORTHERN ELECTRIC REJECTS BID BY CALENERGY
description: A United States joint venture led by Calenergy Inc. raised its bid yesterday for Northern Electric P.L.C. by 3.2 percent, to 650 pence ($10.70)a share. Northern immediately rejected the offer, which totaled $:923 million ($1.5 billion) in cash and assumed debt, as too low. Northern Electric, which supplies electricity to 2.3 million English customers, earlier rejected a bid of 630 pence a share. Northern Electric would help Calenergy's earnings at a time that revenue from its Californian power plants is expected to drop. The takeover would be the fourth of a British utility by a United States company in two years. Calenergy is making its bid with Pieter Kiewit & Sons Inc., a closely held company with interests in construction, telecommunications and mining.

title: New Era for Rents
description: Most New Yorkers cannot remember a time without landlords who clamored for an end to rent regulation, and occasional noises from the Legislature about doing away with rent rules -- but such talk has usually come to nothing.

title: Proud Parent Member
description: To the Editor:

title: Rescuing the Superstore Deal
description: Opening the way for major superstores to bring jobs and cheaper prices to New York City has been one of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's main goals this year. He seemed close to victory this week until final negotiations with the City Council fell through. Each side is bitterly blaming the other. But if they stop complaining and work together, they can still reach a final agreement quickly.

title: Greenspan Asks a Question And Global Markets Wobble
description: Alan Greenspan used the word ''bubble'' while talking about stock prices, and financial markets around the world deflated yesterday, evidently fearful that Mr. Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, might do something to bring down the buoyant stock market.

title: Schwab to Allow Foreigners To Trade Securities on Line
description: Giving a new meaning to the term global investing, Charles Schwab & Company, the country's largest discount stockbroker, said yesterday that it would start allowing foreign investors to buy and sell domestic stocks and bonds through its site on the Internet's World Wide Web next week.

title: Mexico Says It Plans More Privatizations
description: Seizing on new momentum in its privatization program, the Mexican Government said today that it was planning new sales of state-owned railroads, airports and satellites next year.

title: Cliff Mapes, Outfielder, 74
description: Cliff Mapes, whose five-year major league career is remembered chiefly for his links to Yankee uniforms worn by Babe Ruth and Mickey Mantle, died on Thursday in Pryor, Okla. He was 74.

title: Johnson Honored Again
description: MICHAEL JOHNSON, who this summer became the first man to win both the 200 and 400 meters at an Olympics, set another record yesterday without lacing up his gold shoes. Johnson and GAIL DEVERS, who successfully defended her Olympic crown in the women's 100 meters, won the Jesse Owens awards that are given annually to the top American athletes in track and field.

title: Asian Music Unit For News Corp.
description: The News Corporation has started a music venture with Tetsuya Komuro, one of Japan's most popular performers and producers, in a bid to expand the Australian media company's presence in the Asian music market.

title: G.M. TO BUILD FEWER AUTOS THAN PLANNED IN NEXT QUARTER
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it planned to build 1.41 million cars and trucks in North America in the first quarter of 1997, which is 46,000 fewer than it had planned to build a year earlier before an Ohio strike crippled production. Compared with the strike-reduced output, G. M. planned to produce 16 percent more vehicles in the first three months of 1997 than in the 1996 quarter. The strike in Dayton, Ohio, cut G. M.'s production by 240,000. Yesterday's numbers are conservative and show that G. M. is cautious about the number of vehicles it can sell, analysts said. G. M. has eight plants that are shifting over to build new models, a process that generally slows production. G. M. shares fell $2.25 yesterday, to $56.50.

title: Whither '97 Yanks? Don't Ask the Owner
description: George Steinbrenner stayed silent as he was reminded that the player who hit perhaps the most important Yankee homer of the season had been traded to the Anaheim Angels, that the starter who won the clinching game of the World Series was still not signed and that the closer who saved four Series victories was also in limbo.

title: For Foster Children, Artistic Expression
description: In a cinder block room on the South Side, window shades half-drawn against the glare of streetlights, Chicago foster children hone their talents with easels, colors, glues, paint and paper. It is a chance to create something beautiful, for young people who have endured much that is not.

title: SUNDSTRAND TO TAKE $32 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Sundstrand Corporation said yesterday that it expected to take a charge of $32 million, before taxes, in the fourth quarter to restructure its Sullair Europe compressor unit. The company said it could have additional restructuring expenses of $3 million in 1997. The company was negotiating the specifics of the planned reorganization with Sullair employees. Details of the cost-cutting plan were not disclosed. Sundstrand, based in Rockford, Ill., said its European compressor business had not been profitable for several years because of strong competition and depressed market conditions. The Sullair Europe business will be a ''viable'' company and better able to compete after the restructuring, the company said.

title: Free-Spirited Progeny Of the Long Romance Between Dance and Film
description: Inside every youngish choreographer there seems to beat the heart of a budding film maker. That is not surprising. These are restless times in the arts, and dancers are not immune.

title: Elway to Miss Start
description: JOHN ELWAY, still hampered by a strained hamstring, will not start tomorrow against Green Bay. Denver Coach MIKE SHANAHAN said yesterday that BILL MUSGRAVE would make his first career start in place of Elway, who has missed nine games because of injury or illness in 14 seasons. The Broncos are 2-7 in those games.

title: Knicks Show a Lot of Fight in Getting Back at Heat
description: With his teammates about to converge on him, Chris Childs hurled the basketball skyward as the final horn blared. It ricocheted off the scoreboard, which read: 103-85.

title: Campaign Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Offers Tax Amnesty
description: Mayor Sharpe James and the City Council have a gift for Newark taxpayers. Yesterday, they announced a 30-day amnesty for those who owe $56 million in delinquent property and payroll taxes, water and sewer fees and parking lot expenses. Residents who pay outstanding charges before Dec. 31 will not have to pay penalties or interest, said Pamela E. Goldstein, a spokeswoman for the Mayor.

title: The Future Is Very . . . Dark
description: ''Adrenalin: Fear the Rush,'' the futuristic thriller that crept into local theaters yesterday, proposes an obvious solution to the challenge of making a horror film on the cheap. Do it in the dark.

title: Great One for Rangers: Gretzky Scores Twice in Victory
description: With Mark Messier weakened by injury and the Rangers embarrassing themselves with sloppiness, the responsibility to salvage this comedy of errors fell on the slender, 35-year-old shoulders of Wayne Gretzky.

title: Corrections
description: A credit for a Thanksgiving illustration on Nov. 28 misspelled the artist's name. She is Betteanne Terrell.

title: Where Am I?
description: To the Editor:

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE ENDS DEAL TO BUY DOONEY & BOURKE
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that it had terminated its agreement to acquire the Dooney & Bourke Companies, a closely held handbag and luggage maker. The apparel company said the parties were not able to agree on terms. Dooney & Bourke has annual revenue of about $118 million. Liz Claiborne's accessories currently make up about 10 percent of total annual revenue of about $2.08 billion. Liz Claiborne said it planned to continue to seek acquisitions.

title: MCI Wins Right to Begin Broadcast Satellite Services
description: The MCI Telecommunications Corporation won the right today to begin direct broadcast satellite services, and some analysts say the ruling leaves the door open for the company to keep the licenses even after it is acquired by British Telecommunications P.L.C.

title: Despite Odds, Bratton Seems to Crave Spotlight
description: There was a good deal of expensive jewelry on display at the breakfast tables of the Regency Hotel one morning this week, but only one pair of N.Y.P.D. cuff links. Most police officers, even former police commissioners, are not accustomed to paying $20 for poached eggs, juice and coffee at the grand diner of the ruling class.

title: Redecorating the City
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES TO BUY BACK UP TO 5 MILLION SHARES
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that its board had approved the repurchase of as many as five million of the airline's class A common shares. It said the buyback would offset an increase in outstanding shares resulting from the exercise of stock options by its employees. As of Oct. 31, Northwest had 111.9 million shares, assuming the full conversion of all securities into common stock. On the Nasdaq stock market yesterday, Northwest closed at $39.375, down 37.5 cents.

title: Natural Gas Drops on Forecast Of Warming Trend in Northeast
description: Natural gas prices fell yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after forecasts for warming temperatures next week reduced concern about dwindling supplies this winter.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day yesterday about an agreement between America Online Inc. and 19 states over its pricing plan referred imprecisely to customers' options under the agreement. America Online will move all customers to its flat-rate plan except those who choose another plan; the company does not need to obtain their consent before putting them in the flat-rate plan.

title: Pepper Spray Sales Boom
description: Sales of a pepper-based self-defense spray have skyrocketed at local stores since three East Brunswick women were sexually assaulted last month and another was mugged. At Kmart, 36 canisters of the spray were sold on Thursday, three times more than the store normally sells in a week, said the store's operations manager, Amy Cowles. And a Pep Boys discount store ordered a shipment of 36 additional canisters when its stock of eight canisters sold out, said Anthony Todd, the store manager.

title: Not Local Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Head Off the Heating Oil Crisis
description: New Englanders should be praying that they don't have a white Christmas and hoping that their stockings will be filled with coal -- or anything else they could use to heat their homes as the temperature drops.

title: 'Threepenny' From Croats
description: The Croatian actors performing the Bertolt Brecht/Kurt Weill songs from ''Threepenny Opera'' at LaMama on Thursday had the right approach to their material. The songs are inflamed with anger; stepping up to them, a singer has to respond in kind, by mocking them and dragging them through the dirt.

title: Excerpt From the Speech by Greenspan
description: Following is an excerpt from a speech by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, given at a dinner in Washington sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research on Thursday night:

title: Mr. Milosevic's Choice
description: Sensibly, Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, has backed away from confrontation with thousands of protesters outraged by his annulment of opposition victories in recent municipal elections. Compromise, including a belated recognition of the original election results, may be Mr. Milosevic's only hope for long-term political survival.

title: San Jose St. Taps Coach
description: DAVE BALDWIN, the California State-Northridge coach the last two seasons, was hired yesterday to head the program at San Jose State. Baldwin, who replaces the retired JOHN RALSTON, was the receivers coach at San Jose State from 1980-83 under JACK ELWAY. The 41-year-old Baldwin also served as an assistant offensive coach at Stanford.

title: Protests? In Belgrade? What Protests? Asks a State-Controlled Newspaper
description: The senior editors at Politika, Yugoslavia's largest and most powerful state-run newspaper, flicked off the lights in their offices just before deadline this evening and pretended they weren't there.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a planned rise in the Chrysler Corporation's quarterly dividend and a stock buyback and whether other auto makers would follow suit concluded with a garbled passage. It should have read: ''Mr. Vinyard, the Ford spokesman, said the company would consider buying back its stock after it meets its cash reserve target. Ford last raised its dividend in the third quarter, to $38.5 cents -- the fifth increase since early 1994.''

title: Biologist Is Charged In Sex Abuse Of a Student
description: Although she had just met the man she was having dinner with, the college student felt safe with him, a prosecutor said yesterday. The man was a molecular biologist and a doctoral candidate at Columbia University, and the student had got to know him on the Internet, the prosecutor said.

title: Corruption Scandals Rack Tokyo's 'Iron Triangle' : Struggle for Power in Japan
description: TOKYO  The images have flashed across television screens in Japan almost every day since Ryutaro Hashimoto was re-elected prime minister a month ago: Police officials pull up to the home or office of a high-ranking politician, bureaucrat or business executive, search the premises and haul him off to jail.

title: White House Works to Fill Domestic Slots
description: With his major decisions on foreign policy appointments behind him, President Clinton met today with his transition team in hopes of announcing some major domestic and economic appointments next week.

title: Statute on Internet Indecency Draws High Court's Review
description: Setting the stage for a landmark ruling on the constitutional dimensions of free speech in cyberspace, the Supreme Court today agreed to a full review of whether the new Federal law regulating indecency on the Internet violates the First Amendment.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SAKS HOLDINGS INC., New York, the department store chain, said it would open 20 stores in the fiscal years 1997 and 1998, 9 more than originally planned, and expand 12 stores in a more ambitious schedule.

title: A Strange Twist in Christmas Gifts
description: Who would have thought a month ago that the hottest Christmas items would end up being a furry monster that squeals when tickled, a love tome penned by an ice skater and all things related to bread?

title: After Calipari Squirms, Nets Win in Overtime
description: John Calipari knew the winding, jagged brick streets of this town. And yet his team was lost along the way to the Fleet Center, stuck with a misguided bus driver bumping along in the dark on the way to tonight's game.

title: Council Guessed Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Run for Fusion Reactor
description: Scientists at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory are preparing the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor for what they hope will be a glorious last run before it is shut down permanently. Congress recently ordered the reactor to be turned off and disassembled when the cycle of experiments to begin in January ends in March. One of the experiments will test a solution to the potential problems identified recently in the planned $10 billion International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor.

title: Leon Polk Smith, 91, Artist Loyal to Geometry, Is Dead
description: Leon Polk Smith, a painter who furthered the development of American geometric abstraction, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Smith was 91 and also had a home in Shoreham, L.I.

title: Bridge
description: Three decades ago, the island of Manhattan was awash in experts of both sexes who were competitive on the national level, but death, and desertion to warmer climes, has sharply diminished the total.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Joe Bravo, Leading Rider at the Meadowlands, Is About to Hit the Big Time
description: While the rest of the jockeys scraped a cold crust of gray slime from their faces after the sixth race at the Meadowlands Thursday night, Joe Bravo gave his winning mount, a brash black colt named Real Star, a comradely whack on the neck. According to Bravo, colts like the fraternity brother treatment, and as for the fillies, well, Bravo doesn't mind singing to them or tweaking their prettily braided manes a little if that is what coaxes them into fifth gear.

title: Albright May Be Facing Unfamiliar Tests
description: Many of the challenges facing President Clinton's nominee for Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, will come in areas like China, the Middle East and the emerging markets of Asia and Latin America, where Ms. Albright has no great depth of experience.

title: Eager Bratton Strolls On the Power Track
description: For William J. Bratton, the many perquisites of power have been as hard to give up as the Police Department whose insignia he still wears, 10 months after he resigned as Commissioner under pressure from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Even as he considers running against his old boss, Mr. Bratton is delighting in the attention he is being paid, notably at a recent power breakfast, by the people with an interest in his decision.

title: Surprise Senate Challenge to Pollution Plan
description: The Clinton Administration's new proposals to tighten air quality regulations have run into Congressional resistance from an unexpected quarter, as Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, for decades a leading Republican environmentalist, has challenged the rationale for such costly steps.

title: A Ballet Recreates True-Life Obsession and Murder
description: Tina Ramirez cannily touched all the bases in her choice of three new dances for her Ballet Hispanico in its winter season at the Joyce Theater. The company has already presented a dramatic narrative piece by David Rousseve and some stylish European modern dance by Maria Rovira. On Thursday, there was fabulous spectacle from George Faison, a Tony Award winner, in his ''Idol Obsession,'' seen in its world premiere.

title: Tories Slip Into Minority; Labor Silent on Forcing Election
description: John Major, the embattled Prime Minister, lost his parliamentary majority today and came under attack from members of his fractious party over his insistence that Britain remain engaged in discussions with Europe about a common currency.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Delbarton Has Answer

title: U.S. Pays for Jailing Aliens
description: The Federal Government has agreed to pick up a major portion of what Hudson County is spending to keep illegal aliens convicted of crimes behind bars. On Thursday, the Justice Department awarded the county $106,026, which will cover 60 percent of the projected cost next year of housing convicted illegal immigrants at the county jail. The awards to Hudson and nearly 100 other cities and counties across the nation mark the first time the Federal Government has reimbursed local governments for the costs of incarcerating criminals who are illegal immigrants. County Executive Robert Janiszewski said reimbursement was only fair. ''We didn't let illegal aliens in,'' he said. ''It's not our responsibility.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Says 'Bubble,' And World Markets Deflate

title: Company Head Makes a Pitch to Run L.I. School
description: The founder of a private company that operates 12 public schools in 6 states told parents this week that his company would invest $1.5 million in computers and teaching materials if it were hired to run an elementary school here.

title: Observer Yellow Peril's Return
description: In a Sax Rohmer thriller it was always a foggy night in London town when the tireless Nayland Smith appeared in my chambers with dreadful news. ''The Yellow Peril is in London at this very moment,'' he might say.

title: Lawmaker Says V.A. Threatened Doctors for Statements on Gulf War Illness
description: The lawmaker who has led the chief Congressional investigation of illnesses among veterans of the Persian Gulf war accused the Department of Veterans Affairs today of seeking to purge the agency of doctors who publicly questioned the Government's stand on the issue.

title: With the Giants, Ellsworth Is Thriving, and Starting
description: At Virginia, Percy Ellsworth was an all-America safety, but in last April's National Football League draft everyone passed him by. Supposedly, he had an injured shoulder, he wasn't strong enough, he wasn't coachable.

title: Spare the Brady Law
description: A key provision of the Brady gun-control law seemed at risk this week during the continuing and increasingly heated Supreme Court debate over the limits of Federal authority. The provision requires local law enforcement officers to conduct background checks of prospective gun purchasers.

title: Harlan P. Hanson, 71, Who Led Advanced Placement Program
description: Dr. Harlan Philip Hanson, a former professor and college dean who spent decades helping students put their college educations on the fast track, died on Nov. 28 at North Adams Central Hospital in North Adams, Mass. A resident of Williamstown, Mass., he was 71 and also kept a residence in Princeton, N.J., while working for the College Board in New York City.

title: Union Says Big Stores Are Using Sweatshops
description: While Lord & Taylor's Santa Claus was busy listening to Christmas wishes inside the department store on Fifth Avenue, another Santa was arrested outside the store for staging a sit-in, sans sleigh.

title: Teen-Ager Is Fatally Stabbed In Robbery in Queens Subway
description: A 17-year-old boy was stabbed to death and his 16-year-old girlfriend was wounded in an attempted purse-snatching last night on a subway platform in Jackson Heights, Queens, the police said.

title: Nominees Raise Both Hope and Worry Abroad
description: Governments around the world formally welcomed President Clinton's new foreign policy and defense appointments today. But while some hoped that a new Secretary of State and a new Secretary of Defense might see things more their way, many others feared that they would not.

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: Again and again, I am stunned by Schlessinger's abrasive style and flip attitude toward those who consult her. The clincher is that, following these harrowing confrontations with hapless callers, she concludes with the refrain, ''Go and take on the day.'' This is like amputating a patient's legs and admonishing him to ski down the next slope.

title: Mountain Bikers Find Welcome at 2 Parks
description: THE people who maintain the trails at Graham Hills Park here are doing it differently these days. Instead of clearing away rocks and branches, they are deliberately leaving some obstacles in the dirt paths. The reason: to keep the course as challenging as possible for those riding mountain bikes.

title: In New Castle, Recycling Comes Easily
description: NEITHER a biting wind nor a chilly rain deterred a nearly ceaseless stream of Explorers, Caravans, Jeeps and other sport utility vehicles from pouring into the Hunts Lane Recycling Center here on a recent bleak morning. Their occupants were eager to perform their civic duty, undaunted by the gloomy weather.

title: Gunman at a Brooklyn Club Kills 3, Including a Woman Who Saved 2
description: A gunman methodically tried to murder five people yesterday morning during a brutal robbery at a Brooklyn social club, the police said, and 32-year-old Evelyn Davis was stabbed to death trying to stop him.

title: In Considering Cremation, Funeral Pyres Have Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Brash Hip-Hop Entrepreneurs
description: ''CASH RULES everything around me.'' So goes the refrain to ''C.R.E.A.M.,'' a hit by the rap supergroup Wu-Tang Clan. A haunting fable of ghetto economics, the song depicts a grim world of ''stick-up kids, corrupt cops and crack rocks,'' where ''drug loot'' is the only way for the young black men that haunt its street corners to earn a living. While ''C.R.E.A.M.'' reflects the rough-and-tumble life that the group's members had growing up in housing projects on Staten Island, its money-obsessed chorus takes on new meaning in the wake of Wu-Tang's success.

title: Inflating the Inflation Index
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning to Serve At Restaurants
description: Re the amusing article ''Learning Proper Way to Serve in a Restaurant'' (Nov. 17), my favorite story -- probably apochryphal -- is one told by George Jean Nathan. It concerns the difficulty in getting the attention of some waiters. While visiting a cemetery, Mr. Nathan came across this inscription on a headstone:

title: Fall in Tuscany: Crowds Go, the Pleasures Remain
description: SMALL leafless trees covered with orange persimmons strike an incongruous but brilliant note in the still welcoming November landscape of Chianti. Even in Florence, a fruit-loaded tree is tucked in here and there along busy streets or in small back gardens.

title: Legally, Now, Venezuelans to Mine Fragile Lands
description: In an effort to end years of disarray in its mining sector, Venezuela is planning to lift bans on gold and diamond mining in ecologically fragile areas and to grant amnesties to companies that have been mining without Government permission.

title: Producing Maximum Blooms With a Minimum of Care
description: THE African violet is probably the most popular house plant grown. Few homes are without at least one. Many growers have several, while hobbyists and hybridists grow them by the hundreds.

title: Lanie Bertsche, Paul M. McNulty
description: Alane Wright Bertsche, a computer software designer, and Paul Michael McNulty, an investment manager, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. J. Douglas Ousley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation.

title: THE BIG MAN CAN DEAL
description: When I read that Juwan Howard ''wanted to cry'' when he was offered a mere $11.2 million a year by the Washington Bullets, I just about lost it. The next time Falk sits down at the negotiating table with one of his players, he should think of the loyal N.B.A. fans who will work their entire lives and never see anything like the money the players earn in one season. We're the ones who have to pay those outrageous ticket prices to support their crazy salaries. Maybe I'm missing something, but $11.2 million a year looks pretty good from where I'm sitting -- which is way off center court and very close to the rafters.

title: THE BIG MAN CAN DEAL
description: To David Falk, who complains that his pioneering work to get multimillion-dollar fees for athletes is not fully appreciated: drop me a line when you direct your talent toward creating a market for exorbitant salaries for teachers. I'll be happy to organize your fan club.

title: 65 Years Later, an $11 Million Bequest From a Failed Student
description: When James Dye was on his way toward flunking out of Washington and Lee University here in 1931, a chemistry professor gave him a comeuppance that he never forgot.

title: Rapper Is Arrested In Marijuana Case
description: The rap performer known as Flavor Flav was arrested in the South Bronx early Friday morning when he was found carrying two pounds of marijuana, the police said.

title: Welfare All Over the Map
description: IT may get awfully icy there, but for shelter from the chills of indigence, few states top Vermont. Though hardly rich, Vermont spends proportionately more on its safety net than almost every other state. ''In Vermont,'' said Jane Kitchel, commissioner of the state's unabashedly liberal Department of Social Welfare, ''we have a tradition of social responsibility.''

title: Clinton Cites Welfare Gains And Defends Overhaul Plan
description: After four months of criticism by liberal Democrats, President Clinton today defended his decision to sign a bill overhauling welfare programs and boasted that welfare rolls had dropped by 15 percent since he took office.

title: A Toy Soldier Guards the White House Tonight
description: Holly Hynes, director of costumes for the New York City Ballet, was plainly amazed. ''These are the smallest things I've ever made,'' she said, describing her latest creations. The costumes, she added, ''would fit Barbie.''

title: Amish Crafts
description: To the Editor: ''Rolling Through Amish Country'' (Sept. 29) did not mention some of the hidden resources. When I wanted an Amish farmer's straw hat, I was sent to Eli Glick, where I made friends with the whole family. A behind-the-scenes look at Amish life is available at the Glick farm at 248A Monterey Road, Bird-in-Hand, Pa. 17505, where three generations live in harmony.

title: New Way to Treat the Holidays, As the Environmentalists See It
description: CHRISTMAS is coming and so are reams of shiny (as in nonrecyclable) wrapping paper, tables laden with party foods that may or may not be eaten, and gifts that might wind up permanently consigned to the back shelf of someone's closet.

title: On the Edge, but Still in the Driver's Seat
description: ON HALLOWEEN NIGHT Laura Dern was driving through West Hollywood when she spotted two distinctively adorned pedestrians. Perhaps because she tends to vocalize her appreciation, Ms. Dern rolled her window and hollered out: ''Good Lord! You incredible Halloween creatures!'' The two slowly turned their heads to meet her gaze, and only at that moment did Ms. Dern realize that this was a friendship she did not want to pursue.

title: M5 Change Has Bus Riders Hiking
description: In any season, the walk along 135th Street from Riverside Drive to Broadway can be long. But in winter, the block often becomes a frigid wind tunnel, residents say.

title: Because You Are Mortal . . .
description: Every fall, publishers release more fat, important bios and autobios than you could read in, well, a lifetime. Unfortunately, with the holidays approaching, you might have to simulate an informed opinion on a few that stand out. As a public service, we've eased your burden by reading them for you.

title: Serb Village Is Reborn in Muslim Zone
description: There was not the slightest uncertainty in Dusan Djukanovic's judgment or his moves as he smelled the sweet plums fermenting in the vat and announced that they were ready for his wood-fired still, there to become brandy.

title: Lenders Cloaked in Anonymity, Revealed in Their Own Words
description: AN exhibition of American works on paper, called ''Lines of Thought,'' is at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme. The exhibition, from an unnamed private collection, is eclectic in terms of media and historical range, though certain grooves are well-worn. The collectors prefer representations of nature, especially flowers and landscapes. They favor human subjects, too, and almost every one on the walls is female. But what appears to most unify this collection is the premium placed on drafting ability.

title: For the Fall Table, Hearty and Fortifying Risotto
description: AUTUMN risottos have a personality all their own. Bolstered with butternut squash, mushrooms, cabbage and sausage and sturdy herbs like sage and thyme, they tend to be hearty and fortifying.

title: In Hawaii, Another Step Toward Same-Sex Weddings
description: Proponents of same-sex marriage scored a courtroom victory in Honolulu last week that left Hawaii possibly just one legal step away from allowing gay and lesbian couples to wed.

title: Here a Boxer, There a Bride
description: Five parties (one of them B.Y.O.-shovel) raise both spirits and cash.

title: France Asks European Neighbors to Be Alert for Bombing Suspects
description: French officials said today that they had asked their European neighbors to be alert for the terrorists who set off a bomb in a Paris commuter train on Tuesday.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SOLSTICE CELEBRATIONS

title: The Striped-Pants Crowd Gets Gumshoes
description: NEW YORK CITY'S Police Commissioner, Howard Safir, stepped into a diplomatic mess last month when he went to the Dominican Republic with a plan to station a few of the city's police officers in Santo Domingo. The very idea stirred the fury of Dominican nationalism and fears of Yankee imperialism. The nation's new President, Leonel Fernandez Reyna, took to ridiculing it. And the modest plan to try to staunch the flow of drugs and fugitives between the island nation and Upper Manhattan appeared to wither in a diplomatic tempest.

title: An Opening for Democrats To Turn the Tables on Taxes
description: Trying to recapture control of the New Jersey State House next year, Democrats last week began to lay the groundwork for the gubernatorial and legislative races by blaming Republicans for rising property tax bills.

title: Where to Run if the Ceiling Starts to Crack
description: TRUE, stocks have risen more than 50 percent since the end of 1994. True, the July drop, so scary at the time, now looks like a blip. And true, November was the Dow's best month in five years, in points gained.

title: Hallelujah! A Multitude of 'Messiah' Performances
description: CHURCH OF THE ASSUMPTION The 30-member New Jersey Chorale. Next Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and the elderly. 29 Jefferson Avenue, Emerson. (201) 262-1122.

title: Fans Outnumber Tickets At Rivals' Football Game
description: The traditional Thanksgiving Day football rivalry between the high school teams of Manasquan and Point Pleasant Borough, featured in a cover story in the New Jersey section on Nov. 24, was played before a sell-out crowd of more than 4,000. Manasquan won, 26 to 0.

title: Spreading the Lifesaving Message of CPR
description: ROBERT L. LENSETH the chief executive officer and general manager of the American Red Cross of Westchester County, knows firsthand the importance of learning cardio-pulmonary resuscitation. Two years ago, he saved his daughter's life by using CPR.

title: Puppets in Sicily
description: To the Editor: A high point in an Elderhostel trip to Palermo, Sicily, a few years ago was a visit to the puppet museum and theater described by Mary Taylor Simeti in ''The Stately Puppets of Sicily'' (Oct. 20). Forty-five of us were staying in Mondello, and the tourist bureau of Palermo sent a bus for us and entertained us at the puppet theater at no charge. They are making every effort to preserve this art.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: Sullivan eloquently described the emergence of hope on a previously hopeless landscape. Left unexplored, however, were the enormous challenges that remain before we really can declare an end to AIDS.

title: Carolyn S. Brodie, Stuart R. Gelles
description: Carolyn Sue Brodie, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Brodie of Roslyn, L.I., is to be married today to Stuart Roy Gelles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gelles of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Jack Riemer is to perform the ceremony at the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Figure in the Closet
description: INTERIOR DESIGN

title: Waiting for Elmo
description: FORTY grown-ups milled around four store shelves labeled ''Tickle Me Elmo'' at the Toys ''R'' Us store in Herald Square in Manhattan. The shelves were empty. With most other stores fresh out of Elmos, the hottest toy this Christmas, the rumor of replacement dolls had drawn a throng of desperate adults.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE WONDER CHILD: And Other Jewish Fairy Tales. Selected and retold by Howard Schwartz and Barbara Rush. Illustrated by Stephen Fieser. HarperCollins. $16.95. (Ages 8 and up) A collection of carefully annotated traditional fairy tales with Jewish settings in the Middle East and Eastern Europe. Some are variations on familiar stories, others surprisingly new. Suitable reading for any time of year.

title: Foley Steps Into the Fire As Quarterback for Jets
description: They give up more passing yards than any other team in the National Football League and they produce fewer sacks than anyone else. It is just the sort of defense a quarterback can't wait for.

title: It Takes a Little Push to Play the Big Screen
description: IT WAS THE MONDAY before Thanksgiving, and at Unapix, a small film and video company in New York, they were expecting word from Sundance, the important film festival in Utah. ''Pictures of Baby Jane Doe,'' a movie made by Unapix, was being considered for screening at the 1997 festival, in January, and a decision was due any day.

title: Youths' Pastime Disrupting Communities
description: LIKE elderly pensioners who take daily constitutionals along promenades on the French Riviera, students from the Robert E. Bell Middle School here view their Friday afternoon wanderings through the village center as a right, if not a rite of passage.

title: No Headline
description: ''Many companies don't want to lose experienced people and they don't want to keep them on expensive career tracks. So they have come up with contract-worker status for ex-employees. And that is an important step that companies are taking toward rewriting the implicit contract that bound them to their workers.''

title: The Darkest Days
description: These are the shortest days of the year. How does the darkness affect you? What do you do to counteract its effects?

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: I read the article while I was creating sculpture, as an artist-in-residence at the MacDowell Colony, in Peterborough, N.H. Just eight months ago my declining health would not have permitted me this experience. I am filled with gratitude for my own current healthy state since I started taking protease inhibitors last February as part of a study. However, within those months four of my friends have died of AIDS. While I, too, would like to celebrate the end of AIDS, my nine-year roller-coaster ride has taught me to be grateful but guarded when new miracle cures emerge.

title: What's Gained in Translation
description: Sadly, I could never claim to be a speaker of Russian. True, I once studied it for a short while, but I've never held a conversation or read a book in Russian. Given this, what would give me the chutzpah to write about, let alone think I could judge, various English translations of ''Eugene Onegin,'' that exemplary Russian novel in verse by that most Russian of Russian poets, Aleksandr Pushkin?

title: Monroe Green, 92, Times Advertising Director
description: Monroe Green, a former vice president of The New York Times who directed the newspaper's advertising department through more than two decades of significant innovation and growth, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92.

title: Thailand Restoring Pattaya Beach Resort
description: IN a vestige of the Vietnam War, nearly two-thirds of the people who visit Thailand today are men, many of them coming for the kind of red-light district R-and-R that attracted soldiers on leave from the battlefields.

title: Retailers and Diehard Shoppers Plunge Into the Busy Season
description: In a corner of the vast Kids World here the most mega of mega-stores, where grand-opening traffic jams briefly shut down the New Jersey Turnpike -- John and Alice Schreiner were doing some figuring.

title: Elliott Puckette, Hugo Guinness
description: Charlotte Elliott Puckette, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Puckette of Sewanee, Tenn., was married yesterday at the Carlyle in New York to Hugo Arthur Rundell Guinness, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. A. R. Guinness of Heckfield, England. The Rev. Jon Mundy, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony.

title: More Downsized Workers Are Returning as Rentals
description: The call came while Linda Corbett was in her yard gardening. A supervisor at Pacific Bell, a man she knew, told her that his staff was overwhelmed with work. He wanted to know whether Ms. Corbett would consider returning to the company from which, just six months earlier, she had been ''severed involuntarily,'' as she still puts it bitterly.

title: A Coach Who Pushed Sees His Team Pushed Aside
description: The altar boy swaggered through the gyms of Brooklyn in a bomber jacket, intimidating tough guys with a ''ghetto stare'' he practiced in the mirror and a machine-gun rap that drowned out the knocking of his knees. Few knew that Gerard Papa had a Columbia law degree and lived at home with his mother. For more than 20 years, the bluff worked; he created one of the country's most successful shoestring, grass roots basketball organizations, each year serving 500 youngsters, from 8 to 20 years old, mostly black and Hispanic.

title: Cheryl A. Milone and Andrew L. Bab
description: Cheryl Ann Milone and Andrew Laurance Bab, associates at New York law firms, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated at the Yale Club, and the Rev. Dr. John M. Morley, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: There is much to be optimistic about in the world of AIDS care, and Sullivan is correct: the plague will end -- at least for those with access to health care and expensive therapies. However, his article perpetuates a misunderstanding of the meaning of viral loads and current therapies. This misperception began with the media frenzy prompted by Dr. David Ho's theorizing about ''cure'' at the international meeting in Vancouver this past July.

title: The Tax Omission
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncle Duane's curious Christmas list, a sensible collection of bizarre confections and real gifts for imaginary friends
description: Recently my cat told me that she had been my wife, once upon a time ago in another life. Then she said when we were wed that I had been a mouse, and that her name had been Babette, and they called me Klaus. Suspiciously I asked for proof. Weas this a cunning pussy spoof? Then she recalled a secret just the two of us had shared. She said my favorite Christmas gift was always Camembert. Suddenly, epiphany and I could see Babette, and how I loved her long ago and how I love her yet.

title: Nets Fall Face Down in Swamp in Loss to Pistons
description: The Nets thought they knew each other better, believed the awkwardness of a new team, a new coach and a new way of doing things had worn off.

title: Gardening
description: A long with the seed catalogue, the book lies at the heart of the winter garden. Through its pages the gardener, who has worked more or less in isolation all summer, steps out into the wider gardening world, renewing his acquaintance with other gardeners and returning with a rich store of information -- the printed kind, of course, but also, assuming he's been inspired to order a new plant or two, the genetic kind. Undertaken in a comfortable chair or even in bed, this paper gardening might seem idle compared with the work of weeding and mulching, but arguably it is as crucial to the success of next year's garden as any of the more sweaty seasonal pursuits. For without the fresh ideas and novel genes proposed by winter's books and catalogues, next spring's garden would offer nothing new. At least, that's what I tell myself when I absolutely must have this new book about shrubs that, at $59.95, costs more than any existing shrub in my garden.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: I am the last survivor of 11 gay men who founded the people with AIDS self-empowerment movement, in 1983. One key to surviving AIDS is to learn to distinguish between unsubstantiated hope and established fact.

title: Daniel Rosberger, Sonam Tshering
description: Dr. Sonam Lhaden Tshering, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angkoo Tshering of Huntington, L.I., is to be married today to Dr. Daniel Fredric Rosberger, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Rosberger of New York. Rabbi Gerald Goldman is to perform the ceremony at the Sutton Hotel in New York.

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: Show biz, chutzpah and a rigid, conservative ideology have defined success in the 90's. Schlessinger has brought these qualities to talk-radio therapy. Yet she is full of contradictions. She denounces feminism. Does she not remember when the voices on radio were exclusively male? She has been divorced but insists that couples with children must (under any circumstances) stay together and work at it.

title: Shipping Deal Promises Jobs
description: After decades of decline, shipping in Red Hook is hitting a new high -- with a little help. A deal announced by the city's Economic Development Corporation is expected to bring 10,000 additional cargo containers a year to the Red Hook Container Terminal and create an estimated 374 new on- and off-site jobs.

title: Georges Duby, 77, a Scholar Of Medieval Societies, Is Dead
description: Georges Duby, one of the world's great medieval scholars and a member of the Academie Francaise, died on Tuesday at his home in Aix-en-Provence in southern France. He was 77.

title: From Cuba, Gilded Palms and Hearty Spices
description: At the Hardgrove Cafe, the secret is in the sufrito. That's the sauce of tomato, onions, garlic, oregano and cumin basic to Cuban cuisine prepared by the chef, Rafael Valdespino. He is a former biology professor at the University of Havana who teamed with two of his fellow Cuban expatriates, Dominic and Mercedes Santana, as they were opening the Hardgrove two years ago in downtown Jersey City.

title: The Fed Tries To Deflate A Bubble
description: What's a Federal Reserve chairman to do when speculation is running rampant?

title: Man Is Dismissed Over a Game's Gay Images
description: A rogue computer programmer was dismissed last week after secretly coding thousands of copies of a store-bound computer game to create animated images of men kissing each other, the game's manufacturer said.

title: Mugged by Reality
description: NOT LONG AGO, A CLASS OF HARVARD GRADUATE students joined their distinguished professor in a study of public attitudes toward welfare. That is, they opened their notebooks and switched on a tape of ''Oprah.''

title: Developers' Hazard: Legal Hardball
description: NO one knows yet whether the Columbus Circle redevelopment project will wind up as a Sears or Sotheby's, a Reebok health spa or the Museum of American Folk Art, a swank hotel or a high-priced condominium apartment tower. But there is one safe bet. It will almost certainly wind up in court.

title: At Last, The South Loses Well
description: The novelist Walker Percy was often asked why so many darkly comic writers of genius arose from the American South. He answered, ''Because we lost.'' Then he laughed, with a shaman's economy and a cracker's certainty.

title: Bountiful Indian Cuisine in Apt Surroundings
description: SOOTHING sitar music fills the air, tuxedoed waiters glide by, diners savor an array of exotic dishes in an atmosphere of elegant serenity amidst ornate Indian antiques, temple carvings and art. Bombay? Calcutta? Manhattan? No, the Jericho Turnpike in Syosset at midday, where an elaborate Indian buffet is served seven days a week at the new Jewel of India, 347 Jericho Turnpike (677-9898).

title: All Aboard for New York, if There's Parking Near the Train
description: For months, Maureen Monahan looked forward to the opening of New Jersey Transit's Midtown Direct train service, which promised to whisk residents of Morris, Essex, Union and Somerset counties, for the first time, straight into Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

title: From Paris With Love: Raspberries
description: FRANCE'S closest friend through the years has probably been the United States, the ally the French most love to hate. President Jacques Chirac considers himself an Americanophile, but in France this term is relative. Like de Gaulle, Mr. Chirac has been poking the United States in the eye lately, making trouble for plans to reorganize the NATO alliance, among other things.

title: It Was a Very Good Year
description: December 1-7 Correction: December 15, 1996, Sunday

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: Schlessinger's doctorate in physiology qualifies her to treat ingrown toenails, perhaps, but not troublesome libidos.

title: Lessons and Carols, Irish Ballads, Too
description: THE Connecticut Chamber Choir and its music director, Richard Erickson, offer ''A Candlelight Christmas'' this afternoon at 4 at United Congregational Church in Bridgeport. John La Montaine's ''Nine Lessons of Christmas,'' Randol Alan Bass's ''Christmas Flourish'' and carol settings by John Rutter, William Mathias and Bob Chilcott will be performed.

title: A Benz for Baby, a Safety Belt for Spot
description: WHEN the social philosopher Marshall McLuhan wrote, ''The car has become an article of dress without which we feel uncertain, unclad and incomplete,'' he might have understated the attachment of many drivers to their cars. After all, most people don't talk to their pants or name their jackets. But Americans often treat their automobiles like children, friends or lovers -- as objects of affection to be protected by alarms, caressed with creams, sheltered in garages and spoiled with gifts.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: How Landfills Could Light Up Houses
description: LATELY, the Groton landfill has had visitors from several countries, including Russia and South Africa. ''It's going to be on the tourism map soon,'' joked John C. Trocciola, who was there on a recent Sunday afternoon to welcome two officials from China.

title: Christmas, Victorian Style, At Lockwood-Mathews
description: THE Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk has created a winter exhibition around a Victorian American Christmas celebration.

title: Dropping Formalities Helps Doctor and Patient Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Facets of Islam Refracted in a New York Lens
description: AS SHE PARKED HER RED Volvo station wagon on a busy shopping street in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn the other day, Jerrilynn D. Dodds, wearing a putty-colored Armani jacket, looked for all the world like a well-heeled hostess venturing into an ethnic neighborhood in search of exotic recipe ingredients. But when she flipped on a voluminous matching head scarf, the 45-year-old professor at the school of architecture at City College seemed transformed. The process was completed as she stepped inside the deceptively nondescript entrance to the Fatih Camii Mosque, slipped off her shoes and greeted the imam with a fluent ''Salaam aleikum.''

title: Rodent Virus Strikes People in Patagonia
description: In the past two months, at least 10 people in Patagonia, Argentina, are believed to have died from a hantavirus, which is transmitted to people who have close contact with rodents or their waste. But health officials from the United States and Argentina say it is safe for tourists to visit the country and affected areas, providing they exercise certain precautions.

title: Dismissed Workers at Javits Center to Sue
description: Two hundred union members who worked at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center plan to file a lawsuit next week charging that Gov. George E. Pataki and the center's leaders violated the workers' constitutional rights when they were dismissed as part of an effort to end union corruption at the center.

title: Fair Game? Town Protests Pigeon Shoots
description: THE pigeons started showing up at Carl Rancan's horse farm two years ago. A few appeared in the barn one day. Others followed. Before long, there were dozens huddling on the rafters above the stables, hobbling around the haystacks, dropping dead all over the place.

title: Brown Is Fighting, Quietly, Through Giants' Turmoil
description: His must be made of super-reinforced concrete, because there have been few cracks in the armor of Dave Brown despite everything that has gone on around him. It has been said that he couldn't throw a ball into the ocean. Half of Brown's practice snaps have been given to his backup, Danny Kanell, an unnoticed, unheard-of move that is fueling speculation that Coach Dan Reeves is preparing to bench Brown. The coaching staff gives Brown little public support and, in fact, it is no secret around the Giants that one of the coaches trashes Brown to other offensive players.

title: Two Buddies At the Ballet, As Promised
description: Lauren Abruzzo and Rachel Mallory have been friends for years (well, since 1993, but they are only 9). So when they auditioned for the New York City Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker'' this year, they vowed that they would join the production only if they both were offered parts.

title: Mary Higgins Clark, John Conheeney
description: Mary Higgins Clark is almost as well known for the story of her life as she is for her suspense novels or the fact that she is paid $12 million a book, almost as much as Demi Moore's film price.

title: American Fare and People-Watching
description: AMERICAN food at reasonable prices with great people watching'' is what the recently opened Montgomery's in Roslyn Heights promises. It delivers that and more. Managed by Bobby Ochs, partner with Patrick Swayze, the actor, at the Mulholland Drive Cafe in Manhattan, it is aiming for the same ambiance. Additionally, Ken Falk, who was chef at the Manhattan restaurant until it closed last spring, is in the kitchen at Montgomery's.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: A Conspiracy at the L.I.R.R.?
description: SO you don't believe in conspiracy theories? Wait. Right here on Long Island, we have a highly visible organization clearly in the hands of some sinister not-yet-identified group. It is successfully demoralizing New Yorkers, slowly eroding their ability to function and their will to work.

title: Some Dangers In Shopping Malls
description: The interview with Steven B. Tanger $(Long Island Q&A, Nov. 3$) lacked some credibility in that all the questions seemed to be posed to give Mr. Tanger the best possible opportunity to present himself and his super malls as benefits to our economy and quality of life.

title: Milosevic Seems to Soften In the Face of Protests
description: Opposition leaders in Serbia have regularly been mustering crowds of 100,000 in the streets of Belgrade to protest the annulment of local elections that they won. The target of the protests, President Slobodan Milosevic, shut down the last independent news radio station on Tuesday and appeared on state television to denounce the protesters as ''rampaging hordes.''

title: Photography
description: Straightforward, reportorial photography, upstaged of late by more artful and self-conscious styles, has made a comeback this season. There are worthy volumes of classic black-and-white photojournalism, both vintage (''Robert Capa: Photographs''; ''Chim: The Photographs of David Seymour'') and recent (Ian Berry's ''Living Apart''; ''Benedict J. Fernandez: Protest. Photographs 1963-1995''; Alex Webb's ''From the Sunshine State''). But the most gripping photographic reports on the real world this year come from outside the realm of photojournalism.

title: Another Gulf War Mystery: Gaps in the Combat Logs
description: The mystery over the health complaints of thousands of gulf-war veterans only grew murkier last week, as the Pentagon announced that it could not explain gaps in combat logs that should have recorded the detection of chemical or biological weapons during the 1991 conflict. The logs are considered vital evidence to ailing veterans who believe that the Pentagon is hiding proof that they were exposed to chemicals or biological agents on the battlefield.

title: 15 Years Of Fujimori? Peru Faces Its Future
description: The next presidential election is not scheduled until 2000, but Peru is already engaged in an intense debate over whether President Alberto K. Fujimori should run for a third term.

title: Greenburgh Seeking Cable TV Competition
description: AS part of a never-ending quest to bring choice to this town's cable customers, Greenburgh Supervisor Paul J. Feiner conducted a forum on cable television competition late last month. Despite the chill night air, about two dozen interested residents showed up at Town Hall to hear presentations by representatives of TCI Cable, which currently provides service to Greenburgh customers, and a satellite-dish service, Global Satellite Network, which distributes the Digital Sky Highway Network.

title: Another Perspective On Newark's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: Schlessinger not only insults her callers, she insults my profession by calling herself a shrink. Dr. Laura is an entertainer, ignorant of what goes on in therapy (empathy, for one thing); she herself is a candidate for treatment. Being mad at Mommy for 10 years cries out for examination.

title: Hearty, Fortifying Risotto for the Fall Table
description: AUTUMN risottos have a personality all their own. Bolstered with butternut squash, mushrooms, cabbage and sausage, and sturdy herbs like sage and thyme, they tend to be hearty and fortifying.

title: Article Misstated Views On Multicultural Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Girlfriend Tracy. Guy Pathetic.
description: ''If your boss, wife or jealous lover shows up unannounced,'' says the instructional materials for Girlfriend Tracy, a cutting-edge, interactive CD-ROM for lonely-heart guys, ''just press the ESCape key. . . . A meaningless but serious-looking spreadsheet will appear on your screen.'' Fine, but if you're reduced to this, you may also want to hide from the smirking gods of love. Tracy's creators stress that unlike all other sex-oriented CD-ROM characters, she operates with powerful artificial intelligence -- enough to mimic ''the response of a human female'' when you write sexy commands. To test this, we created two suitors with very different styles. As our cyberboys learned during a visit to Tracy's swank pad, she can react to different approaches, but whatever happens, her startlingly non sequitur personality creates a truly, er, unique dating experience.

title: Frenzied Critique
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gay Party Planet Moves Into a Wider Orbit
description: They came in white stretch limos, rental convertibles and tour buses. They came on drugs and off them, to find Mr. Right or to get over Mr. Wrong, to gape or to be gaped at, for a good cause or for far more selfish impulses.

title: Unplug It, Drive It
description: A few years back, when other states and Washington were arguing endlessly about what to do about tailpipe smog and an overdependence on foreign oil, California went off and decreed that, by year 2003, 1 of every 10 cars sold in the state would have to be powered by electricity.

title: SLEEPY-TIME ART
description: 1. One of six finalists will grab $50,000 on Tuesday, when the winner of the first annual Hugo Boss Prize is announced at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo. 2. Judging by the entries, it may be time to reverse the old cliche about modern art to: ''My 4-year-old is forbidden to do that.'' One competitor, Cai Guo Qiang, built a huge raft made of inflated sheepskins, ''powered'' by three Toyota engines. 3. Another, Yasumasa Morimura, served up large photographs of himself in drag. 4. But we vote for Janine Antoni, who slept in the gallery and weaved strips of her nightgown into a blanket patterned on her electroencephalogram. ''It's wonderful sleeping inside your own work,'' says Antoni. ''I hope viewers will feel that intimacy. It's like coming into my bedroom.''

title: Unitarians Striking Chord of Spirituality
description: When the Rev. Thomas J. S. Mikelson told his congregation one Sunday in April that he would end the worship with a healing service for anyone who felt physically or emotionally afflicted, he had no idea how church members would respond. With other ministers on the staff, he stood there, he said, ''waiting to see if anyone would come down the aisle.''

description: A PLAYWRIGHT declares that he has written a role, a summit role as it happens, for one special actor, 22 years older.

description: IN THE SUMMER OF 1974, WHEN I was 12 years old, I received what amounted to permission to run away with the circus. Actually, I ran away with Ellen Stewart's La Mama Experimental Theater Club.

description: Two juvenile detention centers that were scheduled to be completed this month to replace Spofford, now the city's main youth detention facility, have faced a number of construction setbacks and are not likely to open before next summer.

title: Devils' Line Score: Two Goalies, One Loss
description: A sarcastic cheer filled Continental Arena this afternoon when Mike Dunham, the starting goaltender for the Devils, made a routine save shortly after giving up his third goal of the game. It was early in the third period, on the 10th shot he faced from the Phoenix Coyotes. Soon after, Coach Jacques Lemaire pulled Dunham and put in the team's No. 1 goalie, Martin Brodeur.

title: 4 Abstractionists Make Up A Show of Personal Bests
description: THE confrontation at Pace University here is between an exhibition and its setting art and architecture, the present age of unreason and the Enlightenment.

title: Learning to Love London Deluxe
description: ON hearing that my husband and I would be staying at three elegant London hotels, nearly all our friends seemed gripped by a fiercely protective urge to spare us the humiliating slights they feared we might endure. ''Do you have the clothes for those places?'' inquired S., while C. told a story about lunching at the Ritz and being asked to put on his (somewhat rumpled) jacket, which a hotel employee appraised and then inquired, in a disdainful falsetto, ''Sir, is that really a . . . jacket, Sir?'' Recently, in London, when G. tried to help a room-service waiter with a heavy tray, he was rewarded with a withering look, ''because I wouldn't just sit there and be served like the King of England.''

title: Street Watches Gotschl Win
description: It was a trying day for Picabo Street today as the women's World Cup downhill race went on without her. But Street, who tore knee ligaments in a season-ending fall Wednesday, was at the race course anyway.

description: A look at trouble spots you can expect to encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of the State Department of Transportation.

title: Erin's looking for Leg-Rub Steve. Fly's looking for CD's to steal. Star's looking for Jaya. And it's starting to get cold.
description: THERE ARE MANY WAYS TO EARN MONEY ON ST. Marks Place if you are young and have no regular place to stay, and Erin, who is known as ''Nothing'' by his fellow street punks, is waiting around to tap into one of the street's most regular, and lucrative, sources. ''There is a guy,'' he says, ''who is going to pay me $150 to stroke his leg.'' A grim prospect, but Erin says that others who have done it swear that the guy, called Leg-Rub Steve, demands nothing more than what his nickname implies. And in whatever short time things take with Steve, Erin figures he will earn more than he does in several days the only other way he makes cash: to hold out an empty paper cup and present himself -- a tall, healthy 19-year-old with green-blue eyes and bright green hair -- begging for spare change. New Yorkers, he says sourly, are not sympathetic.

description: In your Oct. 27 Connecticut Q&A (''A Psychiatrist Talks About Social Policy''), Dr. Herbert S. Sacks unfortunately mischaracterized the merger of U. S. Healthcare and Aetna when he said the money we paid U. S. Healthcare came from ''the denial and interruption of medically necessary patient care.''

Jim Ruban of Ringwood, a longtime professor of art at William Paterson College until he retired in 1991, is in the last category.

description: Even with their captain out, the Rangers kept rolling on. They polished off the woeful Toronto Maple Leafs for the second consecutive night, this time by 4-0 in a tepid, tedious show at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: Pete Rozelle Dies at 70; Led N.F.L.'s Growth Years
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner who presided over the changes that made the National Football League the premier professional sports organization over the last four decades, died at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., on Friday. He was 70.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the View column, about coffee shops in Larchmont, misidentified a patron at Aroma Coffee. He was Eric Newland, not Ned Purves.

title: Same Roots, Same Tree, Ever New Branches
description: PERHAPS THE MOST impressive aspect of Steve Reich's music is its integrity. Though his language has grown methodically over three decades, Mr. Reich has never repudiated his Minimalist roots, compromised his idiom for commercial gain or purveyed safely defanged banalities. Few living composers have created a style so fiercely original, immediately recognizable and wholly accessible.

title: Opportunity May Knock in 'Scratch and Dent' Stocks
description: WHILE last week brought stocks down a bit, the long bull market has posed a chronic problem: With so many issues at such high levels, where is an investor to put new money?

title: Bissell Case Spurs Calls for Trenton to Rein In Officials
description: In 1983, a year after Nicholas L. Bissell Jr. became Somerset County Prosecutor, he filed a lawsuit to remove Franklin Township's Mayor from office. His complaint? Misconduct in office, he said, because she had distributed fliers at a township Council meeting criticizing a police investigation of several rapes.

title: You Call, She Shops. She Calls You, She Shops. She Never Drops.
description: Forget snow; forget mistletoe; forget the roaring fire. Here's the ultimate holiday fantasy: a gift for all the people on your list, the right size, the right color, wrapped and sent directly to their doors. With just one phone call.

title: INSIDE
description: Paris on the Hudson?

title: When Artists Took Charge in the Glass Factories
description: TODAY THE TERM SWEDISH Modern glass instantly connotes works of artistry and imagination. But it wasn't always that way. At the turn of the century, Swedish glass was considered boring, regardless of how expertly it was made. Then beginning in 1916 artists were hired to redesign those machine-made products. The Swedish Modern style that emerged was unexpectedly dynamic. Characterized by abstract patterns, bubbly phantom images and engraved mythological scenes, the style was quickly imitated internationally.

title: Rita Rubin, Michael Broder
description: Rita Lynne Rubin, a senior editor at U.S. News & World Report in Washington, and Dr. Michael Waldman Broder, a microbiologist at the Environmental Protection Agency, were married last evening. Rabbi Robert Saks performed the ceremony at the Marriott Hotel in Bethesda, Md.

title: Q. & A.
description: Edinburgh Military Tattoo

title: The Internet's Arrested Development
description: A COUPLE OF WEEKS AGO, during a long afternoon surfing the Internet, I experienced an overload. First I checked my E-mail (messages from the kids, from a former colleague setting up a lunch date and from someone in an electronic discussion group I joined a few months ago, talking about the Battle of Trafalgar). Then I made a brisk electronic tour of the Uffizi and the Louvre. I read some valuable tips on lockpicking written by someone named Ted the Tool. I checked out the standings on the College Hockey home page. I browsed through the various on-line journals -- Slate, Salon, Hotwired, Suck, Feed and Swoon. I consulted a weather map customized for my neighborhood. I visited the poetry archive at the University of Toronto and ran a little search on the number of times the word ''thistle'' turns up in Byron. I window-shopped -- screen-shopped -- for a yacht in the Buzzards Bay classifieds. I stopped by the Kraft Interactive Kitchen and watched the dancing utensils for a while. I went to the Timothy Leary home page and read some of the gibberish posted there by fans of the doctor. I also went to the Internet cemetery, a place where people leave testimonials to their departed loved ones. And then somehow I found myself by the pool at the Cybercity Hotel, sipping my third or fourth virtual martini.

title: New Partnership Draws Business to County
description: IN what can certainly be described as a good fit, the newly formed Westchester Partnership for Economic Development began its work by helping to bring a major shoe company to the county.

title: Don't Lose Your Heart To Yankees
description: THE night the Yankees won the World Series, Joe Torre described it as ''like a dreamland for me.'' David Cone said, ''This is a team that New York can really relate to.'' Bernie Williams said, ''Winning here, winning in New York, it's the best.'' Joe Girardi said, ''I truly feel blessed.''

title: Where Your Money Really Goes
description: Yes, you need to be smart about when and how you make a donation, but you should also be smart about where you put your money. Many nonprofit organizations have been criticized as spending too much on administration and related costs and not enough on good deeds.

title: Travel
description: Whatever happened to the know-it-all travel book? Handy guides to every imaginable backwater continue to flourish, telling what's open when, and where to find a decent -- or not so decent -- hotel. And reporters home from foreign assignments still check in with highly perishable accounts of what they've just learned abroad. But where are those solid, seasoned (and often all too deadly) studies of a region by an old hand who knows the place cold -- past, present and future -- and wants to get every bit of it into one hefty book?

title: She Who Wields Scissors, Wields Power
description: FILM historians treat only two Hollywood genres as truly classic, the gangster film and the western. But what about the biblical epic, which usually gets thrown on the pile with vampire films, juvenile-delinquency shockers and beach movies? Where are the forward-looking critics who will do honor to the noble line that stretches from the spectacles of Cecil B. DeMille to ''King David'' with Richard Gere, whose golden age in the 1950's and 60's brought forth ''The Greatest Story Ever Told,'' ''The Robe,'' ''The Bible,'' ''The Ten Commandments'' and ''Ben-Hur''?

title: Sharon Wolmer and Alan Portnoi
description: Sharon Ann Wolmer, the daughter of Eileen Wolmer and Dr. Donald H. Wolmer of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married last evening to Alan Scott Portnoi, the son of Eileen and Lawrence Portnoi of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Philip Berkowitz performed the ceremony at Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: St. John's Learns Heart Doesn't Beat Villanova
description: They played with passion, aggression and heart. All the buzzwords that Coach Fran Fraschilla is hoping will someday be synonymous with St. John's basketball. But it was talent and depth that proved the difference yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden, two things that the Villanova Wildcats have far more of than the Red Storm.

title: Rozelle's N.F.L. Legacy: Television, Marketing and Money
description: Early in his reign as the National Football League's commissioner, Pete Rozelle divined the inequity in the Giants reaping $350,000 a year for their television rights, 10 times what the Green Bay Packers received. He argued that the teams' hodgepodge of individual deals may have benefited some in the short run, but a single network deal would reap a fortune in the long term.

title: Foreign Affairs Big Mac I
description: So I've had this thesis for a long time and came here to Hamburger University at McDonald's headquarters to finally test it out. The thesis is this: No two countries that both have a McDonald's have ever fought a war against each other.

title: Shooting Monkeys Through Cameras
description: IN 1994, Noel Rowe and his bride, Abigail Barber, traveled to a swamp in the Niger River Delta on their honeymoon. Mr. Rowe, a photographer, picked the muddy delta because he was on a mission to photograph a rare subspecies of the red colobus monkey that inhabits the area.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Nov. 17, about getting to Manhattan from airports in the New York area, referred incorrectly to fares on three bus services. The Q-10 from Kennedy and the Q-33 and Q-47 from La Guardia do not accept the Metrocard; this is not expected until 1998. The fare on these buses is $1, not $1.50, except during weekday rush hours. (These buses accept dollar bills, and not coins exclusively.)

title: Big Candy Bars, Small Gain
description: IT'S school fund-raising season, that time from October through May when parents and loved ones are asked to buy everything from gift wrap to grapefruit.

description: The historic Hotel Metropole in Hanoi, now under the management of the Accor Group and known as the Hotel Sofitel Metropole Hanoi, has opened a new wing. The number of guest rooms, previously 109, has more than doubled, reaching a total of 244.

title: The Survival of the Most Efficient
description: IT seems that everybody you talk to nowadays is working harder. Blue-collar workers put in more overtime. Professionals and business executives spend ungodly hours at the office. Nonunion office and service employees commonly hold two or three part-time jobs.

description: REVIVING a play is meant to be an affirming thing. How then to explain the killing of ''The Show-Off'' at the Long Wharf Theater?

title: Jacketeering
description: Browsing in a bookstore not long ago, I came, by happy chance, upon ''the scientific discovery of the century, if not of all time'' (as no less a dignitary than Stephen Hawking called the book I held in my hand). Nearby was a volume with sex and spirituality in the title that was described (by a doctor, on the front cover) as ''one of the most significant books ever published.'' I let my eye stray farther down the table: ''Imagine Vladimir Nabokov and Anne Rice collaborating to produce a historical novel in the tradition of Mary Renault.'' Imagine! ''If a manic J. G. Ballard and a depressed David Lodge got together,'' said one book jacket, they could produce something to sit on the same shelf as the first novel of another author, who ''writes like some pixilated offspring of a secret liaison between J. D. Salinger and Isabel Allende.''

title: The Festival Director as Un-Renaissance Man
description: FESTIVALS ARE THE WAY people greet the changing seasons. Nature gives and takes away with regularity over the period of a year; ritual helps our spirits adjust to every turn. Now it is Christmas: the most comfort-seeking festival of all. The Christmas festival, set in the dead of winter, is about remembering life. Its nourishment is the past.
