A remarkable example of that last possibility is BAKING WITH JULIA (Morrow, $40), based on the 39 half-hour shows in Julia Child's Master Chef series that displayed the work of 26 stellar bakers, including Nick Malgieri, Nancy Silverton and Alice Medrich.

Given any other sitcom principal, this would be a charming detail, but it is almost chilling when connected to Mr. McDowell, the British actor whose name is associated with some of the most sinister performances in film. It makes you wonder what happened to the kid.

title: Architecture
description: ICONOGRAPHY AND ELECTRONICS UPON A GENERIC ARCHITECTURE: A View From the Drafting Room. By Robert Venturi. (MIT, $40.) As the author of one of this century's most influential texts on the building art, ''Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture,'' the Philadelphia-based architect Robert Venturi is in the unenviable position of having every subsequent book of his measured against that 1966 classic. Yet this absorbing new collection of Mr. Venturi's exceptionally literate articles, lectures, letters and aphorisms written over the past two decades offers rewarding insights into a creative intelligence as wide-ranging and iconoclastic as ever. In several respects this is the most thought-provoking architecture book of the year.

Tony Hillerman poses this puzzler in THE FALLEN MAN (HarperCollins, $24), another gripping chapter in the evocative series he sets on the vast Indian reservation that sprawls across Arizona and New Mexico.

description: There's always some cheap, stain-challenged wretch at a cocktail party who, upon learning that Wayne Edelman is a dry cleaner, excuses himself from the lawyer or therapist in his clutch and corners the owner of Meurice Garment Care for some advice, gratis.

title: Short on Cash? Try Parting With Stock, a Computer or an '85 Buick
description: Many charities are not fussy about what they accept. Don't have cash to donate? Maybe you have something else a charity can use, like a computer, or something it can turn into cash, like stock.

title: Can Country Embrace This Rebel?
description: IS THERE A COUNTRY SINGER SO underappreciated as Johnny Paycheck? His biggest hit, ''Take This Job and Shove It'' from 1977, remains the sound bite that most remember him by. Yet he has made 30 years' worth of wrenchingly expressive recordings, including songs from a brightly burning early period that should place him among the finest singers in American music. Now, ''The Real Mr. Heartache,'' a well-annotated reissue (on the Country Music Foundation label) of Mr. Paycheck's mid-60's work, appears at a moment when part of Nashville may be circling back to his old sound.

title: Witnesses to History
description: THE CHINESE CENTURY

title: Giuliani Orders a Review of Parking Rules
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had ordered a review of New York City's alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations in response to complaints from some drivers in Chelsea and Greenwich Village after the rules were tightened in October.

title: Maximum Blooms From Minimum Care
description: THE African violet is probably the most popular house plant grown. Few homes are without at least one. Many growers may have several, while hobbyists and hybridists grow them by the hundreds.

title: Prosecutors Say Videotaped Meetings Back Their Evidence That Suspect Incited Crowd
description: In September and November of 1995, two old acquaintances met in a Brooklyn apartment. Charles Johnson proposed to rob a drug dealer's home. He asked Charles Price for help.

title: A Vote Against D.H.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Army Rally Holds Up, But Just Barely
description: The greatest comeback in 106 years of Army-Navy football games was nearly not enough.

title: BENEFITS
description: Just One Break

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Local Climates

title: U.S. Taking Cautious Approach in Talks on Global Warming
description: The Clinton Administration is taking a cautious approach toward negotiations this coming week on new measures to head off global warming due to air pollution.

title: From Dealmakers to Peacemakers
description: The assessment came from people on both sides: the new labor agreement would not have been possible without the behind-the-scenes initiatives of a group of player agents.

title: One Size Doesn't Fit
description: IN almost any other country in the world, the announcement would have caused yawns.

title: Japanese Hotels
description: To the Editor: More than 20 years ago my husband and I toured Japan for two weeks. One of the highlights was a two-day stay at the legendary Hotel Fujiya in the mountainous region of Hakone, discussed by Sheryl WuDunn in ''Hakone, Once Stern, Now Soothes'' (Nov. 10).

title: Gifts of Gab for 1997
description: A COFFEE STORE that calls itself Sufficient Grounds; a costume-rental outfit named Disguise the Limit; an antiquarian bookshop under a sign that says Yellow Pages; a Chinese food carryout advertising itself as Wok Around the Clock.

title: That's Why The Lady Is a Fan
description: There are Frank Sinatra devotees, and then there's Bernice Perry, a New Yorker who believes that the legendary crooner -- sick or well, alive or deceased -- actually has healing power. Perry (at right) says she first experienced it following complications from a 1972 workplace accident. Unable to walk, she prayed to God and to Sinatra. ''Every day, Mr. Sinatra gives me the strength to get my feet off the bed,'' says Perry, 72, who today walks with a cane. She has written 30 poems in homage (''Mr. Francis Albert Sinatra . . . king among all people/you are the divine man projecting lush sounds'') and pays weekly tribute on her own public-access TV show, ''Lady Bernice Perry Frankly Speaking in Sinatra Land.'' This week's topic: Dec. 12, 1915, which is -- what else? Sinatra's birthday.

title: Mothers and Daughters: Tracing the Oeuvre
description: Relatively Speaking: Mothers and Daughters in Art

title: Christine Looes, Rory T. Welch
description: Christine Ann Looes, an insurance executive, was married yesterday to Rory Timothy Welch, an electronics distribution manager. The Rev. John Negrotto performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of St. Barnabas in Irvington, N.Y.

title: Touring China's Past, and a Bit of America's
description: WHEN you're sleeping in New York, it's tomorrow afternoon in China. This fact was driven home to me at 2 o'clock one September morning, when my fax machine droned into action, delivering a message from the China International Travel Service (CITS) in Chongqing, where an agent named Irene Peng was on the job while I was in bed.

title: Naughty Victorians
description: THE COMPLETE ANNOTATED GILBERT AND SULLIVAN

title: Needed: More Reviews And Better Attitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: Nantucket Reawakens for Its Annual Off-Season Highlight
description: Even a dozen years ago, this time of year on Nantucket was sleepy. Anyone could get a parking space on the cobblestones of Main Street after the resort island had shrunk back to its off-season population of fewer than 6,000, and the gray-shingled shops were shuttered for the most part, hibernating for the winter.

title: No Credit Needed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HOW A QUACK BECOMES A CANARD
description: Here are a couple of ways in which a quack can become a canard (''How a Quack Becomes a Canard,'' by Jonathan Vankin and John Whalen, Nov. 17):

title: Mary, a Force for All Cultures and Religions
description: FOR 50 years, Jaroslav Pelikan has forged an unusual career charting the parallel developments of culture and religion in Western civilization with his books, lectures and courses, most notably at Yale University in New Haven from 1962 until his retirement last year. Now Sterling Professor of History Emeritus at Yale, Dr. Pelikan is president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

title: I Say, These Train Fellows Are Sharpening Up
description: STILL smarting from the film that gave the world the false impression that trainspotters were a bunch of shiftless heroin addicts, Britain's real trainspotters are struggling to improve their extremely tarnished image.

title: Dow Wants Implant Settlement To Hinge on a 'Science' Trial
description: Dow Corning, formerly the nation's largest producer of silicone breast implants, proposed last week to set aside $2 billion for up to 30 years to meet all potential claims from women who say they were injured by the implants. The hitch: before any money is paid out, there would be a ''science'' trial in which a single jury would decide whether there was adequate proof that silicone leaking from the implants could cause the conditions for which they are blamed, including pain, decreased mobility and memory loss. Dow proposed that if it won that trial, no more than $600 million should be set aside for implant claims.

title: Standing Room Only (And That's Not Good)
description: SOMEONE I KNOW RECEIVED AN invitation to the opening night of ''Cakewalk,'' Peter Feibleman's new play about Lillian Hellman at the Variety Arts Theater. Learning that he had been assigned choice seats down front, he was seized by a peculiarly modern form of stage fright.

title: A Once Proud Industry Fends Off Extinction
description: Correction Appended

title: Editor's Choice
description: In the judgment of the nine editors of the Book Review, the best books of 1996 include a novel, three collections of short stories, a memoir, a biography and two books about life -- to be sure, about different kinds of extinction, in a sense, but sometimes life is like that. The writers are an Indian man living very guardedly in England; two Canadian women, one living in Paris; an Irishman who lives in England; an English immigrant to the United States; a native New Yorker who grew up in Ireland; a New Yorker who stayed home; and a western American who, after years of island hopping, is back in the mountains.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Travel Advisory page on Nov. 24 about a refurbished restaurant, Compass Point, misstated its location. It is in the Bahamas, not Bermuda.

title: Things That Go Thump -- Loudly -- in the Night
description: ELLIOT LEVINE and Mara Alper, last seen here two months ago cringing as a low bass line throbbed up through the floor of their Bleecker Street apartment from the Cafe Von below, are in the midst of a Department of Environmental Protection hearing they hope will bring some peace and quiet to their lives.

title: Laura J. Coolidge, Peter F. Touche
description: Laura Jefferson Coolidge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Richards Coolidge of Falls Village, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Francis Touche, a son of Sir Anthony and Lady Touche of Ockley, England. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: A Buyer Is About to Close on Bristol's G.M. Plant
description: THE 1.25-million-square-foot General Motors ball-bearings plant in Bristol, reported to be the largest one-story manufacturing building in New England, has been contracted for sale to SF Bristol, a partnership of Harold Fetner and David Swersky, New York City real estate developers. A closing is to be held in about a week.

title: Poor Teachers Get Coaching, Not Dismissal
description: The French and Spanish classes taught by the junior high school teacher in Queens were overrun with chaos. Students threw books out the window. They broke the glass in the classroom's door. A girl, horsing around, fell off a chair and bruised her head.

title: New Museum of Contemporary Art Near Rio
description: The new Museum of Contemporary Art has opened in Niteroi, about nine miles from Rio de Janeiro, with a permanent collection of more than 1,000 paintings and sculptures from Brazilian artists whose works span four decades of contemporary art.

title: APOCALYPTIC CINEMA
description: Religious film makers looking to do lunch should head for Jonesboro, Ark. That's where Richard Christiano has created Whitestone International, a nonprofit studio that aims to become the production hub for movies about evangelical Christianity and the millennium. Christiano is known among peers for shorts like ''The Appointment,'' a tale about an anti-Christian journalist who gets bopped by a car. One new project on the boards, ''Time Changer,'' concerns an 1890's Bible professor who travels to our era and finds rampant godlessness. ''The point is to get people thinking about eternity,'' says Christiano. ''If you don't put Jesus in it, for me, it's a waste of time.''

title: Rego Leads St. Joseph to Title
description: Cooper Rego put the finishing touch on his brilliant high school career yesterday by rushing for 286 yards on 31 carries and scoring all of the Green Knights' points to give St. Joseph-Montvale (10-1) a 36-20 victory over Delbarton (9-2) in the New Jersey Parochial 3 state championship game.

title: New Toronto Movie Surrounds Patrons
description: One of the hottest theater tickets in Toronto is not a rock concert or a stage production, but an IMAX movie called ''Special Effects,'' in a new 320-seat Omnimax theater that opened last week at the Ontario Science Center in midtown Toronto.

title: Making Money For Simple Living
description: THEY look and talk like the Amish, whom they consider their ''spiritual cousins.'' And, like the Amish, they believe in nonconformity to secular society as well as adult baptism and strict adherence to social, moral and religious codes of behavior.

title: Japanese Hotels
description: To the Editor: Herbert Muschamp's article ''Where a Room Is a Calling Card'' (Nov. 10) brought back memories of my stay at the Okura in 1969.

title: Lights! Camera! South Beach!
description: FEW destinations are as romantic, as exhilarating, as a seaside resort. There is a sense of urgency that heightens its seasonal seductions: those few months of salubrious weather before heat and humidity descend. There is the exotic factor, too, as familiar architectural styles are rendered in local materials, and horticultural impresarios transform the scrubby maritime landscape into a semitropical arboretum. Then, there is that sense of bravado belonging to communities built close to the ocean, their inhabitants blithely ignoring the fact that a particularly hearty wave could wipe the beach clean.

title: A Bit of French Elegance With Big American Profits
description: The city streets were so crowded and messy, the journalist wrote, that pedestrians could barely make their way through the maze of ''chairs and benches of iron, advertising signs, square kiosks, round kiosks, oval kiosks, kiosks for all purposes, kiosks for bars, kiosks for florists spilling out over the sidewalk. The pedestrian, thrust by all these kiosks toward the inner edge of the sidewalk, is thrust back toward them by the cafe terraces which gain ground every day.''

title: New Jersey Prosecutors To Face New Scrutiny
description: In the wake of the conviction of Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., the Somerset County Prosecutor, the New Jersey Attorney General, Peter Verniero, has begun to review the ways his office supervises the state's 21 county prosecutors. ''Reform might be too strong a word,'' he said. ''I don't want to indict the entire system because of one prosecutor gone astray.''

title: Whose Child First?
description: I try to be a good parent and a good citizen. In theory, those roles should not conflict. But when I think about how New Jersey should pay for its schools, they do. It's not a sterile budgeting question; if it were, New Jersey would not be midway through yet another school year with the issue still unresolved.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: The 'Loyal' Opposition
description: Ben Stein (top left), speech writer for President Richard Nixon, actor.

title: For Some, It's Still a Wonderful Life
description: NEARLY four years ago, the public was mad as hell at the dizzying costs of the savings and loan crisis. And Federal District Judge Mariana R. Pfaelzer seemed to capture the public mood when she doubled the suggested Federal sentence and ordered Charles H. Keating Jr. to prison for 12 1/2 years for defrauding and destroying the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, a $3.4 billion disaster. She justified her popular decision by calling Mr. Keating's crimes ''staggering.''

title: High Crimes and Misdemeanors: The Flight Logs of Uncivil Aviation
description: SEATING stressed-out and revelry-minded people in a cramped cylindrical space for hours on end while serving them powerful depressant beverages at high altitude and encouraging them to think they deserve the royal treatment is probably not the best way to elicit model human behavior.

title: hat Has the Computer Done for Us Lately?
description: AT the end of the 19th century, railroads and electric motors were expected to transform America, making a young industrial economy far more productive than any seen before. And they did. At the end of the 20th century, computers were supposed to perform the same miracle.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Cute Animals With a Cutting Edge
description: A LITTLE OVER A WEEK AGO, A significant confirmation of pop-culture status hovered high above Central Park West and Broadway, televised for an entire nation to see: the Bullwinkle balloon, redesigned with Rocky affixed to the moose's back, returned to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade after a 13-year absence.

title: Art Appreciation: More Than One Oasis
description: To the Editor:

title: Generational Pioneer
description: Our parents stand for previous generations until they die, whereupon we have to. Driving down to New York for a holiday, I call and ask my daughter if I can spend the night at her place. She has just turned 27 and is a graduate student in history. She says yes as usual, but with a demurral that startles me: ''I'm just afraid you won't realize I'm an adult now.'' Because I fathom what she means, what's startling is that I like the man she has been seeing, have assumed for the past year that they were sharing their lives at his place or hers and am in favor of postponing such a major event as marriage until one's 30's. Why does she doubt my approval of the firming of the arrangement?

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: L.L. BEAN

title: Everything But the Decorations
description: I would like to point you in the direction of a web site that does. Rutgers Cooperative Extension has put the New Jersey Christmas Tree Growers' Association's 1996 Choose and Cut Christmas Tree Guide on the web. It lists pick-your-own tree farms by county, including operating hours and species of trees carried.

title: To Enjoy Music Is to Understand It
description: To the Editor:

title: A Refinancing in Harlem Ends an Owner's Struggle
description: WHEN Charmayne Rosario moved back to New York City from Atlanta last April she found an apartment at the Dunbar, a landmarked property in Harlem with a distinguished history punctuated by spasms of financial trauma.

title: But What About Quality?
description: TUCKED NEAR THE END OF A WINDING PRIVATE road above Jackson Hole, Wyo., is a house that is more a monument than a home. Its towering entrance is meant to evoke a Shinto temple. Its walls of windows are designed to capture the soaring views of the Tetons. Its living room is anchored by six majestic pillars. Thirty feet high, they are the trunks of 200-year-old spruce trees, still bearing scars from the Yellowstone fires of 1988.

title: Ancient, Priceless And Gone With the War
description: THE story begins about 27 centuries ago, when Sennacherib, King of Assyria, the greatest empire the world had known, failed to conquer Jerusalem in 701 B.C.

title: Important Preparations for Wallpapering
description: WHETHER you cover your walls with paint or wallpaper is a matter of personal taste. Generally, people choose wallpaper when they want to add pattern or texture to a room. Hanging paper on a wall is as easy as painting it. The key to a successful papering job lies in preparing the walls properly. The walls will fall into one of three categories: painted walls, new walls or papered walls.

title: Upgrades to First Class On T.W.A. for a Fee
description: A new program from Trans World Airlines allows upgrades to first class for a fee when space is available.

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: When I stumbled on Dr. Laura in mid-rebroadcast, I thought it was a Garrison Keillor comedy skit gone horribly wrong. Then I realized my mistake. Fascism is alive and well on squawk radio!

title: 'The Nutcracker' Gets a Chance to Swing
description: THE SWINGING RHYTHMS OF Duke Ellington and Billy Strayhorn's arrangement of Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker'' Suite poured from the windows of the Brooklyn Academy of Music Opera House one chilly evening recently, giving the quiet neighborhood an early taste of Christmas. The sounds originated in the building's main rehearsal studio, where 20 dancers whirled across the floor, propelled by a hard-driving piano and an insistent drum.

title: The Dinner Party
description: A DOZEN guests were minutes from arriving at Nan Kempner's Park Avenue duplex for dinner the Saturday night before Thanksgiving, but Mrs. Kempner had only one thing to worry about: positioning a pink curler in her blond bob. The curler's function: to make the dip in the bob fall perfectly over her right eye.

title: Tar Heels And Irish: A Rematch Of the Best
description: College football, take note: women's college soccer has found the formula for the perfect national championship matchup, with no coalition required.

title: Getting Together
description: Waiting To Forget

title: Fifth Avenue Consumption, for the Rest of Us
description: ON any fine day after Thanksgiving, Fifth Avenue teems with holiday shoppers, jostling, weaving in and out of stores, packages colliding. At the southwest corner of 56th Street, though, sidewalk traffic smooths out just a little. It is the site of Harry Winston, purveyor of jewelry to the mega-rich.

title: At Center Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: ART
description: Contrary to rumor, the good art book is not an endangered species. There are new authors, new subjects and new formats. There are new prices, too, but they are in line with the exigencies of the day.

title: Making Happy Talk With Rosie O'Donnell
description: ROSIE O'Donnell, the ''queen of nice'' whose sunny effervescence has made her syndicated talk show seem like a big, yummy cream puff on a daytime platter of stale toast, wasn't her chipper self during a lunchtime interview in her Rockefeller Center office.

title: THE BIG MAN CAN DEAL
description: David Falk was able to negotiate a $20 million contract with Nike for Michael Jordan, but the Indonesian women who make the merchandise earn $1.20 a day. While Falk woos Jordan with expensive bottles of wine, these overseas workers are subjected to horrendously unsafe working conditions.

title: A Report Says Inefficiency Is Costing New York Billions
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan group that studies government finances, released a report last week that said that New York City and State could save up to $15 billion annually if they revamped the way they raise and spend their money. The seven-volume report cited figures to show that the city and state were more costly and less efficient than the rest of the nation, making them less competitive for business. Here are some of the statistics, which the commission culled from government and private sources. CLIFFORD J. LEVY

title: If It Walks and Talks Like Inflation, It's Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Flaming Swords and Wizards' Orbs
description: When matters begin to look bleak for the weary wanderers of J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Lord of the Rings,'' they rest briefly in Lothlorien, an Elven forest of surpassing beauty. The river Nimrodel's cold waters seem to cleanse the soul, trees stand with nearly immeasurable grandeur and in the fragrant grasses grow flowers whose very names -- elanor and niphredil -- seem to speak of grace and sweetness.

title: Commuter Lanes on Turnpike More Popular Than Expected
description: Commuters are so eager to shave even a few minutes off their trips that use of services like high-occupancy vehicle lanes or new rail links has repeatedly exceeded projections, state transportation officials say.

title: The Goodies They Ship Out of Clinton
description: KATHY TILTON rolls out a slab of powdery pastry dough on a large counter, brushes it with water, plops a brimming scoop of apple filling over it, then crumbles a fist-sized clump of brown sugar, cinnamon and nuts over the top before rolling it up.

title: Rewarding Players For the Right Reasons
description: When I won the Heisman Trophy in 1948, I did not know it until two days later. A telegram was sent to Matty Bell, my coach at Southern Methodist University, on a Saturday. I was out of the dorm for the weekend, and when I returned to school on Monday, a note was pinned to my door. It read: ''Coach Bell would like to see you.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the classical record business misidentifies the city in which a Sony Classical recording of film music by John Williams, with the violinist Itzhak Perlman, is to be made. It is Pittsburgh, not London.

title: An Angry Ewing Takes On The Fans
description: It took a furious fourth-quarter rally for the Knicks to avoid another embarrassing home loss. And when it was over, a disturbed Patrick Ewing criticized Madison Square Garden fans for booing the Knicks on almost an every-game basis.

title: Islanders Reach Back for Something Extra
description: Shorty before tonight's game against the Washington Capitals, the Islanders skated onto the Nassau Coliseum ice, each player wearing a jersey with the name Gillies sewn across the back, that familiar No. 9 stitched beneath it.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Vamping It Up
description: EVIL SISTERS

title: A Time to Raise Voices (and Instruments)
description: AT this season, the biggest stars in the musical galaxy have repaired to real or imaginary isles of self-replenishment. The arts calendar moves on to vox communitatis -- the voice of the community. More than at any other time of year, people in a celebratory mood perform in church, attend orchestral and choral concerts, and join in sing-alongs of carols, Handel's ''Messiah'' and a gradually increasing list of other masterpieces.

title: 4 Subdivisions That Appeal to Both Old and Young
description: OLDER couples whose children have grown and who want to move to a development where outside maintenance will be provided along with some recreational facilities have in the past found their choices limited.

title: EPOCH JOURNEY
description: Mike Marcum is back, and the citizens of St. Joseph, Mo., are exhaling in relief. Marcum stunned the fringe-science world last year when he announced on Art Bell's syndicated ''Coast to Coast A.M.'' radio program -- which often focuses on paranormal topics -- that he was inventing a time machine using electrical transformers and 168 electromagnets. In late September, Marcum vanished, and The St. Joseph News-Press chillingly reported that he'd been evicted from his apartment, allegedly for transporting a cat ''a block away.'' Marcum resurfaced last month, taking umbrage with ''the cat deal -- it just ain't true.'' As for his gizmo, he plans to test it as soon as he solves the sticky problems of controlling when and where it sends him. ''Right now,'' he says, ''this would only make a good garbage disposal.''

title: Gay 90's Decor, 1990's Italian Menu
description: PROOF of America's continuing food revolution is that many of the state's smallest towns now have at least one restaurant that strives to offer something beyond standard or fast food fare.

title: Ups and Downs? All an Illusion
description: Things are, indeed, not what they seem. For one thing, you probably thought this was by some contemporary artist caught up in the latest stock-market frenzy. No, it's dated 1937. And you probably thought it was a collage. Wrong again. It's a painting by a master of trompe l'oeil, Otis Kaye. The painting, titled ''D'-JIA-VU'' -- get it? Dow Jones industrials? -- shows the market's ups and downs from 1929, when Kaye lost a bundle, to 1937. On Thursday, just in time for the market's latest wild ride, it sold at Sotheby's for $442,500, a record -- by far -- for his work. Stock-market fever, perhaps?

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: Laura Schlessinger's radio program is popular for the same reason that the guillotine and other forms of public torture and execution were popular in earlier times (''The Just-Do-It Shrink,'' by Rebecca Johnson, Nov. 17). There have always been people who are fascinated with bloodshed and violence (even if only psychological), as long as they're not the victims.

title: The Bad Book
description: THE BIBLE FOR CHILDREN

title: A Room With a View of the Future
description: ''MAXWELL!''

title: Where the Past Is a Pervasive Presence
description: CARPE DIEM'' advises the sun dial inscription on the wall of Bryant Library in the Village of Roslyn, one of four villages in the comfortably affluent and richly historic North Shore, Long Island area known as Greater Roslyn.

title: She's Literally Out of This World
description: SHE'S JUST STANDING IN THE White House driveway, a vision of loveliness, at least to the Presidential Press Secretary. She gazes at him silently, chewing gum, a seven-foot-tall champagne-blond Barbie type with big hair magnified to the 10th power, very red lipstick and breasts the size and shape of traffic cones.

title: In Mail-Order Lists, She's the 'Queen of Catalogues'
description: THE grand prize winner in Ceil Cleveland's mailbox is Victoria's Secret. ''We've received 56 of their catalogues this year,'' she said. ''And I've never bought anything from them.''

title: In Showdown, Elway Will Spectate
description: With the game-time temperature expected to be in the high 20's or low 30's, the Denver Broncos' ironman quarterback, John Elway, will sit out this afternoon's showdown against the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field because of a strained hamstring.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Bus Lift

title: Fulton Street as the Nile
description: Bilal Muhammad, the owner of a T-shirt shop called Wise Up!, is a man who values the power of labels, signs and symbols. And if he had his way, a chunk of Fort Greene would be labeled Bogolan, a truncated form of Bogolanfini, which means mud cloth in Mali.

title: Kermit G. Bailer, 75; Civil Rights Lawyer And Federal Official
description: Kermit Gamaliel Bailer, a Detroit lawyer who spent most of his career working on behalf of rights groups and in public service, including civil rights assignments in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died on Nov. 30 at his home in Detroit. He was 75.

title: Some Important Preparations Before Wallpapering a Room
description: WHETHER you choose to cover your walls with paint or wallpaper is a matter of personal taste. Generally, people choose wallpaper when they want to add pattern or texture to a room. Hanging paper on a wall is as easy as painting it (although some rooms, like the bathroom or kitchen, may be more difficult to cover than a bedroom or living room). The key to a successful papering job lies in preparing the walls properly. The walls will fall into one of three categories: painted walls, new walls or papered walls.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Two Wrenching Dramas Find Unexpected New Lives
description: JUST EIGHT MONTHS APART IN 1991, two American plays made acclaimed New York debuts in the same Off Broadway theater. One was the darkly comic story of a middle-aged woman dying of leukemia who reaches out to her estranged sister; the other, the wrenching tale of the war between a self-destructive Holocaust survivor and his three children.

title: Optimistic Outlook On a Cynical World
description: TO the up-to-the-minute beat of a dissonant, cynical world, Kathryn Grant has written an affirmingly old-style first play.

title: Dina Merrill and Hartley: Partners in/on Film
description: RKO Pictures' romantic comedy ''Milk and Money'' is very much a family affair. The film, which had its premiere at the Hamptons International Film Festival in East Hampton, is produced by Ted Hartley, RKO's chairman and chief executive officer, and his wife, Dina Merrill, vice chairman. Ms. Merrill also plays in the film as Ellen, the mother, and Mr. Hartley gives a cameo appearance as a wacky lingerie salesman.

title: Revenge of the Christmas Novels
description: Of all the great themes for a writer to explore, there can be none so noble as the true meaning of Christmas. Imagine: to be part of a literary tradition that goes straight back to the Bible. To take as one's inspiration the questions that lie at the very core of our existence. And, more to the point, to make a whole lot of of money. If you can hit the nail on the head, if you can capture people's hearts with just the right twist, just the right amount of pathos, just the right moral -- then, my friend, you will be on the receiving end of a real-life Christmas miracle.

title: Alison A. Brooks And John Wallace
description: Alison Anne Brooks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Brooks of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to John Wallace, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Wallace of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Peter Kaczmarek performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gertrude in Bayville, L.I.

title: Shall We Dance? The Risks Of Buying Into Broadway
description: Q. Is it possible for a small investor to put $10,000 into a Broadway show? What is the rate of return for a successful production?

title: Imperial Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Not the Shuttle
description: To the Editor: About the air shuttle (Practical Traveler: ''Shaving Fares on the Shuttle,'' Nov. 3): You missed the best way of all between New York and Washington or Boston -- Trailways Peter Pan bus. It goes about every hour, costs about $54 round trip, takes four and a half hours. Clean, even a movie, downtown to downtown, no reservations. Can't beat it for convenience, cost and hassle-free travel.

title: The Last Act
description: FROM the outside, there's nothing impressive about the four-story headquarters of the Hebrew Actors Union, an austere, stucco-faced building wedged between tenements and sagging row houses of East Seventh Street. But to young Jewish actors like Fyvush Finkel, now 74, it was a forbidding edifice whose all-powerful occupants could make aspiring thespians into household names on Hester Street or condemn them to dreary lives in the sweatshops uptown.

title: A Safety Net Wears Thin
description: THEY woke about 10 A.M. and began to scrounge for change. Philip, Florence and Raymond, emerging from a cinderblock enclosure and slinking toward a Hoboken liquor store for the tall boy and a fifth of vodka. In an hour both bottles were empty but their bellies were warm, the day after Thanksgiving like the day before, this year like the last, their future seeming as bleak as their past.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: A Vietnam Veteran Found Doors Closed
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: Only 10 days before your article appeared, my 42-year-old brother, Patrick, died of AIDS. When Andrew Sullivan described his friend Greg, I could only think of my sweet and brave brother, and the pain and humiliation he endured. I wish that he, too, could have had another chance, but it wasn't to be.

title: Children's Books
description: ELEANOR

title: I Don't Owe, So I Can't Get Credit
description: I CAN'T get a credit card because I don't have one. That's what I discovered when I called the credit check agency to find out why I had been rejected.

title: There Are Choices In Surgical Supplies
description: I was most distressed to read ''As Home Health Care Grows, So Does a New Business'' (About Long Island, Nov. 10) extolling the virtues of Homecare America.

title: No Stomach for Art
description: A 22-year-old art student in Toronto proudly admitted last week that he had deliberately vomited, in color, on two famous paintings.

title: A Move to Advice At a Lower Price
description: DO-IT-YOURSELF advice?

title: Making the Case For State Schools
description: IN the fall of 1955, Richard L. Judd, whose father was a factory worker in Bridgeport and whose mother was an emigrant from Hungary, enrolled at Teachers College of Connecticut in New Britain for a very good reason: It was the only place he could afford.

title: The Incorrigible C.I.A.
description: As a devoted Boston Red Sox fan, Anthony Lake is accustomed to tribulation and disappointment. That may be a good thing, for as the next Director of Central Intelligence he is likely to face a lifetime of frustration packed into just a few years. The Central Intelligence Agency, the flagship organization of the espionage empire he will run, is close to incorrigible. Six years after the disintegration of the Soviet Union and end of the cold war, the C.I.A. is still struggling to get its bearings and still resisting reform.

title: Butter Is Also Sublime, and Then There's Lard
description: EAT FAT

title: Healing Neighborhoos With Comprehensive Community Building
description: James Morrison lives in a squat six-story apartment building on a bleak stretch of cityscape in Brooklyn. For two long blocks, the red brick building is repeated in an architectural echo of dilapidation. Across the street there is a drab supermarket and an abandoned lot. At 9 A.M., the only activity is the swinging of a door to a corner liquor store.

title: Camels Once Again Lend Cachet to Coats
description: An American fashion favorite, the camel-hair coat, has returned as a uniform for businesswomen who place function and practicality above the caprices of fashion. Camel-hair coats, originally worn as steamer coats for trans-Atlantic crossings, gained wide popularity in the 1920's and 30's, when they were tossed over the shoulders at spectator sporting events and worn as an accessory to the period's wood-paneled station wagons. The coats today are no longer languidly draped, Carole Lombard style, but are securely sash-tied for warmth and, in some cases, buttoned. Whether the coats are actually camel's hair or are cashmere, blends or wool, which is less expensive and the most popular, the color is always camel-hair.

title: Holocaust and the Enduring Need to Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: The Moon's Dirty Water
description: Where there is water there is, or could be, life. This maxim seems to drive current explorations of the solar system.

title: Knowing Your Onions
description: ROBERT J. COURTINE, THE FRENCH FOOD critic, once said that onions are the truffle of the poor. Which may be true regarding snob appeal and other matters of the nose. However, in denigrating the common, one forgets how indispensable the common can be. No other ingredient marries disparate flavors as thoroughly or as subtly as an onion. Indeed, the onion is the single most important ingredient in any slowly simmered dish.

title: Sheila Cullen And Craig Dunn
description: Mary Sheila Cullen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anthony Cullen of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Craig Thomas Dunn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Dunn of Cincinnati. Msgr. J. Peter Cullen performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Scholar Sees Leonardo's Influence on Machiavelli
description: Leonardo da Vinci was 51 and already famous for painting ''The Last Supper'' when he returned to Florence in 1503 to paint a mural.

title: Sydney
description: Summer, when Sydney Harbour teems with brightly colored spinnakers, and casually dressed Australians flock to outdoor cafes, is also the season to sample the city's arts.

title: 49ers and Steelers on Statistical Course for Super Bowl XXXI
description: Only three weeks of the National Football League regular season remain, and thus far, each playoff contender has repeatedly uttered the importance of balance in the game's three primary aspects: offense, defense and special teams.

title: Opening the Gate To a Code of Ethics
description: Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, did an about-face late last month when it announced that it would provide a summary of its code of ethics to shareholders who asked for one.

title: Words Warm and Intoxicating
description: LISTEN is the gentle recurring command in ''Under Milk Wood,'' Dylan Thomas's classic ''Play for Voices,'' and his last work written in prose for the BBC in 1954. The director Mark Lamos's lyric placements of 10 lovely actors, a true ensemble, in 60 roles -- 40 are named -- provides the sensual stage pictures to accompany Thomas's rich aural images of a coastal town from one spring night to the next, with an emphasis on the morning.

title: Seeking a Leader and a Role For Economic Policy Council
description: With his foreign policy team in place, President Clinton is now confronting a long-bubbling and central question in the White House: the future of the National Economic Council, Mr. Clinton's biggest innovation in Washington policy making, created to inject economic thinking into every major domestic and foreign policy issue.

title: Audience-Participation Concert, With a Twist
description: A HOLIDAY concert at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery this afternoon will have audience participation in the form of a request to present a donation of toys or clothing. The music will be Christmas spirituals, gospel and African and Caribbean songs, sung by Rejoicensemble!, a chamber vocal group. The group Inner Spirit will be guest artists in a program titled ''Spread Love, Spread Joy.''

title: Giving, And Getting In Return
description: When giving to charity, you can often get something in return besides a tax deduction. Some charities invite you to black-tie dinners, give you a book bag or tickets to an event. There is also a way to make money by giving.

title: From the Ratcheting of Helicopters to a Guitar's Hum
description: IN 1945, Charles H. Kaman, aerospace engineer, founded the Kaman Corporation, now a Fortune 500 company based based in Bloomfield known for helicopter technology. Thirty years ago, Mr. Kaman, guitarist, applied innovations in vibration transmission and composite materials to his musical interests and the Ovation guitar was born.

title: A Pile of Medical Bills and a Heap of Politics
description: She has a ruddy Irish face that blushes when she laughs, which is frequently, but don't let that fool you. Sister Jane Frances Brady, the chief executive officer of St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in downtown Paterson, is one tough cookie.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: Andrew Sullivan's article ''When Plagues End'' (Nov. 10) resonated deeply with me. His overriding message -- that which does not kill us will make us stronger -- is a belief that I have adopted in the 10 years I have been H.I.V.-positive.

title: Doing a Disservice To an Enduring Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Comparing the Districts: The '96 High School Report Cards
description: Since 1989, the State Department of Education has issued an annual Report Card for every public school in New Jersey -- a compilation of data on everything from class size and test scores to per-pupil spending and what languages parents speak at home. The reports are meant to allow parents to see how their schools measure up, taxpayers to see where their money is going, and education officials to monitor progress -- or lack of it -- in the state's 2,200 public schools.

title: THE BIG MAN CAN DEAL
description: Hirschberg's article illustrates how Michael Jordan has become an international superstar who makes a prodigious amount of money from endorsements. But there seems to be a lack of connection between what I call the social ethics of someone like Jordan and those of the late tennis star Arthur Ashe. Ashe used his celebrity, in part, to better the people of his own race, while Jordan seems more concerned with where he is going to get his next manicure or $650 bottle of wine.

title: Airport Unhappy Over Plans For Homes
description: WHILE reading a newspaper in the summer, the director of Republic Airport in Farmingdale saw an article about plans for two housing developments virtually in the backyard of the airport.

title: Ex-Head of Newark Immigration Office Says He Was Punished for Opposing Corruption
description: Soon after Warren Lewis took charge of the Newark office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, he said, he began to notice signs of corruption.

title: When It Comes to Trash, Chinese Just Say Throw
description: It was just another day on the Yangtze River when Zhao Bangying committed the act in front of hundreds of boat passengers, not one of whom blinked when she heaved a huge bag of trash out the window.

title: Germans Find Order Is Just Their Speed
description: DEEP in the bureaucracy, Frau Ratte lurks.

title: Learning the Art Of the Concierge
description: WHAT can be taught in a concierge school? To some degree, the teachers say, it is like a singing school: Techniques can be learned, but the talent -- in this case, the wish to be of service -- must be there to start.

title: BIG COOK
description: Andrew Selvaggio is a trained chef who oversees new menu offerings for 19,263 McDonald's restaurants, and when you ask him about his affinity for the product he creates, he doesn't mess around. ''I would say,'' he replies calmly, clinically, ''that I'm a super-heavy user.''

title: When the Sticky Fingers Are Attached to Hired Hands
description: Who knows how overcrowded the nation's overcrowded jails would be if all the light-fingered people in the workplace were exposed to the heavy hand of justice? Judging by the mail, nothing is sacred -- from a packet of mustard or a pen to big-ticket items like sofas.

title: Las Vegas In Spades
description: IF any trip to Las Vegas ever looked like a break-even proposition before it started, our visit in September did: My wife, Marsha, and I left on Friday the 13th, on America West flight 711. It was a theme that would repeat itself throughout our four-day stay at the new Monte Carlo resort and casino.

title: Deals Are Changing For Frequent Fliers
description: Changes to several airlines' frequent flier programs are taking effect over the next few months.

title: WHEN PLAGUES END
description: Sullivan's article was enlightening and hopeful, to say the least. Good news is as important in fighting H.I.V. and AIDS as any new miracle drug. It gives people hope. With the realization that H.I.V. can be managed comes the desire to fight back. That spirit can help those who are H.I.V.-positive stay healthy.

title: A Warm Glow, and Perhaps a Nice Deduction
description: CHARITY springs from the heart, but it also makes sense to engage the financial-savvy regions of the brain. That way you can maximize your giving.

title: Watching for Order in Court
description: Justice, the old cliche goes, is blind. So at the Queens County Criminal Court building, Mabrouk Mabrouk and his colleagues serve as her eyes.

title: Making a BID to Improve a Bronx Neighborhood
description: The Norwood section of the north Bronx has become a tough territory for sprayers of graffiti. No sooner have they left their signature messages on apartment walls and the metal roll-down gates that protect the glass display windows of retail stores than crews from Partners in Grime, a cleaning specialist, arrive with solvents and pressure washers to clean them off. The intention is to project the image of a community that is safe and economically viable and one that is managed more by productive citizens than idle youths with spray cans.

title: Only State That Lacks A Speed Limit May Get One
description: A year after Montana became the only state without a fixed daytime speed limit on its highways, some leading state officials have decided they want one back.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Idaho, Plan To Protect Wild Horses Causes Furor
description: Earl Maggard has a panoramic view from his backyard horse corral in southwestern Idaho. Sitting on a rail, he points out the 75-mile-long bank of mountains, the Owyhee Front, that rise like a mile-high wave from the Snake River Plain.

title: Reading at 55 Miles Per Hour
description: ADD this to the list of things dangerous to your health: verbose signs.

title: Big-Wig Maker To Bigwig Stars
description: BIG hair is not dead.

title: Rescuing Picasso From the Myths
description: ''I THINK THE WAY TO PUSH Picasso scholarship ahead is to go back to the basics, to tell things the way they happened,'' says John Richardson, whose second volume of a projected four-volume biography of the artist has just been published by Random House to even more popular acclaim, if that's possible, than the first volume.

title: Harlem District Termed Failing And Paralyzed
description: Central Harlem's school district plunged deeper into crisis last week, as Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew handed district officials a scathing report detailing a long pattern of failure.

title: Flashback to Colonial Life, in Hartsdale
description: FORMERLY Aphrodite, this stylish new restaurant has nothing Greek about it. Beyond a porch promising shade and indolence in the veldt come summer and through a bar area conjuring up officers' clubs in remote outposts, the dining areas evoke, as intended, colonial life. in the empires of the 19th and early 20th centuries. Lazy ceiling fans, towering potted palms, rattan and mounted big game hunter's trophies complete the romanticizing of imperial power. (We looked in vain for beaded curtains and fezzed, white-suited Sidney Greenstreet.)

title: A Wary Georgia Prepares to Battle the Kudzu of the Animal Kingdom
description: Slithering through the muck and dead, rotted leaves comes the green and yellow, squirmy, sharp-toothed, fish-eating thing. Most people see one of the hideous creatures and dismiss it as a serpent, but unlike the water snakes that glide through Southern ponds, this species does not belong.

title: The Apollo Theater And 125th Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Artful Arugula
description: YOU would have seen a grown man cry had you been eating gelato and not minding your own business in Cafe Arugula last year.

title: Holocaust and the Enduring Need to Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: Outsider With a Voice
description: ON a blustery Tuesday last January, Junot Diaz was summoned from his day job to the phone. A year out of graduate school, he made photocopies at Pfizer Pharmaceuticals in Manhattan by day and wrote fiction at night and in the early morning. When he hung up, he cried: ''Yo! Somebody wants to buy my book! I quit!''

title: Fairway Pays Price of Success: Traffic Snarls
description: Inside the uptown Fairway market, shoppers seem satisfied with their holiday purchases, but outside the store, which opened 10 months ago, some neighborhood residents and the head of the local community board are concerned that the often-chaotic traffic situation generated by patrons is a serious safety hazard.

title: A Remembrance of Mansion-Renovation Past
description: THE glossy color brochure shows a mansion with crystal chandeliers and walls padded with silk brocade; with Aubusson carpets and Louis XVI gilt armchairs; with oil paintings of gauzy landscapes, individually illuminated; with veined marble mantlepieces and ornate wrought-iron staircases.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-27

title: L.I. Economy Making Some Steady Strides
description: THE Long Island economy, which crawled at a snail's pace in the early 90's and suffered more than the economies in other regions from cuts in military spending, seems headed toward recovery, in large part because of strength in the small-business area, economists say.

title: Real Pain and Anxiety
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Miles to Go'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Merlin of the Mall Tries Out New Magic
description: THE real problem, Leslie H. Wexner says, is other people.

title: King Lear's World, Reborn on a Farm In the Heartland
description: A CROWD OF NEW FACES jams Smoking Harry's Tavern. The Holiday Inn is nearly full. Colonial Flowers has a run of $100 orders; the phone rings nonstop at Headon's Fine Meats. Since Michelle Pfeiffer and Jessica Lange showed up in August near this small city two hours west of Chicago to shoot ''A Thousand Acres,'' based on Jane Smiley's novel about a farm family, business around here has boomed.

title: Abracadabra
description: Where would we be without our briefcases? How would we bring home all that work from the office? Where would we stack the magazines we read during our commutes or carry the box of cookies we munch on all day? Do you carry anything out of the ordinary in your briefcase, or do you ever see other people pull something weird out of theirs? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: Rebecca Johnson's article omits an essential ingredient of Dr. Laura's message: all of us are responsible for the choices we make, including marriage and childbearing. As fallible beings, we make mistakes. As moral beings, we are capable of living with them.

title: Pure Profit
description: IT'S AN OLD STORY,'' SAYS SAUL ZAENTZ, WHO HAS made seven movies, won two Oscars for Best Picture (''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' and ''Amadeus'') and is the producer of ''The English Patient,'' a much-lauded film that every studio in Hollywood was unwilling to finance. ''We went everywhere. We had some hearty handshakes, and they all said, 'We love it, we love it, we love it,' that they wanted to make great movies just like 'The English Patient' that are serious and intelligent, but then they'd look at you and say, 'Could we cast Demi Moore in the role?' They were all afraid of it. And that's the way it is.''

title: In Hawaii, Snowplow Maintains Clear View
description: Hawaii's only snowplow has come to life for the season, removing drifts from the road up the state's highest mountain, more than two and a half miles above tropical beaches.

title: Helping People, Healing 'Villages'
description: Helping the neediest New Yorkers often means recognizing the peril of the city's neediest neighborhoods. That was what the Children's Aid Society, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, did when it took a hard look at a block of 118th Street in Harlem, where it helped Ella M. and her four children, including Adzil, 1, left, and Adzelle, 3, find shelter and a sense of community. ''People would say, 'One block? How can you invest so many resources in one block?' '' said Philip Coltoff, who heads the Children's Aid Society. ''But one block in New York City could have a thousand people living in it. That's as many people as in a village. And some problems in New York City can only be solved block by block.''

title: Holocaust and the Enduring Need to Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Who Lead the Way
description: THIRTY years after the fact, Claudia L. Edwards executive director of the Reader's Digest Foundation and one of the more highly placed women in the county -- still winces at the memory of her 11th-grade economics instructor.

title: THE JUST-DO-IT SHRINK
description: Schlessinger gives therapy in the fast lane to a generation of whining crybabies who can't analyze their own problems. She clears the cobwebs and helps them see through problems many have created themselves.

title: When a School in a Top District Reads Poorly, Officials Ask Why?
description: For years, Community School District 2 has been in the limelight: Its superintendent, Anthony J. Alvarado, has been lauded for setting up small, experimental schools with innovative approaches to teaching.

title: Banker Delivers on His Pledge
description: Three thousand signatures later, Charles J. Hamm is keeping his word.

title: Exotic Exploits
description: John Carpenter's BIG TROUBLE IN LITTLE CHINA (1986) stars Kurt Russell and Kim Cattrall as an indomitable hero and a spunky heroine. In this brashly, comic adventure to burly trucker (Russell) stumbles into a dangerous web of intrigue and mayhem in San Francisco's Chinatown to rescue a damsel in distress. The action - knife-slinging, sword-juggling and high kicking - brims with visual surprises and occult-edged color. Exotic jazz adds musical pizzaz, and the spirit is rakish and bold, seldom lagging. Herewith fast, crackling, Kaleidescopic fun. There's not a dull moment - TUES.-WED. at 1:25 A.M. on TBS.

title: Guiding Little Sugarplums
description: ONE EVENING RECENTLY, eight 12- and 13-year-old girls did jetes across the floor of Studio One at the School of American Ballet, intently rehearsing ''hoops'' -- shorthand for the lively Candy Canes variation from ''The Nutcracker.'' ''Don't try for height; skim along the floor!'' urged Garielle Whittle, a faculty member who is also children's ballet mistress for the New York City Ballet.

title: Instant Tradition
description: COME rain, shine or a Friday the 13th, Francis (Franny) Smith, Atlantic City's luckiest musician, will have his bald head kissed by a gambler hoping to hit a jackpot.

title: Accepting Fat Isn't a License to Gorge
description: To the Editor:

title: How Do You Do Hanukkah?
description: NOW that his children aren't living at home anymore, Saul Bellow doesn't make a fuss over Hanukkah.

title: The Gag Is Off H.M.O. Doctors
description: Federal officials moved last week to guarantee a freer flow of information between doctors and elderly Medicare patients in health maintenance organizations.

title: A Matter of Choice
description: On an Easter weekend, women with different views about abortion are involved in a violent confrontation and realize that with an issue so complex there can be no clear-cut solution. In CRITICAL CHOICES, about a married woman who discovers she is inconveniently pregnant, Betty Buckley plays a doctor at an abortion clinic in Milwaukee, the site of continuing demonstrations; Diana Scarwid is a pro-choice advocate, and Pamela Reed portrays a mother of four who along with her husband strongly opposes abortion on religious grounds. Claudia Weill directed - SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on SHOWTIME.

description: THRONE OF GOLD

description: This selection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 1996 summer reading issue.

title: The Dominican Connection
description: New York City's plan for stationing police investigators in the Dominican Republic caused a stir recently, as fears of American police invading the Dominican streets provoked a backlash among voters and politicians there. But Police Commissioner Howard Safir never intended to place officers in the Dominican streets, as some seemed to think. Instead, Mr. Safir would like to station a pair of officers at the United States Embassy, to develop intelligence on the Dominican-American drug connection.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in On the Towns last Sunday included an erroneous reference to the All Seasons Chamber Players' concert at Central Unitarian Church in Paramus. It was last Sunday; it is not today.

title: Eve S. Rudin, Robert A. Weiner
description: Eve Sandra Rudin, a daughter of Marcia Rudin and Rabbi A. James Rudin of New York, was married last evening to Robert Aaron Weiner, a son of Eileen and Michael A. Weiner of West Bloomfield, Mich. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum officiated at Temple Shaaray Tefila in New York. The bride's father, who is the national director of interreligious affairs at the American Jewish Committee in New York, took part in the service.

title: Tramping the Gray Woods and Finding Comfort
description: Sometimes my family's farm in Maryland strikes me with all the power of a great, living body: a being that I would like to know intimately, from the heaviness of its red clay soil to the eagle we saw flying slowly over the edge of the woods last weekend.

title: THE BIG MAN CAN DEAL
description: Lynn Hirschberg's ''The Big Man Can Deal'' (Nov. 17) was very interesting. I was glad to read that David Falk, the sports agent, is helping so many athletes, primarily black, to attain great wealth and popularity. However, I was disturbed to find no mention of a black executive on his staff. I can't understand why some of these athletes don't insist on negotiating with an agent only if he has a black assistant somewhere in the system.

title: Before the Bankruptcy
description: To the Editor:

title: $20 Million Tribute To Public Education
description: Charles B. Wang, born in Shanghai and a successful software entrepreneur on Long Island, said, ''I'm a product of public education -- Brooklyn Technical High School and Queens College.'' So he chose a public institution, the State University of New York at Stony Brook, for a gift of $20 million to $25 million.

title: DIARY
description: STOCK MARKET

title: A Sensible Plan for Rent Decontrol
description: About a million apartments in New York City are covered by rent regulations that will expire this June. The Republican majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph Bruno, announced last week that he would not allow a renewal of the laws, unless it was tied to a plan for swift deregulation.

title: Of Family, Spirituality and Power
description: MEMBERS of the Deer Spring Bruderhof community in Norfolk appear happy and serene as they work, pray and sing together. The Anabaptist religious group of 360 people live on a 50-acre property with its own church and school. Somewhat like the Amish, the men have beards and wear straw hats, the women wear bonnets and simple dresses and many of the children walk around barefoot.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: The Mural Map Says 'Brazil' And So Does the Food

title: Article Misstated Views On Multicultural Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Estuary Advocates Wary on Fish Farm
description: A FLEDGLING mariculture company's proposal to raise five million fluke in 200 acres of underwater pens southeast of Plum Island is creating concerns about nitrogen from fish feces and other effects in the Peconic estuary.

title: Toiling in the Shadow Of a Rich Big Brother
description: LIKE many other sport utility vehicles, the Mitsubishi Montero has emerged from the deep woods to take a place in the driveways of exclusive clubs.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Merlot Reserve

title: Randy Diamond, Keith D. Wellner
description: Randy Jill Diamond, a sales analyst, and Keith David Wellner, a lawyer, were married last evening. Rabbi Daniel Pernick performed the ceremony at the Pearl River (N.Y.) Hilton.

title: Grumble, Grumble: Ah, It's Bonus Time
description: THE rumble coming from Wall Street these days is more than just the sound of charging bulls. It is also the noise of griping and grumbling -- about some of the fattest bonuses in history, no less.

title: For Poor, Sofas With Star Quality
description: Last week, Angelita McCloud leaned back into a snazzy brown leather recliner formerly owned by Jane Hanson, an NBC newscaster. Yes, it would be perfect for her living room, she said. Later that day, Shaevon Roquemore picked out a white sofa previously owned by Spike Lee.

title: Cross-Country With All the Comforts
description: MOST people may associate Big Sky, Mont., with Jane Fonda, Ted Turner, the late Chet Huntley and challenging downhill skiing. But to the growing legions of cross-country skiers, it is best known for Lone Mountain Ranch. With some 45 miles of packed and groomed trails, their tracks laid down by snowmobile, the ranch offers some of the finest cross-country skiing in the country.

title: Lori B. Doynow, David Schechner
description: Lori Beth Doynow, a daughter of Renee and David Doynow of Hartsdale, N.Y., is to be married this evening to David Sydney Schechner, a son of Norma and David Schechner of South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Lawrence Troster is to perform the ceremony at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Some Like It Hot While in Chinatown
description: HEE LOY TANG ++

title: An On-Line Consultation With a Number Cruncher
description: I HAVE to admit that the prospect of having my portfolio (or a rough approximation of it) analyzed free sounded appealing.

title: Cowboy Spurs
description: And so there comes more non-football news about the Dallas Cowboys. Adding to their previous five-player drug suspensions since 1994 is the sad announcement that Leon Lett will be ineligible to play for at least one year.

title: A Symbol on a Hill
description: CITY OF STONE

title: Kenneth Clark's Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: If Clara Had Met Her Nutcracker Prince on East End Ave.
description: Francis Patrelle, a veteran choreographer, remembers exactly where he was when he began conceiving his new version of ''The Nutcracker'': lost on his way home to Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. ''I was trying to get to the F.D.R. Drive,'' he said, ''and suddenly I saw it, all lit up: Gracie Mansion. I never knew it was there on 88th Street.''

title: A Voice for Israel
description: LIVING HISTORY

title: At La Marqueta, Concrete and Enamel
description: The newest part of La Marqueta, the sloping marketplace along Park Avenue in East Harlem, is a stunning conglomerate of concrete and brightly colored porcelain enamel. But last week it stood vacant, surrounded by a padlocked eight-foot picket fence.

title: Holocaust and the Enduring Need to Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: How 61 Grove Street Lost Its Southeast Corner
description: ROSLYN AND NORTON NESIS have tried to restore their small, oddly shaped apartment house at 61 Grove Street just as it was when it was built in 1890. That they have missed an entire corner should not be counted against them, for it has been absent since 1914, when Seventh Avenue South sliced through the West Village, destroying hundreds of structures and leaving a trail of oddly shaped buildings and tiny leftover lots.

title: Cadets Display Poise
description: On Navy's final play from the Army 10-yard line with 14 seconds remaining -- Colin Kearns, the Cadets' defensive tackle, charged Navy quarterback Ben Fay.

title: Parking Game Takes a Tricky Twist
description: If ever there were a silver lining in New York's budget woes, it was, for Greenwich Village residents' cars, the city's decision in 1991 to cancel street cleaning on Wednesdays and Saturdays. It meant that on those days, at least, their lives were no longer tethered to the alternate-side parking ritual that allows for such cleaning.

title: WHAT WILL GATES GIVE?
description: Michael Lewis's article ''What Will Gates Give?'' (The Capitalist, Oct. 13) overlooks the fact that Bill Gates has donated $270 million to charitable causes, including $200 million to his foundation, over the past several years.

title: I'll Be Home for Bacchanalia
description: The Battle for Christmas

title: A Bond Trader Will Put Quotes and Trades on Line
description: When stocks trade in this country, it is almost always easy for any interested observer to see the price and volume of trading. But when it comes to bonds, it is not so easy.

title: Rangers Turning It Around
description: Two weeks ago, at the low point of their season, the Rangers were refreshed by a visit to Phoenix. They won by 3-1 to launch their current six-game unbeaten streak of five victories and one tie.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unusual Criticism of Fed From Senate G.O.P. Leader

title: Carolers Dent a City-Suburb Wall
description: Kathy J. Tasich, a 51-year-old suburban schoolteacher in a beige overcoat, paused next to an 11th-century basalt column in Detroit's vast art museum and expressed delight with the cultural treasures she has recently discovered in the city, after years of seldom venturing downtown.

title: New York as Welfare Model
description: Gov. George Pataki's welfare plan contains a callous proposal to cut cash benefits nearly in half for long-term recipients. But the plan also includes worthwhile features that go beyond what other states are likely to propose to soften the blow of the new Federal welfare law. The encouraging fact is that the cruel features of the Pataki plan can be removed without wrecking New York's budget, leaving a welfare system that would serve as an enviable model for other states.

title: A Poet's Road Trip Along Main Street, U.S.A.
description: Sometimes he hits upon a lyrical scrap of haiku amid the hum of the crosstown subway. But essentially the Poet Laureate of the United States has put aside consulting his muse in favor of proselytizing Rotarians.

title: Musicians in Cleveland Accept 3-Year Contract
description: The musicians of the Cleveland Orchestra voted on Saturday to accept a three-year labor agreement offered by management on Friday evening, averting a strike the musicians had threatened for Saturday. The players had been performing without a contract all this season, but last week they announced that Saturday was their deadline for negotiations. The orchestra has not had a strike since 1980.

title: Wal-Mart's Free Choice
description: There is news worth celebrating on the popular-culture front. Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, has refused to stock compact disks with lyrics and cover art that it finds objectionable. If the artists and the record companies want Wal-Mart to carry their albums, they can alter the product to eliminate the offensive material.

title: Stocks Climb in Japan
description: Stocks closed higher here today, rebounding from a Friday selloff spurred by comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 327.01 points, or 1.61 percent, to 20,603.71. On Friday, the Nikkei lost 667.20 points, or 3.19 percent.

title: Meier to Receive Architects' Gold Medal
description: Richard Meier, the New York-based architect of pristine white structures of metal and glass, is to receive the American Institute of Architects' gold medal, its highest award. His most famous current work is the immense six-building Getty Center cultural complex, due to open next year in Los Angeles.

title: A new tombstone design can incorporate a person's life story -- including photographs.
description: ALI WEISS, an architect turned tombstone designer, contends that the cremation rate has climbed steadily over the last decade because the American funeral industry has depersonalized death. In an essay she wrote for Tikkun magazine, Ms. Weiss lamented the industry's ''staggering lack of imagination'' and ''blunt insensitivity to the demands of the human spirit.''

title: Allowing Gay Marriage Isn't a Majority View
description: To the Editor:

title: Davis Denounces ABC
description: AL DAVIS, the managing general partner of the Oakland Raiders, yesterday accused ABC Sports of a ''sneak attack'' and a ''cover-up'' yesterday for airing an interview with MARCUS ALLEN in 1992 during the halftime of a ''Monday Night Football'' game.

title: 5 Honored At Kennedy Center Gala
description: Johnny Cash settled into his chair at a Kennedy Center luncheon surrounded by other figures in the arts and leaders in Government and business, and agreed with the suggestion that he has been in far different circumstances.

title: Cool Abstract Patterns With a Playful Spirit
description: With its primary colors, vivid energy and cool geometric patterns, ''Polish Pieces,'' by the choreographer Hans van Manen, recalls the paintings of another Dutchman, Piet Mondrian.

title: Skipperless Denver Sinks in Green Bay
description: Having already clinched the American Football Conference West Division title and home-field advantage through the playoffs, the Broncos entered the game against the Packers at Lambeau Field this afternoon like a bunch of fat cats intoxicated by their success.

title: Letting Towns Limit Growth
description: The State Assembly's housing committee was expected to consider a bill today that would allow rural municipalities to build fewer low- and moderate-income housing units than they are currently required to build.

title: Turning Pages to Children's Pleasures
description: ''Childhood is measured out by sounds and smells and sights, before the dark hour of reason grows,'' the English poet John Betjeman wrote in ''Summoned by Bells.'' The following 10 illustrated children's books are silent, and they smell only faintly of printer's ink and binding glue. But they contain sights that may measure out pleasure to children, and to grown-ups looking for shafts of light in the dark of reason.

title: For Parcells, the Future Is Now
description: NOW that the Patriots were in the Super Bowl XXXI playoffs, the question was: Is Bill Parcells in the Patriots' future?

title: 'Social Clause' Looms As Contentious Issue At Singapore Meeting : WTO Is Set To Grapple With Rights Of Workers
description: SINGAPORE  Protectionism will probably increase in industrialized countries unless the World Trade Organization agrees this week to link working conditions and trade, Western officials and the world's largest workers' union warned Sunday.

title: Ex-Judge Faces Jail Sentence
description: A retired Somerset County Superior Court judge who was convicted of embezzling $173,000 from his former real estate partners was to be sentenced today for evading taxes on nearly $50,000 of that sum. The former judge, Michael Imbriane, 67, was sentenced last year to five years of probation for the embezzlement conviction. Mr. Imbriane, facing up to five years in jail and a $250,000 fine for tax evasion, was to be sentenced by Judge John C. Lifland of Federal District Court in Newark.

title: Brown Steals The Show In Miami
description: At game's end, pain was etched on the face of the quarterback with the Hall of Fame credentials. The other quarterback, the one with almost no job security, was smiling.

title: Quiet New York Welfare Experiment Has Had Mixed Success
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to enact the biggest changes in New York's welfare system in six decades borrows from an experiment that was initiated by his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, and has been quietly conducted in counties across the state with varying degrees of success.

title: On-Line Sales Soar for Cisco
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the leading producer of internetworking equipment, has made $75 million in electronic sales since it went on line less than five months ago with Cisco Connection Online, the company's World Wide Web site for business users, according to a story in the current issue of Communications Week.

title: Cable is busy resurrecting anything and everything that was once on the networks.
description: LIKE children of the 50's rooting through the closets in their old homesteads, searching for those old baseball cards, executives from television production studios are spending more time in their program vaults these days, dollar signs dancing in their heads with every heavy-hitter series from the past that they ferret out.

title: Get Used to It: Panthers Beat Niners Again, to Take Division Lead and Playoff Berth
description: O.K., so the Carolina Panthers had beaten the San Francisco 49ers in two of their three meetings since the Panthers joined the 49ers in the National Football Conference West as an expansion team a year ago. They had even toppled the 49ers by 23-7 in Week 4 in Carolina.

title: Key Leaves Yankees for 2-Year Orioles Deal
description: Six weeks and barely a day after he was the winning pitcher in the game that made the Yankees World Series champions for the first time in 18 years, Jimmy Key defected to the enemy yesterday.

title: A Course in Lit Crit and Pall at the Mall
description: To the Editor:

title: In Peru, U.S. Woman's Parents Lament Prison Conditions
description: The parents of a New York woman who is serving a life sentence for terrorism have been allowed to visit her for the first time -- in Peru's most notorious prison in this bleak, bitter-cold town 12,700 feet high in the Andes.

title: Crew Seeks Special District As Step to Charter Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has proposed what officials said was the first step toward establishing charter schools in New York City by calling for the creation of a special school district in which the city's most innovative and successful schools would be given more autonomy and flexibility.

title: The Safety Net Works
description: Again and again during the fight over welfare we heard self-righteous, sanctimonious and often very rich politicians proclaim that anti-poverty programs hadn't worked. The programs were actually harming the poor, they said. Echoing Dickens's most unforgiving villains, they reasoned that the best approach would be to cut the poor's already meager benefits. That would build character, they said. So they cut the benefits and called it reform.

title: John L. Loeb Sr. Dies at 94; Investor and Philanthropist
description: John Langeloth Loeb Sr., a leading member of the investment community who was long the head of the Wall Street firm of Loeb, Rhoades & Company, a predecessor of Shearson Lehman/American Express, died yesterday at his Upper East Side home in Manhattan. He was 94 and also had homes in Purchase, N.Y., and Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: A Paper Goes Afar For a Look At Itself
description: The St. Louis mayoral election is not until next spring, yet the race between two black candidates has already provoked accusations that The St. Louis Post-Dispatch is biased. So, to reassure the city's minority community, Cole C. Campbell, the paper's new editor, has hired a black journalism professor to act as a watchdog and readers' advocate.

title: Record Crash Death Toll in '96, But Statistically Travel Is Safer
description: With three weeks to go in 1996, more passengers have died in airline crashes this year than in any other, even though statistics show that air travel is becoming safer over time.

title: Ex-Soviet Pilot Still Insists KAL 007 Was Spying
description: Gennadi Osipovich held up his thick hands to show how, 13 years ago, he maneuvered his SU-15 fighter to blast a Korean 747 airliner out of the sky.

title: Police Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Mandarins, and a New Language Muddle
description: Like their British predecessors who landed here staking territorial claims in Victorian patois, China's officials sent to this waning colony swagger about today in the thick argot of Beijing. For the people of Hong Kong, both languages are equally alien, the speech of their rulers.

title: Donations to Universities Sometimes Carry a Price
