description: To the needy scholars of East Asia at the University of California campus here, the unexpected offer of a few million dollars for a new center to study ancient Chinese cultures sounded at first like a godsend.

title: Ad Review Council May Broaden Focus
description: The National Advertising Review Council, the advertising industry's self-regulatory organization, is considering proposals to broaden its focus beyond the truth and accuracy of advertising to handle inquiries into so-called age-restricted campaigns for products like alcoholic beverages, cigarettes and lottery tickets.

title: Above the Law?
description: Next month, a week before Clinton's second Inaugural, the Supreme Court will hear arguments about the right to sue the President for a civil wrong he is charged with committing before he took Federal office.

title: Copywriter Joins Martin Agency
description: Tom McElligott, the copywriter and longtime agency executive, has re-emerged after a four-year absence from the industry to join the Martin Agency as a part-time writer.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: After Burmese Protests, Capital Is Tense
description: The streets of Yangon were quiet but tense today as hundreds of policemen blocked off parts of the Burmese capital to prevent demonstrations by angry students.

title: Rulings in Simpson Trial Fuel Second-Guessing
description: The E-mail exchanges among evidence experts have escalated. The legal pundits have gone into analytical overdrive. And the betting has begun on whether grounds have already been created for a possible third O. J. Simpson trial -- a retrial should Mr. Simpson lose the current one.

title: New Software Speeds Multimedia Distribution
description: Could this be goodbye to the World Wide Wait? The Narrative Communications Corporation, a start-up company based in Waltham, Mass., is set to begin shipping its Enliven suite of software programs today. The software permits the distribution and viewing of feature-length interactive multimedia over the Internet using ordinary phone lines.

title: China Sends Controllers to U.S. To Improve English Proficiency
description: The task for the student air traffic controller was routine: tell the pilot to maintain level flight and pass over a specific point before proceeding to a landing at Orlando International Airport.

title: Foley Gets a Jets Look in His Eyes
description: It took Glenn Foley just a few minutes to realize how bad this Jets quarterbacking thing can get -- interceptions and sacks, that helpless feeling as you search the horizon trying to escape bad field position.

title: J. Walter Thompson gets a one-two punch, but is not knocked out of a review by one client.
description: A PAIR of clients landed a one-two punch Friday on the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York, placing a large account in review and shifting a plum assignment to another agency.

title: Risks of Making Literary Voices Sing Onstage
description: They aren't opponents you would expect to find in the same ring: a plain, scrappy English governess versus the entire United States, at its flashiest, as it struggles to enter the 20th century.

title: Electronic encyclopedias are slick, but have they become more a toy than a tool?
description: IT almost seems illicit, logging on to the Web site of the Encyclopaedia Britannica (http://www.eb.com) and looking up the word ''encyclopedia.'' It is as if one were cheating, not taking the subject seriously enough. The weightless medium seems ill suited to the weighty message.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: America's Shortchanged Diplomacy
description: President Clinton, now preparing next year's budget requests, will have to fight hard to provide Madeleine Albright with adequate resources to represent America's international interests as Secretary of State. Diplomacy is America's first and least costly line of defense against international conflict. Yet for years Congress has been letting that line erode dangerously.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Paterson Gets a Better Grade
description: Five years after the state took control of Paterson's troubled school system, the district has made significant gains in student achievement and teacher training and has improved its accounting practices, said the state-appointed Superintendent of Schools, Dr. Laval S. Wilson. He noted, however, that there is still room for improvement, particularly of performance on standardized tests.

title: First Trip for St. John's To N.C.A.A. Semifinals
description: The soccer program at St. John's climbed to new heights yesterday when the Red Storm reached the final four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament with a 2-1 overtime triumph over William & Mary in Norfolk, Va.

title: SGS-Thomson Carves Niche Outside the Computer World
description: From the standpoint of aeronautical design, seagulls should not be able to fly, Pasquale Pistorio likes to say, when urging his workers to greater achievement. Fortunately, he adds with a characteristic chuckle, the seagulls don't know it.

title: Warning by Benetton
description: The Benetton team manager has threatened to boycott Formula One races in Italy if there are convictions for the 1994 death of driver Ayrton Senna at Imola.

title: It's a Wonderful Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Plans 300% Increase in Spending for Basic Research in 1997
description: Defying a trend away from unfettered corporate scientific research, the Microsoft Corporation plans to increase spending for basic research by 300 percent in 1997.

title: A Surreal Transaction in Sudan Wins Freedom for 3 Aid Workers
description: In a bargain he called ''surreal,'' a United States Congressman teamed up today with a Sudanese diplomat to persuade an unpredictable and prideful rebel leader to free three Red Cross workers held hostage for 38 days.

title: David Osborne, 81; Led Navy Doctors
description: Rear Adm. David Paul Osborne, a retired surgeon who had been the Deputy Surgeon General of the Navy and the commander of the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., died at the center on Nov. 23. He was 81 and lived in Satellite Beach, Fla., and Smethport, Pa.

title: Plug In, Stay Tuned and Take Off
description: Jet travel may have lost its novelty, but something else is coming to aircraft cabins: all the passive entertainment of television, from the 24-hour drone of cable news to re-runs of ''Bewitched'' to live sporting events.

title: Snow Buries Connecticut In Problems
description: A northeaster buried northern Connecticut in up to 16 inches of snow late Saturday and early this morning, leaving the state a tangle of broken trees and fallen power lines and stranding thousands of people in chilly homes that had lost electricity.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In her first solo press conference, CROWN PRINCESS MASAKO of Japan said yesterday that the conflict between ancient palace ways and her self has caused her ''hardship.''

title: Algeria's Constitution Accords With Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is something about a chair that has singular appeal, or so CYNTHIA O'NEAL, the president of Friends in Deed, an organization providing emotional and spiritual services to people with AIDS, cancer and other life-threatening illnesses, has learned in the course of working on a benefit revolving around chairs.

title: French Court Battle Delays Study of Ancient Cave's Artworks
description: Two years ago, amateur explorers found an astonishing prehistoric cave adorned with wall-paintings so masterly drawn and beautifully preserved that experts likened the find to a time capsule full of hidden treasures.

title: Donors for All Seasons Give Appeal a Jump Start
description: They were the stragglers of April and the early birds of November. And some simply considered the plight of others on a summer afternoon. Together, their contributions helped The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begin its annual appeal on behalf of the city's poor.

title: Bellhop Killed, 3 Wounded in Times Square Shooting
description: A shooting on West 43d Street spilled into one of Times Square's new upscale establishments early yesterday morning when a stray bullet crashed through the window of a hotel, killing a 50-year-old bellhop working the late shift in its marble and mosaic lobby, the police said.

title: Publish the Nuptials
description: To the Editor:

title: Offerings of Equities Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Classical and Pop Music Dare to Mix at One Party
description: On PBS tonight ''Great Performances'' does a trendy synergistic turn with a kind of ''you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours'' co-production. The distinguished series has teamed up with Sony Classical for a 90-minute special (two hours with interruptions for subscriber pitches) called, rather laboriously, ''Bobby McFerrin: Loosely Mozart -- The New Innovators of Classical Music.'' Not surprisingly, though there is no hard sell, the show's material is available on Sony Classical recordings.

title: Immigrants' Shortcuts To Essential Information
description: Despite recent anti-immigration laws and sentiment, legal newcomers can more quickly and easily negotiate the roadblocks. Some World Wide Web sites prepare the user for various bureaucratic immigration processes. In addition, there are sites run by ethnic groups with leads on jobs, recreation, schooling, local clubs and legal issues.

title: Hollywood Feels Chill Of Chinese Warning To Disney
description: When the Chinese Government recently warned the Walt Disney Company that the release of a new film about the Dalai Lama could cripple Disney's efforts to expand into China, company officials responded with a terse statement in support of the movie, ''Kundun,'' directed by Martin Scorsese.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Hamilton Mitchell, Company Executive, 80
description: Hamilton B. Mitchell, a former chairman and chief executive of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, died at his home in Tucson, Ariz., last Tuesday. He was 80.

title: SERBIA HIGH COURT UPHOLDS MILOSEVIC ON ANNULLING VOTE
description: The Serbian Supreme Court has endorsed the Government's annulment of local elections that had given control of the capital to the opposition, it was announced tonight. The decision seemed likely to heighten the tension between President Slobodan Milosevic and tens of thousands of demonstrators who have taken to the streets for the last three weeks, accusing his party's officials of vote-rigging.

title: Classical Music Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Are Selected For Hall of Fame
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington has selected four executives to be inducted into the Advertising Hall of Fame in 1997. The honorees are: Jo Foxworth, president of Jo Foxworth Inc. in New York; the late Morris L. Hite, former chairman and president of Tracy-Locke in Dallas, which is now part of several units of Omnicom Group; William E. LaMothe, former chairman and chief executive of the Kellogg Company in Battle Creek, Mich., and the late Frank L. Mingo, who had been chairman of Mingo Group in New York, now Chisholm-Mingo Group, and Muse Cordero Chen in Los Angeles. They will be honored at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York on March 27, 1997.

title: A Cable Giant Loses Its Way and Finds Recovery Difficult
description: It was a startling comeback. After a year of playing the elusive chief executive, the cable titan John C. Malone suddenly appeared at a Bear, Stearns media conference on Oct. 24 and told major shareholders of his company, Tele-Communications Inc., ''It's not true that I have no interest in cable; it's fun being Darth Vader again.''

title: Dying to Be Black
description: As white teen-agers go, so goes the music business. Inner-city buyers initiate the fads, but it takes massive expenditures by whites in the suburbs to sustain them. In the first days of this month, kids from Maine to California swarmed to the mall for new recordings by the recently murdered rap star Tupac Shakur and his fellow rapper Snoop Doggy Dogg, himself narrowly acquitted of a murder charge. Both recordings emanate from Death Row Records and its distributor Interscope, which together pioneered the version of rap music that revels in violence and misogyny in general and drive-by shootings in particular.

title: Pushing the Envelope on Delivery of Customized Internet Data
description: Remember the couch potato? Now the computer industry is eager to create the mouse potato.

title: Republican Senate Chief Questions the Fed
description: Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, said today that he was ''a little bit nervous about the degree of independence'' enjoyed by the Federal Reserve, and that the central bank should push interest rates lower to stimulate more economic growth.

title: Irving Gordon, 81, Writer of Pop Hits
description: Irving Gordon, who wrote the Nat (King) Cole hit ''Unforgettable,'' died Dec. 1 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

title: Skilled Capital Defenders Help Convictions Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Due in Baby's Death
description: A grand jury in Wilmington, Del., was expected to rule today in the case of two New Jersey college students accused of murdering their baby son.

title: INSIDE
description: Party Unity vs. Ideology

title: Bernadette Peters in Carnegie Hall Benefit
description: The Tony Award-winning singer and actress Bernadette Peters is to perform her solo debut at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8 to benefit Gay Men's Health Crisis. Founded in 1981, the service is the oldest and largest AIDS organization in New York City for men, women and children with H.I.V. and AIDS.

title: The Giants Over Miami? It's True: Guaranteed
description: It got so bad for the Miami Dolphins today that boos were even being directed at their coach, Jimmy Johnson. Booed? The savior? Say it ain't so. Of course, it has not reached the point in Miami where the fans want to send Johnson and his perfect hair back to his million-dollar yacht. But it was definitely a blow to his image today when the Giants, of all teams, sent his team into oblivion.

title: Jose Donoso, 72, Fantastical Chilean Novelist
description: Jose Donoso, one of Chile's best-known authors, whose novels and short stories used dark surrealism and social satire to explore the haunted lives of exiles and writers and a world of aristocratic excesses, died on Saturday in Santiago. He was 72 years old.

title: No Headline
description: ''My mantra was, capitalism makes networks. It doesn't make communities. Imagination makes communities.'' ROBERT HASS, Poet Laureate of the United States. $(B8:6$)

title: Target Stores Names Kirshenbaum Bond
description: The Target Stores unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation in Minneapolis has named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York to help introduce the Target chain of discount stores in the metropolitan New York market. Though billings have not been determined, The Delaney Report newsletter estimated them to be at least $10 million.

title: Cabdriver Is Killed on S.I.
description: A livery-cab driver was killed early yesterday on Staten Island, apparently in a robbery, the police said.

title: Magazines Reassess What It Is Men Really Want
description: Walk by any copies on the newsstand and you could mistake them for Glamour, Cosmopolitan or Self. The cover lines promise ''Double Your Sexual Endurance,'' ''Stay Warm, Look Cool,'' and ''What to Do With 30 Pounds of Ugly Flab.''

title: Alabama Expected To Promote Assistant
description: Alabama's defensive coordinator, MIKE DUBOSE, is expected to be named the Crimson Tide's new head coach today. The Birmingham News and Mobile Press-Register, each citing sources close to the athletic department, have reported that Dubose, 43, will be named the successor to GENE STALLINGS at a news conference today in Tuscaloosa.

title: Slovakia Had No Role in Editor's Dismissal
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Wants His Own Chief
description: James Whelan, the Mayor of Atlantic City, caused a stir last week when he said the city's Police Department had a ''Mafia mind-set.'' Officers from the 429-member force had criticized the Mayor's plan to replace the retiring police chief with a director of public safety, possibly from outside the police ranks.

title: Republican Opposition to Party's Candidate Could Elect Democrat in a Texas District
description: Now that the elections are almost over and Republicans have a diminished majority in the United States House of Representatives, Texas Republicans have managed to create a fracas out of what sounds like a political no-brainer: would they like to send one more Republican to Congress?

title: Virginia Downing, Stage Actress, 92
description: Virginia Downing, an actress in theater, films and television for 70 years, died on Nov. 21 in Manhattan. She was 92 and was on her way to a theater.

title: Fitting Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: The Freshman Holloway Helps Out Seton Hall
description: He stands only 5 feet 10 inches, a twig in a forest of overgrown players. His shorts droop over his knees, looking like the last pair in the equipment room or a dirty trick by a 1970's Paris couturier.

title: 3-Day-Old Girl Left In a Bag in Brooklyn Is Found Healthy
description: A 3-day-old girl was found alive in a paper bag Saturday night after she was abandoned in the lobby of an apartment building in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Nobody Reads a Good Movie These Days
description: Three French films opening this month -- Patrice Leconte's ''Ridicule,'' Claude Chabrol's ''Ceremonie,''and Andre Techine's ''Voleurs'' (''Thieves'') -- bring to 55 the total of foreign-language films released in 1996 in New York.

title: In Disney World, Faux Memories of Atlantic City
description: She wore a sequined white wedding gown; he wore a tux. They were married in a pavilion filled with flowers. Afterward, hand in hand, they took a stroll on the boardwalk, just as they had in the rosy summers of their courtship.

title: Language Gap Plays Role In Hundreds of Air Deaths
description: By treaty, controllers and pilots in international aviation are all supposed to speak English, but hundreds of passengers and crew members have died in crashes that were caused at least in part by language problems.

title: Woman Who Saved 2 Is Called 'Fighter'
description: In the 32 years she lived on Madison Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, a neighborhood where the night air is often punctuated by gunfire, Evelyn Davis never aspired to be a hero, her family said yesterday.

title: Saluting Choreographer
description: The Juilliard Dance Division will salute the choreographer Glen Tetley with a free program of his ballets tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, in Manhattan. In addition, Mr. Tetley will speak about his philosophy of dance. There will be free programs Thursday through Saturday at 8 P.M. Information: (212) 769-7406.

title: Monroe Green, 92, Is Dead; Times Advertising Director
description: Monroe Green, a former vice president of The New York Times who directed the newspaper's advertising department through more than two decades of significant innovation and growth, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92.

title: Bridge
description: The best book of 1996 in the area of defensive play is certainly Mike Lawrence's ''Opening Leads.''

title: Light In the Darkness
description: Dr. Ma Thida, a 29-year-old Burmese surgeon, is confined alone in a Rangoon cell, forbidden reading material. She was sentenced to 20 years in prison in 1993 for ''endangering public tranquillity, having contact with unlawful organizations and distributing unlawful literature.'' That means she supported democracy in Burma.

title: Credit Offerings Set for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Fallout From a Storm: Thousands Lose Power
description: A northeaster buried northern Connecticut in up to 16 inches of snow late Saturday and early yesterday, leaving the state a tangle of broken trees and fallen power lines and stranding thousands of people in chilly homes that had lost electricity.

title: A Rematch in New Orleans; An Alliance Snub for B.Y.U.
description: His team had won a conference championship game on Saturday, Brigham Young University's 13th victory in a season that was soon to become a bitter disappointment. Yesterday, LaVell Edwards sat in a control room at CBS, listening to other coaches talking about the major bowl bids. When the official announcements were complete and the six spots in the bowl alliance had been filled without B.Y.U., Edwards removed the microphone he had worn just in case, flipped it on a console and leaned back in a chair.

title: Looking Back With Recipes And Memories
description: METRO MATTERS does not normally much concern itself with food, unless the subject is hunger or food stamps or the zoning of superstores. But the holiday season produced an appetite for sentiment and nostalgia, especially for a time when one could eat anything with impunity and did not have to think of popcorn as fiber or broccoli as a cruciferous vegetable with cancer-fighting properties.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the releases of major economic indicators this week.

title: Ewing Calls Foul On Booing Knick Fans
description: For a person who has been criticized for not being outspoken, Patrick Ewing said a mouthful Saturday night.

title: Protecting Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Parker Plays, With or Without a Sax
description: One of the featured attractions of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater this season is a new production of ''For 'Bird' -- With Love,'' a tribute to the jazz saxophonist Charlie (Bird) Parker that Ailey created in 1984.

title: Re-examining Police Report On Visit to Rowland Home
description: Two years ago, John G. Rowland's campaign for governor began to spin out of control when The Hartford Courant sought to obtain a police report detailing an argument Mr. Rowland had with his former wife, Deborah.

title: Officials' Soaring Egos Battle Over an Airstrip in Chicago
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley and Gov. Jim Edgar have been fighting for years about big ticket public works projects, like a new transportation hub and a new stadium for the Chicago Bears football team.

title: Tar Heels Regain National Crown with Overtime Victory
description: ''It's coming,'' Tiffany Roberts said. ''It's coming.''

title: Race to Equalize School Aid
description: With a court-imposed deadline only three weeks away for New Jersey to develop a plan to equalize spending among school districts, lawmakers are scrambling for ways to even out the dollars. The State Senate Budget Committee was scheduled to consider legislation today that would increase the $4 billion education budget by $259.8 million and limit how much school districts can increase or reduce their budgets. Next week the State Assembly Education Committee is to consider a bill that would increase the education budget by up to $275 million.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES ACQUIRES 3 MICHIGAN MALLS
description: General Growth Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had bought three Michigan shopping malls from the investment group Forbes/Cohen Properties for $40 million in partnership units, $4 million in cash and the assumption of $90 million of debt. The purchase came a week after General Growth, based in Chicago, bought two Oklahoma malls for $52 million. The developer said last month it planned to buy about $250 million worth of malls by the end of the first quarter of 1997. The purchase of the Michigan malls, in Lansing, Battle Creek and Jackson, increases General Growth's holdings to 114 shopping centers in 38 states, with 99 million square feet of space.

title: Only New Packaging
description: To the Editor:

title: Serb Leader's Foes Persist, Hoping He Will Blink First
description: The Serbian opposition, smarting from the latest refusal by Government courts to overturn the annulment of local elections, came out today 100,000 strong to begin the third week of protests.

title: A new proxy strategy: Upgrading the dissident slate.
description: GUY P. WYSER-PRATTE, the New York arbitrager best known for his willingness to wage proxy fights against what he considers recalcitrant managements and boards, has another company in his sights: the Rexene Corporation, which recently rebuffed several takeover bids from the Huntsman Corporation.

title: Ex-Officer to Pay $813,000 in AT&T Insider Case
description: A former AT& T Corporation executive who was part of one of the largest cases of insider trading on record has agreed to pay more than $813,000 in fines, interest and restitution to settle civil charges filed against him in the case, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: Computer Chip Sales Ratio Up
description: The computer chip industry's book-to-bill ratio rose more than expected in November, to 1.15, from October's revised 1.11, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.

title: An Old Leaf and a New One
description: Bush

title: 5 Regional Phone Companies Select Netscape
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said today that it had entered a strategic marketing agreement under which five regional telephone operating companies will make Netscape Navigator their primary browser software for the Internet.

title: Choosing Pragmatism Over Confrontation To Preserve Arts Grants
description: If there is a limit to the political attacks and budget cuts that Jane Alexander is willing to endure on behalf of the National Endowment for the Arts, she is not yet ready to admit it.

title: Reports of Slavery in a Divided Land
description: Tonight's edition of ''Dateline NBC'' features a striking investigation into charges that slavery persists in the Sudan. Taking up a public challenge by Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader, who has put himself forward as a defender of the Sudan's much-criticized Muslim fundamentalist Government, the program's correspondent, Sara James, went to the unreceptive land and talked to some of its people. ''We discovered eyewitnesses to slavery everywhere,'' she says.

title: Sharper Limits on New England Fishing Are Needed, Panel Says
description: The sharp limits already imposed on New England's commercial fishing fleets have not done enough to save the region's cod, haddock and flounder, and much bigger reductions are needed, a scientific panel has told fishery managers.

title: Good News for Good Drivers
description: Many New Jersey drivers know the feeling: after a 20-year record of spotless driving, you are convicted of a moving violation, and your annual car insurance premium shoots up by hundreds of dollars.

title: Don't Be a Stranger, Says Mexico to Emigres in U.S.
description: For decades, successive Mexican Governments mostly ignored Mexicans living in the United States, or even viewed them as traitors who had abandoned their country.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Emergency Rule Keeps Ireland's Strife in Check
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Jury Award In Injury Case Over Keyboards
description: In a significant defeat for computer keyboard makers, a Federal jury in Brooklyn has awarded nearly $6 million to three women who sustained arm, wrist and hand injuries while using keyboards made by the Digital Equipment Corporation.

title: Unicef at 50
description: In 1968, researchers in what is now Bangladesh made a discovery that the British medical journal The Lancet called ''potentially the most important medical advance of the century.'' It was that adding the right amount of glucose and salt allows water to stay in the digestive tract long enough to be absorbed.

title: Chess
description: Judit Polgar has recently headed down a blind alley that is causing her to lose games. Ambitious players are confronting her with an aggressive attack against her favorite defense, and she has not succeeded in counteracting it or in maneuvering around it. Nor has she switched to some other defense.

title: Kohl and Chirac Keep Veneer of Unity on European Currency
description: Two weeks ago, Helmut Kohl and Jacques Chirac were in Perigueux, France, to celebrate a cookbook of German cuisine by Mr. Kohl's wife, Hannelore. Then Mr. Kohl, the German Chancellor, went to Paris for another tete-a-tete with Mr. Chirac, the French President, who strolled to the German leader's hotel to meet him.

title: Time for Peace in East Timor
description: The time has come to end the tragedy in East Timor once and for all. After 21 years of conflict, people in this former Portuguese colony want calm, an end to violence and respect for their human rights.

title: Early Stories, Before a Master Found His Voice
description: FLYING HOME

title: CHRONICLE
description: It is sure to be a bittersweet moment for C. LOWELL HARRISS, 88, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University, when he accepts the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today. He is to receive the award in the name of his friend of 61 years, WILLIAM VICKREY, who died of a heart attack in October at 82, three days after learning that he had won the prize.

title: Combining Caribbean And Modern
description: The National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica brought a generous and spirited program to Brooklyn College on Friday night. Three New York premieres attested to the eclecticism of this group, which combines modern-dance techniques with choreography based on the folklore and history of the Caribbean.

title: Salsa Star Sings Less Carefree Song After Jail Stay
description: When his cell door opened at the end of November after 11 months and 18 days, Jairo Varela could not walk out a free man. He took a few steps outside the prison gate, but fans who had been anticipating his release swarmed around him.

title: Property and Currencies Popular : Appetite of Investors Turns to the Exotic
description: PARIS  "For an Asian, if the Asian markets are doing really well, they generally prefer to stay in the markets they know," said Lin Yoke Seetoh, director of Unit Trusts Asia/Pacific, a unit of Baring Asset Management.

title: Chance of WTO Technology Deal Is Looking Good Again
description: SINGAPORE  Top U.S. and European Union officials said Monday that they had made progress in narrowing differences and were hoping to seal an accord by the end of this week to liberalize global trade in the $500 billion-a-year information-technology market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Shares Surge, Leading Market's Rebound

title: Crew Wins in Effort To Take Over Distrtict
description: In a victory for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, the Justice Department reversed an earlier ruling and approved the Chancellor's plan to take over a district in the South Bronx. The decision was the latest chapter in a long-running battle between Dr. Crew and the members of the District 12 board, whom the Chancellor suspended in a dispute over the board's choice of a superintendent. The Government found that Dr. Crew's new plan met the demands of the Voting Rights Act.

title: HILTON AND LADBROKE IN TALKS ON CASINO JOINT VENTURES
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it was discussing possible casino joint ventures in the United States with Ladbroke Group of Britain. Hilton, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said that Ladbroke was applying for a Nevada casino license but declined to give further details on the talks. Ladbroke would say only that the two companies were in talks. Three months ago, Hilton agreed to acquire a 5 percent stake in Ladbroke, which owns the Hilton name outside of the United States. Hilton's biggest casino project is the $600 million Paris Casino Resort it plans to build on the Las Vegas strip.

title: An Issue of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers Are Changing the Shape of the Utility Industry
description: It was minutes before midnight on Friday, Nov. 22, and John W. Barr and Jeffrey R. Holzschuh had just helped rescue the biggest deal in the hottest year for mergers in the history of the American energy utility industry -- a $7.7 billion combination of the Duke Power Company of Charlotte, N.C., and the Panenergy Corporation of Houston.

title: Mayor Signals an End to D'Amato Feud
description: Signaling a precampaign end to a quarrel that has colored New York Republican politics for years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would attend a fund-raiser for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato this evening, a clear indication that he intends to endorse Mr. D'Amato's re-election bid in 1998.

title: Former Ally of Mandela Plans To Form Rival Political Party
description: A former high-level official of President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress announced today that he was dropping his efforts to regain his standing in the party and would instead begin exploring ways to create a rival political party.

title: Koreans Woo French Public Opinion onTakeover
description: PARIS  One of the media events in France in recent weeks has been an advertising campaign by South Korea's Daewoo Electronics to make itself known to a suspicious French public as it plans to take over Thomson Multimedia (TMM), France's main domestic maker of television sets and video-recorders.

title: From Japanese Princess, a Hint the Crown Feels Heavy
description: In her first solo news conference with Japanese reporters, which was made public today, Crown Princess Masako spoke vaguely about searching for a balance between her own identity and the traditional role of a crown princess.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Guide column of the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday misstated the dates of four events. The winter solstice celebrations in East Norwalk and Glastonbury will be on Dec. 21, not next Saturday; the celebration in Stamford will be on Dec. 20, not next Friday.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Others Tell of On-Line Chats With Torture Suspect
description: About a dozen people from across the country have told the police and prosecutors in Manhattan that they communicated by computer with Oliver Jovanovic, a Columbia doctoral student charged with attacking a woman he met on line.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with Books of The Times yesterday misstated the title of a children's book from which the illustration was taken. It was ''The Story of Little Babaji,'' not ''The Story of Babaji.''

title: Ewing Has It All Wrong
description: THE fans are annoying Patrick Ewing, a tall person who plays a game for a living -- and quite a handsome living, at that. Mr. Ewing expressed his vexation after having played a basketball game Saturday night in Madison Square Garden. He and the group of adults he plays with, collectively known as the Knickerbockers, were booed heartily by some 20,000 spectators after a lackluster victory over the lusterless Los Angeles Clippers.

title: New Mastercard Is Aimed At Middle-Class Borrowers
description: Responding to American Express's moves to lure middle-income credit card borrowers, Mastercard is introducing a travel-oriented card today aimed squarely at American Express's traditional base of people who pay their monthly bills in full.

title: Back in the Statehouse After 4 Decades Away
description: In a campaign stressing clean government and mine safety, Cecil H. Underwood toted a stepladder around the state, using it as a metaphor for ''reaching a higher level.'' He won almost 54 percent of the vote and, at 34, became the youngest person ever elected Governor of West Virginia.

title: 19 Teams Have Eyes On Playoffs
description: With just two more weeks remaining in the National Football League regular season, three division titles and six wild-card spots are still up for grabs. Teams that started out with so much promise, such as Washington and Buffalo, are now fighting to keep from falling out of the playoffs. Teams such as Minnesota (8-6), Indianapolis (8-6), Houston (7-7), Jacksonville (7-7) and San Diego (7-7) are clawing to make it in.

title: Sparks Fly When Reeves Makes Noise
description: The Giants are a team that cannot stand prosperity. They got a big victory over Miami, practically knocking the Dolphins out of the playoffs. Dave Brown played well and Tyrone Wheatley had a sweet 37-yard run. Then, just when things seemed rosy, Giants Coach Dan Reeves took the podium at his news conference this afternoon and that was when things got crazy.

title: Hearing on Victory Bridge
description: Each day, more than 20,000 cars traveling on Route 35 cross the swing bridge across the broad Raritan River at Perth Amboy. But the Victory Bridge, built in 1926 and named to honor the dead of World War I, is deteriorating and causes traffic jams each time its center section swings open to let boats pass through.

title: Tiny Music Niches
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Gray and 50-ish, a 60's Movement Honors Mario Savio
description: The Free Speech Movement came back to Berkeley yesterday, tromping across the campus plaza and pouring into the buildings stormed so many years ago.

title: Avon Lady Leads Way Into Philippine Market
description: MANILA  From crowded city streets to rural villages, theAvon Lady is scouring the Philippines'7,000 islands.

title: Rowland Case Not Fully Investigated, Paper Says
description: A lawyer for The Hartford Courant said today that the police had failed to investigate thoroughly a dispute two years ago between Gov. John G. Rowland and his former wife, Deborah, and then improperly denied a reporter a copy of the police report on the complaints.

title: After 3 Years of Witnesses' Silence, Man Is Charged in a College Student's Killing
description: On a winter night almost three years ago, a college student named Louis Balancio who was planning a career as an accountant was stabbed 12 times outside a Yonkers sports bar and died of his wounds. Twenty to 25 people, many of them members of two Yonkers street gangs, saw the slaying.

title: Suzanne Railey, 85, Christie's Representative
description: Suzanne Railey, a representative for Christie's auction house who was known for her talents as an international hostess, died last weekend in her Manhattan apartment. She was 85.

title: The Americanization of an Offbeat Player
description: Four years ago, Zigmund Palffy could barely speak any English at all. Now, he adds to an ever-expanding, if not exactly erudite, vocabulary by listening to Jerky Boys recordings.

title: Knicks Stand By Their Big Man
description: Through streaks of greatness and slides of horrendous play, Patrick Ewing has always had Jeff Van Gundy's backing. He implored management to retain the longtime Knick assistant after last season, and his support for Van Gundy has been unwavering during an early-season skid.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Sonics Coach Fined
description: GEORGE KARL, the coach of the Seattle SuperSonics, was fined $8,500 for verbally abusing the referees and for refusing to leave the court last Thursday. Karl got into a dispute and was ejected with five minutes left in a 117-86 victory against the Timberwolves at Minnesota. (AP)

title: Accused Unabomber in Court
description: Live via video hookup from Sacramento, Calif., the man accused of being the Unabomber, Theodore J. Kaczynski, is scheduled to enter a plea in the Federal courthouse in Newark today to charges that he mailed a bomb to a North Caldwell advertising executive. Two years ago today, the executive, Thomas J. Mosser, was killed by a package that exploded.

title: Aide Gets Alabama Post
description: Some 20 years after fulfilling his dream of playing for BEAR BRYANT at Alabama, MIKE DUBOSE got Bryant's old job yesterday. BOB BOCKRATH, Alabama's athletic director, announced Dubose's hiring as head coach yesterday to replace GENE STALLINGS.

title: Koreans Find Golf Paradise
description: LOS ANGELES  In South Korea, golfers pay dearly for their time on the green or at the driving range. Not so in Southern California, where the game's accessibility is fueling a boom among the immigrant community.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DEAN KOONTZ, the best-selling author of horror novels, is switching publishers, moving from Alfred A. Knopf to Bantam, it was announced yesterday.

title: Student Foes of Belgrade Leader Embrace Fierce Serb Nationalism
description: The front door of the Philosophy Department at Belgrade University is guarded by several curt young men with tags on their jackets identifying them as ''security.'' The students frequently turn away visitors and at times verbally abuse them as ''liars'' or ''American scum.'' Students who attempt to speak to outsiders are told by the security detail that only ''the committee'' has the right to make statements.

title: Fur That Never Had Paws
description: As autumn segues into winter, it's a good idea to have accessories that do more than look good. A cuddly scarf or hat, say, which can keep you warm as well as stylish. And the most stylish scarfs and hats this season are in fake fur. The newest hats aren't stiff; they are as soft as knits, so they can be scrunched up for storing in pocket or handbag.

title: Levine and Met Orchestra In a Forceful Verdi Requiem
description: You couldn't call it long awaited, exactly, for until James Levine and the Met Orchestra took up residence at Carnegie Hall in recent years, it never seemed a lively possibility. But from the time it was announced early this year, the prospect of a Verdi Requiem by Met forces summoned memories of a performance Mr. Levine led in 1982 on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FELIX and ELIZABETH ROHATYN have left their mark on New York in a variety of ways. He is the managing director of Lazard Freres and was chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation when it helped save the city from bankruptcy in the 1970's. She is the chairwoman of the New York Public Library.

title: $112 Million Offered to End Legal Claims On Spine Pins
description: A medical equipment company has offered to pay $112 million to settle claims by thousands of patients who said the pain in their backs worsened after surgeons inserted steel screws and plates intended to help them. Some patients said the screws broke inside their spines.

title: Heisman Invitees
description: Florida quarterback DANNY WUERFFEL and Iowa State running back TROY DAVIS were among four players invited yesterday to Saturday night's Heisman Trophy presentation. Also invited to the Downtown Athletic Club in Manhattan were Arizona State quarterback JAKE PLUMMER and Ohio State offensive tackle ORLANDO PACE. Another invitation is expected today. (AP)

title: NEW LOOK URGED ON GULF SYNDROME
description: The scientist who led a 1994 Pentagon study that discounted links between chemical weapons and the illnesses reported by veterans of the Persian Gulf war said today that some of the findings might have to be revised in light of newly disclosed evidence from the Pentagon -- evidence the Defense Department did not share with him at the time of his investigation.

title: High Cost of C.D.'s Contributes to the Record Industry's Slump
description: To the Editor:

title: Movement as Meditation And the Body as a Prayer
description: Visitors to a foreign city sometimes find themselves attracted by the splendor of an unfamiliar house of worship. Inside, they discover a service in progress that, though totally incomprehensible, proves stirring simply because of its liturgical beauty.

title: Challenge for the Bulls Is to Repair the Cracks
description: Suddenly, the Chicago Bulls hardly look unbeatable. They have lost two consecutive regular-season games for the first time since February.

title: The Eagles Are Coming, Bringing Bad Memories
description: This is the convergence of the two great opportunities, and two great disappointments, in the career of Coach Rich Kotite. And he will repeat his own tale of two cities all week.

title: Disabled-Children's Camp Offers Respite From Woes
description: Christopher Sanes looked up at his mother, smiled and blinked twice -- once to say yes, he is happy to leave for his trip, and again to show how much he loves camp.

title: Inmate Hangs Himself in Cell
description: A 26-year-old North Arlington man awaiting sentencing for two bank robberies and facing a possible indictment for a third hanged himself with a bedsheet in his cell at the Hudson County Correctional Center early Sunday, officials said. The inmate, William O'Mara, had surrendered to the authorities in October after robbing two Hudson County banks by passing a note to tellers demanding cash, said Carmen Messano, the County Prosecutor.

title: In Their New Digs, the Raiders Bury Their Old Nemesis
description: It is a new Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum here, what with all of the sparkling renovations and spiffy club seating and entertainment. It is a new football team here in Oakland, too, especially in the season's second half.

title: Swiss Economy Continues to Contract
description: Switzerland's economy shrank in the third quarter in its seventh consecutive quarterly decline. Gross domestic product fell at an annualized rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter and seven-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, a Government spokesman said. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Ashland to Cut Back on Refining Business
description: Under pressure from a dissident stockholder group and Wall Street, Ashland Inc. said yesterday that it would cut spending on its core refining business and focus more on its other businesses.

title: Love of Lyrics That Are Here to Stay
description: Carnegie Hall became a dreamland of extravagant romantic whimsy on Friday evening, as a wonderfully well-chosen group of entertainers celebrated the centennial of Ira Gershwin's birth. For nearly three hours, the Rockies crumbled and Gibraltar tumbled under the gentle pressure of songs that conjured happily-ever-after in the tongue-in-cheek vocabulary of a lyricist whose peers nicknamed him ''the jeweler'' for his brilliance at fitting witty three- and four-syllable rhymes into melodies that were usually written ahead of time.

title: Ocean Spray Shifts Work to Arnold
description: In a big change involving two New England agencies and a large advertiser, Ocean Spray Cranberries has moved several assignments, with billings estimated at $50 million, to Arnold Communications in Boston from North Castle Partners in Stamford, Conn. Sixteen North Castle employees -- including Lynn Rotando, chairman, president and chief executive -- will also join Arnold.

title: The Split on Social Security
description: A Federal advisory panel on Social Security ended its deliberations without coming to agreement on a plan to shore up the system's financial future. Instead it will present three different plans, none with majority support. Fortunately, a good plan can be stitched together from the best parts of two of the three plans. But the lack of consensus probably will delay the date that Congress solves the entire Social Security problem.

title: Yankees Ask Wells To Name His Price
description: General Manager Bob Watson asked David Wells's agent last night to tell him precisely how much money it would take to make Wells a Yankee. The agent, Gregg Clifton, hesitated because he does not like to negotiate in that manner, but Wells wants to be a Yankee and he told the agent to give Watson a number.

title: Jones-N.F.L. Lawsuits May End in a Draw
description: A year ago, the Cowboys and the National Football League were fussing and feuding over the Dallas owner Jerry Jones's signing of Nike, Dr Pepper and Pepsi-Cola as sponsors of Texas Stadium, and his advocating the dismemberment of NFL Properties in order to let local teams market themselves more profitably.

title: Monsanto Chooses a Spinoff Of Its Chemical Operations
description: The Monsanto Company, which announced in October that it was considering shedding its $3 billion chemicals business, said today that it would spin the unit off to Monsanto's shareholders and in the process cut up to 2,500 jobs, 9 percent of the company's work force.

title: Careful Screening for the Homeless
description: It has been more than 15 years since New Yorkers last saw mothers with young children sleeping in the streets. Whether stricter policies by the city will bring those days again is the subject of intense speculation. The Giuliani administration says that every family that genuinely needs emergency housing will receive it. But court documents show that the city sometimes turns away even those who qualify, raising the risk that young children will come to harm sleeping in the streets, the subways or abandoned buildings.

title: U.S. Seeks NATO Backing
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher said here today that the United States was urging its NATO allies to join its demand that President Milosevic respect the results of municipal elections and begin talks with opposition leaders protesting in Belgrade.

title: Kendall Gill Left a Bad Reputation, and Depression, in Seattle
description: Four nights and no sleep. Kendall Gill could not understand it. He had been bathed by the hazy blue light of his television night after night, surfing every channel, reading every magazine, staring out each window pane. And yet, nothing could ease his agitation, nothing could be parlayed into a lullaby.

title: Mets Pick Reliever in Draft
description: A 22-year-old left-hander who has never pitched above Class A in the minor leagues is the latest building block in the Mets' efforts to reconstruct their bullpen, which was one of the worst in the major leagues last season.

title: Casual Remarks? Hardly, Mr. Greenspan
description: World markets roiled last week after a few offhand remarks by Alan Greenspan, reminding us of a simple but undeniable fact: namely, that when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board speaks, the markets listen. Major institutional investors have learned to read the subtext behind his most innocuous-seeming comments and to respond accordingly. But until now the small investor has just had to endure the resulting market turmoil without a clue.

title: Thurgood Marshall's Red Menace
description: The controversy over the newly released Federal Bureau of Investigation files on Thurgood Marshall, indicating that he gave the bureau information on Communists when he was the chief lawyer for the N.A.A.C.P., shows the great danger of assessing history out of context.

title: Spending More and More of Huizenga's Money
description: Wayne Huizenga knows how to make money. He's done it in garbage collecting and movie videos, among other pursuits. Huizenga knows the wisdom in the age-old free enterprise adage that you have to spend money to make money.

title: U.S. Backs Chancellor on School Takeover
description: In a victory for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's effort to exert control over troubled local school districts, the Justice Department reversed an earlier ruling yesterday and approved his plan to take over a district in the South Bronx.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN TO ADD LUXURY RESORTS IN WEST
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy all or half of four luxury resorts in the West for $210 million in cash, stock and debt from Resorts L.P. and affiliates. Patriot American, a real estate investment trust based in Dallas, would buy all of two Arizona resorts, the Boulders near Scottsdale and the Lodge at Ventana Canyon near Tucson, and would manage another Arizona resort, the Buttes in Tempe. It would also buy 50 percent stakes in the Peaks Resort and Spa in Telluride, Colo., and the Carmel Valley Ranch in Carmel, Calif. Patriot already owns 45 upscale hotels under the Doubletree, Hilton and Hyatt names, among others.

title: Toll Rises to 10 From Poisoning Traced to Meat In Scotland
description: The death toll has risen to 10 in a food poisoning outbreak linked to tainted meat served to pensioners at a Scottish church luncheon last month.

title: U.S. Faults New York's Welfare Plan
description: Federal officials said today that they had a problem with New York State's welfare plan, and that the state could not get its share of money under the new Federal welfare law until the problem was fixed.

title: Homestake Bids $2.3 Billion for Santa Fe Pacific Gold
description: In an attempt to rise among the leaders in North America's gold-mining industry, the Homestake Mining Company said yesterday it had offered $2.3 billion to acquire Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corporation, exceeding the Newmont Mining Corporation's rival offer by nearly $300 million.

title: AULT FOODS TO SELL FROZEN PRODUCTS DIVISION TO NESTLE
description: Ault Foods Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the assets of its frozen products division to Nestle Canada Inc. for $221 million (Canadian), or $162.6 million (United States). Ault, a Canadian food-processing concern, said the division represented less than 15 percent of the company's sales and profit. Nestle Canada, a unit of the Swiss food-processing giant Nestle S.A., would acquire an ice cream plant in London, Ontario, various owned and licensed trademarks and several warehouses. The deal would also include long-term supply agreements, worth an undisclosed sum. Ault said the workers in the division would become employees of Nestle.

title: INSIDE
description: Hey, Santa, Don't Wait

title: Prudential Insurance Accused by Florida
description: Florida regulators today accused the Prudential Insurance Company of deceptive sales practices and began efforts that could ban the company from selling insurance in the state.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about the sentencing of a retired Somerset County Superior Court judge on embezzlement charges misspelled his surname and misstated the scheduled time of the sentencing. The defendant is Michael Imbriani, not Imbriane. The sentencing is today; it was not yesterday.

title: NATO Close To Popping Big Question In East Europe
description: NATO foreign ministers are to end years of debate on Tuesday and set a date for a summit meeting in July to invite the first formerly Communist countries of Central Europe countries to join the alliance.

title: Are the French Determined to Oppose U.S.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Firms Are Scrambling To Set Up Philippine Plants
description: SANTA ROSA, Philippines  The gleaming structural frames and immaculate interiors of Japan's two largest motor vehicle manufacturers are rising with dazzling speed in this newly industrialized region built on old sugar cane plantations and rice paddies 25 miles (40 kilometers) south of Manila.

title: A Chamber Piece Custom-Made to Balance a Program
description: Christopher Rouse's ''Compline'' fit Friday's Chamber Music Society program at Alice Tully Hall like an interlocking jigsaw piece. Its instruments -- flute, clarinet, harp and string quartet -- were identical to those of Ravel's Introduction and Allegro, sitting next to it in the evening's lineup. This was no accident: the society commissioned ''Compline,'' and a specific place, and the right players, were there waiting for it.

title: Howard Rollins Is Dead at 46; Star in TV's 'Heat of the Night'
description: Howard Rollins, an actor who was nominated for an Academy Award in 1981 for his work in the film ''Ragtime'' and was written out of the hit television series ''In the Heat of the Night'' in 1993 because of drug problems, died on Sunday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 46.

title: AGENCY TO PURSUE 2 PLANS TO SHRINK PLUTONIUM SUPPLY
description: Confronting one of the most intractable problems of the post-cold-war era, the Energy Department said today that it would try to dispose of plutonium from old nuclear weapons both by using it as fuel in utilities' reactors and by mixing it with nuclear waste created when the plutonium was made and solidifying the mixture in glass.

title: Take Another Look at Policy on Nuclear Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Much of a Good Thing Makes Benign Nitrogen a Triple Threat
description: NITROGEN, more plentiful in the air than oxygen and as down to earth as the fertilizer it becomes when applied to a lawn or farm field, has long been taken for granted as an almost wholly benign element.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the newly opened Boardwalk at Disney World in Florida misattributed a reference to Disney's efforts as ''sanitized surrealism.'' The speaker was Stephen M. Fjellman, an anthropologist at Florida International University who has written a book about Disney World. He was not Todd A. Lenahan, a manager for Disney's Imagineering division.

title: F.B.I. Reward of $500,000 In Olympic Bombing Case
description: With its investigative leads starting to dry up, the F.B.I. today took several steps, including the posting of a half-million-dollar reward, intended to generate tips that might solve the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park in July.

title: Hospitals Looking Abroad To Keep Their Beds Filled
description: Not long ago, most foreign patients at the New England Medical Center were wealthy Europeans and Latin Americans. But now a patient from overseas is more likely to be someone like Gladys Soto Pilone, a 62-year-old retired schoolteacher, whose health plan in Argentina agreed to pay for breast cancer surgery in Boston last summer.

title: Tears at Simpson Trial, and Then the Defense
description: Wringing tears even from some jurors, the plaintiffs in the civil suit against O. J. Simpson closed their case today with sobbing testimony from Fred Goldman, the father of the happy-go-lucky waiter who was slain along with Mr. Simpson's ex-wife.

title: Late Shoppers Taking a Risk On Catalogues
description: Don't count on getting that Gore Tex hat for your brother-in-law from L. L. Bean this Christmas. Lands' End, too, has a bit of bad news about its slippers. Would you like a Victoria's Secret red silk pajama top? Perhaps you had better consider it in green.

title: Losing the Feeling
description: To the Editor:

title: Body of Slain Man Is Found
description: Two hunters in the woods near Route 9 found the body of a man yesterday morning who had been shot four times in the back of the head. The authorities said they did not know who the man was or how long ago he died.

title: Report Says Grambling Forcing Robinson Out
description: EDDIE ROBINSON, college football's winningest coach, has been told by Grambling that he must quit as coach, ESPN reported yesterday.

title: Iraq Gets U.N. Approval to Sell Oil to Meet Civilian Needs
description: Iraq will be allowed to begin selling oil this week for the first time since its invasion of Kuwait in 1990, but only in limited quantities and only to raise money for food, medicine and other urgent civilian needs.

title: Cold Calculations Chill the Hot Pursuit of Cheap Fusion Power
description: DREAMS of cheap and unlimited electric power from the fusion of hydrogen atoms were jolted last week with the disclosure of calculations casting doubt on the performance of a projected $10 billion international reactor.

title: The Saddam Questions
description: Six questions that President Clinton's nominees as head of the C.I.A. and Secretaries of State and Defense will face when they go before Senate confirmation committees:

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on Sunday in the Arts and Leisure section misstated the performance date for ''Winter Music,'' a roving event with Phil Kline and the Ice Theater of New York. It is at 7 P.M. on Thursday, not today. The audience assembles at the Department of Cultural Affairs at Columbus Circle.

title: Shift Planned In Network By Microsoft
description: After a complete face lift, some major surgery to fix structural flaws and some introspection about what it wants to be when it grows up, the Microsoft Network is expected to re-emerge today as an aggressive contender for the No. 2 spot in the consumer on-line information industry.

title: Adages, Spousal Abuse And Korean Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Holiday Programs to Help the Artist in You
description: TWO related programs, Print Artist 1500 and Print Artist 4.0, might well be Christmas gifts. Bought earlier, they could be used to make Christmas cards, if you do not get absorbed in exploring them.

title: Patterns
description: New Line, New Images

title: Police Shoot 2 in Mall Chase
description: As crowds of holiday shoppers looked on in alarm, the police chased a stolen car yesterday through the parking lot of the Woodbridge Center mall, then onto an access road where the two cars crashed and a police officer shot and wounded two suspects, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Nov. 8 about access problems posed by the disability of Senator-elect Max Cleland, Democrat of Georgia, misstated the year of the death of a previous wheelchair user, Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina. A reader's letter dated Dec. 6 points out that it was 1986, not 1989.

title: Cheering predictions of increased and sustained growth.
description: TWO forecasters are presenting holiday gifts to Madison Avenue: twin predictions of sustained -- as well as sustainable -- growth in advertising spending for 1997 and the rest of the decade.

title: Multinational Producers Stumble Over Bureaucratic Roadblocks : The Long March to Chinese Stores
description: BEIJING  Su Zhen, a computer science student, seemed an unlikely person to be promoting Mars chocolate products in a Beijing department store. "Some classmates told me about this job," she said, arranging the chocolate bars and candies on her special display stand. "It's an easy way to earn extra money."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Albright as President?
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: CNF Transportation, Palo Alto, Calif., formerly Consolidated Freightways, to Citigate Albert Frank, San Francisco, a unit of Citigate Communications Group Ltd., to handle the creative portion of its account, previously handled by Grey Advertising, San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $4

title: New York's Top Democrat Takes Tougher Stance on Juvenile Crime
description: The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, who has often been accused by Republicans of being the chief obstacle to anticrime legislation, said yesterday that he wanted to sharply toughen penalties against many juvenile criminals and make it easier for school officials to suspend students caught carrying guns.

title: A Magazine for Romance Novels And the Women Who Love Them
description: Kathryn Falk, the self-styled Queen of Romance, looked decidedly unromantic on a recent morning in Brooklyn, swigging cough syrup from the bottle and padding about her romance-magazine offices in Kmart slippers.

title: Police Officer Is Run Down At Crash Site
description: A police officer directing traffic around a highway accident in the Bronx was run down and critically injured before dawn yesterday by a station wagon driven by an off-duty police officer who was arrested at the scene and accused of drunken driving, vehicular assault and other charges.

title: Mary Leakey, 83, Dies; Traced Human Dawn
description: Mary Leakey, matriarch of the famous fossil-hunting family in Africa whose own reputation in paleoanthropology soared with discoveries of bones, stone tools and the footprints of early human ancestors, died yesterday in Nairobi, Kenya. She was 83.

title: With Major Math Proof, Brute Computers Show Flash of Reasoning Power
description: COMPUTERS are whizzes when it comes to the grunt work of mathematics. But for creative and elegant solutions to hard mathematical problems, nothing has been able to beat the human mind. That is, perhaps, until now.

title: EQUIFAX TO SPLIT INTO 2 INDEPENDENT COMPANIES
description: Equifax Inc. said yesterday that it planned to split into two independent companies, one consisting of its financial services business and the other, its insurance operations. The company, based in Atlanta, said the split would be accomplished through a spinoff of insurance operations to shareholders about six months from now. The financial services group has about $1.2 billion in annual revenue and provides credit and commercial information. The insurance business, with $559 million in revenue, will continue to provide risk management information to the insurance industry as well as employment and drug screening. Shares of Equifax gained $2.125 yesterday, to $33.75.

title: Space Doctors Decide Pumping Iron Is Key To Astronauts' Health
description: AS clues of ice on the Moon and ancient life on Mars stir dreams of human explorers trekking across space and perhaps even setting up distant colonies one day, scientists are grappling with a still daunting problem: keeping astronauts healthy for long periods in space.

title: Court Again Casts Doubt On Status of Israeli Lobby
description: The chief lobbying organization promoting close American ties with Israel might eventually have to disclose who provides its money and how that money is spent, under a recent appeals court ruling.

title: A Giant Discount Retailer Pioneers Korean Market
description: SEOUL  When the giant discount retail outlet Korea Makro opened in Inchon, South Korea's second-largest port city, curious shoppers viewed it as a giant, unfamiliar and foreign-owned store.

title: Bond Prices End Higher In Calm Day
description: Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, bolstered by buying overseas and by expectations that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates steady.

title: Teen-Agers Indicted for Murder in Newborn's Death
description: A Delaware Superior Court grand jury indicted a New Jersey teen-age couple yesterday on two counts of first-degree murder for the death of their newborn son, enabling prosecutors to argue different theories before a jury.

title: No Headline
description: We firmly believe that somewhere, someone has a photograph of the person carrying this bomb into the park. They may not know it. They may not realize they have it. -- WELDON KENNEDY, of the F.B.I. $(A16:6$)

title: NBC Pays to Avert a Suit By Ex-Bombing Suspect
description: Lawyers for NBC and Richard A. Jewell, the security guard initially reported to have been a suspect in the Atlanta Olympic Park bombing in July, said yesterday that they had reached a settlement averting a libel lawsuit against the network.

title: Aide Is Leaving the S.E.C.
description: Michael Schlein, the chief of staff to Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will leave the agency at the end of the year to become a senior vice president at Smith Barney, the S.E.C. said yesterday. Mr. Schlein, 35, has been at the commission since February 1994, first as counsel and then as chief of staff to Mr. Levitt. He will be replaced by Jennifer Scardino, 29, currently the S.E.C.'s director of public affairs.

title: Rangers Are in Control From the First Shot
description: Even without their injured captain, Mark Messier, the Rangers are gaining momentum in their first serious surge of the season. In last night's one-sided show at Madison Square Garden, they scored early and often against two Phoenix goalies in beating the listless Coyotes by 5-2.

title: German Industry Losing Appetite for Labor Struggle
description: German corporations, which only recently appeared to be spoiling for a fight with organized labor, are on the verge of crying uncle.

title: Computing Through a Glass Darkly
description: NEW hand-held computers based on an operating system called Microsoft Windows C. E. are small enough to stuff in a Christmas stocking. After using one, you may want to stuff it back on the shelf. This latest attempt to cram a full-fledged computer into an address-book-size package shows promise, but its first incarnations show little improvement over their many predecessors.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Staten Island

title: Violence That Can Go Unpunished
description: TOBY GLICK was lucky, sort of.

title: Q & A
description: Speed of Light

title: Europeans Dubious on British Air Alliance
description: The European Commission said today that it had serious doubts about the proposed alliance between British Airways and American Airlines because it would dominate trans-Atlantic air travel.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: New Twist in Redistricting: What Is Lower Court's Role?
description: A Georgia voting rights case before the Supreme Court today presented the Justices with a new variant on the familiar theme of racially conscious redistricting.

title: A Real Shootout
description: FOX-TV sportscaster JOHN MADDEN diagrammed the action for a national television audience while two men were being arrested in the firing a gun high above the field during the Arizona Cardinals-Dallas Cowboys game on Sunday. Madden and his partner, PAT SUMMERALL, began following the incident while the police wove their way through rocky terrain on Hayden Butte just west of Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Ariz.

title: Softbank Plans Stake In Software Maker
description: The Softbank Corporation of Japan, the world's largest computer magazine and book publisher, said yesterday that it would take a 35 percent stake in Trendmicro, a Cupertino, Calif., maker of anti-virus software, for 3.5 billion yen, about $31 million. Softbank said it would try to persuade some 50 computer hardware makers to use Trendmicro software in their systems and ask other makers to integrate the software in their memory boards. (Reuters)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PEGASUS COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Radnor, Pa., a diversified media and communications company, has agreed to acquire four franchises of DirecTV, a unit of General Motors Corp.'s Hughes Electronics subsidiary, for $31.8 million in cash and $8.6 million in stock. The four franchises serve about 19,000 customers.

title: Devils Make Moves
description: The Devils brought up one center and sent another one to the minors yesterday. They promoted STEVE SULLIVAN from the Albany River Rats and sent PETR SYKORA to Albany, primarily for conditioning because he has missed three games with a groin problem. Sullivan, who was demoted Nov. 14, returned after scoring 8 goals and 7 assists in 15 games for the Rats.

title: Krajicek Out 10 Weeks
description: The Wimbledon champion, RICHARD KRAJICEK, will be out of the game for up to 10 weeks after undergoing knee surgery yesterday, the Dutch ANP news agency said. He will miss the Australian Open in January. (Reuters)

title: New 'Evita' Look Is Too Alive and Well
description: Fashion being an entire industry based on prediction, here is one more: retailers, makeup, jewelry and fashion companies that believe Madonna's Dior-laden ''Evita'' style, coupled with the ''Christian Dior'' exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be a new influence on modern women are wrong.

title: Hebron Tensions Flare Again as Talks on Israeli Pullout Continue
description: The encounter began about 8 A.M. today, when about 300 Palestinian students suddenly barged onto the walled campus of Hebron University, closed by the Israelis since last March, and declared that they would stay until it was reopened.

title: Bank Robber Flees by Train, Takes Hostage And Is Seized
description: For three years, commuters on the Long Island Rail Road have lived with the legacy of fear left by Colin Ferguson, the Brooklyn man who opened fire with an assault rifle on a commuter train, killing 6 people and injuring 19.

title: Loony, Brutal and Raw, Like a Suicidal Machine
description: One of the great things about the Dutch composer Louis Andriessen is that in middle age he is keeping his music uncouth, obtuse, rampant, in revolt. ''De Stijl,'' excellently played on Friday by the Brooklyn Philharmonic under its new conductor, Robert Spano, is scored for a typical noisy ensemble of flutes, saxophones, trumpets and trombones with electric guitars, pianos and percussion, an ensemble barely gentled by the quartet of amplified women's voices singing along in harmony for much of the time. The sound is brutal, and the structure not so much clear as raw. There is the sense of a huge machine -- a machine because Mr. Andriessen deals in blocks and stiff rhythms -- in which the components are at odds. This is a machine tearing itself apart.

title: Swiss Re to Acquire Italian Reinsurer
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company said yesterday that it would buy Unione Italiana di Riassicurazione S.p.A., for about 500 million Swiss francs, or $380 million. Uniorias, a unit of Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni S.p.A., is Italy's leading reinsurer, with total premiums of around 1.3 billion francs in 1995.

title: Visiting Washington, China's Defense Chief Calls for Peace
description: Asserting that his country seeks only ''peace and stability,'' China's Defense Minister met President Clinton and Defense Secretary William J. Perry today in another series of meetings meant to seal improved relations and high-level exchanges between Washington and Beijing.

title: Woman As Icon: Disturbing, Inspiring
description: On the subject of female icons and role models, a media obsession these days, I feel like those characters in Chekhov plays who constantly brood about what future generations will think of them. They worry that the people who come after will think their concerns were trivial, their needs primitive, their beliefs sentimental. I worry about this, too.

title: Panthers' Collins a Master of All He Surveys
description: With so much on the line the division lead, reaching the playoffs and the present and future psychological edge of taming the longtime kings of the National Football Conference West in a December game -- the Carolina Panthers came up with this answer to the question of what would give them the best shot at the San Francisco 49ers: Kerry Collins.

title: Bratton Decides Against Running for Mayor
description: For 20 days, former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton flirted with the idea of running for mayor, slyly defying the skepticism of virtually every politician in town. Yesterday, he validated that skepticism, bowing out of the race for what he said were personal reasons, but he gamely insisted he would have made a strong candidate.

title: VIAG TO BUY A PLASTICS OPERATION OF JOHNSON CONTROLS
description: Viag A.G.'s packaging unit said it would buy Johnson Controls Inc.'s plastic container business in an agreement analysts valued between 700 million and 1 billion marks, or $450 million to $650 million. The acquisition would make Viag's Schmalbach-Lubeca division a leading maker of recyclable plastic beverage bottles. Johnson Controls, based in Milwaukee, said the sale to Viag of Munich was part of its plan to concentrate on automotive and control products. The plastics unit, based in Manchester, Mich., employs about 2,100 people at factories in the United States, Europe and South America. It has annualized sales of about 1.2 billion marks, or $800 million.

title: Scandal Links Turkish Aides To Deaths, Drugs and Terror
description: When a speeding Mercedes crashed into a tractor-trailer on a highway 100 miles southwest of Istanbul last month, killing three people and seriously injuring a fourth, it was at first viewed as nothing more than another accident like those that kill thousands of people on Turkey's rugged roads each year.

title: Sweet Is the Lucre
description: Everything is about money. Alan Greenspan makes a speech about money. ''People making money awfully fast,'' Greenspan says. ''Making money maybe a little too fast,'' says Greenspan. Money markets, wondering what Greenspan just might possibly do to their money, have money fits.

title: Majestic Species' Fate May Ride on Wings Of 6 Freed Condors
description: Atop a red sandstone escarpment half a mile above the rolling desert of northern Arizona, six California condors stretched their enormous wings and gazed out from a pen at the rugged scrubland, plateaus and pinon forests of their new home range.

title: Judge Finds du Pont Is Competent to Stand Trial for Murder
description: John E. du Pont today was found competent to stand trial for murder in the shooting death of the Olympic wrestling champion Dave Schultz.

title: New Teen Queen Reigns in Japan
description: TOKYO  The female idol singer is back in Japan, in a typically big way. After a decade-long drought with no teen queen, Japanese pop culture is awash with images of Namie Amuro, a 19-year-old from Okinawa.

title: Lingerie and Shoe Markets Go Upscale
description: HONG KONG  The lifestyle in Asia is rapidly changing as the region's economies go from strength to strength. Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore, once referred to as "newly industrialized," now boast lifestyles similar to Western standards. "Emerging countries" such as Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia now have a fast-growing middle class flocking to new megamalls, department stores and foreign outlets.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: New York City Hears of Surplus, But Big Budget Gaps Lie Ahead
description: Heady profits on Wall Street are generating so much extra revenue from income and business taxes that New York City may end its fiscal year with a surplus of nearly $350 million, city officials said yesterday. But even with this unanticipated boon, the city still faces huge projected gaps in its budgets for the next several years because its spending continues to grow faster than its revenues.

title: In Minnesota, a Shoplifting Case With a Twist
description: Living in a beautiful house in a St. Paul suburb, the couple would hardly be expected to pilfer merchandise from stores. Instead, the police say, they and two of their grown children had a personal shoplifter do it.

title: Unpopular With Conservationists, State Environmental Commissioner Resigns
description: In his 22 months as New York State's top environmental official, Michael D. Zagata had countless troubles. Private environmental groups and political opponents attacked him again and again for what they saw as a series of actions favoring industry over the environment.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Acrimony at Hearing on Revising Rules for Liver Transplants
description: A Government hearing on proposed changes in the way livers are allocated for lifesaving transplants offered a rare glimpse today of acrimony among transplant centers.

title: G.O.P. Lawmaker Defeated in Texas Runoff
description: Representative Steve Stockman, one of the most outspoken and controversial members of the freshman Republican class that took Washington by storm two years ago, was defeated in a runoff election here tonight.

title: Still Teaching, 4 Years After Conviction
