description: Franklin Lim had been teaching biology at Murry Bergtraum High School in Manhattan for less than a month when he was arrested for Medicaid fraud.

title: Food Notes
description: Christmas Oils

title: Joseph Quinlan, 71, Is Dead; Sought Daughter's Right to Die
description: Joseph Quinlan, who became an early pioneer of the ''right to die'' movement for the terminally ill 20 years ago after his 21-year-old daughter, Karen Ann, lapsed into an irreversible coma, died Saturday at his home in Wantage, N.J. He was 71.

title: Reich's Notes, Enjoying Their Journey
description: Steve Reich's music celebrates easily. Much of it is happy art -- not expressive of the happiness of someone else (presumably the artist), but happy in itself, being made of notes that know where they are going and enjoy the trip.

title: On the Road To Ruin
description: There is always an excuse to defer caring for New York City's bridges, highways, school buildings and other public structures. The reason this time is a 19th century restriction found in the state Constitution.

title: TIME WARNER REACHES DEAL FOR SET-TOP BOXES
description: Time Warner Inc. plans to spend $400 million to $450 million in three years for one million set-top television boxes from Scientific-Atlanta Inc., and other suppliers. The boxes can deliver digital video, Internet access and interactive viewing guides to cable customers. The boxes may help Time Warner, which is based in New York, compete against direct satellite broadcasters, which offer more channels and better reception. Scientific-Atlanta, based in Norcross, Ga., will license the technology to the Pioneer Electronic Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation. Shares of Time Warner rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $40.125, while Scientific-Atlanta rose $1, to $17.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Eating Well
description: AMONG the things our throwaway society discards each year, according to the Environmental Protection Agency, is 14 billion pounds of food, a good portion of which is still edible. But all over the country companies refuse to give their leftovers to programs that provide food to the poor, fearing to be sued if something they have donated makes someone ill. A new Federal Good Samaritan law will protect donors against civil and criminal liability, and it is changing many corporate minds.

title: Reds' Schott Is Hospitalized
description: The Cincinnati Reds owner MARGE SCHOTT was hospitalized yesterday for treatment of pneumonia. She was listed in fair condition at Jewish Hospital in Cincinnati. (AP)

title: HEINZ AND QUESTOR END THEIR TALKS TO BUY BUMBLE BEE
description: The H. J. Heinz Company and Questor Partners Fund L.P. have ended discussions to buy Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. from the Unicord Company of Thailand. Heinz, based in Pittsburgh, said in July that it was in talks to buy three Bumble Bee tuna-processing plants, in California, Puerto Rico and Ecuador, producing the tuna for Questor, which would have owned the brand name and the continuing business. The purchase would have given Heinz, which owns the Star-Kist brand, about two-thirds of the $1.1 billion tuna market in the United States.

title: CHUBB PLANNING TO SELL ITS LIFE INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Chubb Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its subsidiary, the Chubb Life Insurance Company of America. Gail Devlin, a spokeswoman for Chubb, the 13th-largest United States property and casualty insurer, said, ''There's been an enormous interest from possible purchasers.'' Analysts have estimated that Chubb could get about $600 million for the life insurance unit, which is based in Concord, N.H. Shares of Chubb, which is based in Warren, N.J., rose 50 cents a share, to $54.375.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELVIS GRBAC, the back-up quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers, and Mayor WILLIE L. BROWN JR. of San Francisco have patched up their spat, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The Mayor was widely criticized last month when he called Mr. Grbac an ''embarrassment to humankind'' for throwing two interceptions in the team's loss to the Dallas Cowboys on Nov. 10.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN SELLS FLOOR-COVERING UNIT
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that it had sold Collins & Aikman Floorcoverings for $197 million as part of the company's move to focus on the business of supplying textile products to auto makers. The company sold the floor-covering unit, a maker of commercial carpet and carpet tiles, to a group sponsored by Quad-C Inc., a Virginia investment firm, and Paribas Principal Partners Inc. The floor-covering division is based in Dalton, Ga. The shares of Collins & Aikman, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., rose 25 cents yesterday, to $6.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Relentless Drive

title: Music vs. Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Heart Surgery May Halt Trial For Gigante
description: Vincent Gigante, who the authorities say is the nation's top Mafia boss, underwent coronary surgery yesterday, putting in doubt his fitness to stand trial in March on murder and racketeering charges.

title: Suzanne Railey, 85, Who Gave Black-Tie Parties for Christie's
description: Suzanne Railey, a representative of Christie's auction house who was known for her talents as an international hostess, died last weekend in her Manhattan apartment. She was 85.

title: The Thrill Is Nearly Gone for Cross
description: Howard Cross was sitting in front of his locker at Giants Stadium on Monday wondering why a group of reporters with notebooks and cameras had crowded around running back Tyrone Wheatley.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SCENE: The New York premiere of ''The Crucible'' at the Coronet Theater. A fleet of stretch limos with darkened windows purr expectantly. Autograph seekers, paparazzi, excited movie fans, all huddle behind police sawhorses straining for a glimpse of Winona Ryder, Daniel Day-Lewis, Arthur Miller.

title: A Personal but Political Novel of South Africa
description: IMAGININGS OF SAND

title: Real Estate
description: The exterior of the Fifth Avenue building that houses the Elizabeth Arden retail store and beauty salon will remain much the same, but a makeover is to take place on the other side of the famous red door.

title: Fellow Riders Honor Solis
description: ALEX SOLIS won the 1997 George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award yesterday in Arcadia, Calif., which is given annually to a rider whose career and character are a tribute to thoroughbred racing.

title: 2 MAJOR HOSPITALS FORM CORPORATION
description: Beth Israel Medical Center and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center announced yesterday that they were forming a single parent corporation to oversee both hospitals, another shift in the realignment of the health care industry in New York City.

title: Big Mac II
description: The folks at McDonald's like to tell the story about the young Japanese girl who arrived in Los Angeles, looked around and said to her mother: ''Look, mom, they have McDonald's here too.''

title: Hang 10, Pay $475
description: Three surfers who caught waves churned up by Hurricane Bertha on July 13 have been convicted of disobeying police orders to paddle ashore. The surfers, Luke Morgan of Manasquan and Larry Schmidt and Mark Oliver, both of Spring Lake, were fined $475 each yesterday and ordered to perform 24 hours of community service, said Peter O'Mara, a lawyer for the Surfers' Environmental Alliance, a group that protests restrictions on surfing.

title: Write It Down, Welfare Officials Tell Albany
description: New York would already have been eligible for its share of the money provided under the new Federal welfare law, but for a minor omission in its welfare proposal to the Federal Government.

title: Accounts
description: * Boehringer Mannheim Corp., Indianapolis, to Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee, to handle advertising and public relations for its diabetes care division, previously at Medicus Communications, New York, owned by MacManus Group. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: U.S.-Europe Accord Is Seen On Technology Trade Issues
description: The United States and the European Union appeared to come within striking distance today on an accord that would pave the way for a global pact to liberalize trade in the $500-billion-a-year global market for computers, chips, telecommunications equipment and some 300 other high-technology products.

title: Home Heating Help Backed
description: Members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation have joined a campaign to head off proposed cuts in the 15-year-old Federal program that helps low-income residents heat their homes.

title: Drug May Avert Cerebral Palsy in Tiny Infants
description: HARDLY daring to hope it may be true, medical researchers are uncovering data hinting that cerebral palsy and possibly even mental retardation might be largely preventable in very premature infants. The most recent study, published today, confirms two smaller ones that seemed too good to believe.

title: Streaking Rangers Meet Their Rising Rivals
description: Throughout their seven-game undefeated streak, the Rangers have constantly repeated one caveat: we are not beating teams in our division; wait and see how we do when we play division rivals again.

title: When an Agency Does a Parent's Job
description: Kenya Eubanks dreams of becoming an actress. Sometimes, in her mind, she fashions herself as a 14-year-old Angela Bassett, glamorous and tough, sashaying across the screen.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Taking the Subtle Approach

title: Bank of America Picks Finalists
description: The Bank of America unit of the BankAmerica Corporation has named four finalists to compete for its combined corporate image and retail accounts, with billings estimated at $50 million to $70 million. The corporate account had been at the San Francisco office of Ketchum Advertising, a unit of Omnicom Group, for six years while the Evans Group in San Francisco and Seattle handled assignments including retail advertising for four years.

title: German Inflation Rate Eased a Bit Last Month
description: German consumer price inflation fell in November to 1.4 percent on an annual basis from 1.5 percent the previous month, data from the Federal Statistics Office showed yesterday. The data also confirmed earlier figures showing a similar drop in west German inflation to 1.4 percent from 1.5 percent, while prices rose in the east by 1.6 percent after a 1.5 percent rise in October. (Reuters)

title: The Joy of Cookies Starts in the Cooking
description: ''JOY OF COOKING,'' by Irma S. Rombauer and Marion Rombauer Becker, has been a bible for generations of cooks. Now, for holiday bakers, comes ''Joy of Cooking Christmas Cookies'' (Scribner, $16.95).

title: Social Security Crisis Isn't Coming. It's Here.
description: To the Editor:

title: Finnish Pulp Maker Realigning Operations
description: UPM-Kymmene Oy of Finland, Europe's largest forest products company, said yesterday that it was realigning pulp and paperboard operations to reduce price fluctuations. UPM-Kymmene and Metsa-Serla Oy, another forest products maker, said they would each sell a pulp mill to their jointly owned Metsa-Botnia venture. Metsa-Botnia will become Finland's biggest pulp producer at 2.5 million tons a year. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Political Consultant Defends His Tarnished Profession
description: His suit was rumpled, his hands were trembling and his sentences broken by bursts of nervous laughter. It was four months since Dick Morris left the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in disgrace, and yesterday President Clinton's former political consultant turned up in front of a classroom of New York University political science students, offering a defense for a profession whose fortunes seemed to have fallen with his own.

title: Sudler & Hennessey Chairman Retiring
description: Sudler & Hennessey, the health care communications division of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, said yesterday that William B. Gibson, its chairman and chief executive, would retire in January after 26 years at the agency. Mr. Gibson, 58, who has been chairman since 1984, will be succeeded by Jed Beitler, 44, who joins from Harrison & Star in New York, where he had been president and chief operating officer. At Harrison & Star -- a unit of Omnicom Group formerly known as Harrison, Star, Wiener & Beitler -- Meryl Fischman, 45, executive vice president and managing director, will succeed Mr. Beitler.

title: S.&L. Anger Lives On
description: To the Editor:

title: From Outrage to Outrage In Urban Nightmare of '92
description: ''Riot'' is a riveting reconstruction of the 1992 mayhem that began with the clubbing of Rodney G. King by several Los Angeles police officers. Or to be more precise, began with an 81-second amateur video of white officers beating a black man. Played and replayed on countless channels at the time, the image's repeated appearance throughout tonight's edition of ''20th Century'' confirms that it has lost none of its immediacy and power.

title: From Anguish Onward, A Course in Emotions
description: Anniversary celebrations tend to make for genial sorts of dance programs. But a performance celebrating the 40th year of the Mary Anthony Dance Theater, presented on Saturday night at Kaye Playhouse, packed a considerable wallop with a premiere that was almost painful in the intensity of its emotions.

title: Dollar-Denominated Stocks an Elixir in China
description: When China opened a stock exchange here six years ago, two kinds of shares were created, one denominated in Chinese currency, the other in dollars.

title: Let's Make a (10-Player) Deal
description: Houston traded five players, including starters BRIAN HUNTER and ORLANDO MILLER, to the Detroit Tigers for catcher BRAD AUSMUS and four other players.

title: Unabom Plea Is Heard In Newark
description: In an unusual hearing in which television linked a Federal court in Newark to a public defender's office in California, the Unabom suspect, Theodore J. Kaczynski, entered a plea of not guilty today on charges of murdering a New Jersey advertising executive with a booby-trapped package in 1994.

title: Reward in Postal Bombing
description: On Nov. 16, a package from the Fairton Post Office here exploded in the car of a Bridgeton woman, identified by The Associated Press as Tracey Lynn Ridgway Elliot, 28. The victim was hospitalized for a week with burns, said Judy Starliper, a spokeswoman for the Federal Postal Inspection Service. Yesterday, the postal service offered a $50,000 reward for information leading to an arrest and conviction in the case. The 24-hour number to call is (888) 271-5274.

title: Devils' Lamoriello Chewing Over Changes
description: With a package of cinnamon gum opened in front of him and its contents scattered about, Lou Lamoriello sat with his chin in his hands, high in the Maple Leaf Gardens press box.

title: Work on Swatch Is in Review
description: The Swatch USA division of SMH Inc. has placed in review the creative part of its account, which has been handled by Ogilvy & Mather New York for 18 months. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Mobutu Plays a Part in Africa's Ethnic Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: BUSINESS SUMMARY
description: Iraq Reopens Pipeline To Send Oil Abroad

title: Tax Phobia Fills a Mall In Delaware
description: THE land is flat and as plain as a sheet of paper. Its distinguishing feature is a maze of highways. This could be just another speck of Delaware that cars fly past on the way to somewhere else.

title: Yugoslav Opposition Adjourns to the Streets
description: Noval Kilibarda, his long gray hair in unruly strands, strode swiftly through the rotunda of the Yugoslav Parliament, out the huge double doors and down the stairs. He stopped at the bottom and began to applaud the tens of thousands of demonstrators passing in the street.

title: Officer Is Injured, Suspect Is Killed on L.I.
description: A robbery suspect was killed last night and a Suffolk County, L.I., police sergeant was injured following a chase and shootout that ended in Smithtown. The incident began about 9:30 P.M. on Veterans Highway and Old Willets Path in Hauppague, where two officers exchanged gunfire with the suspect. The man, who was not identified, fled and the police followed him to Plymouth Boulevard in Smithtown, where his car crashed. He then exited the vehicle and exchanged more gunfire with the police. It is not known whether he was shot or died from injuries in the car accident, the police said.

title: Yale to Renovate Most of Divinity School
description: Yale University will restore and renovate several core buildings of its Divinity School rather than shuttering the complex and moving students and faculty to a smaller space on the main campus, university officials said yesterday.

title: Controlling the Risks of Plutonium
description: The Clinton Administration is taking a reasonable if controversial approach toward solving a worrisome problem caused by the dismantling of nuclear weapons in Russia and the United States -- how to get rid of thousands of plutonium ''pits'' from the warheads that are rapidly accumulating in each country. America will need to dispose of more than 50 tons of excess plutonium. Russia has an even greater stockpile. Until these softball-shaped nuclear cores, now under guard at selected sites in each country, are somehow neutralized, they pose a double threat. Either nation could reverse the course of disarmament and stick the plutonium right back into new weapons. Or thieves, especially in economically distressed Russia, might steal some pits for use in bombs by terrorists or renegade nations.

title: Hoechst to Buy Rest of Roussel
description: Hoechst A.G. said today that it would buy the 43.5 percent of the drug maker Roussel-Uclaf that it does not own for 18 billion French francs ($3.4 billion) in a move to expand its drug business as it reduces its chemicals operations.

title: Soldiers Say They Detected Chemical Use In Kuwait
description: Two American soldiers who manned the most sophisticated chemical-detection equipment used in the 1991 Persian Gulf war told Congress today that chemical weapons were found in Kuwait during and after the war, contradicting repeated statements from the Defense Department.

title: Ford Returning to Suburb, Souring Detroit Real Estate Shift
description: Dealing a blow to this city's hopes of an economic revival, the Ford Motor Company announced today that it was moving 2,500 office workers out of the downtown area and back to its base in suburban Dearborn.

title: Wal-Mart's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mets Will Raise Most Ticket Prices
description: Despite a lackluster 71-91 season, the Mets will raise most of their ticket prices at Shea Stadium in 1997. The steepest increase will be for premium field boxes, which have been renamed Metropolitan Club Seats and outfitted with cushioned seats and drink cup holders and will be attended by waiters. Those seats will jump from $17 to $25 each. Other box seat tickets will rise to $18 and $19.

title: Chicago Is Rojas's Kind of Town
description: MEL ROJAS, who saved 36 games in 40 chances last season for the Montreal Expos, agreed yesterday to a three-year, $13.75 million contract with the Chicago Cubs.

title: Shell to Revamp European Refineries
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that it would shake up its refinery business in Europe, selling at least one plant in an effort to raise margins in a crowded market.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: MTV Grows Up. Well, A Little.
description: On the Beavis and Butt-head ''Movie Special,'' one of those blatant plugs for a new film disguised as a behind-the-scenes documentary, Chris Connelly interviewed the movie's cartoon stars. They are, of course, the proud poster boys for MTV and for hormonally driven adolescent airheads. ''You've been held responsible by many for what's known as the dumbing down of America,'' Mr. Connelly said, in the mock-serious tone that gave the special (on MTV on Sunday) a saving touch of wit.

title: Contested Plan Cleared for Jewish Housing in Arab Jerusalem
description: An Israeli planning commission today approved construction of the first housing development for Jews in an Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem, drawing Palestinian protests and warnings of renewed conflict over this bitterly contested city.

title: A New Font of Spicy Holiday Beers
description: A NEW source for holiday libations -- especially spicy seasonal beers like Catamount Christmas Ale, Coor's Winterfest and Samichlaus, an expensive but delicious rarity from Switzerland -- is New York Beverage Wholesalers, at 428 East 91st Street. The market also carries hundreds of other brews plus soft drinks, bottled water, sweet and hard cider, and snacks. Party kegs are available, too. Prices are reasonable; among the sale items this week are a six-pack of Sierra Nevada Pale Ale for $6.99 and a case of 12 1.5-liter bottles of Evian for $17.99. Delivery in Manhattan from 59th Street to 135th Street is free for orders of at least $50, and free anywhere in Manhattan for orders of $75 or more. Information: (212) 831-4000.

title: NATO TAKES STEPS TO EXPAND RANKS INTO EAST EUROPE
description: NATO took the first formal step today to expand its alliance to include formerly Communist nations of Eastern Europe and then moved quickly to ease Russia's apprehensions by offering to negotiate a special charter with Russia and to increase military cooperation and contacts.

title: County Colleges Seek Aid
description: A 1962 law allowed counties to set up their own community colleges as affordable alternatives to private and state institutions, with the state paying one-third the cost, says Raymond H. Bateman, chairman of Raritan Valley Community College.

title: Treading Softly, but Firmly, Timor Bishop Accepts Nobel
description: After reports that he had been threatened by the Indonesian Government, Carlos Felipe Ximenes Belo, a Catholic Bishop from the occupied territory of East Timor, steered clear of confrontation today as he accepted the 1996 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: The Way It Would Be During the Holocaust
description: After all these years, is there anything left for Anne Frank to say?

title: In a Surprise, Delta's Account Is Put in Review
description: For the second time in five months, a giant airline is warning its longtime advertising agency of turbulence ahead.

title: 58 Years to Life For the Murder Of a Friend
description: In nine minutes filled with tension and the muffled sobs of a dead woman's suffering mother, a Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to at least 58 years in prison for the kidnapping and killing of Kimberly Antonakos, who had been his friend.

title: Bernadette Peters, Sweet With Sondheim
description: Genuine sweetness, not the saccharine regality dispensed by the average show business diva, is such a rarity on the pop concert stage that it is difficult to believe when it stares you in the face. But Bernadette Peters, who made her New York solo concert debut on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall as a benefit for Gay Men's Health Crisis, effuses sweetness as naturally as she breathes.

title: Empty Seat Signals Turkey's Sensitivity Over Role in Europe
description: Although many European countries are knocking loudly on the door of the European Union, seeking admission to a club that they believe will bring them prosperity and political stability, one prominent guest who was invited to dinner at the European Union summit meeting in Ireland this weekend has declined.

title: Administration Renews Efforts on Prevention of Repetitive Motion Injuries
description: With Congressional restrictions removed in the new budget year, the Clinton Administration said today that it planned to renew its efforts to set mandatory rules to prevent repetitive motion injuries at work.

title: DANCE
description: A Leisurely Give-and-Take

title: No Headline
description: ''For 70 years the Russian people were robbed of self-knowledge. Psychoanalysis is one weapon with which we can restore some order to our society.''

title: Oh, to Be Young, Brave and Shirtless
description: YES, Virginia (and Jennifer, Jessica and, sure, why not, Jeffrey), there is a Santa Claus. This year, for the very first time, the New York Fire Department has given the city that perfect something for Christmas: the Firehouse Hunks 1997 Calendar. Those lips, those eyes, those pecs.

title: Preparing a Party, With Time to Gossip
description: WHEN I moved into a new apartment last summer, among the first things I noticed was that the oven had never been used, and the top of the stove only barely. Then I thought about the long lines at carryout counters in specialty shops and supermarkets at dinner time each night and about how much space prepared frozen foods now take up, and it dawned on me that there are stoves like mine all over the country. They are artifacts of an earlier age when people actually cooked.

title: Child Welfare Goes on Line
description: After years of promises, New York City's child welfare system is finally coming fully into the computer age. The city joined a statewide system last week that will eventually provide prompt, up-to-date information on abused and neglected children. This will hardly solve all of the city's child welfare problems, but it goes a long way toward making a beleaguered agency more efficient and responsive.

title: Court Jester, Dancer, Cook, Whatever
description: Among my several, some might say countless, failings has been an inability to appreciate the comic talents of Danny Kaye. I've watched his movies, 17 in all, beginning with ''The Kid From Brooklyn'' in 1946. I went to see him play New York's Palace. I've tried, but Kaye's childlike qualities always seemed to be childish. Which may explain his extraordinary ability to connect touchingly, especially through Unicef, with children around the world.

title: $10 Seats, for Freedom and Survival
description: Broadway, home of the $75 ticket, is about to get some cheap seats. Very cheap. Circle in the Square, struggling to reorganize after declaring bankruptcy in August, will sell $10 tickets -- for all seats, all performances -- to patrons who pay a $37.50 yearly membership fee. The new policy begins with the first production under the theater's new management, ''Stanley,'' a British import, which begins performances on Feb. 4.

title: Dancers and Aerialists
description: Sean Curran and the dance team of Heidi Latzky and Larry Goldhuber are to join with aerialists and other modern dancers in a benefit program on Friday at 8:30 P.M. for the Soundance Studio, a dance theater and rehearsal space. Tickets for the program, at the studio at 385 Broadway, at White Street, TriBeCa, are $15. Information: (212) 941-6457.

title: Justices Sound Sympathetic but Troubled on Law to Confine Sex Offenders
description: With the national debate over how to protect children from sexual predators clearly in the Justices' minds, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Constitution permits a state to keep a sexual offender who is dangerous but not mentally ill confined in a mental hospital after the expiration of a criminal sentence.

title: North Tarrytown Votes to Pursue Its Future as Sleepy Hollow
description: By an overwhelming margin, the people of this struggling Hudson River village voted today to change its workaday name to the more evocative appellation of Sleepy Hollow, in the hope that it will bring a much needed economic lift.

title: A Kiribati Day
description: To the Editor:

title: One-Day Strike Is Set Against Lufthansa
description: Germany's union for white-collar workers said yesterday that flight and ground personnel at Lufthansa airline would stage a one-day warning strike this week over a contract dispute. Michael Tarp, a union spokesman, said employees would walk off their jobs tomorrow at Frankfurt International Airport and at other selected airports. Lufthansa had to cancel 35 flights on Nov. 11 because of a warning strike.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a settlement between NBC and Richard A. Jewell, initially a suspect in the Atlanta Olympics bombing, to avert the threat of a libel lawsuit, referred incorrectly in some editions to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, the first news organization that cited him as a suspect. It has not been negotiating with Mr. Jewell on a settlement.

title: Installation Artist Wins First Hugo Boss Award
description: Matthew Barney, an installation artist, has been named the winner of the inaugural Hugo Boss Prize, a $30,000 award created by the German menswear company and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: Banquet Nights At Culinary School
description: Winning the lottery at the Culinary School of Kendall College in Evanston, Ill., a suburb north of Chicago, will not make you a millionaire. But it will give you a chance to go to one of the school's international banquets. The school, founded in 1985, offers two- and four-year culinary programs for its 330 full-time students. The student-staffed, on-site restaurant generally offers American and French cuisine, but on Tuesday nights, the format changes.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Academic Freedom Is Key to Foreign Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Counting Starts In Race to Lead The Teamsters
description: An independent election officer began counting ballots yesterday in the race for the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, with both sides acknowledging that a victor might not emerge for two or three days.

title: Too Much Protecting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Groups Gearing Up to Fight For More Precise TV Ratings
description: As a television industry group puts the finishing touches on its proposed ratings system, strong opposition is growing among educational and parents organizations that say the system will not provide the information parents need.

title: A German-Czech Pact on Wartime Abuses
description: More than half a century after the end of World War II, Germany will apologize for Hitler's invasion of the former Czechoslovakia, and Prague will express regrets for the postwar expulsion of millions of Germans, according to the draft of a joint declaration to be endorsed this month.

title: Faron Young, Singer, 64, Dies; Country Star and Businessman
description: Faron Young, a honky-tonk singer who became a pillar of Nashville country music, died yesterday at Columbia Summit Medical Center in Nashville, said Melanie Lamb, a hospital spokeswoman. He was 64.

title: South Africa Frees Apartheid Killer, Hinting at Broad Amnesty
description: In a move that signals that the most heinous crimes of apartheid will be forgiven rather than punished, South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission granted amnesty today to a white police officer who was already serving a life sentence for his role in the slaying of 11 people.

title: Hess to Pay $5 Million Fine
description: The refining arm of the Amerada Hess Corporation of Woodbridge pleaded guilty yesterday to illegally shipping hazardous waste from its giant Virgin Islands refinery to a cement company in Arizona and agreed to pay $5.3 million in fines and restitution.

title: Keller Is Set to Take Back a Seat in Goal
description: Kasey Keller has not surrendered a goal in three World Cup qualifying matches, but, at least temporarily, he has surrendered his starting job with the United States soccer team.

title: Giuliani Parlay: D'Amato Fund-Raiser and Then Dinner With Gore
description: Performing a trademark feat of political acrobatics, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani moved from Alfonse M. D'Amato's side to Al Gore's in the space of an hour last night, all the while maintaining that the evening demonstrated his lack of partisanship.

title: Apples of Yore Make a Comeback
description: Twenty-five years ago, John Kilcherman decided he needed a hobby. Never mind that he and his wife, Phyllis, were running an 85-acre commercial cherry and apple orchard in the Lelanau Peninsula of northwest Michigan.

title: Britain to Check Veterans for Illnesses Linked to Duty in Gulf
description: The British Government announced today that it would study complaints of illness among veterans of the Persian Gulf war and acknowledged that it had furnished Parliament incorrect answers to questions about the matter in the past.

title: It's Dangerous to Disarm
description: More than 60 retired generals and admirals from more than a dozen countries have signed a statement calling for the abolition of nuclear weapons. Their idealism is to be applauded, but their ideas should be rejected.

title: Fans Share Their View With Patrick
description: UP to now, Patrick Ewing has seemed like a Washington guy who earned his living running up and down Madison Square Garden during the basketball season. But all that has changed now.

title: Executive Changes
description: BAY NETWORKS INC., Santa Clara, Calif., said William Ruehle, its executive vice president and chief financial officer, would resign as soon as a successor was found.

title: Barney's Reports A Smaller Loss
description: Barney's Inc. said yesterday that its loss narrowed in the year that ended on Aug. 3, as sales and profit margins improved and costs declined.

title: Robert Holloway, Dancer, 62
description: Robert Holloway, the wardrobe master at American Ballet Theater, died on Monday after collapsing on a street in Brooklyn, where he lived. He was 62. The cause was cardiac arrest, said his brother Wayne.

title: F.C.C. RULING HELPS RCN'S PLANS FOR VIDEO VIA TELEPHONES
description: RCN Inc. took a step toward offering video transmission over telephone lines yesterday, after the Federal Communications Commission approved a filing by a sister company, MFS Communications. RCN, a unit of the C-Tec Corporation, a cable operator, has leased MFS's fiber optic cable to allow it to sell a package of 105 cable channels in New York City and Boston. RCN said the filing was the first step in converting the video dial-tone service to an open video system. RCN is based in Princeton, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Monday, and a correction in this space yesterday, misstated the scheduled day of the sentencing of a retired Somerset County Superior Court judge, Michael Imbriani, on embezzlement charges. It is today; it was not yesterday or Monday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For four years, President Clinton said yesterday, ''the strong, unique voice'' of EVELYN S. LIEBERMAN has reverberated through the White House, most recently as deputy chief of staff. Now Mrs. Lieberman's authoritative growl will reach a wider audience: the President has named her director of the Voice of America.

title: One Legacy of Welles: Tons of Unfinished Film
description: When Orson Welles received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Film Institute in 1975, he accepted it with a wry good humor ''in the name of all film mavericks,'' and cheerfully talked about how he used his acting to subsidize his film making.

title: The Prolific Snail Changed Their Life
description: After careers as a city manager and a university professor, Kenneth Ohler has settled down to the quiet farmer's life at his 10-acre home in southwestern Pennsylvania. Quiet indeed: Mr. Ohler farms snails.

title: Democrats Seek to Shrink Size of Albany's Tax Cut
description: Democratic state legislators began laying the groundwork today for a campaign to scale back the final phase of the state's three-year income tax cut, releasing a study showing that increases in property taxes and other local fees in 1995 far outpaced savings from the tax cut.

title: Preaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Will Face Best With Rare Optimism
description: It is not just the Nets' record, it is a phone number for directory assistance: 4-11.

title: Two Hardware Co-ops Join To Form Giant Wholesaler
description: Two of the nation's largest hardware co-ops said today that they planned to merge, forming a new wholesale company with annual sales of $4.5 billion to more than 10,000 independent hardware and home improvement stores.

title: Korea Fund's Goals
description: To the Editor:

title: Enron Names Trading Chief As President of Company
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had named as its president and chief operating officer Jeffrey K. Skilling, an executive who came to the company only six years ago and built up a huge business trading natural gas and electricity.

title: REPORT OF PRODUCTION PROBLEMS HURTS KOMAG STOCK
description: The stock of Komag Inc. of Milpitas, Calif., sank almost 18 percent yesterday on news that production problems would drag down fourth-quarter earnings at the company, which supplies components for computer hard disk drives. The announcement was made late on Monday. Komag's shares rose last week after another component maker, Hutchinson Technology Inc. of Hutchinson, Minn., said its earnings would be higher than anticipated this quarter. Hutchinson makes suspension assembly parts and Komag makes thin-film media components. The products from Komag, Hutchinson and another component maker, the Read-Rite Corporation, also of Milpitas, Calif., are used in conjunction, so frequently if one company does well, the others do as well. Komag's stock closed down $5.875 yesterday, at $27.25, on the Nasdaq stock market. Hutchinson closed up $1.375, at $73.25. Read-Rite closed down 62.5 cents, at $25.75.

title: Boo Who? Forwards Take Center Stage for Knicks
description: He started the game 0 for 8 from the field, lofting awkward-looking jump shots that clanged badly off the rim. The jeering picked up momentum with each miss. St. Patrick, who last week wondered aloud why his fans are more fickle than loyal, did not emerge unscathed.

title: A Regressive Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Sneaky Censoring
description: To the Editor:

title: Muzzling Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Robinson Not Ready To Leave Grambling
description: The inspiring coaching career of Eddie Robinson remained in limbo yesterday, somewhere between Robinson's wish for a farewell tour of a 55th season at Grambling State University and the apparent conclusion of Raymond A. Hicks, the university president, that it is time for the coach to go.

title: VW Strives To Make Up With G.M.
description: With a flurry of activity the last two weeks, Volkswagen A.G. is desperately trying to put an end to the messy affair over its hiring of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the former purchasing star at the General Motors Corporation. It has offered its regrets; it has accepted Mr. Lopez's resignation, and it has proposed elements of a settlement.

title: Bank Robbery Suspect Says He Got Inspiration From TV
description: Anthony Norman has served time for several petty crimes, but when he decided to rob a bank on Monday, he says in a statement to the police, he drew his inspiration from a television program.

title: Plutonium Stockpile Fosters Fears of 'a Disaster Waiting to Happen'
description: During the nearly four decades that the Rocky Flats nuclear complex here made plutonium triggers for America's atom bombs, plant managers smothered the rare visitor with soothing safety scenarios. Voices of alarm came only from outside the gate, where protesters were relegated to a wind-blown patch of prairie two miles from the assembly lines.

title: Robbery Suspect Cites TV as His Inspiration
description: Anthony Norman has served time for several petty crimes, but when he decided to rob a bank on Monday, he said in a statement to the police, he drew his inspiration from a television program.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Bulldogs and Tigers

title: Wuerffel Begins to Pick Up the Prizes
description: Danny Wuerffel was at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday not only because he is the gifted quarterback for the University of Florida football team that is headed for the Sugar Bowl but also because he is a gifted student athlete worthy of an $18,000 graduate school scholarship.

title: Investigation Of Ex-Executives
description: New York prosecutors are conducting a grand jury investigation of former executives and brokers at A. R. Baron & Company, the defunct penny stock firm.

title: Test Run of Pipeline by Iraqis Sends Oil Prices Tumbling
description: Crude oil prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as a test of a pipeline to Turkey removed doubts that Iraq would soon begin exporting oil for the first time since 1990.

title: Clinton's Chief Economist Accepts Post at World Bank
description: Joseph E. Stiglitz, who served for the last year and a half as chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he would leave the Clinton Administration early next year to become chief economist at the World Bank.

title: Kotite's Long Goodbye Lingers
description: Once again, the last days of a Jets regime are unfolding. It seems likely these are the final two games of Rich Kotite's tenure and the Jets will be hiring their fourth head coach of the 1990's.

title: Corps Is Tightening Rules on Wetlands To Curb Developers
description: The Clinton Administration significantly tightened wetlands regulations today, saying it would phase out a kind of expedited permit procedure that has allowed developers to drain tens of thousands of acres of wetlands, 10 acres at a time.

title: The New Consensus on Medicare
description: When it was created in the 1960's, Medicare gave the elderly the same fee-for-service coverage that everyone else used. But now Medicare stands nearly alone in providing this most expensive health-care choice, at huge taxpayer expense.

title: Feeding Hope as Well as Hunger
description: A SENSE of holiday leftovers seems general in the capital: at the White House, President Clinton has been busy picking over lists of potential Cabinet members to fill out his second term. At the D.C. Central Kitchen, countless gift turkeys from the city's expense-account overclass are being converted daily into toothsome meals for 3,000 members of the ever-hungry underclass.

title: British Utility Lifts Payout in Face of Bid
description: Northern Electric P.L.C., seeking to fend off a $:923 million, or $1.52 billion, takeover bid led by the Calenergy Company, said it would increase its dividend and develop its businesses through joint ventures.

title: Wal-Mart Is Opening a New Gate to Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Alliance Formed Around Sun's Java Network
description: In a show of strength intended to rally Internet software developers around its Java programming language, the Javasoft division of Sun Microsystems Inc. said yesterday that more than 100 companies -- with the conspicuous exception of the Microsoft Corporation -- were agreeing to more closely adhere to the rules set by Sun on Java network applications.

title: Quartet Losing Its Leader of Five Decades
description: ''So, are you shocked?'' asked Robert Mann, the first violinist of the Juilliard String Quartet, a few moments after saying that at the end of this season he would retire from the ensemble he helped found in 1946. His last New York performance with the group is to be the closing installment of a Bartok quartet cycle at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in some copies on Saturday with an obituary of the painter Leon Polk Smith was published in error. It showed Leon Smith, an abstract sculptor.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day on Monday misstated the terms of an offering by Level 8 Systems Inc. It is for one million common shares, not one million shares and warrants.

title: Freud in Russia: Return of the Repressed
description: The young Russian psychoanalyst was confused. His patient, an alluring, intelligent but deeply unhappy young woman, seemed affronted when he interpreted her flood of sexual reminiscences as her fantasy of their future relationship.

title: Cardinals Make Some Changes
description: The pendulum has swung back to KENT GRAHAM and LEELAND McELROY. Arizona Cardinals Coach VINCE TOBIN said yesterday that he would start Graham at quarterback and McElroy at tailback Sunday against the Washington Redskins. The decisions makes benchwarmers of BOOMER ESIASON and LeSHON JOHNSON, who have had the most productive single-game performances in the National Football League this season at their positions.

title: For Abused Saint, the Last Straw: Santa Weighs In
description: A cluster of small children was serenading St. Nicholas, the European ancestor of Santa Claus, when a group of teen-agers rushed up to him, knocked off his bishop's miter and ripped off his beard. The incident forced the holy man to flee by car, when everyone knows he travels by horse.

title: Milbury Gets the Islanders Stirred Up
description: Mike Milbury gave Zigmund Palffy and Travis Green new dance partners tonight. He taught his conservative defensemen new offensive moves.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RITA DOVE, the former Poet Laureate of the United States, thought there could be no surprises left for her after her appointment to that august post in 1993.

title: A U.S. Split With France Is Seen in Poll On U.N. Chief
description: A potential battle between France and the United States over who will be the next Secretary General loomed in the Security Council tonight after informal voting on new African nominees who entered the race since Boutros Boutros-Ghali put his candidacy on hold last week.

title: Fresno St. Comes East and Gives a Lesson
description: Chris Herren, the highly recruited player from Fall River, Mass., who went West after playing one game at Boston College, returned to his home state tonight as the chief tormentor in Fresno State's 102-81 victory over the University of Massachusetts.

title: Japan Corporate Profits Up 12.7% in Quarter
description: Japan's corporate profits rose an average 12.7 percent in the July-September quarter compared with the corresponding period in 1995, the Ministry of Finance said yesterday. While the quarterly rise in pretax profits was the ninth consecutive increase, it was the smallest growth in a year. The data also showed that Japan's economic recovery has not broadened, since profits fell in a number of industries.

title: Alain Poher, 87, Political Figure And Interim President of France
description: Alain Poher, a central figure in French politics for half a century who twice served as the nation's caretaker President, died on Monday. He was 87.

title: When the Country's Welfare Officials Gather, the Topic Is Change
description: It's 70 degrees in the Valley of the Sun, but the Hilton resort hotel's deck chairs are empty, and none of the 400 people at the meeting here this week sport shorts or a sunburn. This is the welfare establishment, the elite of the nation's biggest bureaucracy. In workshops and presentations, these somber-suited civil servants have come to grapple with a Federal welfare law that will end their careers as they have known them.

title: Oil Flows From Iraq
description: Iraq began pumping oil abroad for the first time in six years, reopening a 616-mile pipeline to terminals on the Turkish coast under a deal with the United Nations. But experts said that it could be weeks before the oil reached delivery points.

title: Council Vows Defeat of Giuliani's Superstore Plan
description: City Council leaders declared yesterday that they would defeat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to make it easier for superstores to open in the city, dealing a bitter blow to his most ambitious effort to eliminate regulations that he said discouraged investment in New York.

title: Iraq Resumes Pumping Oil Through Pipeline to Turkey
description: Iraq began today to pump oil abroad for the first time in six years as President Saddam Hussein reopened a 616-mile pipeline that will deliver Iraqi crude to terminals on the Turkish coast.

title: Clinton Chides Senate for Not Approving Women's Rights Treaty
description: Surrounded by half a dozen women's-rights advocates from around the world, President Clinton sought today to blunt criticism of his Administration's record on human rights by chiding the Republican-controlled Senate for failing to approve a 15-year-old United Nations treaty guaranteeing women's rights.

title: Business Travel
description: The Exchange Conference Center in Boston, a new meeting space in the former New England Fish Exchange on Boston Harbor, is offering Delta Air Lines shuttle passengers discounted meeting services.

title: DANCE
description: Hushed and Haunted Journey

title: Court Upholds First Jersey Fine
description: A Federal appeals court upheld a $71 million fine yesterday that the penny-stock promoter Robert E. Brennan, and his former firm, First Jersey Securities, were ordered to pay to the Securities and Exchange Commission for defrauding hundreds of thousands of investors.

title: Seton Hall Stymies St. Peter's
description: Seton Hall plays in the Big East Conference, one of the nation's best. St. Peter's plays in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, where the competition is not the same.

title: In Season of Lights, a New Generation of Miracles
description: WITH wide eyes and waving hands, Patti Wollman leaned close to the children hunkered down on the carpet and recited the Hanukkah story. One child helped her through the story of Judah Maccabee's fight against the Syrians and broke into a pretend gallop when she got to the part about soldiers on horseback sweeping into town to conquer the Jews.

title: 101 Evitas
description: At the Sony Lincoln Square on Sunday, the packed house that had come to see Woody Allen's glorious new movie musical, ''Everyone Says I Love You,'' was laughing even before it began. The source of the titters was a trailer for another movie musical, ''Evita'' -- ''the story of the love between a girl and her dream,'' intoned the narrator -- in which Madonna, dripping in Dior, declared to the adoring multitudes, ''I'm only a simple woman!''

title: German Builders Cut Costs Importing Eager Europeans
description: Ray Briggs and his crew of eight construction workers share a four-bedroom apartment here in the heart of what used to be East Germany. Most of them speak little or no German, and they long for their families in places like Liverpool or London.

title: Sidney Grossman, 91; Entrepreneur Headed Lumber Concern
description: Sidney Grossman, an innovative entrepreneur who salvaged forests, sold Army tanks for tractors, turned home buyers into home builders and recycled entire towns, died on Thursday at his home in West Newton, Mass. He was 91 and had been president of his family's lumber business in Quincy, Mass., from 1948 to 1968.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TOM BROWN INC.,

title: Yankees Make Call to Stanton While Aiming for Clemens
description: George Steinbrenner predicted the Yankees would sign a major player this week, but the owner declined to say whether he thought it would be Roger Clemens, David Wells or John Wetteland. Forget the huge names for a moment, because the Yankees will announce today the signing of the left-handed reliever Mike Stanton to a three-year contract for about $5.3 million.

title: When Puttanesca Sauce and Tuna Join Forces
description: PUTTANESCA is the famous highly seasoned pasta sauce, and tuna, a strong flavored fish, stands up well to it. For balance, a version of Irish colcannon -- mashed potatoes and cabbage -- flavored here with buttermilk, mustard and chives, instead of the traditional cream.

title: INSIDE
description: Hope for Cerebral Palsy

title: Senator's Wife Kills Friend
description: Allison Ewing was only trying to pull her car over to talk to a longtime friend who was walking down the road in Bedminster. But in a freakish accident on Sunday, Mrs. Ewing, 76, the wife of New Jersey's senior State Senator, John H. Ewing, ran over her friend, Peggy Pulleyn, 85, and killed her.

title: Port Authority to Sell Part of Its Art Collection
description: None of the artworks will fetch anywhere near the $15.6 million that Willem de Kooning's 1949 ''Woman'' brought last month. Nor is the collection of paintings, sculptures, prints, etchings, lithographs, tapestries and photographs worth anywhere near the $82.3 million taken in at an auction at Christie's on Nov. 13.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about shortages at apparel catalogue companies referred incorrectly to the situation at L.L. Bean. The company is beginning to experience shortages in many items; it did not expect to be sold out of many items by yesterday.

title: MORGAN STANLEY GROUP BUYING ASSET-CUSTODY BUSINESS
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the global asset-custody business of Barclays P.L.C., making the investment bank the world's seventh-largest caretaker of stocks and bonds held by investment funds. Morgan Stanley said it would take custody of $250 billion in institutional assets held by Barclays by the beginning of the second quarter of 1997, bringing its total assets under custody to $390 billion.

title: Wine Talk
description: GIVING a wine book as a holiday gift takes courage. Everyone assumes that wine-loving friends know all there is to know about the subject and that a simple volume will offend.

title: Personal Health
description: PARENTS, doctors, teachers and counselors who deal with teen-agers and preteen-agers may be able to draw some good from the case of the teen-agers from New Jersey who were indicted on Monday on charges of first-degree murder in the killing of their newborn baby at a Delaware motel. This case can be an opportunity to discuss sexuality and its potential consequences with young people and to let them know you will help if they get into trouble.

title: Staying One Step Ahead of Guests, Expected or Not
description: WHEN people stop by at this time of year, whether expectedly or unexpectedly, in ones and twos or in full-size crowds, I want to serve some food along with a glass of wine or another drink. It is always comforting to have a couple of items on hand that can be easily prepared, preferably ahead of time, and set out on a table with pride. The food should look appealing while satisfying all taste preferences.

title: Bond Prices Fall as Data Are Awaited
description: The prices of Treasury securities slumped yesterday in light, choppy trading as investors waited for reports on inflation and retail sales that are to be released in the next few days.

title: United Airlines and NatWest to Issue Corporate Charge Card
description: United Airlines and National Westminster Bank P.L.C. will introduce a corporate charge card in the United States for use at merchants who accept American Express cards.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Silence Is Deafening in C.I.A. Suspension Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Force Inquiry Clears General In Saudi Bombing That Killed 19
description: The Air Force has concluded that the general in charge of a military housing complex in Saudi Arabia where 19 Americans were killed and 500 wounded in a terrorist truck-bombing last June took reasonable steps to protect against attack and should not be punished in any way.

title: 2 Weeks Before Paris Blast, French Report Predicted New Attacks
description: A report predicting attacks on European targets by militant Islamic groups from Algeria was completed by French intelligence services on Nov. 19, two weeks before a bomb exploded at a Paris rail station, killing four people.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. and Europe Agree On Technology Trade Deal

title: One Cool Character When the Heat's On
description: Two weeks ago in Costa Rica, Eddie Pope made his third appearance with the United States soccer team, his first before a hostile crowd. He had not expected to be showered with applause. But neither did he or his teammates expect to be showered with batteries, coins, fruit, screws, bits of wire, saliva and other liquids that may or may not have been limited to soft drinks and beer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Did She or Didn't She? A Tale of Two Murders
description: ALIAS GRACE

title: From a Choir, Carols and the Classics
description: Choral singers, bad and good, are the surest harbingers of Christmas. Various ''Messiahs'' issue from choir stalls and rented concert stages around the city. Freelance orchestra musicians are busy and prosperous. The amateurs give Christmas its general musical flavor, but leaving them to gratify themselves, and the friends and families who come to admire them, may be the best holiday strategy. Moments of real interest, however, do interpose occasionally, adding the element of excellence to the general celebration.

title: In Jockeying to Lead U.N., Ghanaian Is Moving Ahead
description: Kofi Annan, the Ghanaian in charge of United Nations peacekeeping operations, emerged the clear leader today in the race for a new Secretary General. But even as his support was solidifying, there were indications that France, which has veto power, would deny him the job.

title: Pataki Urges Gradual End Of Rent Laws
description: A week after the Republican leader in the State Senate called for ending most rent regulation by mid-1999, Gov. George E. Pataki called that plan too hasty today and said he would push for a more gradual approach.

title: Veterans Dept. Blames Pentagon For Delay in Gulf Health Studies
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs acknowledged today that it had waited more than five years to begin major research studies on the health effects of exposure to low levels of chemical weapons because of the Pentagon's repeated -- and inaccurate -- assurances that there was no evidence that American troops had been exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons during the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

title: Clinton Promises to Create a 'Coalition of the Center'
description: In his first major speech since his re-election, President Clinton promised today to ''forge a coalition of the center'' in his second term, working to balance the Federal budget, expand access to education, create jobs for former welfare recipients and overhaul campaign finance laws.

title: Seeking Contract, N.Y.U. Workers Walk Out
description: New York University's clerical and technical workers staged a half-day walkout yesterday that drew several hundred workers and a few of students and other supporters to a rally across from Washington Square Park that later moved to Washington Square Church.

title: Centuries of Writing by Blacks Distilled Into a Single Volume
description: ''We are canon makers!'' said Henry Louis Gates Jr.

title: Shareholders to Vote on Joe Camel Ads
description: Shareholders of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation will vote at next year's annual meeting whether to end the company's Joe Camel cigarette ads.

title: Bridge
description: Although there might be objections from Britain and Australia, there is an expert consensus that the world's leading bridge magazines are both American. Which of them should get the top rank is a matter for debate.

title: Spin City Becomes Spin Cycle For Knicks
description: Larry Johnson remembered the down cycle that the Knicks experienced two weeks ago. It was a desperate time, when shots would not fall and all the summer hype was thrown back in the face of a franchise that had spent lavishly in the off season.

title: Opposition flares as Canada's Parliament considers strict limits on tobacco advertising.
description: PERENNIALLY cool Canada is fanning the flames of an advertising firestorm. The flash point? Tobacco, of course; Parliament is on the brink of endorsing stringent curbs on cigarette advertising, marketing and sponsorship.

title: Look, Grandma! Remember This?
description: New shop owners have a rule of thumb: Open around Thanksgiving, and by Christmas you could reap 25 percent of the year's gross sales. Perhaps that's why four home stores chose this season to debut.

title: U.S. Linked Rebel to Killings But Granted Visa, Study Says
description: United States intelligence officials and prosecutors had already concluded that a former commander in El Salvador's leftist guerrilla army was involved in the killing of six Americans when the Government brought him to the United States in 1990 and paid him thousands of dollars to inform on the rebels, Federal investigators have determined.

title: A Day at the High Court: Fickle Fortune v. Reno
description: It was supposed to be an easy case, a comfortable, almost ceremonial occasion for Attorney General Janet Reno to make her first Supreme Court argument, in support of increased discretion for the police in dealing with passengers in cars that are stopped for speeding or other traffic violations.

title: Ovitz Is Said To Be in Talks To Quit Disney
description: Michael Ovitz, the president of the Walt Disney Company and one of the most formidable power brokers in Hollywood, has held conversations with Sony in recent weeks about taking a top job there, a high-level entertainment executive said tonight.

title: FORD TO STRESS COST REDUCTION IN '97
description: The Ford Motor Company chairman, Alexander Trotman, said yesterday that the auto maker would concentrate on cutting costs in 1997 instead of bolstering its market share in the United States. Mr. Trotman said at a year-end news conference here that executives were not losing sleep worrying about the company's 25 percent of the American market, but adding, ''We do stay awake nights thinking about how we can drive down costs.'' Ford is undergoing a five-year reorganization intended to cut development costs $11 billion by 2000. Mr. Trotman predicted that industry sales would be flat or barely higher in 1997.

title: G. de Montebello, Banker Who Started Fund, Is Dead at 62
description: Georges de Montebello, an investment banker and president of the Swiss Helvetia Fund, the first mutual fund in the United States to specialize in Swiss securities, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 62, and lived in Manhattan and Paris.

title: Japanese Investment Abroad Up 27% in Half
description: Foreign direct investment by the Japanese was 2.66 trillion yen, or $23.46 billion, in the first half of this fiscal year, up 27 percent from 2.10 trillion yen in the corresponding period last year, Japan's Finance Ministry said yesterday.

title: Retailers Pledge to Build Superstores, Despite Council's Killing of Giuliani Plan
description: Even as the City Council killed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to allow more superstores in the city, major retailers vowed yesterday to build more stores that would bring New Yorkers 64-ounce mayonnaise tubs, 48 colors of toilet seats and bulk packs of Post-It notes.

title: From the ivory tower, a tough economist for the World Bank.
description: ON first impression, Joseph E. Stiglitz seems to fit the part of distracted ivory tower genius better than Washington mover and shaker.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Townspeople Mourn Daisy, a Dog Whose Day Was Too Brief
description: Late in November, 125 people here attended a memorial service for Daisy, a rising young model whose refined countenance has graced a greeting card, T-shirts and postcards.

title: RUSSIA TELLS NATO IT ACCEPTS OFFER ON A FORMAL LINK
description: Despite its continuing vigorous objection to NATO's plans to expand into Central Europe, Russia accepted the alliance's offer today to negotiate a separate formal security relationship with Moscow.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A dog's best friend may just be a fashion designer, especially if the dog is a greyhound.

title: Carrefour Buys Into GMB To Bolster Market Share
description: Carrefour S.A., France's largest publicly traded food retailer, said yesterday that it had acquired a 33.34 percent stake in Societe GMB, a family-owned company that controls the retailer Groupe Cora, for an undisclosed amount.

title: A Passport to Home, Or a Route to Prison?
description: When L. J. Lin paid a smuggler $2,000 to obtain a Chinese passport, she thought it would give her the legal means to return to her homeland. But with news reports from China that Fujianese immigrants have been arrested there for carrying fraudulent passports, Ms. Lin and other illegal immigrants now fear that they too will risk arrest if they return to China. Ms. Lin said she got her passport after an interview at the Chinese Consulate in New York.

title: Eliot Bailen, 90, Legal Adviser And Personal Agent for Onassis
description: Eliot Bailen, who served for decades as legal adviser to the Greek shipping magnate Aristotle Onassis, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Cable Channel Will Carry The Big Board Ticker Live
description: The New York Stock Exchange ticker, which shows each trade in Big Board issues seconds after the trade is made, will now be made available to television programs on a live, rather than a delayed, basis, exchange officials said yesterday.

title: Microsoft and Pointcast in Broadcast Alliance
description: Heading off what could have been a protracted battle for a new generation of Internet ''viewers,'' the Microsoft Corporation and Pointcast Inc. announced a broad alliance yesterday in the fast-growing area known as Internet broadcasting.

title: Aquarium Turns 100 With Renewed Popularity
description: When the New York Aquarium opened on Dec. 10, 1896 in Battery Park, it quickly became a hit. As the biggest aquarium in the world, it drew more than two million visitors its first year, making it the best-attended institution in New York.

title: Fund Investors Seek Sidelines After Joining Earlier Rallies
description: Mutual fund investors jumped into last month's market rallies with both feet, adding significantly to their holdings in stock and bond funds. But as financial markets trembled this month, fund investors have backed away, preferring to remain on the sidelines or to direct new money to the safer haven of money market funds.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Nov. 21 about coffeetable books that are explicitly promotional misstated the name and the position of an observer of the retail book market who commented on the value to retailers of publishing a book about their business. She is Dulcy Brainard, not Delsie Brainer, and she is an editor at Publishers Weekly, not a book reviewer.

title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge
description: Jennifer M. did not drink much in the mornings, maybe a swig of vodka at home or a beer on her way to school, just enough to make a teen-age alcoholic feel that she could face the day.

title: Learning to Love Superstores
description: Growing up as a mall rat in suburban Michigan, I spent long afternoons at the Tel-12 mall, shopping at the cool clothes boutiques and music emporiums. But I always ignored the Kmart. What good was anything so cheap and generic? My beloved Aunt Ettie shopped there, but only because she'd get great discounts on huge Hershey bars and cartons of Chesterfields.

title: An Albright Presidency? The Law Is Clear: No Way
description: Madeleine Korbel Albright, assuming she is confirmed by the Senate, will be the first female Secretary of State. But, no, Virginia, she could not become the first female President.

title: The Next Millennium: 2001? 2000? Who Says?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheers and Boos for Tax Cuts
description: Asked to name Governor Whitman's biggest accomplishment since taking office, New Jersey residents answered tax cuts more than any other, according to the latest Quinnipiac College poll. But asked to name her biggest failure, residents also said tax cuts. Of 874 respondents, 24 percent named tax cuts as the Governor's best achievement and 17 percent rated it her worst, said Maurice Carroll, director of the polling institute at the college, which is in Hamden, Conn.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTEGRATED HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS INC.,Reston, Va., which develops and sells health-care management software, said it was in active negotiations with two companies for the sale or merger of its businesses.

title: Bonds Drop Sharply; Yield Up to 6.62%
description: The prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday amid concern that the economy was not slowing fast enough and that interest rates could rise if foreign investors slow their buying. And traders kept in the backs of their minds comments last week by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, in which he questioned the high valuation of the stock market.

title: AON TO BUY ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER
description: The Aon Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. for about $1.23 billion, creating one of the nation's largest insurance brokerage companies. Aon will pay $17.50 in cash for every Alexander common share, or $790 million. It will also buy out preferred shares held by the insurance group American International Group Inc. for $317.5 million. That means a big profit for A.I.G., which paid $200 million for the stake in June 1994. Aon will also offer to convert Alexander's series A preferred shares into $120 million in cash. Shares of Alexander & Alexander surged $3.125, to $17.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Aon shares rose $1.125, to $58.75.

title: In Japan, U.S. Auto Makers Fare Worse Than Expected
description: The Neon sat under a garish arch of rainbow-colored lights. But neither the glare nor the special low-interest financing was enough to attract even glances from the few customers at the Yokohama Chrysler dealer one recent Sunday.

title: Singapore, Where Ruin Is Reward For Error
description: With parliamentary elections expected in the next few weeks, the fastest-rising star in Singapore's fragmented and fumbling opposition has escaped a jail sentence and instead must pay an $18,000 fine.

title: Some Students In Serbia Find It Pays to Be 'Independent'
description: The new pro-Government Independent Student Movement may not have much credibility on the campus here, but it certainly has the best-dressed students in Belgrade.

title: The Shrinking of the Home Office Machines
description: THE convenience of working from home -- as 42 million Americans are now doing -- can quickly be overshadowed by the reality of having to make room for a computer, a printer, a copier, a scanner and a fax machine as permanent house guests. And expensive ones, too.

title: New Sparks From Old Fires
description: ''THIS is the best part of the day for me,'' said Saul Cohen. It was after work, and he was lying on his bed as his 4-month-old daughter perched on his chest, primed for her favorite game.

title: 2 Settlers Die in Attack on West Bank Family
description: Breaking a five-month lull in armed assaults, Palestinian militants attacked a family of Jewish settlers in the West Bank today, killing a boy and his mother and wounding five others when they raked the settlers' car with gunfire on a winding road at nightfall.

title: At the Rape of Nanking: A Nazi Who Saved Lives
description: When the invading Japanese Army overran the Nationalist Chinese capital in December 1937, soldiers embarked on a two-month rampage of looting, rape and killing that left tens of thousands of Chinese civilians dead in what became known as the Rape of Nanking.

title: To Concentrate Milosevic's Mind
description: Two snapshots of the crisis over Slobodan Milosevic's tyranny:

title: J. P. MORGAN TO BUY BACK UP TO $750 MILLION IN STOCK
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $750 million of its stock and raise its quarterly dividend. The company, the nation's fourth-largest bank, raised the payout to 88 cents a share from 81 cents. The dividend will be payable on Jan. 15 to stockholders who own J. P. Morgan stock on Dec. 23. J. P. Morgan's board also authorized the purchase by the end of next year of another 7 million shares to offset the impact on the bank's per-share earnings of employee stock-based compensation plans. The board had authorized a 7-million-share buyback for the same purpose in 1996 and so far has repurchased 6.5 million shares. The shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $94.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2 of 3 School Bonds Fail
description: Voters in the growing Woodbridge and Edison school districts rejected large school bond measures Tuesday, while residents of Middletown approved spending $78 million to upgrade their aging schools. The Woodbridge superintendent of schools, Dr. LeRoy Seitz, said he was disappointed by the defeat of the $145 million bond referendum, which would have paid for three new schools and the renovation of 16 others at a cost of $217 a year to the average homeowner. Dr. Vincent J. Caprana, superintendent of Edison's school system, said the $37.1 million bond measure was the third school bond measure to be defeated in a year.

title: Leslie Signs a Two-Year Deal
description: LISA LESLIE, the 6-foot-5-inch center who led the United States team to a gold medal in the Atlanta Olympics, joined the Women's National Basketball Association yesterday.

title: Indonesia Sells Shares In Telephone Monopoly
description: The Indonesian Government said yesterday that it had sold 388 million shares of its domestic telephone monopoly, P.T. Telkom, for 1.41 trillion rupiah, or around $600 million, in the third-largest sale of shares in Indonesian history.

title: Michigan Extinguishes The Red Storm's Flame
description: Fran Fraschilla has his vision, and for this one moment it felt real. He was part coach, part orchestrator and part cheerleader. He stood in front of the St. John's bench, turned his back to the court, turned his palms upward and waved toward the roof of Nassau Coliseum, and the people responded.

title: A Treasure Quest Leads to the Bronx
description: New shop owners have a rule of thumb: Open around Thanksgiving, and by Christmas you could reap 25 percent of the year's gross sales. Perhaps that's why four home stores chose this season to debut.

title: Evoking Revolution And Battle
description: With his Focus festivals and Continuum and Summergarden concerts, Joel Sachs sees to it that students at the Juilliard school get their hands on plenty of contemporary music. Four years ago he extended his mandate a step further by establishing the New Juilliard Ensemble, a flexibly proportioned chamber orchestra that not only performs publicly in New York but also tours and makes recordings, with Mr. Sachs on the podium.

title: For That Unusual Gift
description: THE Christmas Antiques Show, which opened yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 66th Street, does not rely on high-profile divas like boule marquetry to pack visitors in. It's more an ensemble production with trusty supporting players, including some memorable character actors.

title: 2d Amendment Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Modern Facing Strike By Union
description: The Museum of Modern Art's professional employees' union, which includes some of the museum's curators, has voted overwhelmingly to strike unless it can settle salary and job security issues with the museum's management by next week. The union, which has been working without a contract since Nov. 1, has set Tuesday as the target day for a one-day strike. But many union members, unhappy with the pace of negotiations, say the one-day strike could turn into a full-fledged, long-term walkout.

title: Secondary Snowfall
description: The snow that fell in the Berkshires this past weekend was a predatory snow, heavy, wet and punishing. It fell hastily, clumsily, and by the time the storm ended there was as much precipitation stacked overhead in the tangled woods, waiting to precipitate, as there was on the ground. It looked as though someone had turned up the planet's gravity during the night. Under the weight of the snow, every tree, every bush, every wire in sight bowed closer to the earth than it had the day before.

title: President's Counsel Quits
description: Jack Quinn, the White House counsel, resigned today, the Clinton Administration said. His resignation creates another important vacancy for the Administration to fill.

title: A Passport Quandary For Illegal Immigrants
description: Six years ago, L. J. Lin left China for the United States. She says she paid a smuggler $30,000 to get to New York City, where she is a garment worker. Two months ago, wanting to return home to see the son she had left when he was a newborn, she paid the same smuggler $2,000 for a Chinese passport.

title: Jury Finds for I.B.M. in Keyboard Lawsuit
description: A jury in Manhattan ruled yesterday that an I.B.M. keyboard did not cause a 911 operator to suffer hand and wrist injuries.

title: Ex-Judge, Foe of Embezzlers, Gets Prison Term in Tax Fraud
description: A former New Jersey Superior Court judge, known for his tough stands on white-collar crime, was sentenced to two months in Federal prison today for failing to pay tax on some of the $173,000 he embezzled from his real estate partners.

title: U.S. AND EUROPE AGREE ON FREEING TECHNOLOGY TRADE
description: The United States and the European Union reached agreement early today on a deal to liberalize trade in information technology, paving the way for a broader pact incorporating most of the world's big trading nations.

title: Evidence Doesn't Fit Pilot's Story on KAL 007
description: To the Editor:

title: A Third Bowden Is a Head Coach
description: TOMMY BOWDEN became the third member of the family to take over a major college football program when he was named coach at Tulane yesterday. Bowden joins his father, BOBBY, longtime coach at Florida State, and younger brother, TERRY, the coach at Auburn who had employed Tommy as offensive coordinator.

title: It Takes a Big Leap to Reject Brady Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Something for Both Sides in the Texas Runoffs
description: Democrats and Republicans are already arguing about who had a bigger night in special runoff elections in Texas on Tuesday. The Democrats won two prominent face-offs in Congressional elections in the Houston area, while the Republicans achieved a milestone in winning a State Senate seat in West Texas, meaning the party can now claim a majority in a state legislative chamber for the first time in 124 years.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Fragrant Houseplants

title: Liberal Allies Split in Bid For New Labor Secretary
description: The White House, which has suggested that it will not make diversity a primary goal in its Cabinet choices, as it did four years ago, is being pressured by racial, ethnic, women's and labor interest groups pushing their choices for Labor Secretary.

title: Lopez Indicted by Germans And Charged in G.M. Theft
description: German prosecutors have indicted Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the former General Motors executive who switched to Volkswagen A.G., on charges of embezzlement and theft of confidential documents from G.M., the auto makers and lawyers for Mr. Lopez said today.
