title: Teamster Head Has Slim Lead In Vote Count
description: Ron Carey, the incumbent president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, took a narrow lead today in the unexpectedly slow vote count in the race to head the 1.4-million-member union.

title: Austria's Largest Bank To Bid for Stake in Rival
description: Bank Austria A.G., Austria's biggest bank, said its supervisory board had approved a plan to bid for the Government's 49 percent equity stake in the rival Creditanstalt-Bankverein.

title: Birds and More Birds
description: To the Editor:

title: Chargers' Humphries Is O.K. to Play
description: The San Diego Chargers' sagging playoff hopes got a boost yesterday when quarterback STAN HUMPHRIES received medical clearance to resume practicing. Humphries, who suffered a severe concussion following a hit by New England Patriots defensive end MIKE JONES in a 45-7 loss Dec. 1, is listed as probable for Saturday's game in Chicago against the Bears. (AP)

title: Second Job For President's Departing Aide
description: George Stephanopoulos, one of President Clinton's closest advisers, has been hired by ABC News as a contributing correspondent, completing the second pillar of a dual career he said he planned to pursue after leaving the White House.

title: The Party Is Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Words, But Words Are All The Jets Have
description: At last, the Jets seem fired up about an opponent, even though it could all be based on a simple misquote. For the Jets, the game Saturday against the Eagles has become personal.

title: N.Y.R.A. Names New President
description: TERRY MEYOCKS was named the president of the New York Racing Association yesterday and the embattled KENNY NOE JR. will remain its chairman.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the Washington visit of the Chinese Defense Minister referred incorrectly in some editions to United States Navy maneuvers in March, when China was making military threats against Taiwan. Two United States aircraft carrier battle groups cruised in waters off Taiwan, but they did not cross the Taiwan Strait.

title: Voices of Eastern Orthodoxy
description: Along with the many excellent artists who have invaded the West since the dissolution of the Soviet Union has come a salutary wave of interest in music of the Eastern Orthodox Church. The St. Petersburg Chamber Choir brought some to Manhattan last month, as Arte Corale of Moscow will do on Sunday at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street. Meanwhile, the Russian Chamber Chorus of New York, which did good service as the Russians got up to speed, offers a program this evening at the Catholic Center of New York University, 58 Washington Square South, to be repeated at other sites.

title: Banana Republic Chooses Baron & Baron
description: The Banana Republic retail chain, owned by Gap Inc. in San Francisco, said yesterday that it had named Fabien Baron -- who has handled editorial, advertising and packaging projects for fashion marketers and magazines like Calvin Klein, Hugo Boss, Giorgio Armani and Harper's Bazaar -- to serve as the lead creative resource for its advertising. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday comparing the recent performance of class A shares with class B shares on the Shanghai stock exchange carried an incorrect date label in some editions. The changes reflected trading in November and December, not October and November.

title: Banned in Boston: Guaranteed to Help Make a Show a Hit
description: Herbert Ritts Jr., a 44-year-old photographer known for commercial layouts, celebrity portraits and pop videos, could hardly have had a better reception for his first major museum exhibition.

title: Calendar: Holiday Shows and Sales
description: Benefit Craft Show

title: Tainted by Corruption, Colombian President Is Ceding Power
description: Six months after the Colombian Congress absolved President Ernesto Samper of charges that drug dealers pumped $6 million into his election campaign, the travails of the President and this country of 36 million have grown only more desperate.

title: Women Pass Milestone in the Board Room
description: Women passed a milestone in the board room in 1996, for the first time holding more than 10 percent of the directors' seats at the nation's 500 largest companies, according to a census conducted by Catalyst, a nonprofit women's research group based in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 2 about the proliferation of awards in the arts misstated the name of the sponsor of one award. It is the Taos Talking Picture Festival, not the Taos International Film Festival. The article also misstated the amount of land donated to the festival by its sponsor, Jeffrey Jackson. It was 50 acres, not 450.

title: INSIDE
description: Sharp Selloff in Stocks

title: Tinkering With Europe
description: The Clinton Administration is barreling toward an eastward expansion of NATO by the end of the decade without adequate discussion with the American people and Congress. Though the issue seems remote and abstract to many citizens, and tends to come larded with the highfalutin terminology of the foreign-policy priesthood, it is exceedingly important. NATO expansion would involve a crucial political and military realignment of Europe, the continent still most directly linked to the national security of the United States. The consequences are likely to be great and unpredictable.

title: Van Vechten's Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: James Nevins Hyde, 87, Lawyer And Deputy U.N. Representative
description: James Nevins Hyde, a retired international lawyer who served as a United States delegate in the early years of the United Nations, died on Monday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. A former resident of Manhattan's Upper East Side, he was 87 and lived in Newtown, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Night column in the Styles pages on Sunday about Saul Bellow's lifetime achievement award from the Yivo Institute for Jewish Research misstated the surname, age and position of one of its librarians. She is Dina Abramowicz, not Abromowitch; she is 87, not 89, and she is reference librarian, not head librarian.

title: The Message Giuliani Sends To the Police
description: WHEN Rudolph W. Giuliani speaks, New York City listens. He is the Mayor, and he is most generous about sharing his views. Therefore a question for him: Has he ever given thought to the message his comments, when seen as a whole, send to his city, especially to its police officers?

title: Student Killed in Parents' Home After Firing at Police With Rifle
description: A 21-year-old criminal justice student was fatally shot by the police in his parents' home in Mount Laurel, N.J., early yesterday after he told the officers, ''I'm going to die tonight and I'm going to take a cop with me'' and then fired at them, the police said.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK TO ACQUIRE WELLS FARGO BOND BUSINESS
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it and its affiliate, the BNY Western Trust Company, had agreed to acquire the corporate and municipal bond administration business of Wells Fargo & Company for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition involves more than $85 billion in outstanding securities for municipal and corporate issuers primarily in the Western United States. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, is now digesting First Interstate Bancorp, which it acquired for $14.2 billion.

title: Groups Press Clinton On Labor Secretary
description: The White House has suggested that it will not make diversity a primary goal in its Cabinet choices, as it did four years ago.

title: Nets Send Boom All the Way Back to Seattle
description: Kendall Gill did not see George Karl. He was there, all right, standing on the Seattle sideline with his suspenders curving around his barrel-shaped body. A can't-miss, but Gill was shutting his eyes to him.

title: Peace on Earth
description: Hyperbole is the lingua franca of political fund-raisers. That is probably why, at a Republican fete this week, Senator Alfonse D'Amato was described during the invocation as ''our radiant beacon of hope'' and Mr. D'Amato described the New York State party chairman as a guy with ''a heart bigger than himself.''

title: Black, White and Greed Paint the Rap Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Urges F.D.A. Approval of a New Type of Diabetes Drug
description: An advisory panel recommended today that the Food and Drug Administration approve a new type of diabetes drug that could help some diabetics reduce or stop their daily insulin injections.

title: In Land of the Free, a Modern Slave
description: Last year Francesca Ekka came to the United States as an au pair and housekeeper for an affluent couple with two children. There was a large house with a swimming pool, a salary offer three times higher than what she used to earn and the promise of a better life for a young woman who had worked since childhood in her native India.

title: Curbing Special Counsels
description: The Independent Counsel Act, though overused and perhaps sometimes abused, has at its heart an institution essential to our constitutional government.

title: Labor Commissioner Resigns
description: Citing ''personal and professional considerations,'' the State Labor Commissioner, Peter J. Calderone, submitted his resignation yesterday to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Calderone, 48, said he planned to return to his former position as a state workers' compensation court judge. The Governor said she asked him to resign because he attempted to enlist the support of organized labor to oppose a proposed administration policy, but she would not elaborate on what that policy was.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about an outbreak of food poisoning in Scotland referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of a similar outbreak in Japan. It was this year, not last.

title: UNION CARBIDE SEES DISAPPOINTING 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit would be well below expectations because of surging prices for raw materials. The company, a plastics and chemicals maker, will report net income of about 65 cents a share, far short of the 92 cents forecast and about half the earnings of the corresponding period last year, analysts said. Union Carbide's shares fell $2.0625, to $42.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Chemical makers' earnings are under pressure after years of benefiting from low prices for petroleum, which is used to make the raw materials for plastics, coatings and solvents. The fourth quarter will mark the third time this year that Union Carbide's earnings were shy of analysts' expectations, First Call said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. popped into his father's old office at the White House yesterday some people wondered if he was under consideration for a post with the Clinton Administration.

title: Living Off-Center on Purpose
description: A YEAR ago, when I first started telling people that my 10-year love-hate relationship with New York was over and that I was moving to Washington, D.C., something strange happened: No one asked me why I was leaving New York. They only asked me why I was moving to Washington. Even after I told them it wasn't because of a job, a man or a dream.

title: Micron Electronics Names Trahan, Burden
description: Micron Electronics Inc., a maker of computer products in Nampa, Idaho, said yesterday that it had named Trahan, Burden & Charles in Baltimore to handle its account, which has been in-house for two years. Billings were estimated at $30 million. Denise Smith, a Micron spokeswoman, said that the decision came after a review that also included eight advertising agencies she declined to identify.

title: In Retailing, Biggest Gains Come From Big Spenders
description: Hermes has a waiting list for its $4,000 Kelly bags. Neiman Marcus sold all 50 of the $75,000 Jaguars featured in its Christmas catalogue in eight days. Patek Philippe has back orders for a $44,500 watch.

title: East Harlem District Is Considering an All-Boys Public School
description: An educational policy organization and officials of an East Harlem school district are discussing the establishment of an all-boys school that would mirror the all-girls school the district opened under legal challenge in the fall.

title: Buttons, Bows and Damask: Designer Chairs at Auction
description: CHAIRS -- actual and miniature, drawn or photographed, plain and wildly decorated -- are the focus of ''The Chair Event,'' an auction tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Pavilion in Manhattan. The evening will benefit Friends in Deed, a counseling organization for people with AIDS and cancer.

title: Longtime Guide to Broadway Actors Ends Publication
description: Terese Hayden threw open the doors to a dusty office in an old brownstone in Times Square in the 1940's and soon the city's actors were crowding in, clutching their black-and-white portraits and their dreams of making it big.

title: Jules Davids Dies at 75; Helped Kennedy With 'Profiles' Book
description: Jules Davids, a retired Georgetown University professor whose scholarly works on American diplomacy were eclipsed by his almost offhand contributions to someone else's book, died on Friday at a nursing home in Rockville, Md. He was 75 and had lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Oil Prices Register Decline On Signs of Ample Supplies
description: The prices of crude oil and its products fell sharply yesterday for a third consecutive session on signs that supplies appear to be more ample just as Iraq is beginning to export oil.

title: Hemp Gets Cinderella Treatment
description: New shop owners have a rule of thumb: Open around Thanksgiving, and by Christmas you could reap 25 percent of the year's gross sales. Perhaps that's why four home stores chose this season to debut.

title: From the Age When Traders Ruled the Seas
description: New shop owners have a rule of thumb: Open around Thanksgiving, and by Christmas you could reap 25 percent of the year's gross sales. Perhaps that's why four home stores chose this season to debut.

title: Trade Groups Propose Web Banner Guidelines
description: Two trade organizations that represent buyers, sellers and producers of Internet advertising issued the first voluntary guidelines yesterday for creating banner ads on the World Wide Web.

title: Is Rocket Worth It At Age 34?
description: NUMBERS. That's a familiar word in sports these days. Numbers meaning stats, which in baseball's free-agent follies translate into numbers meaning years and dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARTHUR L. LIMAN, who was chief counsel to the Senate Iran-contra committee, is not wanting for accolades these days.

title: Du Pont Acts To Farm Out Its Computing
description: The Du Pont Corporation, despite being known as one of the most innovative corporate users of information technology, yesterday joined a growing list of American companies that have farmed out their computing operations to giant technology-service specialists.

title: Compact Solutions For Easy Traveling
description: TRAVELERS without their own private porters will be caddying (read lugging) their own baggage around airports this holiday season. And editing (read cramming) their wardrobes into carry-on totes to avoid the chaos and long lines on the pick-up end.

title: Key Senator Has 'Doubts' On Candidate For C.I.A. Job
description: In an indication that Anthony Lake is likely to encounter problems in his effort to be confirmed as Director of Central Intelligence, the chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence today repeatedly expressed ''grave and serious doubts'' about Mr. Lake's fitness for the job.

title: Farewell to Manchester
description: I like New Hampshire. ''Live Free or Die'' is my kind of motto.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Coyotes Fire General Manager
description: The Phoenix Coyotes fired their general manager JOHN PADDOCK yesterday. BOBBY SMITH, executive vice president of hockey operations, will take over the general manager's duties.

title: Another Sign Fed May Not Raise Rates
description: Except for a surge in energy prices, inflation at the producer level remained benign in November, more reassurance that Federal Reserve policy makers will likely find no need to raise interest rates at their final 1996 meeting next week.

title: Shipping Tycoon, at Ease in U.S., To Govern Hong Kong for China
description: A tough-talking shipping magnate was confirmed today as China's choice to administer Hong Kong when 150 years of British colonial rule end next July 1.

title: How SUNY Got $25 Million Donation
description: Charles B. Wang, whose genius for computers has earned him a fortune, is proud to be an alumnus of Queens College. He hires its graduates, serves on the board of its fund-raising foundation, and has contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to its coffers.

title: Congressman Indicted on Charge of Lying About Service in Korea
description: A Republican Congressman from eastern Oregon has been indicted by a state grand jury on charges that he lied about serving in Korea on official state voters' pamphlets.

title: Markets Get Jitters, and Dow Falls 70.73
description: Markets showed what they could do yesterday when investors get nervous.

title: Cavanaugh Not Going to Pitt
description: MATT CAVANAUGH is staying as the 49ers' quarterbacks coach. MARC TRESTMAN is staying as the team's offensive coordinator, but that might not last long. Cavanaugh confirmed yesterday that he had withdrawn his name from consideration for the head coaching job at the University of Pittsburgh, his alma mater.

title: Sure Hands For Giants: Calloway's On a Roll
description: Of course, everything has been difficult for the Giants this season. Especially on offense. The quarterbacks are splitting snaps during the week. The running back has scored only one touchdown. The offense over all is ranked dead last in the National Football League for the second straight season.

title: Brooklyn Prosecutor Seeks Death Penalty in a 2d Case
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that he would seek the death penalty in a second case, this one against a 22-year-old man accused of killing another man execution style while stealing a jeweled gold pendant and necklace from him.

title: Bane of Slopes Is Hope for the Future
description: The sign on the bus to the Park City Ski Area in Utah is polite but to the point. It urges snowboarders to please hold their boards upright. And oh, by the way, could they also avoid laying their boards on the seats or floor. This is, after all, a bus with racks on the outside for skis. But none for snowboards.

title: Latin Groove For Sounds Of Christmas
description: Some 25 years ago, the quatro player Yomo Toro recorded an album with Willie Colon and Hector LaVoe called ''Asalto Navideno'' for the Fania label that celebrated Puerto Rican Christmas songs; the record still sells. Mr. Toro has recently released his own Christmas record, ''Celebremos Navidad'' (Ashe,), and it, too, will have legs. It's a classic, and Mr. Toro, who wrote most of the songs, brought his band to S.O.B.'s on Monday night to honor both the album and the season.

title: Urban Life, Urban Danger: Scholar Stabbed on the Subway
description: Fred Kaplan is one of those inveterate New Yorkers, a street-smart kid from Bensonhurst who used to roller-skate to Coney Island and ride the subway into Manhattan to ice-skate in Central Park, who went on to become a well-known literary biographer and scholar firmly rooted in the City University system.

title: To Partake of Ex-Soviet Cinema
description: ''I would find it hard to imagine a Russian film without drinking,'' said Galina Verevkina, the coordinator for the Confederation of Film Makers Unions in Moscow, which is sponsoring a new series of films from Russia and other former Soviet republics with the Museum of Modern Art. The series begins tonight at the museum's Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1, and will continue for 10 days.

title: Youth Is Served, and the Rangers Wind Up Doing the Serving
description: The Islanders skated into Madison Square Garden last night and handed the Rangers a revealing defeat in a performance that seemed to represent an intersection between an older, slower team in decline and a younger, quicker team on the rise.

title: Major Airlines Agree to Install Fire Detectors Inside Cargo Holds
description: The major airlines will voluntarily install fire detectors in the cargo compartments of the airplanes that do not already have them, aviation executives say.

title: William Parsons, 87, Ex-Board Chairman Of Teachers College
description: William Parsons, a retired senior partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy and former chairman of the board of Teachers College of Columbia University, died on Dec. 4 at the Maine Medical Center in Portland, Me. He was 87 and lived in his native Kennebunk, Me., where he moved from Manhattan's Upper East Side in 1990.

title: At Shea, Cost of Cheering Rises
description: Has anyone here seen the Mets? Do they still reside in New York City? Are they still in the National League? If they are, are they relieved that the Philadelphia Phillies are still in their division?

title: From Dayton to Sarajevo: Spirit of Giving and Eye for Deals
description: On one of the dreariest days so far of this Balkan winter, when only half the city at a time has natural gas for heating, and drinking water comes intermittently, the people from Dayton, Ohio, hit Sarajevo bearing stuffed animals and offers of help and, in some cases, keeping an eye out for commercial opportunities.

title: Pataki's Chief For Insurance Takes New Job
description: Edward J. Muhl, the State Insurance Superintendent and an architect of Gov. George E. Pataki's efforts to reduce government regulations on businesses, announced today that he was resigning.

title: Swiss Promise 'Sweeping Study' Into Jewish Victims' Money
description: In an attempt to calm Switzerland's first major dispute with the United States in half a century, a senior Swiss official said today that his country was now fully committed to tracking down and returning any assets of Holocaust victims ''still being wrongfully held'' in its banks.

title: Man of Few Words, Fierce Punches
description: Andrew Golota arrived for today's news conference wearing a Chicago Bulls cap and a red and black sweatsuit.

title: U.S. Ex-General Lavish in Praising Mexican Allies in Drug War
description: In his nine months as director of national drug control policy, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey has used broad praise to try to improve the diplomatic cooperation between the United States and Mexico in the war against drugs.

title: Yanks Reserving a Seat With Clemens's Name on It
description: The Yankees did not dare place an empty chair beside Mike Stanton and Joe Girardi at yesterday's news conference to symbolize the possible arrival of Roger Clemens. That would have been too presumptuous, especially since the Cleveland Indians have escalated the Clemens sweepstakes by offering him a four-year, $28 million contract while hinting at the possibility of adding a fifth year.

title: Death Penalty Is Rejected
description: A Monmouth County jury declined to impose the death penalty on a 31-year-old woman convicted last month of burning her two young children to death inside her car. After two days of deliberating the fate of Maria Dolores Montalvo, jurors reported that they were unable to reach a verdict on whether the aggravating factor in the murder -- the fact that it was committed in the course of an another felony, arson -- outweighed 23 mitigating factors. The mitigating factors included Ms. Montalvo's lack of a criminal record and a finding that she was emotionally disturbed, said Robert A. Honecker Jr., the second assistant county prosecutor.

title: No Headline
description: ''It's not Russia if it doesn't snow. In the old days we would have thought the C.I.A. did it.'' VYACHESLAV SESOYEV, proprietor of a Moscow sporting goods store. $(A4:3$)

title: Design Elves in Toyland
description: THE lights burn brightly past midnight. Heads bend over tables as busy hands dab primary reds and blues on plastic airplane wings and stuff the limbs of goofy, grinning animals with wadding.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about plans by the Microsoft Corporation to increase spending for basic research misstated the extent of the planned expansion. It will not create the world's largest computer science laboratory; I.B.M., with 1,100 people working on basic research, has the largest one.

title: MetroStars Re-sign De Avila
description: The MetroStars secured the services of ANTHONY DE AVILA for two more years yesterday by signing to a contract the Colombian international striker, who scored 8 goals in 11 games, including 2 in 3 playoff games, after joining the Major League Soccer team late last season. ''Our two main objectives heading into the off season were to re-sign ROBERTO DONADONI and Anthony De Avila,'' said CHARLIE STILLITANO, the general manager of the MetroStars.

title: Whipsawing The Groves Of Academe
description: IT is harvest season in the northern suburbs. The backyard basil crop has been brought in. Jeffrey Kittay is in his dining room, dropping dollops of homemade pesto into ceramic bowls and smothering it in steaming vegetable soup.

title: Man Convicted in Carjacking
description: A Newark man who was accused of sexually assaulting a woman and beating her so badly that she suffered a shattered hand and a severely bruised face was convicted Tuesday of a Federal carjacking charge, prosecutors said yesterday. Jose Luis Nunes, 26, will be tried next year in Hudson County Superior Court on the assault and robbery charges stemming from the carjacking last January, said Patty Shwartz, an assistant United States attorney.

title: Russian Dirge: Where Are Snows of Yesteryear?
description: Even for Russians, whose character depends famously on a shared ability to endure punishment that would devastate a weaker nation, this has been a particularly trying year.

title: Times Mirror Buybacks
description: The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that it bought back 12.5 million shares and share equivalents this year for about $420 million, and plans to spend about the same amount on buybacks next year. Speaking at a media conference in New York, Mark H. Willes, the company's chairman and chief executive, said it was going to concentrate on investing in its core publishing businesses, but would buy back stock or raise its dividend if money was left over. He said 1996 earnings would rise to between $1.45 and $1.50 a share from 84 cents last year.

title: BMW Picks Agency For Midwest Ads
description: BMW of North America has named McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago to handle advertising for its Midwest regional dealers.

title: More Sexual Crimes Reported at Base
description: In a widening inquiry, Army officials said today that investigators had identified more than 50 women who may have been raped, assaulted or harassed at the Army Ordinance Center and School here in the past two years, double the number of just a few weeks ago.

title: Media Images
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Plunge Again In a Nervous Market
description: Stocks continued a December slump yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 98.81 points in its sharpest one-day fall since July. Since reaching a record high on Nov. 25, the Dow is now down 3.73 percent, as investors grow increasingly nervous.

title: Mating Game of Fruit Fly Is Traced to a Single Gene
description: Will she? Won't she? Does he care? Will he call? Courtship is an intricate behavior in almost every species from human to fruit flies. It energizes mind and body in life's great game of contributing to the next generation. But biologists have now discovered to their amazement that almost the entire courtship repertoire of the male fruit fly is governed by a single gene.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Chain Reaction

title: Teamster Vote Drags as Chief Clings to Lead
description: With just over one-third of the votes counted, Ron Carey, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, held on to a slim lead today in his race for re-election against James P. Hoffa, son of the legendary teamsters' leader.

title: What, Me Not Worry?
description: In recent years, science has become the ultimate commodity, the truth you cannot afford not to buy. It is, of course, not surprising that science has acquired such authority, given the benefits from all those diverse achievements that began with the so-called scientific revolution of the 17th century. After all, who would want to live in a world without anesthetics, for example?

title: Devils Quit Defending And Go Ballistic
description: It is hard to say what was more astonishing: the Devils finding themselves in a shootout or the Devils actually winning the shootout quite handily.

title: On the Eve of a New Life, an Untimely Death
description: Jonathan Larson, who created the hit rock opera ''Rent,'' died as he was about to achieve success. Following is an account of the last days of his life and the first days of his production, assembled from the accounts of co-workers (in italic print) and from a New York State Department of Health case report released yesterday.

title: Justice Marshall's Blot Needs No Condescension
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Coaches Named
description: Three more college football coaching vacancies were filled yesterday -- at New Mexico State, Baylor and Arkansas State.

title: A U.S. Jet Jettisons a Bomb Off Okinawa
description: An American jet fighter trying to land at a United States military base in Okinawa was forced to drop a bomb into the ocean off the island, the United States Marine Corps said today.

title: Charles Hamilton Jr., 82, An Expert on Handwriting
description: Charles Hamilton Jr., the flamboyant autograph dealer and handwriting expert who invented the term philography to describe what he did with more panache than anybody else, died on Wednesday in his apartment in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: The Contrast Of Business And Celebrity
description: With his resignation as president of the Walt Disney Company, Michael Ovitz joins the many high-powered Hollywood executives who have left top jobs in the last two years, including Time Warner's Michael Fuchs, Viacom's Frank Biondi, MCA's Tom Pollock and even Disney's Jeffrey Katzenberg.

title: Selling the First Nuggets Of a Nation's Collection
description: One of the best customers of Knoedler & Company, whose current show celebrates its 150th anniversary, was the industrialist Henry Clay Frick. Between 1894 and 1919, he bought more than 225 paintings from the celebrated gallery, paying for at least some of them in Pennsylvania Railroad stock that at the time amounted to less than the value of the works.

title: Zenith Names Bagby To Handle Account
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said yesterday that it had named Bagby & Company in Chicago to handle its national account, which for five years had been handled in-house and by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at more than $10 million.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY AGREES TO SELL ITS THREAD DIVISION
description: The Belding Heminway Company, a maker of sewing products, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Belding's Thread division to Hicking Pentecost P.L.C. for $62 million, including some debt. Belding, based in New York, also said that it planned to change its name so that the thread business could continue under the Belding Heminway brand. Hicking Pentecost is a British maker of specialty threads. The sale would let Belding concentrate on its Blumenthal/Lansing Company, a button business. Belding Heminway's shares closed up 75 cents yesterday at $2.625.

title: Nobel Laureate to Head Panel Pushing for AIDS Vaccine
description: Dr. David Baltimore, a Nobel laureate microbiologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will lead an effort to revitalize the nation's drive to develop an AIDS vaccine, the National Institutes of Health announced today.

title: 2 Hospitals Fined In Wake of Death Of 'Rent' Creator
description: Cataloguing a succession of omissions and errors, New York State health officials leveled fines and unusually harsh criticism yesterday at two Manhattan hospitals for deficiencies in their emergency room treatment of the playwright Jonathan Larson in the days before his death earlier this year.

title: Restaurants
description: My mother couldn't resist a bargain. She deeply approved of the S. Klein department store, and every time I am near Union Square my mother comes along, if only in my imagination.

title: Report Faults Dole and Clinton on Flight Costs
description: Bob Dole's Presidential campaign received hidden ''subsidies'' of hundreds of thousands of dollars through the use of corporate jets from 1995 to 1996, a nonpartisan research group said yesterday. It also said that taxpayers picked up some costs of the use of Air Force One by President Clinton's campaign.

title: Who Can Challenge Giuliani?
description: Tammy Brown has never voted for a Republican. She's 34, Jewish, liberal and lives in Whitestone, Queens. She voted for David Dinkins in the last mayoral election. Last month she voted for Bill Clinton. She worries about the impact of conservative policies on the poor, especially children, and believes more should be done to combat discrimination against women, ethnic minorities and gay people.

title: Linett & Harrison Gets Alpine TV Ads
description: Alpine Brands Inc. in Maplewood, N.J., which sells cheeses and meats under the Alpine Lace brand name, has named Linett & Harrison in Millburn, N.J., to handle a national television campaign. Those duties had been handled for a decade by Vito Catalano Inc. in New York. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $1 million to $3 million. The decision came after a two-month review that included Linett, Vito and three other agencies: the Ad Store in New York; Lois/EJL in New York, a unit of Lois/USA Inc., and Rolstar Advertising in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Welfare's Cozy Coat Eases Norwegian Cold
description: Suffer from rheumatism? The Norwegian state will send you to the Canary Islands for a month of therapy, all expenses paid. Husband walked out, leaving children to raise? Not to worry. As a single mother under the generous Norwegian welfare system, you will get special subsidies for the children and paid leave from your job so you can stay home and rear them.

title: The World Through Women's Lenses
description: IT's doubtful that any woman who uses a camera professionally relishes the term ''female photographer.'' One of the historic attractions of the medium has been that it is a kind of artistic no man's land, far less sex-linked than painting and sculpture. Women have made themselves at home in photography virtually since its invention and in recent years have helped position the photographic process at the very center of art.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about a series of films from the former Soviet Union at the Museum of Modern Art misstated the opening date. The series begins tonight; it did not start last night. ''A Play for a Passenger'' will be shown tonight.

title: Hospital Aide Found Guilty Of Extortion
description: A hospital administrator who prosecutors said lived a second life as an aspiring mobster was convicted yesterday of racketeering, arson and other charges, but the jury was deadlocked on charges that he committed two murders.

title: Lufthansa Strikes Disrupt Air Traffic
description: Lufthansa's employees staged two-hour strikes yesterday at Germany's principal airports in a contract dispute, and the airline said 92 flights were canceled. More than 6,500 passengers were delayed by the walkouts, Lufthansa said.

title: Art in Review
description: Willie Birch

title: Smith Feels A Huge Block From Giants
description: In the remaining days of the season, the Giants are trying to take care of some final issues involving their coaches and, of course, their players. One of those issues concerns guard Lance Smith, who is involved in intense and sensitive discussions with the Giants involving his contract.

title: MULTICARE IN A $95.2 MILLION DEAL FOR CARE PROVIDER
description: The Multicare Companies said yesterday that it had acquired A-D-S Group, a privately held provider of long-term care, for about $60.1 million in cash, $10.5 million in newly issued stock and the assumption of about $24.6 million of debt. A-D-S, based in Newton, Mass., owns or manages 23 long-term-care facilities with 3,072 beds, 20 hospital-based subacute units with 514 beds and eight assisted-living operations with another 820 beds. Multicare, which is based in Hackensack, N.J., owns, leases or manages more than 150 long-term-care facilities with more than 16,000 beds in 11 states. The company said the acquisition would strengthen its presence in New England.

title: Art in Review
description: Ellen Berkenblit

title: 'Messiah' and More
description: Here is a sampling of performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' and other oratorios in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations.)

title: Esiason Returns To the Cardinals
description: BOOMER ESIASON's problem with the Arizona Cardinals was about time. Seven years. That is the difference in age between the most productive left-handed quarterback in the game's history, and KENT GRAHAM, 28, whose return to the starting lineup led Esiason to miss two practices.

title: Vance Packard, 82, Challenger of Consumerism, Dies
description: Vance Packard, a journalist turned social critic whose best-selling books -- ''The Hidden Persuaders,'' ''The Status Seekers'' and ''The Waste Makers'' -- warned Americans in the late 1950's about the excesses of advertising, social climbing and planned obsolescence, died yesterday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital. He was 82 and had homes in New Canaan, Conn., and Martha's Vineyard.,

title: INSIDE
description: Sweeping Charges in Illinois

title: Ghanaian Gains Ground In Candidacy To Head U.N.
description: Kofi Annan, the Ghanaian head of United Nations peacekeeping operations, who emerged this week as the top contender in the race for Secretary General, strengthened his lead significantly today in informal voting, prompting speculation for the first time that France might withdraw its opposition to his candidacy.

title: Hong Kong Continues to Eclipse An Economic Rebirth in Shanghai
description: A few years ago, when the city fathers got the go-ahead to revive Shanghai as the financial center it once was, they saw no better symbol than bringing the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank back into its majestic old building, the jewel in the row of grand colonial structures that line the waterfront.

title: Menorahs Bloom From Act of Vandalism
description: At 5 A.M. Sunday, Judith and Martin Markovitz were awakened by the sound of breaking glass. Vandals had walked across their front lawn and smashed in their living room window to destroy an electric menorah that had remained lighted through the night in celebration of Hanukkah.

title: Ex-Prosecutors and Deputies in Death Row Case Are Charged With Framing Defendant
description: In a sweeping and rare indictment, three former DuPage County assistant prosecutors and four sheriff's deputies were charged here today with conspiracy, perjury and obstruction of justice in the wrongful murder convictions of two young Hispanic men, who spent years on death row before being released from prison last year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a review of the Mary Anthony Dance Theater's 40th-year celebration at Kaye Playhouse misidentified the dancer shown. She was Pamela Luedtke, not Renee D'Aoust.

title: Crash Inquiry May Prompt Order to Inspect Wiring on 747's
description: Even though investigators examining the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 have not yet determined what destroyed the plane, Federal aviation officials say the investigation has turned up a potential problem in some fuel-pump wiring on Boeing 747's that is serious enough to warrant ordering airlines to inspect their fleets.

title: Zaire City a Symbol of Nation's Chaos
description: From the tidy airport set in a red-earth landscape dotted by thousands of anthills to the crisp, dry air unknown in equatorial Africa, almost everything in this deep southeastern corner of Zaire seems a world removed from the steamy capital of Kinshasa, 1,000 miles to the northwest.

title: Jordan Is the NExt Task In Initiation for Kittles
description: Kerry Kittles did not smell any different. And that could be a mistake.

title: Burmese Pipeline Helps Business, Not People
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ovitz Leaving Disney To Start Own Business

title: New Night Life in Midtown Manhattan
description: THE bright lights of Times Square now advertise multinational corporations. The peep shows on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues have been ousted, replaced by aggressively wholesome businesses. And one by one, as entrepreneurs see people willing to linger in midtown, clubs are coming to the area, providing live entertainment to supplement the revivals and spectacles on Broadway. In recent months, new clubs have opened in midtown, including two jazz clubs, Birdland and the Village Gate; a rhythm-and-blues supper club, the Soul Cafe, and Sullivan's Restaurant and Broadcast Lounge, a theme restaurant where a band knocks out 1960's oldies four nights a week.

title: Mile Renamed After Cigar
description: Cigar is on the New York stakes schedule for 1997, but this time as an event instead of as racing's top competitor. The N.Y.R.A. Mile has been renamed the Cigar Mile for the recently retired champion, and the Grade I race will be run on Nov. 29 at Aqueduct.

title: Yanks Pitch to Clemens as Texas Woos Wetteland
description: Is George Steinbrenner ready to make Roger Clemens the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history? Quite possibly. Steinbrenner might blast open the vault to lure Clemens to the Bronx, one person familiar with the free-agent pitcher's situation said yesterday, adding that the Yankee owner had discussed a staggering four-year, $32 million contract with the right-hander.

title: 3 Human Species Coexisted Eons Ago, New Data Suggest
description: Scientists have found stunning new data showing that a third human species apparently coexisted on earth with two others as recently as 30,000 years ago.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Frighteners

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot In Robbery Attempt
description: An off-duty police officer was shot in the back yesterday during a robbery attempt in the parking lot of a motel near La Guardia Airport, officials said. He was listed in good condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center.

title: $148 Million Renewal Plan Announced for New Rochelle
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced today a $148 million revitalization plan for the troubled downtown here, including the construction of up to 1,000 apartments, stores, skating rinks and a 20-screen movie theater.

title: Panel Recommends U.S. Takeover of Many Services in Capital
description: After 18 months of intensive efforts to stabilize the District of Columbia, the city's financial control board has concluded that permanent stability can occur only if the Federal Government takes over many city services.

title: Black Youth's Summer to Remember
description: The long-running and often distinguished ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' reaches its 190th presentation on Sunday with ''The Summer of Ben Tyler,'' a drama that manages to capture the series at its production-values best and its patronizing-uplift worst.

title: Milbury Is Finding the Right Mix
description: A big reason for the resurgence of the Islanders this season is the bold dealing by Mike Milbury, their aggressive, young general manager and coach.

title: To Abort, Not to Abort: A Comedy
description: Anyone who thinks the battle over abortion rights is no laughing matter should enjoy being proved wrong by ''Citizen Ruth,'' a hilariously brazen comedy whose heroine is an improbable hoot. Meet Ruth Stoops (as this film was once titled): a skanky, glue-sniffing derelict with four children she doesn't care about and a fifth on the way. When Ruth has to choose between a can of brake fluid and her baby's welfare, that's easy. The brake fluid wins every time.

title: Did Somebody Send for an Angel?
description: Whitney Houston barely has to act to bring a gritty nobility to the title role of Penny Marshall's sweetly uplifting film ''The Preacher's Wife.'' As Julia, the indefatigably high-minded wife of Henry Biggs (Courtney B. Vance), an embattled inner-city minister facing the bankruptcy and possible demolition of his beloved church, all she has to do is sing, and you begin to believe in angels, miracles, happily ever after and all the other corny items that this inspirational comedy spills across the holiday table.

title: Motorola in Chinese Deal
description: Motorola Inc. has received three contracts worth a total of $108 million for equipment to expand cellular networks in the Fujian province of China. Motorola said the contracts with the Fujian Posts and Telecommunications Administration would increase the capacity of the Fujian networks to 490,000 subscribers from 280,000. Motorola is based in Schaumburg, Ill.

title: Assembly May Debate A Measure On Abortion
description: The Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly, Sheldon Silver, said today that he would allow floor debate on a measure to outlaw a type of late-term abortion.

title: The Hotshot Has a Heart
description: WHEN Jerry Maguire, looking like Tom Cruise at his considerable best, shows up unexpectedly at the house of his admiring young business assistant, he mentions that he has suddenly split up with his fiancee. Jerry turns his back to Dorothy (Renee Zellweger) as he says this, just long enough for her jaw to drop.

title: Home Care for the Elderly Was Cut Illegally, a Report Says
description: Leaders of a bipartisan legislative committee today accused the State Social Services Department of violating state law by unilaterally reducing the number of elderly people eligible for support services at home.

title: Serbian Town Finds the Cost Of Democracy Is Lost Jobs
description: At 3 this afternoon the whistle sounded at the huge Zastava industrial complex and hundreds of grim-faced workers poured through the iron front gates, struggling into overcoats and clutching dented lunch pails.

title: Retaliating, Mexico Increases 8 Tariffs on U.S.
description: Mexico raised import tariffs on eight American products today, responding sharply to a recent decision by Washington to punish Mexican straw-broom makers with higher duties.

title: Jets' Douglas to Play Under a Microscope
description: There will be at least one close observer of the Jets and Eagles game on Saturday, and he won't be interested in scintillating plays.

title: Lying to Cost Officers Jobs, Safir Asserts
description: To strengthen the Police Department's corruption-fighting efforts and to reverse the perception that officers frequently cover up for each other, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that he will dismiss any officer who lies during a departmental disciplinary hearing or to a superior.

title: Art in Review
description: Richard Pettibone

title: Panel Recommends Costly Program of Improved Airport Security
description: A government advisory committee on airline security today recommended a billion-dollar-a-year program of improvements including screening carry-on baggage for explosives as well as weapons and licensing security workers much the way pilots and mechanics are licensed.

title: How Fears in the Neighborhoods Killed the Mayor's Superstore Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was visibly thrilled on Wednesday night when a woman stood up at a town meeting that he was holding in the Midwood section of Brooklyn and condemned the City Council for voting down his superstore plan, just as he had been doing all week. After joking that he should hire the woman, he assured skeptics in the audience that his plan to attract large stores had gone through ''three years of community input.''

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17

title: Home Video
description: Hit With Buyers and Renters

title: Plan Revamps Hospital Care For Uninsured
description: To help control the cost of providing medical treatment to the poor, the Whitman administration announced today a plan that requires hospitals to manage the care of uninsured patients, who now have little choice but to go to emergency rooms.

title: Bowe Is Trim and Eager
description: RIDDICK BOWE will find out tomorrow night if having a trimmer body makes him a better boxer.

title: Behold, the Smiling Land, if People Follow Orders
description: If you see an immigration official smiling the next time you arrive in Singapore, he may be smiling at himself.

title: Sprint Spectrum Debt Transfer Set
description: Northern Telecom Inc. will transfer to banks about $1.1 billion of a $1.3 billion debt owed it by Sprint Spectrum for building the latter's personal communications services network.

title: Anti-Abortion Fliers
description: After it was reported yesterday that a graphic anti-abortion flier had recently turned up in a few boxes of cereal and cake mix, police began receiving calls from other people who had found an unwelcome message in their groceries, police said. The flier, found in items purchased at supermarkets in several northern New Jersey communities, contains drawings of a late-term abortion, said Joseph J. Delaney, the police director of Ramsey. The most recent incident of the 20 reported so far, occurred on Wednesday, when a Fair Lawn woman found a flier in a copy of The Record of Hackensack, which first reported the discoveries, Mr. Delaney said.

title: Good Recovery Seen for Yeltsin In Heart Tests
description: Boris N. Yeltsin's heart function has improved significantly since his bypass surgery last month and his recuperation continues smoothly, according to an American consultant in the Russian President's case.

title: Accounts
description: * Loews Hotels, New York, part of Loews Corp., to Hill, Holliday/Altschiller, New York, a unit of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, to handle its national account, previously at E. J. Sarraille Advertising & Co., Palo Alto, Calif. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Art in Review
description: Ida Applebroog

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Go to the Videotape? Not CNN/SI
description: At 9:11 last night, 71 minutes into the existence of CNN/SI, I began to wonder: where are the highlights in this 24-hour sports news venture of CNN and Sports Illustrated?

title: WET SEAL OFFERS TO BUY 508 COUNTY SEAT STORES
description: County Seat Inc. said yesterday that it had received a proposal from Wet Seal Inc. to buy 508 of its casual clothing stores but that the offer was ''grossly inadequate.'' Instead, County Seat said it would proceed with its bankruptcy reorganization. County Seat, based in Dallas, declined to disclose details of Wet Seal's offer. County Seat filed for Chapter 11 protection on Oct. 17, saying it planned to shut 200 of its 740 stores. Wet Seal said it would convert the stores it wanted to buy into Wet Seal or Contempo Casuals stores.

title: $6.9 Million Awarded in Claim Of Verbal Abuse at Fannie Mae
description: A jury awarded a former employee of the Federal National Mortgage Association $6.9 million today for verbal harassment by a supervisor who the employee said later reorganized her out of her job.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a jury award to three women who sustained injuries while using Digital Equipment keyboards misspelled the name of the law firm where one of the women had worked. It is Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Mayor RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI, famous for a short fuse when it comes to complaints from cranky citizens, took a surprisingly solicitous stance yesterday toward a famously cantankerous constituent.

title: Let's Make Burgers (Never War) in Belize
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Legal Fees for the Disabled
description: Disabled people who succeed in getting manufacturers to repair or replace defective wheelchairs under the Wheelchair Lemon Law still can end up paying hundreds of dollars in legal fees and court costs. A bill approved unanimously by the Assembly yesterday would allow courts to order the manufacturers to reimburse the handicapped for those expenses.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Charge Is Sticky Fingers In Nixon Stamps Caper
description: When Christie's auctioned 141 misprinted Richard M. Nixon stamps in January, the stamps' unusual defects made them such a hot item that a collector paid $800,000. The commemorative stamps have the President's name printed upside down, and are misaligned in such a way that Mr. Nixon's face extends across the perforation lines and can be torn apart.

title: Fines for P.S.E.&G.
description: Like many nuclear plants, the Hope Creek power station has a sophisticated security system, one that allows only employees with key cards bearing their photographs to enter the reactor area. But when the lock on the door to the room that holds the badges malfunctioned, Government regulators say, workers at the plant came up with a low-tech solution: they taped it open.

title: Finding Wizardry in Some of the Younger Old Masters
description: IN Italy centuries ago, the level of virtuosity in drawing was so uniformly high that we tend to take it for granted now. Not only were first-string artists wizards with ink or chalk, but their sons and brothers-in-law, students and assistants seem equally touched by magic.

title: Candy Kingdom With Jazz Frosting
description: The Kingdom of the Sweets in ''The Nutcracker'' was never like this. The Sugar Plum Fairy is called Sugar Rum Cherry, and she is a pelvis-popping showgirl with two chorus boys at her feet. Later, to the vaguely heard tinkle of Tchaikovsky's Chinese Dance, she becomes a porcelain-like figure in thrall to a zoot-suited partner.

title: Forget Diplomats, but Not Your Gold Card
description: To the Editor:

title: In northern New Jersey, more retirement communities are being built to meet demand.
description: WORK began this week in West Caldwell, N.J., to turn 35 acres into a retirement community that will provide people age 62 and older with housing, services and health care.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 16
description: SATURDAY 12:30 P.M. GAME

title: Unaccountable Commanders
description: For organizations that stress the importance of honor and duty, America's armed services too often excuse the failures of their top officers. The Air Force has followed this offensive pattern by concluding that Brig. Gen. Terryl Schwalier should go unpunished despite glaring security lapses under his command at the apartment tower in Saudi Arabia where 19 American airmen were killed and 500 wounded in a terrorist bombing in June.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a Congressional delegation's visit to an Army training center in Aberdeen, Md., referred incorrectly to two members of the delegation, Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of New York, and Elijah E. Cummings, Democrat of Maryland. Both are currently members of the House, not representatives-elect.

title: A State Steps Into a Takeover Battle
description: Until this October, the world of corporate raiders and hostile takeovers seemed a million miles from the small Nashua, N.H., factory where Louis C. Chagnon carries on the work of his great-grandfather running a company that builds what many see as the Cadillac of machines that fold and seal cardboard boxes. But all that changed when an unsolicited merger agreement landed on Mr. Chagnon's desk at the International Paper Box Machine Company.

title: Assembly Will Debate An Abortion Measure
description: Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly, says he will allow a measure to come to the floor next week that would outlaw a controversial type of late-term abortion. Although it is virtually certain that the measure will not be approved, Mr. Silver's move is apparently intended to please abortion opponents, like the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Messier Stays Home
description: MARK MESSIER practiced yesterday but did not travel with the Rangers to Buffalo for tonight's game with the Sabres. Messier has missed three games with a hyperextended left elbow and it is not known if he will be available for Monday night's home game against Hartford.

title: A Counsel's History
description: The man who has been hired to be a White House official handling Whitewater issues has only recently emerged from his own legal and financial problems arising from a publishing business he helped to run before it collapsed three years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about an appearance by President Clinton before the Democratic Leadership Council misidentified a person applauding the President. The man standing with Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado and Mr. Clinton was Al From, president of the council, not Bernard L. Schwartz, chief executive officer of the Loral Corporation.

title: Critics Choose 'Fargo' As the Best Film of 1996
description: ''Fargo,'' the Coen brothers' mordantly funny film noir about crime in the snowy Midwest, was voted the best film of 1996 yesterday by the New York Film Critics' Circle. On a fourth ballot, ''Fargo'' won over the runners-up ''The People vs. Larry Flynt'' and ''Breaking the Waves,'' although the last film received two other top awards. The Danish film maker Lars Von Trier was voted best director for ''Breaking the Waves,'' his strange, haunting story of sexual passion and spiritual sacrifice.

title: European Vote Backs Open Electricity Market
description: The European Parliament voted yesterday to allow the biggest corporate users of electricity in the European Union to buy from generators anywhere in the 15-nation group starting in 1999 as a first step to opening the electricity market. The parliament, made up of lawmakers from each country, endorsed draft legislation approved by European Union governments in June.

title: Where New York Pedestrians Risk Life and Limb Every Day
description: ''I saw a woman killed here, run over by a van,'' Alva Gonzalez said, pointing at a crosswalk at Parsons Boulevard and Jamaica Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. Moments earlier, she had needed a little quick footwork to escape the same fate.

title: Insistent Urge: Confessions Of a Jaywalker
description: The light flashes unmistakably red. Don't walk, don't walk, don't walk, it pulses. Traffic bears down from across the intersection, horns blaring. A police officer, bulky in a reflective vest, glowers and holds up his palm, daring pedestrians to disobey.

title: Jail Reverts to County
description: Nearly one year after the state took control of the troubled Hudson County jail, the county got it back yesterday, and the man who was removed as warden last January is once again in charge, officials said. The state-appointed acting warden, George Blaskewicz, left the Kearny jail yesterday at the county's request, said Bob McHugh, a spokesman for the Corrections Department.

title: Clinton Is Said to Have Asked Attorney General to Stay On
description: As he wrestles to fill top domestic posts for a second term, President Clinton met with Attorney General Janet Reno this evening intending to ask her to stay on for a second term in his Cabinet, and he might announce other decisions on Friday, senior Administration officials said tonight.

title: For Children
description: Gingerbread-House Workshops

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMRION INC., Boulder, Colo., a maker of nutritional supplements, said it was in discussions with an unidentified company in its industry to consider a possible business combination. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Disney Reaction Calm To Ovitz's Resignation
description: In the bistros and bungalows of Hollywood, yesterday's announcement that Michael S. Ovitz would resign from the Walt Disney Company was big news: the climax to a drama that began last year when Disney lured the industry's most feared and powerful talent agent to be its president.

title: LITTON TO BUY ELECTRONICS BUSINESSES FROM RACAL
description: Litton Industries said yesterday that it would buy Racal Electronics P.L.C.'s marine electronics businesses for $49 million in cash. The Racal businesses, which include radar systems and electronic chart navigation systems, had sales of $100 million in the year ended March 31. Racal is based in Berkshire, England. The businesses employ 580 people in eight countries. Litton, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., makes electronics equipment and destroyers for the Navy. Litton's stock dropped $1.125 yesterday, to $44.

title: Art in Review
description: '19th-Century Photographs of Greece and Rome From the Collection of the Berkshire Museum'

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Face to Face on Multiculturalism

title: Soybeans Soar on Forecast; Oil Rises First Time in 4 Days
description: Soybean prices soared yesterday after the Agriculture Department said it expected stockpiles to fall to a 13-year low because of robust world demand. On other markets, oil prices rose for the first time in four days.

title: Rising From a Quagmire Of Drugs and Violence
description: Susanna C. is not sure exactly how it happened. She was 17, living with her boyfriend at his aunt's home. And she was high on marijuana. It was not the first time she had used drugs, and it would not be the last. But this time was different.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Tin Cup

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Does Keeping the Peace Spoil G.I.'s for War?
description: After nearly a year in Bosnia, American soldiers have lost some of their ability to fight in a conventional war, officers say.

title: $3.37 Billion Bid For Swedish Company
description: In one of the biggest takeover battles ever in Sweden, Handelsbanken offered almost 23 billion kronor ($3.37 billion) yesterday to buy Sweden's largest mortgage provider, Stadshypotek A.B. The combined company would be the Nordic region's largest financial company, with assets of 869 billion kronor.

title: Ovitz, Hollywood Power Broker, Resigns From No. 2 Job at Disney
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that Michael Ovitz, its second-ranking executive, would resign, having apparently been unable to make the transition from Hollywood power broker to manager at a giant corporation.

title: The Moral: Be Careful of Aliens
description: If there's anything Tim Burton ought to know, it's exactly how a mean little Martian disguised as a seven-foot Barbie would slither mechanically into the White House, trying to lure Earthlings to their doom. Mr. Burton does get this right in ''Mars Attacks!'' (with Lisa Marie looking wonderfully spooky as the Trojan space babe), but it's one of the rare occasions when his star-filled, prankish new film doesn't misfire.

title: Art in Review
description: Romare Bearden

title: Let's Make Burgers (Never War) in Belize
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Demote Bertuzzi
description: Todd Bertuzzi thought there might have been a bit of a vendetta involved. To Mick Vukota, it was just the inevitable.

title: Of Slavery and Sex in a Time Warp
description: In ''Insurrection: Holding History,'' Robert O'Hara's time-bending comic fantasia at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, ideas about slavery, homosexuality and the value of scholarship collide and converge in ways that are both clever and confusing. Is that Nat Turner wielding an ax in a Virginia motel? Is the spinning bed that lands on the slave owner supposed to tell us that we are in the antebellum South, or Oz?

title: Burmese Pipeline Helps Business, Not People
description: To the Editor:

title: Styles That Dovetail, With Democratic Ideals
description: ARCHITECTURE AND THE AMERICAN DREAM

title: SHARES OF ALLERGAN CLIMB 7% ON TAKEOVER SPECULATION
description: The shares of Allergan Inc. rose 7 percent on speculation the company may be acquired and optimism about new products in development. Allergan's shares rose $2.375, to $35.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said speculation that Allergan, which is based in Irvine, Calif., could be acquired was renewed after Hoechst A.G. said this week that it would pay $3.5 billion to buy the shares in the French drug maker Roussel Uclaf that it does not already own. Allergan is often the subject of takeover speculation because its market value of about $2.3 billion is relatively small for a pharmaceutical company. In addition, Allergan said its new treatment for psoriasis and acne, Zorac, had been approved for sale in Germany. Zorac is expected to be a major product for Allergan.

title: TV INDUSTRY VOWS FIGHT TO PROTECT NEW RATINGS PLAN
description: Signaling a long battle, a spokesman for the television industry declared yesterday that the industry would fight any effort by the Government or children's advocacy groups to toughen a proposed new system for rating television programs.

title: TWO COMPANIES TO BUY ANCHOR GLASS FOR $392.5 MILLION
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought for $392.5 million by Consumers Packaging Inc. and Owens-Brockway Glass Container Inc., rejecting a previous agreement with the Ball-Foster Glass Container Company. Anchor, a unit of Vitro S.A. of Mexico, has been operating since September under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Anchor, based in Tampa, Fla., agreed in October to sell its assets to Ball-Foster, which is based in Muncie, Ind., for $365 million in cash. At that time, Anchor filed for an injunction to prevent Owens-Brockway from interfering with its sale to Ball-Foster. Owens-Brockway and Consumers Packaging both make glass bottles and jars. Owens-Brockway is a unit of Owens-Illinois Inc.

title: Siemens Plans To Cut 6,000 More Workers
description: Siemens A.G. of Germany, which has made big cuts in its work force, said today that it would dismiss 6,000 more employees in an effort to return to earnings growth in the 1998 fiscal year.

title: Art in Review
description: Peter Soriano

title: A Princess Speaks
description: While Princess Diana again demonstrated the restorative powers of celebrity at the Metropolitan Museum's annual costume exhibit this week, her counterpart in Japan reached a milestone of her own. Speaking to reporters in Tokyo, Crown Princess Masako felt compelled to say that she was not ''in a state of depression, so I hope no one will worry.'' Her statement was offered cheerfully, but it reflected the anxiety of contemporary royalty in Japan, where the subject of the Princess's difficulties is both taboo and pervasive.

title: Germany's Defect
description: To the Editor:

title: Big-Spending Marlins Lure Alou to Florida
description: The Florida Marlins completed a three-week whirlwind of activity yesterday by signing Moises Alou to play left field. Then the Baltimore Orioles ended a historic 14 1/2-year run by signing Mike Bordick to play shortstop so they can move Cal Ripken Jr. to third base.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When EUGENIA ZUKERMAN, the flutist, was asked to perform with the New York Youth Orchestra, she had but one request: that she be given a new work by a young composer to play. She didn't ask that the composer also be an acquaintance. But as it turned out, the piece she will play at the concert on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall is by THEODORE SHAPIRO, a longtime friend of her daughter Arianna Zukerman.

title: U.S. Pulls Out 250 G.I.'s on a Relief Mission
description: The possibility that an international military force might be sent to aid Rwandan refugees in Central Africa was quickly fading today as the Pentagon announced that it had withdrawn half of the 450 American soldiers sent to the region to prepare for a relief mission, including all of those in Rwanda.

title: Childs Rises To the Top For Knicks
description: When he fell awkwardly to the floor and clutched his right ankle in the first half, the Knicks were concerned. When he returned in the third quarter and found himself caught in midair with no one to pass to underneath the basket, they started to worry again.

title: Man Kills Ex-Girlfriend and Then Hangs Himself in the Bronx
description: Reenu Persaud and Sunil Remeharian were teen-age sweethearts, reared in Guyanese families in the Bronx and attending Hunter College. But they broke up last month, and soon after that things went drastically wrong.

title: On the Ropes, Chirac Fights Back in French Television Interview
description: His popularity plummeting, his Prime Minister under attack even from within his own party, and his compatriots fed up with high unemployment, President Jacques Chirac of France went on television tonight in an effort to regain voter confidence.

title: Austrian Insurer's Shares Fall as Bid Is Topped
description: The last-minute entry of Bank Austria A.G. as a bidder for Creditanstalt-Bankverein A.G. may force the Austrian insurer EA-Generali A.G., to raise its bid for Creditanstalt. The possibility that the insurer, Austria's largest, may lose its bid for Creditanstalt, Austria's second-largest bank, and in the process a lucrative agreement to sell insurance through the bank's branches, pushed its shares down 8.2 percent yesterday.

title: Western Resources Ready to Sell Natural Gas Pipelines to Oneok
description: Western Resources Inc., a utility based here that has been looking to expand, said today that it would sell its natural gas pipelines and plants to Oneok Inc. for $660 million in stock, in a deal that will give it access to Oneok customers across Oklahoma.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon:

title: Questions Arise Over Stock Portfolio of Candidate to Head C.I.A.
description: President Clinton's choice to head the Central Intelligence Agency is increasingly becoming the focus of Republican opposition.

title: Joyful Noises: A Guide to Holiday Music in New York City
description: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). This selection, compiled by Anthony Tommasini, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations.

title: Select Comfort Hires Messner Vetere
description: The Select Comfort Corporation has selected Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York as the first agency to handle advertising for its adjustable mattress products. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Can't get data on securities fraud suits? Try the Internet.
description: IT is the investing world's version of ''Godzilla vs. Megalon,'' a titanic struggle over the fate of the planet, watched from afar by hand-wringing government officials and hordes of small investors.

title: 2 Shot in a Murder-Suicide
description: A 45-year-old man and a 39-year-old woman were found fatally shot in the man's bed yesterday afternoon in what police called a murder-suicide by the man, Miguel Montoya. The woman, Nhora Gomez of Bloomfield, had been missing since Wednesday, when she did not come home from work, said Police Chief Thomas J. Russo. Mrs. Gomez's husband told police that he went looking for his wife yesterday at Mr. Montoya's house on Grove Street, but could not get in. Another resident of the building saw the bodies and called police, who found a .32-caliber revolver in Mr. Montoya's hand.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The table is covered with little dishes of food: wild mushrooms zhulien, tossed with onions and sour cream. Roasted beets shredded with walnuts. Shashlik, tiny skewers of marinated lamb. Soft, velvety slices of hot smoked sturgeon. And spears of sour pickles to dip into sour cream and honey. The flavors dance across the palate, an alternating pattern of sweet, sour and salty.

title: The Dangers When Police Turn to Drink
description: THE woman drove west on Canal Street and turned left into narrow Greenwich Street, weaving through two lanes of solid traffic inching toward the Holland Tunnel from the opposite direction on Canal. She never saw the police car, she said, until it was too late.

title: Charles Schwab Widens Mutual Fund Access
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation announced yesterday that it would make its Mutual Fund Onesource program available for the first time through another financial institution. Two banks, Keycorp and the First Union Corporation, expect to offer their customers access to the popular mutual fund supermarket, which includes more than 600 mutual funds available without a sales charge or transaction fee, sometime next year.

title: Dior's Look, 50 Years Ago And Now
description: AS famous as the placid Irving Penn photos of Christian Dior's revolutionary New Look are the New Look photos from the dark side: women in postwar Paris angrily ripping the extravagant clothes off one of the first women presumptive enough to wear it amid poverty.

title: A Fatter School Finance Bill
description: With a Dec. 31 deadline looming, the Assembly Education Committee approved a school financing bill yesterday that is substantially different from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal.

title: Stocks Plunge Again as Dow Falls by 98.81
description: Stocks continued their December swoon yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.5 percent in a daylong decline that was capped with a 46-point plunge in the last half-hour of trading.

title: Celebrating With Song and Story
description: Here is a sampling of holiday celebrations, including dance and drama events, in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations).

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Captives

title: Philips May Shed Its Cable TV Stake
description: Philips Electronics N.V. said yesterday that it might sell or spin off its half of Europe's largest cable television operator, in what could be another move in a campaign to pare unprofitable units. Analysts said the Philips's interest in United and Philips Communications could fetch 1.2 billion guilders ($698 million).

title: School Bus Flips Trying to Avoid Teen-Agers Throwing Rocks
description: Swerving to avoid teen-agers who were pelting it with bricks and rocks, a school bus carrying 26 junior high basketball players and their coach flipped onto its side on Wednesday night. One student was hospitalized.

title: Art in Review
description: Michele Basora

title: Arizona State's Plummer, Heisman Hopeful, Is Faceless No Longer
description: Tourist: ''Do you know where we can find the quarterback, Jake Plummer?''

title: Robinson Has Earned Victory Lap
description: BOBBY BOWDEN understands how abruptly a career can turn. But Bowden strongly believes that if any coach deserves one more shot -- strictly from loyalty, straight from the heart -- it is Eddie Robinson of Grambling, age 77, with the most victories in the history of college football.

title: Retail Spending Off a Bit; Price Index Up 0.3%
description: Shoppers kept a wary eye on spending in November as this year's late holiday shopping season got under way, the Government indicated today in a report that seemed to confirm indications of only modest improvement from last year's poor sales.

title: A Better Way on Budgets
description: For at least a generation, two axioms have ruled state and local government in New York. All budgets drown in a sea of red ink, and the Mayor of New York City and the Governor of New York State are always at war over what to do about it. Now the Citizens Budget Commission has assembled some veterans of 25 years of budget battles and asked whether there is any way out of these twin fates. The result is a recently released fiscal blueprint bearing more common sense than any budgets proposed by mayors or governors in the last 10 years. Politicians would do well to use its recommendations as a guide for the future.

title: Iverson to Miss 2 Games
description: Taking the advice of the team president, PAT CROCE, who is a former physical therapist, Philadelphia 76ers guard ALLEN IVERSON will miss at least the next two games to rest a persistently sore left shoulder.

title: Whipsawed, Bond Yield Is Unchanged
description: The prices of Treasury securities finished nearly unchanged yesterday, as the credit markets stubbornly tried to hold on to early gains of nearly a point on the long bond.

title: RWANDANS LEAVING TANZANIAN CAMPS, BUT NOT FOR HOME
description: With a deadline to return home hanging over their heads, hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees abandoned their camps in western Tanzania this afternoon and started marching east into the bush and away from their homeland, United Nations officials said.

title: A Very Slow Death For Confederate Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Storm Is Soccer's United Nations
description: The soccer team from St. John's, in the Final Four for the first time in its history, is a melting pot, with players of African, Brazilian, Caribbean, English, Dutch, Italian, Polish and Spanish descent. If New York City is looking for a perfect representative on the playing field, this Red Storm squad may be the answer.

title: At Least 25 Countries to Join Far-Reaching Deal to Cut Tariffs : Trade Ministers Agree on Global High-Tech Accord
description: SINGAPORE  In the most far-reaching global trade accord in recent years, trade ministers agreed Thursday to abolish tariffs on more than $500 billion a year of trade in computers, software, chips and telecommunications equipment by 2000.

title: Don't Let Politics Sway Mammogram Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Susana Solano

title: Neil Reagan, 88, Ad Executive And Jovial Brother of President
description: Neil Reagan, a retired advertising executive and radio and television director who was most notably known as President Ronald Reagan's older brother, died on Wednesday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in San Diego. He was 88 and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: In Sudden Move, Miller Shifts Ad Agencies
description: The Miller Brewing Company, bedeviled by slumping sales in an increasingly competitive beer market, responded yesterday by suddenly shaking up its roster of advertising agencies. The changes at Miller, the nation's second-largest brewer, affect assignments with billings estimated at more than $300 million.

title: BankAmerica to Cut Jobs And Shut Some Branches
