description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the latest and largest prosperous bank to announce sharp cutbacks, said yesterday that it would eliminate 3,700 of its 92,700 jobs and close 120 of its 1,017 branches in California.

title: No Headline
description: ''We are a very social democratic society, and we don't know another system. It may be costly but there is social peace. There are no poor people in Norway, and I don't want to see any. There are no strikes, and no high demand for salary increases. I want to adjust the system, but only to preserve it.''

title: Lawmakers Assail Clearing Of Officers in Saudi Bombing
description: Several leading Democratic and Republican lawmakers today criticized the Air Force's decision to exonerate the officers responsible for protecting the housing complex in Saudi Arabia where 19 American servicemen were killed by a truck bomb in June.

title: $25 and Under
description: ''Bissaleh'' is a Yiddish word Jewish mothers use when they're encouraging their children to eat. ''Ess a bissaleh,'' they might say, meaning, ''Eat a little bit.'' In the vernacular of easily insulted mothers everywhere, though, a little bit means a lot.

title: Times Co. Sees '96 Profit Gain
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it expected to report higher earnings for 1996 compared with the previous year.

title: Fiat to Lay Off Workers Temporarily
description: Fiat S.p.A. plans 25,900 temporary layoffs of workers in January as new car sales falter, Italian television reported yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Congressional hearing on the illnesses of veterans of the Persian Gulf war misspelled the given name of a witness from the Department of Veterans Affairs in some editions. She is Dr. Frances M. Murphy.

title: New Whitewater Aide Had Troubles From Failed Business
description: A lawyer-lobbyist hired this week to be a high White House official handling Whitewater issues has only recently emerged from his own significant legal and financial problems arising from a small publishing business he helped to run before it collapsed three years ago.

title: Inside Art
description: The Shelburne Splurges

title: P.& G. TO INVEST IN REGENERON PHARMACEUTICALS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would invest $28.8 million in Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc. in five years as part of an alliance to develop treatments for muscle diseases and disorders. Regeneron shares rose $1.25 yesterday, to $21.125, and Procter & Gamble's shares fell $1.75 yesterday, to $104.625. The investment would be at a 27 percent premium over the price at the time. Any profits from products developed would be shared equally, Procter & Gamble said.

title: City Opera Using 2 Pianos, Not Orchestra, on Tour
description: The administration of the New York City Opera has decided to send out the company's national touring troupe this year with two pianists instead of an orchestra accompanying its singers in ''La Boheme.'' The tour includes 90 performances in 68 cities between Jan. 10 and April 27. Sherwin M. Goldman, the company's executive producer, said yesterday that costs were rising faster than performance fees, and that City Opera's choice was either to drop the orchestra or cancel the tour.

title: As Mets Wait for Arms to Heal, Expectations Change
description: The hype that surrounded Bill Pulsipher, Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson last winter has changed to hope that the trio of young pitchers can overcome recent surgeries and become the franchise anchors the Mets were once so confident they would become.

title: Naked in the Square
description: With a superb sense of timing and of its own power, Communist China picked exactly the right messenger, the right message, the right day, place and audience to humiliate the Government of the United States.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDWIN A. SCHLOSSBERG received an offer about three years ago that he could not refuse: to redesign the office of his former Columbia University physics professor, Dr. I. I. Rabi, a Nobel laureate.

title: Disturbers Of the Peace
description: Yes, to be sure, I know that etiquette is important only to fuddy-duddies these days. What glorious beasts we are now that we are freed of the tyranny of good manners. And a fine thing, too, of course. We are liberated at last to express ourselves.

title: A Proposal on Rabbis' Role in Interfaith Weddings Splits Reform Judaism
description: Jewish leaders have voiced growing concern in recent years over the high rate at which Jews marry non-Jews. Rabbinical organizations, particularly alarmed, warn that such unions threaten the Jewish population's continuity, because of the chance that children of interfaith couples will not be reared as Jews.

title: Aggressive Policing
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Fills Top Posts, Keeping Reno
description: President Clinton rounded out his team of senior economic advisers today, nominating William M. Daley, a Chicago lawyer and scion of his city's legendary Democratic family, as Commerce Secretary, and selecting several others whose appointments effectively consolidated the powers of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin as the dominant Cabinet officer of a second term.

title: Linotype to Cut 1,200 German Jobs
description: The German graphic equipment maker Linotype-Hell A.G. said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,200 jobs, or about one-third of its work force. The company also said it expected to lose more than 70 million marks, or about $45 million, for the second straight year in 1996. (Dow Jones)

title: Clinton Says Rating System Wanted by Industry Deserves Trial
description: President Clinton stepped into the skirmish over a proposed television ratings system yesterday, essentially telling critics to let the television industry test its ratings system before demanding that it be retooled.

title: Treasury Securities Higher As Firm Dollar Aids Bonds
description: Government securities traded higher yesterday, aided by weak economic data and a firm dollar.

title: Chasing Common Ground
description: One runner lives in the Boston suburbs, trains on Heartbreak Hill and has been competing in cross-country races since he was 12. He used to snatch stalks of corn on workouts through farmland, and he paints to capture the artistry of his sport.

title: New York City Slow to Help Its Pedestrians
description: Nearly four years after receiving about $50 million in Federal money to make life easier for pedestrians in New York City, officials with the city's Department of Transportation acknowledge that they have made little headway in achieving that goal.

title: Maine Case Shows Both Sides of '94 Gun Law
description: When David A. Godfrey walked into the Wise Trading Company in Bangor last September to buy a 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol, he filled out the forms required to run a background check under the Brady gun control law. When nothing conclusive turned up after the five-day waiting period, he was permitted to buy the gun.

title: TV Industry Tunes Out Families
description: A year ago, President Clinton and Congress said parents should have an electronic way to screen out television content they deem inappropriate for their children. The law now requires that as of 1998, new TV sets have a V-chip, a device that will enable parents to supervise the more than 1,000 hours a year most children spend watching television.

title: Beliefs
description: It began as a set of heated essays by conservative philosophers, religious leaders and legal scholars. It quickly became an internecine political squabble. And now it is being cast as an ideological battle with ominous religious overtones.

title: Anti-Apartheid Fighter Charged With Defrauding Relief Funds
description: A former clergyman who was once a prominent anti-apartheid activist and became a high-level official in the African National Congress was charged today with fraud and theft involving the misuse of half a million dollars contributed to his nonprofit organization.

title: Democracy, the Teamsters Way
description: As votes are counted in the teamsters election, you can almost hear the outside rooting section for Ron Carey, the union's incumbent president. After all, when Mr. Carey was first elected in 1991, he vowed to root out corruption in an organization notorious for mob infiltration. Federal labor officials and others outside the union may fear that a victory for James P. Hoffa, the son of the legendary teamsters' leader Jimmy Hoffa, would abruptly end that commitment to reform.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge books from Britain are generally of high quality, but also high price. Two recent imports, each $19.45, are ''Step-by-Step: Card Play in No Trumps,'' by Robert Berthe and Norbert Lebely, and ''Step-by-Step: Planning the Defense'' by Raymond Brock. Both are excellent for the intermediate player who wishes to sharpen his skills in essential areas.

title: For Bowe, A 2d Chance
description: Riddick Bowe has all the motivation he needs. He looked bad in his last fight. Some people believe his best days are over. A victory over Andrew Golota in their rematch would re-establish him as a major force in the heavyweight division.

title: Steinbrenner's Money Can't Buy Clemens's Love
description: Roger Clemens surprisingly signed a three-year, $24.75 million contract with the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday that left a stunned George Steinbrenner holding a $32 million paycheck and a city that revered and reproached the pitcher mourning his departure.

title: No, It's Not the Handshakes, But a Gilded Hall, Grand and Gleaming
description: Masonic Hall on West 24th Street -- a dozen stately chambers with a dozen architectural themes, where visitors travel from the Ile de la Cite to the Acropolis to the Valley of the Kings in the time it takes to ride an elevator -- will be rededicated today after a 10-year renovation by the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York.

title: B.C. Hires Coach
description: TOM O'BRIEN, offensive coordinator at the University of Virginia the last six years, was hired yesterday as head football coach at Boston College. O'Brien replaces DAN HENNING, who resigned last month after the Eagles ended a 5-7 season during which 13 players were suspended for the last two games following a gambling probe. Although the investigation found no evidence of point-shaving, it concluded that two players had bet against Boston College in a loss to Syracuse on Oct. 26.

title: Crackdown on Tax Loopholes Will Benefit All
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton, in Emotional Terms, Explains His Abortion Veto
description: Presi-dent Clinton today emotionally defended his veto of a bill that would have banned a kind of late-term abortion. But, as he had previously, the President opened the door to a compromise if Congress would create an exception allowing the procedure in cases of a pregnancy that threatened a woman's health.

title: Requiring Residency in City
description: City employees are going to have to live in Newark if they want to keep their jobs. That is, unless the Municipal Council overrides Mayor Sharpe James's veto of a proposed ordinance that would have waived a residency requirement for 57 workers who live out of town. In a letter sent Thursday to Donald Bradley, the Council president, the Mayor said that the waiver would have been unfair and would have exposed the city to lawsuits by out-of-town workers who had spent money moving back to Newark.

title: Despite His Defeat in Disneyland, Ovitz Remains a Force to Reckon With
description: Michael Ovitz turns 50 today, humbled and fallen from grace like few power brokers in the history of Hollywood. But no one -- not even his numerous enemies -- is predicting that Mr. Ovitz will disappear from the entertainment industry's corridors of power.

title: Marjory Grannis, 80, Community Leader
description: Marjory Banks Grannis, a lecturer and community volunteer, died last Saturday at her home in Lake Bluff, Ill. She was 80 and also had a summer home in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Children Come First
description: To the Editor:

title: The Task of Enunciating In a Comedy by Britten
description: The voice departments of many American music schools seem to operate under an inferiority complex regarding American culture. Too often, students are expected to develop skills for singing in Italian, French and German, but not in their native language, which is taken for granted. Usually, the result is mushy English, which was the frustration of an otherwise admirable production of Benjamin Britten's ''Albert Herring'' by the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater on Wednesday night.

title: Nervous Moments for School Reform
description: New York's many political fiefs are not known for their ability to set aside their own narrow interests and pull together for the common good. That is why everyone who cares about New York City's public school system has been waiting nervously for the State Legislature to meet next week and pass a promised reform bill.

title: A Main Street Fights to Keep Local Flavor
description: FUZZY arches of red, white and green garlands graced Fifth Avenue, a street whose name evokes images of packed sidewalks and stores. Tony? You bet. He's in there somewhere, probably walking right past Tiffany. Or Sean, Juan or Chan.

title: Study Here, Collect $2,500
description: Rutgers University is attempting to lure New Jersey students to its campus in Camden, the state's poorest city, by offering them a $2,500 scholarship, covering more than half of the in-state tuition of $4,028. Yesterday, Francis L. Lawrence, president of the university, announced the establishment of a new $800,000 merit scholarship for freshmen at Rutgers-Camden starting next fall.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Candidate for the U.N.
description: Following are excerpts from Representative Bill Richardson's remarks today at the news conference in which he was chosen by President Clinton to be United States' chief delegate to the United Nations, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a transcription company:

title: JAZZ
description: Like Independent Components

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., said its Missiles and Space unit had more than 1,000 job openings and expected to hire about 3,000 people at its unit in Sunnyvale, Calif., during the next three years.

title: Gene Sperling: National Economic Council
description: One day last summer, Gene Sperling, then the deputy director of the White House's National Economic Council, gave reporters a detailed criticism of Bob Dole's tax-cutting proposals, arguing that they would put the nation's economic resurgence under President Clinton at risk.

title: Falling In and Out Of Love
description: George Faison's ''Suite Otis,'' revived by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater this week at City Center, is a classic with an unquenchably youthful spirit. Created in 1971, the piece is an affectionate, teasing salute to the music of Otis Redding, whose songs provide the dance with a series of mini-plots. Endearingly post-adolescent men and their ladies wind through urban streets in these songs, falling in and out of love with hilarious ease. And Mr. Faison captures the yearning sensuality of the music in taut jazz dance for dancers who strain toward one another and to the sky.

title: Iraq Hunts Anti-Hussein Gunmen
description: The Iraqi authorities were still searching today for armed men who opened fire in the capital on Thursday in an attack that left President Saddam Hussein's eldest son hospitalized.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Fills Economic Jobs, Bolstering Rubin's Powers

title: An Operatic Voice That Doesn't Sing
description: No quiz show in the history of broadcasting has had a longer run than the ''Texaco Opera Quiz.'' Not ''Jeopardy.'' Not ''The Price Is Right.'' There isn't even a close second.

title: Charlene Barshefsky -- Trade Representative
description: Her husband was there, and their two young daughters, when Charlene Barshefsky was formally nominated by President Clinton today to be the United States Trade Representative. But, as usual, Ms. Barshefsky herself was a no-show -- she was en route from Singapore to Tokyo, moving on from a successful effort to win a world-wide agreement to wipe out tariffs on technology products, to talks on a nasty dispute with the Japanese Finance Ministry over American access to the Japanese insurance market.

title: Childs Running A Tight Ship
description: Allan Houston and Larry Johnson say they are both starting to feel comfortable playing in New York. Chris Childs is pushing the ball up the floor and exhorting his teammates to follow him.

title: Coming: High-Seas Shortcut to High Stakes
description: Gambling in the metropolitan region still takes a little effort. From New York, a trip to Atlantic City or Foxwoods in Connecticut can take up to three hours in a car or bus. Cruises that leave from Manhattan's West Side can take just as long to reach the three-mile limit offshore -- where gambling is unregulated -- before the first cut of the cards and clatter of the slots.

title: Aid for Settlers On West Bank Inflames Arabs
description: The Israeli Government decided today to restore large subsidies for the Jewish settlements in the West Bank, drawing warnings of confrontation from the Palestinians and fears from politicians on both sides that the drive to peace was crumbling.

title: Boss, God, Daddy, Everything
description: Working for a great man has its rewards, and its price, as Emmett Foster learned during his 18 years as personal assistant to Joseph Papp, the founder of the Public Theater. It was a job that so consumed the affection-starved, impressionable Mr. Foster that Papp was more than a mentor to him: he became a symbol of all that was missing from the life of Mr. Foster, a gay Mormon whose mother had married nine times.

title: Joseph Kovago, 83, Hungarian Freedom Fighter
description: Joseph Kovago, political prisoner, Mayor of Budapest during the 1956 uprising, spokesman for Hungarians in exile and, finally, a champion of Hungarian democracy in the post-Soviet era, died on Tuesday at his home in Linwood, N.J. He was 83.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 24 about a collection of Jewish texts in Lithuania misidentified the source of the title of Elijah ben Solomon Zalmen, the scholar known as the Gaon of Vilna. The term ''Gaon'' was a title of respect, later associated with the street on which he lived. He was not named for the street.

title: A Van Delivering Hopes of Good Health
description: It was 10 o'clock on Tuesday morning when Zainab Samura stepped inside the van at 149th Street and Riverside Drive to ask a question. She was worried because her 4-year-old son, John, was just getting over an ear infection, and she wanted to make sure his ears were O.K.

title: Common Currency, Uncommon Images
description: ''Is there space for the Queen's head?''

title: Stocks Slow Their Decline; Dow Up 1.16
description: The good news for Wall Street yesterday was that the Dow Jones industrial average eked out a gain and the broad stock market slowed its rate of decline.

title: POP
description: A Brush With Fame in the 50's

title: Europeans Report Breakthrough in Monetary Union Effort
description: European leaders reached agreement today on how to overcome the biggest remaining obstacle to creating a full monetary union, paving the way to start replacing national currencies like the German mark and French franc a little more than one year from now.

title: Cutler, Gotti's Lawyer, Gets 3-Month Contempt Sentence
description: Bruce Cutler, the flamboyant lawyer best known for his defense of John Gotti, has been suspended from practicing law for three months because of statements he made in defiance of a judge's order during one of Mr. Gotti's trials.

title: Benedict I. Lubell, Tulsa Oil Executive And Arts Patron, 87
description: Benedict I. Lubell, a retired oil executive and a patron of the arts in Tulsa, Okla., died yesterday at his home in Milwaukee. He was 87.

title: POOR EUROPEAN SALES BRING DROP IN ORACLE SHARES
description: The shares of the Oracle Corporation fell yesterday after the company, the second-largest independent software maker, posted disappointing second-quarter sales in Europe. The company reported late on Thursday that its earnings rose 31 percent in the three months ended Nov. 30, in line with most forecasts, as revenue surged 35 percent. But sales in Europe, which account for just more than a third of revenue, fell behind expectations. Analysts said it could take more than six months to solve the European problem. In September the company hired a new European chief to help turn things around. On the Nasdaq stock market yesterday, Oracle shares dropped $3.25, to $44 in trading of 25.2 million shares, making it the most active stock in United States trading. The stock has risen 67 percent this year.

title: Ex-Dean at Berkeley to Head Columbia Journalism School
description: Tom Goldstein, the former dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California at Berkeley and a writer with a long association with New York City, has been named dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

title: A Child Abused, Body and Soul
description: After months of news reports about ''Bastard Out of Carolina,'' it may be difficult to separate the film from the fuss around it. The first feature directed by Anjelica Huston, it tells of a little girl beaten and raped by her stepfather in South Carolina in the 1950's. Made for TNT, the film was abruptly dropped after Ted Turner took a look and declared its content too rough for his network. Plenty of unsettling issues are still swirling around that late-in-the-game decision, questions that touch everything from how Mr. Turner's iron whims might function at Time Warner to what television ought to show in prime time. But ''Bastard Out of Carolina'' (on Showtime tomorrow night at 9) deserves to be judged apart from its volatile history.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Mets ticket prices for 1997 misstated the comparison with the cost of Yankees tickets. For comparable seats the Mets are less expensive, not more.

title: Genentech Chooses A New Chairman
description: Genentech Inc. named a former head of Time Warner Inc., J. Richard Munro, today to become chairman, succeeding a co-founder, Robert Swanson, who steps down at the end of the month. Mr. Munro, 65, who was co-chairman and chief executive of Time Warner in 1989 and 1990 and is now chairman of that company's executive committee, has served on the Genentech board for eight years. Mr. Swanson founded Genentech with Herbert Boyer in 1976. He said Thursday that he had decided to leave the biotechnology company to focus on developing companies. Genentech made an accord last year with its majority owner, Roche Holding A.G., that gives the Swiss drug company the option to buy the 34 percent of Genentech it does not already own by 1999.

title: Excerpts From the President's News Conference at the White House
description: Following are excerpts from the question-and-answer portion of the news conference held today by President Clinton at the White House, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription company:

title: WMX ORDERED TO PAY $91.5 MILLION IN LANDFILL DISPUTE
description: WMX Technologies Inc. said yesterday that a Federal court had ordered it to pay $91.5 million in a landfill contract dispute and that it might take a fourth-quarter charge for the judgment, which would materially hurt earnings. The waste management company said it would appeal the court's decision. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, WMX shares fell 37.5 cents, to $34.25. WMX said the United States District Court in Memphis held that WMX's Chemical Waste Management Inc. unit must compensate the former owners of a hazardous waste landfill in Emelle, Ala., in a dispute that involved a 1978 landfill purchase agreement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ARMCO INC., Pittsburgh, said its chief financial officer, David Harmer, would resign at the end of the month to become president of Jetway Systems in Ogden, Utah, a unit of FMC Corp.

title: Truck Fatality Rate Is Low
description: It may come as a surprise to people who do daily battle with tractor-trailers on state highways, but drivers in New Jersey are among the least likely in the nation to be killed in a crash involving a large truck, a highway safety group reported this week.

title: American Express Denies Seeking Deal
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it was not in talks regarding a possible sale of the company.

title: Oil Leak Is Kept From New York City Water
description: A strange environmental threat -- the tainting of New York City's water supply by oil leaking from a heating system at a Westchester County library into a city water tunnel -- has been averted by a bit of luck and some nifty detective work, above and below ground, state officials said last night.

title: A Final Year For an Icon At Grambling
description: EDDIE ROBINSON will get the one-year extension he campaigned for. In a happy celebration in northern Louisiana, the 77-year-old Robinson won the right yesterday for a 55th season as head football coach at Grambling University.

title: Rein In the Local School Boards
description: I find myself in an unusual position for an elected official. I want less power.

title: U.S. AGENCY SAYS A DEFECT IN 747'S COULD CAUSE BLAST
description: The National Transportation Safety Board says it has identified a fuel-system-pipe problem on Boeing 747's that can ignite explosions, like the one that occurred aboard Trans World Airlines Flight 800 last July, and it issued an urgent recommendation today that airlines be required to take steps to address the problem.

title: MCGRAW-HILL TO CUT 340 JOBS IN HIGHER EDUCATION UNIT
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies plans to cut 340 jobs at its higher education publishing unit in the wake of the purchase of a Times Mirror Company unit in October. Most of the cuts would be in the New York area, where 85 positions would be lost. The company, which is based in New York, plans to complete the cuts by September 1997. The staff reductions include 130 job cuts in Iowa and Illinois that the company announced last month.

title: Bulls Show How Little Trouble They're In
description: If the Chicago Bulls are in trouble, plenty of teams would like to join them.

title: Bulls Remind Nets They're Really the Nets
description: They were side by side, with the slim Kerry Kittles looking like another pinstripe on Michael Jordan's uniform. Kittles stuck to Jordan, but in a polite way.

title: NIPPON SANSO TO CLOSE U.S. THERMOS UNIT AND CUT JOBS
description: The Nippon Sanso Corporation of Japan said yesterday that it was closing its Thermos Company unit in the United States and a subsidiary in the Netherlands to consolidate its household products divisions. Nippon Sanso would dismiss 400 workers at a Thermos plant in Freeport, Ill., where the unit manufactures insulated bottles, ice chests and barbecue grills. Nippon Sanso said it would discontinue its line of barbecue grills because of increased competition from the Sunbeam Corporation and other companies. Nippon Sanso U.S.A., based in Schaumburg, Ill., will take over the manufacturing operations of other Thermos brand items and household products.

title: Mandela Broadens Limits For Apartheid-Era Amnesty
description: President Nelson Mandela agreed today to further expand the umbrella of amnesty to include even those who tried to use a bombing campaign to disrupt South Africa's first nonracial elections.

title: Larry Gates, 81, Actor of Stage and Screen
description: Larry Gates, a character actor with a 50-year career in theater, films and television, died Thursday at a hospital in Sharon, Conn. He was 81 and lived in Cornwall, Conn.

title: Traveling Troubleshooter Is Ready to Settle Down, at the U.N.: William Blaine Richardson
description: If Bill Richardson could sing, this bulky Congressman from northern New Mexico and self-described ''under secretary for thugs,'' could star in a musical parody of Americans abroad: ''If it's Tuesday, it must be Pyongyang.''

title: Woman Ahead of Her Time As a 19th-Century Rabbi
description: Feminist aspirations are pinned to obscure religious history in the new musical that is ushering in the 81st season of the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Rwandans Won't Go Home

title: Wal-Mart Should Consider Another Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a major mathematical proof achieved by a computer misstated the given name and affiliation of a researcher who worked on the problem before his death. He was Dr. Alfred Tarski, not Albert; he was at the University of California at Berkeley, not at Stanford.

title: Sayonara to Mondale, the Custom-Made Envoy
description: After three years of being taken so seriously by people here that they never laughed at his jokes, Ambassador Walter F. Mondale says wryly that he is heading home to a land where people will recognize his punchlines.

title: No Accord Soon on Treaty For Data Base Copyrights
description: The chances of early agreement on a much-disputed proposal for an international treaty to provide powerful copyright protection for computerized data bases evaporated yesterday when the chief American negotiator acknowledged that many countries needed more time for debate.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Mezzo More Comfortable

title: Ovitz Still Has Grip On Hollywood Power
description: After a turbulent 14 months as the company's No. 2 executive, Michael Ovitz is leaving the Walt Disney Company somewhat humbled and fallen from grace.

title: Often-Criticized Bridge Agency Votes to Increase the Only Toll on L.I.
description: In the world of bridges, the Nassau County Bridge Authority, whose sole purpose is to operate a drawbridge here, is one of a kind.

title: Unabom Case Will Return To New Jersey For 2d Trial
description: A Federal judge here has rejected an attempt by lawyers for Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in the Unabom case, to consolidate all the charges in California, thus laying the groundwork for a second murder trial in Newark.

title: Kennedy School Revives a Tradition, With a New Look
description: The on-again, off-again love affair between Cambridge and Washington is on again.

title: G.M. Recalls Cavalier Sedans in Japan
description: The General Motors Corporation has recalled three-quarters of the cars that the Toyota Motor Company sold for G.M. in Japan under Toyota nameplates. Owners of the Cavalier sedans have complained that the cars stall in Japan's stop-and-go traffic, G.M. said.

title: German Union Halts Talks in Hamburg
description: The German union IG Metall said yesterday that it had broken off talks with employers in Hamburg after failing to reach a compromise on wage terms and sick pay for workers in the car, engineering and metals industries.

title: Red Sox Fans Feel a Sense of Betrayal
description: At least long-suffering Red Sox fans can take solace in the fact that Roger Clemens didn't head off to New York.

title: Heisman Hype Reaches an End
description: Danny Wuerffel has been the post-season awards champion so far, winning the Maxwell, O'Brien and Johnny Unitas awards. Tonight, the all-America quarterback from Florida and three other finalists find out who wins college football's biggest prize -- the Heisman Trophy.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Salesman For Unity Kofi Atta Annan
description: A year ago, Kofi Annan flew to the war-battered capital of Bosnia to preside as the United Nations handed over a foundering peacekeeping mission to NATO.

title: Struggles With the Past
description: Nelson Mandela agreed to expand an amnesty to those who planned a bombing campaign to disrupt South Africa's first nonracial elections.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about William Parsons, a retired senior partner in Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy and past chairman of Teachers College, Columbia University, misstated his relationship to the New York Blood Center. He was its vice chairman at his death, not a former vice chairman.

title: Leave Heating Oil To the Private Sector
description: To the Editor:

title: BELL ATLANTIC AND NYNEX END DEAL WITH CAI WIRELESS
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation said yesterday that they were suspending a business agreement with CAI Wireless Systems Inc. that was aimed at helping them enter the video business. CAI will have the option of buying back a $100 million investment that the regional phone companies made in its stock and debt securities when the pact was formed in 1995. The move followed reports last week that Bell Atlantic, Nynex and Pacific Telesis Group were taking steps to shut down Tele-TV, an interactive television venture that was to use CAI technology to deliver programming. On the Nasdaq stock market in afternoon trading, CAI stock plunged 19 percent, falling 31.25 cents, to $1.3125 a share.

title: Wal-Mart Should Consider Another Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Fred Kaplan, the scholar and biographer who was wounded in a subway stabbing in Manhattan, misattributed a quotation from one of the police officers who arrested two suspects in the case. In noting that a locked door had kept the officers, in one subway car, from immediately coming to the aid of the victims in the next car, it was Officer John Kenny, not Officer Antonio Esparra, who said: ''That was the worst part of it. Having a victim's wife scream for help and not being able to do anything about it is probably one of the worst feelings you could ever experience.''

title: Tide of Rwanda Refugees Flows Back to Tanzania Camps
description: Tanzanian troops assigned to move tens of thousands of Rwandan refugees homeward ended up leading them back to their refugee camps in western Tanzania today, a day after the refugees had fled into the bush in a panicky attempt to avoid being sent back to Rwanda.

title: Navratilova to Coach 1997 Fed Cup Team
description: The mission for 1997 was to replace BILLIE JEAN KING, the victorious but departing coach of the 1996 Fed Cup team, and from a cast of nominees that originally included CHRIS EVERT and TRACY AUSTIN, MARTINA NAVRATILOVA stepped forward yesterday and took the one-year assignment.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing

title: Germans Plan Combat Troops Outside NATO, A Postwar First
description: Five years after it refused to send troops to join the American-led coalition in the Persian Gulf war, the German Parliament today approved the deployment of 2,000 peacekeeping soldiers in Bosnia. It is the first deployment of German combat-ready ground troops outside NATO borders since World War II.

title: Sentenced for Loan Sharking
description: A 58-year-old Montville man who pleaded guilty in August to running a loan sharking operation that charged borrowers an annual interest rate of as much as 264 percent was sentenced yesterday to 6 years and 10 months in prison and a $40,000 fine, prosecutors said. Nicholas F. Mitarotonda admitted in court that he knew that people acting in his behalf had issued violent threats against one borrower whose payment was late, said Frederick R. Kessler, an assistant United States attorney.

title: A Silver Lining of Sorts
description: Even on the sunniest days, the New Linden Car Wash typically gets only about a third of the 300 cars that rolled in out of the rain on Thursday. ''We're busier now in the rain than I am in the sun,'' Jerry Schneider, owner of the car wash, said yesterday, when business was still booming.

title: Welfare Plan Wins Approval, Bringing $2.4 Billion to State
description: The Federal Government approved New York State's proposed welfare plan today, making the state eligible for its share of the money provided under the new Federal welfare law.

title: Eulace Peacock Dies at 82; Track Star Was Owens Rival
description: Eulace Peacock, one of the world's leading sprinters and long jumpers in the decade before World War II and Jesse Owens's major rival, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Nursing Home in Yonkers. He was 82.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a White House ceremony marking International Human Rights Day misstated the timing of comments by Hillary Rodham Clinton that indirectly criticized China's human rights record. Mrs. Clinton made the comments at an international women's conference in Beijing last year, not at the White House this week.

title: MARATHON TO SELL ALASKAN OIL INTERESTS TO FORCENERGY
description: The Marathon Oil Company agreed yesterday to sell its interests in three producing crude-oil fields and a pipeline company in Alaska to Forcenergy Inc. for $128.2 million. Marathon, a unit of the USX Corporation of Pittsburgh, said the sale would allow it to focus on its natural gas business in Alaska. The oil interests, in Cook Inlet and Prudhoe Bay, would cost $113.8 million. Marathon's 30 percent interest in the Cook Inlet Pipeline Company would cost $14.4 million, including the assumption of about $6.7 million in debt. Forcenergy explores for and produces oil and natural gas. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, its shares rose $4.125, to $34.25.

title: St. John's a Soccer Game Away From First Title
description: Move over, Chris Mullin. Jesse Van Saun became an overnight legend today at St. John's.

title: Still Woman, Still Roaring
description: ''Here's something I wrote 25 years ago,'' Helen Reddy brusquely announced as she introduced her signature song, ''I Am Woman,'' at Rainbow and Stars. The Australian singer sped through a pop-jazz rendition of her well-known feminist anthem that was so crisply matter-of-fact one couldn't tell how she felt about it a quarter of a century after its creation.

title: Bank of Spain Cuts Rate Again
description: Cheered by tame inflation, the Bank of Spain sanctioned its seventh interest rate cut of the year yesterday. The central bank cut its key money rate half a percentage point, to 6.25 percent from 6.75 percent, at its regular repurchase tender for central bank certificates. (Reuters)

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7

title: No Headline
description: ''A year ago, the European view was that the project was dead. All of a sudden last summer, people began to talk about it as almost inevitable.''

title: The Quietest Bidder Gets Its Man
description: Just what did the Toronto Blue Jays get for the record $8.25 million a year they expended yesterday for Roger Clemens? A high-ranking official of one club said they got a right-handed pitcher whose medical record shows he has a loose shoulder, a rotator cuff tear and a left knee that should have been operated on by now.

title: GHANAIAN CHOSEN TO HEAD THE U.N., ENDING STANDOFF
description: Weeks of confrontation between the United States and France over who will be the next Secretary General of the United Nations ended today when the Security Council chose Kofi Annan of Ghana for the job.

title: Richter's Shutout Boosts Rangers
description: The Buffalo Sabres entered tonight's game against the Rangers in a positive frame of mind, thanks to an emotional overtime victory against Montreal in their previous game. For the Rangers, there was more a sense of anxiety after a waxing at the hands of the rival Islanders two nights earlier.

title: Remarks From Nominee for Commerce Secretary
description: Following is a transcript of William M. Daley's remarks today after being chosen as Commerce Secretary, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a transcription company:

title: Santa Is Flexible
description: To the Editor:

title: A Desire to Prove Everyone Wrong May Motivate Jets
description: It is a game that caps an emotional week of bad vibrations, bad news and bad memories for Coach Rich Kotite as the Jets start to wind up their horrible season with a meeting today with the Philadelphia Eagles, who come into Giants Stadium with playoff hopes in their grasp.

title: Will Rent Reform Hurt or Help Middle Class?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Patient Nominee: William Michael Daley
description: The appointment of William M. Daley to President Clinton's Cabinet was supposed to have been a done deal four years ago, or at least that was the way people around here saw it.

title: Will Rent Reform Hurt or Help Middle Class?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lamoriello Gets Post
description: USA Hockey named the Devils' president and general manager, LOU LAMORIELLO, as general manager of the 1998 United States Olympic hockey team. The 1998 Games in Nagano, Japan, will allow National Hockey League players to compete for the first time.

title: A Second-Term Cabinet
description: After letting her dangle for five weeks, President Clinton announced yesterday that he had invited Janet Reno to stay on as Attorney General. Mr. Clinton also announced the names of several other Cabinet members and senior advisers who will help guide him through a second term, but in political terms, Ms. Reno's reappointment was the most important.

title: A New Leader for the United Nations
description: After months of deadlock and aggravation over the selection of a new Secretary General for the United Nations, the Security Council has settled on a fine choice, Kofi Annan of Ghana. Mr. Annan, who heads the U.N.'s peacekeeping operations, is a sophisticated and mild-mannered man with a reputation for competence. His department is one of the better-run offices in the U.N. Part of his job has been to negotiate agreements for the use of U.N. peacekeepers, and those who have negotiated with him praise his skills.

title: Boutros-Ghali Hails Man Who Will Succeed Him
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali spent a routine morning in his office today. He had only one appointment, with Giancarlo Aragona, Secretary General of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which lasted 45 minutes. Otherwise he was occupied with meetings with staff members.

title: On Our Mean Streets, Pedestrians vs. Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Franklin D. Raines: Director of the Office of Management and Budget
description: Announcing today that he had reappointed Franklin D. Raines as director of the Office of Management and Budget, President Clinton noted that the post is ''often the biggest headache in town.''

title: Swiss Acknowledge Profiting From Nazi Gold
description: Under pressure to explain its financial dealings with Nazi Germany, the Swiss National Bank publicly acknowledged today that it had made a profit on its wartime dealings in gold bullion with the German central bank. And for the first time, it gave an estimate of its gains: 20 million Swiss francs.

title: Major Presidential Appointments
description: WILLIAM M. DALEY, Secretary of Commerce. A member of Chicago's powerful Democratic political family, he is comfortable working with Republican business executives.

title: Deer Alert Is Issued
description: For deer, the holiday season is a time for mating and moving about, and, quite possibly, being accidentally struck by drivers while crossing the road. From October 1995 to October 1996, removal crews picked up 16,000 deer carcasses on New Jersey roads, said Dave Brown, a spokesman for the state Department of Transportation. Yesterday, the department requested that drivers who spot a dead deer notify the police immediately.

title: Clinton Suggests Review of Counsel Law
description: President Clinton, whose Administration has been the focus of investigations by four independent counsels, suggested today that the law should be reassessed with an eye toward limiting the use of special prosecutors.

title: Fuel Tank Vapors Cited As Problem 30 Years Ago
description: On Dec. 8, 1963, lightning ignited fuel vapors in the tanks of a Pan Am Boeing 707 circling over Elkton, Md. The plane exploded, killing 81 people.

title: Robert E. Rubin -- Treasury Secretary
description: From the start of the scramble to assemble key economic players for Bill Clinton's second term, there was no mystery about who would serve, in the President's words today, as ''the captain of the team.''

title: Will Rent Reform Hurt or Help Middle Class?
description: To the Editor:

title: Skandia to Review Bid For Mortgage Company
description: The Skandia Insurance Company, Sweden's leading insurer, said yesterday that it would review its $3 billion stock offer for Stadshypotek after Svenska Handelsbanken A.B., Scandinavia's largest bank, made an all-cash offer for the mortgage company. Analysts are doubtful that Skandia can afford to beat Handelsbanken's bid of 23 billion kronor in Sweden's largest all-cash bid ever, which has already won the support of Stadshypotek's largest shareholder, the Government. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Mickey Mouse Clubbed
description: When the history of greed, excess and abuse of power in late-20th-century American business is written, perhaps its most telling chapter will begin in the unpretentious suburban San Fernando Valley town of Van Nuys, Calif. It was from Birmingham High there that both Michael Milken and Michael Ovitz went out into the world to seek their fortunes in 1964.

title: Number Becoming Citizens Drops Sharply in New York
description: Even as immigrants seek citizenship at a record pace, the number who are being naturalized in New York City, one of the nation's immigrant meccas, has dropped precipitously since October.

title: Leave Heating Oil To the Private Sector
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Head Tells Of Elf's Work As Paris Agent
description: PARIS  A former head of Elf Aquitaine has been quoted as saying that the French oil giant functioned for decades as a secret arm of the French state, making and breaking African regimes, carrying out huge bribery operations and providing cover for French covert operations in petroleum-producing nations,

title: Leave Heating Oil To the Private Sector
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Detectives Charged With Larceny
description: Investigators who suspected a Bronx detective of corruption set up a sting operation by planting cash in a car on a Bronx street, and yesterday they charged him and another detective with taking the bait and stealing the money.

title: Prosecutors Give Details of Case Charging Lopez As Industrial Spy
description: German prosecutors gave details yesterday of the charges against Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the former General Motors executive who left for Volkswagen A.G. and who was indicted this week.

title: N.F.L. Settles With Cowboys
description: The Dallas Cowboys and the National Football League dropped Federal lawsuits against each other yesterday, thereby ending their dispute over the signing of Texas Stadium sponsors such as Nike and Pepsi by the Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones.

title: Amelia Agostino del Rio, 100, Professor, Poet and Playwright
description: Amelia Agostino del Rio, a professor, author and longtime head of the Spanish department at Barnard College, died on Wednesday in Spring Lake, N.J., where she lived. She was 100.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS BUYS 9% STAKE IN INTERLINK COMPUTER
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired a 9 percent stake in the computer networking concern Interlink Computer Sciences Inc. for an undisclosed amount. The news sent Interlink stock up $3.9375, or 34 percent, to close at $15.625 a share, on the Nasdaq stock market, while Cisco's shares fell $1, to $64.75. The stock purchase is part of an agreement under which the two companies will jointly develop and market Cisco's Internetworking Operating System, or IOS, a networking software for MVS mainframe computers. Cisco also purchased product licenses for Interlink's TCP access software.

title: Sifted, Gathered, Boxed and Ribbon-Ready
description: No archive has been left uncombed for this year's assortment of boxed sets geared for holiday gift giving. Call it the year of obscurity: record companies seem to be trying to appeal to the archivist in every fan. Here are three dozen choices that New York Times critics find noteworthy. Prices are suggested retail.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: You Were Right in Saying Some People Make You Sick
description: WINTER can give you a cold because it forces you indoors with coughers, sneezers and wheezers. Toddlers can give you a cold because they are the original Germs ''R'' Us. But can going postal with the boss or fretting about marriage give a person a post-nasal drip?

title: Using Force as a Tourniquet
description: LAST MONTH, TO THE WORLD'S ASTONISHment, 600,000 tired and hungry Hutus emerged from the Zairian countryside and trekked back to Rwanda after a two-year exile. The migration aborted the deployment of a 15,000-strong international force about to embark for Rwanda to rescue these very refugees. Yet this deployment, though canceled, achieved its mission. According to some reports, news of the troops' imminent arrival may have weakened the morale of the Hutu militia who had held the refugees hostage and emboldened the refugees to defy the militia and take their chances on returning home.

title: Sifted, Gathered, Boxed and Ribbon-Ready
description: ANTONIO CARLOS JOBIM: 'THE MAN FROM IPANEMA'

title: The Pumps Resume in Iraq
description: Six years after his army was roundly defeated and thrown out of Kuwait, Saddam Hussein proclaimed that Iraq had returned ''to the international market'' in oil exports. Indeed, Iraq began to pump oil abroad for the first time since the war last week, via a pipeline through Turkey. But its output remains limited to $2 billion worth during the next six months. The United Nations set that limit as a way to let Iraq buy food, medicine and other civilian needs while it remains under economic sanctions.

title: Sifted, Gathered, Boxed and Ribbon-Ready
description: No archive has been left uncombed for this year's assortment of boxed sets geared for holiday gift giving. Call it the year of obscurity: record companies seem to be trying to appeal to the archivist in every fan. Here are three dozen choices that New York Times critics find noteworthy. Prices are suggested retail.

title: Tenants Irked At Eviction By Seminary
description: With enrollment surging 40 percent in the last five years, to 650 students from about 450, the Jewish Theological Seminary is now faced with a shortage of housing, even after taking such steps as converting dining rooms to dorm rooms.

title: The Beat's Long Journey Out of Africa To America
description: Why is a pair of worn black tap shoes spotlighted in a vitrine in a dimly lighted tribal-art gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art? Unexpected though the shoes may be, they provide a contemporary note for ''Enduring Rhythms: African Musical Instruments and the Americas,'' an exhibition of 80 instruments at the museum through March 30. Tap shoes translate into an American idiom the centuries-old rhythms of African bells that musicologists now recognize as basic to all sub-Saharan music.

title: BENEFITS
description: New York Youth Symphony

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Opulent, Ravishing And Loud
description: WITH his unrestrained vision of opulence, Christian Dior created the New Look in Paris, dominating fashion in the decade after World War II. Last Monday, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 900 dinner guests at the Costume Institute's ball, inaugurating its Dior exhibition, looked pretty opulent, too.

title: Jets Look Promising, Then Look Like Jets
description: Maybe it took the final straw the possibility of a national television audience laughing at them -- but the Jets, yes, the Jets, almost produced a spectacular upset today over a stunned Philadelphia Eagles team that held its own playoff fate.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: Let's hope that in her search for heroes, the young girl on your cover looks beyond this list of way too many models, entertainers and tragic victims (and way too few women of substance, especially living ones -- no scientists, doctors, Nobel Prize winners, philosophers or mathematicians). A girl could be forgiven for doubting that there ever was a women's movement.

title: A Luddite's High-Tech Plea
description: The Unabomber tried to justify his 18-year bombing campaign as an attempt to slow the march of technology blindly crushing man's freedom. The suspect in the case, Theodore J. Kaczynski, got a flavor of that technology last week when he was arraigned in Newark, N.J., via television while he sat in the public defender's library in Sacramento, Calif.

title: . . . and How to Spend It.
description: Thinking of buying your loved one the $350 sterling silver Slinky they're selling at Neiman-Marcus or the $850 Montblanc pen introduced two months ago? You'd better get a move on for the Slinky (going fast), and forget about the pen (sold out). Scratch the $400 gray flannel Prada stretch pants and the $4,000 Hermes Kelly bag off your list too (also sold out). Just about any luxury good (translation: hideously expensive) is selling these days.

title: Mexican, With a Lightly Spicy Touch
description: MEXICAN restaurants still aren't really plentiful in Connecticut, but a new one, Miguel's, has recently opened in Woodbury. An outpost of Casa Miguel in Westchester County, Miguel's specializes in Southwest and Tex/Mex cooking.

title: With Hollies, the Facts of Life Cannot Be Ignored
description: Holly, like the Christmas tree, owes its origins as holiday ornamentation to old pagan rites. This should come as no surprise.

title: Correction
description: A review on Nov. 24, about ''Andrew Wyeth: A Secret Life,'' by Richard Meryman, referred incompletely to sales representatives for the artist Andrew Wyeth. He is represented by Frank E. Fowler of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., in addition to Nicholas Wyeth of New York.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: New Coat for a Duck

title: Underground Operation
description: IT was no longer night and not yet morning on the E train and the car was half full of tenants. At a buck-fifty, it's the cheapest room in town. Two men slept in blankets, their packs folded between their legs.

title: Beijing's Man in Hong Kong
description: After a ritual orchestrated by Beijing, China named Tung Chee-hwa, a Hong Kong shipping tycoon known for his toughness and impatience with democratic governance, to administer the territory when British colonial rule ends next July 1. As the territory's first Chinese chief executive, he will preside over the dismantling of its democratic institutions, including the Legislative Council and other elected councils. EDWARD A. GARGAN

title: Carla P. Hoke And Max Miller
description: Carla Prescott Hoke and Max Miller were married last evening by David N. Dinkins, the former Mayor of New York. The ceremony took place in a private Manhattan loft.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: I was intrigued by the confident young girl on your cover but disappointed to discover that the ''heroines'' in your issue were not the strong and confident role models I expected to find. They were, indeed, objects of ''worship.''

title: Daylight
description: Sylvester Stallone, Amy Brenneman, Stan Shaw, Viggo Mortensen, Claire Bloom

title: A Gallery Season Closing Down in Kent
description: AFTER next weekend, the railroad station and caboose, the two parts of Jacques Kaplan's Paris-New York-Kent Gallery, will close for the winter. But the hard freeze hasn't settled in yet in Kent, and the season is going out with energy and high spirits.

title: Training Brokers for Financial Planning
description: THE needs of today's investor are changing, and so, too, is the brokerage industry. Individuals putting children through college, caring for elderly parents and planning for their retirements -- sometimes all at once -- are seeking comprehensive financial advice.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: The special issue ''Heroine Worship'' (Nov. 24) was delightful -- especially Charles Kuralt's funny and touching memoir of Eleanor Roosevelt and Jessye Norman's of Marian Anderson. Diane Johnson's Audrey Hepburn was extraordinarily insightful -- yes, she was valued. I met her when I had a small part in the TV version of Anatole Litvak's ''Mayerling,'' in which Hepburn starred. On the set (and this was before tape; the entire two-hour production was live), her concentration was awesome. That the camera found her breathtaking had much to do, I think, with her inner qualities, and the sense of poetry that infused every moment. Her very individual speech was delicious. Like everyone else, I loved and admired her.

title: M.S. Viteles, 98, Industrial Psychologist, Dies
description: Dr. Morris S. Viteles, who helped shape the way industrial psychology is taught and practiced by writing the first modern textbook in the field and setting up the first vocational counseling center at a university, died on Dec. 7 at the Medford Leas retirement home in Medford, N.J., where he lived. He was 98.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: What better role model could there be than the astronaut Shannon Lucid? By focusing on mathematics and science, women can have engrossing careers. And who knows? The best and brightest can even shoot for the moon -- the real one.

title: From Ukraine, With Cab Fare And Hope, But Not Much Else
description: For a week after winning green cards in a United States immigration lottery, Boris and Luba Umansky of Zaporozhe, Ukraine, agonized over their good fortune. ''I could not eat,'' Mr. Umansky said. ''I could not sleep. To go, not to go. To stay, not to stay. We didn't know what to do.''

title: Couples
description: CAROLINA MOON

title: At the Mohegan Tables: A Brief Guide
description: ESTHETES can revel in the ornamentation of the new Mohegan Sun casino, and philosophers may debate the direction of civilization. But everyone else who goes to Uncasville will probably want to know about the more practical realities.

Call it the year of obscurity: record companies seem to be trying to appeal to the archivist in every fan. Here are three dozen choices that New York Times critics find noteworthy. title: Speculative Offices End 7-Year Construction Drought
description: THE latest sign of a gradual improvement in New Jersey's office market is the willingness of developers to start new projects, ending a seven-year drought in speculative construction.

title: Nuisance Charges Raise Suspicions At Indian Center
description: Last spring, someone complained that the American Indian Community House was selling food without a permit. Then about six weeks ago, the group was accused of failing to collect state sales taxes. And a few days later, Federal agents arrived with a complaint that tobacco was being sold without a permit.

title: How to Be Sure the People's Voice Comes In Loud and Clear
description: The 1996 election season is over, and like it or not, the 1997 elections are about to begin in New Jersey. We're one of only two states (Virginia is the other) that holds statewide elections in the year after Presidential elections. And for us, it is the big one! We elect a Governor and the entire Legislature.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: Brubach tells us that the women in your issue are significant for what they have come to stand for to young girls like 11-year-old Kate Axelrod whose identities are in ''the formative stages'' and to ''women of all ages who tend to regard themselves as works in progress.''

title: Trouble Spots On the Road
description: A look at trouble spots you can expect to encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of the State Department of Transportation.

title: A Bitter Fight Rages Over Files and a Famous Name
description: For 20 years, William Moses Kunstler, the shaman and showman lawyer of the radical left, started his mornings by climbing upstairs to the second floor of his Greenwich Village brownstone, taking coffee to the bedside of his wife, Margaret Ratner. No one disputes that Mr. Kunstler adored Ms. Ratner, a fastidiously private woman 25 years his junior who is the mother of two of his four daughters and a civil rights lawyer.

title: Adventure Travel Offers a Tonic for the Ailing
description: FEW people like to ponder their inevitable appointment with the Grim Reaper, but those who believe their day may be drawing near are fast becoming big clients of the adventure-travel industry.

title: The Management of Pests Gets Organized
description: PEST control is coming under increasing scrutiny. Many home gardeners, as well as several produce growers, are becoming more and more reluctant to use chemicals. Witness the increase of ''organically-grown'' sections in supermarkets.

title: And Getting the Relics Fixed? There's Only One Godfather
description: There is no Checker in the Smithsonian Institution, and there will probably never be any mention of Raffaele Pepe. But owners of the bulbous cars that were once synonymous with yellow cabs say the names of the vehicle and the mechanic go together like Roy Rogers and Trigger.

title: Cuban Family Seeks Foothold in Land of Opportunity
description: Back in Cuba, they were educated professionals. Ilia Lerma taught English, and her husband, Pablo Jose Diaz, taught chemistry. As a refugee in New York, she learned culinary skills, hoping they would help her get work. Now, the couple would be happy with any full-time jobs they can find.

title: Happy in Camelot, Better Known as Summit
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Boat Tour of Italian Villas

title: Mack Back From Japan
description: The Boston Red Sox agreed yesterday to a one-year, $1.85 million contract with outfielder SHANE MACK, 33, who spent the last two seasons with Yomiuri of Japan's Central League. Mack, who was with Minnesota from 1990-94, hit .293 last season with 22 homers and 75 runs batted in. (AP)

title: Experts Say Refinements Are Needed In the Polls
description: Although most of the final national polls before last month's Presidential election came fairly close to the actual vote, the polls as a group somewhat underestimated Bob Dole's electoral strength, leading some polling experts to give the polls a good rather than an excellent grade this year.

title: Cry Only for What Peron Really Wore
description: IF you believe the publicity machine for the forthcoming film ''Evita,'' Eva Peron, the first lady of Argentina, was fabulously chic. She wore fashionable furs, Dior's New Look, Ferragamo's shoes, Bulgari's jewels. She was the Wallis Simpson of South America, the Jackie Onassis of Buenos Aires.

title: Co-op Building Put Up by Artists, for Money's Sake
description: BUILT from 1916 to 1919, 2 West 67th Street marked a turning point, as West 67th Street changed from a street of art into one of comfortable wealth. Now the co-op, one of the oldest in New York, is trying to reverse changes to the building made over decades.

title: Financial Powerhouse Takes Aim at Bad Credit Risks
description: HENRY FORD famously insisted that buyers could have any color of car they wanted, as long as it was black. But he was just as reluctant to offer them credit. Only in 1923, two decades after he began selling cars, did he begin to experiment, cautiously, with financing.

title: A Harsh Story Finally Avoids a Harsh Fate
description: Seldom has so provocative a title also been so prophetic. ''Bastard Out of Carolina,'' the film adaptation of Dorothy Allison's acclaimed novel about a girl who is physically and sexually abused by her stepfather, will be shown tonight at 9 as an original Showtime production, but only after a wayward four-year journey from the printed page to cable television.

title: Just I and Just II
description: My Father's WarBy Adriaan van Dis.Translated by Claire Nicolas White.261 pp. New York:The New Press. $23.

title: Queens Youth Is Beaten in Subway Station
description: A Queens teen-ager was in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday after he was beaten with a baseball bat by five youths on the platform of a Greenpoint subway station, the police said.

title: Hazardous Cargo
description: Your clients are waiting for your presentation. Just a minute, you say, as you open your briefcase to get a report. But as you grab the papers, out pops a (blank) from your briefcase. Wow, are you embarrassed. Fill in the blank. What kind of weird stuff do you or your co-workers keep in briefcases? And has anyone else ever found out? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Salute to Seven Municipal Heroes, Formerly Unsung
description: THE report stung. The way the Transit Authority hired and trained bus drivers was so flawed, according to a 1990 in-house investigation, that it jeopardized ''the safety of bus riders as well as pedestrians.'' Between 1985 and 1988, accidents at the Department of Buses had soared 30 percent, to nearly 9,700 collisions in a year.

title: STATES NEGLECTING POLLUTION RULES, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: Worried that some state governments are neglecting Federal environmental laws, the Clinton Administration is mounting detailed investigations of several states' performance, according to senior Administration officials.

title: In Spanish, It's Another Story
description: ONE Friday early this month, ABC, CBS and NBC all began their nightly newscasts with the same story: the testimony of Nicole Brown Simpson's mother at the latest O. J. Simpson trial.

title: The Gastronomical Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: Zodiac Case Suspect Remains an Enigma
description: For six years, New York City detectives faced what seemed like an impenetrable question: Who is the Zodiac killer? Now, six months after the authorities charged Heriberto Seda in the killings and shootings that terrorized the city in 1990 and 1993, the case has shifted to perhaps an even more inscrutable one: who is Heriberto Seda?

title: Airline Tax Expiring; Fares May Go Down
description: Travelers may see a drop in air fares when the 10 percent Federal tax on domestic fares expires at the end of the year.

title: Only 4 Left: Countdown For Checkers
description: Some 10 to 12 hours a day, 5 to 6 days a week, for 18 years, the front seat of Earl Johnson's Checker cab has reflected his life. He keeps his lunch and a telephone on the front floorboard, his briefcase by his side, his mail wedged beside the meter . Dozens of business cards collected from passengers are held by rubber bands to the visors.

title: Offer Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Show That Sees Beauty in Everything
description: IS it art? The question that once only Philistines dared ask is currently serving as the title of a relentlessly educational show at the Katonah Museum of Art here.

title: Do I Hear $5,000 For That Dinosaur Egg?
description: Eons from the usual array of Christmas gifts, items at an Upper East Side auction house beckoned shoppers of oddly discriminating tastes. Among a menagerie of fossils at the ''Natural History'' auction were dinosaur eggs and the day's biggest hit, a 5-foot-long, 41-inch wide Triceratops skull that sold for $65,000.

title: Serbian Student Movement Isn't Violent
description: To the Editor:

title: Novelist's Public Death Creates Chicago Mystery
description: High above the streets of the city and the sounds of children laughing and the Salvation Army bells ringing, a man's body dangled from a 14th-story window of a Loop office building here a week ago. A noose was wrapped around the neck.

title: U.S. Accuses Suffolk Police Of Violating Bias Laws
description: Black and Hispanic police officers in Suffolk County have repeatedly endured racial and ethnic discrimination on the job and routinely been denied promotions, the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has concluded.

title: Key West Seminar
description: To the Editor: Mireya Navarro's What's Doing in Key West (Oct. 27) was a model of succinct information but it was a pity there wasn't room for what, to my mind, is Key West's most important annual event, the Key West Literary Seminar, now in its 15th year.

title: Westchester's Movable Chic
description: Baronial houses and vast estates rise proudly amid rolling hills here. Chief executives, entertainers and gray-suited Wall Streeters live in homes that command between $500,000 and $10 million. Schools are good, land is plentiful, and the address has a cachet rivaled by only a handful of other Westchester communities.

title: Youthful Newspaper Tradition Is Ending
description: Making his rounds in the darkness, Eric Anderson, 17, walked up the steps of the Harringtons' house on Bancroft Street and placed the morning paper in the mailbox.

title: Communities Squabble Over Water Charges
description: SEVERAL central Westchester communities have recently thrown down the gauntlet in unrelated disputes over water bills. The disagreements reflect the complicated relationship between some water districts and some municipalities, which can be as bewildering as the plumbing underneath the kitchen sink.

title: Correction
description: A picture on Dec. 1 with an article about the Wakkerstroom Marsh in South Africa was published in error. It showed a northern bald ibis. The species of ibis found in the area is a southern bald ibis, which has iridescent green rather than greenish-black plumage; it does not have a shaggy mane of black feathers.

title: From Olympia & York Bankruptcy, a New Company
description: THE remains of Olympia & York's United States operations emerged from bankruptcy recently, marking a symbolic end to the wild, speculative era of the 1980's that was followed by the crash of the early 1990's.

title: South Africa Begins To Memorialize Its Past
description: WHEN it comes to monuments, South Africa has little to show off. The skyline of Johannesburg is dominated by two microwave towers. Pretoria, the capital, is a bit prettier, but it's no Washington.

title: Lefrak City: Racial Redux With a Twist
description: They sat around a large table discussing a future of peaceful coexistence: a rabbi from Tashkent, two Uzbeki Jews, a Catholic businessman, a black American who converted to Islam, a Guinean Muslim and two Argentines.

title: Jets Could Still Lose No. 1 Pick
description: ONLY the Jets, who have turned losing into an art form, might still find a way to lose what has seemed their birthright since the beginning of their sad season -- the No. 1 choice in the 1997 National Football League draft of college livestock.

title: Alien Nation
description: BECOMING NATIVE TO THIS PLACEBy Wes Jackson.121 pp. Washington:Counterpoint. Paper, $12.50.

title: Correction
description: A recipe for braised rabbit in the food column on Nov. 17 gave incomplete instructions. A corrected version follows.

title: Out, Out, Shakespeare . . . In, In, More Health and Beauty Aids
description: The stretch of Broadway between Zabar's at 80th Street and Barnes & Noble at 82d is one of the most heavily traveled in Manhattan, so when Shakespeare & Company announced it was closing, competition was fierce for the soon-to-be-vacant two-story site at the southwest corner of 81st.

title: Betting Against The Fed? Good Luck
description: Don't fight the Fed.

title: DIARY
description: LEAVING DISNEY

title: Daring to Wear Fur In Spite of Protests
description: ALLA ZELIKOVSKY walks to work on Fifth Avenue every day in a long, silky mink coat. ''I came all the way from Russia 23 years ago,'' said Mrs. Zelikovsky, a skin specialist at Elizabeth Arden, ''and I won't be told what to do.''

title: Cast of Characters Is Set For Clinton's Second-Term
description: President Clinton answered most of the remaining questions last week about whom he will work with in his second term. The clear winner: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, whose current position of great influence was bolstered by the naming of allies to other economic posts.

title: Duke's Swarm Spoils Housewarming Party
description: Today was supposed to be a coming-out party for Villanova and its freshman sensation, Tim Thomas. It was a big game, the Wildcats' first of the season. It was being played at the new Core States Center and it was shown on national television.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FLICKERING SHADOWSBy Kwadwo Agymah Kamau.Coffee House, $21.95.

title: Wheatley's Problems With Giants Did Not Start at Michigan
description: H sees Tyrone Wheatley run on television and he notices right away there is a hitch in Wheatley's giddyup. In his office, hundreds of miles away at the University of Michigan, he hears scattered reports about a player who misses meetings and sleeps through practices and does not believe them because, after all, this is the same kid who used to baby-sit for his children.

title: An 18th-Century Flutter Mill Reborn
description: WHEN Benedict Silverman and Jayne Bentzen bought their home in Washington a few years ago, they did so because they thought the property had charm. Charm they got, plus plenty of history. Their house was on the site of an archeological dig and boasted the remains of what is thought to be the only remaining flutter mill in New England.

title: Serbia Tries to Buy Social Peace With Back Pay
description: Business is brisk on the corner of Goce Delceva and Bulever Lenjina streets. And when business here prospers, the rest of Serbia suffers.

title: A Wholesaler And Neighbors Make a Deal
description: In what may prove to be a model for future quality-of-life conflicts on Chinatown's ever-expanding borders, a group of SoHo business owners and residents have settled a bitter dispute with a wholesale vegetable dealer, opting for dialogue over litigation.

title: What the Mice Say About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bulls Were Right To Whack Rodman
description: THE part that really annoyed Jerry Krause about Dennis Rodman's profane diatribe on television is that it was premeditated. That is why Krause hammered Rodman with a two-game suspension that cost Rodman $104,878.

title: A Tenor Unafraid of Heights, He Has Found Them
description: The tenor John Aler can measure his success by many yardsticks: some 50 recordings (including 3 Grammy winners), ranging from Handel to Stravinsky; lots of frequent-flier miles, and a packed calendar that has just swept him from Santiago, Chile, by way of Sydney, Australia, and Tokyo to Alice Tully Hall for a recital this afternoon.

title: President Tells Government To Promote More Adoptions
description: President Clinton today directed the Federal Government to take steps to double the number of children moved from foster care to adoption over the next six years.

title: Modern Cliffhanger: Movies on Main Street
description: For 74 years, the Rialto was where fantasy could be lived out on a movie screen, a home away from home where parents still drop off young children on a Saturday afternoon and feel they will be safe. Now, it is in danger of closing, another casualty of the more profitable highway multiplexes.

title: In Response to Jewish Protests, Hungary Bans 'Mein Kampf'
description: In response to protests from Jewish groups, prosecutors here have banned Hitler's ''Mein Kampf,'' saying the book violates individual rights.

title: Stacy Mallin, David Plimpton
description: Stacy Lynn Mallin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mallin of Lanse, Pa., was married yesterday to David Conant Ary Plimpton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Austin Plimpton of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Ron Sager performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Toms River, N.J.

title: I Laughed! I Cried! I Want the Dress!
description: WHEN ''Clueless,'' the movie about a young cell-phone-toting teen-ager who loves dressing up as much as matchmaking, was released last year, it spurred fashion trends that are still evident today. The film's surprising fashion success -- including brightly colored mini-suits and mini-tank dresses -- helped sell the movie itself. The strong reaction caught everyone off guard, proving how unpredictable a film's influence on fashion can be.

title: Giuliani Plan Would Revamp Child Services
description: Nearly a year after announcing its intention to remake the city's child welfare system, the Giuliani administration is expected to unveil a 120-page plan this week that it hopes will significantly transform the care and protection given the city's most vulnerable and neglected children.

title: Down the Street, Holdouts Appear To Win 20-Year Fight With Columbia
description: In the early 1970's, six buildings stood on the south side of 122d Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Morningside Drive. Today, only one remains, 130 Morningside. The five families who remain, down from 25, are a testament to the power of perseverance. Since then they have fought the neighborhood's biggest landlord, Columbia University. Now, they may have won.

title: Weighing The Ethics Of a Trip
description: A VACATION trip does not commonly require a moral choice, but in the case of Myanmar, the former Burma, there is no way to avoid one.
