description: Airframe

title: Injury Timeout Benefits Freeman
description: Antonio Freeman of the Green Bay Packers has been one of the hottest receivers in the league the last two weeks since returning from a broken left forearm. Despite wearing a cast on his left arm, Freeman has caught 19 passes for 331 yards and 3 touchdowns in the last 2 games. And he had career highs in receptions and yards in each game.

title: Richer Gives the Devils Fits, and the Canadiens Steal a Tie
description: It was not so much scoring a pair of goals against his former team that had Stephane Richer in a lighthearted mood tonight. It was scoring twice against his friend Martin Brodeur.

title: Before Hanging the Wallpaper, Preparations Are in Order
description: UNTIL recently, hanging wallpaper was always a job for a professional, but today the average do-it-yourselfer can easily paper a room without much difficulty.

title: Sifted, Gathered, Boxed and Ribbon-Ready
description: No archive has been left uncombed for this year's assortment of boxed sets geared for holiday gift giving. Call it the year of obscurity: record companies seem to be trying to appeal to the archivist in every fan. Here are three dozen choices that New York Times critics find noteworthy. Prices are suggested retail.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: I think Brubach's male friend was being slightly dishonest in his assessment of men and icons. It is not strictly about camaraderie and fraternal acceptance -- far from it. After seeing ''Rebel Without a Cause,'' what man could deny wanting to put the wrong end of his cigarette in his mouth just so it could be righted by a woman like Natalie Wood? We all wanted to be James Dean at that moment. Men may have greater difficulty admitting to these venerations, but you shouldn't let that fool you.

title: Dissension Is a Friends World College Legacy
description: WHILE a buyer waits to close on buying the former Friends World College waterfront in Lloyd Harbor, dissension among people associated with the institution prevents the sale from moving forward.

title: Delivery Isn't Guaranteed, but Stamps Are Turning Profits
description: WADE SAADI was anxious before he sold his collection of rare 1869 American stamps last summer. ''The fun is in putting the collection together,'' he explained, and he was worried about parting with stamps he had spent four years gathering.

title: Mendik Company To Form a REIT
description: For the last few years, owners of commercial real estate across the country have been converting their properties into a type of ownership called a a real estate investment trust and selling shares to the public, but New York City landlords have lagged behind. Last week a major Manhattan property owner, the Mendik Company, announced plans to establish a REIT, and industry analysts expect others to follow.

title: Alex Schoenbaum, 81, Founder Of Shoney's Restaurant Chain
description: Alex Schoenbaum, who built the Shoney's restaurant chain from a small drive-in restaurant in West Virginia, died on Dec. 6 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida. Mr. Schoenbaum, who lived in Sarasota and West Virginia, was 81.

title: Living the American Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: On Radiation And Breast Cancer
description: How much radiation would it take to cause cancer, especially breast cancer? Should comprehensive studies of breast cancer on Long Island examine radiation sources?

title: For Cornell Medical, a Macro School in Micro Space
description: WHEN it came to design, the new education center at Cornell University Medical College posed a double challenge. It had to accommodate the needs of a revamped science curriculum, which relies heavily on computers. And it had to fit into the limited space available.

title: The 'Chetnik' Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Detective Is Adviser to Films on Police Work
description: DETECTIVE Hal Sherman, a New York City police officer from Yonkers, would be the first to advise moviegoers not to see the film ''Ransom'' just because he is in it. One of his two scenes as a medical examiner lies on the cutting-room floor. As for the scene in which he appears, he says, ''If you blink, you'll miss me.''

title: Blame the Lawyers, Not Just the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Clinic's Move Stirs Protest
description: Kips Bay and Gramercy Park are home to so many major hospitals -- seven, including New York University Medical Center and Bellevue Hospital Center -- that residents joke that their neighborhoods should be called Bedpan Alley. But they are not laughing about a continuing clash with Beth Israel Medical Center over as many as 250 drug addicts in a methadone program who are to move from a clinic on the Upper East Side to one near 25th Street.

title: In the Northeast, a Possible Answer to Double Taxation
description: SOME may be where the heart is, but not when it comes to taxes.

title: Ten-Year-Old's Net Surfing Lands White House Invitation
description: Alex Burg, 10, was browsing on his computer last spring and, as a lark, sent a message to the White House. That set off a string of unlikely events that will culminate on Monday, when Alex and two dozen other members of a Dobbs Ferry grade-school chorus board a chartered bus at 5:30 A.M. for Washington to sing their pint-sized hearts out at a holiday celebration in the East Room.

title: In a First Feature, a Generation X Romance
description: BREAKUP or makeup is a sad yet romantic problem, and possibly one of the oldest in the history of love. But for Kathy and David, a young New York couple in the movie ''Breathing Room,'' it means taking some time away from each other to test their true feelings.

title: Refrigerator Queen
description: FOREVER, ERMA

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: By rough count, you describe some 35 ''icons . . . who inform women's lives.'' Of those, at least 21 are in the entertainment industry (TV, film, country music, sports, model, Playboy bunny), 8 are in the arts (high-class entertainment), 3 are brides of rich men, 2 are in politics (you had to go all the way to England to get one, and the other was a President's wife), 1 teacher and 1 pilot.

title: Cars That Tell You Where to Go
description: DON'T toss out your road maps just yet, though you may be needing them less. A number of navigation and communications systems are taking their places in cars, promising to get you where you want to go and even making reservations for your arrival.

title: For Great Neck Plaza, a New 68-Unit Condominium
description: FOR 15 years, residents of the Village of Great Neck Plaza and the neighboring Village of Kensington have watched with dismay as a complex of brick buildings on Bond Street and Nassau Drive that once housed the Kensington-Johnson Elementary School fell into decay.

title: Born to Be Wild
description: I read in a recent magazine that all human history can be explained in terms of sibling rivalry, and that so-called later-borns are more easygoing, cooperative, innovative and popular with their peers than firstborns. Or so a certain Dr. Frank J. Sulloway would have us believe. Well, he would think that. He has two older siblings. In articles about his book called ''Born to Rebel: Birth Order, Family Dynamics and Creative Lives,'' he says that he spent 26 years analyzing the biographies of 6,000 people who have played a role in the scientific and social revolutions of the past 500 years. But has he interviewed me? He has not. You would think that he would want to talk to the older sister of the designer who has been hailed as the next great renegade, the wild visionary who has been appointed to take fashion into the 21st century. But no, the phone never rings. I can tell you one thing, we firstborns are a lot more thorough when it comes to doing research.

title: What the Goose Eats

To make his point, Mr. Lu opted for an analogy. He said in all seriousness that if a journalist in America were to call for a different form of government or for the independence of Hawaii, ''Will it be allowed? I don't think so.'' Therefore, he added, it's hardly unusual that journalists in Hong Kong would be barred from calling for the independence of Hong Kong or for a new government in Beijing.

title: The Ultimate Approval Rating
description: WILLIAM JEFFERSON CLINTON NOW FACES HIS RENDEZVOUS WITH history. Debarred by the 22d Amendment from pursuing a third term, he must make his mark between now and Jan. 19, 2001. This may not be easy. The 22d Amendment, by turning re-elected Presidents into lame ducks, reduces their political potency. Second terms tend to be times of trouble: Ask Franklin D. Roosevelt, Eisenhower, Nixon, Reagan. On the other hand, lame-duckery, by liberating Presidents from the demands of re-election, does allow them to run political risks for national benefits.

title: Newark's Slice of Italy That Survives Only in Memory

As the tenements in the half-mile square around St. Lucy's Church fell to make way for the Christopher Columbus Homes Housing Project, so did a way of life. For the First Ward had been the heart of a community, one of the largest Little Italys in America. Thousands of Italian immigrants had settled there and had families, the first generation of Italian-Americans. Today, their countless descendants throughout the United States can still trace their roots to Newark.

title: City of Immigrants, Pausing, Offers A Belated Welcome
description: Immigrants have been helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since its inception. Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The Times, began the fund after encountering a pauper, an immigrant, on Christmas night in 1911. Mr. Ochs believed that if readers of his newspaper knew how some of their neighbors lived, they would want to help. So the next year, a reporter searched the files of social service agencies to write about the city's 100 neediest cases. They included an Armenian immigrant who suffered from leprosy and the widow and four children of an Italian immigrant who had died of tuberculosis and who all suffered from the disease. The fund's 85th annual appeal, now under way, runs through Feb. 28. The Times pays all administrative expenses so donations can go directly to services for people who need them. And those who need them, officials of social service agencies say, are increasingly going to be immigrants affected by the new Federal welfare law, which sharply restricts Government assistance for noncitizens, among others. More than two million immigrants live in New York City today, and traditionally, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has noted, immigrants are among its hardest workers. ''Those tenement scenes of the Lower East Side were in fact a thriving and prosperous population; they were just packed in,'' he said. ''Emma Lazarus, wherever she is in heaven, has a lot to account for. They weren't the wretched refuse of anybody's shores. They come here to work.'' And work, as they so often find, is not easy to come by. Here are some of their stories.

title: Illusions Created By Masters, Credibly Restored
description: The piano is, to be blunt, a ridiculous musical instrument. It depends almost completely on sleight of hand. Each note begins with a percussive strike and immediately begins to decay. But by distracting the ear with harmonies that push and pull, by using swells in the supporting left hand, by striking a second note milliseconds before the first ends, by invoking resonances of partially damped strings, a pianist can turn crude impacts of hammers into music. A master of illusion can make it seem that a sustained note is gradually getting louder, that one tone is sliding liquidly into the next, that there really are vocal cords, or at least violin strings, inside that massive machine of wood and metal and felt.

title: A General Is Cleared
description: In the wake of the terrorist truck bombing that killed 19 American troops at a housing complex in Saudi Arabia last June, a Pentagon investigation singled out the Air Force general in charge of the complex for failing to adequately protect the buildings.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: Cynthia Ozick's ''Saloonkeeper'' is a classic example of the dismissive essay, with its assumption that Gertrude Stein is of interest only for her role in the lives of the modernist men to whom she played hostess and its casual dismissal of Stein's own work as silly gibberish.

title: The Rediscovered Modernist
description: ''Charlotte Perriand? Isn't she a furniture designer?'' ONE prominent architect, a man, responded when told that I was writing about her. And, indeed, that is the way she has usually been characterized, if not dismissed -- on those rare occasions when she has been mentioned at all. The distinction is taken for granted. Men design the buildings; women furnish them. Men work in concrete and steel; women, in fabrics and occasionally wood. Men organize the public spaces; women feather the nest, presiding over the realm of domestic interiors. That Perriand, despite the buildings she has designed, should be known as a furniture designer while Philippe Starck and Ettore Sottsass, whose fame is based primarily on their furniture and household objects, should be known as architects is only one indication of the bias at work in a field that is notoriously and to this day overwhelmingly male.

title: Jews in Curacao
description: To the Editor: Donna Rosenthal's superbly researched article ''Sephardic Tradition on Curacao'' (Nov. 10) should tempt readers to visit the island where we go every year for snorkeling. Two notes on attending services at the synagogue: Men must wear jackets and ties (tourists off cruise ships are often unprepared and disappointed); and Friday evening and Saturday morning services are followed by refreshments, to which visitors are welcomed by congregants, all of whom speak English.

title: The New Gulag
description: I WANT LAOGAI TO become a word in every language,'' said Harry Wu, the Chinese dissident, to Gerald F. Seib of The Wall Street Journal.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: Not too long ago I was in my local used-book store looking for a copy of ''Orlando.'' While I didn't find that, what did pop out at me was Kate Smith's autobiography, ''Upon My Lips a Song.''

title: Mini-Camps to Puppet Shows for Children Over the Holiday Break
description: SEASONED parents know all too well that it is a matter of seconds before enthusiastic children are finished ripping open gifts bought and wrapped and arranged over many hours. This knowledge increases the trepidation in the hearts of parents when facing the almost two weeks of holiday vacation that most Westchester schoolchildren will enjoy this year. Fortunately, there are many time-consuming activities planned in Westchester this holiday season, which are sure to provide hours of distraction and amusement. This winter, the hollow thud of school doors closing will not intimidate parents armed with plans to fill their children's empty hours and perhaps contain their holiday exuberance.

title: A Change in Menus for the Winter
description: WHEN summer becomes autumn and autumn slides into winter more than the weather changes, menus do. Hearty, sturdy, warming dishes replace summer's fruits, vegetables, grilled fish and salads. Most Island restaurants are now involved in just such a transition.

title: Countless Renditions Later, Sousa's Beloved March Turns 100
description: Fragments of music from a student band drift through the Sousa Archives at the University of Illinois, the final repository of thousands of pages of the music that John Philip Sousa and his band played over 40 years on tour.

title: The Man Wouldn't Play Ball
description: Five years before Michael Jordan made his acting debut opposite Bugs Bunny, in that exercise in synergy called ''Space Jam,'' a small and serious film about inner-city basketball entitled ''Heaven Is a Playground'' quietly opened. It had no stars, no cartoons and no merchandising campaign. Rather, ''Heaven Is a Playground'' represented the decade-long effort of a first-time director to bring to the screen a classic book about one summer on the courts of Brooklyn.

title: Architecture of Light and Remembrance
description: NEVER FORGET. BUT THERE IS A GREAT deal more than the Holocaust to remember. There is creativity: the blazing talent of 20th-century Jews, the inspiration of a people marked for extinction but not destroyed. And there is remembrance itself: the capacity of a culture to bring itself to mind. Memory, creativity: the linkage of these two ideas is the cornerstone of the Skirball Cultural Center, a museum and study center that opened in April in Los Angeles.

title: TRY 'EM ON A LONG BUN
description: Lampreys are ugly, toothy, eel-like, parasitic creatures that latch onto fish, and they reportedly taste like liver. Mmm, you say, let's order up a mess! You may get the chance. For the past year, researchers at the University of Minnesota have been testing lampreys from the Great Lakes on Portuguese diners, who have enjoyed Atlantic-dwelling lampreys for years. The idea is to see if the American lamreys, which are despised threats to commercial fishing, are tasty enough to be got rid of via export, abroad and at home. And? ''They're firm textured, but not chewy,'' says Jeff Gunderson, the project's leader. ''My wife said they made her think of beef.'' Wistfully, no doubt.

title: At Long Last, Adventureless Travel
description: ON the subject of vacations, I am a slow learner. Every year for the last two decades, out of an impulse I can only describe as witless, I have spent my two-week allotment of free time torturing myself. I have, for instance, stumbled around Southeast Asia on streets so hot my rubber thongs melted. I have edged my way along the sheer walls of Utah's slot canyons, numb with fear. I have hauled myself and a 40-pound pack up the White Mountains, the Green Mountains, the Adirondacks and the Rockies. One year, I bicycled 500 miles in a week, a feat that required dawn risings, constant toil and more mental fortitude than a debate with Newt Gingrich. I even spent 10 days charting the path of my pain -- building a trail with the Sierra Club on the west slope of the Tetons. On sunny days I excavated rocks with a crowbar. On cold, rainy days I hiked ankle-deep in mud or enjoyed group huddles in the community tent garbed in so many clothes I looked like the Pillsbury Dough Boy. This is called adventure travel.

Ochs, publisher of The New York Times, was moved to help an impoverished immigrant, inspired the creation of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund has helped immigrants ever since. In what remains a city of immigrants, the fund's 85th annual appeal is under way. The money raised goes to seven agencies that aid needy New Yorkers -- immigrant and native-born alike. title: What to Do With Plutonium
description: When the United States built up its stock of plutonium, there were few questions. In the cold war no price, in money, health or environmental damage, was too high. Getting rid of the surplus is another matter. Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary announced last week that the department had chosen two alternatives from among three dozen: mixing plutonium back in with the high-level radioactive wastes that it was produced with and encasing both in glass, or consuming it in a reactor. The department says the Russians will never turn their plutonium into waste, but might be induced to use it in reactors if America did likewise. But some opponents say this could turn into yet another government subsidy for the American reactor industry. All agree, though, that getting the plutonium out of warheads is not enough, because that step is reversible and what is needed is a way to lock in deep reductions in nuclear arms. MATTHEW L. WALD

The singers will perform their fifth annual Winter Concert on Friday night at the Old First Reformed Church in Park Slope and appear Saturday afternoon with the Brooklyn Heights Orchestra at the St. Ann's Holiday Family Concert.

title: Backing Up Santa at the Post Office
description: Dear Santa Claus, I'm almost 10 years old. I have two brothers. I am very good with my Mom. I help her and take care of my baby brother. Santa, I know you are just like God. I know you could do miracles. I've been very, very good. And all I want for Christmas is happiness and to be with my family. Santa, I want you to make the best Christmas for my Mom. She needs it because she is the best Mom in the whole world. My Mom is very sad and if she is sad, I can't be happy. She takes care of me, my brother and my baby brother and her mentally retarded brother. She is the only thing we have. I don't know where my father is. He left us. My Mom has to take care of us by herself. So please Santa, make my wish come true. Make my Mommy happy for Christmas.

title: Gault-Millau Rates the Top Tables in France
description: The 1997 Gault-Millau restaurant guide to France, just out, has named Jacques Chibois, chef and owner of the seven-month-old La Bastide St.-Antoine in the Provencal resort town of Grasse, its chef of the year. Chibois, 43, was previously the chef at the luxurious Grey d'Albion hotel in Cannes. His new restaurant, in an ocher-toned farmhouse surrounded by 100-year-old olive trees, features the cuisine of Provence, offering menus ranging from $40 for lunch to $110 for dinner. While La Bastide St.-Antoine was not classified among the top 12 restaurants in the new guide, this ranking places Mr. Chibois among the top 35 chefs in France.

Figures and landscapes are drawing the crowds: a pretty Dutch housewife caught in a fall of light, a French garden atomized in paint. Abstract paintings, by contrast, go more or less unnoticed, absorbed, if they are at all, as a kind of scenic ambiance.

title: In High Sumatra, Another Way of Life
description: FOR the price of a cup of coffee -- home grown Sumatran kopi, served in a big glass with rough brown sugar for a sweetener -- what an eyeful of glory we got! The precarious back porch of a roadside food stall clung to the rim of a deep, long valley. In the distance there were the ubiquitous green, green rice fields of Indonesia. But here, near the town of Bukittinggi in the highlands of Sumatra, a volcanic island about the size of California, there was more. Rose-red leaves atop the cinnamon trees and huge yellow daisies bobbing in the morning sun splashed unexpected color over dense tropical undergrowth. Off to one side the soaring pinnacled rooftops of a village peopled by one of Indonesia's most sophisticated cultures, the Minangkabau, could be glimpsed above a tangle of trees.

For years, Melvilleans have anticipated his book ''Herman Melville: A Biography,'' which was published last month by the Johns Hopkins University Press.

title: SWEET TOOTH MADNESS
description: Richard Dedell, a Miami lawyer, admits that his client, Wesley Shaffer, was guilty of burglary. ''No question he did it,'' says Dedell. Shaffer, 57, was caught red-handed in a Boca Raton, Fla., home, clutching loot and wearing all-black clothing, and he has bragged that he committed 400 burglaries in his youth. Facing tall odds at Shaffer's recent trial, Dedell pressed a novel defense: that cotton candy was to blame. He claimed that Shaffer was an undiagnosed diabetic who snorfed a bag and a half of the stuff, an act that spiked his blood sugar and prompted a ''psychotic episode'' that left him unable to tell right from wrong. The jury didn't buy it, but Dedell remains adamant. ''This was a real medical problem,'' he says. ''I don't do nutball, stupid things.''

title: Paradors

title: How Firm a Foundation
description: Smart and sprightly, the lavishly illustrated UNMENTIONABLES: A Brief History of Underwear (Simon & Schuster, $30) is a literary rummage through lingerie drawers past and present. Without flogging the idea to death, Elaine Benson, a Long Island gallery owner, and John Esten, an art director, suggest we are what we wear underneath it all. With men's undergarments, whether loincloths or Calvin Klein briefs, form has generally followed function. But women's undergarments have always involved altering the figure to suit the physical, and sometimes moral, ideals of the time. For example, tight lacing and corsets were popular when sexual restraint was most valued (hence the term ''straitlaced''). Conversely, women lost the stays and underwiring at about the same time they made strides forward socially and politically: after getting the vote in 1920 and the Pill in the 1960's, both flappers and feminists went braless. The authors' wide-ranging anthropological curiosity extends from Eden (where fig leaves were arguably the first underwear) to Southampton, L.I. (which still has laws demanding the portion of the breast below the areola be covered ''with fully opaque clothing'') to Hollywood, where in the 1950's James Dean's performance in ''Rebel Without a Cause'' and Marlon Brando's sweaty turn in ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' revived the T-shirt industry. The text is also full of fascinating tidbits about the fripperies we take for granted. Take, for instance, the current convention of embroidering a tiny rosette on the cleavage of brassieres: it is a tribute to a fashion of 16th-century France, where women, whose hygiene habits were not the best, wore a scented pomander between their breasts. The biggest news flash in ''Unmentionables?'' We finally learn what Scotsmen wear underneath those kilts. The answer is not ''nothing.'' Judith Newman

Yet for some reason -- vengeful Fates who just don't care for plantation kitsch? -- it never happens. ''I think the whole thing has a jinx on it,'' grumbles one participant in a 1980's project. title: A Victory for Wetlands
description: Over the last decade, the fight to save the nation's diminishing wetlands has focused on the bigger and more obvious threats. Former Vice President Dan Quayle and, later, Representative Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania advanced various schemes that would have transferred millions of these valuable acres to developers and industry almost overnight. Their efforts failed. But all the while, under 10-year-old regulations, the Army Corps of Engineers has been transferring land to private interests in small enough chunks to escape radar detection by most environmentalists and conservation-minded politicians. This has contributed mightily to the steady erosion of the wetland inventory, which is declining at a rate of some 70,000 acres a year.

title: Speech With the Weight of Literature
description: I guess the first question that needs answering is why I'm writing about Mario Savio in a book review section. He wasn't, in the strictest sense of the word, an author. He never published a book. He was even a bit wary of publishing, as I learned when I set out to print one of his commemorative speeches in a 1995 issue of The Threepenny Review. He confessed to me, with an almost painful nervousness, that he hesitated to engage in any sort of publication for fear of losing the copyright; and when I assured him that I was acquiring one-time rights only, and that he would retain all further copyright, he explained to me the source of his anxiety. Early in his career he had allowed some of his speeches to be published, only to discover that in doing so he had unwittingly given away the rights to them. That such a thing was possible -- that he could be deprived of the possession of his own sentences -- surprised and wounded him. He had thought of speech as something free; it shocked him to see it treated as a salable commodity, a product divorced from its maker.

title: Family Fables
description: When the family members in CENTAUR OF THE NORTH (Arte Publico, paper, $11.95) talk about the past, they contradict one another -- and sometimes themselves. In one of the stories in Wendell Mayo's powerful first collection (most of which are set in Corpus Christi, Tex.), a mother offers her son conflicting accounts of the youth she may or may not have spent in Guatemala, Italy or China. And hers are the lies that bind. ''Unlike most self-respecting teen-agers,'' the son tells us, ''I stayed near my mother out of sheer curiosity. I needed a story I could believe.'' Ten years after his mother's death, he is still striving to find one. In the title story, relatives tell a teen-ager incompatible versions of the family's ''one great story.'' What is the truth of his grandfather's claim to have been part of the American Army contingent sent to Texas in 1916 to capture or kill Pancho Villa? If the boy's grandfather was in the Army, did he desert? Did he run from Villa? Join him? Did he ever even meet him? These questions lead, of course, to a much larger one: What provides the force of family mythology when the myths themselves are called into question? As the collection unfolds, it becomes clear that the power of these stories lies not in their accuracy but in the strength of their roots in a particular place. Evoking the visceral intensity of such memories, one narrator recalls having moved at age 10 to Chicago from ''the sweltering South, Corpus Christi, the Gulf, a place of sand and broken white seashells, of heat and a kind of bluish, fermented slowness of the body, a warmth within warmth that felt like family.'' Janet Kaye

title: S.I. Driver Sentenced To 25 Years to Life In Fatal Hit-and-Run
description: A man with four previous drunken driving convictions has received the maximum sentence, 25 years to life, for the hit-and-run death of a Staten Island woman last year.

title: HEART STOPPER
description: Until recently, the logo for the House of Blues -- a nightclub chain with outlets in Cambridge, Mass., Los Angeles and New Orleans -- depicted a glowing, bleeding heart wrapped in thorns. But after the company announced it was hitting Chicago, local Catholics cried blasphemy. The symbol (near right) is a revered icon -- the Sacred Heart of Jesus -- and the Archdiocese of Chicago urged Isaac Tigrett, the nightclubs' founder, to scrap the image. Tigrett stalled at first, arguing that he strives to ''bring spirituality'' to mainstream culture, but the evidence for that was a bit thin. (To wit: ''On a mission from God,'' a saying from the movie ''The Blues Brothers,'' is part of the company motto.) He compromised in time for the Chicago club's opening last month, switching to a no-thorns heart with a rose in the middle (far right) whose petals symbolize humane values like love and peace. The flames that continue to shoot out of the aorta obviously mean that the music remains red hot.

title: Gingrich's Shelter Visit Is Canceled
description: Given his frequent portrayal by Democratic enemies and the news media as a stingy denier of alms for the poor, Newt Gingrich is not the first politician one would expect to sling hash for the needy at a homeless shelter.

description: WHEN the stock of an obscure outfit called Systems of Excellence started to jump last spring, Internet-savvy investors knew whom to thank: SGA Goldstar, an on-line tip sheet.

description: THE one-word headline on Page One should read, terrific. The lead story at this Glen Cove newcomer is the food. The surroundings are pleasant if somewhat cold, but they are warmed by live music and an attentive, friendly staff. The enthusiastic welcome at the door is provided by the owner, Gustav Hausser, whom diners may remember as the proprietor of the former Cafe Harlequin in Sea Cliff.

Their heart-tickling anecdotes affected me: Charles Kuralt's story-telling grandmother; Rosanne Cash's purse-lipped mama; Isabella Rossellini's mother and her run-in with the great Greta; Charles McGrath's mom and her affinity for Babe Zaharias.

description: THERE it is: an old seven- or eight-story brick manufacturing building with big windows across the front, standing vacant or partly vacant and forlorn on a side street in TriBeCa, SoHo, North Gramercy, Flatiron, Chelsea, the Meat Market area, the Financial District, across the river in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn -- anywhere in New York City where art collectors, bankers, designers, stockbrokers and hip upper-middle-class parents might consider living in enormous sheet-rocked spaces.

description: It was a small thing, a ruptured blood vessel on the end of her nose. Wendee Harper's family doctor told her he would arrange to have her see a specialist, assuring her that Canada's universal health care system would cover even the smallest detail.

description: The president of Reform Judaism's synagogue organization has called for expanding the movement's small presence in Israel, to develop a liberal religious alternative within a nation overwhelmingly dominated by secular and Orthodox Jews.

description: A year after he began a hand-over-hand climb from a legal and personal abyss, Roy Lassiter today helped to hoist the United States into the final round of World Cup qualifying with a 2-1 victory over Costa Rica.

description: UNTIL recently, hanging wallpaper was always a job for a professional, but today the average do-it-yourselfer can easily paper a room without much difficulty.

title: Gift Ideas for the Connoisseur
description: WHILE the extensive array of wine-related items should make shopping a pleasure, the spectrum of possibilities -- especially glassware -- can be as overwhelming as buying wine itself. Moreover, many rather elegant-appearing choices are quite impractical. To guide consumers in their selection of gifts for the wine enthusiast, the following suggestions are offered.

title: The Year Of The Woman, Finally
description: The year was 1993, and in the lexicon of Hollywood hype, it was the Year of the Woman. As the glitterati thronged into the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion for the 65th Annual Academy Awards, the orchestra blared out that pedophilia-tinged ode to blooming femininity ''Thank Heaven for Little Girls.'' During the show, Liza Minnelli belted an embarrassing piece of special material proclaiming Hillary Rodham Clinton leader of the drive for women to become pilots and auto mechanics. Later, a tribute to great ladies of the screen somehow forgot to mention Lillian Gish and Marlene Dietrich. Talk about condescension!

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 17 about the film ''The Children of Paradise,'' with an article about the French director Marcel Carne, misidentified the actress shown with Jean-Louis Barrault. She was Maria Casares, not Arletty.

title: Sheri Colonel And Alan Baron
description: Sheri Lynn Colonel, the president of Gotham, a New York advertising agency, was married last evening to Alan Robert Baron, a partner in Decameron Partners, a private investment firm in New York. Rabbi Daniel Alder performed the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York.

title: Nicole Waldbaum, Michael Moser
description: Nicole Elizabeth Waldbaum, an associate at the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher, and Michael Alan Moser, a lawyer at Wolfson Equities, an investment partnership in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Judith Lewis performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Seasonal French Food in Port Chester
description: SINCE its opening more than two years ago, Le Radis Blanc has transformed its wee self into a homey and personal, yet proper, restaurant of the modest sort found on residential side streets in most French cities. The former dining room now holds a bar and bistro tables for the weekend overflow. In the new eating space, rough-cast walls are softened by white lattice, mirrors and masses of fake flowers. They peek out of wooden kegs and flowerpots and from behind fake windows; rosebuds hang from drying racks, and grapevines meander along trellises.

title: Postal Service Extends Hours for the Holidays
description: The United States Postal Service is taking a bit of the stress out of the holiday season by extending weekday hours and opening for business for the two Sundays before Christmas at many post office branches in New Jersey.

title: A Showman's Vintage Memories
description: TO Oscar Hammerstein II, he was a protege, to Irving Berlin, a muse. Berlin wrote a song just for him -- it was called ''Kick in the Pants'' -- during the World War II tour of ''This Is the Army.'' Those were the nights of parties on the Nile, thrown by King Farouk. And New Year's Eve wasn't New Year's Eve if not spent at the Jimmy Cagneys.

description: A picture caption with the Journal column on Dec. 1 about a 1910 holiday tea in St. James misidentified the server. She was Robin McKinnon, not Sue Diffily.

description: In the basement of St. Marks United Methodist Church on Ocean Avenue, under a low ceiling and on a creaking hardwood floor, a political movement is blossoming with practical fanfare: the scribbling of pen on paper.

description: As a member of the Bruderhof, the religious community reported on in the article (''Of Family, Spirituality and Power,'' Dec. 8), I wish to correct several inaccuracies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Nov. 24 about the tomb of the magician Harry Houdini, in Machpelah Cemetery in Queens, misstated the number of people buried in the Houdini family plot. There are 10, not 24. The article also misstated the burial place of Houdini's wife. It is Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, N.Y., not Machpelah.

title: A Nazi in China Who Used His Swastika to Save Lives
description: RECENT works like ''Schindler's List'' and ''Hitler's Willing Executioners'' have stimulated public debate about what German civilians did and did not do during the Third Reich to lessen some of this century's signal horrors. Add to that discussion now the case of John Rabe, a German businessman and Nazi organizer in China who worked to protect Chinese civilians caught in the two-month rampage by invading Japanese soldiers known as the Rape of Nanking.

title: Where 'Uplift' Bypasses a Plot of Loose Ends
description: GRACE TANNER, an elderly and, all right, an amazing woman who calls herself a career psychic, has had the power to heal since the age of 15. She will knead the kink out of your neck, rub the pain from your knee, sense the hurt in your heart and bend your ear about your ''fated destiny.'' That energy of hers is so boundless, it sets off television sets and beepers.

title: Martin H. Moynihan, 68, an Authority on Animal Behavior
description: Martin Humphrey Moynihan, an authority on animal behavior who built the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama into a world-class scientific center, died on Dec. 3 in the General Hospital of Albi, France. He was 68 and had a farmhouse-research station in Albi.

title: The Long March
description: D. H. LAWRENCE

title: The Ghost of Christmas Depression
description: Next weekend's televised showing of ''It's a Wonderful Life'' marks the movie's 50th anniversary, and a revival of the debate over what makes the film so well-loved. Like ''A Christmas Carol,'' it is the story about having a bad (but instructive) holiday dream, courtesy of otherworldly spirits. Jimmy Stewart plays a suicidal George Bailey, who is shown what his hometown of Bedford Falls would be like if he had never been born. Needless to say, even though George is just the owner of an about-to-be-bankrupt savings and loan, his life turns out to have been critical to the happiness of hundreds of other people.

title: Recalling an Era Now 'Sadly Gone'
description: Thelma Sokoloff writes with great insight $(''When Merchants Were Family,'' Opinion, Dec. 1$) of an era that is sadly gone when she describes the small business merchants who knew customers by name and took the time to cater to their needs and wishes. Superceeded by supermarkets, chain stores and malls, the customer has become a mere number in the name of progress and efficiency. Ms. Sokoloff hit the proverbial nail right on the head.

title: Ambassador Names Marshall Scholars
description: A straight-A student at Columbia University who intends to pursue a career in cognitive neuroscience, the president of the Puerto Rican students association at Cornell University who says he takes ballroom dancing very seriously and a Korean-American immigrant majoring in English at Harvard University are among the 40 young men and women chosen to be British Marshall Scholars next fall.

title: Why Seizing Drugs Barely Dents Supply
description: TRAFFICKING in illegal drugs often seems to defy basic economic principles.

title: Modern Hunt For the Linen And the Wool
description: Federal cutbacks, environmentalists and global capitalism have turned an Orthodox Jewish tradition into a grueling, high-tech hunt for microscopic fibers. Five days a week, a small group of workers in a Midwood yeshiva, armed with needles, a microscope and their teeth, do battle with clothing manufacturers from across the globe.

title: A Startling Discovery At a Dreyfus Fund
description: THE Dreyfus Corporation had finally found something to roar about.

title: Is It Broke?
description: MAKING CAPITALISM WORKBy Leonard Silk and Mark Silk with Robert Heilbroner, Jonas Pontusson and Bernard Wasow.228 pp. New York:A 20th Century Fund Book/ New York University Press. $24.95.

description: Five hundred law enforcement investigators have hunted the globe to find out who did it. An army of scientists and engineers has applied meticulous analysis to find out what did it.

title: From Classics to CD-Rom's, It Still Has All the Answers
description: At the Bloomfield Public Library, you can follow the clock and calendar by the kind of readers who have claimed spots there. Weekday mornings, retirees come to read newspapers and check stock reports. For many it's a daily routine. Susan Grehl, 79, walks over from nearby senior housing to sit an hour or two, scanning recipes in the Ladies Home Journal and business news in Fortune and Forbes. ''You don't realize you're a fixture,'' she said good-humoredly.

title: The Long March
description: D. H. LAWRENCETriumph to Exile, 1912-1922.By Mark Kinkead-Weekes.Illustrated. 943 pp. New York:Cambridge University Press. $39.95.

title: A Pilot Comes Clean
description: When a Soviet fighter shot Korean Air Lines Flight 007 out of the sky over Soviet territory 13 years ago, Moscow kept the pilot under wraps. But now Gennadi Osipovich, the 52-year-old retired pilot who pulled the trigger, is free to tell his story. And his first-hand account raises new questions about the Soviet military's role.

title: Putting On the Dog
description: Some pampered dogs were wearing coats and sweaters with gold buttons in the style of Chanel last Sunday at the 10th annual ''Miracle on Madison Avenue.'' During this event, the street was closed to traffic and open as a pedestrian mall, and 165 shops participated, donating 20 percent of sales to four local children's charities. Other dogs were buttoned into sweat suits and leopard-patterned coats, or slung in baby carriers so that shoppers had hands free for carrying bags. A pair of snow-white poodles, coifed to perfection, needed no man-made coats, nor a Great Dane, regally watching from the steps of St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: Crafts From All Over, and Wearable Too
description: THAT art can be integrated into daily life is the idea behind ''Designer Crafts,'' the 20th annual holiday exhibition and sale at the Brookfield Craft Center through Dec. 24. ''Art is no longer just something to hang on the wall or place on a pedestal,'' said Judith Russell, manager of the show. ''It can be worn as garments and jewelry, as well as decorate the home.''

title: Even the Victorians on the Walls Hang Looser
description: In 1931, a new book made waves in London. It was called ''The English: Are They Human?'' That title bit deep, though the eventual answer was yes. Anyone who is tussling with that same question today can get an instantaneous fix at the National Portrait Gallery here. The museum's collections go back 500 years, but the 19th- and early-20th-century rooms have just been completely revitalized and brought up to the minute. The result is a walk-through dictionary of men and women who in one way or another put a new face on England.

title: The West Comes East
description: PEOPLE say the wines on the menu at Sonoma Grill are so carefully chosen that you can't err in terms of price or quality, even if you make your selection blindfolded.

title: Minnesota Hires Mason
description: Kansas Coach GLEN MASON was hired yesterday as the new coach at Minnesota. Mason, 46, had a 47-54-1 record at Kansas, including 4-7 this season. He inherits a Minnesota team that lost 24 of its last 27 Big Ten games under Jim Wacker, who resigned after compiling a 16-39 record in five seasons. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A caption last Sunday with a Reuters picture of a tequila distillery misstated provisions of a labeling agreement between Mexico and the European Union. For sales in Europe, the agreement confines the tequila label to beverages made predominantly from the blue agave plant. The caption also referred incorrectly to the distilling process. The agave is mixed in vats of water to promote fermentation, not to extract its sugars. The caption also mischaracterized the blue agave. While a succulent, it is not a cactus.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on page 73 of The Times Magazine today, with the Food column about fresh dates, was printed in error. The dates shown are dried.

title: $250,000 Theft Reported
description: Thieves broke into an art gallery on Madison Avenue during the weekend and escaped with rare Persian and Oriental rugs, cash and other items valued at $250,000, the police said yesterday.

title: Dr. Karl Beyer Jr., 82, Pharmacology Researcher
description: Dr. Karl H. Beyer Jr., a researcher in pharmacology who led teams that created new classes of drugs, died on Dec. 2 at Suburban General Hospital in Norristown, Pa. He was 82 and lived in Gwynedd Valley, Pa.

title: A Hard Landing, Even for Giants of the Air
description: When Americans watched the televised aerial dog fights during the Persian Gulf war, it was fighters built by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation they saw knocking 35 Iraqi fighters out of the sky.

title: Jets Secure One Thing: No. 1 Pick
description: Few Jets, from the $25 million dollar quarterback to the lowliest special teamer, feel secure today as they begin their final week of the 1996 campaign. The insecurity is not only on the field, but in the front office as well, from the personnel to the scouting to the coaching staffs.

description: Continental Airlines Inc. has ended merger talks with other airlines and has no immediate plans to restart them, the carrier's chief executive told employees on Friday.

title: For Timor, Stop U.S. Arms Sales to Indonesia
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan and U.S. Resolve Dispute on Insurance
description: American and Japanese negotiators hammered out a final agreement today on greater foreign access to the insurance market here, ending a protracted trade dispute hours before a midnight deadline.

title: As Slashed Arts Grants Are Unveiled, The Backlash Begins to Take Shape
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced a set of drastically reduced grants to organizations today, the first to reflect major budget cuts imposed by Congress after a rancorous debate over whether the agency should exist at all.

title: Marlene's Street of Dreams? To the Barricades!
description: Anyone waiting underneath the lantern for a latter-day Lili Marlene could barely find a less alluring spot than the Tempelhofer Weg in Berlin's Schoneberg district -- a nondescript thoroughfare with a grim-looking high school, a cluster of small businesses and auto repair shops, a scrap yard and a sense that time has long passed it by.

title: Rich Areas in Miami Talk Secession
description: Struck with the kind of fiscal emergency that other cities have survived and most financial experts agree is manageable, Miami instead finds itself in the throes of an identity as well as a budget crisis.

title: Finding Buried Treasure in Beautiful Mathematics
description: FERMAT'S LAST THEOREM

title: When the Executives, Not the Stars, Get the Hollywood Spotlight
description: If ''The Front Page,'' the classic film about 1930's-style journalism, was remade today, there's a good chance the news story at its heart would no longer be a reporter trying to save a man being sent unjustly to the gallows, but a reporter ferreting out whether a movie studio president was being dismissed, and how much he was being paid.

title: Equity Offerings Expected for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Internet Sex-Assault Suspect Enjoyed Macabre and Mythical
description: Oliver Jovanovic immersed himself in the world of the fantastic. When not working well after midnight on his doctoral studies in the laboratories of Columbia University, he was refining a mythical domain he had helped to create, a domain he hoped would be visited one day by the millions of people who enjoy role-playing games.

title: Holiday gifts may someday include pants to sled in and a play mat to keep a child in one place.
description: IT IS gift-giving season again, which means another opportunity to consider some of the new gadgets and toys that inventors hope will one day top your shopping list.

title: Boeing Chairman Offers 'Exuberance and Dynamism'
description: As he announced the Boeing Company's plan to acquire its longtime rival, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Philip M. Condit, Boeing's president and chief executive, departed from his prepared statement yesterday with a word that spoke volumes: ''Wow!''

title: Pataki Announces an Anti-Smoking Program
description: Answering criticism that his administration has done nothing in its first two years to advance anti-smoking initiatives in New York State, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday announced a $12.7 million package of television advertisements, prevention programs and proposed legislation to try to reduce smoking by children and pregnant women in particular.

title: Divedend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Deaths Belie Algerian Picture of Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing Business in Myanmar
description: Politics should not be an issue for international corporations, says a spokesman for the California-based energy company Unocal, the single largest American investor in the Southeast Asian nation of Myanmar. He was replying to suggestions that Unocal pull out of Myanmar. Business executives, as they like to point out, are not social workers. But at times a government is so repressive and a company's support of it so significant that its presence cannot help but be political. South Africa under apartheid was such a country. Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, is another, and Unocal should not be doing business there.

title: Iraqis Look Ahead to Fattening Of Rations as Part of U.N. Deal
description: From a Baghdad storefront today, Khalid al-Zuweidi measured out Government rations for each of 136 families in his charge, scooping out flour, sugar and rice according to strict prescription. But for the first time in six years, he did so with a hope that next month the portions will be bigger.

title: Murphy's Law Dictates For a Woeful St. John's
description: Stephon Marbury, the New York City kid turned rookie millionaire in the National Basketball Association, sat among the crowd of 13,351 in Williams Arena this afternoon and watched in disbelief as St. John's endured nearly the worst defeat in its history.

title: Steelers Take to the Air But Deflate Under Stress
description: The Steelers realized Coach Bill Cowher's nightmare today. Cowher would awaken during training camp and worry: what would happen if the Steelers fell behind and had to shift away from a running attack spearheaded by Jerome Bettis and leave the offense in the erratic hands of quarterback Mike Tomczak?

title: Dredging For Jet Parts Is Suspended Until January
description: Earlier this month, Federal law enforcement officials diverted some of the scallop-dredging boats recovering wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 to rake miles of sand outside the heart of the crash site for any remnants of a missile.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Once again, EUGENE M. LANG, the philanthropist and founder of the I Have a Dream Foundation, which finances college educations for entire classes of students, has broken a record with a gift. He has given $10 million as a challenge grant to the Eugene Lang College, an undergraduate liberal arts college that is a division of the New School for Social Research. It is the largest single gift ever given to the university.

title: Wetteland Closes, but It's With Texas
description: The relationship between the Yankees and John Wetteland ended abruptly last night when the most valuable player of the 1996 World Series agreed to terms with the Texas Rangers on a four-year contract for $23 million, according to a person familiar with the deal.

title: Another Faulty Encryption Policy
description: The Clinton Administration has issued its third plan in as many years to keep powerful encryption programs for telephone and computer messages out of the hands of international terrorists and criminals. But this latest plan to control the export of encryption software, like the two before it, is unworkable and risks trampling on privacy rights and harming American software firms.

title: An Experimental Approach Revisited
description: Lar Lubovitch's ''Cavalcade,'' set to music by Steve Reich, is the latest addition to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and it continues, in an odd sense, a policy initiated by Ailey himself.

title: Tourists Flock to New York To Catch Its Holiday Glitter
description: The lights were twinkling, the carolers were warbling and war was erupting outside the glass-walled studio of the ''Today'' program in Rockefeller Center. Elbows jabbing and bodies slamming, hundreds of tourists pushed and shoved as they battled for a glimpse of Katie Couric. ''All I got to see was the back of her coat,'' Sharon Bryars of Mobile, Ala., lamented.

title: How Albany Avoids Stand On Abortion
description: Yesterday, a handful of reporters engaged in a useful exercise that every member of the New York's Legislature has managed to evade. At a news conference about late-term abortions held by Planned Parenthood of New York City, the journalists questioned a medical expert and three women who underwent the procedure.

title: Revenge, And Using Nine Bullets
description: Court TV begins its theme of the week, ''The Breaking Point,'' with an account of the recent murder trial of a retired Navy officer for killing a man who was the bane of his San Diego suburb of Spring Valley.

title: A shot at getting the big spenders to invest in the commercial potential of the Internet.
description: THE big question on the collective mind of the on-line advertising community as the year comes to a close is: When are the big consumer products companies going to begin advertising seriously on the Internet?

title: Gay Marriages Get a Hearing
description: Two weeks after a Hawaii judge's ruling left that state one legal step away from allowing homosexual couples to wed, a New Jersey bill to outlaw same-sex marriages and to refuse to recognize those performed in other states faces its first legislative hearing today before the State Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Journalism Is Still Columbia's Priority
description: When Joan W. Konner became dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism in 1988, she took a look at the dingy interior of the old building on the corner of Broadway and 116th Street and declared that her first priority would be ''a fresh coat of paint.''

title: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bills and notes markets, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Wednesday the Treasury will auction a new two-year note, and on Thursday it will auction a new five-year note.

title: 2 Parolees Arrested In Officer's Shooting
description: Two parolees were arrested yesterday in the robbery and shooting of an off-duty police officer Thursday night in the parking lot of a Queens motel near La Guardia Airport, the police said.

title: Los Angeles Critics Honor 'Secrets and Lies'
description: The Los Angeles Film Critics Association gave the British director Mike Leigh's comedy-drama ''Secrets and Lies'' the bulk of its top prizes when it awarded them on Saturday night. The film, about an adopted black woman seeking her white birth mother and facing a dysfunctional family, beat out the quirky comedy ''Fargo'' for the top award.

title: Plutonium Fuel's Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: How Bad Can It Get? Saints Crush The Giants
description: New Orleans Coach Rick Venturi celebrated his third victory in 51 games as a professional and college coach today. He had Gatorade dumped on him by the New Orleans Saints players after a 17-3 victory over the embarrassing Giants.

title: Silver's Push Right Has Liberal Troops Pushing Right Back
description: Despite the gains Democrats made in this year's elections, liberals in the State Assembly are finding themselves pushed to the margins as the Legislature prepares to confront a host of issues they hold dear, from rent regulations to welfare to abortion rights.

title: J. Hexter, 86, Who Began History of Freedom
description: J. H. Hexter, an American historian who conceived an ambitious and continuing project to produce a history of freedom and democracy, died on Dec. 8 at his home in St. Louis. He was 86.

title: City Hall Defends OTB Chief
description: The Giuliani administration vigorously defended the president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation yesterday after a newspaper article suggested that City Hall was unhappy with many of his management decisions and had effectively stripped him of his powers.

title: Helping a Stage Expand Beyond the Living Room
description: Roulette, a 17-year-old performance space on West Broadway in TriBeCa that will soon have to move, is the kind of stimulating, pleasantly lighted place that quiets your nerves immediately; you find yourself suddenly patient, receptive to hearing music unfold.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's leading bridge writers died Thursday in his native France at the age of 79. Jose Le Dentu was the author of many high-quality books on the game, one of the most notable of which, Bridge a la Une, or Front-Page Bridge, was translated into English with the title Championship Bridge.

title: Cao Yu, 86; Modernized Chinese Drama
description: Cao Yu, who has been called China's foremost modern playwright, died on Friday at a hospital in Beijing. He was 86 and had been hospitalized for the past eight years, China's official Xinhua News Agency said in reporting his death.

title: Rift at Safety Board
description: An investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board said he and other investigators were surprised by the assertion of his agency that it had identified a possible cause for the crash of Flight 800.

title: See the World and Have a Bargain Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Golota Implodes, Part II: Low Blows Save Bowe
description: It was a bizarre and brutal fight. And when it ended, Riddick Bowe was writhing in pain on the canvas, the victim of a final, intentional, vicious low blow from Andrew Golota in the ninth round.

title: One in Four
description: From Columbia University comes the latest evidence of the growing disturbance in the American dream.

title: BOEING OFFERING $13 BILLION TO BUY McDONNELL DOUGLAS, LAST U.S. COMMERCIAL RIVAL
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday that it planned to acquire the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in a $13.3 billion deal, the 10th-largest merger in American history and the largest ever in the aerospace industry.

title: Woman Is Killed by Stray Bullet
description: A Bronx woman who was on her way to a Christmas party was struck and killed by a stray bullet early yesterday after a street fight erupted into gunfire, the police said.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Bill to Cover Hospital Stays
description: In the wake of a law passed last year that guarantees new mothers insurance coverage for a 48-hour stay after childbirth, the Legislature is scheduled to consider a bill today that would make insurers pay for three days of hospitalization after a mastectomy.

title: Countdown for a Libertarian Lawyer
description: Leaning back from a plate of barbecue, the country lawyer fantasized about his forthcoming appearance before the United States Supreme Court, pleased that he, a heartfelt Libertarian from backroads America, will have his day before the court on an issue of most personal liberty.

title: Seoul Court Overturns Ex-Leader's Death Sentence
description: A South Korean appeals court today overturned the death sentence of the country's former President, Chun Doo Hwan, reducing his sentence to life imprisonment.

title: Officers Changed At Three Agencies
description: Three agencies are making changes in top management.

title: NATO: Bigger Is Better
description: ''Who wants to die for Danzig?''

title: Coca-Cola, in Direct Attack on Pepsi, to Introduce Challenger to Mountain Dew
description: In an escalation of the soda wars, the Coca-Cola Company plans to challenge Mountain Dew, a 50-year-old icon of successful consumer marketing that has been a major money maker for Pepsico Inc., people with knowledge of Coca-Cola's plans said this weekend.

title: St. John's Flips Head Over Heels For Title
description: A soccer team that drew players from the four corners of the globe and assorted addresses all over the New York area gave St. John's its first national title in any sport today.

title: MOVING TO DEFUSE SPLIT, NETANYAHU AND ARAFAT TALK
description: After a daylong war of words, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, joined tonight in seeking to defuse the rising tensions here. Mr. Netanyahu first sent two envoys to Mr. Arafat, then had a telephone conversation with him that an Israeli official described as ''amiable.''

title: No Headline
description: The merger creates this incredible powerhouse with massive technical, financial, manufacturing and marketing resources. They've got it all. -- WOLFGANG H. DEMISCH, an aircraft industry analyst on the proposed Boeing purchase of McDonnell Douglas. $(D14:1$)

title: Approval of Intelligence Nominee Is Not Assured, G.O.P. Says
description: The question of whether the Senate will confirm Anthony Lake, President Clinton's nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence, remains ''very much up in the air,'' the chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today.

title: Dr. Margaret J. Rioch, Psychotherapist, 89
description: Dr. Margaret Jeffrey Rioch, a clinical psychologist who developed an innovative training program in psychotherapy, died on Nov. 25 at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 89.

title: Churning Complexity From Rare Cuban Visitors
description: Los Van Van, the Cuban group that spent the weekend playing in New York City, is a huge music machine, with gears and cogs and cylinders all churning simultaneously. The band consists of six independent sections: three vocalists, two violinists, three percussionists, three trombonists, two keyboardists and the group's leader and bassist, Juan Formell. With their different origins, they suggest the depth of the Caribbean experience over the last 500 years. And at Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts on Friday night, the sections, driving away with utter cool, had the audience dancing for nearly two and half hours.

title: Bay Has Fewer Crab Eggs
description: The number of horseshoe crab eggs laid along the Delaware Bay has definitely dropped, a study commissioned by the state has found, and it may be bad news for birds. Last spring, state officials and environmentalists voiced concern that the crabs, whose eggs are a crucial source of food for the biggest shorebird migration east of Alaska, were being overfished for eel bait. But hard data on the problem were lacking.

description: Concerned that the Israeli Government's settlement policies are harming the chances for peace in the Middle East, eight former high-ranking American officials have written to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, urging him ''not to take unilateral actions that would preclude a meaningful settlement and a comprehensive and lasting peace.''

description: Strength and Beauty, Forward and Backward

title: 2 Lips, Many Puzzles: Must Be Beckett
description: One day in 1972, Samuel Beckett sat down with the actress Jessica Tandy; his frequent collaborator, the director Alan Schneider, and others who were about to tackle ''Not I,'' his enigmatic 15-minute monologue for a set of lips, tongue and teeth. He handed out the five single-spaced typed pages of the play, which he had completed in 12 days that spring, and waited for the reaction.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Can Next Weekend Be Worse Than This For Giants and Jets?
description: IF you are thinking it can't get any worse than this, it might.

title: Frank Aram Oski, 64, Retired Johns Hopkins Specialist, Dies
description: Frank Aram Oski, a specialist in blood diseases and cancer in children who recently retired after 10 years as head of the Johns Hopkins Children's Center in Baltimore, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Baltimore. He was 64.

title: A Swift Transformation
description: With the Boeing Company's startling announcement today of a $13 billion merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, it signified the near-completion of one of the swiftest and most complete transformations ever of an industry -- as a matter of an explicit Government policy.

title: A Mourner's Ritual: Gifts in Remembrance of Lives Gone By
description: Like the heartache of loss, need in New York City never goes away. Perhaps that is why so many people send gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in remembrance of lives gone by. For many, it is a mourner's ritual.

title: Previously Reluctant States Moving on Welfare Changes
description: Banking on a vibrant economy, states once reluctant to change their welfare systems are devising ambitious ways to push aid recipients into the jobs at the heart of the new welfare law.

title: Winter Weather Tempered By Sassiness and Passion
description: ''The Winter in Lisbon'' is neither a travelogue nor a weather report, but a plotless suite choreographed by Billy Wilson to recordings by Dizzy Gillespie. Nevertheless, its combination of sultriness and sauciness made Portugal seem a pleasant place when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed the work on Saturday afternoon at City Center.

title: Soldiers Force Refugees Into Rwanda From Tanzania
description: Thousands of Rwandan refugees crossed the border into their homeland today after soldiers forced them to leave camps in Tanzania where they have lived for more than two years.

title: Shift on Rabbis Is Voted Down By Lay Leaders
description: Lay leaders of Judaism's largest branch, the liberal Reform movement, have rejected an unusual proposal to ask Reform rabbis to abandon a Rabbinic statement that advises them not officiate at interfaith marriages.

title: Al Santiago, 64, Dies; Recorded Latin Music
description: Al Santiago, a record producer, historian of Latin music and educator, who had a large impact on Latin music in New York City, died last Monday at Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Westchester. He was 64.

title: Free Year-End Help With Your Taxes
description: While many people wait until April 15 approaches to begin dealing with their taxes, savvy taxpayers realize that now is the time to prepare their strategies. What you do before the end of the year, especially with asset allocations, can go a long way toward curbing anxieties come April.

description: An Ailey Evening of Dance But Also of Fond Farewells

title: Netanyahu on Peace
description: Palestinian leaders are holding up renewal of peace negotiations under the Oslo accord, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says, in order to keep Israel under pressure. Now, ''coddled by the international community,'' they are planning violence.

title: After Battling Their Way Onto Playing Field, Girls Are Fighting to Make It Level
description: They were fierce, dogged athletes, and when they played home games, the whole town took notice. Friends and relatives -- even grandparents in wheelchairs -- swarmed to the sidelines. The cheerleaders pranced, the fans shrieked and the players felt adored.

title: Down the Right Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Teamsters Chief, Despite Victory, Is Remaining Defiant
description: After five years of death threats and five years of his adversaries' accusing him of being corrupt and in over his head, Ron Carey is in no mood to offer them an olive branch.

title: Charles Molnar, 61, a Personal Computer Pioneer
description: Charles Edwin Molnar, an electrical engineer who was co-designer of the machine that is widely considered the world's first personal computer, died on Friday at his home in Mountain View, Calif. He was 61.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks traded slightly higher here today. At the end of the afternoon session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks was up 80.65 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,422.04. The Nikkei closed last week with a loss of 159.81 points.

title: Baboon-Cell Transplant Failed, but AIDS Patient Is Improved
description: In the year since an AIDS patient in San Francisco received an experimental transplant of baboon bone marrow, he has gained weight and strength and remained free of severe infections, even though the transplant did not take.

title: A Singer Who Takes It Easy On Songs Without Clutter
description: Morcheeba brought sensual, soft-focus melancholy to the New Music Cafe on Thursday night, all breathiness and subdued rhythm and blue modes. Like Portishead, another English group, Morcheeba updates the languid serenity of Sade with current accessories: beats adapted from hip-hop and reggae and a disk jockey scratching records, along with echoes of slide-guitar blues, old lounge music and current acid jazz.

title: Accord With Catholic Teachers Collapses on Issue of Back Pay
description: After more than a year of negotiations, a tentative agreement reached last month between 450 Roman Catholic high school teachers and the Archdiocese of New York has been abandoned, an archdiocesan spokesman said yesterday.

title: Iraq Ruler Condemns Attack on His Son
description: In his first public comment on the assassination attempt against his eldest son last week, President Saddam Hussein denounced the shooting as an ''atrocious attack'' but said leaders must be prepared for sacrifice, Iraqi television reported tonight.

title: I.M.F. Resumes Paying Credit Of $10.1 Billion to Russia
description: In a qualified endorsement of Moscow's economic policies, the International Monetary Fund has decided to resume disbursement of its $10.1 billion loan to Russia.

title: Re-engineering Firm Tries Some of Its Own Medicine
description: When CSC Index, the $200 million management consulting firm, recently completed work on the redesign of the cash- and paper-handling systems of Wells Fargo Bank, the CSC Index consultants created a blueprint for consolidating and streamlining thousands of the bank's cash distribution points.

title: 2 Newspapers Battle for Hearts, Minds and All Those Ad Dollars
description: Some executives use the backs of their business cards to promote a product line, or to print their names in Japanese. Managers of The Denver Post hand out this message with theirs: ''Return for a 30-Day Free Sample of Colorado's Only Statewide Newspaper.''

title: The DNA Hard Sell
description: Imagine the scene: a middle-aged patient, visiting her doctor for her yearly physical, reminds him that her mother and aunt had breast cancer. With the patient's consent, her well-meaning physician decides to conduct a new test that will reveal whether she carries recently discovered genetic mutations that could radically increase her chances of developing breast cancer. The doctor submits a claim for the test to the woman's insurer. Before the results are back, the insurer, seeing what the test is for, triples the price of her coverage.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Nancy Macdonald Dies at 86; Aided Spain's Loyalist Exiles
description: Nancy Macdonald, the well-born anarchist who helped radicalize her husband, Dwight Macdonald, in the 1930's, managed his magazine Politics in the 1940's, and then struck out on her own in the 1950's to aid refugees of the Spanish civil war, died last Monday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 86 and had lived on East 10th Street for more than half a century.

title: Seeking Trauma Center
description: Trenton may be the state capital, but it is no place to be seriously injured. Victims of accidents or violence in Trenton whose injuries threaten death or permanent disability must go to a hospital in New Brunswick or Camden, where two of the state's six certified trauma centers are located. That could take 45 minutes -- too long, said Ira G. Shimp, the chief executive of Helene Fuld Medical Center in Trenton. The Fuld center is trying to become accredited as the state's newest trauma center. To do so, it must prove to regulators that it can provide trauma surgery teams, operating rooms, CAT scans and other services at a few minutes' notice around the clock. On Thursday, officials will appear before a State Health Department board to request certification.

title: Losing Races, and Shirts
description: Running for public office can be hazardous to a candidate's personal financial health, particularly if he or she loses. According to records filed last week with the Federal Election Commission, New Jersey's Congressional candidates are out hundreds of thousands of dollars they loaned to their campaigns, The Associated Press reported.

title: Serbian Leader Tries to Mute Anger Over Disputed Elections
description: Faced with huge street protests, the Government of Slobodan Milosevic appeared to try to mute anger today over its annulment of opposition victories in local elections by handing its opponents control of Serbia's second largest city.

title: Messier Takes Practice, But Is Likely Not to Play
description: Mark Messier needs neither surgery nor sympathy. But his hyperextended left elbow needs more time to recover.

title: Somaya Fahmy, 86, Egyptian Psychologist
description: Somaya Fahmy, a pioneer of clinical psychology in Egypt and a women's rights advocate who developed literacy programs for rural Arab villages, died in Cairo on Nov. 29. She was 86.

title: A Nightmare Along the Mississippi
description: The massive, muddy river that rolls through the heart of New Orleans and its people has always carried a certain danger from the towering freighters, twice the length of a football field, that churn through the treacherous currents. But the people here, both the ones who live here and the ones who visit, have always been drawn to the romance of the river's edge, to eat, drink and spend money.

title: Windows NT Chip Support Is Dropped
description: In a move that shows how efforts by I.B.M. and Motorola to establish a successful competitor to Intel's Pentium computer chip are flagging, both companies are dropping support for the Windows NT operating system on computers built around their Power PC microprocessor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VICTOR BORGE, the comedic pianist, has been making audiences laugh for 70 years, nowhere more so than in Copenhagen, where he celebrated the 70th anniversary of his concert stage debut earlier this month.

title: The Grande Dame of Archeology
description: Mary Leakey, who died in Kenya last week at 83, was one of the greatest heroes of the heroic age of paleoanthropology. The matriarch of an extraordinary family of fossil hunters, her own discoveries in decades of careful digging in the remote Rift Valley of East Africa helped shape our understanding of the origins and evolution of early humans. Tossed out of two convent schools, without even a high school diploma, she nevertheless won coveted scientific awards and honorary degrees. A shy helpmate to her more flamboyant husband, she went on to equal -- some say surpass -- his accomplishments.

title: As HUD Seeks to Avoid Cuts, Its Efforts for Homeless Are Praised
description: As he tries to fend off proposed cuts in his agency's budget, Housing and Urban Development Secretary Henry G. Cisneros has released a study by Barnard and Columbia Universities praising HUD's programs to help the homeless.

title: Six Straight Reasons For Knicks To Party
description: It was in the back of Jeff Van Gundy's mind on Saturday night. He did not think about it while he was drawing up the play that won the game. But afterward, he could not help but wonder.

description: As his two younger brothers cried in the background, a 6-year-old Bronx boy calmly told an emergency operator that his parents were dead and that someone had shot them, the police said yesterday.

title: A Night at the Opera, Or at the Multiplex?
description: All other things being more or less decent, the star attractions at the Metropolitan Opera's current revival of ''Tosca'' are Franco Zeffirelli's sets, which undeniably match the music and enhance the impression this work gives of live cinema. They lead one to wonder if Puccini had some experience of the movies in their infancy, or if it is just that film composers followed his way here of using the orchestra to set atmosphere, to direct movement and even to sing, as when ''E lucevan le stelle'' starts out as an aria for instruments with tenor accompaniment.

title: Hughes Electronics Wins Missile Contract
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation has won a $421.7 million contract to develop a new Pentagon missile, beating the Raytheon Company.
