description: A Soprano's Met Debut As a Debunker of Love

title: Boeing to Buy McDonnell Douglas
description: WASHINGTON  Boeing Co., the world's largest commercial aircraft maker, said Sunday it would buy its long-time rival McDonnell Douglas Corp. for $13.3 billion in stock, creating the world's largest integrated aerospace company.

title: Clinton Takes Aim at Critics on 'Right-Wing' Talk Radio
description: President Clinton today described a ''war of words in America where people are always bad-mouthing each other,'' and he called talk radio ''overwhelmingly right wing'' and ''not serving the country well.''

title: Jaspers Need a Little Charity to Beat Rams
description: Like most basketball games between Manhattan and Fordham, this one was intense. But as tough as Fordham was yesterday, Manhattan was tougher. The Jaspers did not score a basket in the last 5 minutes 27 seconds, but in the last 2:27 they did sink 10 of 12 free throws and won, 61-57.

title: A Sense of Well-Being Among Boeing Workers
description: More than a year ago, the fortunes of nearly 70,000 people at the world's largest airplane-manufacturing complex here seemed to have hit rock bottom. The Boeing Company was in a prolonged slump and was still laying off workers. And 30,000 machinists were on strike, trying to keep their jobs from being sent to overseas contractors.

title: Donald J. Mercer, 80, Television Executive
description: Donald J. Mercer, who was hired in 1933 as a page for NBC and retired in 1981 as a senior vice president for the television network, died on Dec. 5 at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 80.

title: L.I. Crash Investigators Dispute Their Leaders' Theories
description: A senior investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board, who has been working in the Long Island hangar where the wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 is being reassembled, said yesterday that he and other agency investigators directly involved in the wreckage analysis were surprised and disturbed by the assertion of his agency's leaders that they had identified a possible cause for the crash.

title: Salamander Deaths Add to Debate Over Protection
description: The deaths of 12 rare salamanders near Austin's most famous swimming hole are adding to the debate over enforcement of the Endangered Species Act and whether states can take the necessary steps to save rare species.

title: The World That Awaits U.N. Envoy
description: Razali Ismail, who has represented Malaysia at the United Nations for more than eight years and is this year's president of the General Assembly, thought about how he would describe the environment into which Bill Richardson is about to step as the new United States envoy here.

title: Marines Polish Command Skills, Switching Places With Traders
description: Col. Robert E. Lee skirted the unleaded gasoline pit, negotiated a thicket of telephone cords stretched as tight as trip wires and took the center of the New York Mercantile Exchange's main trading floor just before 3 P.M. last Monday.

title: Global Debate Over Treaties On Copyright
description: Will new copyright laws destroy the global village in order to save it?

title: Turks Hope U.S. Will Push Cyprus Pact
description: With President Clinton's new foreign policy team now nominated, Turkish officials are wondering whether the expected American ''big push'' to resolve the festering Cyprus conflict, and perhaps the larger Greek-Turkish confrontation, will materialize in 1997.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day yesterday misspelled the name of the lead underwriter for an offering by Netsource Communications Inc. It is Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.

description: High school basketball players, listed alphabetically by state, who bear watching in the New York metropolitan area this season:

title: Chess
description: Swiss-system tournaments were looked down upon as unfit for serious chess in the old Soviet Union. Since tournaments of this type are too big for each player to meet all of the others, the luck of the pairings creates a nest of tournaments, some weaker and some stronger. But these days in Russia, there is no choice. All the foremost competitors cannot be packed into a round-robin format. In this year's Russian Championship, there were 52 entrants, including 34 grandmasters. For a round robin, that would have required 51 rounds in the same number of days.

title: Blood Center Agrees To Change Its Practices
description: The New York Blood Center, which supplies about 80 percent of the blood used in New York City hospitals, agreed yesterday to overhaul its laboratory and record-keeping procedures to reduce the risk of having tainted blood reach a patient.

title: Accounts
description: * Sports and Recreation Inc., Tampa, Fla., to the Richards Group, Dallas, as the first agency to handle broadcast creative assignments for the sporting-goods chain. Horizon Media, New York, continues handling media and Nova Marketing Inc., Boston, handles print creative duties. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: Pinstripes For Wells? Looks Like It's a Deal
description: After willingly relinquishing baseball's most successful relief pitcher this year, the Yankees last night appeared to move close to completing what essentially would be a swap of free-agent starting pitchers with Baltimore. The Yankees, who eight days earlier lost the left-hander Jimmy Key to the Orioles, were nearing agreement with the left-hander David Wells, his agent said.

description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday about planned cutbacks by the Nippon Sanso Corporation misstated their scope. The company is closing a Thermos barbecue-grill factory in Freeport, Ill., and consolidating its household products divisions at a subsidiary in the Netherlands; it is not closing its entire Thermos Company subsidiary or its Dutch subsidiary.

title: Stadium Foes Can Force Vote
description: The decision on whether to build a minor league baseball stadium in a park alongside the Passaic River may be made by Newark voters. A park preservation group that opposes the stadium has gathered enough signatures on a petition to force a referendum, the City Clerk determined yesterday. The City Council has already authorized a $20 million bond issue to pay for the stadium; unless it repeals that measure within 20 days, a referendum must be held before mid-March, said Ira Karasick, a lawyer for the Save Riverbank Park Coalition.

title: Ritalin Use Is Lower Than Thought
description: RITALIN, a drug used to quell hyperactive children and perk up the inattentive, is being prescribed less than earlier reports had suggested, a study says. The earlier reports said that nearly six times as much Ritalin was used in 1995 as in 1990. In fact, the new study says, its use was just two and a half times as high.

title: Pentagon Pursues Proof in Gulf War Illnesses  To the Editor:    Your news article on a House subcommittee hearing (''Veterans Dept. Blames Pentagon For Delay in Gulf Health Studies,'' front page, Dec. 12) failed to report the assertion by Dr. Susan H. Mather, a senior public health officer at the Department of Veterans Affairs, that she was ''not aware of one'' Persian Gulf war veteran who was diagnosed ill because of exposure to chemical weapons.
description: That chemical alarms sounded during the gulf war has been known for years. Efforts to determine whether these alarms were real have failed to produce conclusive evidence of chemical exposure. But they are still being investigated. Thus, the Department of Defense believes you are incorrect to blame the military for ''inaccurate assurances that there was no evidence that American troops had been exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons during the Persian Gulf war in 1991.''

title: Union Plans a Strike Today at the Modern
description: Members of the Museum of Modern Art's professional employees union, which includes curators, librarians, sales people, graphic designers and conservators, voted 96 to 3 yesterday to hold a one-day strike today. Picket lines are to form at the museum's main entrance on West 53d Street, the entrances to the adjacent bookstore and in front of the design store across the street.

title: Fault Line of a New Generation
description: Ennio Capasa is the No. 1 designer for Hollywood hipsters haunting the Fred Segal/Ron Herman Melrose boutique. Celebrities actually buy his clothes at full retail price, instead of demanding designer handouts. His style has influenced heavyweight labels like Calvin Klein and Gucci. He, along with Helmut Lang, is most often credited for inventing the mood of men's fashion for the 1990's, much as Giorgio Armani did for the 80's.

title: A Giant in Jets and Foreign Policy
description: Long before it announced plans to acquire the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Boeing Company was already one of the most influential corporate voices in American foreign policy. It is the country's largest exporter, occasionally a back-channel conduit to China's leaders and the impetus for the tension between Europe and the United States over the huge subsidies and political favors that have bolstered the fortunes of Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that is Boeing's archrival.

title: Ascap Asks Royalties From Girl Scouts, and Regrets It
description: The queen of American songwriters, Marilyn Bergman, was dining out in Los Angeles last summer when she ran into Milton Berle.

title: 8 Candidates Competing for Chairmanship of Republican Party
description: The Republican Party is in the market for a new chairman, and about eight people who want the job are engaged in a scrappy, behind-the-scenes campaign that could signal what direction the party takes in the next four years.

title: Legal Fund for Clintons Rejects $639,000 Raised by Businessman
description: The legal defense fund established for President Clinton and his wife said today that it had returned or rejected more than $639,000 in questionable donations after private investigators were unable to verify the sources of the money.

title: Forecast of Severe Cold Snap Sends Gas and Oil Up Sharply
description: A forecast of frigid weather unnerved energy markets yesterday, sending prices surging on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about a professor, author and longtime head of the Spanish department at Barnard College misspelled her maiden name. She was Amelia Agostini del Rio, not Agostino.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: An Artistic Father for Half a Century
description: THE FATE OF A GESTURE

title: Hardtack For the Journey
description: The chairman decides that the man he wants most in the world to be president of the Walt Disney Company is an old friend from outside with a terrific reputation as a creative superagent. Less than a year later chairman and old creative friend aren't getting along at all well -- personality conflict, clash of working styles, that kind of thing.

title: Stick to Basics in Albany
description: The State Legislature returns to Albany today for a special session on reforming the New York City school system. The Senate and Assembly should stick as close to that agenda as possible, and avoid being sidetracked on issues that could be dealt with during normal business next month.

title: Carville's Political Theatrics Jolt the Holiday Calm
description: With Congress out of town, Washington finds itself in an end-of-year lull, suspended between Election Day and Inauguration Day with little to do but contemplate the second Clinton term and what pitfalls may lie ahead.

title: No Headline
description: George Soros is the only American who rivals the great philanthropists of the 1890's -- John D. Rockefeller Sr., Andrew Carnegie and Julius Rosenwald. -- NELSON ALDRICH JR., editor of The American Benefactor. $(A12:1.$)

title: CHRONICLE
description: L. JAY OLIVA, the president of New York University, is such a New York Knicks fan that when he had to go to Moscow during the playoffs four years ago with Andrew Schaffer, senior vice president and general counsel, he sent a photograph of them taken there to the Knicks. ''I wanted to tell them we were thinking of them,'' Dr. Oliva said yesterday.

title: Social Security's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Paul J. Goldsmith was named president of Franklin Spier Inc., New York, succeeding Len Fogge, who left to join the Showtime Networks unit of Viacom Inc., New York, as executive vice president for creative and marketing services. Mr. Goldsmith had been president at Goldsmith & Associates, Glen Rock, N.J., which closed.

title: A Payout Ends A Family Feud But Could Be Costly To Investors
description: SHARES in Value Line Inc., the investment advisory firm, have turned weak after rising substantially in the weeks following the announcement that a fight within the founding family for control of the company had been resolved.

title: L.P.G.A. Honors Top Golfers
description: Foreign golfers dominated the presentation of the Ladies Professional Golf Association's top awards yesterday, with Laura Davies of England leading the way as the tour's player of the year.

title: 3 Dead in L.I. Plane Crash
description: A small aircraft crashed yesterday in Connetquot River State Park on Long Island, killing the pilot and two passengers, the police said.

title: Walt Disney In China: Adventure Or Fantasy?
description: During a trip to Los Angeles in November, Mayor Xu Kuangdi of Shanghai stopped at Disneyland, like many Chinese officials who go to the United States.

title: Spinoff Sets NCR's Value at $3.96 Billion
description: The AT&T Corporation plans to distribute 101.4 million shares of the NCR Corporation in this month's spinoff, valuing the money-losing computer maker at $3.96 billion -- about half of what AT&T paid for it in 1991.

title: Some Will Never Learn to Love Superstores
description: To the Editor:

title: Tense Zaire Is Primped For Return Of Mobutu
description: Rushing to complete preparations for the return of President Mobutu Sese Seko, the Zairian Government distributed free cloth bearing Mr. Mobutu's likeness today, hung banners hailing the President's imminent arrival and issued elaborate instructions to dignitaries and journalists for the ceremonies on Tuesday.

title: Quietly, in Isolated Off-Limits Area, Rarest of Wolves Is Being Groomed For Return to the Southwest Wild
description: AT dusk one day last month, a captive Mexican gray wolf known as Cisco by his keepers at the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago became the first of his kind to walk out of a crate into newly built chain-link pens for Mexican wolves at the isolated Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge in central New Mexico.

title: New U.S. Muscle May Send China to Europeans Instead
description: China, expected to be the world's biggest customer for commercial aircraft in the coming decade, is looking at the Boeing Company's planned purchase of McDonnell Douglas with more than casual attention.

title: Alas, Poor Hamlet! He's Turning Rotten in Serbia
description: There are many ways to ruin Shakespeare, but Belgrade's newest production of ''Hamlet'' -- meant to convey the message that usurping authority, even illegitimate authority, only brings chaos and ruin -- is certainly one of the most novel.

title: Reeves-Giants Pairing Was Not Meant to Be
description: With one game remaining in a 6-9 season, the handwriting on the wall at the Giants' offices has apparently got so large that even Coach Dan Reeves can read it. To Reeves it reads: YOU'RE OUTTA HERE!

title: Red Storm Rising? Champions Are Young
description: There is something to be said for dynasties in college soccer. North Carolina's women captured their 14th title in 16 years this season. Virginia's men won four consecutive championships in the 1990's.

title: Social Security's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Limits Off Tickets
description: In October 1995, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill lifting price restrictions for 18 months on sports and concert tickets resold by brokers. The trial period will not end for another four months, but yesterday, the Assembly's Consumer Affairs and Regulated Professions Committee approved a measure to make deregulation permanent. The bill's co-sponsor, Assemblyman Walter J. Kavanaugh, a Republican of Somerville, said prices for many concerts and sports events have dropped since the restrictions were eliminated because the number of licensed brokers has increased to 54 from 2.

title: Ontario Doctors Reach Agreement on Fees
description: Doctors in Ontario have reached a tentative agreement with the provincial government that would end a monthlong protest that interrupted medical care in Canada's largest province.

title: Patterns
description: Thinking Big for Age 10

title: Everything Seems Right In Rangers' World
description: After 34 games, the Rangers are above the .500 mark for the first time this season. After missing four games with a hyper-extended left elbow, their captain, Mark Messier, is again playing.

title: At Football-Mad Clemson, Coach Rick Barnes Has Led a Basketball Revival
description: A child from a broken home on the wrong side of the tracks doesn't fear an oncoming train. A gym rat who kept getting turned down for assistant coach jobs, including one at Hofstra, doesn't back down from a fight with Dean Smith. A mischievous dare-taker who once rode his bike naked merely winks at the improbability of basketball in this long-lost oasis of football.

title: NEEDY WHO LOSE PARENTAL RIGHTS GAIN IN TOP COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the parent-child relationship is so fundamental that a state cannot prevent poor people from appealing the termination of their parental rights simply because they lack the money to pay court costs.

title: Geologists Link Black Sea Deluge To Farming's Rise
description: LONG before the splendid palaces and minarets of Istanbul lined its shore, the Bosporus was little more than a narrow spillway where fresh water from the ancient Black Sea flowed out to the Aegean Sea and on to the Mediterranean. Then rising sea levels worldwide brought about a cataclysmic reversal. Suddenly, sea water cascaded through the Bosporus with a force 400 times mightier than that of Niagara Falls, the terrifying sound of the roar carrying for at least 60 miles.

title: Italy Assigns a Value To Its Shares in Stet
description: The Italian Government released a decree yesterday to transfer control of the telecommunications company Stet S.p.A. to the national Treasury, valuing the 62 percent stake in Stet at a minimum of 14.53 trillion lire ($9.7 billion). That figure produces a minimum value for the entire company of 23.4 trillion lire ($15.6 billion).

title: She's No Rodman
description: Clarissa Davis-Wrightsil, a forward for the New England Blizzard, was fined $1,500 and suspended without pay for two games for hitting a Seattle player in the head during the first American Basketball League all-star game in Hartford, Conn.

title: Toxic Spill at a Factory
description: An adhesives factory and a nearby condominium complex were partly evacuated yesterday after more than 200 gallons of a highly toxic solvent spilled at the factory's loading dock. Officials of the Sika Corporation said they refused to accept a shipment of 55-gallon drums of toluene diisocyanate because the containers were bulging. While the delivery truck was parked at the dock, four drums burst open, Bergen County health officials said.

title: A Payoff for Lives Twisted by Gulf War
description: In the next few weeks, some of the world's lower-income workers -- from strapping members of Polish construction crews to Egyptian agricultural hands to Filipino nurses -- are going to be pleasantly astonished by the arrival of a check for $2,500.

title: For Nets, Filling the Lineup Proves to Be a Painful Task
description: The Nets' roster looks about as bare as a bachelor's refrigerator right now: a team cleaned out by injuries, left empty but for a few leftovers.

title: Controversy Finds Irvin Once Again
description: Now that the Cowboys have wrapped up the National Football Conference Eastern Division title and the home field for the first round of the playoffs, they should be able to concentrate on defending their Super Bowl championship. Right?

title: Analysts Are Optimistic About the Proposed Deal
description: The proposed merger of the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation received the blessings of Wall Street and aerospace industry analysts yesterday, who said the deal would cement Boeing's leadership in commercial aircraft and military contracting.

title: Standoff Between Giuliani and State Democrats Threatens a City Tax
description: Negotiations over extending an income-tax surcharge that paid for thousands of new police officers in New York City broke down tonight because of a standoff between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Assembly Democrats over how to spend $450 million generated from the tax.

title: Organized Labor Outlines Ambitious Goals for the Next Congress
description: Even though the A.F.L.-C.I.O. failed in its efforts to return Congress to Democratic control this year, John J. Sweeney, the federation's president, outlined ambitious legislative goals yesterday that included revising the new welfare law and revamping health care to provide medical insurance to more children.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS IN DEAL FOR ITALIAN GLASS MAKER
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Italy's largest maker of glass containers, Avir S.p.A., for about $580 million in cash, to expand its overseas business. Owens-Illinois, based in Toledo, Ohio, a maker of glass and plastic containers, said it would buy 76 percent of the company from Avir's chairman and his family and would begin a tender offer for an additional 21 percent held by the public. Another 3 percent interest would be bought from private owners after details were worked out. Owens-Illinois said it would finance the acquisition with bank loans. The $580 million offer values Avir at 19,988 lire, or $13.12, a share. Its stock closed yesterday at 16,870 lire.

title: CAMDEN PROPERTY TRUST TO ACQUIRE PARAGON GROUP
description: Camden Property Trust, a real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Paragon Group, which owns apartments in the South and the Midwest, for $338 million in stock. Camden, which is based in Houston, would give Paragon shareholders 0.64 Camden share for each share of Paragon, also a real estate investment trust. The transaction, approved by the boards of both companies, values Paragon's shares at $18.32 each. Camden would also assume $287 million of Paragon's debt, said Richard J. Campo, Camden's chairman and chief executive. Shares of Camden rose 12.5 cents, to $28.625. Shares of Paragon, which is based in Dallas, fell 25 cents, to $16.375. The announcement was made after the close of trading.

title: Chi-Chi's Names Campbell Mithun
description: Chi-Chi's, a chain of Mexican-style restaurants based in Louisville, Ky., and owned by Family Restaurants Inc., has named Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to handle the creative part of its account as well as efforts like in-store promotions, which had been handled by various agencies and freelancers on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $12 million. The decision came after a three-month review that had been narrowed to Campbell Mithun; Evans, Hardy & Young in San Francisco, which continues to handle the media part of the account; Earle Palmer Brown in Bethesda, Md., and McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C. Campbell Mithun is owned by top managers and the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Some Issues Are Resolved In Bid for School Changes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders said tonight that they had resolved several sticking points on a bill to change the way New York City's schools are governed and were optimistic that they would reach a final agreement for Tuesday's special one-day session of the Legislature.

title: Group Sues I.R.S. In I.B.M. Buyout
description: A group of 2,139 former employees of the International Business Machines Corporation sued the Internal Revenue Service yesterday seeking $46 million of income tax refunds. The employees contend that severance packages received when their jobs were eliminated should not be taxed.

title: Boeing's Deal Quickens Pace For Arms Industry Takeovers
description: Anyone trying to understand the pressures behind the frenzy of billion-dollar mergers that are reshaping weapons production in this country need have looked no further than the classified ads in The St. Louis Post-Dispatch last month.

title: Ohio State's Harris Takes Over at Pitt
description: WALT HARRIS, the Ohio State assistant who built his career on defense and his reputation on offense, was chosen yesterday to succeed JOHNNY MAJORS as Pitt's coach.

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES TO BUY ELJER FOR $171.7 MILLION
description: Zurn Industries said yesterday that it would buy Eljer Industries for $24 a share, or $171.7 million, to combine Zurn, a maker of pipes and fittings, with a leading maker of sinks and toilets. In addition, Zurn, based in Erie, Pa., would pay as much as $30 million to settle claims in the bankruptcy of Eljer's U.S. Brass unit, bringing the total value of the deal to about $27.50 a share. Shares of Eljer, based in Dallas, soared 75 percent yesterday, or $10.125, to $23.625. Shares of Zurn fell $2, to $24.125.

title: With Big Money and Brash Ideas, A Billionaire Redefines Charity
description: At the peak of a storm last February, several of the nation's most gifted philosophers and political scientists met for a weekend at the Westchester County estate of George Soros, the Hungarian-born billionaire financier. As the wind rattled the windows, Mr. Soros raised a glass in honor of his guests and gave them a challenge: if they were to advise him on how to spend more money each year than the Ford Foundation does on philanthropy, much of it in the United States, what would they suggest?

title: High Court Won't Hear School Appeal On Bible Club
description: The student Bible study club will hold its regular weekly meeting at Roslyn High School Thursday night, but this time it will do so courtesy of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Vons Accepts the Second Bid by Safeway
description: More than six weeks after it made an offer to buy the 65 percent of the Vons Companies it did not already own, Safeway Inc. said yesterday that Vons had accepted a second bid, worth $1.56 billion in stock.

title: Nothing New Under the Light Towers
description: BASEBALL has become like square dancing, or so it seems. At every turn you get a new partner. John Wetteland, who showed up only 20 months ago in Yankee pinstripes from Montreal, and Los Angeles before that, has now skipped off to Texas. David Wells, who was with Baltimore last year and with Detroit and Cincinnati the year before, and Toronto before that, appears set to whirl into town as a Bronx hurler.

title: Major, Feeling Political Heat, Plans to Step Up Slaughter of Cows
description: In a retreat before European Union demands, the British Government announced today that it would increase the number of cattle to be slaughtered in its effort to eradicate mad cow disease.

title: Laurens van der Post, 90, Dies; Thoughtful Man of Adventure
description: Laurens van der Post, the South African-born author, explorer and soldier who became a mentor to Prince Charles and a godfather to his son Prince William, died on Sunday at his home in London. He had turned 90 on Friday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Rolston's Short-Handed Goal Sends Devils on a Scoring Spree
description: Their power play continues to sputter at the bottom of the National Hockey League. With that avenue closed, the Devils found an alternate route tonight: give the other team a power play.

title: Fishing, Cattle and Survival:Major Is Pushed Into a Corner
description: BRUSSELS  With an embarrassing reversal in British policy on beef, the government of Prime Minister John Major signaled Monday that its long fight over European policy had turned into a daily struggle for survival.

title: Next for Stephanopoulos, a Capital Memoir
description: It's official. To the many titles of George Stephanopoulos will soon be added that of author.

title: H. B. Keck, 83; Led Superior Oil and Charity
description: Howard B. Keck, a former chairman of the Superior Oil Company, philanthropist and racehorse breeder, died on Saturday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: From France's Premier, an Unaccustomed Cri de Coeur in Print
description: In an attempt to break with the image of unfeeling technocrat that has made him France's most unpopular Prime Minister, Alain Juppe has abruptly published a book full of references to love, personal suffering and the transcending power of passion.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Killed by Car
description: A 16-year-old girl was killed and a 15-year-old boy was critically injured when a car struck four teen-age pedestrians on a darkened road in the Meadowlands on Sunday night, the police said.

title: Mother Confronts Her Mistakes and Her Family's
description: The stark facts of Cecilia Gibson's life frustrate her. She is 37, healthy and able to work. But she does not have a job. She has five children, two with infants of their own, and she cares for all seven alone. The father of three of her children is in jail, she said. The father of another has disappeared and pays no child support.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Time Again For Old Idea: 51st State?
description: SENATOR JOSEPH L. BRUNO took time the other day from the horses and swimming pool on his estate in Rensselaer County to visit New York City and inform the locals that their way of life would soon change.

title: New Partner in Bid For Austrian Bank
description: A group led by EA-Generali A.G., an Austrian insurer, emerged yesterday as the favorite to buy Creditanstalt-Bankverein A.G., Austria's second-largest bank, after Union Bank of Switzerland agreed to join the estimated $1.5 billion bid.

title: Bookstore Bounces Back With Mount Kisco's Help
description: The folks at the Mount Kisco Book Company knew their store was well liked in the community, but it was not until something really bad happened that they got a glimpse of just how deeply the affection ran.

title: The End Is Near For Reeves Era
description: Last Friday, Dan Reeves went down the hall at Giants Stadium to speak with the co-owner Wellington Mara. When Reeves poked his head in the door, he saw Mara; the other co-owner, Bob Tisch, and General Manager George Young. With rumors continuing to circulate that he would be fired, Reeves couldn't help wondering if the hierarchy was talking about him.

title: Fox and Time Warner Square Off Over Ad
description: The angry corporate feud between Fox and Time Warner has escalated again, with Fox seeking to draw football fans into the dispute by placing ads in newspapers in several cities warning that they might be left scrambling to see this year's Super Bowl.

title: Trial Set in Senna's Death
description: The head of a top Formula One racing team will be tried Feb. 20 in Italy on manslaughter charges in connection with the 1994 death of the star driver AYRTON SENNA.

title: Prices Plunge As Factory Output Climbs
description: Treasury prices dropped sharply yesterday after a stronger-than-expected manufacturing report, weak dollar and supply concerns discouraged many buyers.

title: Storm Swirls Over Aboriginal Salmon In Maine's Rivers
description: NO less than the eagle, the wolf and the bear, the bullet-sleek Atlantic salmon has inspired human wonder. It captivated the Romans, who named it ''salio'' (the leaper), and Izaak Walton, who in 1653 crowned it the king of freshwater fish. The species even figures in Cro-Magnon cave art.

title: Earth's Core, a Planet Within the Planet, Is Spun by Twin Streams of Molten Iron
description: Remote and poorly known, the inner core of the Earth is beginning to give up some of its secrets to scientists listening to faint rumbles in the ground with seismic instruments and probing the planet's inner fury with the visualizations of supercomputers.

title: Conseco in Deal to Buy Yet Another Insurer
description: Conseco Inc., a rapidly growing insurer, said yesterday that it was buying Pioneer Financial Services Inc. in a stock swap valued at $417 million. Conseco also agreed to take on $60 million of Pioneer's debt.

title: In Polish Film, Brooklyn Isn't Paved With Zlotys
description: Adam Baldyga, movie extra for half a day, stood on the stone steps of his Lutheran church in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and as the film director went over last-minute instructions and the cameras rolled, saw his own life unfold before his eyes.

title: Abduction Casts New Doubts on Slovakia Chief
description: On a sleepy road just outside this capital in August 1995, a blond man at the wheel of a Mercedes-Benz was cut off at a roadblock, jumped by a group of strangers, hauled from the driver's seat and thrown into the trunk of a waiting car.

title: A Holiday for Velvet
description: December is party time, and many holiday parties call for dressing up in something special. Some years, what looks right is shiny lame or Lurex. Other times it's sparkly sequins. But this season it's cut velvet or burn-out velvet, which has the nap burned away in areas to form a textural pattern.

title: Donnelley Confirms Plans to Sell Stream
description: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, the nation's largest printer, confirmed today that it planned to sell Stream International, a money-losing company it formed last year as part of a strategy to expand into software manufacturing and distribution.

title: 2 Airlines Deny Report of Merger
description: Lufthansa and Scandinavian Airlines System denied a Danish newspaper report today that the alliance between the two airlines could lead to a merger or an exchange of holdings.

title: Municipal Bond Dealers Face Scrutiny
description: In recent years, Wall Street's municipal bond operations have been rocked by one scandal after another: evidence of political payoffs; fallout from the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.; the conviction of one of the industry's leading advisers for concealing his role in steering business to one firm in return for a fee.

title: A Giant Gets Bigger
description: The acquisition of McDonnell Douglas will not only cement Boeing's leadership in aircraft and military contracting, it will also increase its already large influence in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: The Media column in Business Day yesterday about William J. Bennett's campaign against the distribution of gangsta rap referred incorrectly to a change in the ownership of Interscope Records, a label that offers gangsta rappers and other artists. A 50 percent stake was sold to MCA Inc. this year by Inter scope's founders, Ted Field and Jimmy Iovine, not by Time Warner. Time Warner had earlier sold its 50 percent stake back to the founders.

title: Q&A
description: In a Whirl

title: CHRONICLE
description: A wedding in the offing: The AGA KHAN, spiritual leader of the world's 20 million Ismaili Muslims, a Shiite sect, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Princess ZAHRA AGA KHAN, 26, the oldest of his three children, to MARK BOYDEN, a London businessman.

title: Bristol to Buy 61 More Holiday Inns
description: The Bristol Hotel Company said yesterday that it would acquire 61 Holiday Inns from Bass P.L.C. of Britain for $659 million, in stock, cash and debt. The transaction, expected to close next spring, will make Bristol, which is based in Dallas, the world's biggest Holiday Inn franchisee, with 84 properties, and one of the biggest owner-operators of full-service hotels.

title: Volatile Day of Market Losses, Led by I.B.M.
description: Stocks extended their December slide yesterday as computer issues tumbled in the late afternoon.

title: Former Daiwa Trader Sentenced In Cover-Up of $1.1 Billion Loss
description: A former bond trader at Daiwa Bank Ltd. was sentenced to four years in prison yesterday for concealing $1.1 billion in trading losses from United States regulators for more than a decade.

title: Globetrotter Owner Isn't in It Just for Laughs
description: Peals of timeless young laughter came from the basketball court at Chelsea Piers yesterday afternoon: the Harlem Globetrotters were up to their old tricks. Timeless tricks. These were students from P.S. 163 in Manhattan. They laughed -- as their mothers and grandmothers, fathers and grandfathers, had laughed -- at the Globetrotters' routines.

title: INSIDE
description: Tax Surcharge Talks Fail

title: Pataki Tells State Agencies To Melt Their Old Handguns
description: Responding to concerns over the fate of handguns once used by state law enforcement officials, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday ordered all guns no longer needed by state agencies to be melted down as soon as they are replaced.

title: Watching Teams' Fortunes Sink Slowly in the West
description: The wild West has become the mild West.

title: Still Timely, Yet a Writer of His Time
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald's centennial year should not end without a final celebration, especially now, when fiction has lost its pride of place as the form all serious writers must measure themselves by.

title: Beyond The Birds And Bees
description: WNET's ''Sex and Other Matters of Life and Death'' is bound to raise a few hackles, especially among entities like the New York City Board of Education, which is shown turning a deaf ear to the argument that ignorance equals death when the subject of sex education was raised a couple of years ago. Produced and directed by Roger Weisberg, the documentary takes for granted that no matter how many warnings they are given, adolescents are going to engage in sex. How could it be otherwise in a society that blatantly uses sex to sell everything from sneakers to beer?

title: Industrial Output Surges; Rise is Biggest in 9 Months
description: America's industrial production surged in November, showing the largest gain in nine months as strikes against the General Motors Corporation ended and causing a positive ripple effect through the economy, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Sober Steps Through Feverish Verse
description: John Aler is a welcome presence in the midst of other singers because he brings to music a fastidiousness that they often do not. The rhythm is right, ensemble is respected, and there is great caring both for the shape of words and what they mean. This American tenor evidently enjoys being a good musician as well as a maker of handsome sounds. In a crowd, he personifies control.

title: Towards Safe and Sane Holiday Computing
description: COMPUTER products are truly gifts that keep on giving. Long after the spirit of the holidays has disappeared elsewhere, the warm glow lives on at help desks, where resident elves patiently turn wretched recipients into rejoicing users. The computer industry's merry tradition is to fix known defects only when absolutely necessary, so assume problems are not your fault until you get proof otherwise. Novices and veterans alike naturally tend to assume they must not be ''getting it'' when confronted by failures of this sometimes daunting technology. More often than not the problems are all too real. After a day on hold with the elves, I offer some suggestions to help maintain holiday computing sanity.

title: Plea Deal in Killing of Woman On the Subway Is Criticized
description: A 15-year-old who admitted in court yesterday that he pushed a young woman to her death from a moving subway train while robbing her will be eligible for parole in as little as five years under a plea agreement that drew criticism from prosecutors.

title: To Give or Not? The Gadget Decision
description: EEK. One week left. Time running out. No time to think, let alone shop. Need clever, fool-proof gift for computer user, minimum hassle. Not software; too confusing, too common. Something solid, like hardware. Aim car toward computer store, dash in, hand column to clerk and point at budget category.

title: Primitive Ritual Emotions, Still Raw in a 2d Revival
description: ''The Trojan Women'' a period piece?

title: Police Chief's Quest for a Second Term Threatens to Divide Los Angeles
description: Willie L. Williams came to post-riot Los Angeles in 1992 as a healer, the black Police Chief who parachuted into the epicenter of American racial conflict to help restore public trust in law enforcement here.

title: Feeling Pressure, Airbus Hopes to Respond
description: The Boeing Company's plans to acquire McDonnell Douglas have shaken Europe's Airbus Industrie.

title: Student Who Hid Pregnancy Has Stillborn Boy at Fairfield U. Dormitory
description: A Fairfield University student who hid her pregnancy from her family gave birth in a dormitory bathroom on Sunday to a stillborn baby boy, but the police said the father, who was visiting from New York, immediately summoned help, and a preliminary investigation yesterday found no criminal conduct by the parents.

title: All Aspirin Poses Risk Of Bleeding
description: FOR those ascribing to the new wisdom of ''an aspirin a day keeps the doctor away,'' it may be no safer for the digestive tract to take buffered or enteric-coated versions, a new study suggests.

title: Agassi to Play in Davis Cup
description: No one can accuse Andre Agassi of not doing his part for creative schedule making.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IMC MORTGAGE INC., Tampa, Fla., will buy Mortgage America Inc., Bay City, Mich., for an initial payment of about $26.6 million in stock.

title: Italy's Marxist Party Still a Power
description: As literal Marxists, members of Italy's Communist Refounding party leave little to the imagination. Their flag bears the hammer and sickle, they call one another ''comrade,'' and when they get together for a party congress, as they did last week in a vast hotel basement in Rome, they give a warm rendition of the old Communist hymn, the Internationale.

title: Blood Center to Revamp Its Testing and Training
description: The New York Blood Center, which supplies about 80 percent of the blood used in New York City hospitals, agreed yesterday to overhaul its laboratory and record-keeping procedures to reduce the risk of having tainted blood reach a patient.

title: An Aerospace Colossus
description: The proposed $13 billion takeover of McDonnell Douglas by Boeing would create an aerospace behemoth that, for all its size, would do little to stifle competition in the commercial and military aircraft industries. Instead the newly merged giant would simply become a more effective global competitor.

title: What the Russians Added
description: Kurt Masur's current program at the New York Philharmonic is a vivid reminder of the pivotal roles Russians have played internationally in the music of this century, from the restless modernism of Igor Stravinsky to the searching post-modernism of Alfred Schnittke.

title: A Move to License Guards
description: If the local mall can sometimes seem as dangerous as a city street, maybe the armed security guards hired to protect shoppers should be licensed. That was the reasoning behind a bill approved yesterday by the Assembly's Consumer Affairs and Regulated Professions Committee.

title: KLM to Buy Its Shares, Reducing State's Holding
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that it would pay 976.5 million guilders ($560.2 million) to buy some of its common and preferred shares in a deal that will trim the state's stake in the carrier to 25 percent from 38 percent. KLM will pay 46.281 guilders ($26.55) a share for the 17.3 million common shares and a total of 176.25 million guilders for 11.75 million preferred shares. (Dow Jones)

title: This Congregation Reaches Out to Community
description: To the Editor:

title: DART OFFERS TO BUY, OR SELL, STAKE IN SUPERMARKET CHAIN
description: The Dart Group Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to either buy or sell a 50 percent stake in the Shoppers Food Warehouse Corporation for $210 million. Dart, based in Landover, Md., will either buy the 50 percent stake owned by the investor Kenneth Herman or sell its own 50 percent stake to him. Under a stockholders' agreement between Dart and Mr. Herman, the investor must accept one of the offers within 60 days, with the transaction closing 60 days later. Shoppers Food Warehouse is a 34-store supermarket chain operating in the Washington area. It had sales of $836 million and net income of $18.9 million in the year that ended on June 29.

title: Cablevision Sets Link to Internet For L.I. Viewers
description: It will not unclog the Long Island Expressway. But thousands of cable television subscribers across Long Island will be getting a new service designed to ease traffic jams on the Internet.

title: Union Plans To Market Own H.M.O.
description: One of New York State's most powerful unions is planning to market its own new managed-care health plan to the state's 2.5 million union members, a move that could deal a serious blow to huge insurers like Empire Blue Cross and H.I.P., which have relied predominantly on labor unions for their patient base.

title: Up in Abe's Room
description: Somebody is bound to call it Abegate. I mean this business of the White House renting out the Lincoln Bedroom for rates varying from $750,000 to $1.2 million per night.

title: Michael Ovitz, Hollywood's Last Tycoon
description: To hear his detractors tell it, the resignation of Michael Ovitz, Disney's second-in-command, was as inevitable as the fall of a hero in a Greek tragedy. Mr. Ovitz made too many enemies, they say. His bullying and strong-arming didn't fit in the sedate corporate world. He couldn't take orders. He didn't know how to read a spreadsheet. His schemes were harebrained. Above all, he had too much hubris for the business gods not to take him down.

title: Sehorn Is One Man the Team Does Want Back
description: While the Giants have been dealing with the status of their coach, they have also quietly begun negotiations with cornerback Jason Sehorn, one of the best defensive players on the team this season.

title: Chance of Heart Attack Increases For Those Who Suffer Depression
description: DEPRESSION may be as powerful a predictor of a looming heart attack as high blood pressure or soaring cholesterol rates, researchers report. A new study that traced people 13 years after they had been screened for depression, found that those who were depressed were four times as likely to have a heart attack as those with a more cheery state of mind.

title: An 'All You Can Eat' Price Is Clogging Internet Access
description: The most popular number for computer users in 1996 has become $19.95, which is emerging as the standard monthly price for unlimited access to the Internet. But this new ''all you can eat'' price is rapidly causing indigestion among network-access providers, phone companies and many customers.

title: The Real Hungarian Count Was No 'English Patient'
description: The character compassionately depicted in the film ''The English Patient'' as a desert explorer of enigmatic origins is based on a real-life Hungarian who served German military intelligence in World War II and then, apparently, spied for the Soviet Union.

title: Netanyahu's Hebron Dilemma
description: Weeks of wrangling about whether Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will -- or should -- agree to a partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Hebron have been intensified by his decision to increase economic aid to the Jewish settlements and by the murder of a Jewish woman and her child near Ramallah, another West Bank city.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES APPOINTS ACTING CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. named Gerald L. Gitner acting chief ex ecutive and vice chairman, and David M. Kennedy acting chief operat ing officer. The interim appointments were made as the airline contin ues its search for a new president and chief executive to succeed Jeff Erickson, who plans to leave the company. Mr. Gitner, most recently the chairman of the New York investment firm Avalon Group Ltd., will be assisted by Mr. Erickson until a replacement is found. Mr. Kennedy, most recently the chairman of the Bank of Ireland pension fund and an aviation consultant to the World Bank, will serve in the newly created post of chief operating officer.

title: New Zealanders Invest In Australian Publisher
description: Brierley Investments Ltd. of New Zealand said yesterday that it had bought a 20 percent stake in John Fairfax Holdings Ltd., one of Australia's major newspaper publishing companies. Fairfax publishes The Sydney Morning Herald, The Melbourne Age and The Australian Financial Review.

title: Kotite Ponders 1-14 Resume
description: Across the Hudson, Dan Reeves acknowledged today that his Giants coaching days are evidently over. Here at the Jets, where dreams die harder, Rich Kotite ran his Blue Monday news conference as usual. But he didn't appear to leave himself much of a future, either.

title: Israel's Rash Settlement Policy
description: The Clinton Administration has been moving sensitively but firmly over the past few days to restart stalled peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians and to head off a dangerous new round of tensions over Israel's reinstatement of generous financial subsidies for Jewish settlers in the West Bank. The resumption of negotiations on Hebron and other issues yesterday is one encouraging result. But the Administration needs to keep pressing its concern over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's increasingly incautious handling of the settlements issue.

title: Yes, Money Still Talks. Bowe Only Mumbles.
description: Before Time Warner considers hiring Riddick Bowe for another pay-per-view bout, it should listen to Bowe's post-fight comments on TVKO Saturday night after he was savaged senseless by Andrew Golota but won by disqualification.

title: Union to Start H.M.O.
description: Unhappy with existing health care plans, 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, said it would market its own health maintenance organization to the state's 2.5 million union members.

title: Thief Calls Off The Weddings Of 6 in Queens
description: Couples who planned to tie the knot in Queens yesterday were out of luck. The marriage bureau was closed all day after a masked bandit entered the office just before opening time, pulled a gun on a deputy city clerk and fled with $6,700 from the safe.

title: Those Numbers Show The Jazz Will Be Tough
description: Cautioning against the possibility of Utah taking his team to school Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy has done his homework.

title: Giving Voice to Testosterone, With Id Rampant
description: The Jon Spencer Blues Explosion isn't about the blues. It's about energy: frantic, headlong, jump-out-of-your-skin energy, testosterone hopped up on anarchy. The singer wants love, and he wants to shake things up. ''When I say 'Come on!' I mean, 'Come ON!' '' Mr. Spencer proclaimed when the band played at the Roxy on Saturday night.

title: Netanyahu at Bay: Bloom Is Off His Promise
description: This week marks six months since Benjamin Netanyahu took office as Prime Minister of Israel, and the country is already a different place, though perhaps not in the ways he promised.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO LIMIT INSPECTIONS' SCOPE AT NURSING HOMES
description: The Clinton Administration is proposing to scale back inspections of many nursing homes that care for elderly people under Medicaid and Medicare.

title: Weather Slows Search of Riverside Wreckage
description: Heavy rain and wind made already unstable rubble even more treacherous today at the site of a giant freighter's collision with a crowded riverfront shopping mall, forcing rescuers to postpone the search for survivors or victims.

title: Congress Should Act On Women's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Exoneration Shows New Military Ethos
description: Gen. Curtis LeMay, head of the nation's airborne nuclear strike force in the 1950's, was notoriously unforgiving of commanders whose air crews failed no-notice combat inspections.

title: Low Exposure Is Risky
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Confidence Slips in Germany
description: Business confidence in western Germany unexpectedly fell in November, breaking a four-month increase in optimism and creating doubt about the strength of economic expansion in 1997. Ifo, an economic research institute, said yesterday that its index of business confidence fell to 96.9 in November from a revised 97.3 in October.

title: Power Brokers and the Maximum Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: After Eurotunnel Fire, Train Service Is Inching Back on Track
description: A month after a fire that put one section of track out of service until next spring, the rail tunnel under the English Channel has limped back into action, but at only a fraction of peak capacity.

title: Playing for Pride, Dolphins Stop Bills
description: Words came hard tonight for Bruce Smith, the Buffalo Bills' defensive end.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a telephone dictation error, an article yesterday about Miami's financial turmoil rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from Max Castro, a sociologist, about calls for the city to merge with the government of Dade County. Mr. Castro said, ''The proposal to abolish Miami is part of a larger trend toward class and ethnic Balkanization of urban space and economic polarization of American society.'' (He did not say ''vulcanization.'')

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Investors Support Merger

title: Officer Is Held in Shooting
description: An off-duty Bronx police officer was arrested on attempted murder charges early yesterday and accused of firing three shots at a romantic rival as a sometime girlfriend looked on, the police said. None of the shots hit anyone.

title: Spanish Phone Company To Cut 15% of Its Jobs
description: Telefonica de Espana will cut 11,000 jobs, or 15 percent of its staff, by 2001 as the company, the dominant telephone provider in Spain, braces to meet competition, its chairman and chief executive said yesterday. The executive, Juan Villalonga, also said the Government would soon announce that it would sell more shares in the company early next year. The Government, which owns 21 percent of Telefonica, agreed this month to advance introduction of full telecommunications competition to 1998 from 2001.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the crash of the freighter Bright Field into the Riverwalk shopping mall in New Orleans misspelled the surname of the freighter's pilot. He is Ted Davisson, not Davis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA CARTLAND, the 95-year-old romance novelist, is trying to persuade the town fathers of Tewkesbury, England, to convert one of her ancestral homes into a museum that would celebrate her life.

title: Naumburg Saluted By Winners
description: If you've got it, flaunt it, the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation seemed to be saying at its celebratory 70th-anniversary concert at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: Best Western Looks At Its Marketing
description: Best Western International said yesterday that it had begun an examination of its advertising and marketing efforts that would include an assessment of the relationship with Rogge Effler & Partners in Los Angeles, its agency of four years. The Best Western lodging chain is estimated to spend $18 million annually on advertising.

title: DeLorean Loses Some Land
description: John Z. DeLorean, the failed automobile magnate, will lose the farm, but he'll keep the house. In a court-approved settlement yesterday, Mr. DeLorean agreed to give 400 of the 434 acres of his Lamington Farm estate to the Merrill Lynch Credit Corporation, to which he owes $8 million in mortgage loan payments and interest, said his lawyer, David C. Roberts. Mr. DeLorean will keep the 34 acres on which his Georgian mansion and several cottages stand. Mr. DeLorean, 71, is retired and lives on Social Security, Mr. Roberts said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: American Home Products Will Buy the Rest of Genetics Institute
description: The American Home Products Corporation, which bought a majority stake in Genetics Institute Inc. in 1992, moved yesterday to buy the rest of the company after a new blood-clotting therapy being developed by Genetics Institute cleared a regulatory hurdle.

title: Don't Limit Inquiries by Independent Counsel
description: To the Editor:

title: After 'Today,' an Uncertain Tomorrow
description: Bryant Gumbel was sitting in his tastefully cluttered, librarylike office at Rockefeller Center, feet propped on his desk, hands clasped behind his head. With only a couple of weeks to go before he leaves NBC's ''Today'' program after a record-setting 15 years as its host, and with no certainty where he would be working after Jan. 3, Mr. Gumbel looked as unperturbed as a man in a hammock rocking in the afternoon sun.

title: Mother Still Mourns Racial-Killing Victim
description: For most New Yorkers, the memory and emotional impact of what happened in Howard Beach, Queens, 10 years ago this Friday have faded. But for Jean Griffith Sandiford, the racial killing remains as vivid and piercing as ever, the wound still throbbing.

title: Bittersweet Lessons As a Family Reunites
description: Powerhouse casting and a heartbreaking history make the screen version of ''Marvin's Room'' more memorable than it otherwise would be. This adaptation of Scott McPherson's 1991 play, which opened in New York shortly before its young author died of AIDS, uneasily mixes pathos with broad humor and too often gears its subtle shadings to the rear row of the balcony. But thanks to fine, stellar acting in the film's main roles, the bittersweet lessons of ''Marvin's Room'' do come through.

title: Drug Suspect Freed in Inquiry on Trial
description: A man convicted of masterminding a drug network in New Jersey was freed on bail yesterday while the State Attorney General's office investigates the way Nicholas L. Bissell, who was the Somerset County Prosecutor, and his detectives handled his arrest and trial.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Deny Slaying Newborn Son
description: The New Jersey teen-agers charged with murdering their newborn son saw each other for the first time since the birth when they appeared in State Superior Court today to plead not guilty. One defense lawyer said at the hearing that the baby had been brain-damaged and that the parents did not harm their son.

title: Skandia Quits Bidding For Mortgage Bank
description: Skandia A.B., Sweden's leading insurer, said yesterday that it had withdrawn its $3 billion stock offer for Stadshypotek A.B., leaving Svenska Handelsbanken A.B. as the sole bidder for the mortgage bank. Handelsbanken, Scandinavia's largest bank, last week made an all-cash offer for the mortgage company. That bid, which challenged Skandia's offer, immediately won the backing of the largest shareholder, the Swedish state.

title: Dance in Review
description: A Sexual Role Reversal

title: A failed luxury mall in South Miami, Fla., is demolished for a new mall with a new concept.
description: FEW retail projects failed as badly as the Bakery Center, a luxury shopping mall that opened 10 years ago at one of Greater Miami's busiest commercial crossroads. This year, new owners have demolished it and started anew with a different design and marketing plan.

title: Replayed Warning Opens Hearing on Ship's Crash
description: The voice of the river pilot was laced with desperation as he tried to guide his crippled freighter through the Mississippi River traffic.

title: Big Lies, Red Menaces And U.S. Communists
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Montgomery Asset Management, San Francisco, to Katsin/Loeb Advertising, San Francisco, to handle its account, previously at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, a unit of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: MILLIPORE TO BUY TYLAN GENERAL FOR $133 MILLION
description: The stock of Tylan General Inc. rose sharply yesterday after the Millipore Corporation, a filter maker, announced it would buy Tylan for $16 a share in cash, or about $133 million. Tylan said on Monday that it was in discussions with an undisclosed suitor, pushing its shares up 24 percent. Millipore, which is based in Bedford, Mass., was named as the buyer after stock markets closed, and Tylan's shares rose an additional $1.50 yesterday, to $15.75, in Nasdaq trading. Tylan is a San Diego-based maker of flow-control and processing equipment.

title: Genetics of Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Responses Of Alcoholics To Therapies Seem Similar
description: Trying to match types of alcoholics with specific therapies has little effect on the results, according to a major Government study released today.

title: Executive At a Charity Faces Charges
description: A top official of a politically connected social-services organization in Borough Park, Brooklyn, was charged yesterday with conspiring to steal more than $600,000 in government money that had been awarded to the group.

title: Singapore Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Gives Nets His All, For Naught
description: The player slumped on the bench, the one with a towel about to slide off his throbbing head, was one sneeze short of delirium.

title: 61 Arrested in Drug Raids at South Bronx Tenements
description: In raids that officials said dismantled 12 violent drug gangs, nearly 600 police officers, F.B.I. agents and other investigators fanned out across a troubled housing development early yesterday morning to break up a criminal network that had established a stubborn hold on the South Bronx.

title: Tellier Contract Gets Extended
description: Ray Tellier, who has turned Columbia's football program completely around during his eight-year tenure, has been rewarded with a five-year contract extension. The agreement, which will be announced today, keeps Tellier as head coach through the year 2001. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: Brooke Astor Has a Year's Worth of Giving Left
description: At 94, Brooke Astor is giving up giving away money.

title: Holiday Festival Is a Homecoming
description: Bobby Cremins is coming home for Christmas. Fran Fraschilla will be entertaining some old friends. The two coaches are part of a Holiday Festival that is living up to its name in literal fashion this year.

title: Timing Allows Crew To Respond Quickly
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will be able to use his new power to hire school superintendents almost immediately in 27 of the city's 32 school districts.

title: Generals, Battlefields And What Raleigh Said
description: THE READER'S COMPANION TO MILITARY HISTORY

title: The Fed Holds Rates Steady; Housing Gains
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, concluding that inflation remained dormant despite sporadic surges in economic activity.

title: New Way With Old Tunes
description: The Beaux-Arts Trio is devoting its annual series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Beethoven piano trios, and no doubt some familiar with the breadth of this ensemble's repertory groaned at the prospect of a full season devoted to such familiar works. But in the first installment, on Saturday evening, the ensemble gave performances of such freshness and vitality that an objection on programming grounds would be beside the point.

title: A High Fat Intake Takes Off Dietary Brakes
description: YOU may think it is the sweetness of holiday treats that prompts you to shovel in the thousands of tongue-tickling calories that show up as extra padding by year's end. But recent studies of the human appetite show that while sugar may lead one into temptation, fat is what pushes the indulgence to caloric excess.

title: Desserts Fit for a Good King Wenceslaus
description: TOP off that Christmas feast with a desert extravaganza, a sumptuous English trifle from the Black Hound shops at 149 First Avenue (Ninth Street) and the Mall at Short Hills in New Jersey. A glass trifle bowl, layered with orange cake, poached pears, whipped cream and cranberry-orange preserves and laced with eau de vie, is $95 including the bowl. It serves 25 to 30.

title: For Ex-Patient, Voices of Hope Are Real
description: The first time Mervyn Matthews heard the voices he was 19, working in Manhattan, operating a ditto machine.

title: Nostalgia Shaped Some Teamster Votes
description: A generation ago, when this city roared as a blue-collar powerhouse, when unions were still winning fat contracts and picket lines were still dangerous to cross, nobody stood tougher than Jimmy Hoffa and his teamsters.

title: Laws on Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SCENE: A Bergdorf Goodman fragrance counter, where a woman is returning a box of potpourri that contains, along with the usual flowers, an assortment of dried vegetables.

title: Quietly, Wall St. Basks in Holiday Cheer
description: Last Wednesday night, Jim Natoli, a 28-year-old Wall Street broker, walked across the dimly lighted Liberty Suite at Windows on the World atop One World Trade Center, with a bottle of Cristal Champagne in his left hand, low to his side, being purposely inconspicuous.

title: Joseph Ades, 95, Businessman Who Financed Schools and Causes
description: Joseph Ades, a self-made businessman and investor who was a leading supporter of Sephardic Jewish life and philanthropy in Israel and the New York City area, died on Sunday at his home in Kings Point, L.I. He was 95.

title: METROPOLITAN LIFE BUYS LOAN PORTFOLIO
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has acquired the agricultural loan portfolio of the closely held MBL Life Assurance Corporation for more than $350 million. Metropolitan Life acquired the rights to more than 1,600 loans nationwide, in what it called one of the largest acquisitions of farm mortgage loans in insurance industry history. The deal will increase Metropolitan Life's agricultural loan portfolio to more than $4 billion by the end of the year, with a record amount of $1.1 billion in new investments in 1996.

title: After Third Straight Defeat, Bills' Number May Be Up
description: The numbers don't look good for the Buffalo Bills heading into the final week of the regular season.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN GIVES STOCK OPTIONS TO ALL EMPLOYEES
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation awarded stock options yesterday to all 67,000 employees, promising a potential windfall of hundreds of millions of dollars to workers if the bank's shares surge in coming years. Chase plans to give all 63,000 full-time employees options to buy 450 shares of stock at a discount in the next three years. This year Chase employees get an option to buy as many as 150 shares of Chase stock at yesterday's average price of $86.38 a share, if the stock rises to $110 a share for five straight days within three years. If the stock never reaches $110, employees will still be able to exercise the option to buy shares at $86.38 a share after six years. Employees will get the rest of their options in two equal parts in December 1997 and December 1998.

title: Yankees Lost More From Pitching Staff Than They Gained
description: Pat Gillick, the Baltimore Orioles' general manager, was on the telephone asking about the status of the Yankees' negotiations with David Wells. Told the numbers they were discussing, he said, ''I like my contract better than the one they're talking about.''

title: Rose Is Leaving Calvin Klein
description: Martin J. Rose is leaving Calvin Klein Inc. after 17 months as executive vice president and head of the company's in-house agency, CRK Advertising.

title: Centerpiece With All the Moves Sparks Surprisingly Torrid Start
description: He is a work in progress, but Grant Hill's progress has been rapid.

title: Feasts for the Eyes, to Give and to Cook
description: BRIGHTLY colored holiday gifts in extra large are not always welcome. But books that fit that description, especially cookbooks, are a notable exception. Here are one reader's choices for the season's brightest oversize highlights, along with a few small- and medium-size treasures.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday about planned cutbacks at the McGraw-Hill Companies' higher-education publishing unit misstated their scope. The company plans to eliminate 340 positions at the unit; the number does not reflect announcementslast month about the elimination of 130 jobs in Iowa and Illinois.

title: Goldman, Sachs Profit Up, Boding Well for Wall Street
description: Goldman, Sachs, the nation's biggest investment banking partnership, said yesterday that its pretax earnings rose 69 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, as profit from investment banking, trading and sales led the firm to its second- best year.

title: 6 Red Cross Aides Slain in Chechnya, Imperiling the Peace
description: In the worst premeditated attack in the 133-year history of the International Committee of the Red Cross, six Western aid workers were shot and killed in their sleep early this morning in the separatist republic of Chechnya.

title: One Man's Shoes, and the Many Who'll Fill Them
description: It is a tiny warren, cluttered with coffee cups and crumpled papers, Greek icons, a bottle or two of expensive wine and row upon row of books. But in a world where proximity is power, the White House office of George Stephanopoulos, right next to the Oval Office, is the ultimate address.

title: Hidden Danger In a New NATO
description: The parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all . . . .'' These hair-trigger words of Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty only just fall short of an automatic commitment to go to war.

title: Executive Changes
description: FLAGSTAR COS., Spartanburg, S.C., named John Romandetti president of its Denny's restaurant subsidiary. He had been president of the company's El Pollo Loco fast-food chain. Mr. Romandetti replaces Ronald Petty, who resigned in October to become president of the Peter Piper Pizza chain, which is based in Phoenix.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Broadway is far from the West End of London, so it fits that British actors, directors and technicians working in New York yearn for a touch of home during the holidays. Or so says MICHAEL ALLINSON, president of the Players and a star of ''An Ideal Husband.'' The club is giving a party -- high tea, of course -- for some 40 British theater people tomorrow in its stately quarters on Gramercy Park.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15

title: China's the Game
description: The question of how Hong Kong will evolve over the next few years is a question you can debate until you're blue in the face, and Hong Kongers are doing just that. But for my money there's only one interesting question here: How will China evolve? Because no matter what Hong Kong wants to be, once it becomes part of China next July 1 its fate will be linked to the fate of ''The Deng Xiaoping New Deal.''

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Holiday Pause

title: How Should the Price Index Change When Consumers Pay More but Get More?
description: As heart bypass operations are perfected, more people have them, extending their lives. But the operations raise health care costs. Is this inflation, as the Government's statisticians contend? Or is it simply fair value for the promise of longer, healthier lives, as a blue-ribbon panel of economists argues?

title: Robert Adams, 81, A Literary Scholar And Classics Editor
description: Robert M. Adams, a writer, editor and teacher, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 81 and lived in Santa Fe.

title: Sic Transit Yankees
description: When the New York Yankees ruled Major League Baseball, the losers would cry ''Break up the Yankees!'' in the hope that some outside force would come to their rescue. No such intercession ever occurred, and certainly none is required now. A mere five weeks after capturing the World Series, the Yankees are slowly dissolving themselves.

title: East-West: It Happens Once a Year
description: SEE YA in June. If the Knicks and the Utah Jazz should happen to meet again in the Garden this season, that would mean both had reached the finals of the playoffs -- and, in fact, one of them would win the championship.

title: S.E.C. to Ease Trading Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to adopt a new rule on Wednesday to relax trading restrictions on stocks and bonds in the days before companies sell new issues of the securities to the public, commission officials said.

title: Dance in Review
description: A Social Twist for Men

title: Devaluing Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance in Review
description: It's Weird, Scary, Surreal?

title: New Hints Spain's Leaders Knew of 'Dirty War' Against Rebels
description: Two Spanish newspapers published alleged new disclosures today about shadowy death squads in the 1980's, printing what appeared to be copies of classified intelligence documents that could implicate former Government officials in directing a ''dirty war'' against Basque separatists.

title: Turkish Grants
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Men With Machine Guns Shot at Hussein Son, Iraqi Editor Says
description: A leading Iraqi editor said today that the attack on President Saddam Hussein's eldest son last week had been carried out by two men armed with machine guns who opened fire at close range.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Ribald Romp 300 Years Old

title: New York to Buy Pineland Tract From L.I. Scouts
description: When the Nassau County Council of Boy Scouts announced plans last summer to sell 147 acres in the Pine Barrens preserve to a golf course developer, many environmental groups were enraged.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Who was the mysterious person who paid $607,500 at Christie's in Los Angeles on Sunday to buy the Oscar won by Clark Gable for ''It Happened One Night''?

title: The PG-Files
description: It's always heartwarming to watch show-business executives, professional child advocates, Congressmen and even the President fret over the television habits of America's youth. But after listening for a week now to the great and heated debate over the TV ratings that Jack Valenti will hand down tomorrow with fanfare worthy of Moses and the Ten Commandments, it's clear that the nation's parents need more protection from fatuous reformers than their kids do from ''Baywatch.''

title: An Underdog Victor Savors the Limelight
description: Wherever she goes now, from a shopping mall in California to an orientation for Congressional freshmen at Harvard, Representative-elect Loretta Sanchez encounters strangers who suddenly declare, ''Thank you!'' as if she had stamped out a social disorder.

title: Guitarists in a Face-Off
description: When Pat Metheny and Derek Bailey squared off against each other on Friday night at the Knitting Factory, sitting at opposite corners of the stage, it was an impressive sight. Both are consummate craftsmen, beloved by their respective (and completely distinct) audiences.

title: Choices and No Choices In the Abortion Wars
description: With volunteer guards on either side of her, a young blond woman walks through a crowd of protesters and enters a health clinic, most likely to have an abortion. A version of this scene appears in no less than three recent films. In ''Critical Choices,'' a stultifyingly evenhanded movie made for Showtime (tonight at 11:40), the woman entering the clinic is a married mother of two, scraping by financially. Pamela Reed, as an anti-abortion protester, yells at her, ''If it has brain waves and a heartbeat it's alive!''

title: A Welcome Handgun Meltdown
description: If anyone should be sensitive to the dangers posed by illegal sale of handguns, it is law enforcement officers. But a report from the New York State Inspector General's office has shown that when officers in one agency were given a chance to buy their used guns at a discount, they were shockingly indifferent to filing the simple paperwork needed to keep track of where the guns were going. Gov. George Pataki did the right thing when he responded by ordering that in the future, state agencies should keep their unneeded handguns out of the market by melting them down.

title: VALUE LINE TO PAY A $15 DIVIDEND
description: Value Line Inc. said yesterday that it would pay an extraordinary dividend of $15 a share as part of a settlement of a legal dispute between the company's majority owners. The company had earlier said the payout would be either $14 a share or $15. Value Line, a publisher of investment guides, will pay the dividend on Jan. 2 to shareholders of record as of Dec. 26. The company also reported yesterday that its net income in the quarter that ended on Oct. 31 was $7.8 million, down from $8.3 million a year earlier. Value Line stock rose 11 percent, gaining $4.625, to $47.125 a share, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Albany Fails to Extend Tax for New York City Police
description: A tax that has paid for a major expansion of New York City's police force apparently will expire Dec. 31, since the Legislature failed Tuesday and early this morning to reach an agreement to extend it.

title: Pennsylvania Attacks E.P.A. Audit on Violations
description: Pennsylvania officials have criticized as ''misleading and inaccurate'' a report by Federal auditors that questioned the state's reporting of environmental violations.

title: NATO Clears Smaller, U.S.-Led Force to Extend Bosnia Mission
description: NATO defense ministers gave the final go-ahead today for a scaled-down American-led force to keep the peace in Bosnia during the next 18 months, one that officials said would be even less likely than its 60,000-member predecessor to pursue people indicted for war crimes.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT'S panic time: a dozen gifts to buy, no ideas at all, the stores jammed, the clock ticking. It all adds up to holiday stress.

title: 6 Arrested in School Fires
description: More than 70 times since the start of the school year, arson blazes set in trash cans have forced the evacuation of East Side High School in Newark. Yesterday, after a two-month investigation, the state police arrested three East Side students and three other youths. Five were juveniles and have been charged with delinquency. The sixth, Antwain Curry, 18, was charged with attempted arson. The fires did not cause any damage, said Larry Krieger, a spokesman for the Newark Fire Department.

title: AUDITOR DOUBTS ACCLAIM ENTERTAINMENT'S FUTURE
