description: The stock of Acclaim Entertainment Inc., a maker of video game cartridges, plunged 41 percent yesterday after its auditor, KPMG Peat Marwick L.L.P., was quoted as doubting the company's future. KPMG said Acclaim's significant losses, its violation of certain loan agreements and various uncertainties raise doubt about its ability to continue operating, Federal Filings Business News reported. In its latest fiscal year, which ended Aug. 31, Acclaim lost $221.4 million, compared with profits of $44.8 million the previous year. Acclaim is in talks with its lenders to reorganize loan agreements. Acclaim shares fell $2.625 to close at $3.75 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WALDEN RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES INC., Dallas, a real estate investment trust, bought Nashboro Village, a development consisting of 994 apartment units, and about 80 acres of adjacent land in Nashville, for about $48.8 million.

title: BELL ATLANTIC TO BUY ADDITIONAL STAKE IN OMNITEL
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire an additional 5.8 percent stake in Omnitel, an Italian wireless company, for 432.5 billion lire, or about $282.5 million, increasing its interest to 17.4 percent. A Bell Atlantic spokesman said the company was purchasing the equity interest from Olivetti S.P.A., which is a member of Omnitel Systemi Radiocellulari, a consortium that holds a 70 percent stake in Omnitel. The sale will reduce Olivetti's interest in Omnitel from 50.7 percent to 35.5 percent and will make Bell Atlantic, which is also part of the consortium, the second-largest Omnitel shareholder.

title: Her Crime? Daring to Be Different
description: ''I walk on anger,'' Dael Orlandersmith declares in ''Monster,'' her smoldering account of a cruel upbringing in a dysfunctional household in Harlem. Inside the apartment, the resentful, alcoholic mother sways to the steady beat of the clinking ice cubes in her tumbler of scotch. Outside, the neighborhood toughs spit the words ''White girl!'' at the black teen-ager, not because she is light-skinned, but because she holds herself aloof.

title: Prudential Policyholders' Deadline Nears
description: The last opportunity for 10.7 million Prudential Insurance policyholders to battle the company on their own over whether they were cheated by agents is fast approaching.

title: Venture in Japan In Satellite TV
description: The News Corporation of Australia and Softbank Inc. of Japan will spend 20 billion yen ($176 million) to start a satellite television service in Japan, the last big market not part of Rupert Murdoch's global network.

title: Shares of Frontier Plunge on Expected Loss of Phone Revenue
description: Stung by the departure of one of its major wholesale customers, the Frontier Corporation warned analysts yesterday that its long-distance telephone revenue would fall well short of analysts' expectations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Up 39.98 Points As I.B.M. Rises

title: A Starship Chief Goes Bravely Into Directing
description: EVEN out of his Starfleet uniform, Jonathan Frakes, who has made a lucrative career of playing the clear-eyed executive officer of the starship Enterprise in the ''Star Trek'' spinoffs, looks like a man in orbit.

title: Devils' Rolston Is the Apple of Lemaire's Eye
description: A couple of weeks ago, Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire took wing Brian Rolston aside and told him bluntly, ''I've got confidence you can be a good player.''

title: New TV Ratings Are Parent-Friendly
description: There is no way I am going to allow my children to watch this show!

title: Years Later, Still Mad At the World
description: Back in the 70's, there were a number of bands like Rush. The group's lyrics convey a fascination and a loathing for technology. It uses huge symbolic totems to transmit the thematic meaning of each album. It speaks for the alienated, yet flirts with the alienation effect in its music. They are post-modernity-watchers: they once even thanked NASA on an album sleeve for letting them attend the launching of a space shuttle.

title: Carl W. Shaver, 82; Planned Campaign For Carnegie Hall
description: Carl Woodrow Shaver, an innovator in bringing corporate management practices and fund-raising techniques to cultural institutions, died on Dec. 6 at his home in New York. He was 82.

title: ALBANY IN SCHOOLS ACCORD TO GIVE CHANCELLOR POWER AND WEAKEN LOCAL BOARDS
description: The State Legislature tonight enacted the most significant overhaul of New York City's school system in a generation, sharply curtailing school decentralization and vesting broad new authority in the schools chancellor to hire the people who run the city's schools.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for coq au vin last Wednesday with an article about party food that can be prepared in advance misstated the nutritional analysis. One serving contains about 688 calories, 21 grams fat, 152 milligrams cholesterol, 153 milligrams sodium (before salting), 56 grams protein and 32 grams carbohydrate.

title: Commuting by Electric Car
description: A few dozen corporate employees who commute to Morristown, Princeton Junction or Woodcrest by train will be able to drive electric cars from the station to their suburban offices under a pilot program approved yesterday, officials said. Beginning in April, 21 electric cars bought with $1.28 million in state money from the Solectria Corporation of Wilmington, Mass., will be assigned to commuters from corporations that agreed to participate in the program. The companies will pay $100 a month per car to offset the electrical costs, said Steve Coleman, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit.

title: Scandals at the School Boards Led to Loss of Their Powers
description: For much of its history, the New York City school system has struggled with the question of where decision-making should lie: at the center, with the Chancellor and the elephantine bureaucracy at 110 Livingston Street, or out on the periphery, with locally elected school boards that would be more responsive to their communities.

title: Food Notes
description: Doughnut Empire

title: A Store Manager Interrupts a Theft, and His Career
description: Catch a thief, lose a job.

title: France Cuts 2 Rates; Little Impact Is Seen
description: The Bank of France trimmed two key interest rates yesterday. The independent central bank shaved its intervention rate by a five-hundredths of a point, to 3.15 percent from 3.20 percent. It cut another less crucial one, the 5-to-10 rate, to 4.60 percent from 4.75 percent.

title: BEN & JERRY'S TO REPORT FOURTH-QUARTER LOSS
description: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. said yesterday that it would report a loss for the fourth quarter, after spending more on marketing. The company, which makes Cherry Garcia, Wavy Gravy and other premium ice cream and yogurt flavors, was expected to earn 6 cents a share, according to three analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research Inc. Ben & Jerry's said it expected to lose 13 cents to 17 cents a share for the period. The company earned $859,000, or 12 cents a share, on revenue of $32.8 million in the comparable period last year. Ben & Jerry's said promotional costs were much higher in the fourth quarter and that costs from its entry into the European market added to the loss.

title: It's Back: The Burger Stand From the Dawn of McCivilization
description: At the log cabin of fast-food restaurants, even the food is authentic. That means the revived little McDonald's stand here sells no Arch Deluxes. In the very beginning, before McDonald's was a household word and a fixture from here to the Champs-Elysees, McDonald's was just another hamburger joint.

title: A One-Day Strike at the Modern
description: Starting at 6 A.M. yesterday, unionized employees of the Museum of Modern Art marched in front of the museum's West 53d Street entrance, its design shop, bookstore and loading dock, blowing whistles, banging on pots and screaming, ''Don't go in,'' to anyone who tried to enter the museum or its stores.

title: Turmoil, Even if the Slaves Are Dead
description: It takes most of the hourlong ''Slavery's Buried Past'' before Bill Kurtis gets around to significant findings from studies of the bones of slaves discovered by New York construction workers near City Hall in 1991. Researchers at Howard University, scrutinizing the remains of hundreds of bodies in what was known in colonial times as the Negro's burial ground, have come up with indications of the hard labor and poor nutrition that meant short, sickly lives for many children.

title: Islanders Answer Milbury's Wake-Up Call
description: From the opening face-off of tonight's game against Los Angeles, the Islanders looked like a desperate team, and for good reason.

title: At 90, an Advocate Retains a Velvet Touch
description: IN 1964, when President Lyndon B. Johnson appointed Esther Peterson to be a Special Assistant for Consumer Affairs, a trade group denounced her as ''the most pernicious threat to advertising today.'' She had advocated truth in advertising.

title: Holiday Wish For Tree Seller Who Said No
description: MOE STEIN doesn't sell Christmas trees, but they have been on his mind a lot lately. Inevitably, his thoughts turn to shotguns, which he does sell. And in this particular holiday reverie, the wise men with flowing robes and precious gifts have been replaced by wise guys in long leather coats demanding tribute.

title: NBC Hires Breen
description: MIKE BREEN, the voice of the Knicks on WFAN-AM Radio, was hired yesterday by NBC Sports to call pro football and other sports. He has broadcast a partial National Football League schedule for Fox Sports, but NBC offered a full-season commitment. The 35-year-old Breen called women's basketball games for the network at the Atlanta Olympics.

title: Society, Not Science, Owns the Worry Gene
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong's New Chief Sees The Meeting of East and West
description: The shipping tycoon chosen by Beijing to administer Hong Kong next year declared today that he would preserve the territory's autonomy and its British-inspired legal system and would resist efforts by mainland China to gain special economic privileges here.

title: Astute Collector of Big Money and Powerful Friends
description: Charles Yah Lin Trie, the Chinese-American restaurateur and businessman who raised hundreds of thousands of dollars in questionable contributions for President Clinton's legal defense fund, has always been a hard worker and a quick learner, say those here who have known him. And the lesson he learned most astutely, they say, is the importance of knowing people in high places.

title: Wearing Fur, and Proud of It
description: Not this fur coat, you don't. Keep the lid on your can of spray paint. Spare me the guilt-making slogans.

title: In Their Own Words
description: ASSEMBLYMAN JAMES F. BRENNAN

title: The Travels Of a Donated Can of Corn
description: IT started the week as a simple can of corn, 16 ounces of Goya brand, sitting on a shelf in a grocery store.

title: A Christmas Tale of the Gottis and Tickle Me Elmo
description: It is said that as a boy, King Arthur freed a sword embedded in stone. It is said that Daniel Boone killed a bear with his bare hands, and that Babe Ruth called a World Series home run. Now add the following to the stuff of which legends are made:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Dance in Review
description: 'E.R.' Meets 'Marat-Sade'

title: The Vilification of Richard Nuccio
description: When secrecy and conscience clash in Washington, secrecy almost always prevails. Richard Nuccio is the latest idealist to discover that telling the truth in the Government can destroy a career. For informing a member of Congress about Central Intelligence Agency misconduct in Guatemala, Mr. Nuccio, a State Department official, has now been stripped of his high security clearance.

title: Irving Caesar, Lyricist of Timeless Hits Like 'Tea for Two,' Dies at 101
description: Irving Caesar, the Tin Pan Alley lyricist who put words to such enduring musical standards as ''Tea for Two,'' ''Swanee,'' ''Is It True What They Say About Dixie?'' and ''Sometimes I'm Happy,'' died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 101 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mets Take The Road Less Costly
description: Overshadowed by the Yankees' captivating run to a World Series championship, the Mets escaped a scorching for their sixth straight losing season in 1996. It ended with a dismal 71-91 record and with a managerial switch from Dallas Green to Bobby Valentine.

title: Injury Sidelines Seles
description: MONICA SELES, who broke the ring finger on her right hand during an exhibition last week in Czechoslovakia, announced her withdrawal from the Jan. 6-12 tournament in Sydney, Australia. Her status for defending her Australian Open title the next week is still undecided.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 18 about a private foundation's gifts of children's books to small-town libraries referred incorrectly to the high school library in Las Animas, Colo. A letter from the librarian, faxed last week, says the library has not been closed. The article also misstated the enrollment of the high school. It has 213 students; 50 is the size of its senior class.

title: No Headline
description: ''I would like to have one year, before I dance into my grave, of doing something good for myself.''

title: Huge Amnesty Is Dividing Guatemala As War Ends
description: As Guatemala ends a 36-year civil war in which at least 100,000 people were killed, its Congress is poised to approve a sweeping amnesty law that would exempt both soldiers and guerrillas from prosecution for killings, kidnappings and acts of torture committed during that conflict.

title: KELSO TO SELL AMERICAN STANDARD STAKE
description: The American Standard Companies said yesterday that its largest stockholder, Kelso & Company, would sell its remaining 27 percent stake, or 20.8 million shares, valued about $780 million. Kelso, which took American Standard private in a 1988 leveraged buyout, will sell 9.9 million of the shares in a public offering, while American Standard will buy back 7.9 million shares. Kelso has been reducing its stake since it took the company -- a maker of air-conditioners, auto parts and plumbing products -- public for $20 a share in February 1995. American Standard accepted Kelso's $2.45 billion buyout in 1988 rather than a hostile offer from Black & Decker. Shares of American Standard, based in Piscataway, N.J., rose 62.5 cents, to $38.50.

title: Employee Ownership
description: To the Editor:

title: Belle Is Sued
description: The photographer who said ALBERT BELLE threw a baseball at him last spring has sued the former Cleveland slugger for unspecified damages. TONY TOMSIC was taking pictures of Belle for Sports Illustrated on April 6 at Jacobs Field when the incident occurred. The lawsuit was filed Friday in the Cuyahoga County (Ohio) Court of Common Pleas.

title: Prosecuted by Bissell, Prisoner Is Now Set Free
description: A man convicted of masterminding a drug network in New Jersey was freed on bail yesterday while the State Attorney General's office investigates the way the late Nicholas L. Bissell, who was the Somerset County Prosecutor, and his detectives handled his case. The inquiry is thought to be its first into a major criminal trial conducted personally by Mr. Bissell, who killed himself after fleeing sentencing on embezzlement charges.

title: Fund-Raiser Visited White House Even After Concerns Were Raised
description: Charles Yah Lin Trie, the Arkansas businessman whose fund-raising efforts were rejected by President Clinton's legal defense fund earlier this year, continued to be a visitor to the White House long after Presidential aides began raising questions about money he had given to the fund and to the Democratic Party.

title: Turning Colombia's Drug Plots Over to Peasant Plowshares
description: To get to her office, the director of the Colombian Government agency for land reform must wade through a living illustration of Government failure: peasants and their children making their homes on mattresses in the hall outside her office.

title: B.Y.U. Dismisses Coach
description: ROGER REID, who won at least 20 games in six of his seven seasons at Brigham Young University, was abruptly dismissed yesterday after a 1-6 start this season. B.Y.U. athletics officials said Reid would ''step down'' as coach and remain at the university in an unspecified capacity. An assistant, TONY INGLE, was named interim head coach. (AP)

title: Right to Campaign Upheld
description: An appeals court upheld the right yesterday of political candidates to distribute campaign literature inside the privately owned Galaxy Towers condominium complex in Guttenberg. The panel agreed with a lower court's ruling that as long as the condo association continued to hand out political leaflets, a nonresidents' group, the Guttenberg Taxpayers and Rentpayers Association, must also be allowed to do so.

title: After Bradley, Office Politics
description: The departing occupant of the spacious duplex in the Hart Senate Office Building in Washington had not finished packing yet, but prospective tenants were already coming by to check the place out. ''Senator Murkowski of Alaska was here today,'' Dan Maffei, press secretary to Senator Bill Bradley, said yesterday. ''Senator Harkin of Iowa and Senator Leahy from Vermont have looked at it, too.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: State Board Sees Wider Budget Gaps
description: The gap between New York City's spending and its income is becoming wider than in the past and will make it increasingly difficult to balance each year's budget, according to a dour report on the city's finances issued yesterday by the New York State Financial Control Board.

title: When Will Giants Finally Seek a Black Coach?
description: When Pete Rozelle was commissioner of the National Football League, he would begin many owners meetings with a plea to hire more blacks for front office and coaching positions. Paul Tagliabue, the current commissioner, has done the same thing and takes it further: he hires blacks for key positions at the league office. Tagliabue knows he cannot encourage owners to do something he does not do himself.

title: Amnesty in Guatemala
description: As Guatemala ends a 36-year civil war in which at least 100,000 people were killed, its Congress is poised to approve a sweeping amnesty law exempting both soldiers and guerrillas from prosecution for abuses. Human rights groups and relatives of victims have expressed outrage.

title: Arthur D. Shores, 92, Lawyer And Advocate for Civil Rights
description: Arthur D. Shores, a prominent figure in the civil rights movement in Alabama in the 1950's and 1960's, died on Monday at his home in Birmingham, Ala. He was 92.

title: Fast, Last-Minute Gifts For Cook and Kitchen
description: IT sounds like the old joke: what is black and white and red all over?

title: Paying Tribute but Trying to Surpass
description: A Baroque composer like Arcangelo Corelli would have been stupefied by the fuss Americans make over Christmas. Back then, this holy day, just one of many in the church calendar, was simply a time for contemplation and quiet joy. These qualities are abundant in the Concerto Grosso from Opus 6 that Corelli composed for Christmas Eve, the opening work of ''A Baroque Christmas,'' the rewarding program presented on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall by the estimable early-music ensemble Concert Royal.

title: Scientists Reporting New Details About 'Bursts' of Gamma Rays
description: For more than five years, an American space observatory has been counting the pieces of a cosmic mystery, some 1,700 detections of high-energy bursts of gamma rays coming from all directions in the sky. But no one has been able to agree on the nature and origin of such flares, only that they never seem to occur in the same place twice.

title: Bundesbank Warns Against Reducing Rates
description: The Bundesbank dashed hopes yesterday for a German interest rate cut anytime soon, warning that reducing rates to help the economy could unsettle financial markets and drive bond yields higher. ''Increasing the role of monetary policy to stimulate the economy would increase the risk premium of long-term interest rates and raise the danger of speculative upheavals in financial markets,'' the German central bank said in its monthly report.

title: With Childs Connecting, Streaking Knicks Jolt Jazz
description: He wanted everything that John Stockton had: a playoff team to direct, a man in the post who could sink baseline fallaways with the clock winding down and, most of all, the ability to alter a game with one magnificent shot. Last night, before the loudest mob of the season at Madison Square Garden, envy was benched by the real deal. Chris Childs.

title: Opening the Door to Equal Justice
description: The Supreme Court took a small but significant step for fairness this week when it ruled that a state may not prevent poor people from appealing the termination of their parental rights simply because they cannot afford the court fees. But the Court's duty to protect the basic rights of the indigent does not stop here.

title: Campbell Questions Rangers' Toughness
description: Ryan VandenBussche is a Ranger rookie who sometimes wears a T-shirt adorned with the words ''Wanna Go?'' This isn't an invitation to the movies. It is what hockey enforcers say to each other before they drop their gloves for a fistfight.

title: Remember that Datsun 240Z you drove 25 years ago? Nissan hopes you will buy it again.
description: THERE are used cars, and then there are used cars.

title: Theater in Review
description: Of Illusion and Fate,

title: For Retailers, Weather Is Wild Card in Holiday Sales
description: As the final week of the holiday selling season begins, retailers are finding their sales stuck between mediocre and decent, meaning that these last few days could be crucial to their success.

title: People
description: * Sean M. Neall was named client services director for the Ford Motor Co. European operations account at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, London, a unit of WPP Group. He succeeds David Miller, who continues at Ogilvy in an undisclosed post. Mr. Neall had been executive management director for the Ford domestic operations account at the J. Walter Thompson Detroit unit of WPP.

title: ALLMERICA FINANCIAL TO BUY REST OF ALLMERICA PROPERTY
description: The Allmerica Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy the 40.5 percent of the Allmerica Property and Casualty Companies that it does not already own for about $700 in cash and stock. The offer, announced after stock markets closed, values Allmerica Property shares at about $29 each. Allmerica Property shares closed at $28.25 each, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Allmerica Property shareholders would receive $16.59 in cash and 0.385 common share of Allmerica Financial for each share held. Alternatively, shareholders can choose all cash or all stock in exchange for their shares. Allmerica Financial, based in Worcester Mass., owns a group of insurance and financial service companies.

title: U.S. Puts Off Plan to Pare Nursing Home Inspections
description: Reacting to a barrage of criticism from state officials and consumer groups, the White House said today that an Administration proposal to scale back inspections of many nursing homes would be thoroughly revised to guarantee the protection of patients.

title: Borough President Is Cleared on Ads
description: The city's Conflicts of Interest Board has found that Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, did not misuse public money last month when she used her office's funds to pay for radio commercials attacking Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to attract more superstores to the city.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They're probably not having tea parties or any other kind of parties at the London offices of HarperCollins. Less than a year after he signed a record-breaking $360,000 contract with the company, MARTIN AMIS, the novelist, is returning to his original publisher, Jonathan Cape, the venerable London publishing house that is now a division of Random House.

title: Conrail Ordered to Hold Vote on CSX Offer
description: As a major group of investors questioned the fairness of Conrail Inc.'s plan to merge with the CSX Corporation, a Federal judge in Philadelphia yesterday ordered Conrail to let shareholders vote on a crucial aspect of the $8.5 billion railroad deal.

title: Personal Health
description: FAT. Until quite recently that three-letter word had a decidedly positive connotation. A rich man was a fat cat. A fat check was much to be wished for, especially before the holidays. A fat baby was said to be beautiful and healthy-looking. My parents and grandmother spent my skin-and-bones childhood years trying to fatten me up, stuffing me with sticks of butter, bars of Velveeta cheese and cans of evaporated milk. (The effort failed, incidentally, until adolescent hormones took over.)

title: Natural Gas and Heating Oil Retreat From Monday's Rally
description: Natural gas and heating oil prices, which surged on Monday on forecasts for frigid weather, retreated yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as some traders bet that temperatures would not drop far enough to extend the rally.

title: FKI of Britain Bids For Building Supplier
description: The diversified British engineering company FKI P.L.C. made a hostile bid yesterday of $:195.7 million ($324.7 million) in cash or stock for the building supplier Newman Tonks Group.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Dance in Review
description: An Opportunity to Show

title: For Some Jets, Grass May Be Greener
description: Amid the uncertainty of the Jets' coaching and front-office situations is another annual concern of professional football teams, whether their records are 1-14 or 14-1: what to do about their soon-to-become free agents, assuming the free agents want to return.

title: INSIDE
description: Weak Flu Vaccine

title: In Modern War, Emblem Is No Shield
description: For more than a century, the distinctive emblem of the International Committee of the Red Cross has been recognized as a banner of neutrality, enabling its doctors and nurses to treat soldiers and civilians on both sides in the world's most brutal war zones.

title: A U.N. Exit and Entrance: Words of Regret and Hope
description: Following are excerpts from the farewell address to the General Assembly today by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and the inaugural speech by his successor, Kofi Annan:

title: Agencies Add Units In Brazil and Texas
description: Two agencies announced acquisitions yesterday in Brazil and Texas.

title: Wells Makes His New Home In the House Ruth Built
description: Moments after David Wells agreed to a three-year contract for $13.5 million with the Yankees yesterday, the pitcher asked for permission to use their spring training facility in Tampa, Fla.

title: Schott Out of Hospital
description: MARGE SCHOTT, the 68-year-old owner of the Reds, was released yesterday from Jewish Hospital in Cincinnati, where she spent a week being treated for pneumonia, said a hospital spokesman, RICK PENDER. (AP)

title: Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, a Dec. 15 letter by Mladen Lazic misspelled the anthem that he said opens protest rallies in Belgrade, Serbia. It is ''Gaudeamus Igitur,'' meaning ''Let us therefore rejoice.''

title: Zaire's Weary Capital Makes a Party of Mobutu's Return
description: After four months' absence for cancer treatment in Europe, Zaire's longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, staged a triumphal return home today to a country on the edge of collapse.

title: 2 Get 25 Years to Life in Subway Murder
description: Two teen-agers convicted last month of murdering a token clerk by setting his booth afire with matches and gasoline were given sentences of 25 years to life yesterday.

title: AS TORCH PASSES, U.N. CHIEF SCOLDS U.S. FOR ARREARS
description: Minutes before the General Assembly appointed his successor, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali used a reflective farewell speech today to scold the United States for failing in its obligations to the United Nations.

title: Washington hotels are filling up fast for the Presidential inauguration next month.
description: ANYONE planning to be in Washington from Jan. 17 until Jan. 21 had better already have hotel reservations or make them pronto -- and be prepared to pay in advance for all four nights. The Presidential inaugural events over those four days is expected to bring in some 45,000 visitors, according to the Washington Convention and Visitors Association. While the $94 million they are expected to spend during their visit will help ease the city's financial distress, the influx will tax the city's approximately 90 hotels.

title: Archdiocese and Teachers Reach Accord on Back Pay
description: Negotiators for 450 teachers in Roman Catholic high schools and the Archdiocese of New York resolved a dispute on back pay yesterday that removed the final obstacle to a new three-year contract.

title: Clinton Made Political Appointments to Panel
description: President Clinton expanded an advisory panel on trade with Pacific nations earlier this year so that it could include several political appointees, including an Arkansas businessman who several months later orchestrated more than $639,000 in questionable donations to the President's legal defense fund.

title: A high-technology initial public offering is a novelty in Japan.
description: AS initial public stock offerings go, a sale by ATL Systems Inc. would not at first appear to be one that would make investors drool. ATL, a five-year-old Japanese software company, recorded a loss of about $230,000 on sales of only $120,000 in its last fiscal year.

title: U.S. Negotiating With Ex-Official In Texaco Case
description: Federal prosecutors and lawyers for a former executive of Texaco Inc. are negotiating to avoid trial on the first criminal charges resulting from a company scandal stemming from a racial discrimination case.

title: Thieves Kill a Print Shop Owner in Queens
description: The small printing shop on Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, had been burglarized at night five times during the last 30 years. In all those burglaries, no one was hurt or injured.

title: Once a Hero, Now the Enemy
description: The deal was done in a matter of hours. Allan Houston clicked on his cellular phone last July on a golf course outside Detroit. Through his agent, he heard the Knicks' final offer.

title: Stake in Duty-Free Store Chain Bought by LVMH After a Dispute
description: One of the world's leading purveyors of high-priced perfume, liquor and other luxury goods has taken a controlling interest in a chain of duty-free shops that sells its wares, after getting approval from an arbitrator assigned to help resolve a dispute among the chain's partners.

title: Acquisitions Set At Three Agencies
description: Three public relations agencies have announced acquisitions.

title: Heating Oil Prices Rise
description: The worst of winter has not yet arrived, but the price of home heating oil in New Jersey has already risen by 20 cents a gallon, officials said yesterday. The wholesale price per gallon increased to 75.6 cents yesterday, from 55.05 cents on July 1, said Dan Post, assistant director of the New Jersey Citizen Oil Group, a group that helps poor people buy oil at cheaper prices.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Bonds Falter On Strong Housing Data
description: Prices of Government securities dropped yesterday following a housing report that was stronger than expected, but the bonds partly erased some early losses and managed to end above the day's lows.

title: Greenwell Is Going To Play in Japan
description: The former Red Sox outfielder MIKE GREENWELL has said he will play in Japan next season. Greenwell reached agreement with the Hanshin Tigers and plans to sign today, The Boston Herald said yesterday.

title: Lawyer Is Indicted
description: A lawyer who was the business partner of Lawrence Taylor, the former New York Giants linebacker, was arrested yesterday on charges of embezzling $276,000 from a client and lying on loan applications to raise money for ventures that included the Lawrence Taylor Golf Center and L.T.'s Restaurant and Sports Bar in East Rutherford.

title: The Liberal Arts Role
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Issues Alert Over Weakened Flu Vaccine
description: Because 5.8 million of the 75 million doses of flu vaccine produced this season were not full strength, Federal health officials today advised doctors to consider giving another flu shot to roughly two million recipients who are at highest risk from complications of the viral infection.

title: Calligraphy Slips in Japan, Pushed by Computer
description: The standard way to begin a letter in Japanese is ''haikei,'' an honorific that can be literally translated as ''your enlightened worship.''

title: Redskins May Ask Nolan For Help
description: There is someone besides Dan Reeves who may be a hot commodity on the coaching market once the Giants' season ends. The defensive coordinator, Mike Nolan, is drawing attention from several teams, and one of them may be the Giants' biggest rival.

title: World Watching, a Death-Row Reprieve
description: WASHINGTON  Stepping into a death-row case that has drawn international attention from Pope John Paul II and other opponents of the death penalty, the Supreme Court granted a stay of execution Tuesday to a Virginia man convicted of a brutal rape and murder.

title: A Jug of Wine and a Printout Beside It
description: TEN years ago, Daniel Boulud would not have been allowed to serve caviar on oysters and blinis at 67 Wine and Spirits. And customers in the store, at 179 Columbus Avenue, would not have been served free glasses of 1988 Veuve Clicquot La Grand Dame. But there was the chef of Restaurant Daniel on a recent Saturday amid $75 bottles in a newly installed kitchen.

title: 3 L.I. Crash Victims Worked Together
description: The victims of the fiery crash of a twin-engine plane in a wooded area near MacArthur Airport on Monday were identified on Tuesday as the founder of a Long Island defense contracting company and two other top officials of the company.

title: Harry Kemelman, 88, Mystery Novelist, Dies
description: Harry Kemelman, the author of a popular series of 11 mystery novels that feature a small-town rabbi as their offbeat sleuth, died on Sunday at his home in Marblehead, Mass. He was 88.

title: Pork With a Garlic-Strong Couscous
description: Pork tenderloin is one of the more delicious and tender cuts of meat, and it happens to be low in fat. It takes nicely to strong seasoning, and garlic lovers may want to add an extra clove, this one uncooked, to the couscous after it has been cooked. For brussels sprouts, choose the smallest available. They will be sweeter and milder.

title: Kimberly-Clark Mill Sale
description: Alliance Forest Products has said it intends to buy a paper mill near Birmingham, Ala., from the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, which is based in Dallas, for about $600 million. Montreal-based Alliance said the Coosa Pines operation included a fully integrated paper mill that produces 367,400 tons of newsprint a year. It also includes 360,620 acres of timber and a sawmill. The mill employs about 1,400 people.

title: Jerry Diamond, 68, Women's Tennis Leader
description: Jerry Diamond, a sports entrepreneur with a feminist bent who helped transform women's professional tennis from an experiment into an industry, died on Monday morning at his home in San Francisco. He was 68.

title: What's Coffee Got to Do With It?
description: MOCHA ware's splotches and lusty colors -- orange, blue, yellow -- lend this 18th-century earthenware an effervescence that could be 1960's as much as 1760's. ''It's zippy, it's fresh, and some of the patterns look like Matisse,'' said Peter-Ayers Tarantino, a Philadelphia pottery maven. And though a machine-washable, microwave-safe mug by his firm, Winthrop & Swann, is good for an afternoon's java, know that this mocha has nothing to do with coffee. It refers instead to the Yemeni port of Mocha, famed in olden times as a conduit for exporting an Arab stone with similar patterns. The pottery is at Ad Hoc, 410 West Broadway, (212) 925-2652; Treillage, 420 East 75th Street, (212) 535-2288, and the Colonial Williamsburg catalogue, (800) 446-9240. Prices range from around $18.95 for a salad plate to $125 for a 10-inch bowl.

title: Private Funds Set Up For Clinton's Benefit
description: The Clinton Administration and the President's friends have created more than a dozen private funds for political and personal causes, including paying legal bills and building a White House jogging track.

title: A Chief Executive For Bates USA West
description: The Bates North America unit of Bates Worldwide said yesterday that it had named Timothy W. Hart to the new position of president and chief executive of the three offices that make up Bates USA West.

title: Dow Resumes Its Rebound, Adding 38.44
description: Stocks climbed yesterday for a second consecutive session, as semiconductor, computer and software stocks surged.

title: A Vote for Cat Sense
description: To The Home Section:

title: INSIDE
description: Plan for Balkans Arrests

title: Entergy Will Pay $2.1 Billion For a Utility, London Electricity
description: Continuing the push by American utilities into the British market, the Entergy Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy London Electricity P.L.C. for $:1.27 billion, or $2.1 billion.

title: Store Owners Held In a Computer Sting
description: When detectives pretending to be thieves offered to sell stolen computers to merchants at Manhattan electronics stores, police officials said yesterday, they did not have to go far to find takers.

title: CT FINANCIAL TO BUY CANADIAN INSURER MELOCHE
description: CT Financial Services, a unit of Imasco, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Canadian insurance provider Meloche Monnex Inc. for about $141.5 million, or $103.5 million (United States). The London Insurance Group, based in London, Ontario, owns 66 percent of Montreal-based Meloche; Meloche management owns the rest. Meloche, which provides home, automobile and travel insurance, employs more than 600 people and has assets of about $303 million. London Insurance said it would use the proceeds from the sale to increase provisions against real estate losses or to offset the cost of buying the Canadian business of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: Title Bout Hinges on McCall
description: Lennox Lewis's rematch with Oliver McCall will take place in Nevada on Feb. 7 provided that McCall can make it. He was arrested early Monday morning on charges of vandalism, disorderly conduct and resisting arrest and did not participate in yesterday's telephone news conference announcing the title bout, which will be staged at the Las Vegas Hilton and televised live by HBO.

title: Chairman Resigns At Dallas Shops
description: Michael S. Rawlings, chairman and chief executive of the Dallas office of DDB Needham Worldwide and a sibling shop, the TL Partnership, said yesterday that he would leave at the end of the year. His decision, which was unexpected, prompted the reshuffling of top management at both agencies.

title: Injury Sidelines Isles' Palffy
description: The Islanders took a bus to Philadelphia yesterday without their best player, Zigmund Palffy, who stayed home to undergo tests on his sprained right shoulder.

title: Shock Waves in Geneva From Chechnya Atrocity
description: The Christmas party was canceled.

title: Russia Still Upset at NATO
description: Russia's Defense Minister told his NATO counterparts today that the alliance's plans for an expansion to include East European countries were ''unacceptable,'' but that it should be possible to negotiate a Russian-NATO security agreement anyway.

title: Rally to Support Serb Chief Draws Only a Few of the Faithful
description: When President Slobodan Milosevic called his supporters to the streets this week to stage demonstrations to counter the anti-Government protests against his cancellation of election results, the local Socialist Party leaders in this farming town set to work.

title: For the Japanese, Hostages' Release Must Have Priority
description: As the crisis unfolds in their Ambassador's residence in Lima, Japanese officials appear to be looking nervously over the shoulder of President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru and calling for a priority on the lives of the hostages.

title: No Headline
description: ''You just learn to cope with whatever you have to cope with. I spent my childhood in New York, riding on subways and buses. And you know what you learn if you're a New Yorker? The world doesn't owe you a damn thing.''

title: European Commission Studies Thomson Subsidy
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it had opened an antitrust investigation into the French Government's plan to inject 10 billion francs ($1.9 billion) into Thomson Multimedia, giving competitors like Philips Electronics N.V. a chance to challenge the subsidy.

title: Red Cross Admits Knowing of the Holocaust During the War
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross today released copies of its World War II files, some of which provided verification that it knew of the persecution of Jews in Nazi concentration camps but felt powerless to speak out.

title: Still Waiting for the E-Mail and Faxes to Start Coming In?
description: CONGRATULATIONS! You have mastered the complementary software, have gone on line and acquired an E-mail address. You have also figured out how to use the new and improved fax machine that you brought home last week. To make life easier, you have even installed a separate telephone line to go with it.

title: Bridge
description: In the New York area, the man with the most irons in the bridge fire is surely Bob Blanchard.

title: The Nets: Hurting, Missing And Losing
description: Coach John Calipari beat the buzzer, darting off the court and quick-stepping it down the hallway before the clock wound down.

title: The Real Eva Peron, With Surprising Images
description: Fake Evitas are everywhere, or soon will be, from movie screens to Bloomingdale's. Here is a chance to see the real Eva Peron, in life and in mummified death. ''Evita: The Woman Behind the Myth'' is an especially vivid episode of the A&E ''Biography'' series (tomorrow night at 8), filled with photographs and film from the period.

title: Battles for the Throne At a Galloping Pace
description: It is a list of names to choke on: kings and would-be kings and cousins and uncles and aunts and fathers and sons all coming at you like a genealogical cavalry.

title: Giuliani Discussed Hiring Morris as a Consultant for His 1997 Race
description: Three months after Dick Morris quit as President Clinton's political consultant during a sex scandal, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met with Mr. Morris to explore whether he might help run his re-election effort, associates of Mr. Morris and the Mayor said yesterday.

title: 'Artful Interiors' Is Fun!
description: EVERY era has its Martha Stewart. Georgian householders flipped through books on neo-classicism, Victorians swore by Charles Eastlake and 1940's suburbanites scanned Dorothy Draper's ''Decorating Is Fun!''

title: BAY NETWORKS BUYS NETICS IN CASH AND STOCK DEAL
description: Bay Networks, based in Billerica, Mass., said yesterday that it had acquired Netics, a privately held maker of computer networking equipment, for about $99 million -- $55 million of its stock and as much as $44 million in cash. Bay expects to take an unspecified charge in the current quarter for the purchase of Netics research and development. Netics makes switches that help move information between computers. The switches are based on a technology called 100Base-T and will be used in new Bay products. The market for the switches is expected to grow to more than $2.5 billion in 2000 from more than $700 million in 1996, the market researcher International Data Corporation said.

title: Guatemalan Amnesty Is Approved Over Opponents' Objections
description: Struggling to the last moment with the legacy of hatred and brutality left by a long civil war, the Guatemalan National Assembly approved a comprehensive amnesty law today that opponents say will allow many human-rights offenders to go unpunished.

title: CHASE TO BUY SOURCE ONE'S MORTGAGE BUSINESS
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation agreed yesterday to buy most of the Source One Mortgage Services Corporation's mortgage operation, making the bank the No. 2 processor of home loans behind the Norwest Corporation. The New York-based Chase, the largest United States bank, will acquire the right to process payments for $19.3 billion in mortgages from Source One, which is owned by Fund American Enterprises Holdings. Terms were not disclosed. After the purchase, part of the consolidation in the mortgage business, Chase will be processing $160 billion in loans. Mortgage processors charge a fee for collecting loan payments for the banks that hold the loans.

title: 'Little Ironies' Opened Path To School Bill
description: WHY now?

title: Corporate Stonewall
description: To the Editor:

title: City Hall Says Tax Surcharge Was Salvaged in Albany Deal
description: After a long night of on-again, off-again negotiating in Albany, New York City officials said yesterday that they were now confident that a surcharge on the local personal income tax would be renewed for two years beginning in January, averting the prospect of a huge hole in the city's budget.

title: White House Reports Many Visits by Fund-Raiser
description: The Clinton Administration disclosed this evening that Charles Yah Lin Trie, the Arkansas businessman who raised hundreds of thousands of dollars in questionable contributions for the Clintons' legal defense fund earlier this year, went to the White House at least two dozen times in the last four years and was in the Oval Office at least twice.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NANCY KERRIGAN, the Olympic figure skater, has become a mother. She gave birth on Tuesday to her first child, a boy, Matthew Solomon. He weighed 7 pounds 10 ounces. Ms. Kerrigan's husband, Jerry Solomon, is also her manager.

title: U.S. Ponders Special Force To Arrest War Suspects
description: The United States is drawing up plans for an American-led paramilitary force to capture suspects indicted on war crimes charges in the former Yugoslavia, senior officials said today.

title: Slain Red Cross Aides Lived With Danger
description: The job demanded fierce concentration and the kind of serenity that comes mainly with age. Five of the six Red Cross field hospital workers who were slain in their beds by masked gunmen in Chechnya early Tuesday morning were women. All six were middle-aged and unmarried. Work consumed them. But theirs was an idealism tempered by years of experience in other hellish places -- Somalia, Afghanistan, Bosnia.

title: Company Briefs
description: DATA PROCESSING RESOURCES CORP., Newport Beach, Calif., a provider of information-technology staff, agreed to buy another staffing concern, Leardata Info Services of Dallas, for $19.8 million in cash and stock.

title: Poison pills are still popular, but their purpose has changed.
description: WALL STREET'S pharmacy is doing a land-office business as more companies decide that poison pills are a needed part of a takeover defense.

title: Nike Profit Up 81%, Delighting Analysts
description: Nike Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income surged 81 percent, well past Wall Street estimates, on strong sales of its shoes and athletic apparel worldwide.

title: U.N. Says Iraq May Be Hiding More Missiles Than Suspected
description: The leader of a United Nations team in charge of destroying Iraqi weapons told the Security Council today that he believes Baghdad may be hiding more operational missiles than monitors had suspected.

title: Suffocation Approach Wins Again for Devils
description: Martin Brodeur is the Devils' No. 1 goalie, and Mike Dunham gives them a capable backup. They both have enough talent to start, which would raise the specter of a goalie controversy, except that if the Devils play as they did tonight, they won't even need a goalie.

title: Judge Prefers a Long Sentence In Muni Sales Kickback Case
description: A Federal judge said today that he wanted to give a long prison sentence to Mark Ferber, a former partner of Lazard Freres & Company, who was convicted of swindling public agencies around the country of an influence-peddling scheme in the sale of municipal bonds.

title: AVENOR TO ACQUIRE REPAP FOR $449.5 MILLION
description: Avenor Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the struggling Repap Enterprises Inc. for $614.8 million (Canadian), or $449.5 million (United States), in a combination of forest-products companies. The company agreed to assume $1.4 billion of Repap's long-term debt and $990 million in bank loans. The offer values Repap at roughly $3.65 a share; shares of Repap dropped 96.9 cents, or 24 percent, to $3.03 in Nasdaq trading. Avenor said Repap's chairman and chief executive, George S. Petty, had committed to voting his 29 million Repap shares, or about 23 percent of the outstanding shares, in favor of the transaction. Both companies are based in Montreal.

title: Forget Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the killing of six Red Cross workers in Chechnya misspelled the surname of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in some editions. She is Sadako Ogata, not Otagi.

title: Big Brother's Brother
description: To the Editor:

title: Road Mishap Puts a Focus On Shipments Of A-Bombs
description: The Energy Department describes it simply as an ''off normal'' event. But it had all the drama of the opening scene of a post-cold-war thriller.

title: Technical Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: In South Brooklyn, Guarded Desire for Change
description: Asked just a year ago whether they would have supported legislation to severely curtail the power of community school boards, many parents and teachers in District 15 in Brooklyn would have answered loudly in the negative.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Trading Retorts Over Social Security
description: Television interviewers learned early in the recent campaign season that asking a candidate about Social Security was guaranteed to bring forth a pledge on the head of his elderly mother that it would be saved, followed quickly by a change of subject. But off-screen a vigorous debate was developing among economists and others over whether the system deserves saving. That argument moves from the closet to the living room tomorrow night in a two-hour prime-time slugfest on ''Firing Line.''

title: Remembering the Mambo In Its Ballroom Heyday
description: The repertory movement reached into Latin jazz in an exuberant, heartwarming concert on Sunday evening at Aaron Davis Hall. ''Oh . . . So Many Stars'' was a tribute to the three major Latin dance bands of the 1950's, when New Yorkers flocked to the Palladium ballroom on Broadway to mambo the nights away. Big bands didn't disappear with World War II; they just revved up their percussion sections and applied musical sophistication to please dancers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The fashion designer ARNOLD SCAASI has more than one reason to celebrate as year's end approaches. His latest triumph came yesterday when he learned that the retrospective of his work at the New-York Historical Society will be held over through Feb. 9. It had been scheduled to close after a three-month run on Jan. 5.

title: A Misbegotten Amnesty in Guatemala
description: On the brink of ending a brutal war that has killed more than 100,000 people over the past 36 years, Guatemala has made a momentous mistake. Yesterday its congress gave final approval to a law that will make it nearly impossible to prosecute most of the worst crimes committed against innocent people by security forces and guerrillas in the course of the conflict.

title: Hardaway on Injured List
description: ANFERNEE HARDAWAY went on the injured list for the second time this season yesterday, and the Orlando Magic signed point guard KENNY SMITH to fill his roster spot.

title: British Airways to Sell Its Stake in USAir
description: British Airways took another step in dissolving its soured relationship with USAir yesterday, announcing that it planned to sell its stake in its United States partner.

title: A Pattern Among SOD's?
description: To The Home Section:

title: It Gives One to Think, N'est-ce Pas?
description: Hercule Poirot, Agatha Christie's finicky Belgian sleuth, is in the midst of his eighth, and unfortunately last, season on PBS's ''Mystery.'' ''Poirot's Christmas,'' a two-parter beginning tonight, is the final new entry in the Poirot series, produced for London Weekend Television. Reruns will keep Poirot on PBS through early January. Gather them while ye may.

title: Guerrillas in Peru Threaten to Kill Hostages
description: Marxist guerrillas continued to hold hundreds of international dignitaries hostage in the Japanese Ambassador's residence here today after saying on Wednesay that they would begin killing their prisoners one by one unless the Peruvian Government agreed to release the rebels' jailed comrades.

title: Darling: Having A Surreal Time. Are You Here, Too?
description: THE Mondrian hotel, Hollywood's newest hot spot, is a magnificent design for dubious living: a smart place for a time when smart people are finding it very hard to merge.

title: He Shoots, He Saves: Rangers Keep Going
description: Luc Robitaille of the Rangers has been booed for much of the season at Madison Square Garden. His name is often heard in trade rumors. Skeptics wonder if he has lost his shooting touch.

title: How Words Become the Real World
description: FINDING A FORM

title: Texaco Plans Wide Program For Minorities
description: In what civil rights experts described as one of the most comprehensive equal opportunity programs ever adopted by an American corporation, Texaco Inc. yesterday announced initiatives that would significantly expand virtually all of its business dealings with minorities.

title: Lifeline for Widow With Troubled Sons
description: Hilda A.'s adult life began more with promise than with pain, all her hopes conjured in the meeting of eyes on a dance floor in Queens.

title: About-Face, Forward, (Playoff) March!
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars opened the season at home by shocking the league -- and maybe even themselves -- by thumping the Pittsburgh Steelers, 24-9. And then the Jaguars sank fast, losing three in a row. At different junctures in their season, the Jaguars were limping along with records of 1-3, 2-4, 3-6 and 4-7.

title: A Television Rating System Won't Hurt Anyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Once Held as a Spy In North Korea Is a Suicide
description: Less than a month after basking in the Thanksgiving Eve glow of release from North Korea, where he was held as a spy and threatened with execution, Evan C. Hunziker was found this morning in a rundown hotel here with a bullet in his head -- dead in an apparent suicide.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Gains 38.44, As Computer Stocks Climb

title: Madeleine Albright's 'Munich Mindset'
description: One reaction to the nomination of Madeleine Albright as the next Secretary of State is that political convenience has again triumphed over substance in Bill Clinton's calculations. Instead of using the occasion to indicate a clear foreign policy direction, it is lamented, the President characteristically decided to placate a powerful constituency, namely women.

title: Final Stretch for Schools Bill
description: The State Legislature set to meet today for the last time this year -- is expected to pass a long-awaited bill that would add $286 million in state aid to local school districts, including $10 million for middle-class areas. The measure is expected to be approved without much help from the Democratic minority.

title: Hispanics And Blacks Resisted Bill On Schools
description: Of the 23 lawmakers who voted against a bill that would overhaul the way New York City schools are governed, well over half represent heavily black or Hispanic districts where mistrust of the central Board of Education runs high and participation in local school elections has historically been low.

title: Judge to Drop a Publisher's Drug Charges
description: A Manhattan judge has agreed to dismiss drug charges against a publishing executive who was arrested after his wife, a stockbroker, overdosed in their Upper West Side apartment.

title: Police Defuse Crude Bomb on Staten Island
description: A crude homemade bomb was discovered near a natural gas pipeline at a Staten Island construction site yesterday, prompting the police to evacuate two schools and more than 100 homes, then use two remote control robots to defuse the explosive.

title: Tour Without Orchestra Angers City Opera's Hosts
description: Several halls and series in a 68-city tour by the New York City Opera National Company have reacted angrily to the company's plan to send its singers out on Jan. 20 with a two-piano accompaniment instead of an orchestra. Some called the plan unacceptable under any circumstances; others are demanding that the City Opera renegotiate its fees, which run from $23,500 to more than $40,000 per performance.

title: Crude Oil Passes $26 a Barrel; Refinery Problems Are Feared
description: Crude oil prices jumped yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, bolstered by speculation that the Tosco Corporation had encountered new problems making gasoline at its big refinery in New Jersey.

title: Refunds for Utility Customers
description: In other business yesterday, the Board of Public Utilities approved $96 million in refunds to customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, mostly to offset charges related to the out-of-commission Salem nuclear plants. The refund, which will be credited on January and February bills, amounts to about $16 per customer. Customers of the Atlantic Electric Company, a co-owner of the plants, will get $13 million, or $14 a household.

title: Jean-Pierre Guerlain, 91; Led Perfume Company
description: Jean-Pierre Guerlain, who oversaw the international expansion of the perfume company bearing his name, died in Paris last Thursday. He was 91.

title: People
description: * Heide Gardner was named to the new position of manager for diversity and strategic programs at the American Advertising Federation, Washington. She had been director for project management and corporate development at Focal Point Communications, Largo, Md.

title: Brain Damage Found More Common From Bypass Surgery
description: Heart bypass surgery leads to serious physical and mental impairment from strokes and other brain damage more often than many experts had previously believed, a large study has found.

title: U.N. Chief Seems Unlikely To Make Abrupt Changes
description: Kofi Annan, who will take over as Secretary General of the United Nations on Jan. 1, outlined his plans for the organization at a news conference today, leaving the impression that he was not planning any abrupt policy changes.

title: SCHOOLS BILL ADDS TO BOROUGH POWER
description: Tucked into the new school governance bill passed by the State Legislature at midnight Tuesday was an eight-line provision in the 24-page measure that came as a complete surprise to many, even officials actively involved in negotiations on the bill: the creation of new borough-level deputies in the school administration.

title: Netcom to Seek Profitable Niche: Internet Access Just for Business
description: Netcom, one of the country's largest Internet access providers, said yesterday that it would phase out the ''all you can eat'' pricing model next year and would concentrate instead on offering higher-quality, higher-priced services for business users.

title: Reputed New Gambino Boss Is Arrested
description: The man who the authorities say replaced John Gotti only two months ago as the boss of the Gambino crime family was arrested in Florida yesterday on charges of attempted murder, loan sharking and racketeering.

title: Judge Rules Against U.S. in Encryption Case
description: Government attempts to control the export of data-scrambling software are an unconstitutional restriction on free speech, a Federal judge said in a ruling made public today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Dec. 4 about the history of the martini, which was compared to classics that have been reinterpreted, referred incorrectly to the Mozart opera that Peter Sellars staged in a diner setting. It was ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' not ''The Marriage of Figaro.''

title: Tellier's Pact Extended
description: Columbia, where losing had almost become a tradition in football, apparently cannot get enough of its reversal of fortune. The school officially announced yesterday that RAY TELLIER's contract as head coach, which had two years to run, had been extended to a five-year deal running through 2001.

title: Chess's Effort to Attract More Women Is Stalemated
description: It was women's night at the Manhattan Chess Club on West 46th Street. Openly acknowledging what one 20-year member of the city's oldest chess establishment called ''our need to socialize ourselves,'' the club, which has only 12 women among its 225 members, had sent invitations to some 60 women to come and spend the evening of Dec. 9 playing chess, talking chess or even learning chess.

title: Gay Issue Embroils Boy Scouts After a Chapter's Policy Memo
description: A small semantic shift in an internal memorandum at a Boy Scout chapter here has reignited the often volatile issue of homosexuality in the Scouts.

title: Psychoanalysis in Russia Is a Mark of Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Isolating Myanmar Would Only Cause Hardship for Its People
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Money Mysteries, Again
description: Facing an avalanche of new disclosures about White House fund-raising, Attorney General Janet Reno continues to maintain that there is no credible evidence of illegal behavior by senior officials that would require appointment of a special prosecutor. But Ms. Reno's narrow interpretation of the law cannot obscure the fact that someone in Washington -- the Federal Elections Commission, the Justice Department or the appropriate committees in Congress -- needs to get busy. For journalistic reports make it clear that President and Mrs. Clinton, the Administration and the Democratic National Committee were involved in a finance system that was running amok throughout 1996. Money was being harvested while benefits ranging from jobs on obscure Presidential commissions to nights in the Lincoln Bedroom were being handed out like candy.

title: Mirer May Be Out
description: RICK MIRER may miss his final game as a member of the Seattle Seahawks. Mirer, expected to be traded after the season, did not practice yesterday because of a bruised left knee.

title: Train Trip to Vermont Offers Some of the Fun
description: It's a cold, blustery night in New York. The roads are slick with ice; snow is blowing sideways in a whiteout as opaque as sheets on a clothesline. Yet you want to go skiing.

title: Gift of a Forehand Smash
description: Tennis stars are rarely accused of moonlighting as philanthropists, but top-ranked PETE SAMPRAS has made it clear that his participation in tomorrow's Nike Cup exhibition at Madison Square Garden, a benefit for the Tim and Tom Gullikson Foundation, is a not-for-personal-profit venture.

title: A star athlete goes from naughty to nice, hoping to earn a Kodak Advantix camera for Christmas.
description: DENNIS RODMAN, the flamboyant Chicago Bulls basketball star who has a penchant for tattoos, cross-dressing and dyeing his hair fuchsia, is being naughty again.

title: Viag and Veba to Make Joint Bid for Utility Stake
description: Viag A.G. and Veba A.G. said today they would bid jointly for a 25.8 percent stake in Berliner Kraft und Licht A.G., forming a team that analysts say would most likely outbid other contenders for the shares in the electric utility. The joint bid for the stake being sold by the Berlin state government could fall anywhere between 1.3 billion marks ($837 million) and 1.7 billion marks, analysts said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: F.C.C. Plans to Attack Overseas Phone Rates
description: In a full-frontal assault on overseas telephone calling rates, the Federal Communications Commission is expected to announce a series of proposals today intended to slash the $5 billion that American long-distance carriers pay to complete calls to foreign countries.

title: Inquiry Is Set On Prudential
description: A Federal judge today ordered an investigation into document destruction by Prudential Insurance Company of America employees at the company's Cambridge, Mass., office.

title: A Legacy of Presents That Say Too Much
description: AS I lie here -- eyes closed, cold compress on my forehead, soothing Celtic flute music on -- I'm envisioning the perfect holiday gift for you. The one I bought and wrapped two months ago.

title: Valentine Wants Mets To Wait Out the Pitches
description: When his players get to spring training in two months, they will learn that it didn't take Bobby Valentine long to learn what was wrong with the Mets last season.

title: Steinbrenner Endorses 'New' Yanks
description: George Steinbrenner has endured a precarious off season in his power broking and power stroking. He discovered $32 million was not enough to steer Roger Clemens away from Toronto. He found out John Wetteland could get almost $6 million a year to switch baseball addresses to Texas. He also learned that a one-year contract was not enough to prevent Jimmy Key from moving to Baltimore.

title: Nafta's Impact on Employment Is Slight, Study Says
description: Despite arguments from supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement that the pact would bring big employment gains to the United States and warnings from opponents that it would cost hundreds of thousands of jobs, the accord's net impact so far has been slight, according to an academic study to be released on Thursday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Yield Climbs To 6.70% for 30-Year Bond
description: Prices of Treasury securities came under pressure in thin volume yesterday, after traders were disappointed that the response to the Government's auction of new two-year notes was only average.

title: New Rules for Pay Phones
description: Small pay-telephone companies that charge customers up to $9.90 for a collect local call or calling-card call will soon have to change their ways. After fielding more than 500 consumer complaints over the last two years, the State Board of Public Utilities voted yesterday to prohibit the companies from charging more than a dollar above what Bell Atlantic and AT&T charge for an operator-assisted call.

title: Man Called Gotti's Heir Follows His Path to Jail
description: The man whom the authorities say replaced John Gotti only two months ago as the leader of the Gambino crime family was arrested in Florida yesterday on charges of attempted murder, loan sharking and racketeering.

title: On Welfare Generosity
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Garden of Eden, Fouled by Adam and Eve
description: Over the last decade, more than a million people have visited Manuel Antonio National Park here, attracted by the capuchin monkeys, two-toed sloths, poisonous dart frogs, the long-tailed coatimundi and scarlet macaws that roam its lush rain forest.

title: At an Afghan Execution: It's Swift and Personal
description: When it came time for Ghulam Mohammed to die today, he raised his eyes toward the deep blue Afghan sky. Then he stretched his bound hands out before him, palms upward, and gestured swiftly up and down, as though toward heaven.

title: Pistons Put a Screeching Halt to Knick's Streak
description: While Patrick Ewing was pushed around by Rick Mahorn, that 38-year-old Bad Boy, and Allan Houston's homecoming was turning into a nightmare, the Knicks shattered two widely held perceptions tonight: Grant Hill and the Detroit Pistons are doing it with mirrors, and Jeff Van Gundy's team is capable of providing two sustained efforts within 24 hours.

title: The Real Schoolwork Begins
description: For the first time in years, New York City can have real hope about its public school system. Dramatic reforms approved by the State Legislature on Tuesday should end a long era of frustration and lack of accountability. But now the real work must begin.

title: Japanese Form Chip Consortium
description: Japan's major electronics companies are forming a consortium to develop an alternative approach to the microprocessors now used in personal computers, the group's organizer said today.

title: Giuliani Studies Regulating Gambling Cruises
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was creating a commission to oversee operators of gambling cruise ships that sail out of New York City, and to consider how the city can collect fees or taxes from such businesses.

title: Mary Cooper Jewett Gaiser, 95, a Philanthropist
description: Mary Cooper Jewett Gaiser, a philanthropist who served on the boards of nonprofit institutions in the fields of education, community service and the arts, died on Sunday at Deaconess Medical Center in Spokane, Wash. She was 95 and lived in Spokane.

title: In the Eye of a Political Storm, a Peaceful Ashram
description: The disciples speak, joyful-eyed and verbose, about instant enlightenment. The sign over the meditation hall reads, ''Keep Thought, Speech and Body Purified.'' And the bookstore offers dozens of postcard pictures enshrining the woman known as ''the perfect master,'' in poses as princess, as fashion model, as monk.

title: Many Airlines Not Worried By Boeing-McDonnell Deal
description: Even though the proposed merger of the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation would shrink the number of commercial jet aircraft makers to two from three, several airline executives said yesterday that they did not oppose the deal.

title: Bacall Still Walks and, Especially, Talks
description: She's 72, still glamorous and feisty, and looking for work.

title: Money From Private Sources Helps Clinton and Associates With Bad Times and Good
description: Over the past four years, the Clinton Administration and the President's friends have created more than a dozen private funds, financing a range of political and personal causes -- from paying legal defense bills and restoring the President's birthplace to building a White House jogging track.

title: Privatizing Port of Salem
description: The last remaining public portion of the Port of Salem was turned over to private hands yesterday when a lease agreement was signed with a group of British and American investors. Under the five-year lease, the partnership will spend about $15 million in improvements to the docks and infrastructure in the economically depressed city, The Associated Press reported. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Andrew Cuomo Is Prospect for the Cabinet
description: As President Clinton moves to round out his Cabinet by week's end, Andrew Cuomo, an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and the eldest son of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, has emerged as a leading candidate to succeed Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros, White House aides said today.

title: U.S. Agency Moves to Ease Utility Mergers
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission adopted the most sweeping changes in 30 years in its guidelines on utility mergers today, focusing on how such combinations would affect consumers' rates.

title: No Messianic Dreams
description: ''I have strong emotions about the parts of the Land of Israel that are heavily populated by Palestinians,'' Ehud Barak said. ''It has to do with the roots of our civilization.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Buys Marketing Agency
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in New York said yesterday that it had acquired McCracken Brooks, a promotional marketing agency in Minneapolis, from BDDP Group. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Rams Unravel at End, Wasting a Good Effort
description: Fordham's young basketball team was leading Iona, 69-66, last night and had the ball with 1 minute 3 seconds left. Then Fordham did three bad things and lost the game, 71-69.

title: Medical Center Bill Is Yanked At 3 A.M., Angering Backers
description: Officials in Westchester were thrilled to learn today that the State Senate had passed a bill that would turn over management of the County Medical Center to a new public benefits corporation.

title: Jets' Murrell Is Best for the Worst
description: Adrian Murrell, a player who hardly would have been the preseason favorite for individual honors when the Jets imported so many bigger names, was voted today the club's most valuable player by his teammates.

title: Quentin Bell, the Chronicler Of Bloomsbury, Dies at 86
description: Quentin Bell, author, artist, critic and biographer of his aunt Virginia Woolf, died on Monday at his home in Firle in East Sussex, England, near the Charleston farmhouse where he grew up at the center of the Bloomsbury group. He was 86.

title: Entertainer, Denied Job Because He Has H.I.V., Settles Case
description: A cruise line and an employment agency accused in a lawsuit of rescinding a job offer to a man after he tested positive for the AIDS virus have agreed to pay him $90,000 in damages in a settlement that also prohibits the employer from screening for the virus.

title: Tapping 'Mom Power' To Police a Huge Mall
description: Brandy Madsen, a security officer, approached a group of five teen-agers on one of her regular Friday night sweeps here inside the Mall of America, the country's largest shopping center.

title: 'Chetniks' Have Proud History as Anti-Fascists
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cake Stand Worthy Of Its Lineage
description: HOLIDAY hosts with Merchant-Ivory aspirations, take note. Desserts in the 19th century were borne on footed salvers, but alas, such niceties have

title: Ex-Gitano Officials Settle S.E.C. Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged three former Gitano Group Inc. executives today with insider trading and two of the company's former officials with financial fraud.

title: The Pop Life
description: In Demand, Suddenly

title: Banker Wins Libel Suit Against ABC Over '20/20'
description: A Federal jury in Miami awarded $8.75 million in damages yesterday to the chairman of a major bank who had accused ABC News of libeling him in a television broadcast about real estate investments.

title: Judge Rules Breast Implant Evidence Invalid
description: A Federal judge who is overseeing breast implant cases in Oregon has ruled that lawyers cannot introduce evidence saying that implants cause disease, because such evidence is not scientifically valid. He also said that Oregon women with implants cannot sue manufacturers saying they fear they will become ill.

title: DART TO BUY REST OF SHOPPERS FOOD WAREHOUSE CHAIN
description: The Dart Group Corporation said yesterday that the investor Kenneth M. Herman had accepted Dart's bid of $210 million in cash for the 50 percent stake in the Shoppers Food Warehouse Corporation owned by Mr. Herman and his family. Shoppers Food Warehouse is a regional supermarket chain in Washington owned equally by Dart and Mr. Herman. Earlier, Dart invoked its right to demand that Mr. Herman either buy out Dart's stake or sell his share to Dart for $210 million. The deal was announced after Dart's stock closed down $4.875 a share at $92.

title: Trading Ebbs as Technology Advances, Costing Jobs
description: In the rough-and-tumble world of foreign exchange trading, where $1.2 trillion changes hands every day, Matthew S. Lifson fought his way through a string of small banks all the way to the big show -- a job at the Chase Manhattan Bank and the presidency of Forex USA, the industry association.

title: Savings and Loans Win Favorable Ruling
description: Savings and loan associations can recover damages from the Federal Government for the potential profits they lost as a result of a 1989 accounting rule change, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Freighter Captain Says He Overruled River Pilot Before Wreck
description: The Chinese captain of the freighter that destroyed a 200-foot section of this city's downtown riverfront on Saturday testified today that he heard and understood a river pilot's order to drop anchors in the crucial three minutes before the impact. But he delayed doing so, he said, because he was afraid that deployment of the anchors would swing his vessel into a docked cruise ship.

title: 3 at Times Are Promoted to Vice President
description: Three business executives at The New York Times have been promoted to vice president, Janet L. Robinson, president and general manager, announced yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Supervisor Charged With Spying for Russians
description: An F.B.I. agent was arrested today at the agency's training academy on charges that for five years he secretly sold classified information to Moscow in return for payments totaling $224,000.

title: Old Houses, Just Gotta Have 'Em
description: PETER PALUMBO, the British peer who is a peerless collector of modernist houses, turned 61 the day the Fox River flooded last summer. On that memorable birthday, 15 feet of water hurled itself through the window walls of his beloved Farnsworth House here, 50 miles southwest of Chicago, destroying the pristine interiors of the Mies van der Rohe masterpiece and causing the architect's famous daybed to float around like a gondola.

title: As Talks Stall, Somalia Strife Kills 300 Over 5 Days
description: With peace talks on Somalia stalled, rival faction leaders in Mogadishu, the capital, have been waging street battles and hammering each other with mortars for five days in the worst fighting since July, aid workers and diplomats say. At least 300 people have died, many of them civilians, even though no faction has gained any territory.

title: Albany's Marathon Session Dwindles to an Anticlimax
description: Round about midnight on Tuesday, the galleries of the State Legislature were empty. The hordes of spectators, lobbyists and television crews had already begun heading home. Just about the only ones left were the lawmakers themselves, a bleary-eyed and rumpled bunch.

title: Hostile Bid Is Initiated For ADT Ltd.
description: Western Resources, which already owns a stake of 27 percent in ADT Ltd., the country's biggest provider of home security systems, initiated a hostile $3.5 billion cash and stock bid yesterday to buy the rest of the company.

title: Superintendent Under Fire in Central Harlem
