description: Last month, after the superintendent of central Harlem's school district got into a fistfight with a parent advocate in the middle of a school board meeting, speculation mounted that Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew was on the verge of seizing control.

title: Zaire's Leader Names General to Lead Armed Forces Out of Chaos
description: One day after returning home from a long stay in Europe for cancer treatment, President Mobutu Sese Seko announced changes today in the command of the armed forces aimed at restoring Government control over the country's rebellious eastern regions.

title: Army Chief Links Abuses To Failure Of Command
description: The Army Chief of Staff today blamed a failed chain of command at a training center in eastern Maryland for incidents of sexual misconduct there, but suggested that the general in charge of the center might have been so busy with other tasks that he should not be held directly accountable for the problems.

title: In First Test of School Bill, Board Ousts Superintendent
description: In an odd first test of legislation in Albany giving the Schools Chancellor the power to hire and fire district superintendents, Lower East Side school board members allied with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a key sponsor of the bill, last night ousted the district's superintendent, who is widely credited with improving test scores in the district.

title: Heaven vs. Manhattan
description: To The Home Section:

title: Parcells's Thoughts? Don't Bother Asking
description: Bill Parcells may be a great coach, but Mr. Personality he is not. During a conference call with the news media today, he was his usual gruff self, refusing to address anything pertinent. In other words, it was like old times.

title: Storage in a Frame
description: THERE are easy ways to liberate family photographs from their dusty resting places in shopping bags and shoe boxes.

title: Jail Space, Just $10 a Day
description: Checking into the Ocean County jail will now cost $10 a day. The Ocean County Board of Freeholders decided yesterday to become the third county in New Jersey (besides Camden County and Atlantic County) to impose charges on its 370 inmates.

title: Home Team and Visitors In Russian Church Works
description: One of the happier features of this concert season in New York has been a movable feast of Russian Orthodox music. And it reached a climax of sorts over the weekend with sterling performances by Arte Corale of Moscow and the Russian Chamber Chorus of New York.

title: The Rebels and the Cause: 12 Years of Peru's Turmoil
description: Masters of publicity, the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement first burst into Peru's largest news media market, Lima, in 1984 with a spray of machine-gun fire against the United States Embassy, then the most important foreign mission.

title: In the Wake of a Teen-Ager's Death, a Cloud of Racism, Then a Lawsuit
description: SO much has happened in the year since Cynthia Wiggins was struck and killed by a dump truck.

title: Gulf Canada Makes Bid for British Concern
description: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., seeking to expand its oil production into the British portion of the North Sea, offered $:432 million, or $722 million, today to buy Clyde Petroleum P.L.C., which rejected the bid as ''unsolicited and wholly unacceptable.''

title: Albany Holds Up Foster Care Payments
description: Saying that New York City failed to adequately monitor foster parents and keep its records up to date, state officials have refused support payments to hundreds of those who are charged with caring for the city's most vulnerable children.

title: Calendar: Wreaths and Trees By Daylight and Candlelight
description: Candlelight Christmas

title: CHRONICLE
description: Add PRINCE ALBERT of Monaco to the list of public figures who are irritated by the constant attention of the paparazzi. The heir to the throne of the principality says the persistent photographers are to blame for the fact that he is still a bachelor at 38.

title: City to Cancel Its Contracts With Charity
description: New York City said yesterday that it was rescinding more than $800,000 in contracts with a politically connected Brooklyn social-services group whose officials have been accused of stealing its funds.

title: New Tax Cut for Jersey City
description: After imposing an increase in property taxes last year that erased consecutive tax cuts he made during his first two years in office, Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City has proposed another tax cut -- just in time for his re-election bid in May. But to cut property taxes 3 percent, the Mayor also proposed that the city sell a recreation complex to the Board of Education for $8.9 million.

title: Keeping The Faith At Jimmy's
description: EVERYONE has something to say about Felipe Lopez. From the Bronx, where men stand around and debate over lunch, to Minnesota, where a young pro basketballer from Brooklyn offers him advice. Everyone has something to say.

title: Chief Urges Overhaul of Child Care Unit
description: Vowing to produce ''measurable, dramatic reductions'' in cases of abuse and neglect, the head of New York City's long-troubled child welfare agency yesterday proposed a series of steps to overhaul the system radically, including efforts to decentralize the vast bureaucracy and to reduce the amount of time children spend in foster care.

title: A Truce on the Super Bowl By Fox and Time Warner
description: Fox Broadcasting said yesterday that it would not pull a group of stations off cable systems owned by Time Warner, insuring that viewers in cities like Milwaukee, Tampa, Fla. and Austin, Tex., will not have to watch the Super Bowl at the nearest local tavern with a satellite dish.

title: Chief Stepping Down At Samsung Electronics
description: The executive who helped build the Samsung Electronics Company into the world's biggest maker of computer chips resigned as part of the most sweeping management reshuffle in Samsung's 58-year history.

title: Ruling Curbs Use of Name Of Kunstler
description: Ronald L. Kuby, the longtime associate and disciple of William M. Kunstler, may not use his mentor's name in his law practice, a judge ruled yesterday. Deciding in favor of Mr. Kunstler's widow, Margaret Ratner, the judge ordered Mr. Kuby to stop representing himself as Mr. Kunstler's partner and to refrain from using his name in any manner.

title: Politicized trade law: helping companies avoid market forces.
description: IF free market economists wrote their own fair trade law from scratch, the little known Antidumping Act of 1916 would not be a bad model. The law, which is still on the books, provides antitrust protection against predatory pricing by foreigners, sanctioning importers who sell at low prices in America with the intent of putting American competitors out of business.

title: Charities Debate Tactic To Limit Gifts' Life Span
description: When 1996 dies at midnight on Dec. 31, so will New York's Aaron Diamond Foundation -- on schedule and in keeping with its strategy for using up its more than $200 million within 10 years to finance ambitious projects, including a Manhattan laboratory that has been in the forefront of AIDS research.

title: Clinton's Dirty Money
description: Never in the history of the White House has so much influence been for sale for so much money to so many foreign connections.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Boys Choir Is Scrambling, Again
description: It has sung before presidents and diplomats, at the United Nations, the Statue of Liberty and the 1992 World's Fair in Spain. Despite its high profile, however, the 28-year-old Boys Choir of Harlem has frequently had to scramble for money, and now, according to its director, faces a financial crisis that threatens to drastically diminish its voice.

title: Issue in Battle on TV Ratings: Control
description: This morning in Washington, when the television industry introduces its plan for putting sex-and-violence ratings on television programs, the shouting will resume over whether the best system has been chosen. It has often been billed as the beginning of a debate over censorship, but with Government thus far staying out of the process, the issue is more complicated than that.

title: G.M. Encourages Analysts To Cut Earnings Estimates
description: A variety of marketing, sales and production costs has led the General Motors Corporation to encourage analysts to reduce their estimates of the company's fourth-quarter earnings.

title: Seeking Change Where It All Began
description: They were schoolchildren then and there was something breathtaking about the clamor in Ocean Hill-Brownsville: teachers refusing to work, teachers walking into schools under police escort, community leaders confronting the New York City power elite and demanding the right to ''decide who will teach our children.''

title: Adolescent Drug Use Continues to Rise
description: The use of illegal drugs by adolescents continued to rise this year, raising fresh questions about the effectiveness of drug prevention programs for schoolchildren.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Matilda

title: Islanders Lack Punch Without Palffy
description: Life for the Islanders is not the same without Zigmund Palffy. For the Philadelphia Flyers, it could not be better with Paul Coffey.

title: For Children
description: 'A Dyckman Christmas'

title: Real estate agents are increasingly being consulted on plans for new apartment buildings.
description: WITH an increasing number of residential developments around the city, the role of the real estate agent -- traditionally limited to selling -- is being transformed: some of the city's best agents are now being consulted in the planning process.

title: Disputed Study on Clean Needles for Drug Addicts Gets Approval
description: The National Institutes of Health said today that researchers could begin a disputed study to determine the best way for illicit drug users to get clean needles in hopes of avoiding AIDS and other diseases.

title: Subway Flood At Rush Hour Chases Riders
description: More than 50,000 subway riders were sent scrambling for other ways to get home during the evening rush yesterday when a major subway station in Jamaica, Queens, flooded after a faulty pressure valve burst, Transit Authority officials said.

title: Art in Review
description: Charles Searles

title: INSIDE
description: Blue-Chip Stocks Surge

title: Legal Aid Suit Hits Workfare Practices
description: The Legal Aid Society filed a lawsuit yesterday contending that the city was illegally forcing welfare recipients to leave education programs and accept workfare assignments.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: A Family Thing

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football

title: Between a Female Image and Fantasy
description: ''Once Upon a Mattress'' isn't the only revisionist fairy tale being told on a New York stage these days. Down at the WPA Theater you can experience the sordid but uplifting personal history of a not-so-very-wicked stepmother who only wanted to do right by her family and get a little glamour out of life.

title: An Accuser Is Charged In Tax Case
description: Eight years after the Internal Revenue Service began an investigation of the Amcor Capital Corporation -- certain that the agricultural tax shelters it offered were actually frauds costing the Treasury up to $1 billion -- the first criminal charges were brought in the case, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEWBRIDGE NETWORKS CORP., Kanata, Ontario, which manufactures voice and data communication equipment, agreed to buy Tandem Computers Inc.'s UB Networks subsidiary, a maker of computer network equipment, for about $150 million in cash and future payments based on the unit's earnings.

title: Labor Statistics Chief Takes Issue With Critics of Inflation Index
description: In the first formal response to calls for a reduction in the index that measures inflation, the head of the agency that compiles the statistic said today that no significant remedies could be adopted before 1999.

title: Jumping Through A Hoop
description: A writer like Rilke demanded that art change a person's life. Moses Pendleton, the founder and director of Momix, sees to it, at least, that his choreography leaves the viewer refreshed. Fun and games are on the agenda: the company's new bill is an entertaining family show and opens up new definitions and possibilities for dance.

title: Speculation Follows St. Paul Mayor's Switch to Republicans
description: Of all places for Democratic politicians to defect to the Republican Party, traditionally liberal Minnesota would seem to be about the unlikeliest.

title: Curriculum Standards Set
description: Attempting to end the 26-year legal battle over the gap in education quality between rich and poor school districts, the Legislature approved a bill yesterday that would set broad curriculum standards and commit the state to help each district spend what it takes to meet those standards. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she would sign it today. Largely based on a plan she submitted to the Legislature, the measure attempts to provide an equal education for all students by mandating what they should learn rather than how much each district should spend. $(Page A1.$)

title: 6 Arrested Outside Macy's
description: Six people were arrested yesterday in front of Macy's in Manhattan, including a woman dressed like a nun, and charged with duping passers-by into making donations and with operating a shoplifting ring, the police said.

title: Swissair Says a Loss For This Year Is Likely
description: The Swissair Group, the Swiss national airline, warned yesterday that it was likely to report a loss for 1996 amid continued losses at Sabena S.A., the Belgian carrier that is a Swissair partner. Swissair said it might post an unexpected 1996 loss, the second annual loss, and could write down the value of its recently acquired 49.5 percent stake in Sabena. Swissair said in August that it expected to make a profit in 1996. The airline had a 1995 loss of $110.5 million. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Art in Review
description: Mat Collishaw

title: The Rev. Dr. David M. Cory, 93, Preacher of Social Reform
description: The Rev. Dr. David Munroe Cory died on Wednesday, having spent many of his 93 years embracing socialism, preaching to American Indians in their own tongue and generally dashing any notion that he was a blue-blooded Presbyterian.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Winter's Eve Sees Big Area In Cold's Grip
description: Awaking the nation to the official arrival of winter on Saturday, Arctic air blew across the continent this week, burying the Dakotas in snowdrifts, breaking low-temperature records in Colorado, panicking Georgians with snow flurries and sending Texans to an outdoor ice skating rink.

title: Scarcity and Mystery, a Magic Formula
description: ''GEORGES DE LA TOUR AND HIS WORLD'' is here in the rooms of the National Gallery of Art where mobs this year thronged to Vermeer, his near-contemporary.

title: Philip Morris Wins Bidding in Portugal
description: The Philip Morris Companies has won the bidding to take over the Portuguese tobacco company Tabaqueira S.A. as part of the nation's push toward privatization, the Government said yesterday. Philip Morris's bid for 65 percent of the company at 5,100 escudos a share values the takeover at 33.2 billion escudos ($212.1 million).

title: SCHAWK PLANS TO SELL OFF ITS PLASTICS GROUP
description: Schawk Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its plastics group to the Esco Electronics Corporation for about $92 million in cash. Schawk, based in Des Plaines, Ill., said the sale would allow it to focus on its imaging products and services businesses. The plastics group contributed about $75 million of Schawk's revenue of $172.3 million in 1995. Costs associated with the sale are expected to reduce Schawk's earnings by $33 million, or $1.65 a share. Esco Electronics, a military and electronics concern based in St. Louis, had revenue of $438.5 million in the year ended Sept. 30.

title: Komansky, an Old Retail Broker, Takes the World Stage
description: The negotiations were tense, the stakes were high and the players were world class. Merrill Lynch & Company was trying to buy Smith New Court P.L.C., a London brokerage firm it had earmarked as the next must-have piece in its international expansion plan. But the talks last year were snagged over the price and other concerns expressed by Smith's biggest individual shareholder, Sir Evelyn de Rothschild.

title: Trump May Merge 2 Casinos
description: State gambling regulators gave Donald J. Trump a Christmas present Wednesday by agreeing to allow two of his casinos -- Trump Plaza and the World's Fair -- to function under one operating license, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Elderly Man Is Killed By Pit Bulls In the Bronx
description: A sickly 82-year-old Bronx man left home alone with his grandson's three pit bulls was mauled and killed yesterday by one or all of the dogs, the police said.

title: Not as Easy as Pi
description: To the Editor:

title: Hobson Agrees to Enter Drug Program
description: BUTCH HOBSON, a former manager of the Boston Red Sox, agreed yesterday to enter a program for first-time criminal offenders and will avoid jail time for a cocaine possession charge. In the settlement, Hobson acknowledged using cocaine in the past but did not admit guilt. He will be required to lecture young people about the dangers of drugs and may have to submit to drug testing and undergo counseling.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Overby

title: Who's Beating Swords Into Plowshares in Balkans: A Score Card
description: In the course of the Bosnia war, it became axiomatic that the various governments in the region made promises on which they quickly reneged.

title: Mets Show a Strong Interest in Jays' Olerud
description: The Toronto Blue Jays snatched Roger Clemens out of the Yankees' grasp a week ago, but now they are on the verge of sending one of their players to New York. He is John Olerud, and the Mets are seriously discussing a trade that would make him their first baseman.

title: Worker Pursues Robbers
description: The bank robbers sped off in their getaway car, the authorities said, but they never quite got away: they were chased for seven miles and caught by a bank employee and a concerned citizen.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Island of Dr. Moreau

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Serbia Has No Vaclav Havel
description: In its demand for electoral rights, Serbia's opposition has mounted the first serious challenge to President Slobodan Milosevic after nine years of virtual one-man rule. The opposition movement has its flaws, but it offers the only hope for democratic reform in Serbia. It deserves Western support.

title: Tricks of the Gory Trade
description: Having established himself as the best and most mischievous film maker currently working in the dead-babysitter horror genre, Wes Craven (of the ''Nightmare on Elm Street'' films) is in the mood for parody. So ''Scream'' winks at everything from a virginal heroine in a flowered cotton nightie to ''the moment when the supposedly dead killer comes back to life for one last scare.'' Along the way, proving it's not too detached to get down to business, ''Scream'' also finds time to disembowel a pretty young victim or two.

title: Clinton Ready to Fill Cabinet Posts Today
description: President Clinton plans to announce his choices for the remaining Cabinet openings today, including that of Andrew Cuomo as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena as Energy Secretary; Rodney Slater, the Federal Highway Administrator, as Transportation Secretary, and Alexis Herman, a White House aide, as Labor Secretary, Administration officials said.

title: What Will It Take to Make Peace in Israel?
description: To the Editor:

title: New York, the Place to Be for a Celebration
description: SOMETIME in early December, as the air gets clearer and colder, and the people on the sidewalks look more vivid, more sharply etched, I remember that this city, four centuries ago a pastoral island dense with trees and bushes, is today the largest stone sculpture in the world, a sometimes insane triumph of inventiveness over the predictable and ordinary. The buildings know it's winter -- they contract a millimeter, snapping into crystalline focus and carving the sky into a frieze of bold blue patterns. New York is now an extravagant Christmas mise en scene, provoking an endless kaleidoscope of self-realization.

title: A Casino Boat Sails From Brooklyn, Leaving Debate Ashore
description: The roulette wheels spun, the chips clicked and clacked and the gamblers pleaded with the dice. But the tipoff that this was not Monte Carlo, or even Atlantic City, was on the waitresses' trays. Beside the glasses of scotch and white wine were little purple-and-white packets of Dramamine.

title: Providence Guard Misses Court Hearing
description: An arrest warrant was issued for Providence point guard GOD SHAMMGOD after he failed to appear Wednesday for a court hearing in Providence, R.I., on a summons for a traffic accident. Shammgod, 20, a sophomore who played at La Salle Academy in Manhattan, is charged with driving to endanger for an accident at a mall in North Attleboro, Mass.

title: Siedlecki Eagerly Takes Over at Yale
description: Jack Siedlecki took forceful command of Yale's football fortunes today just moments after being introduced as the successor to the venerable Carmen Cozza, who retired after 32 years.

title: School District Elevates Status of Black English
description: In a decision that touches on explosive educational and racial issues, the Oakland, Calif., school board officially declared on Wednesday that many of its 28,000 black students did not speak standard English, but a distinctive language spoken by American blacks.

title: Image of John Brown, Clean-Shaven, Emerges From the Past
description: The National Portrait Gallery unveiled today its most recent photographic acquisition, a daguerreotype of the abolitionist John Brown that shows him clean-shaven and erect, without his prominent gray beard.

title: The Enduring Espionage Wars
description: The spy games of the cold war have proved more durable than the cold war itself. A few weeks ago a fast-rising officer of the Central Intelligence Agency was charged with selling secrets to Russia in recent years. Now a supervisor at the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been arrested and accused of similar misdeeds in the late 1980's and early 1990's. No doubt the C.I.A. has been working just as feverishly in Moscow to learn the secrets of the Russian intelligence services. All this espionage activity seems excessive.

title: A Bride for the Prince? Stack Up the Bedding!
description: THERE'S no denying that, on at least one level, the job description fits. A princess, as you are told (any number of times) in the misbegotten revival of ''Once Upon a Mattress,'' which opened last night at the Broadhurst Theater, should be ''a delicate thing, delicate and dainty as a dragonfly's wing.''

title: The Trouble With Bill
description: We have already seen some of the political fallout from President Clinton's fund-raising scandals.

title: Separated In Old Age By Ingrates
description: Ready for a bighearted, inspiring holiday revival beyond ''It's a Wonderful Life''? The Anthology Film Archives has a lovely suggestion: ''Make Way for Tomorrow,'' a wistful beauty of a film directed by Leo McCarey in 1937, the same year he made ''The Awful Truth.'' With great dignity accompanied by flashes of rueful humor, it tells of a proud old couple (Beulah Bondi and Victor Moore) who can no longer make do financially. Reluctantly, they turn to their five grown children for help.

title: Restaurants
description: Remember manners?

title: Art in Review
description: Jonathan Seliger

title: Diner's Journal
description: If you're feeling flush and festive, the Sea Grill, with its view of the great tree at Rockefeller Center and the skating rink, is a fine place to celebrate.

title: Former Partner at Lazard Gets 33-Month Prison Term
description: Ending one of the biggest criminal cases in municipal finance, a Federal judge today sentenced Mark S. Ferber, a former Lazard Freres & Company partner, to 33 months in prison and fined him $1 million. At the same time, Mr. Ferber settled fraud allegations with the Securities and Exchange Commission by agreeing to pay an additional $650,000 and to be barred from the securities industry.

title: New Small-Town Mayor Is a Man for All Serbs
description: Vojislav Seselj is easy to spot, well over six feet tall with a huge, protruding stomach and a small army of bodyguards in crew cuts and black leather jackets. He races through the city streets in a metallic-gray Mercedes.

title: Former Bond Trader Wins a Round Against Kidder
description: Joseph Jett, the bond trader accused of creating $339 million in false trades at Kidder, Peabody & Company, won a partial vindication yesterday as an arbitration panel rejected Kidder's accusation that Mr. Jett had engaged in ''fraud, breach of duty and unjust enrichment.''

title: AMERICAN BRANDS TAKES CHARGE TO CLOSE FACTORY
description: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that it would take a $55 million charge when it closes a cigarette factory in England as it prepares to spin off its Gallaher Tobacco unit. The company, which makes Master Lock padlocks, Titleist golf balls and Jim Beam bourbon, said about 950 workers at the Gallaher's factory in Manchester would be dismissed when it was closed. The charge will be used in the fourth quarter to cover termination benefits. The plant closing is part of American Brands' efforts to clean up Gallaher's balance sheet prior to the spinoff, which is expected in the second quarter or early in the third quarter of 1997.

title: Another Disappointment in Court for Seles
description: A distraught MONICA SELES received the news yesterday that her $15.7 million civil suit against the German Tennis Federation and its agent DTB for failing to provide sufficient security at the 1993 German Open, where she was stabbed during a quarterfinal match on April 30, has been dismissed by the Hamburg courts.

title: No Headline
description: ''Washington is basically about power, access and influence. If you have power, you have it. If you don't, you don't. I have no illusions.''

title: Christopher Is Sending Envoy to Spur the Mideast Peace Effort
description: Concerned about the ''recent drift'' in the Middle East peace effort, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that he was dispatching his special ambassador to the region, Dennis Ross, to talk to the parties in an effort to ''re-energize this effort.''

title: MacNeil Mitchell, 92, a Legislator in New York State for 27 Years
description: MacNeil Mitchell, who as a New York state senator sponsored legislation that helped to create 150,000 units of middle-income housing around the state, died on Tuesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 92.

title: Words Have a Price
description: Hundreds of thousands of independent artists, musicians and writers owe their livelihoods to copyright -- that is, the right to control the copying of their works. But copyright has come under heavy fire on the Internet lately. At a conference in Geneva this month, the World Intellectual Property Organization of the United Nations has been considering proposals to clarify copyright protection on line.

title: Collectors Both Daring and Lucky
description: FIFTY years ago, major private collections of vanguard American art were few and far between. The venturesome individuals who did collect such work were lucky, though. They had first pick of a fertile harvest and, if they chose wisely, they had treasures for a song.

title: Open Positions of Short Sales Reach a High on the Big Board
description: Short interest positions also increased on the American Stock Exchange, but remain below record levels.

title: IRISH LIFE PLANS TO ACQUIRE ANOTHER U.S. INSURER
description: Irish Life P.L.C. of Dublin said yesterday its United States unit would purchase the U.S. Guarantee Reserve Life Insurance Company for $163 million. U.S. Guarantee Reserve is a privately owned company that provides risk benefits to older age groups. Irish Life has two life insurance units in the United States, the First Variable Life Insurance Company of Boston and the Interstate Assurance Company of Des Moines. Irish Life said its total U.S. premium income would total $400 million after the acquisition.

title: Keenan Is Out As the Coach Of the Blues
description: When Mike Keenan left New York after coaching the Rangers to the Stanley Cup in 1994, the circumstances were cloudy. He didn't exactly resign and he wasn't really fired.

title: Bozell Worldwide Wins 2 Accounts
description: Bozell Worldwide in New York was awarded two accounts yesterday with combined billings estimated at $98 million.

title: Prince Philip Angers Britons on Gun Control
description: Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, spoke out in a broadcast today against pending handgun legislation, using an offhand analogy to cricket, and promptly found himself at the center of the latest round of dismay over the conduct of the British royal family.

title: Paroled Man Attacks Five At a Hospital
description: A paroled convict apparently brooding over the treatment of a 12-year-old daughter who died of leukemia five years ago while he was in prison returned yesterday to a Manhattan hospital and, in a bloody rampage with a razor blade, slashed the girl's doctor and four other people.

title: Nafta Cuts Out 3,922 Jobs
description: New Jersey, a state rich in low-wage manufacturing jobs in older industries, has felt the effects of the North American Free Trade Agreement more than most states, according to a study released yesterday. The study, by researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles, showed that in New Jersey, 3,922 workers -- more than in all but five other states -- are eligible to participate in a United States Department of Labor job-training program created for people thrown out of work because of the trade accord.

title: Banco Santander Buys 80% of Venezuela Bank
description: Banco Santander, Spain's largest commercial bank, has bought majority control of the state bank Banco de Venezuela, Venezuelan officials said yesterday. Banco Santander bid $301.1 million for 80 percent of Banco de Venezuela, the country's third-largest bank. Santander was also given rights to buy an additional 9 to 10 percent of the bank's shares, meaning the overall purchase could be about $338 million. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Prices of Natural Gas Surge As Cold Disrupts Production
description: Natural gas prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as freezing weather disrupted output in Texas and Louisiana at a time of lean inventories and rising demand.

title: Medical Report Gets Better For the Nets
description: The eagerness of Jayson Williams is endearing when it comes to his zest for rebounds but nerve-racking when he makes his own diagnosis.

title: Rank Says Profit Won't Improve in Half
description: The Rank Group said yesterday that growth in operating profit would not improve in the second half, causing a drop in the company's shares as investors expressed doubt about Rank's new focus on leisure and entertainment units like the Hard Rock Cafe chain of restaurants. In the first half, operating profit before a one-time gain rose 12 percent, to $:93 million ($155.7 million). As part of the new focus on leisure businesses, Rank plans to sell more than $:1 billion in assets, including its 20 percent stake in Rank Xerox. But the company told analysts yesterday that it might not sell the stake, valued at $:930 million, until 1998. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: New Weapon: The Muffin
description: Crime is continuing to plague holiday shoppers, despite beefed-up security at New Jersey malls. A woman from New Rochelle, N.Y., had her car stolen Wednesday night at the parking lot of the Garden State Plaza while she was reporting a robbery, the Paramus police said.

title: Look, Up in the Air, It May Be a Toyota
description: Will Toyota's next model have wings?

title: 'Judaizing Jerusalem'
description: ''The Israelis are trying to Judaize Arab East Jerusalem.''

title: Bombings Aimed at Nigerian Government Raise Questions
description: When Col. Mohammed Marwa, a close aide to the Nigerian military leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, narrowly escaped two explosions this week, one near his office and the other a bomb attack on his convoy as he was driving through Lagos, many Nigerians began to wonder whether it was a sign of a stepped-up campaign against the Government.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Joe's Apartment

title: Art in Review
description: Elizabeth Bishop and Robert Bordo

title: MERCK AND RHONE-POULENC IN JOINT VENTURE
description: Merck & Company and Rhone-Poulenc S.A. said yesterday that they were combining their animal health businesses in a joint venture, creating the world's largest maker of medicines for pets and livestock. The joint venture, to be called Merial Animal Health, will have yearly sales of about $1.7 billion, passing Pfizer Inc. in the $10.7 billion market. The financial details of the agreement were not disclosed. Merck's shares rose $4.375, to $81.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Under the agreement, Merial will sign production and research agreements with the two parent companies and will have access to their drugs and technologies that could be applied to animal health.

title: $25 and Under
description: A Family Steakhouse

title: The South Has Risen. It's the North.
description: DIXIE RISING

title: Art in Review
description: Ron Ehrlich

title: Is It Hayes Or Boggs? Now Who's On Third?
description: Before a bubbly David Wells even pulled on his new pinstriped jersey as the $13.5 million pitcher who is expected to be the last major addition to the 1997 Yankees, an intriguing story had already blossomed in another corner of the Stadium Club at Yankee Stadium. Get ready for the Yankees' version of ''Who's on Third?''

title: CHRONICLE
description: A Harlem librarian sued the author JOE KLEIN and his publisher yesterday, contending that his novel, ''Primary Colors,'' portrayed her as an adulterous woman who had an affair with a politician resembling PRESIDENT CLINTON.

title: Accepting Nature On Her Own Terms
description: NOT the most dynamic of 19th-century American landscapists, William Trost Richards (1833-1905) started out as a painter of almost obsessive detail, virtually turning the great outdoors into a series of well-wrought still lifes.

title: Former Boeing Workers Seek Pension Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Marcello Mastroianni, Self-Deprecating Charmer of Italian Film, Is Dead at 72
description: Marcello Mastroianni, the Italian actor whose diffident but romantic charm made him one of the movies' best-loved Latin lovers and whose keen dramatic sense made him an international star in such films as ''La Dolce Vita'' and ''8 1/2,'' died today at his home in Paris. He was 72 and also had a home in Rome.

title: Tokyo Takes Usual Path: Conciliation And Caution
description: The hostage crisis in Peru may be on the other end of the globe, but Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has been bustling about in an effort to resolve it, setting up task forces and talking to foreign leaders and dispatching envoys to the scene.

title: To a Team Like Knicks, Years Are Often Unkind
description: About 2 A.M. Wednesday, the Knicks' charter plane landed in Detroit. Tired and sore, Patrick Ewing and his teammates shuffled through another airport, rode another charter bus to another hotel and tried to catch some sleep before a morning shoot-around and a game that night.

title: Italy Joins Death Row Appeal In Virginia
description: There can't be many people left in Italy who have never heard of Joseph Roger O'Dell 3d, an inmate on Virginia's death row who, but for an eleventh-hour stay of execution issued by the Supreme Court, would have been put to death on Tuesday by lethal injection.

title: Treasures Trickle Back to a Plundered Cambodia
description: In 1924, the French writer Andre Malraux was arrested and imprisoned when he removed nearly a ton of stone carvings and ornaments from a temple in the remote Cambodian jungle and trundled them away in oxcarts.

title: Cutting A Rug With Song
description: Nobody seems to have told Doug Varone that there is less than a week left for Christmas shopping and it seems to have been raining forever. Mr. Varone, known for dark dances, offered bubbling Champagne on Wednesday night at Performance Space 122 in the East Village. ''Let's Dance: The Cabaret,'' which continues through Sunday at the theater, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, is the perfect antidote for holiday misery and comes with refreshments and a post-performance dance party.

title: Meet. Fight. Fall in Love. What a Day!
description: ''One Fine Day'' is about great looks, and not only because it stars Michelle Pfeiffer and George Clooney as one cute twosome. This film also revels in New York City at its touristy best, dashing madly among appealing landmarks all around the town. The list of locations ranges from the ''21'' Club to the Circle Line to Central Park to City Hall and includes the environs of Radio City Music Hall. That's where a big, bright, squeaky-clean romantic comedy of this sort might once have played.

title: Vote in Trenton Sets Standards On Curriculum
description: Seeking to end a 26-year legal battle over the education quality gap between rich and poor school districts, the State Legislature today approved a bill that would set broad curriculum standards and commit the state to help each district spend what it takes to meet those standards.

title: Playing Through Pain, Widmer Proved Tough
description: Linebacker Corey Widmer has had an outstanding year, playing well at middle linebacker when many thought he would not. And over the last six weeks, Widmer has quietly played with painful bone chips in his elbow, an injury that has prevented him from fully extending his right arm.

title: White House's Odd Man Out Reflects on Ouster
description: Harold M. Ickes sounds surprisingly gentle in his final days at the White House, given his reputation as a flinty infighter who does not yield anything easily, least of all his own perch on power.

title: Interference Called
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Dropped By 30.2 Percent in October

title: More Shares Are Sold In Bull by France
description: The French Finance Ministry said yesterday that it had sold 10 million shares in the computer company Groupe Bull for 22 francs a share to Motorola, NEC and Dai Nippon Printing. France Telecom raised its stake in the company to 18.7 percent from 17 percent. NEC and Motorola also raised their stakes in Bull to 18.7 percent from 17 percent while Dai Nippon raised its stake to 5.8 percent from 3.3 percent. I.B.M. lowered its stake to seven-tenths of a percent from eight-tenths of a percent and Bull employees lowered their share to 3.5 percent from 4 percent. The state cut its directly held share to 30.5 percent from 37 percent. (Dow Jones)

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17

title: Art in Review
description: Cody Choi

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANNA WINTOUR, editor in chief of Vogue, was just winding up a holiday lunch with three colleagues in the Grill Room of the Four Seasons yesterday when a well-dressed woman approached her table, pulled out a dead raccoon and tossed it onto her plate.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 17
description: SATURDAY 12:30 P.M. GAME

title: Inflation Is More Than a Pocketbook Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Rival Bidders Raise Offers For Conrail
description: The CSX Corporation and its rival, the Norfolk Southern Corporation, traded body blows yesterday in an increasingly expensive battle for control of Conrail and rail freight traffic in the Northeast.

title: Army's Sutton Wins Coaching Award
description: BOB SUTTON, who directed Army to a 10-1 record this season, won the Bobby Dodd national coach of the year award for 1996. The award, named in memory of the late Georgia Tech coach, is given each year by the American Sportsmanship Foundation in cooperation with the Bobby Dodd Foundation ''in recognition of a higher and more noble aspect of college coaching: a belief that the game of football should be kept in perspective of college life in general.'' Sutton, in his sixth season at West Point, will take his team to the Independence Bowl to face Auburn on Dec. 31. (AP)

title: Law to Help Police Win Big Pay Raises Is Voided
description: The state's highest court declared unconstitutional today a law that would have helped New York City police officers and firefighters win larger pay raises, delivering an important victory to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in his effort to hold down labor costs.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Drama? Nah. This Is Show Biz!

title: DIPLOMATS IN PERU SHUTTLE TO TALKS TO FREE HOSTAGES
description: As the siege on the Japanese Ambassador's residence here stretched into its third night this evening, diplomats shuttled between Peruvian officials and rebel leaders in an attempt to free about 400 international dignitaries held hostage by Marxist guerrillas.

title: Inside Art
description: Monet Here, There, All Over

title: The Death of the Last Emperor's Last Eunuch
description: Over the centuries, the most secretive and grotesque corner of China's extensive imperial court belonged to the fraternity of special guardians: the eunuchs, whose high voices and soft demeanors often cloaked the viciousness of their back-alley politicking and custody of the Forbidden City's magnificent exotica.

title: A Handmaiden, Time Saver and Occasional Rival
description: In 1839, when a French official introduced Daguerre's invention in the Chamber of Deputies, he predicted that the new medium would be immensely useful to the arts and sciences, but he spent more time describing its effect on painting and sculpture. Speaking of the benefits to draftsmen and painters, he said: ''The process will afford them a quick and easy method of forming collections of sketches and drawings, which they would not be able to procure, unless they were to spend much time and trouble in doing them with their own hand, and even then they would be far less perfect.''

title: A Friendship Transcends The Past
description: THE young German knocked on the door in Flushing, Queens, and was let into the book-lined apartment by the aging Jew, a survivor of several Nazi concentration camps.

title: Royal Caribbean Cruise Line Indicted on Charges of Dumping Oil
description: Royal Caribbean Cruises, a huge cruise line that advertises its commitment to environmental protection, routinely dumped waste oil from five of its ships for years and falsified its log books to hide its activities, according to a 10-count felony indictment unsealed today.

title: Joan Hartman-Goldsmith, 63, Scholar of Chinese Art and Jade
description: Joan Hartman-Goldsmith, an art historian and writer known for her expertise in Chinese works, especially jade, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 63.

title: Looking Beyond the Loud
description: To sum up Tony Williams as a loud drummer has become a way of avoiding listening to him. His heavy-handedness has become an inevitable quantity, but underneath it is a powerful understanding of song form and rhythmic flow. In an early set on Tuesday night at Birdland, he occasionally thudded and bashed the music down but generally let it levitate again.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Let his friends go to Miami, the Caribbean or Mexico. GIL GROSS is seeking summertime weather farther south: in Antarctica.

title: A Parody of a Pregnant Actress Stands Up in Court
description: When the actress Demi Moore, eight months pregnant and nude, appeared on the cover of Vanity Fair magazine in August 1991, the photograph by Annie Leibovitz raised eyebrows and made a best seller of that issue.

title: Whitewater Defendant Is Sent to California Jail in a Second Case
description: Susan McDougal, a former partner in the Whitewater land venture who has been jailed for refusing to testify before a grand jury about President Clinton, was transferred last weekend to a county jail in Los Angeles for preliminary hearings in a separate criminal case.

title: Ending a Bad Police Law
description: New York City has won an unusual but welcome victory against the heavy hand of state micromanagement. The State Court of Appeals yesterday ruled unanimously that the Legislature was overstepping its authority when it changed the rules for arbitrating contract disputes between the city government and its police and fire unions.

title: For a True Story, Dipping Into the Classics
description: ''This story is true,'' reads an opening title in ''Ghosts of Mississippi,'' Rob Reiner's self-important new drama. But true as it is, Mr. Reiner's film feels like the Hollywood version. In describing how Byron De La Beckwith, the assassin who killed the civil rights leader Medgar Evers, was brought to justice 30 years after his crime, Mr. Reiner falls back on pat dialogue, courtroom grandstanding and the excessive nobility of a white crusader helping black victims.

title: Compared to What?
description: To the Editor:

title: Domino Effect at the Top Is Looming for Vietnam
description: The prospect of a domino effect is once again troubling Vietnam as the severe illness of one of the nation's three aging leaders is forcing it to face the long-postponed issue of generational change at the top.

title: Home Video
description: Promoting Quirky Films

title: Fred Schulman, 77, Nuclear Chief at NASA
description: Dr. Fred Schulman, a former chief of nuclear space power programs at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, died on Dec. 9 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 77.

title: Help for a Father and Daughter Who Faced Eviction
description: Even as her father removed his favorite rocking chair, packed his clothes and took the television set, Elsie Detres refused to safeguard her own possessions, convinced that she could stop the marshals from padlocking the apartment door.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Maid Is Hired: Danger Is Served
description: IN ''La Ceremonie,'' the instant suspense classic that is Claude Chabrol's best thriller in more than a decade, the action unfolds in an elegant, isolated chateau whose inhabitants rely unduly on the comforts of the television screen. Upstairs, the maid watches junk in her room; downstairs, the rich, complacent owners are capable of planning a black-tie evening around a broadcast of ''Don Giovanni.'' And in between, danger lies in the social and cultural tensions that have made natural enemies of these separate classes.

title: Environmental Defiance
description: Carol Browner decided that she had been ignored and insulted by the Commonwealth of Virginia long enough. The normally patient administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency sued Smithfield Foods for $125 million last week, one of the largest fines in the E.P.A.'s history, for allegedly dumping illegal levels of hog waste into a Virginia river that feeds into Chesapeake Bay. The E.P.A. believes that the fine, which Smithfield will contest, is not excessive for a company whose revenues are nearing $4 billion or inappropriate given the violations it is charged with, which include dumping a toxic brew of fecal coliform, ammonia, cyanide, oil and grease into the Pagan River.

title: No More Knocking the Suns
description: He is wearing tube socks, sandals, jeans, polo shirt, wedding ring and his latest accessory: whistle. Danny Ainge is fresh out of the players union, one year removed from a hearty booing in Houston, and now he somehow answers to ''Coach.''

title: Elster Going to Pirates
description: After having earlier rejected an offer to remain with the Texas Rangers, the American League West champions, shortstop Kevin Elster decided yesterday to play for the Pittsburgh Pirates, perhaps the worst team in the National League. Elster, who had career highs with 24 home runs and 99 runs batted in last season, agreed to a $250,000 signing bonus and a $1.4 million salary.

title: Former Boeing Workers Seek Pension Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: How F.B.I. Ensnared Agent Suspected of Spying
description: Last Dec. 28, a recently retired Russian diplomat sat surrounded by law books in Room 228 of the New York Public Library, waiting to meet an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Jet Victories, Not Prizes, Mean Most to Johnson
description: The contract is complicated, and Keyshawn Johnson says he hasn't even read it. So in this Jets season of nothing but frustration and failed promise, the prize rookie said today that he did not even know whether he will get a bonus for setting a record for first-year receivers.

title: French Drug Stocks Soar as Elf Proposes Alliance
description: French drug stocks surged today as Elf Aquitaine S.A. proposed that its pharmaceutical unit, Sanofi S.A., form a strategic alliance with another company.

title: Hexter's Good Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Tainted Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Urges City to Extend Savings on Trash
description: After a crackdown against a suspected Mafia cartel, trash-removal costs have recently plunged by two-thirds or more for some office towers and major customers in New York City.

title: Davis of Iowa State to Turn Pro
description: TROY DAVIS of Iowa State, the first major college football player to rush for 2,000 yards twice, announced yesterday that he would forgo his senior year to make himself available for the 1997 National Football League draft.

title: Campbell Soup To Shift Assignments
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it would again realign assignments among its agencies, this time involving brands with billings estimated at $100 million out of total billings of $250 million.

title: New York Crime Rate Plummets To Levels Not Seen in 30 Years
description: From midtown Manhattan to Riverdale to the Rockaways, New York City's crime rate has plunged for the third straight year, dropping 16 percent below last year's figures, preliminary Police Department records show.

title: A broad patent is spurring the shares of Protein Design Lab.
description: SHARES of Protein Design Labs Inc. have gained nearly 25 percent since the company disclosed on Monday that it had been awarded a broad patent covering the production of so-called humanized antibodies in mice.

title: Yuli B. Khariton, Father of Soviet Atom Bomb, Dies at 92
description: Yuli B. Khariton, a physicist who oversaw the building of the first Soviet atomic bomb, died yesterday morning at Sarov in central Russia 250 miles east of Moscow. He was 92 and had lived at Sarov, also known as Arzamas-16, for many years.

title: Trade Deficit Declined Sharply in October
description: The nation's trade deficit declined sharply in October despite widening gaps with Japan and China, the two nations that have been the focus of American trade policy, the Government said today.

title: Rumblings in New Jersey About a Yankee Plan
description: Where will the Yankees play when their lease in the Bronx expires in 2002? Only the Manhattan Project was kept this close to the vest. The choices remain staying at a renovated Yankee Stadium, moving south to the West Side of Manhattan or heading west to New Jersey.

title: Correction
description: A chart on Wednesday showing the rise in the Dow Jones industrial average, with an article about holiday parties on Wall Street this year, misstated the starting date of the period covered by the chart. It showed Dow closes from Dec. 30, 1994, through Tuesday, not from 1995.

title: A Cuomo Seen as One of 4 Final Cabinet Picks
description: President Clinton plans to round out his selection of a new Cabinet on Friday with the announcement of his choices for several remaining openings, including that of Andrew Cuomo, the eldest son of the former New York Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Administration officials said today.

title: Prices Surge As Inflation Remains Low
description: The Treasury market surged yesterday, amid more signs that the economy is slowing and inflation remains low. Market enthusiasm was lifted by a report on manufacturing and by a solid Treasury auction. Interest rates in general fell near the levels of a week ago.

title: Devils' Effective Defense Drama Enough for Lemaire
description: Someone might look at the Mona Lisa and merely see a tight-lipped sourpuss. Someone might look at the Venus de Milo and see only a piece of plaster with missing arms.

title: John's Wish Comes True, Almost
description: ALL those years, John McEnroe fixed his withering glare at line officials, wishing they would drop through a crack in the earth. He once called a Wimbledon chair umpire, ''Pits of the world.''

title: Trying to Deal With the Customers Who Want Their Cars Back, and Now!
description: It's 8:44 in the morning, and Ralph Simmons is fuming, at least inwardly. Not just one, but two absent-minded businessmen have knotted up the parking garage he manages by leaving their cars and walking off with the keys.

title: Bundesbank Takes Steps To Pave Way for Euro
description: The Bundesbank set its first two-year money supply target yesterday, outlining a strategy to keep interest rates across Europe stable and pave the way for adoption of a common currency, the Euro, in 1999.

title: Quaker Oats may bring back the Snapple Lady.
description: AS the Quaker Oats Company considering another fling with Wendy the Snapple Lady?

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES IS SELLING ITS AUDIO BUSINESS
description: Mark IV Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Mark IV Audio business to an affiliate of Greenwich Street Capital Partners Inc. for $151.5 million in cash. Mark IV Audio, a maker of professional audio products, had revenue of $195.5 million in the year ended Feb. 29. Mark IV Industries, of Amherst, N.Y., makes power and fluid transfer systems and components for industrial and automotive markets. Mark IV's stock was up $1.25 yesterday, to $22.375 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Greenwich Street Capital Partners, based in New York, is a private equity fund.

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''JEWISH TRADITIONS IN INDIA,'' American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and West 79th Street. A lecture on the Jewish sects that emigrated from India to Israel in the 1950's and those that remained in India, by Joan Roland, a history professor at Pace University. Tomorrow at 2 and 3:30 P.M. Admission, $8; $6 for students and senior citizens; $4.50 for children. Information: (212)769-5315.

title: Breast-Feeding Rights
description: Legislation to protect the right of mothers to breast-feed their babies in public was unanimously approved by the Senate yesterday. The bill before the Senate had been stripped of an amendment added by the Assembly last month, which would have permitted restaurants and hotels to force mothers to breast-feed in sections set aside for that purpose. The sponsor, Assemblywoman Shirley K. Turner, Democrat of Ewing Township, said the amendment undermined the bill's purpose. The bill goes back to the Assembly.

title: Dow Up 126.87; Point Increase Is 2d Best Ever
description: Driven by a decline in interest rates and trading in the futures market, the Dow Jones industrial average raced to its second-best point increase in history yesterday, surging 126.87 points, to 6,473.64. But in percentage terms, the Dow's jump of 2 percent was just the 47th best since the 1987 crash.

title: Perry Says Pentagon Didn't Withhold Data on Gulf War Illnesses
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that any perception that the Pentagon had intentionally withheld evidence from the public about the possible causes of illnesses among veterans of the Persian Gulf war was ''dead wrong.''

title: TV Industry Leaders Unveil Technique of Rating Shows
description: The two most popular shows on television, ''E. R.'' and ''Seinfeld,'' may sometimes be labeled inappropriate for children under 14 -- ''E. R.'' for blood and gore, ''Seinfeld'' if it deals, as an episode once did, with a topic like masturbation. And the first broadcast network program to earn a rating of ''TV-M'' -- for adults only -- will be the movie ''Schindler's List,'' which NBC will broadcast, uncut, in February.

title: SUBPOENAS ISSUED ON CONTRIBUTORS
description: The Justice Department has issued subpoenas to the White House and President Clinton's legal defense fund seeking four years' worth of records containing details of activities by many of the Democrats' most important fund-raisers and supporters.

title: Looking Backward
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale and Its Union Reach Settlement on a Six-Year Contract
description: Yale University and its union declared a truce today in one of the most bitter labor-management relationships in higher education, announcing an agreement that gives the university the right to subcontract work while guaranteeing all union members their jobs for 10 years.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Reginald Marsh's New York'

title: Hormones Coursing O'er the Land
description: ''Beavis and Butt-head Do America,'' the nastily amusing feature film debut of those tittering, pig-snorting MTV cartoon groundlings, finds the duo coping with the worst of all possible fates: the theft of their precious television set. Unable to soak in music videos from morning till night, and unable to sleep without the drone of television to lull them, America's most libidinous couch potatoes leap at the first job opportunity that presents itself.

title: Giving the White House A Couple of Black Eyes
description: Is it just coincidence that Jack Lemmon and James Garner, as bickering ex-Presidents in ''My Fellow Americans,'' look a lot like George Bush and Richard Nixon? Probably not. In this funny, farcical spoof of Presidential mediocrity, greed and arrogance, any resemblance to an American statesman living or dead is pure gravy. If the moviegoing public guffawingly laps up the film's bone-deep cynicism, it will be a sign of just how tarnished the nation's highest office has become since Watergate.

title: A Camby Acquaintance Arrested in Extortion Bid
description: A Connecticut lawyer who had hoped to become Marcus Camby's agent was instead charged with attempted extortion today, accused by the authorities of providing the former University of Massachusetts basketball star with cash and sex and then threatening to expose him.

title: Carrefour Raises Stake In GMB, Causing Feud
description: Carrefour S.A., France's largest publicly traded food retailer, raised its stake in the privately owned Societe GMB to 41.4 percent, causing a feud in the family that controls GMB and threats of a bidding war for the rest of the retailing group. GMB's president, Philippe Bouriez told a French newspaper he would consider linking up with a competitor like Auchan, a major Carrefour competitor.

title: UMass vs. N.C. In the Jimmy V
description: One legendary basketball coach at North Carolina will help honor another legendary one from that state at the Meadowlands tonight when Dean Smith brings his Tar Heels to Continental Arena as part of the Jimmy V Classic.

title: Panama Will Keep Canal Apart From Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics Panel Was Misled On Gingrich, An Ally Says
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich, under investigation after being accused of giving false information to the House ethics committee, did make an erroneous statement, but it was his lawyer's fault, Representative John Linder of Georgia, a close Gingrich ally, said today.

title: Rethinking the Schools Where Changes Began
description: The year was 1968, and the neighborhood was Ocean Hill-Brownsville. Then and there, school decentralization was born with heady expectations of better education for the children. But ultimately local control of the schools never yielded the breakthrough its backers had promised. And now many parents look forward to a new era where the power of local school boards are sharply curbed. Article, page B3.

title: Gingrich Error at Issue
description: Newt Gingrich's lawyer caused him to mislead an ethics panel, an ally of the Speaker said, as others sought more explanation. Page A32.

title: Peru Shrugged Off Warnings Of Rebel Attack, Experts Say
description: Terrorism experts said today that Peru dismissed several well-executed attacks in the last year and ignored warnings that foreshadowed the commando-style takeover of the Japanese ambassador's house, where guerrillas are holding several hundred hostages.

title: Head of F.B.I. Says It Can't Trace Disclosure in Olympic Bomb Case
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has not been able to identify the person who told reporters that Richard A. Jewell was a suspect in the Centennial Olympic Park bombing in Atlanta last summer, Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the bureau, said today.

title: COKE SAYS WORLDWIDE SALES OF CASES ARE UP 10%
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it expected worldwide sales of cases to rise about 10 percent in the fourth quarter, a sharp improvement from the third quarter. Coke, the largest maker of soda in the world, said the largest part of the increase occurred in Latin America, Europe, the Mideast and the Far East, where the gains ranged between 16 percent and 10 percent. North American case sales are expected to increase 5 percent to 6 percent. The sales met the most optimistic of Wall Street's forecasts. Shares in Coca-Cola, based in Atlanta, rose $2.75, to $51.125, in trading of 5.2 million shares.

title: Dole Goes to the White House, at the President's Invitation to Talk
description: Bob Dole made it to the White House after all.

title: Call It 'Gay Friends'
description: Michael has a lot of problems. His boyfriend, Greg, broke up with him; he can't get the bar boy, Ron, to notice him, and his roommate, Kenny, has met the man of his dreams.

title: Woman and Son, 6, Are Slain in Bronx
description: A woman was found slashed to death and her 6-year-old son hanged by an electrical cord in their South Bronx apartment late Thursday, the police said.

title: A Proper Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: S.M.U. Hires Cavan
description: Southern Methodist University hired Coach MIKE CAVAN to turn around its football program. ''His background of building programs is what caught my eye,'' the S.M.U. athletic director, JIM COPELAND, said. ''I think he can pull that off here.'' (AP)

title: State Agrees to Speed Help For Infants Without Homes
description: New Jersey agreed today to stop keeping healthy infants whose parents are unwilling or unable to care for them in hospital wards for weeks and sometimes months at a time.

title: Bridge
description: In a close match, there is usually one pivotal deal that sticks in the players' minds when it is all over. In the October final of the Greater New York Bridge Assocation's Harter Cup, a double-knockout team event for non-life masters, it was the one shown in the diagram.

title: In Tokyo, Speculation About Role For Castro
description: As officials search for ways to end the hostage crisis in Peru, one of the more intriguing possibilities is the notion of asking for help from Cuba.

title: Just Say No More to Tourists and Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Killed by Gunman Posing as Deliveryman
description: A gunman posing as a United Parcel Service deliveryman and an accomplice invaded a brownstone apartment on the Upper West Side yesterday and shot and killed a fashion designer, Roy Ogden, and wounded his companion, Roberto Andujar, who was listed in serious but stable condition after surgery at Roosevelt Hospital. The shootings stunned neighbors on the block, on West 75th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

title: A Coaching Dilemma Only the Jets Could Have
description: ONLY the Jets.

title: No Headline
description: ''Dorothy and I being retired, it's quite a jolt to see these prices go up. When that delivery truck comes along, I don't quite swear, I say shoot, or something a little stronger, the truck is here again.''

title: ABC Held Liable for Fraud In Reporting on Store Chain
description: In a closely watched media case involving the use of hidden cameras and undercover reporters, a Federal jury in Greensboro, N.C., found yesterday that ABC producers trespassed and committed fraud when researching a ''Primetime Live'' segment in 1992 suggesting that a supermarket chain sold spoiled meat.

title: An Inevitable Conclusion For the Jets
description: THE television trucks, with tall masts carrying heavy cable, gave a sense of impending doom yesterday: something bad was about to happen. Of course, in the ''Alice in Wonderland'' world of the Jets, bad often means good, and what is clear becomes obscure.

title: Court Rejects Big Toy Store In Manhattan
description: New York State's highest court rejected plans yesterday for a big toy store on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, in a ruling that several lawyers said would make it easier for people throughout the city to fight businesses they see as threats to the residential character of their neighborhoods.

title: An Immigrant Revels in Land Of the Free
description: FREE Verdi. Free Bergman. Free Christo. And, why not, Free Bird, too. Sound like the demands of an odd terrorist group with a soft spot for Lynyrd Skynyrd? Consider it the rallying cry of Natella Vaidman, a Russian immigrant who came to America in 1979 to savor freedom -- with the emphasis on free.

title: The Knicks Cast Out Some Demons
description: Exorcism night went well for the Knicks. Gone was the major discomfort the Philadelphia 76ers had caused Jeff Van Gundy. Gone was Allan Houston's lack of confidence. Gone was the Allen Iverson highlight reel.

title: Giants Begin Their Quest For a Coach
description: It is the final game of the regular season and, from the Giants' perspective, this afternoon's contest at Giants Stadium against the New England Patriots does not matter. What is happening off the field involving Coach Dan Reeves is more important. And there is a lot going on with that situation.

title: Messinger Chooses a Consultant With No New York Experience
description: Laying the groundwork for her 1997 campaign for mayor, Ruth W. Messinger has selected a consultant who has not worked in New York to direct her effort to win the Democratic nomination and challenge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, her aides said yesterday.

title: Loan to Fix Haledon Dam
description: The dam that created Haledon Reservoir, which supplies water to the residents of Haledon and part of North Haledon, was built in 1939 and needs major renovations to reinforce the structure and safeguard the water supply. That work can be done with a $1.1 million low-interest loan that was approved by the Senate Thursday and sent to the Governor. The loans for the Haledon dam -- and seven others in the state -- will be made through bonds worth $8.6 million authorized by the Green Acres Bond Act of 1992.

title: Mets Hoping For a Little '93 From Olerud
description: In acquiring John Olerud from the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday, the Mets raised some questions, but they offered answers both by explanation and by the terms of the trade itself.

title: Crisis Attracts Readers to Web
description: Since the hostage-taking in Peru on Tuesday night, hundreds of computer users have clicked onto a Web site devoted to the case of Lori Helene Berenson, the New Yorker who is serving a life sentence in a harsh mountaintop prison in Peru after being convicted last year of treason by a secret military tribunal.

title: Union-Run H.M.O. Will Aid the Working Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite the Dangers of Steroids, Bodybuilders Are Still Tempted
description: Dave Palumbo did not know the young men, but he had heard what they had done and he shook his head in what-fools-these-mortals-be disgust. Then he shifted his body in his chair ever so gingerly, for that body is his franchise, his obsession, his work in progress.

title: Price of Heating Oil Hits Highest Levels Since the Gulf War
description: The way oil prices are jumping, Barney and Dorothy Foltman figure it will take at least $300 more to heat their home in Rye, N.Y., this winter than last, a 25 percent increase.

title: Kotite Fires Himself Before Jets Can Fire Him
description: After presiding over the most agonizing stretch of ineptitude in the history of one of sport's most beleaguered franchises, Rich Kotite fired himself as coach of the New York Jets today, but said he would coach the team for its season finale on Sunday.

title: Mere Shadow of Itself, UMass Takes a Beating
description: Nine months ago, Massachusetts reached the Final Four of college basketball. The Minutemen had the player of the year in Marcus Camby and a bright young coach in John Calipari.

title: Same Predicament, Different Agency: Federico Fabian Pena
description: President Clinton's plan for Federico F. Pena is to move him from one sprawling, cash-strapped bureaucracy trying to downsize, the Department of Transportation, to another, the Department of Energy. As Mr. Pena noted this afternoon, each is more a conglomeration of programs than a unified department.

title: Mrs. Onassis's Estate Worth Less Than Estimated
description: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis's estate was worth far less than was widely estimated at the time of her death, and her two children will get most of her assets, leaving very little for charity, according to the State Attorney General's office.

title: French Concern Selling Its Construction Unit
description: The French electrical equipment and construction company Schneider S.A. will sell its Spie Batignolles segment to the unit's management and Amec P.L.C. for a total of 1 billion francs ($190 million).

title: Having His 'Messiah' and Tradition Too
description: The classical music world likes to regard itself as the guardian of tradition, steadfastly resistant to trends. But anyone interested in measuring how far that conceit is from reality need only look in on the annual parade of ''Messiah'' performances. Trends never die in ''Messiah'' readings; they merely move over to make room for their successors, and now the interpretive styles of several generations -- everything from Victorian grandeur to scaled-back period-instrument readings -- coexist peacefully.

title: Bleak Choices Facing Zaire's Fallen Idol
description: For one whole day this week in Kinshasa, it was like old times. When President Mobutu Sese Seko returned to Zaire on Tuesday from four months of cancer treatment, his name and his name alone seemed to be on every tongue; his image crowded every view.

title: Hard Work And Talent: Rodney Earl Slater
description: When Rodney E. Slater was a senior on his high school football team, a scout from Eastern Michigan University happened, by chance, to see him play and recruited him. Four years later, when Mr. Slater was a college senior, his speech professor was so impressed with his performance in class that he persuaded him to join the college's competitive-speaking team.

title: U.S. Chooses 2 to Develop New Rocket
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation will each receive about $60 million to develop prototypes for the Air Force's next family of rockets, Air Force Secretary Sheila Widnall said today.

title: Open the Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Becker's Home Raided
description: German tax investigators raided BORIS BECKER's home and took away several files, a newspaper said yesterday. The Bavarian Finance Ministry neither confirmed nor denied the report in Bild. The documents seized Thursday from the tennis star's home in Munich concerned 1990-93, when Becker was living in Monaco to avoid high German taxes, Bild said without naming sources. Becker was on vacation in Florida, the paper said. (AP)

title: 2 Are Shot, One Fatally, By Intruders
description: With Christmas deliveries approaching floodtide, a gunman posing as a United Parcel Service deliveryman and an accomplice invaded a brownstone apartment on the Upper West Side yesterday and, in an apparent robbery that went awry, shot and killed a 53-year-old fashion designer and wounded his companion, the police said.

title: Io Scrivo Linguine
description: Bumping into Santa Claus outside the five-and-dime, I dropped a dollar into his bucket and asked him to bring me a three-month vacation at a villa in Tuscany for Christmas. This is why I am now studying the beautiful Italian language, or, as I shall call it when among the Tuscans, il lingo Italianissimo bel canto.

title: Standards That Sound Different
description: The pianist Ray Bryant spent his first set at Sweet Basil ruminating on standards. He played ''Take the A Train'' and ''Come Sunday,'' and his improvising was beefy and robust. Mr. Bryant's rhythmic sense, complex and sure, made the walls of the tune, the harmonies and melodies, fall away.

title: New Union Vote at Casino
description: About 950 dealers at Tropicana Casino and Resort will vote today for the second time this year on whether to join the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, The Associated Press reported.

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS TO ACQUIRE SEVERAL BUSINESSES
description: Arrow Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the electronic component distribution businesses of Premier Farnell P.L.C. for about $300 million. The Premier businesses have annual sales of $500 million and operations in 15 countries, distributing products including semiconductors and connecting components to manufacturers and other industrial customers. Arrow, based in Melville, L.I., distributes electronic components and computer products.

title: Guatemala's Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nightmare in Lima: Hostages in Squalor
description: Three days ago a glittering crowd of diplomats, business executives and Peruvian officials jammed into the elegant residence of the Japanese Ambassador to eat sushi and toast the birthday of Emperor Akihito of Japan.

title: Natural Gas Prices Surge Again On Cold's Threat to Production
description: Natural gas prices surged yesterday for a second consecutive session on the New York Mercantile Exchange on persistent concern that frigid weather would cut production in Texas and Louisiana while bolstering demand across the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Ralph Simmons, who manages a parking garage in lower Manhattan, misidentified the man shown with him. The man was an unidentified customer, not Victor Morel, an employee.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Nancy Macdonald, who aided refugees of the Spanish Civil War, misstated the year of Francisco Franco's death. It was 1975, not 1974.

title: Four New Choreographers From Japan
description: Solo dances in various moods were featured in a program called ''New Japanese Choreographers'' this week at Dance Theater Workshop. The presentation, arranged by Mayumi Nagatoshi, was most compelling when choreographic images were vivid -- not necessarily forceful or bizarre but eye-catching and clear-cut.

title: Powlus Stays With Irish
description: RON POWLUS, the Notre Dame quarterback, said yesterday that he would return for his fifth year of eligibility at the school, and cited the recent Irish coaching change as the biggest factor in his decision.

title: Criticism of Cynicism
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7

title: Gingrich's Lawyer Seeks to Quicken Ethics Case
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich's new lawyer, J. Randolph Evans, is trying to speed up the ethics case of Mr. Gingrich, hoping to make it easier for Republicans to vote for him for Speaker on Jan. 7, Congressional officials said tonight.

title: Doyennes of Philanthropy
description: Declaring that the foundations they head have largely fulfilled their missions, Brooke Astor and Irene Diamond are going out of business. New York City, where so much of their philanthropy was centered, will sorely miss their civic contributions.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Holiday Road Trips

title: Limits on Panhandling
description: Following the lead of several other cities, including New York, Mayor Sharpe James signed an ordinance yesterday that will ban aggressive panhandling. Begging will be prohibited in front of bank entrances and automated teller machines and in lobbies and at parks, playgrounds and parking lots. Panhandlers must refrain from touching passers-by, making threatening gestures or blocking pedestrians or cars, said the Mayor's spokeswoman, Pamela Goldstein.

title: The Rangers Are Winning, but Campbell Is Still Nervous
description: The Rangers have lost only once in their last 11 games after winning 7 times in their first 24 games, but Coach Colin Campbell is still unimpressed about the rather remarkable turnaround.

title: City Opera Relents: Orchestra Will Tour
description: Bowing to pressure from presenters who were unhappy with the New York City Opera's plan to send out its national touring company with piano accompaniment instead of an orchestra, the company has decided to use an orchestra after all.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Calipari Puts Blame For Loss On Bench
description: A demolition crew toured the Omni Arena today, looking for weak points to set implosion charges for this spring's detonation of the building.

title: DANA TO BUY A UNIT OF INGERSOLL-RAND
description: The Dana Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Ingersoll-Rand Company's Clark-Hurth Components subsidiary, which makes off-highway vehicle parts. Financial terms were not disclosed. Clark-Hurth Components had 1995 sales of $350 million and operates factories in Belgium, Italy and the United States. Dana said it would combine the Clark-Hurth operations with its Spicer Off-Highway units to form an Off-Highway Components Group that would produce axles, brakes and transmissions for heavy-duty vehicles. Dana, an auto parts maker based in Toledo, Ohio, had 1995 sales of $7.6 billion. Ingersoll-Rand, a maker of industrial and construction machinery, is based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Chip Makers Scrap Plan For Malaysian Factory
description: The LG Semicon Company unit of the LG Group of South Korea and Hitachi Ltd. of Japan have scrapped a plan to build a $1.25 billion semiconductor plant in Malaysia, citing slumping computer chip prices and inadequate incentives offered by the Malaysian Government. Global chip prices have plunged this year because of flat demand for personal computers and excess capacity.

title: Escape From Bedford Falls
