description: Yes, we all want to believe ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' but what if our lives are less than wonderful? What if we live not in the Christmas-card setting of Bedford Falls, like Jimmy Stewart's George Bailey, but in a grimy city where that sound of crunching underfoot emanates not from fresh snow but from a spent pint bottle nesting in its brown paper bag? What if lovable old Mom and Dad are angrily divorced? What if Mary, the dreamy girl-next-door, is a nut case?

title: Liberty Theater Facing Virtual-Reality Future
description: The already crowded game board of the new Times Square is about to acquire a new player. Sega Gameworks, a joint venture of Dreamworks SKG, MCA and Sega Enterprises, is in the final stages of negotiating a lease on the Liberty Theater on 42d Street. The company was created in March to develop arcades of interactive attractions and computer games.

title: Things Of This World
description: My father died on Thanksgiving night. As I sat with family and friends over the next few days, my grief and sense of disbelief barely lessened.

title: The Universal Shame of Child Labor
description: On any given day, an estimated 250 million children between the ages of 5 and 14 work under dirty, hazardous conditions in developing countries and many more toil as migrant farm workers in industrialized countries. In many cases, work takes the place of school.

title: Social-Worker Roots and Political Experience Lead to Labor Post: Alexis Margaret Herman
description: For a time this past week, it seemed as though Alexis Margaret Herman's beginnings as a social worker developing jobs for Southern women, and her later experience as a Labor Department official in the Carter Administration, would be overlooked in her quest to be Secretary of Labor.

title: Rebels in Peru Release 38 But Still Detain Over 300
description: Peruvian guerrillas released 38 hostages tonight, the largest group freed since the early hours of the raid on the Japanese Ambassador's residence on Tuesday night, but they continued to hold more than 300 international envoys and business executives captive.

title: School Reform Is Needed, but Do It Properly
description: To the Editor:

title: Palffy Returns to the Lineup
description: Zigmund Palffy will be back in the lineup tonight when the Islanders play host to the Dallas Stars at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders announced yesterday.

title: Reality Versus Legality In Use of Christmas Tree
description: The doorman had never heard of such a thing. He called down the superintendent, who said he had never heard of such a thing. But the two firefighters who trudged into the Astor Court apartment building on West 89th Street at 1 A.M. Tuesday swore it was so.

title: Japan, in Error, Overstated the Foreign Share of Its Chip Market
description: Japan significantly overstated the share of its market held by foreign semiconductor companies in the first quarter of the year, at the time the United States and Japan were negotiating a new computer chip trade agreement.

title: Company Briefs
description: INTERSTATE HOTELS CO., Pittsburgh, a hotel management company, agreed to acquire Marriott International Inc.'s Casa Marina and Beach Resorts in Key West, Fla., for about $94.3 million.

title: CS Holding to Take a Charge Of $3.8 Billion for Bad Loans
description: CS Holding said today that it would take a charge of $3.8 billion to cover bad loans, joining its major Swiss rivals in preparing for a flood of sour loans as the domestic economy flounders.

title: KEYSTONE FINANCIAL IN STOCK DEAL FOR FINANCIAL TRUST
description: Keystone Financial Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Financial Trust Corporation for $371 million in stock in a move that would reduce expenses and add customers in central Pennsylvania and Maryland. Keystone, the fifth-largest Pennsylvania bank, plans to exchange 1.65 shares of its stock for each Financial Trust share. Financial Trust's stock surged $10.8125, or 37 percent, to close at $40.0625. Keystone fell $1 a share, to $25.74. Financial Trust, based in Carlisle, Pa., has $1.2 billion in assets and operates 48 branches in Pennsylvania and Maryland. Keystone, based in Harrisburg, Pa., said it would take a $10 million charge to cover merger-related expenses. Keystone has 147 branches in Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia.

title: Simpson Wins Custody Fight For 2 Children by Slain Wife
description: A family court judge restored O. J. Simpson's two young children to him today, awarding him full custody despite his being on trial in a wrongful-death suit that accuses him of killing their mother and a friend.

title: Ex-Air Controller Is Acquitted of Fraud
description: A former air traffic controller has been acquitted of charges that he defrauded the Federal Government of $830,000 in disability benefits.

title: INSIDE
description: Jury Rules Against ABC

title: Businessman at White House Social Has Close Ties to China's Military Power
description: The White House said today that no one knew who Wang Jun was when he passed through the gates last February to meet President Clinton at a coffee set up by the Democratic National Committee. But he is well known to almost everyone else in Washington involved in monitoring China, including Federal law-enforcement agents.

title: U.N. Shift on Rwandans A Bow to 'New Realities'
description: In supporting the recent expulsion from camps in Tanzania of more than 200,000 Rwandans, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has departed from its longstanding opposition to forced repatriation of refugees, agency officials here acknowledge.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Battered and Bruised, Devils Come Home with 3 Victories
description: Marked men, the Devils were tonight. The Oilers took cheap shots, one that led to an injury, and repeatedly tried to steamroll Devils goalie Martin Brodeur. But the Devils, at the end of a three-game trip through western Canada, showed why they are rolling up the Eastern Conference standing.

title: Churches Rescue a Town
description: For 50 years, residents of Port Norris, an 850-mailbox town in Cumberland County, have shopped at a site most recently occupied by Newcomb Market, the only grocery store within 18 miles. But on Dec. 8, a single-engine plane crashed into the market, killing the pilot and injuring a customer in the store. The crash also destroyed the store and left the town without a nearby supply of fresh meat, frozen food or produce. Because the town does not have a public transit system, three local churches responded to the crash by arranging temporary bus service -- beginning yesterday -- to the nearest supermarket, a Pathmark in neighboring Millville. The driver of the bus, Pastor Chris Miller of United Methodist Church, said public transportation agencies have ignored Port Norris because it is economically depressed. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Keep the Independent Counsel
description: The Independent Counsel Act is under fresh attack. One of the most valuable reforms to emerge from Watergate, the law requires the Attorney General to ask a special three-judge panel to appoint a special prosecutor if there are reasonable grounds to believe ''specific credible allegations'' made against senior executive officials. Critics complain that the law covers too many officials and is too easily invoked for cases that could be handled by the Justice Department.

title: Manley Can Go to Game
description: The former Washington Redskins defensive end DEXTER MANLEY was granted a weekend travel permit by the Texas Parole Board, allowing him to attend the team's final game at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium tomorrow. Manley, who was paroled on Nov. 4 after 14 months of a four-year prison sentence for drug possession, will be part of the halftime celebration. (Bloomberg)

title: Clinton Fills Cabinet After Scramble to Diversify
description: President Clinton filled out his Cabinet for his second term today after a last-minute scramble to give the team more racial and ethnic diversity.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Brooke Astor's plans to close the Vincent Astor Foundation misidentified her son, who expressed support for his mother's decision against leaving it in his hands or someone else's. He is Anthony D. Marshall, not Tony Russell.

title: Black English Plan Baffles Some Students in Oakland
description: Like many of his classmates at Oakland Technical High School, Aaron Andrews had just one question about the school board's decision to declare black English, not standard English, as the ''primary language'' of its black students.

title: Patriarchal Yeltsin Says He's Eager to Get Back to Work
description: In his first sustained address to the nation since he underwent heart surgery on Nov. 5, President Boris N. Yeltsin assured Russia today that he is rested and ready to address some of the country's most pressing problems when he returns to the Kremlin on Monday.

title: For a Political Son, Forging an Identity: Andrew Mark Cuomo
description: During the hectic days when Andrew M. Cuomo was the principal adviser to his father, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, he would sometimes take a moment to consider his own career. The younger Mr. Cuomo was ambitious -- he, too, wanted to be a governor one day -- but was convinced, he would say with an edge to his voice, that it could not happen so long as his father remained a force in Democratic politics.

title: Minimum Sentence Imposed in Firefighter's Death
description: The man convicted of murder earlier this month for setting a fire that led to the death of a firefighter received the minimum sentence of 15 years to life in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday. Firefighter Louis Valentino, 37, was killed last February after responding to a blaze in an illegal Brooklyn garage when the roof collapsed under the weight of snow and crushed him.

title: Treasury Prices Are Lower In Day of Weak Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were weaker yesterday, with volume down considerably. Foreign investors, retail traders and money managers stayed mostly on the sidelines ahead of the forthcoming holidays.

title: Generosity Of Children Helps Those With Less
description: Just as the neediest New Yorkers are often the youngest New Yorkers, so too are those who are moved to help them.

title: Stars Throw Out Rules for a Good Cause
description: They don't play tennis with wooden racquets anymore. Shots that hit the scoreboard don't usually count, and coaches don't often sit on a player's lap during change-overs. But those oddities came off without a hitch in the anything-goes atmosphere of the Nike Cup exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Teacher Named in Assaults
description: A former fifth-grade teacher at an Atlantic City school was indicted yesterday on charges that he sexually assaulted six students between September 1990 and last June, prosecutors said. The teacher, Kenneth Wilburn, 52, was accused of fondling the girls at the Chelsea Heights Elementary School, on school field trips and in his home in Somers Point, according to prosecutors. Mr. Wilburn, an Atlantic City public school teacher since 1970, was arrested in September.

title: Carol Robbins, 54, Who Taught Music to the Profoundly Deaf
description: Carol Robbins, a trained musician, educator and co-director of the Nordoff-Robbins Center for Music Therapy at New York University, died on Dec. 12 at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 54.

title: At Off-Price Stores, the Thrill of the Hunt
description: Christmas retailing conjures images of fanciful window displays, richly wrapped gifts and department store Santas. But a far less refined sector of the industry, known as off-price, may be the one that cleans up this holiday season.

title: Germany Drops Daimler-Benz Investigation
description: German prosecutors said today that they had dropped an investigation into accusations that top managers of Daimler-Benz A.G. deliberately misled investors about the company's financial condition in 1995.

title: English Works Without the Tinsel
description: The holiday season brings with it an undercurrent of musical Anglophilia that is expressed most directly in the old English carols and Victorian arrangements that have become standard fare, and indirectly in the countless performances of Handel's ''Messiah,'' a cosmopolitan work by a German composer who lived in London. Curiously, this spirit largely vanishes during the rest of the year, when many American listeners reject the works of the 20th-century English mainstream composers as bloated and mawkish.

title: Steven Jobs Making Move Back to Apple
description: In a daring gamble to revitalize itself, Apple Computer Inc. announced tonight that its co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, would return to the company to help create an operating system based in part on the technology he developed after resigning 11 years ago.

title: He Knows His Opera: He Dug the Pit
description: Oh my gosh, isn't that. . . .? It can't be! Yes, it's them! It's the Three Tenors, onstage at -- the Dicapo Opera Theater in a Manhattan church? Singing: ''You deserve a break today, at McDonalds,'' and ''Double your pleasure, double your fun.''

title: Armstrong Recovering
description: The cycling star LANCE ARMSTRONG said he is back on track toward a normal life after tests showed no cancer in his body. Doctors told Armstrong that he will most likely not have to have more chemotherapy or surgery, The Austin American-Statesman reported yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the New York State legislators who opposed a bill passed on Tuesday that gives more power to New York City's Schools Chancellor misidentified the area represented by Assemblyman Anthony J. Genovesi, Democrat of Brooklyn, who voted against it. His district, the 39th, encompasses Canarsie and some adjacent neighborhoods; it does not include Bushwick.

title: Vast Plant For Tanks Has Closed
description: Longer and broader than the Statue of Liberty is tall, the vast tank factory in Warren, Mich., helped give the Detroit area its nickname as the Arsenal of Democracy, and contributed to the legend of Rosie the Riveter, the model woman worker in the arms industry during World War II.

title: Hong Kong Puppet Play
description: Hong Kong is officially set to be handed over to China on June 30, 1997. But a de facto transfer of sovereignty is set to happen today in Shenzhen, a border town in southern China, when Beijing appoints a puppet legislature that will eventually replace Hong Kong's elected Legislative Council. It will be the beginning of the end of human rights and the rule of law in Hong Kong.

title: More 'Trojan Women'
description: La Mama E.T.C. has added performances of ''The Trojan Women.'' In addition to a matinee today at 3:30 P.M., there will be evening performances on Thursday and Friday and a matinee and evening performance next Saturday. Information:(212) 475-7710.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Widenhofer Is Coach
description: WOODY WIDENHOFER was promoted to head coach at Vanderbilt yesterday to succeed ROD DOWHOWER, who resigned under pressure a week earlier. Dowhower quit after consecutive 2-9 seasons. Widenhofer, 53, came to Vanderbilt in January 1995 to handle defense. (AP)

title: A Pioneer Passes
description: The generation of local heroes who first carried the civil rights revolution across the South is slowly passing, and the death of Arthur D. Shores of Birmingham, Ala., at 92 leaves a formidable gap in the pantheon of surviving pioneers.

title: Whitman Plan to Standardize School Spending Becomes Law
description: Laying a cornerstone for her re-election bid, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation today that sets broad new curriculum standards for public schools and makes drastic changes in the way that education is financed in the state.

title: Corrections

title: Strange, That's Santa in the Seat of the Sultans!
description: Santa's rosy cheeks and broad smile are beaming from store windows, trees have been bought and decorated, the strains of ''Jingle Bells'' and ''Silent Night'' waft through the air in cafes and shops, and children wait anxiously for the moment when they can unwrap their gifts. All is as it should be at this time of year.

title: Speight Leaves B.C.
description: KIERNAN SPEIGHT is leaving Boston College for Hampton University, while his family remains determined to find out how he came to be wrongly accused in the Big East school's gambling scandal. Speight, a sophomore cornerback, returned to his old high school in Washington yesterday to announce his transfer.

title: 7 Chicago Police Officers Indicted in Extortion Scheme
description: For the second time in eight days, law-enforcement officials in and around Chicago have been indicted for crimes committed under the cloak of duty and justice.

title: Dollar Is Flat to Slightly Down As Traders See Pause in Rally
description: The dollar slipped against the German mark and was little changed versus the Japanese yen yesterday, in what traders described as a pause in the dollar's rally.

title: Iraq Reports Uncovering A Spy Ring Led by C.I.A.
description: The Iraqi Government said today that it had uncovered an espionage ring sponsored by the Central Intelligence Agency, and it broadcast the confessions of four Iraqis who said they had taken part in the operation.

title: GLOBAL AGREEMENT REACHED TO WIDEN LAW ON COPYRIGHT
description: Negotiators from some 160 countries reached agreement in Geneva yesterday on the most sweeping extension of international copyright law in 25 years, the chief United States representative said, paving the way to broaden protections for the creators of art, software and music into cyberspace.

title: DENDRITE SHARES PLUMMET ON DISAPPOINTING OUTLOOK
description: The stock of Dendrite International Inc. plunged 59 percent yesterday, a day after the software maker said that it expected to post a fourth-quarter loss and revenue below year-earlier levels. Dendrite, based in Morristown, N.J., also said Thursday that delays in orders would hurt revenue and profits for the full year. Analysts had predicted fourth-quarter profits of 21 cents a share. Dendrite attributed the decline to the failure of expected new business to materialize, delays in customer orders and high research and development costs. Shares of Dendrite plummeted $11.625, to close at $8 in Nasdaq trading.

title: 3 Arrested in October Shooting Of Police Captain in the Bronx
description: Acting on a tip from a driver with a suspended license, the police arrested three men yesterday in connection with a sniper attack on a police captain outside his precinct station two months ago.

title: Tajik Gunmen Seize 23 Hostages, Including 8 U.N. Observers
description: Tajikistan's civil war worsened today when gunmen loyal to a rogue warlord abducted eight United Nations military observers and threatened to kill them and detonate bombs around the capital.

title: Carl Sagan, an Astronomer Who Excelled at Popularizing Science, Is Dead at 62
description: Carl Sagan, an astronomer who became one of the nation's best-known scientists by enthusiastically conveying the wonders of the universe to millions of people on television and in books, died yesterday at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle. He was 62 and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Transfer Back to Texas
description: A judge today granted a request by Susan McDougal, a former partner in the Whitewater land venture, that she be returned from custody in Los Angeles to a Federal prison in Texas while she awaits trial in a theft case here.

title: Progress for Trauma Center
description: The Helene Fuld Medical Center's application to become a state-certified trauma center cleared the first of several hurdles Thursday, when it got the blessing of a state regional health advisory board. Mercer County has no trauma center, and the Trenton-based hospital contends that transporting victims of serious or life-threatening injuries to distant hospitals puts them at risk.

title: Same Faith, but Different Approaches
description: For Christians everywhere, the approach of Christmas offers a unifying ground for the celebration of Jesus' birth. But a certain unity, of course, never means uniformity. What happens within the very broad bounds of a particular faith, no matter the season, depends on its diverse followers, whose various concerns and projects help keep religious traditions alive and dynamic.

title: Court Allows CUNY Layoffs and Changes
description: Overturning a lower court decision, an appeals court ruling has cleared the way for the City University of New York to abolish City College's black studies department and to lay off about two dozen professors in other departments throughout the system.

title: $1.43 Billion Fortis Deal To Buy Unit of Amro
description: Fortis, the Belgian-Dutch bank and insurer, said yesterday that it would pay 2.5 billion guilders ($1.43 billion) in cash to buy Mees Pierson N.V. from ABN-Amro Holdings N.V., giving Fortis an instant presence in investment banking. Fortis said the purchase would help earnings next year for both its parent companies: Fortis Amev of the Netherlands and Fortis A.G. of Belgium. ABN-Amro benefits by ridding itself of an in-house rival to its British investment bank, ABN Amro Hoare Govett.

But after sober reflection, industry officials are realizing that any final pact will take years to put in place and may not even address the most important barriers to United States technology exports.

description: The Paxar Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the remaining 55 percent of closely held Monarch Marking Systems from Odyssey Partners L.P. and Monarch's management for $130 million in cash, warrants and stock. Paxar bought a 45 percent stake in Monarch, based in Miamisburg, Ohio, a supplier of bar-code products to retail and industrial customers worldwide, in June 1995 with Odyssey Partners for $30 million. Paxar, based in White Plains, is a leading maker of identification products for the apparel and textile industries. Paxar's shares rose $1.125, to $17.875.

The co-op residents had sued, complaining that the 200-foot-tall complex would have put many of their apartments into darkness. Under the agreement negotiated before the State Supreme Court, Baruch agreed to redesign the top two floors so that they cast a smaller shadow on 330 Third Avenue, the co-op building 10 feet northwest of the complex. Baruch agreed to hold informational meetings, as needed, with the residents. Two single-room occupancy hotels have been cleared and construction is set to begin in February and finish in the autumn of 2000. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

title: Nick's Pix
description: Perhaps December doesn't need another book about Santa Claus or his real-life counterpart, St. Nicholas, but two new small and arty books, for adults, satisfy a reader briefly. THE SECRET LIFE OF SANTA CLAUS (Chronicle, $17.95) is an illustrated alphabet book, originally published in France. ''A'' is for ''actually,'' and the example given is: ''Some of Santa's elves actually have a car. A real car.'' Next to ''actually'' is Gregoire Solotareff's painting of a hot-red 1940's-style automobile. The cuteness grates after the letter ''B,'' so don't feel bad if you want to skip the text and just derive pleasure from the artwork and its jaunty humor: the thickly painted, almost smeared images in primary colors (red, of course, being dominant) are so generous in feeling that you flip through the pages without a trace of humbuggery. THE LIFE OF SAINT NICHOLAS (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $18.95) is a whole other animal. The life is portrayed in comic-bookish parables drawn by R. O. Blechman in pen and ink, lightened with muted silk-screened color. The vignettes swirl around how Nicholas, born a Roman in A.D. 314, just as Christianity had gained legal tolerance, got to be so saintly. At a young age, Nicholas becomes aware that Roman life is grossly unfair. This dawning occurs as he is riding with his privileged parents in their caravan and he notices poor people. ''Who are all those people out there?'' he asks. ''Close the curtain, Nicholas!'' he is told. ''They look so wretched!'' he responds. Thereafter, he travels the Empire to work ''miracles.'' Nicholas eventually becomes a near-martyr (he saves himself from a bull) after he is thrown into an amphitheater for giving his overcoat away to someone in need. Mr. Solotareff's book is incidental but picturesque; Mr. Blechman's tries to be soul-searching. Like these books, Christmas in the 90's is an amalgam of both approaches. Dulcie Leimbach

title: Paved With Promises
description: Natalie L. M. Petesch's latest collection of stories, THE IMMIGRANT TRAIN (Swallow/Ohio University, cloth, $24.95; paper, $14.95), offers a sobering series of portraits of newcomers from Lunawicz, Poland, as they arrive in America in the early part of this century. Portraying an experience of unrelenting heartache and disappointment, Ms. Petesch presents the disparity between the opportunity her characters expect to find and the exploitation and poverty they actually encounter. In a representative story, ''The Beekeeper,'' a young man accustomed to farm life works 12-hour shifts in a Pittsburgh steel mill and lodges in an overcrowded tenement. For consolation, he spends his savings on a swarm of bees -- and is promptly rejected by his narrow-minded fiancee for, as she sees it, lavishing more care on his hive than on her. In ''The Orphan Train,'' a motherless boy leaves New York and goes to work for a family in Minnesota, harvesting vegetables and carting water to miners in the iron pits. His attempts to find his father, who had abandoned the family to head west, eventually come to naught. The most ambitious section of the book, the novella ''Pawel in America,'' depicts a politically persecuted doctor who emigrates with a forged passport and is snared by the authorities when he gives his countrymen medical attention. The stories in this volume are written with evocative, understated prose and contain memorable characters, yet the sameness of their conclusions suggests that the author has political as well as artistic objectives in mind. In ''The Immigrant Train,'' Ms. Petesch pays tribute to the millions who embarked on new lives here, believing, however incorrectly, that ''opportunity is everywhere in America.'' Gardner McFall

description: THE elegant Art Deco buildings stretching skyward around the sunken plaza in Rockefeller Center dwarf the little girl with red hair and a lavender jacket, who is standing on skates in the center of the ice rink. The beautiful 90-foot Norway spruce Christmas tree, twinkling above the gilded statue of Prometheus, seems imposing. Hesitantly, the girl begins to skate backward. Wobbling, she reaches out her hand. Melanie Bliden is there to grab it and right her.

title: A Different View Of Mount Vernon
description: In your article of Nov. 3 on state aid to Yonkers schools to redress discrimination, a distorted picture of Mount Vernon schools in presented.

title: Getting A Reverse Mortgage
description: FOR many elderly homeowners, the equity in their homes is their most valuable asset. For some, the equity is all they will be able to pass on to their children when they die. For others, their home equity is their ''money in the bank'' -- a safety net available when necessity demands. For elderly homeowners on limited incomes, however, the equity may represent the difference between continued independence or reliance on their children's generosity.

title: Nanjing With Extras
description: IN a cushy, first-class car on a Nanjing-Suzhou express train (for about $3 one way), I met an American tour group, nearing the end of their 14-day visit to China. The top level of the double-decker car had been assigned exclusively to foreigners, but I was traveling on my own, which made me something of an oddity. As I sat sipping green tea (purchased from the attendant for a few cents) and gazing out at the ordered farm fields of southern Jiangsu Province on that warm morning in late October, the tour members filed down the aisle to talk to me.

title: Victorian Dolls And Other Delights
description: Parents and grandparents have always loved to dress up little girls. Today, the Victorian doll look is the eye-catcher, and it adds a nostalgic charm to the bustle of holiday crowds.

title: Out of Nowhere
description: FASCISM

title: Gordon Vickery, 76, Founder Of Model Paramedic Programs
description: Gordon F. Vickery, a Seattle fire official who created paramedic programs that were widely adapted in the United States and abroad and who later headed Federal emergency and fire safety programs, died on Dec. 14. He was 76 and lived in Seattle.

title: A City Defined by Its Bridges
description: WHENEVER I go to Venice, I am always struck by the fact that Venetians count their ways in bridges. Ask a policeman for directions, and he'll tell you how many bridges away you are; ask a friend where her home is, and she'll ignore the usual indications of time or space and say that it's al di la del ponte (on the other side of the bridge) or do ponti da qui (two bridges from here). That's because in a city stretched over 116 islands and crisscrossed by more than 150 canals, bridges -- not the unsortable tangle of alleyways that pass for streets in Venice -- are the true and most reliable points of reference.

title: Eye-Closing Surgery Restores Vision
description: IT was Nov. 27. The bandages swathing the head of a patient at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan were being unwrapped. When the job was finished, his wife came into the room.

title: God and Toothpaste
description: IN THE SECOND STORY OF A WOODEN LODGE OVERLOOKING A MEADOW AND POND VEILED by mist, Tom Chappell, the C.E.O. and co-founder of Tom's of Maine, exhorts his 75 employees to contemplate nature. Normally these workers would be churning out fennel toothpaste, calendula deodorant, honeysuckle shampoo and other aromatic aids to personal hygiene. But on this overcast Tuesday morning, the company's executives, salesmen, toothpaste mixers and warehouse workers are gathered at an off-site location to discuss the company's commitment to the environment as articulated in its ''mission statement.'' Attendance at the meeting is mandatory; Chappell has shut down the company's plant, at a cost of more than $100,000, to insure that everyone is present.

description: To the Editor:

description: Last Sunday, thick crowds hovered outside Jing Fong on Elizabeth Street, waiting for a table at what is the city's biggest Chinese restaurant. But a block away on the Bowery, there were plenty of empty chairs at the next-largest, the Silver Palace.

description: MY friend Raul, who is from Galicia in northern Spain, shook his head when I told him where I had previously eaten in the Ironbound section of Newark.

description: The caller told the game warden, Debbie Palman, that he had killed a very large coyote, but when Mrs. Palman saw the animal she knew right away that it was something else.

title: HOW CRAZY WAS ZELDA?
description: One might also ask, upon review of the letters you printed, ''How jealous was Scott?'' I don't harbor much doubt about Zelda -- manic depression does seem a better diagnosis than schizophrenia. But I do find it strange that Scott's letters about Zelda, while revealing far more about him than about her, seem somehow not to draw scrutiny, as if it were rude to pry. Rude to speculate about Scott, while acceptable, indeed expected, to extrapolate from his texts all sorts of conclusions about Zelda's ''condition'' -- without looking at the textual record that she left behind.

title: Pataki Plan Hurts the Children
description: THE welfare reform bill, according to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, is based on the premise ''that the behavior of certain adults can be changed by making the lives of their children as wretched as possible. This is a fearsome assumption.''

title: Housing for AIDS Patients Has First Occupants
description: Seventeen people who have AIDS or are H.I.V.-positive recently moved into specially renovated houses with a combination of public and private funds. An equal number of houses in Camden, Trenton, Irvington, Newark and Paterson will be ready for other patients by spring under the first program of its kind in New Jersey, said Susan Sands, public information officer for the state Housing Mortgage Finance Agency.

title: Bomb Victim Has Justice, but Not His Clothes
description: Dec. 21, 1994, is a date that lives in a strange kind of infamy for Thomas N. Tally. On that date, Mr. Tally was sitting in the sixth car of a No. 4 subway train when a man named Edward J. Leary set off a crude firebomb that maimed 48 people.

title: Turnpike Authority to Vote On Ramps to Incinerator
description: Much to the surprise and anger of Linden officials, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority is to vote tomorrow on whether it would be feasible to build access ramps to a proposed toxic waste incinerator there.

title: Supporting an Arson Suspect Respected by Most (and Related to Many)
description: In most small towns, a man accused of setting fire to several historic barns would be vilified, or at the very least avoided. But when Vernon Shultis, a volunteer firefighter, was arrested on Nov. 21 in connection with setting 10 fires that caused an estimated $400,000 in damage, people here rallied behind him, even other firefighters.

title: Guys Who Think They Are Nothing Without a Gadget
description: IT is well after midnight, the rest of the family is dreaming of sugar plums and the male-type insomniac is watching guy stuff on T.V. Specifically, George Foreman, heavyweight champ of the world (one of them anyway), is hawking the Lean Mean Fat Reducing Grilling Machine. It grills four burgers at once, draining the fat off, making cleaning easy, something suddenly very important to the sleep-deprived consciousness.

title: Revitalized, Spruced Up and Friendly
description: LIKE many postwar communities on Long Island, Bellmore had begun to show wear by the beginning of this decade. The downtown shopping district had about a 30 percent vacancy rate, says the Chamber of Commerce, and some homes that had not changed owners in decades had begun to look their age.

description: Barry Gray, the smooth-talking but sometimes tart-tongued host of a late-night radio talk show, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: From Her Lips to God's Ear
description: THE REV. JOAN J. BRIGHTHARP doesn't quite fit the traditional image of a black Baptist preacher. First of all, she's a woman -- with fire-engine-red nail polish, spike heels and sparkle in her wardrobe.

title: Bachelor's Labor of Love Brings Joy to Harrison
description: IF the Guinness Book of Records had an entry for most decorated house, it might well go to 50 Parsons Street, Harrison, where for 19 years Roy Aletti, a 38-year-old bachelor, and some friends, relatives and employees -- Ken McClure, Bill Campbell, Matt Russo, Kevin Gabriele, Joe Ruto and Robert Santoro, to name some of them -- have given the neighbors and others who drive by the house off Oakland Avenue something to behold.

title: Once Villainous, Now Virtuous
description: ''Evita,'' the latest movie to make a fashion statement, arrives on Christmas Day. Madonna, that faux blond of so-so flicks, plays Eva Duarte Peron, a peplum-wearing, wasp-waisted Lady Bountiful to Argentina's poor.

title: Killing of 6 Workers Puts Red Cross at a Crossroads
description: Shocked by the killing of six of its workers in Chechnya this week, officials at the International Committee of the Red Cross are doing a great deal of thinking about the future for the 133-year-old organization.

description: IN khaki pants, denim shirt and longish gray-white bangs, N. Jay Jaffee may bear a passing resemblance to the abstract painter Willem de Kooning.

title: New Nursing Home Rising in Westchester
description: Residents with Alzheimer's dementia will have the freedom of walking safely around their own landscaped garden when the new two-story Hebrew Hospital Home of Westchester is completed on a 30-acre site along Grasslands Road in the Town of Greenburgh by the summer of 1998.

title: For Answers on Crash, New Pathways and Old
description: While aviation investigators try to pinpoint a mechanical cause for the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, nearly 75 F.B.I. agents are continuing to search for evidence of a bomb blast or missile attack. Agents insist they are far from ruling out a criminal act. The investigators who are pursuing the theory that a static spark was the cause are taking their inquiry into fresh and difficult terrain.

title: Techniques for Hanging Wallpaper
description: LAST week this column covered the preliminaries for hanging wallpaper. These included: gathering the necessary tools, establishing a vertical line as a starting point, cutting the wallpaper strips (''drops'') to length, applying adhesive, and folding the drop (''booking''). This week, the techniques for hanging wallpaper will be described.

title: Evidence Barred On Breast Implants
description: A Federal judge in Oregon ruled Tuesday that lawyers cannot introduce evidence that says breast implants cause disease, because such evidence is not scientifically valid.

title: Share Work Equally
description: To the Editor:

title: Molly O'Neill
description: LEE SMITH LOVES GETTING CHRISTMAS mail and she loves holiday cooking. When a friend refers to those annual summaries that come tucked inside holiday cards as ''brag and gag letters,'' Smith merely smiles. To the author of ''Fair and Tender Ladies,'' whose novels are all about daily life south of the Mason-Dixon line, Christmas letters are fascinating documents. As fascinating for what they leave out as for what they include.

title: INSIDE
description: In Peru, Both Sides Bend

title: Window Program Puts Life in Empty Stores
description: DOWNTOWN White Plains may have empty stores, but the White Plains Beautification Foundation has made sure that it does not have empty windows.

title: Fixing Politics, More or Less
description: FOR decades, the dominant view here has been that campaign finance reform meant imposing stricter laws and regulations governing who could give how much money and what ways the politicians could spend it.

title: A View of Old Faithful Will Cost More in '97
description: Fees for entering the most popular places in the national park system will rise sharply next year. And new fees will be instituted at other sites and for some services that previously had none. The increases are part of a three-year test by the Department of the Interior to raise money for repairs and improvements long delayed under Federal budget strictures.

title: A Place To Call Home
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Towns Where Creative Minds Congregated
description: MANY parts of New Jersey have long, intriguing histories as havens for painters and sculptors.

title: Miss Tausch, Dr. Gonzalez-Molina
description: Valerie Joan Tausch and Dr. Robert Gonzalez-Molina were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Colapietro performed the ceremony.

title: Pasadena
description: The weather on New Year's Day in Pasadena is easy to predict. Just use the Tournament of Roses parade as a barometer: It has not rained on the flower petal floats, horse brigades and marching bands since 1955.

title: Islanders Fall Just Short Of the Streaking Stars
description: Zigmund Palffy was back, but his touch was not. And when he is held without a goal or an assist, the result is pretty much a given.

title: A Giant Awakens, To Yawns
description: TWO months ago, Rubbermaid Inc. held a product fair here in its headquarters town. It displayed storage bins, kitchen items and other plastic housewares, each with a label that detailed what it cost to make and what it usually sold for.

title: On Fertile Ground With the Master of Momix
description: Moses Pendleton's first choreography was trying to get 60 cows to charge after a few dancers who were running down a hill with white sheets over their heads. That was about 25 years ago, on his family's 500-acre dairy farm, Lochlyndon, in Vermont.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LIFE IN A DAY

title: A Quartet of Monstrous Mothers
description: At movie theaters this season we have been offered a faded bouquet of middle-aged women whose children have run off, snubbing them, got into trouble and, worst of all, returned home. These are women whose fragile equilibrium is threatened by sullen daughters and their sexy lovers, daughters who get married too often or who can't get a date, or by sons who are cold or clinging. These mothers think far too much of themselves or far too little. Some have sacrificed too much; others have forgotten how to love.

title: To Fellow Free-Agent Fans, Cheers!
description: I've declared myself a free-agent fan.

title: Nets Sign Lloyd Daniels
description: Lloyd Daniels's cat-like life in the National Basketball Association took another interesting twist today when the sputtering Nets signed the former New York City high school legend before their game against the Boston Celtics.

title: Protection for Poor Parents
description: Should a parent have to forfeit a battle for the legal rights to her children because she cannot afford an appeal? Six members of the Supreme Court thought not, ruling last week that the Constitution requires states to waive court costs so that poor people can appeal orders terminating their parental rights.

title: Lace Updated: Now It's for All Seasons and Reasons
description: THE lacy bra and trimmings on the dress worn by Diana, Princess of Wales to the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute gala on Dec. 9 set a royal seal of approval on a wispy, intimate fabric that's enjoying yet another turn in the spotlight. Her Dior gown was the haute version of the current lingerie look.

title: Miss Silvershein And Mr. Gibbs
description: Sabrina Faye Silvershein, a daughter of Beverly Somach of New York and Seymour G. Silvershein of Clifton, N.J., was married last evening in Fort Lee, N.J., to Dr. Eric Paul Gibbs, a son of Emily Gibbs and Dr. Stanley L. Gibbs of Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Irving Spielman performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Fort Lee.

title: Eagles Drop Their Duel
description: A quixotic four-month duel over a treasured newspaper name that gave readers in Brooklyn Heights two separate -- though not wholly distinct -- free daily newspapers ended last week when one of the publishers sold his rights to produce a publication under the name Brooklyn Eagle.

title: The Shield for Exiles is Lowered
description: THE images, once again, are vivid. Long columns of Rwandans bearing small bundles of their worldly goods trudge on in the thousands, along narrow roads that lead them to an uncertain fate back home. Nobody knows what reprisals these Hutus face for genocide committed in their name two years ago. A first group, fleeing fighting in Zaire, returned to Rwanda weeks ago. Now Tanzania, another country where they sought refuge, no longer wants them either, and its policy is being enforced by troops with guns.

title: Jack Mognaz, 70, Gallery Executive
description: Jack Mognaz, the senior vice president of Marlborough Gallery in Manhattan, died last Sunday in Queens. He was 70 and had homes in Manhattan and at La Garde-Freinet on the French Riviera.

description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Soda Label Fizzles

title: Tips for a Taxi Ride, and Life's Longer Treks
description: PAN-FRIED periwinkle is a good choice for the first-time diner at Taipei Big Rice Bowls on Baxter Avenue in Queens. Despite its 500,000 inhabitants, the Green-Wood Cemetery on Fifth Avenue in Brooklyn is one of the city's most peaceful strolling areas. Telephone instructions on how to communicate telepathically with your pet costs $40 a half-hour.

title: New Issues '96: Euphoria, Then Ennui
description: THE new-issues market, which earlier this year resembled a scene out of the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis auction, with overenthusiastic buyers bidding prices up to astonishing heights, now looks more like a rummage sale. Some investors are turning up their noses and shopping elsewhere, while others, sharp-eyed, are rooting around for bargains.

title: Elizabeth Nelson And Gordon Cliff
description: Elizabeth Alice Nelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Nelson of North Granby, Conn., was married yesterday to David Gordon Cliff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Lee Cliff of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Peter Meister performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Granby.

title: Texaco's Turnaround
description: Embarrassed by a discrimination case that exposed a regressive corporate culture, Texaco has announced a comprehensive plan to promote employment and business opportunities for minorities. The move should help Texaco's bottom line and is being done for business reasons, the company says. But Texaco also seems genuinely contrite. Civil rights leaders who had condemned Texaco as a dinosaur now hail it as a model of corporate commitment to diversity. Moreover, at a time when the concept of affirmative action has fallen on hard times politically, Texaco may emerge as a leader in the struggle for equal opportunity.

title: How Westchester Rates On the Environment
description: FRUSTRATED in their earlier efforts, environmentalists have taken a new tack in recent months, relying increasingly on report cards and similar rating systems to get their message across. And neither elected officials nor municipalities are escaping their scrutiny.

title: Not So Innocent Abroad
description: Reflecting on the unseemly access political donors and their business friends have had to the White House, President Clinton said on Friday that better screening of visitors is needed. That is an understatement. It now turns out that earlier this year Charles Yah Lin Trie, the Little Rock restaurateur turned Democratic Party fund-raiser, brought a hugely powerful Chinese business official, who oversees arms deals, to a meeting with Mr. Clinton. This occurred at a time when tensions between Washington and Beijing were high.

title: Corrections
description: The Gazetteer chart last Sunday, about Tappan, N.Y., misstated the name of the Town Supervisor of Orangetown. He is Thom Kleiner, not Thomas Kaiser.

title: A Performer Who Finally Grew Into Her Talent
description: Noel Coward's ''Present Laughter'' may be the chain-smoking-est play on Broadway, and though Allison Janney maintains she had quit a half-pack-a-day habit, it looks like the actress has slid backward a bit. She definitely has all the paraphernalia. One of the play's producers, David Richenthal, has given her an engraved cigarette case, and Scott Elliott, the director, presented everyone in the cast with lighters bearing the play's title. Perhaps, she suggests, nicotine patches would be an appropriate present on closing night.

title: Haven't I Heard That 'Whoop' (Or 'Hoop') Somewhere Before?
description: The Manhattan apartment is filled with bookshelves, but most of them don't hold books. Instead, they overflow with albums -- classical over here, jazz over there, and lots of soul and rock-and-roll in between. A parakeet named Adri flies around the living room offering guests, as the bird's owner puts it, ''sweet gangsta kisses.'' Most always there's the steady thump thump of hip-hop blasting in the background.

title: Fighting the Estate Tax During a 2d Life in Capital
description: Former Senator Bob Packwood is back on the Washington scene -- in a job he once dreamed of holding.

title: Gym Mats Replace Shelter Cots
description: The crowding for shelter got so bad during last year's brutal winter that the city opened a emergency homeless center in the Flushing Armory. And to get the homeless from Manhattan to Queens, a bus was used to shuttle them in nightly.

title: Mink Stole Dress-Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Will Out, and It Did in 'Chicago'
description: Like the adultery and murder it depicts, ''Chicago'' has been around a lot longer than people realize. Most reviewers of the recently opened hit musical on Broadway discussed its brief appearance last May in the acclaimed ''Encores!'' concert musical series at City Center as well as the show's indebtedness to Bob Fosse's original 1975 production. But barely noted, if even mentioned, was the fact that all three versions (plus the 1942 film ''Roxie Hart'' starring Ginger Rogers) have roots in a 1926 Broadway comedy by a playwright named Maurine Watkins, unknown then and still unknown today.

title: A Dervish of Curiosity
description: AT HIS SIDE

title: Monumental Remnant From a 1900's Estate
description: ONLY in winter, as the leafy jungle of the upper Henry Hudson Parkway shrinks back, can you see it fully -- a strange, giant stone gallery that resembles an ancient temple lost in the rain forest. The speeding automobiles do not stop, but it is a familiar curiosity to any northbound driver.

title: Fooleries From Fey to Tedious
description: THE rarefied world of Bertram Wooster, upper class yo-yo, and Jeeves, his manservant and mastermind, is cheering to its devotees, too too arcane for the unconverted. Since 1975, it has been a mission of sorts for Andrew Lloyd Webber and Alan Ayckbourn to make a coherent musical of the blunders and misunderstandings of P. G. Wodehouse's idiosyncratic characters, the subjects of 16 English novels and three short story collections, written from 1917 to 1946.

title: Parcells Coy About Plans
description: When Bill Parcells was asked today about the speculation that the Jets will pursue him to be their new head coach, he shook his head from side to side.

description: ANSONIA **

title: A Wonderful 'Wonderful Life: The Musical'
description: THIS is the way it is supposed to be. The critic sits, oblivious to audience cheers, tears or jeers, wise to, but unaffected by, the desperate ploys of press agents who will plant laughers, whistlers, weepers and other aficionados with an agenda near the professional playgoer who should have eyes and ears for only the players.
