description: THE MAN BEHIND THE BOOK

title: A QUESTION FOR: Albert Brooks
description: Albert Brooks's new film, ''Mother,'' which he wrote and directed, opens Dec. 25.

title: Man Charged After His Wife Is Found Buried
description: A 62-year-old Manhattan man was charged with murder yesterday after his wife's body was found in a shallow grave in New Jersey, behind the office building where the suspect works, the police said.

title: Bethlehem Christmas Departs From the Carols
description: THE carols may sing of silent nights and peace on earth, but the celebration of Christmas at the spot where it all happened about 1,996 years ago does not always jibe with the image of a glowing cradle under a starry night.

title: Worker Accused in Killing
description: Richard Trupkin, the print shop owner who was found shot to death Tuesday night in the basement of his business in Woodside, Queens, was killed by a trusted employee, the son of his business partner of 30 years, the police said yesterday.

title: Evoking an Ageless Spirit
description: Parties and performances for actors, dancers and gardens.

title: To Croak For
description: THE FROGBy John Hawkes.191 pp. New York:Viking. $21.95.

title: Testing a Theory Of Elusive Sparks With Little Trace
description: As aviation investigators pursue their theory that a static spark ignited the explosion that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800, they are taking their inquiry into fresh and difficult investigative terrain. Static electricity has never been blamed for an in-flight explosion or a crash of a commercial airliner, and when these sparks do occur, they rarely leave any trace to prove they were even there.

title: TV's Powerful Doctor Shows vs. the H.M.O.
description: Tommy Wilmette slouches against a doorjamb with coiled reptilian calm, his hooded eyes searching for signs of weakness in his lumbering prey. A specialist in hostile takeovers, Wilmette has set his sights on a new victim: Chicago Hope Hospital. ''You're too expensive; your surgeries aren't cost-effective,'' he tells one of the hospital's finest doctors, who also happens to be his ex-wife. ''In fact, you're exactly the kind of doctor I'll be eliminating when we downsize.''

title: F.B.I. Perseveres in Flight 800 Search
description: While aviation investigators try to pinpoint a mechanical cause for the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, nearly 75 agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are continuing their methodical search for evidence of a bomb blast or missile attack on the Boeing 747.

title: Last-Minute Listening Choices
description: THERE are only three concert days before Christmas, so for last-minute listeners, here are a few suggestions.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THEY FORGED THE SIGNATURE OF GOD

title: Precinct Feels Too Stretched
description: A Roman Catholic priest, on his way to deposit money from the Sunday collection basket, was robbed in Rosedale last month by two masked gunman. In response, a foot patrolman from the 105th Precinct was stationed in front of the bank during business hours. A week later, a tailor, whose shop is just around the corner. was held up in daylight, forced to the floor as robbers made off with his cash drawer.

title: Charity Triage: One Giver's Struggle
description: AN OLD FRIEND, A COLLEGE classmate, calls up one night when I'm at my desk filling out an application for a line of credit from Chase Manhattan Bank. (It's tuition time again.) He's normally reserved, my friend, a distinguished editor with a calm New England manner, but on the phone he's crying with laughter. He has been asked, as a member of the Harvard class of '71 fund-raising committee, to approach two classmates the committee has targeted as prime prospects for ''gifting.''

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: BACKGROUNDS - from San Francisco to Paris art museums and a biblical epic filmed in Europe - make for interesting speculation on this week's movie menu.

title: A Fond Farewell to R.F.K. Stadium
description: I am home for the holidays to see my ill stadium. We are the same age, you know -- born in 1961 -- but this is the stadium that raised me. It is the first place I prayed, the first place I saw a President, the first place I booed a Dallas Cowboy. I have wept in its box seats, I have slaved in its press box, I have concussed my head on its brick roof.

title: Exhibit on a Slave Ship in Charlotte, N.C.
description: Visitors can envision the experiences of African slaves through ''A Slave Ship Speaks: The Wreck of the Henrietta Marie,'' an interactive exhibition at the Spirit Square Arts and Education Center in Charlotte, N.C., through Jan. 25. The exhibition, on a four-year tour in the United States, is accompanied in Charlotte by a series of programs with the theme ''From Enslavement to Empowerment.''

title: Christmas in Camelot
description: 'Twas the night before Christmas, and the location of the party was a complete mystery. The couple of the year vowed that their first Christmas together would have no trespassers, not even a mouse. They planned every detail.

title: For One Alou, the Turf Is Greener in Montreal
description: The children's toe-tweaking game about how many piggies went to market and how many piggies stayed home can be applied to developments with certain managers. A couple of months ago, Jim Leyland went to market and, leaving Pittsburgh, wound up in Florida for about $1.5 million a year. A year ago, Tony La Russa figuratively had roast beef, leaving Oakland for St. Louis and maintaining what was then a rare $1.5 million salary for managers.

title: One Cause. One Check. Less Junk Mail.
description: SOON, tax strategists will be telling us to reduce our 1996 income tax by increasing charitable giving. Sound advice. But give how much and to whom?

title: Actors Leave Addiction in Wings
description: When he's scheming for a fix, Charles Shaw knows how to put on a good show. ''If I need to get high, I can be the best actor in the world and manipulate the hell out of anyone,'' Mr. Shaw said the other day, as he painted a black mole above his fiery-red lips and teased his wig to even greater heights. Wedged into the chatter-filled dressing room at the Chelsea Playhouse, where he plays a dying drag queen in the musical ''Every Beat Face Ain't Beautiful,'' he explained how performing onstage has, for now, eclipsed the kind of acting that only leads to trouble.

title: An Infant's Death, an Ancient Debate
description: DISCORDANT images from a Wilmington, Del., courthouse last week:

title: Restaurants Offer Feasts for the Holidays
description: THE most important culinary doubleheader of the year is again upon us. Island restaurants will usher in Christmas Day and New Year's Eve with music, movies, dancing and, most of all, elaborate holiday feasts.

title: Overseas Tours For Over 50's
description: THE overseas catalogues for Elderhostel and In terhostel print their warnings and caveats in full-size type. In contrast to the glorious wish books of costly conventional tour operators, the two sponsors of educational programs for older people emphasize that the living will be Spartan and participants should be prepared to walk rough paths, eat in cafeterias and carry their own suitcases.

title: Relatives Subletting A Co-op
description: Q I am a residential shareholder in a Westchester County co-op. Our proprietary lease permits subleasing, but only with board approval. It also permits relatives to live with shareholders. Several apartments are occupied by relatives of shareholders without the shareholders in occupancy. Although board approval has been given, the occupancy is not treated as a sublease and no sublease fee is charged. Recently, there have been complaints about the behavior of some of these tenants. Can the board now rescind its permission for occupancy? . . . Carol Goldwater, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Sandra Valles and Joseph Mahoney
description: Sandra Louise Valles, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jean-Paul Valles of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Bernard Mahoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Mahoney Jr. of Sunnyside, S.I. The Rev. Dr. Paul D. Alcorn performed the ceremony at the Bedford Presbyterian Church in Bedford Village, N.Y.

title: Hurdles Remain For Salem
description: The troubled Salem nuclear power plant put at least some of its difficulties behind it last week, when state regulators approved a settlement that would refund $96.9 million dollars to customers of the two utilities that own large shares of the plant, which has been shut since the middle of last year.

title: For Some, The Beat's The Thing
description: It has been a good year for mainstream jazz recordings, and the proof is albums by Danilo Perez, David Sanchez, Leon Parker, Steve Wilson and Conrad Herwig. Most years critics have to scrape together a list of the top 10 records. Not so this year, and while the reasons are multiple, what stands out on these recordings is the desire to make rhythm a greater part of the music. The drum, and its role in jazz, is changing.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: An Art Center's Growth Is Catalyst for Expansion
description: THE Wooster Community Art Center in Danbury started out a little over 30 years ago with a dual mission: to serve as the art department for the Wooster School, which was then a boarding school for boys, grades 9-12, and as a community art center. That was the agreement in 1965, when the Ford Foundation provided a grant to start the center.

title: To Save Jobs, Painters' Union Agrees to Relax Its Rules
description: If a featherbedding Olympics were ever held, the gold medal might go to the New York City painters' union, with its rule banning the use of paint rollers wider than 9 inches and another requiring afternoon coffee breaks even though the workday ends at 3:30.

title: Exact Count Called Unlikely on Chemical Exposure in Gulf War
description: A panel of independent scientists has determined that there is a ''very real possibility'' that the Pentagon will never know how many American troops may have been exposed to chemical weapons in the demolition of an Iraqi ammunition depot shortly after the 1991 Persian Gulf war, the Defense Department has announced.

title: Time to Clean Out Your Briefcase?
description: A briefcase can be very useful, but, like the top of the desk, it is prone to clutter. Sometimes, it hides things that would amaze anyone who could peek inside. What sort of weird stuff is in your briefcase? Or that of a co-worker? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Aid Workers Singled Out And Killed in Chechnya
description: Last week six Red Cross field hospital workers in Chechnya were murdered in their sleep by unknown gunmen. The killings were the worst, but not the first, intimation of a new threshold crossed in modern warfare -- humanitarian groups have lost their cloak of inviolability. Accorded free passage to help war victims, aid workers are increasingly being singled out as targets. Although the new Government of Chechnya has won its battle -- Russian troops are withdrawing after two years of warfare -- its leadership was shaken by another enemy -- the one within. The killings made clear that the brash rebels who defeated mighty Russia are not yet in control. ALESSANDRA STANLEY

title: Jane Curtin, Everywoman With an Edge
description: JANE Curtin was cleaning her kitchen in Conneticut one frigid January evening when the phone rang. It was her old friend, the comedy writer Bonnie Turner. The call was not spur of the moment: this was a television emergency. Would Ms. Curtin, she wanted to know, consider another go at a sitcom?

title: Mourn a Parent, but Hold the Social Agenda
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the first Kmart in Manhattan misstated the company's history in New York City. The 34th Street store is its first in Manhattan; its first in the city opened in the 1960's, on Staten Island.

title: In Search of a Winning Coach: Who's Next for This Frustrated Franchise?
description: The Jets close out their 1996 season against Miami today at Giants Stadium, marking the end of a year that stamps them as one of the great sad-sack franchises in the world of sports. No team has spent as much money to build a winner, only to wind up with the worst record in the league, and for the second straight year, to boot.

title: A Show Celebrating Icons, But Not Just Figural or Sacred
description: THE traditional icon remains an essential part of Orthodox Christianity, even in the United States, where it arrived with the faith by way of Alaska, when the area was a province of Russia.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ALL GOD's CHILDREN: The Bosket Family and the American Tradition of Violence

title: A Store for All Seasons, Especially This One
description: They come first for the stollen.

title: Don't Take Shortcuts On Road to Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: The Christmas Legends, Great and Small
description: THIS is the time of the year when baking, concerts, travel, shopping, wrapping and mailing happen, when tradition is the byword.

title: Lawyers Weigh Simpson Custody Ruling
description: Viewed from the other side of the country, the custody decision in the O. J. Simpson case reflected one judge's haste, some lawyers say. Or perhaps it reflected differences in legal philosophy between other states and California, where the law is weighted overwhelmingly in favor of the biological parent. Or maybe it was a reminder of the limitations of the law.

title: Deborah Reingold, Robert Klapper
description: Deborah Hannah Reingold, a daughter of Ruth Reingold and Dr. Edward M. Reingold of Urbana, Ill., is to be married today to Rabbi Robert David Klapper, the son of Drs. Molly and Jacob Klapper of Manhattan. Rabbi Howard Jachter is to officiate at El Caribe, a catering business in Brooklyn.

title: Off-Duty Police Officer and Store Owner Are Slain in Queens
description: An off-duty police officer -- one of a handful who initiated New York City's heralded community policing program in 1990 -- and the owner of a Queens check cashing store who employed him as a part-time security guard were waylaid and shot to death by armed robbers yesterday morning as they opened the business.

title: China's Last Eunuch
description: Sun Yaoting, a few days short of 94 years of age, died Tuesday, an anachronism of imperial China: a eunuch whose official role ended in 1911 just months after his family forced him to undergo castration. Mr. Sun was China's last eunuch.

title: One for the Buyers, Another for Renters
description: Two new books could give a helpful overview to prospective New York City apartment renters or to buyers prospecting the New York City market. One focuses on rental apartments, the other on condominiums and, to a lesser extent, co-ops.

title: The Walls Have Ears? That May Be the Least of It
description: In business parlance, a flat market is not unlike a flat line on an electrocardiogram. Fix it quickly, or it's curtains. But in the evolving world of home theater, the next few years could redefine ''flat'' as the best market imaginable.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with a review of the Sonoma Grill in East Rutherford was printed in error. It showed Casa Vasca in Newark, which is reviewed today on page 12.

title: Guild Building Tentatively Sold For Hotel Space
description: The Newspaper Guild, the union that represents reporters, editors and others, has tentatively agreed to sell its 85-year-old headquarters building near Times Square to a Singapore hotel developer for $3.4 million. The developer plans to tear down the building and use the site to add 130 rooms to the 627-room Millennium Broadway hotel

title: One Block, Nine Photographers, One Show
description: ''CLOSE TO HOME'' is both a photography show and a block party. The 17 pictures on the walls at the new Mary Gearhart Gallery, at 252 Mott Street, focus strictly on the Little Italy neighborhood outside the door of this tiny storefront, and all nine photographers live on this one block, between Houston and Prince Streets.

title: And to All a Good Night: In Beds, a Simple Gift of Solace and Sleep
description: Whether a simple pillow-and-mattress sanctuary from everyday stress or a lavish shrine to slumber decorated with all manner of trim, a bed is a hallowed thing.

title: A Mouse in the House? Click Here
description: WHEN Shaul and Laurie Dover decided it was time to build their dream house, they wanted to be sure the dream would be theirs and not someone else's. Just as important, Mr. and Mrs. Dover also wanted to do their dreaming on their own time, and not while paying an hourly fee in an architect's office.

title: Walther Birkmayer, 86; Treated Parkinson's
description: Dr. Walther Birkmayer, a neurologist in Austria whose early work with Parkinson's disease helped lead to the standard treatment for the disorder, died on Dec. 10 in Vienna. He was 86.

title: Commercial Real Estate Reporting Turnaround
description: IN another sign of a strengthening regional economy, premiere commercial space on Long Island, until recently a glut on the market, is now in scarce supply.

title: Nancy Yellin, Leonard Panzer
description: Nancy Barbara Yellin, a special education teacher at the Lorge School in New York, was married last evening to Leonard Brian Panzer, a vice president at Prudential Securities in New York. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: RIDING THE BULL FOR A DAY
description: Michael DiCarlo, who oversees the John Hancock Special Equities Fund, is part of a culture that values only the act of selling something for more than it was bought (''Riding the Bull for a Day,'' by Diane K. Shah, Dec. 1). When he and others like him are finished, they will, no doubt, have become more wealthy and more powerful. Yet they will have contributed so very little to the society from which they skim their profits. With all his talent, DiCarlo offers nothing to the arts, nothing to the sciences and nothing to our shared stock of human ideas.

title: Gillian Hirsch, Jeffrey Schwartz
description: Gillian Amy Hirsch, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, and Jeffrey Brian Schwartz, an associate at Willkie Farr & Gallagher, the Manhattan law firm, were married last evening. Rabbi Jill Kreitman officiated at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 6/

title: Listening for the Other Mahler, the Hopeful One
description: In all likelihood, we are still getting Mahler wrong. Somewhere in the Mahler boom of the last 30 years a Viennese Titan turned into a Kafkaesque hunger artist or an Upper West Side neurotic out of a Saul Bellow novel. The anguished Mahler we have come to admire is morose, obsessive, hypersensitive -- darkly prophetic, as Leonard Bernstein claimed, of all the horrors of this century. This is the Mahler of the grotesque scherzos, the lachrymose funeral marches, the tragic hammer blows.

title: A Musicians' Musician Still Singing the Blues
description: QUALITY can be recognized but not described,'' the musician Mose Allison said, quoting from Robert Pirsig's book ''Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance.'' As a songwriter and master at piano improvisation, Mr. Allison can approximate what he does musically, but he cannot precisely describe it.

title: Saving a Beloved Chapel by Cutting Out Its Soul
description: This is a story about the power of institutions and the meaning of buildings -- or perhaps about the meaning of institutions and the power of buildings. Either way, it seems right to ponder at Christmas, for it involves the divinity school of one of the world's finest universities and the question of how much the values of great architecture and a splendid setting could have to do with a religious and educational mission. What price architectural glory?

title: For Wealthy Americans, Death Is More Certain Than Taxes
description: Martin M. Shenkman, who is 40 years old, knew that by the time he and his wife died and their house in Teaneck, N.J., went to their three children, hundreds of thousands of dollars in taxes would be owed before the children could inherit it. But as a tax lawyer, he also knew a way around those taxes.

title: What About the 'Boo'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Prepares Campaign, Eager for Lasting Impression
description: Expressing enormous confidence about the strength of his re-election campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says he needs another term in office to cement his policies into the bedrock of New York City government. Otherwise, he says, any of his opponents would need only a year to undo his work reducing crime and redefining the welfare system.

title: Community Shopping Centers Refining Their Niches
description: THOUGH community shopping centers are a time-tested retail concept, owners and managers are reinventing them to keep pace with an ever-changing marketplace.

title: The 'Oldest Old,' 80 and Over, Are on the Increase Globally
description: Joseph Chamie is a demographer who pores over statistics for hints of the world to come. But he also sees the future in a new kind of cap on medicine bottles, in wider car doors, more off-the-rack eyeglasses and shorter risers on stairs in many new houses.

title: 'The Home Team,' Perspectives on Parenting
description: RUTHANN LOBO never thought she was an expert on parenting, but a lot of other people did.

title: Peggy W. Pulleyn, 85, Founder Of Child Development Institute
description: Peggy Wattles Pulleyn, whose grandchild's ill fortune moved her to found the Princeton Child Development Institute in 1970, died on Dec. 8 in a freakish accident near her home in Oldwick, N.J. She was 85.

title: What China Would Bury in Moroccan Sand
description: The Moroccans who were working on ''Kundun,'' Martin Scorsese's movie about the Dalai Lama's boyhood, seemed unimpressed by the transformation of their hometown into the capital of Tibet, complete with Buddhas painted on the hillsides and golden rooftops topping houses in the casbah below. Then again, Jerusalem was just down the road, where Turner Network Television had recently shot ''David,'' its latest work in the ''Bible'' series. Perhaps the locals are just inured to strange sights.

title: An Earlier America From Currier & Ives
description: ROBERT PELTON, curator of the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport, explains his current exhibition, ''Currier & Ives, Printmaker to the American People,'' in terms of the circus entrepreneur's long connections to the lithographers Nathaniel Currier and James Merritt Ives. They were, he says, ''not only contemporaries but friends, neighbors and business associates in New York.''

title: Personal Styles Centered on Enigma
description: THE Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield hasn't done much photography programming, but its ground floor gallery has the right intimacy for showing photographs, and in the future it might be set aside for this.

title: Holiday Messages
description: There was once a time, not so long ago, when public schools crammed their December calendars full of Christmas activities, confusing and isolating children who did not observe the holiday. In some cases, parents decided the best situation was to keep their children at home.

title: Nancy Buirski, Kenneth Friedlein
description: Nancy Florence Buirski and Kenneth Harper Friedlein were married yesterday in Englewood, N.J. Judge Arthur J. Lesemann of the Superior Court of New Jersey in Hackensack officiated at the home of Adela and John Piskora, friends of the bride.

title: Don't Forget 'Bravo!'
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting the Green Light To Go Down Under
description: Travelers can now get permission to enter Australia through a new program that issues electronic travel authority, or an E.T.A., the equivalent of a visa.

title: Mayor Plans Suit to Control A Casino Ship
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he planned to seek a court order to stop a floating casino from running day trips from Brooklyn until the backgrounds of the cruise operators could be scrutinized.

title: Beth Silberstein and Thomas Grotta
description: Beth Lynn Silberstein, a mathematics teacher at the Blind Brook School in Rye Brook, N.Y., was married last evening to Thomas John Grotta, a product manager at Comp-U-Card, a direct marketing service in Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: ''It makes me feel like the Grinch stealing everybody's Martians.''

title: Trump Nears a Missing Link: A Sewage Hookup
description: Despite concerns from community groups and local politicians, the Department of City Planning gave the green light last week for the Department of Environmental Protection to issue a sewage permit that is expected to clear the way for Donald Trump to break ground on his embattled $2 billion Riverside South development.

title: A Bill to Legalize Decking The Halls With Boughs of Holly
description: It is against the state's Uniform Fire Code to set up a Christmas tree or any holiday display using straw, hay or other flammable material in a public place, including stores, offices and churches. The fact that you can see displays using these materials all over the state indicates that the code is often ignored.

title: Winter in a Tube Or on Skinny Skis
description: For winter sports fans who would rather begin on their backsides than end up there, the Jack Frost Mountain and Big Boulder Lake ski areas in Blakeslee, Pa., have expanded their snow-tubing facilities, adding new lifts and chutes at both areas.

title: Everything Was Possible
description: SOMEHOW A PASTThe Autobiography of Marsden Hartley.By Marsden Hartley.Edited, with an introduction, by Susan Elizabeth Ryan.Illustrated. 246 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:The MIT Press. $27.50.

title: 28 Free Agents on List
description: Contrary to the expectations of baseball officials, only 28 players became free agents yesterday after their clubs did not tender them 1997 contracts by the deadline midnight Friday. A year ago, clubs did not tender contracts to 46 players, and league and club officials expected at least that many this year.

title: HEROINE WORSHIP
description: Your issue ''Heroine Worship'' (Nov. 24) certainly emphasizes that this is still a man's world. The surest way to become an icon is to be pretty and excel at something that displays femininity -- acting, singing, dancing, modeling, cooking or being married to an important man. The only women to make your list as creative writers or artists were all born more than 90 years ago, and are now dead. (Why Gertrude Stein rather than Toni Morrison?)

title: The Spinner Spun
description: THE BROOKLYN pitcher ''Candy'' Cummings, who flummoxed the Harvard baseball varsity by inventing the curveball just after the Civil War, has been ill served.

title: Stop Blaming The Internet
description: The viewpoint expressed by Sy Reisman in ''How the Internet Threatens Bliss'' (Dec. 1) is an example of the latest neo-Luddite thinking: blame the Internet for everything. Before the Internet, television, telephones and automobiles all had their turn at being bashed by people afraid of social change wrought by new technologies.

title: In Illinois, Quiet Block Glows in Joy For Holiday
description: Grant Place is one block long, a narrow street without sidewalks, small houses on small lots in a neighborhood that people pass without notice most of the year.

title: 'Evita,' the Look, Drives Vintage Shoppers
description: The mannequin at the top of the stairs, looking a bit worn around the edges, is dressed in a floral 1940's dress and a wide-brimmed black hat with a net veil and flowers. She is the token Evita at the Family Jewels, a vintage clothing store in Chelsea that specializes in 20's, 30's and 40's clothing, and she has been greeting more customers lately, as the barrage of publicity increases for the movie ''Evita,'' starring Madonna, which opens on Wednesday.

title: To Control Cambodia, Rivals Are Stripping It Bare
description: Late at night, slow-moving trucks rumble past a military checkpoint here on the northern outskirts of Phnom Penh, hauling giant logs from deep in the forests of central Cambodia.

title: If You Don't Levitate, Stay Seated
description: To the Editor:

title: At Baghdad Airport, Proof Life Can Go On in a Vacuum
description: As in any other capital, the road to the international airport is boldly marked on highway signs in Baghdad.

title: Metropolis
description: JULIUS KNIPL, REAL ESTATE PHOTOGRAPHER

title: The Holocaust Was No Secret
description: THE RECENTLY RELEASED INTERCEPTS OF THE BRITISH MILITARY intelligence include 282 pages of reports from Belarus and Ukraine to Nazi headquarters in Berlin. They detail the beginning of the Holocaust. The intercepts began reaching England on July 18, 1941, and continued until Sept. 13, 1941, when the Nazis decreed that their mass executions should be treated as ''the most secret matters of the Reich.'' The information thereafter would be delivered to Berlin by courier. The Nazis were protecting themselves against something that they doubted was possible but that in fact had already happened. The British, through brilliant intelligence work, had broken the Nazi top secret codes. Prime Minister Churchill had total access to the intercepted information, which informed him of what the Nazis were doing.

title: Bobby Unser Missing In New Mexico
description: The three-time Indianapolis 500 winner BOBBY UNSER and another man were missing yesterday after embarking on what was supposed to be a day trip of snowmobiling, the New Mexico state police said.

title: Litchfield Weighs Tax on Home Sales for Land Bank
description: LITCHFIELD, the quintessential New England town, is favored as a second-home site by affluent New Yorkers for its avenues of grand old Colonial homes, an elegant village green, vistas of Connecticut's hills, forests and meadows, and a population density of 146 residents per square mile. It may attempt to preserve all that by levying a 2 percent tax on the sale of homes, to be paid by the purchaser.

title: Coalition Seeks Curb On Local Lobbying
description: A COALITION of groups that advocate open government has called on County Legislators to regulate lobbyists at the local level.

title: One Day's Death Toll on the Job
description: STATE HIGHWAY 84 parallels the Mississippi River as it cuts through northwestern Illinois and the flat cornfields north of Cordova. The land along the road looks untouched by the 20th century except for the Rock Island Nuclear Power Station, which squats heavily on the ice-crusted river bank amid a spider's web of transmission lines.

title: Crime
description: Archer Mayor doesn't do anything in THE RAGMAN'S MEMORY (Mysterious Press/ Warner, $22) that he hasn't done in six previous police procedurals featuring Lieut. Joe Gunther, his square-jawed lawman from Brattleboro, Vt. But by practicing his craft with dazzling skill and by digging for the deeper moral issues behind every grass-roots crime, he has made an honorable art form of the regional mystery.

title: Cabinet Doors Open
description: President Clinton filled out his second-term Cabinet Friday.

title: Revisiting Might-Have-Been Street
description: IT had been 10 years, nearly to the day, and my memory had almost certainly faded. But this couldn't be the place, surely.

title: Loophole in Law Permits States To Put Off Cuts in Food Stamps
description: Because of a loophole in the new Federal welfare law and a mistaken economic analysis underlying it, many of the hundreds of thousands of the nation's poorest men and women who were to have lost full food stamp benefits will continue to receive them for at least a year.

title: Barbie's Journey in Japan
description: SIX-YEAR-OLD Machi Nishiyama was shopping for dolls in a Ginza toy store recently when she was shown two models. One was a glamorous doll named Barbie, a replica of a 1960's model, with a stunning figure, heavy eyeliner, a bare-shouldered dress and a pearl choker. The other, named Licca, was a smaller doll with big eyes and a plain, knee-length dress.

title: Teamster Counterrevolution: Why It Nearly Won Election
description: By teamsters' standards, Ron Carey has been nothing less than a revolutionary since taking the union's helm five years ago, booting out hundreds of corrupt officials and getting rid of the limousines, private jets and meetings in Hawaii.

title: Model Patrolman Who Calmed the Chaotic Streets
description: Along Guy R. Brewer Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens, Officer Charles A. Davis was regarded as the prototype community police officer.

title: Parents Say School for Gifted Is Mostly Magnet for Whites
description: Back in 1975, a lawsuit brought by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People resulted in a landmark civil rights ruling: a Federal judge ordered the desegregation of Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island, a predominantly black school in a sea of mostly white schools. That September, over the protests of many parents in District 21, which stretches from Sheepshead Bay to Coney Island to Bensonhurst, Mark Twain became a magnet school for so-called gifted and talented students.

title: By Grieg, Hour Upon Hour Upon Hour of Piano
description: When i was a boy studying piano, I listened constantly to an old monophonic RCA Victor record from 1955, ''Rubinstein Plays Grieg.'' The only substantial selection on it was the impressively titled ''Ballade in the Form of Variations on a Norwegian Folk Song,'' a tumultuous piece that began and ended with the saddest melody I had ever heard.

title: Excerpts From Ethics Panel's Statement
description: Following are excerpts from a Statement of Alleged Violations issued today by the House ethics committee investigating the activities of Speaker Newt Gingrich:

title: A New Year's Resolution
description: If you have the time to read this, I can assume you have finished your Christmas shopping. Trimming the tree. Wrapping the presents. Hauling the stockings down from the closet. So I'd like to say a few words about the next big holiday, the holiday that really requires, for preparation, only a series of phone calls and perhaps a last-minute dry-cleaner trip. I'm speaking, of course, about New Year's Eve. Or, as Charles Lamb called it in 1820, ''that awful leave-taking,'' the night on which the mournful sound of the midnight bell reminded him of the previous year and ''all I have done or suffered . . . in that regretted time.'' Very upbeat guy.

title: Karina Borthwick, Fritz Harding
description: Karina Kelsey Borthwick, the daughter of Mary and Alan Borthwick of New York, was married yesterday to Fritz W. Harding, a son of Elizabeth and Fredric Harding of Hamilton, Ohio.

title: Don't Distort Flaws In Canada Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Homes for Greyhounds Whose Racing Days Are Done
description: The greyhound is an ancient breed of dog, a member of the sight hound family, which includes the Afghan hound, the whippet and the Rhodesian ridgeback. Its likeness appears on 5,000-year-old Egyptian tombs. Originally bred as hunting dogs, greyhounds can reach speeds of 37 miles per hour. Now their speed is used in racing.

title: Challenges to the Viewer's Imagination
description: Recent Work: Charlotte Brown and Robert Chapman

title: Not-So-Odd Couple Personifies the Spirit of Helping
description: THEY are the Oscar Madison and Felix Unger of charity work, the Ralph Kramden and Ed Norton of volunteerism. To the odd couples of male friendship, add Arthur and David, two men from Nassau County who bonded through their caring for others.

title: Gang Rivalry Cited in Police Captain's Shooting
description: The Bronx police captain who was wounded by snipers outside the 46th Precinct station house in October was shot by members of a heroin gang trying to intimidate a rival drug organization, investigators said yesterday.

title: Umberto's Is Rubbed Out
description: Long after the bloodstains were gone, mob buffs kept flocking to Umberto's Clam House, the restaurant where the Mafia boss Joseph Gallo was gunned down 24 years ago (scene at left). Last month, Umberto's closed after its owner, Robert Ianniello, sold the building. On Mulberry Street no tears were shed. ''For us, there's no nostalgia about that place,'' said Anne Compoccia, president of the Little Italy Chamber of Commerce. ''It's not something we were proud of.'' ANDREW JACOBS

title: Watch the Birdie
description: In the old days, coal miners used to bring a canary down into the shaft with them to serve as an early warning system. As long as the canary was alive, things were fine. But if the canary keeled over and died it meant there was a gas leak and it was time to get out -- fast. On July 1, Hong Kong returns to China under a deal with Britain in which Beijing has promised to maintain Hong Kong's open, freewheeling and autonomous character. For a week I've been asking people here what canaries the world should watch to know whether Hong Kong is alive and well after China takes over.

title: Girl's Violin Is a Lesson in Family History
description: FOR Katrin Stamatis of Mohegan Lake, a junior at the Hackley School in Tarrytown, her success playing the violin has special meaning. The 200-year-old instrument she uses belonged to her grandfather and survived the Holocaust.

title: Pressing the Nets
description: The Nets are off to a less than rousing start this season. What advice would you give to them or their new coach, John Calipari?

title: Midnight's Child
description: Who would have thought she could be so young? Her story seems to have existed since the beginning of time: a spiritual adventure laid out and waiting for us, as unalterable as the shining glass slipper, and as perfect a fit.

title: In Washington, Many Monumental Moments
description: Pick a memory from R.F.K. Stadium? One general memory remains, not from any particular game but from hundreds of games - sold outsince 1966 - in a now-outmoded facility, where the fans behind the benches have to stand the entire game, where the noises is unbelievable and where everyone says the old public-address system can't be heard. The Redskins score, and the stands along the sideline of the north side of Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium shake. From across the stadium, you can see the north stands bouncing up and down. Literally.

title: Patriots Can Deliver When It Counts Most
description: If you are Bruce Armstrong, you are a frequent Pro Bowl offensive tackle for the New England Patriots. You are captain. You are in your 10th Patriots season. Only six years ago, your team was 1-15.

title: DIARY
description: THE BIG NEWS

title: Whole Lotta Switching Going On
description: A sk bruce zaccagnino to compare how men and women react to ''Northlandz: Home of the Great American Railway'' -- his gargantuan new model-train exhibit in Flemington, N.J. -- and he says laconically, ''Women react to it heavier.'' He means that women are better at perceiving the layout's grandiose wholeness rather than obsessing, guy style, about its nuts and bolts and stats.

title: Don't Worry, Television. Film Has Been There.
description: PARENTS complain about the killing and maiming they see on the screen. Religious groups also decry the violence, and add indignant denunciations of the sexual scenes being paraded in front of children. But producers warn that any curtailment of their creative vision will be the first step on the slippery slope to government censorship.

title: No Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Pollen Police vs. Wheeze- and Sneeze-Making Leafy Outlaws
description: Soon after Arizonans voted in November to legalize the medical use of marijuana, Mayor Martin Chavez of Albuquerque signed a city ordinance banning the sale, cultivation, importation or planting of pollen-producing trees.

title: On Mars, Life's Getting Tougher (If Not Impossible)
description: The Martians of summer are facing a hard winter. Their very survival is in question.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: READING JAZZ

title: Signs to Newark: No Longer an Afterthought Along the Way
description: The next time you approach Newark on a major New Jersey highway, try counting the number of times the word Newark is mentioned on signs. Then, once you get into the city, try counting the number of signs offering directions to the Newark Museum, the Ironbound District and the cluster of universities.

title: Worthy Behemoth: The Bigger Boeing
description: LAST week, Boeing announced that it would proceed with the long-anticipated acquisition of its rival, McDonnell Douglas. The combination will leapfrog the smaller, $30 billion Lockheed Martin to become the world's largest aerospace-military company.

title: Last Call For Fans Of Holiday Programs
description: WITH only three days to go until Christmas, a few suggestions may be in order.

title: Heroic Enterprise
description: THE ODYSSEYBy Homer.Translated by Robert Fagles.Introduction and notes by Bernard Knox.541 pp. New York:Viking. $35.

title: A Vacation Not Taken May Be 401(k) Fodder
description: UNTHINKABLE as it may seem, each year many workers just don't get around to taking vacations, or they take less time off than they are entitled to.

title: Let's End the Cold War Again
description: This week marks the fifth anniversary of the breakup of the Soviet Union, perhaps the most astonishing single event in the second half of the 20th century. The collapse combined at least three-and-a-half revolutions in one. Leninist politics were to be supplanted by democratic pluralism; Stalinist economics, by private ownership and the market; the czarist empire, by a dozen suddenly independent states, and what little was left of the cold war in 1991, by rapturous Russian-American partnership.

title: Desperately Seeking Deductions? Year-End Tips
description: WITH the clock ticking on 1996, the smart money is scrambling to make the financial moves that will pare taxes. Even if you can carve out only a day -- or just a couple of hours -- to go over your finances before the end of the year, it should pay off with a lower tax bill come April 15.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about SGA Goldstar, an on-line tip sheet that the Securities and Exchange Commission has accused of manipulating small-company stocks, misstated the number of those stocks that trade on the Nasdaq market. It is two, not three.

title: Buy Your Company's Stock Plan And Get a 'Captive Broker,' Too
description: WHEN an employee buys stock as part of a company plan these days, he is likely to get something else -- a new stockbroker.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 24, about Beijing, misstated the number of rooms in the Forbidden City. It is 9,000, not 900.

title: Day-Care Delays Continue
description: Two years ago, officials at the Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation were eagerly anticipating the day when they could open a neighborhood day-care center for low-income families. The site was in place: an old convent on Bainbridge Avenue and East 196th Street. And there was definitely a need -- the waiting list at a nearby day-care center topped 300.

title: PANEL CONCLUDES GINGRICH VIOLATED RULES ON ETHICS
description: A House ethics subcommittee found today that Speaker Newt Gingrich had brought discredit to the House by using tax-exempt money for political purposes, and by providing the committee with ''inaccurate, incomplete and unreliable information'' about the role of a political action committee in a college course he taught.

title: Jennifer Rippa And Peter Jones
description: Jennifer Marie Jean Rippa and Peter Lowry Jones were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in White Plains. The Rev. Jonathan L. King performed the ceremony with the Rev. Robert Carbonneau, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: And How Do We Love Thee, Puffball?
description: MARION BUSH handed the chef, Todd McGarvey, a plump, brown boletus edulis.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LOWER EAST SIDE

title: Home for the Holidays
description: EXCEPT for a quick trip to Manhattan, Rosemary Clooney has spent most of her three weeks here reading, catching up on correspondence, luxuriating in room service and mastering long-distance and toll-free telephone dialing.

title: Memories Of the Titanic1
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Widens Property-Tax Exemption for Elderly
description: THOUSANDS of additional residents of Nassau County may be eligible for property tax exemptions for the first time, or for further abatements under a new law signed earlier this month by the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta. However, there is a Dec. 31 deadline for applications.

title: Where Christmas Starts On Labor Day
description: LITTLE did Rick and Joan Setti realize what they were getting into seven years ago when they put a wooden snowman, a snowwoman and two reindeer, along with a spotlight, on the lawn of their home on Midwood Road in Norwalk.

title: Quick Tidbits to Fix for Last-Minute Holiday Guests
description: HOLIDAY entertaining, sometimes orchestrated well in advance, but sometimes more spontaneous, often calls for tidbits to nibble with drinks. When the event is long in the planning, hors d'oeuvres can be made, frozen and reheated. But with last-minute guests, some quick but fancy footwork is necessary.

title: Is It the Real Dickens, or Merely the Mock?
description: WHO is the redeemable man? The cranky old miser, an ''altered spirit'' once possessed of ''nobler aspirations''? Or the Harlem slumlord who is ''at his best being at his worst''?

title: It Happened One Day
description: Benjamin Franklin knew all about the power of electricity. In 1750 his famous kite experiment was two years off, but he had already knocked himself unconscious trying to shock a man out of paralysis. Worse, at Christmastime that year, he was nearly killed when he tried to electrocute his holiday turkey as a parlor trick. Franklin had zapped smaller fowl before, and wrote in correspondence that the technique made them ''eat uncommonly tender.'' His apparatus: two metal wires inserted into Leyden jars, which store static charges. Absent-mindedly touching the wires to a chain that connected the jars, Franklin himself became a conductor. Witnesses reported a loud flash and crack. Franklin passed out; his body convulsed briefly before he came to, left with an aching chest and a swollen spot where the charge apparently entered his head. It was, he wrote later, an experiment ''I desire never to repeat.'' The turkey's fate? Not recorded.

title: Elmo, the Spirit of Christmas
description: DUANE, who is 19 and lives near New Brunswick, scalped the last of his Tickle Me Elmo dolls the other day. ''I got about $200 apiece, average,'' said Duane, who said he had paid $500 for a dozen Elmos, no questions asked, from a friend who works for a toy distributor.

title: Inna Shtekel, Stephen Berman
description: Faye Inna Shtekel, the daughter of Dora and Arsen Shtekel of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Stephen Gary Berman, a son of Judith and Joseph Berman, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Arthur Rulnick officiated at the Woodbury (L.I.) Jewish Center.

title: Remembering The Renegade
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Trust, Not Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: WRECKING LAS VEGAS
description: It's New Year's Eve in Vegas, you're broke and there's nothing you'd like better than to see a casino explode. You're in luck! At midnight Eastern standard time on Dec. 31, the owners of the Hacienda Hotel, an 11-story relic built in 1956, will demolish it with charges of gelatin dynamite. The blast, to be shown live on Fox, will feature peripheral fireworks and zippy bons mots by Sinbad, but don't expect much sentiment. Vegas developers are on a demolition bender -- this is the fourth hotel to fall in three years -- to make room for bigger, glitzier casinos. With the Hacienda still settling into a pile, viewers will be shown plans for a new resort, brusquely superimposed on its rubble and smoke.

title: Boarding Schools Thinking Global
description: IT is difficult to imagine new students at Kent School not being intimidated by their surroundings. The coeducational private school, nestled in the foothills of the Berkshires, regarded as one of the ''Select 16'' boarding schools in the country, carries the luster of privilege and a sense of high expectations for its 514 young charges.

title: Gill's Last-Second Jumper Ends Nets' Five-Game Skid
description: The clock ticked under five seconds, the basketball was in Kendall Gill's hands and the Nets trailed the Celtics by 1 point. It was obvious Gill would take the last shot, but no one knew which Gill would take the shot. The slumping Gill or the silky Gill?

title: A Way to Speed Up Buses: Just Stop Less Often
description: In the part of Manhattan that is sometimes referred to as the ''far East Side,'' cutbacks in bus service are not taken lightly. Even for the able-bodied, the blocks between York, First, Second and Third Avenues are long to walk and, with only one subway line on the East Side, bus service on the avenues takes on added importance.

title: She Shoots, She Scores! No Apologies.
description: The Brooklyn Blades, the city's only women's traveling ice hockey team, have come half circle.

title: On an Oversized Horse
description: LAST year, in a flash of product-planning genius, General Motors came out with a new sport utility vehicle that held great promise. Smaller than the king-sized Suburban and bigger than the compact Chevrolet Blazer and GMC Jimmy, it could carry several tons, came with four doors and combined genuine go-anywhere ruggedness with an extra layer of plushiness.

title: Low-Income Housing in a Tourist Mecca
description: When 40-year-old Janice Jones walked away from what she called a ''controlling marriage,'' she and her three daughters moved to this booming entertainment town in the Ozarks, just 30 miles from their old home but light years away in hope and opportunity.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report feature on Nov. 24, about Disney tours of Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, referred incorrectly to Quasimodo's death in Victor Hugo's novel ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame.'' Quasimodo vanished without a trace, though a skeleton presumed to be his was found much later, entwined with Esmeralda's, on the grounds where executed criminals were disposed of. He did not fall to his death from a cathedral tower.

title: Holiday Parties Reflect Business Upturn
description: LET the good times roll. After two dismal years, corporate parties are making a resounding comeback this holiday season, according to those in the hospitality industry.

title: Quitting Time
description: Kellogg's Six-Hour Day

title: Who Keeps Leaving the Lights On?
description: Among the many ways the city dolls up for the holidays, perhaps none is more uplifting than lights. Amid the seasonal glitter are these statesque standbys, brightly lit towers that keep New York festive year round. It's not easy or cheap. From downtown to uptown, the lighting plans for these torches of stone and electricity were scrutinized by the Federal Aviation Administration to make sure airplane traffic would not be distracted. And how would you like to pay the Empire State Building tower's 84,000-watt electric bill? Here is a primer on some of the best and brightest buildings, with their address; date built; height; total wattage of light tower; and hours the lights are on:

title: Green, but Not With Envy
description: In front of the room, 200 excited kids in Manhattan awaited a Christmas party with a couple of players from the New York Jets. In the back of the room, an adult snickered: ''They've given away enough games this season. The least they can do is give away a few presents.''

title: A Rebel Whose Dolls Embodied Her Demons
description: The first time I met Greer Lankton she was still a boy. A mutual friend took me for tea to her dorm room at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, where she lived in drag in the discomfort of those times. Pratt made Greer pay two rents because they wouldn't allow anyone to room with her; she was her own roommate.

title: A Night to Remember
description: EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF

title: The Daring of Fosse's Indelible Signature
description: Most of the greatest practitioners of the art of Broadway choreography -- Jerome Robbins, Michael Bennett, Tommy Tune -- have subjugated their personal dance styles to that of the shows they were working on. But Bob Fosse, who died in 1987 at the age of 60, was different. The Bob Fosse of ''Steam Heat,'' from his first Broadway assignment, ''The Pajama Game'' in 1954, is instantly recognizable as the Bob Fosse who choreographed ''Magic to Do'' in ''Pippin'' in 1972 and who, in 1986, created sizzling numbers for ''Big Deal,'' his last show.

title: Blustery Seaport With a Soul
description: NEWFOUNDLAND is not for everyone, which is perhaps why a guidebook to the island is called ''Come Near at Your Peril.'' It is poor, with as many as 25,000 left unemployed by the current moratorium on cod fishing; its rocky topography, soil and climate could charitably be described as challenging. But Newfoundland's Never-Never Land combination of Ireland, Norway, Iceland and something irrepressibly its own is unforgettable.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit is omitted on page 52 of The Times Magazine today for a photograph of Evelyn Lauder. It should read: Karen Kuehn/Matrix, for The New York Times.

title: Two Huge Industries, But Only One River
description: In the evening, the big ships are an awesome sight. Larger than almost any man-made, movable thing on this earth, they glide down the Mississippi River and past the city's downtown, the diesel engines at a dull throb, the black hulls all but invisible in the gloom except for the running lights, so impossibly far apart.

title: Who's Minding the Schools?
description: WHEN the New York State Legislature sharply curtailed New York City's school decentralization last week, it marked the end of one of the nation's most significant education experiments. The long, anguished experience in New York, and an equally dramatic experience in Chicago, highlight a long conflict: should children's education be controlled by communities and individual schools or by a main office?

title: UConn Defeats Rival Fairfield
description: Today's halftime score reflected the difference between last season's Connecticut men's basketball team and this one.

title: Giving Short Shrift To Mackintosh's Wife
description: To the Editor:

title: On Top of Old Whiskey
description: NOT much snow falls on the reddish badlands and short-grass foothills surrounding Dubois, in western Wyoming, and what does fall usually gets blown away by the wind or evaporates into the dry air. But a few miles away, up on the Continental Divide, the snow is relentless, turning the high country into an icy, uninhabitable desert. The bighorn sheep that live among the craggy peaks must descend in order to survive, and by November more than 900 sheep concentrate near Dubois on the bare, windswept slopes of Whiskey Mountain.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about President Clinton's Cabinet misstated the number of women chosen in some editions. The Cabinet choices include four women, not 14.

title: Hold the Spam
description: THIS JUST IN FROM dreams@hotmail.com: ''You were referred to me as someone who may be interested in the following information.'' Of course, I wasn't really ''referred''; my E-mail address was harvested from Internet discussion groups or searches of Web sites or service-provider customer lists, and then sold and resold. A lot of my E-mail these days begins exactly the same way and continues: ''If you are not, please let us know, and we will promptly take your name off our mailing.'' This, too, is usually a lie.

title: Polish Chief Faces Strains With Vatican
description: Aleksander Kwasniewski is still waiting. The President of Poland has been in office for a year now, but there has been no invitation from the Pope.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: A No-Frills Steakhouse in Another Guise
description: THE Union Street Tavern does not call itself a steakhouse but should. This New Hyde Park newcomer serves some of the most satisfying steaks on the Island.

title: U.S. Takes Low Profile In Lima Hostage Talks
description: Holding firm to its policy of refusing to negotiate with terrorists, the Clinton Administration is playing a quiet, backstage role in trying to resolve the Peruvian hostage standoff.

title: The Inside Story on a Window Painter's Art
description: Mia Rodriguez's business card says ''We Do Windows,'' and so she does.

title: A Secret Society Is Publicly Proud of Its Restoration
description: WHEN New York's Masons built the first of their buildings at the corner of 23d Street and Sixth Avenue, the plan was for it to be a money maker. Indeed, the charter of the corporation formed to build and own the temple required that ''funds derived from the rent or income thereof'' be used to establish educational and charitable programs.

title: Months After Disappearance of Leading Atheist, Group says $600,000 Is Missing, Too
description: Through more than three decades of crusades as a leader of American atheism, Madalyn Murray O'Hair was never silent. She took her battles to the Supreme Court, sparking a landmark 1963 ruling banning organized prayer in public schools, and to the nation's advice columnists.

title: SCALPEL SEASON
description: 1. More nose jobs are performed during the last two weeks of December than in any other two-week period. 2. Why? Holiday largess and spare time. ''Many young people receive new noses for Christmas and Hanukkah,'' says Dr. George Brennan, a plastic surgeon with offices in Beverly Hills and Newport Beach. 3. Dr. Sherrell Aston of Manhattan says his business quadruples the week before Christmas, when he performs 80 percent of his rhinoplasties. 4. Cooperative Images, a Pennsylvania company, offers noses on layaway: $35 a week for a standard $5,000 procedure. 5. ''We like it when Christmas falls midweek -- people have more time off for surgery,'' says Dr. Peter Adamson, president of the American Academy of Facial Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery. Downside: ''You might miss some parties, and you have to be careful to avoid nasal frostbite.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Harry's Bar

title: End-Time Manhattan
description: On a mild, joyous Sunday morning at Bethel Gospel Assembly in Harlem, the sermon turns to the apocalypse. ''I believe it deep in my heart,'' cries out Ezra N. Williams, the church's pastor for 30 years. ''We are of the terminal generation!''

title: Sibling Rivalry Divides Parks
description: In most neighborhoods, highway construction work is bad news. But in Chelsea, the current rejiggering of the West Side Highway brought an unforeseen boon: a newer, larger park at 23d Street between 11th Avenue and the highway. Because the rebuilt roadway will plow through the existing Thomas F. Smith Park, the Federal Government agreed to pay about $1.5 million to more than quadruple the amount of park space.

title: Kelly Newman And Joseph Lash
description: Kelly Irene Newman, the daughter of Irene and Thomas Newman of Wilton, Conn., was married last evening to Joseph V. Lash, a son of Norma Lash Tarr of Rutland, Vt., and the late Norman M. Lash. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at Estherwood, a historic house in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Bookshelf
description: WOMBAT DIVINE. By Mem Fox. Illustrated by Kerry Argent. Harcourt Brace. $15. (Ages 4 to 8) This particular Christmas pageant takes place in Australia, where the animals play all the parts. Wombat auditions for every role, and is, in the end, divine. The story and the illustrations are both enchanting and endearing. Plus nifty animals.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 8 about the crush of seasonal shopping, particularly at the new Kids World store in Elizabeth, misstated the effect of heavy traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike on Nov. 16, the day the store opened. Interchange 13A was closed for about 90 minutes in midafternoon; the turnpike itself was not closed.

title: A Man Among Men
description: Nothing much happens in NOBODY'S FOOL (1994), a small, thoughtful, beautifully crafted Robert Benton film, but it suits the story, and the star, Paul Newman, suits it. He plays a touchy, irresponsible handyman in a blue collar community in upstate New York. The film etches his mundane but quirky amblings among friends and foes. His staunchest ally is his landlady, an exschoolteacher (Jessica Tandy, in one of those sublime cameos of hers). On holidays he visits the son he deserted years ago and two grandchildren. Gone are the days of the golden ''Butch Cassidy'' and the towering ''Hud.'' In this vest-pocket venture, Mr. Newman shows his age, but time hasn't dimmed a superbly vigorous actor. Who could want more? - TUES.-WED. at 2:45 A.M. on HBO.

title: They Did Windows

title: HOW CRAZY WAS ZELDA?
description: I can appreciate that your purpose in publishing F. Scott Fitzgerald's letters regarding his wife's mental illness was to shed light on her condition and on the history of treatment of mental illness (''How Crazy Was Zelda?'' by Peter D. Kramer, Dec. 1). However, I feel compelled to point out that much of Zelda's difficulty in coping with life arose from Scott's treatment of her. This is especially clear in his letter dated March 22, 1934, in which he appears to be providing Dr. Slocum with an analysis of Zelda's writing. But in the biography ''Zelda,'' a very different picture emerges. Scott had an extreme dislike for his wife's writing. In fact, he was threatened by her attempts and he barred her from using any experiences that were common to them both. He took for granted that the shared terrain of their lives was his alone to use as fodder for his fiction.

title: The Silent Policewoman

The dummy cop was suggested by the township committee as a way to stretch the resources of Franklin's police force, said Roy Valentine, a township committeeman. The mannequin, which was donated by a local department store last month, sits in full uniform behind the wheel of a patrol car parked near the township's elementary school to trick drivers into obeying the speed limit. The decision to use a female dummy, Mr. Valentine said, was a pragmatic one. ''It was what we were able to obtain,'' he said.

description: This season started as several had before it. Dan Reeves was shooting himself in the foot.

title: Vatican Newspaper of Record Best Read for What It Doesn't Record
description: Like Pravda, the Kremlin mouthpiece of old, the Vatican's semiofficial newspaper L'Osservatore Romano is best read for the news it does not print, or buries in a mountain of text, tucks onto a back page or otherwise tries to avoid.

title: Officer's Death Highlights Perils of After-Hours Work
description: When Officer Charles A. Davis decided to earn some extra cash to buy Christmas gifts this month, he requested a few more shifts at the 103d Precinct in Queens, a police commander said. But Officer Davis also made money the way many moonlighting New York City police officers do: working as a security guard.

title: Smith Pushes the Bills Right Into Post-Season
description: Bills center Kent Hull heard defensive end Bruce Smith before he saw him. Smith, angry at the way the team, and particularly the offense, had played today against Kansas City, roared into the offense's halftime meeting ''like a big ole grizzly.''

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Rangers Get Break But Don't Need One
description: Their coach and the National Hockey League schedule are forcing the torrid Rangers to take three days off. They won't play or even practice until after Christmas.

title: Disabled Children's Families Brace for Benefit Cuts
description: Sitting on the floor of her mother's small two-bedroom garden apartment, Alexcya Marshall gurgles, coos and smiles like almost any other 20-month-old baby. But that is about all she does.

title: Brumfield Goes Home
description: Cincinnati Bengals offensive lineman SCOTT BRUMFIELD has returned to his home in Utah to continue his recuperation from a spinal injury and will undergo rehabilitation as an outpatient. Brumfield, 26, sustained a cervical spinal cord concussion during a Nov. 3 game in Baltimore when he collided with a teammate. (AP)

title: Humanoids And Props Celebrate Life's Ups And Downs
description: Every day is a holiday for Mummenschanz, the Swiss mime group that celebrates life in all its eccentricities. It goes without saying then, that ''Parade,'' the new production that the troupe is presenting through Jan. 4 at Alice Tully Hall, is the perfect holiday show.

title: Peru's Rebel Leader: An Able Talker and Terrorist
description: The leader of the Marxist guerrillas holding about 140 hostages in the Japanese Ambassador's residence here is a former textile union official whose adept attacks and ability to evade capture have elevated him to almost mythic stature in Peru.

title: Retailers, Full of Optimism, Report Brisk Weekend Sales
description: Shoppers stepped up their spending on the final weekend before Christmas, retailers said yesterday, leaving them optimistic that they would have little problem exceeding last year's weak sales.

title: Tokyo's New Player, From Ukraine via Moscow
description: The Tokyo String Quartet, founded in 1969, gave its first New York concert with its new first violinist, Mikhail Kopelman, on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall. This Ukrainian-born musician is the third violinist to occupy the first chair. Given the turnover rate in established string quartets, this is not unusual.

title: Bobby Unser Survives Snowmobiling Ordeal
description: BOBBY UNSER, the three-time Indianapolis 500 winner, was safe at home yesterday, having spent two perilous nights in the New Mexico wilderness after a snowmobile breakdown.

title: Philharmonic's Tricks Abetted by a Sorcerer
description: When Walt Disney turned ''The Sorcerer's Apprentice'' into an escapade for Mickey Mouse in the animated film classic ''Fantasia,'' he immortalized this vivid score by Paul Dukas. Yet this has had an unintended result: the work seldom turns up these days on orchestra programs.

title: In Guatemala, All Is Forgotten
description: Guatemala's sweeping amnesty, or ''law of National Reconciliation,'' is the capstone of the arduous three-year negotiation to put an end to a brutal 36-year civil war.

title: These Days, the Knicks Stare Adversity Down
description: While winning 9 of their last 10 games, the Knicks have looked far better than the team that stumbled through the first month of the season.

title: The Whoops Defense
description: Representative Newt Gingrich's defenders did not seem to have much wind in their sails yesterday, and it is easy to see why. They have been left with a very weak case for his re-election as Speaker of the House. As laid out by Representative Dick Armey, that case is that Mr. Gingrich was so busy following the 1994 elections that he failed to check with tax attorneys to see that his political and educational expenditures were legal.

title: The Jets and Kotite Share a Final Loss
description: He walked off the field slowly, never noticing the sign that read ''The End of a Error,'' not looking up to the fans over the tunnel who waved goodbye with mocking sincerity.

title: Margret E. Rey, 90, Creator Of 'Curious George' Books
description: Margret E. Rey, who teamed with her husband to create the ''Curious George'' children's books featuring the inquisitive little monkey, died on Saturday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 90.

title: Tackling a Mysterious Mass Rescuer
description: IN SEARCH OF SUGIHARA

title: Plant Celebrates More Than Holidays
description: The Elks Club, a mile from the Hathaway shirt plant, was festooned with white Christmas lights, a beacon of warmth and cheer on a night of driving rain.

title: After Fire, 8th Grader Acts as a Father to His Brothers
description: Julio Valdez cautiously pronounced each letter in heladeria, the word for ice cream parlor, which would make him the champion Spanish speller of School District 6 in Washington Heights. His slow, deliberate voice quavered slightly as he noted the accent -- always the trickiest part -- and sealed the title.

title: INSIDE
description: The War on New Drug Laws

title: Tiananmen's Genesis
description: To the Editor:

title: Ovitz Gives Some Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Singapore Worries About Rival Next Door
description: Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew has a new message for his countrymen: Watch out for Malaysia.

title: He Slyly Sings About the Facts of Life: His Life
description: As he sang ''In Memory of a Memory'' at Tramps on Saturday night, Johnny Paycheck's voice soared with tense bravado to admit, ''You think I'm crazy.'' Then, dropping to a confiding baritone, he added, ''I just might be.''

title: Jim Karayn, 64, TV Executive Who Organized 1976 Debates
description: Jim Karayn, a former public television executive who organized the broadcasts of the Presidential campaign debates in 1976 and the Watergate hearings in 1973, died on Dec. 12 at the National Rehabilitation Hospital in Washington. Mr. Karayn was 64 and lived in Washington.

title: Walter J. Johnson, 88, Refugee Who Founded Academic Press
description: Walter J. Johnson, who fled Germany after Hitler seized his family's publishing business and founded Academic Press in New York, a major publisher of scientific books and journals, died Dec. 15 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND

title: Rebuilding Community Through Churches
description: Rains gradually rusted the metal roof, rotted the cedar belltower and melted the adobe walls of the Spanish-style chapel, abandoned decades ago to a cow pasture below Black Mesa.

title: Serbia's Apartheid Victims
description: The political crisis that has filled Serbia's streets with protesters for more than a month provides some hope for the forgotten victims of President Slobodan Milosevic -- the 1.8 million Albanians who live in the southwestern region of Kosovo. Although 90 percent of the population, the Albanians are ruled in brutal apartheid style by the ethnic Serbs.

title: Groups Protest a Proposal For Disposing of Bomb Fuel
description: A dozen influential groups concerned with the environment, energy supplies and the spread of nuclear weapons have appealed to the Energy Department not to consume plutonium from old weapons in nuclear reactors unless the other leading disposal method, mixing the plutonium with waste and embedding the mixture in glass, proves impractical.

title: Rock and Roll for Grown-Ups
description: Imagine a retirement village with street names like Neil Young Circle and Jimi Hendrix Way -- and gray-haired garage bands rock 'n rolling into the night. The baby- boom generation that made rock music a religion will surely take the music to its grave. The burning question is what, if anything, boomers will buy at the record store. If even a fraction of them embrace new music, it could revive a $12 billion industry that was thriving until this year, when it suddenly hit a wall. If they tune out -- or cling to old music they knew as kids -- new music will go unsold and the business could wither.

title: Cable, Cable Everywhere But Not a Thing to Watch
description: Welcome to cable television's parallel universe, where dozens of networks are on the air, producing thousands of hours of original programming for American audiences, yet the vast majority of cable viewers cannot tune them in.

title: A Fund-Raiser Becomes a Charity Case
description: For years, eager children poured change by the trainload into gumball and candy machines bearing March of Dimes stickers, happy to get a treat and play a small role in the battle against polio and birth defects.

title: States Are Doing a Good Job Fighting Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Exile Speaks
description: A former senior Mexican police commander, now in exile in the United States, is speaking out publicly about political espionage by Mexican leaders and the corrosive effect of drug money on politics, including cash payments to the brother of a former President.

title: Managed Care Turf War
description: From his state-of-the-art headquarters just off Times Square, Dennis Rivera has launched a counterattack against the profiteers of managed care. Mr. Rivera, a 45-year-old union leader who is intense, intelligent and aggressive, makes no attempt to conceal his anger at the corporate types who are reaping fabulous riches by giving ever shorter shrift to patient care. ''Leeches,'' he calls them.

title: One Shot Proves to Be All Medicine Gill and Nets Need
description: Kendall Gill had felt like an impostor virtually every time he stepped on the court this season. His shot was not there and his confidence was not there. And so, of course, the results were not there. Gill looked ill.

title: Communication Breakdown When Laptops Meet Pay Phones
description: Two crucial communications tools for business travelers are the laptop computer and the public telephone. So why do they not talk to each other?

title: Four Down, and Counting: The Coaching Watch Begins
description: Rich Kotite got the ball rolling when he stepped down as the Jets' coach on Friday. But the dismissals of the Rams' Rich Brooks on Sunday and the Giants' Dan Reeves and the Falcons' June Jones yesterday could open the gates for a flood of coaching changes, rivaling the purge that followed the 1992 season when nine head coaches lost their jobs.

title: When Jurisdiction Is Global
description: State Superior Court judges have international jurisdiction in child custody cases, when a parent has transported a child to a foreign country, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday. The unanimous decision came in the case of a 3-year-old girl whose mother took her to Morocco despite a joint-custody agreement with the child's father that was made in a New Jersey court, The Associated Press reported. A State Appeals Court had dismissed the father's complaint, saying that New Jersey law did not give the Family Court judge jurisdiction in the matter. In his opinion yesterday, Associate Justice Stewart G. Pollock reversed the appellate decision and ordered the custody case reopened.

title: Pronghorn's Speed May Be Legacy of Past Predators
description: RACING at top speed across the Western plains, as close to flying as four hooves can take it, an American pronghorn in motion is a biological marvel running nearly 60 miles an hour, faster than anything else on the continent.

title: Executive Changes
description: AIRTOUCH COMMUNICATIONS INC., San Francisco, said its vice chairman, Lee Cox, would retire as head of its cellular division on Feb. 1. He will continue as vice chairman until April 4 and then be a director and consultant. Brian Jones, executive vice president of the cellular unit's Los Angeles market, will succeed Mr. Cox as chief executive of Airtouch Cellular.

title: Two Clients Move Their Accounts
description: Two advertisers are changing agencies on their accounts.

title: People
description: Robert Riesenberg was named to the new post of senior vice president and broadcast and programming director for the Coca-Cola Co. account at McCann-Erickson North America, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had been president at RER Communications, New York.

title: Bosnia Serb Leaders Refuse To Join United Government
description: Bosnian Serb leaders said today that they refused to take part in the new national government of Bosnia, a position that reflects the abiding influence of the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic.

title: Red Cross and Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Does MARTHA STEWART practice what she preaches when it comes to the holidays?

title: Phillips Gets Probation
description: LAWRENCE PHILLIPS, 21, pleaded no contest yesterday in El Monte, Calif., to a drunken driving charge resulting from a June 15 arrest, and the St. Louis Rams' running back was placed on probation for three years. The rookie was also fined $1,000 plus penalty assessments -- a total of $2,900 -- and must serve 80 hours of community service. (AP)

title: Israelis and P.L.O. Push for Accord on Hebron
description: Prodded by an American mediator, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization broke a long and bitter deadlock today over Israel's withdrawal from the West Bank city of Hebron, holding marathon talks through the night in a furious push to reach an agreement.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Further Earnings Strength Seen in Some Forecasts

title: Italy Suggests Amount Of Metal Workers' Raise
description: The Italian Government has proposed that companies pay a salary increase of 200,000 lire ($120) a month for the country's 1.5 million metal workers, Prime Minister Romano Prodi said in an interview on state television. The Government's weekend intervention was an attempt to settle a wage dispute that has lasted seven months.

title: For the Barbie Doll's New Clothes
description: IN the flood of technology inundating my office I nearly overlooked what must be the first program ever to come with peripherals like sequins, rosettes, ribbons and five pairs of tiny shoes. Luckily an unscheduled refueling stop in Billings, Mont., gave a proud papa in the airplane seat beside me time to extol his daughter's ''creativity'' with a CD-ROM for making Barbie doll clothes.

title: Dollar and Foreign Economies Influence Earnings
description: Now that the second consecutive super year for equities is drawing to a close, investors will be looking more and more at the outlook for corporate earnings in 1997, which some forecasters believe is strong enough to support another good -- although less ebullient -- year for stocks.

title: Gene Trigger Discovery May Help Protect Crops
description: IN a discovery that could help in the effort to guard agricultural crops from blight and reduce the need for pesticides, scientists have identified a genetic trigger that protects plants from disease.

title: Suit on Landfill Is Dismissed
description: A suit seeking to stop Atlantic City from giving a 150-acre abandoned landfill to a casino developer, Stephen A. Wynn, was dismissed yesterday by a Superior Court judge. The plaintiffs are residents of a neighborhood whose homes would be demolished to make way for a tunnel to serve the site.
