They claimed that the city had no right to give public land to a private developer and should have included a plan to relocate them in its agreement with Mr. Wynn. But the judge, L. Anthony Gibson, ruled that the public benefits of the land transfer -- a mammoth casino that is projected to create 5,000 jobs and pay $127 million a year in taxes to local and state authorities -- justified the deal, especially since the city had been unable to sell the property. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Anheuser-Busch Ads Shifted From MTV
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that commercials for its beer brands had been withdrawn from the MTV cable television network and shifted to the VH1 network, which, like MTV, is owned by Viacom Inc.

title: The Sudan's Islamic Leader: Enigmatic Foe for the West
description: Hassan al-Turabi sits in his office overlooking the Nile, talking at the speed of sound, weaving great mosques and minarets of words in the air.

title: NABORS INDUSTRIES TO BUY ADCOR-NICKLOS DRILLING
description: Nabors Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Adcor-Nicklos Drilling Company for about $68 million in stock. Adcor-Nicklos, a privately held company based in Houston, owns 36 drilling rigs and related equipment. The rigs are in east and south Texas, Arkansas, Oklahoma and the Rocky Mountain region. Nabors, a drilling contractor also based in Houston, operates about 330 land drilling and 78 land well servicing rigs. It said all of Adcor-Nicklos's shares would be exchanged for 3.4 million common shares of Nabors. Shares of Nabors stock were unchanged yesterday at $20.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM PAYING $45 MILLION FOR TELRAD STAKE
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. will pay $45 million for a 20 percent holding in Telrad, a telecommunications-equipment unit of Israel's Koor Industries, Koor said. Northern Telecom, based in Ontario, is a telecommunications equipment unit of BCE Inc. of Montreal. Koor, Israel's largest company, said Northern Telecom would pay $17.5 million in cash up front and the rest in four payments. Koor plans to sell shares in Telrad in the United States.

title: After Trailing Early, Bulls Have Their Way With Kittles and Nets
description: It was the day after his first brush with Michael Jordan, the day after the idol of idols first planted his forearm into the bird-caged body of the Nets rookie Kerry Kittles.

title: Sears of Britain Discusses Catalogue Sale
description: Sears P.L.C., a British department store and retail chain operator unrelated to Sears, Roebuck & Company, said yesterday that it was in ''advanced discussions'' to sell its catalogue shopping business, Freemans, to the Littlewoods Organization. Sears has sold several businesses and properties in the last two years to deal with falling profit, sluggish sales and battered margins.

title: T.W.A. Plans Cuts; Job Losses Possible
description: Seeking to stem heavy losses from flights across the Atlantic, where the market has grown crowded, Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it would cut some routes and possibly hundreds of jobs at its hub at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Bonn Stake in Lufthansa To Be Sold to Bank
description: The German Government said yesterday that it would sell its Lufthansa shares to a state-owned bank, Kreditanstalt fur Wiederaufbau, by the end of the year to help reduce Germany's budget deficit. Kreditanstalt will buy the 35.68 percent stake for 2.1 billion marks ($1.35 billion), which Government officials in Bonn will be able to apply to this year's deficit, the Finance Ministry said.

title: Few Forints to Spend, but Hungarians Like the Mall
description: Diana Galli had already bought several toys and a knock-off Walkman, and now she contemplated an elegant display of tableware in the first American-style shopping mall in Central Europe.

title: World's Most Powerful Accelerator To Be Completed 3 Years Early
description: SOME good news for particle physicists came from Geneva on Friday, when the 19 member nations of the European Laboratory for Particle Physics decided to speed completion of the world's most powerful accelerator by three years.

title: 2 Findings in a Boy's Death
description: At 3:25 A.M. on June 16, Essex County prosecutors say, a young man got out of a stolen Jeep and tried to break into a car belonging to the wife of Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James. When a police officer guarding the Mayor's house approached, prosecutors say, the youth got back in the Jeep and tried to run him over. The officer, a 27-year veteran of the force, fired four shots at the Jeep, one of which struck a 14-year-old passenger in the back of the head and killed him.

title: Transaction By a Charity Is Questioned
description: New York State charity regulators asked the March of Dimes yesterday for financial information about an arrangement under which a trustee of the organization was allowed to have his business use $1.7 million it owed the group.

title: Closing Tax Loopholes
description: To the Editor:

title: Mail Bomb Injures Lawyer
description: A lawyer in Santa Cruz, Calif., was severely injured today when a package wrapped in green paper exploded in his office, the police said.

title: Making Money the Makeshift Way At Small Mail-Order Food Houses
description: The view from the picture window of Tom Perini's house on his ranch near this tiny West Texas town suggested calm. Mesquite trees stood unmoving in the crisp air. Black brangus cattle -- a mix of Brahman and Black Angus stock -- grazed in silence. In the distance, the Edwards Plateau, whose 300-foot ridges define Buffalo Gap, seemed dry and timeless.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARVIN INDUSTRIES, Columbus, Ind., a multinational maker and distributor of auto parts, said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell four million preferred shares through a finance unit.

title: Christmas Manger
description: On at least one farm in the Berkshires, the horses do not eat from mangers. They gather at feeding time in a corner of the pasture near the water tank and take their oats from heavy rubber pans set on the ground. Hay is placed here and there, wherever the earth is dry. When the horses finish their oats, they paw the flakes of hay apart, as if they were searching for something in the smell of dried grass. Mud clings to hooves and boots and it dries on the horses' flanks. Now, at last, the mud has frozen, making the footing better for everyone. It has been possible, once again, to see stars at night and to watch, at feeding time, the sky dying out in the pale rose of winter.

title: Prayer and the Civic Religion
description: I grew up in a conservative Baptist family in which we honored some basic premises that had defined Baptists for more than three and a half centuries. One of the most fundamental was the separation of church and state, based on Jesus' admonition to ''render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's and to God the things that are God's.''

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: St. John's

title: A Headstone, a Coffin And Now, the DNA Bank
description: DR. JERRY MILLER says he came within a hairbreadth of missing his last chance to save a bit of his mother for posterity. Dr. Miller, a Philadelphia dentist, had already decided that he wanted his mother's genetic material, or DNA, preserved, just in case it might be useful in the future when he or his children, or, possibly, his great-grandchildren, might want to know if they had inherited any disease-causing genes.

title: Pistons' Mission? Beat Bulls
description: The Detroit Pistons have been good enough to win 20 of their first 25 games. They have been good enough to hold opponents to 85.8 points a game.

title: NATIONWIDE FILES TO SELL SHARES IN LIFE INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Nationwide Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell to the public as much as 20 percent of its life insurance unit, a leading provider of annuities. The stock sale would raise as much as $500 million, according to a registration statement filed yesterday with the commission. That suggests that Nationwide's life insurance business, based in Columbus, Ohio, has an initial market value of about $2.5 billion. The offering, along with a $300 million note sale planned by the life insurer, would provide new sources of capital to finance future growth. The stock sale would also enable Nationwide to obtain a market value for the unit that would almost certainly be higher than the price currently reported to regulators. The increase in value would ultimately give Nationwide a greater cushion for losses or the leeway to write more insurance.

title: Being an Angel Doesn't Guarantee You're a Saint
description: John Travolta may be the only Hollywood star these days who can pull a movie out of a hat and make it dance on the head of a pin. And in Nora Ephron's winsome, wafer-thin comedy, ''Michael,'' his portrayal of a mischievous angel with the appetites of a trucker and the table manners of a 2-year-old puts the film on on its toes and sets it spinning.

title: Chase and First Data in Joint Venture
description: Chase Manhattan Bank and the First Data Corporation agreed yesterday to form a venture that will provide merchant-processing services, beginning in the first quarter of next year. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Patience in Peru
description: History is repeating itself at the Japanese Embassy in Lima, Peru. The scene -- Latin American Marxist guerrillas holding Government officials and foreign diplomats hostage -- has so far been a replay of the M-19 guerrilla takeover of the Embassy of the Dominican Republic in Colombia in 1980. That hostage crisis ended without bloodshed, as this one can if both sides show restraint.

title: Mazda Settles Leasing Suits
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation of America has agreed to settle suits by attorneys general in 21 states over reportedly deceptive lease advertisements that promised ''zero down'' and ''penny down'' terms.

title: A Clash of Rock Stars In an Existential Mode
description: It is reported that in the unenlightened year of 1972, angry audience members fled in disgust from the American premiere of Sam Shepard's ''Tooth of Crime'' at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., when intermission arrived. That was, of course, before the play's author had won a Pulitzer Prize, become a movie star and been on mainstream magazine covers and people figured it was important to at least pretend to understand him.

title: Can He Be Beaten?
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's increasingly confident appraisal of his re-election prospects has not come as a surprise to the Democratic leaders who would like to unseat him. Many of them have been saying the same thing -- if less publicly -- for months.

title: Q&A
description: Millers

title: Giuliani Offers Plan to Ease Restrictions on New Housing
description: Seeking to ease a housing shortage that is growing worse by the month, the Giuliani administration is preparing a broad plan to open up manufacturing areas to residential development while eliminating regulations that it thinks are discouraging housing construction in New York City.

title: OM GROUP ACQUIRING U.S. INDUSTRIES' SCM SUBSIDIARY
description: OM Group said it had agreed to acquire SCM Metal Products Inc., a unit of U.S. Industries, for $122 million in cash. SCM Metal, based in Research Triangle Park, N.C., reported sales of about $94 million in the fiscal year ended Sept. 28. The unit makes specialty chemicals and powders for the automobile, electronics and transportation industries. OM Group, with 1995 revenue of $361 million, is based in Cleveland and makes metal salts and powders used in plastics, coatings, petroleum refining and other industries. U.S. Industries, a diversified industrial management company based in Iselin, N.J., has annual sales of about $2.2 billion.

title: Becker Will Not Play In Davis Cup Match
description: BORIS BECKER will not play for Germany in a first-round Davis Cup match against Spain in February.

title: Audi Says Profit Was Better This Year
description: Audi, a subsidiary of Volkswagen A.G., said last week that its group pretax profit for 1996 would be at least 25 percent more than 1995's.

title: Going to Die, but First There's a Lot to Say
description: THIS WILD DARKNESS

title: Accounts
description: Teleport Communications Group, Staten Island, to Partners & Shevack, New York, a unit of Mickelberry Communications, to handle advertising, previously handled by Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Key West Reefs Dying Of Mysterious Disease
description: DIVING offshore south of here recently, Craig Quirolo was shocked to find much of the coral a sickly white, smothered by a mysterious, creeping disease that was choking the life from reefs more than 5,000 years old.

title: Gulf War Panel Reviews Researcher's Ouster
description: A Congressional panel said today that it was investigating why a White House committee studying the illnesses of veterans of the Persian Gulf war abruptly dismissed its respected chemical-weapons investigator last year.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Linguistic Confusion
description: The school board in Oakland, Calif., blundered badly last week when it declared that black slang is a distinct language that warrants a place of respect in the classroom. The new policy is intended to help teach standard English and other subjects by building on the street language actually used by many inner-city children and their parents. It is also designed to boost self-esteem for underachievers. But by labeling them linguistic foreigners in their own country, the new policy will actually stigmatize African-American children -- while validating habits of speech that bar them from the cultural mainstream and decent jobs.

title: Marlins Re-sign Nen
description: The Florida Marlins, who in the past few weeks have given $89 million to six free agents, gave $17.5 million to one of their own players yesterday. ROBB NEN, the Marlins' No. 1 relief pitcher, accepted that sum for the next four years. Nen, 27, will receive salaries of $3 million, $4 million, $5 million and $5.5 million. He had 35 saves last season, a 5-1 record and a 1.95 earned run average, lowest among the seven National Leaguers with 35 or more saves.

title: Hearings on Flood Control
description: In 1973, the raging, rain-swollen Stony Brook killed six people in Green Brook and North Plainfield, prompting years of study by the United States Army Corps of Engineers on how to control flooding in the area. But it was not until last year that the communities within the basin were able to agree on where to locate the dams and levies. Yesterday, the corps released a draft report on the environmental impact of its proposed $334 million system to control flooding.

title: Jets Prove Perpetual Motion Is Possible
description: The only Jet who calls Long Island home is from Tonga.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday about job cuts by the Zenith Electronics Corporation referred incorrectly to the company's status as a maker of television sets. It is not the only company making them in the United States. Others include Sony.

title: Phone Bill Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: INACOM AGREES TO ACQUIRE THREE NETWORK CONSULTANTS
description: The Inacom Corporation, a technology management services company based in Omaha, has agreed to acquire three network consulting providers for about $10.5 million in cash and around 360,000 common shares. The purchase may also include an additional 120,000 shares, depending on future events. Inacom said it expected to take a fourth-quarter after-tax charge of $1 million to $1.25 million in connection with the transactions. The companies it is buying are Perigee Communications Inc. of Minneapolis; Networks Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Gorham Clark in New York.

title: Economy not expanding? Some companies don't mind.
description: BECAUSE of the increased volatility in the market and signs of a possible slowdown in the economy, some Wall Street advisers are telling investors to focus on companies with predictable profits that are not dependent on an expanding economy.

title: INSIDE
description: Deal Seems Near on Hebron

title: Cable Rights Stall Isles Deal
description: With rumors swirling around Nassau Coliseum today concerning John O. Pickett's $165 million sale of the Islanders to the Texas businessman John Spano, a member of the Islanders' front office who requested anonymity said today that the $85 million portion of the deal concerning the final buyout of cable rights is still under negotiation.

title: Hercules of Bees Is Rescuing a Rare Mistletoe
description: AN international team of researchers has brought good tidings about a rare species of mistletoe: a tiny bee may be coming to its rescue.

title: Assignments Added For Two Agencies
description: Two marketers are expanding relationships with roster agencies.

title: Where Home Was
description: There was a time when I knew exactly where home was -- the house my grandfather built in 1939 outside Green Bay, Wis. Looking for land to build on, my grandmother spotted a three-story oak tree, and told her husband, ''here.''

title: Archer in $430 Million Deal To Buy W. R. Grace Cocoa Unit
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company said yesterday that it would buy the cocoa business of W. R. Grace & Company for about $430 million in cash and debt, expanding its reach beyond grains and soybeans.

title: Fiesta Snub Stings B.Y.U.
description: They've won 13 games against 1 loss, are ranked No. 5 in the nation, and their coach of 25 years believes this is one of the nicest teams Brigham Young University has ever put on the field. How nice? Lavell Edwards has 36 Eagle Scouts on his Cougar roster.

title: Advertisements for Winn-Dixie Are Referred for F.T.C. Review
description: The National Advertising Review Board, which is part of the advertising industry's self-regulatory mechanism, has referred Winn-Dixie Stores Inc.'s comparative pricing advertisements to the Federal Trade Commission for review after deciding they could be misleading.

title: Aerodynamic Secrets of Insect Flight
description: WITH the help of a giant, smoke-spewing mechanical moth, researchers say they have finally figured out how insects fly.

title: Nativity Scenes Become an Issue Even in Mostly Catholic Italy
description: In Italy, where the creche has been a central symbol of the holiday that calls for peace on earth, the Nativity scene has become a battleground this year.

title: INA of Italy Plans Swap With a Bank
description: INA S.p.A., said yesterday that it would swap its banking operations for the life insurance unit of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro as part of a plan in which the two institutions would buy Banco di Napoli from the Government.

title: S.E.C. Filing by Bottler
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today to sell as much as $2.5 billion in securities. The bottler and distributor of Coca-Cola soft drinks plans to sell senior debt securities, warrants to purchase the debt securities or currency warrants, the filing stated. Combining the latest filing with previous ones means that the Atlanta-based company could now raise as much as $3.17 billion from securities sales, according to the filing. The company will use the proceeds from the offerings for general corporate purposes, including the repayment of debt and possible acquisitions, the filing stated.

title: HUGHES ELECTRONICS TO BUY AN ALLIANT BUSINESS
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation has agreed to acquire the Marine Systems Group of Alliant Techsystems Inc. for $141 million in cash. The companies said the acquisition was subject to Government approval. The Marine Systems Group, based in Mukilteo, Wash., has about 650 employees in six states and makes torpedoes, an underwater surveillance system and a mine-neutralization system. Alliant, based in Hopkins, Minn., is an aerospace and defense company. Hughes Electronics, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is based in Los Angeles.

title: Lauer Named to Replace Gumbel on 'Today'
description: NBC made a long-expected appointment official yesterday when it named Matt Lauer the next co-host of the ''Today'' show, replacing Bryant Gumbel, who will step down on Jan. 3 after 15 years in the job.

title: A Stolen 18th-Century Violin Is Recovered
description: The nightmare that began when Dale Stuckenbruck woke up one morning two weeks ago has ended.

title: Direction? Give Young A Compass
description: IN awarding Dan Reeves what amounted to an honorable discharge, George Young kept talking about how the Giants simply wanted ''to go in another direction,'' meaning another coach. But the more the Giants' general manager talked yesterday, the more he seemed to still be going in the same old direction, meaning his direction.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Cameron Crowe yesterday with an article about the making of his new film, ''Jerry Maguire,'' carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Steve Goldstein.

title: Gingrich Weathering His Ethics Storm
description: Even as Democrats continued to rage against him for his admitted ethical lapses, Speaker Newt Gingrich appeared today to have overcome any threat to his leadership by rallying his staunchest supporters and winning over his harshest Republican critics.

title: Treasury Postpones Its Auction Of New Inflation-Indexed Notes
description: The Treasury today postponed its first auction of inflation-indexed 10-year notes, which have been promoted as a way to save for college or retirement. The auction had been tentatively planned for early January.

title: A Windfall: 1,400 Jobs
description: For Mercer County, which lost 6,000 jobs during 1995, there was some good news yesterday. Raytheon Engineers and Constructors will set up its eastern region headquarters at the Carnegie Center at Princeton, in West Windsor Township, adding 1,400 jobs to the county. Of these, 450 employees will be relocated from the high-technology company's Lyndhurst offices and another 950 jobs will be transferred from company offices in Philadelphia and New York City.

title: Dwarf Mouse's Secret to Long Life Seems to Be Linked to Its Tiny Size
description: WELL into what should have been her dotage, a dwarf mouse with peach-color fur, weighing barely half an ounce and measuring two inches from the tip of her snout to the base of her tail, retained her youthful looks and energy. Her younger, full-size relatives became grizzled and humpbacked, and slowed from scurrying to hobbling, long before she sprouted her first gray hair. She outlived them all.

title: Brooklyn's Offshore Casino
description: If New York City is to become a harbor for floating casinos that conduct their gambling operations in international waters, it makes sense for the city government to learn about who is going into the business. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is thus right to try to stop the activities of a new company that suddenly began taking gamblers from Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn last week so they could play blackjack and use slot machines offshore. The city may have limited powers to prevent the offshore gambling business from getting started, but carefully regulating such activities serves the public's interest.

title: Predicament in the Pulpit: The Christmas Eve Crowd
description: On Christmas Eve, the view from the pulpit is not what a preacher sees on a typical Sunday morning. The holiday congregation includes not only the regular reverent, but also no shortage of the sleepy, the fidgety and the festive, people whose evenings probably began with a party.

title: Copyright Treaties Come From a Global Reach
description: To the Editor:

title: Avery Near a Deal
description: The Boston Red Sox are reportedly close to signing STEVE AVERY. ESPN reported last night that a one-year deal with a base salary of $4.2 million was imminent. Said Red Sox General Manager DAN DUQUETTE, ''We have nothing to report right now.''

title: Long Bond Rises on Poll Of Consumers
description: Prices of Treasury securities were up yesterday, after a consumer sentiment report suggested expectations about the economy were waning, a development that is market-friendly since it suggests the Fed will not need to push up interest rates to fight inflation.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Big Australian Retailer Sells More Assets
description: Coles Myer Ltd., Australia's largest retailer, said yesterday that it had sold a number of its retail property assets for $558 million (Australian), or $445 million (United States).

title: A New Symbiosis Between Men's and Women's Wear
description: Designers have been begging for a means to slow the speed of change in women's fashion for a long time. Finally, they have one.

title: Mattel Fined for Late Deliveries
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that Mattel Inc. had agreed to pay $146,186 in civil penalties for not making timely deliveries or prompt refunds in the sale of Barbie collectible dolls.

title: Eyes and Ears Rejoice At a Musical Renewal
description: The development office at St. Patrick's Cathedral is having an unexpected problem with the campaign to raise money for the restoration of the 66-year-old pipe organ. When visitors enter St. Patrick's, the most famous Roman Catholic cathedral in the United States and a major tourist attraction, they gaze up into the organ lofts and are dazzled by what they see.

title: Ferrer Enlists Former Adviser To Jesse Jackson
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, has hired the political consultant from Ohio who managed Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign in 1988. The consultant, Gerald Austin, will manage Mr. Ferrer's mayoral campaign, aides said yesterday.

title: Newell Jenkins, 81, Conductor Who Found Gems in Archives
description: Newell Jenkins, a conductor and musicologist whose discoveries helped expand contemporary perceptions of the Baroque, Classical and early Romantic repertories and whose enterprising Clarion Concerts introduced listeners to hundreds of fascinating rarities, died on Saturday at his home in Hillsdale, N.Y. He was 81.

title: A Two-Hour Psychological Test Turns Into Giants' Lightning Rod
description: WE knew there were problems between Dan Reeves and the Giants' brass. But it wasn't until yesterday afternoon that we finally got a frank, public dialogue on the bitter estrangement.

title: British Utility Bid Wins Approval
description: Calenergy Inc. said yesterday that British regulators had rejected Northern Electric P.L.C.'s last-ditch effort to block a hostile $1.54 billion takeover bid by Calenergy and Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc.

title: Islanders Squander Three-Goal Comeback
description: Bizarre. Devastating. Heartbreaking.

title: For Devils and Sabres, the Shutout Is Mutual
description: From the early going, it was clear that goals would be hard to come by tonight.

title: Guatemala Amnesty Balances Peace and Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: A Housing Security Crunch
description: Since Dec. 14, when security guards walked off the job at Hoboken's public housing complexes, the police have been juggling shifts and rerouting patrols to protect residents of the 1,350 apartments.

title: Neediest Cases Controls Are Strict
description: Every dollar sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reaches a poor person in New York City. From Thanksgiving until the end of February, readers are reminded: ''The Times pays all of the fund's expenses, so contributions go directly to the charities, which use them to provide services and cash assistance to the poor.''

title: Where Is the Trust?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's China Wriggle
description: President Clinton, his supporting cast of bureaucrats and even most of his political opponents are so twisting the essence of the visit to the White House of Communist China's top weapons dealer that the deeply important meaning is wrung right out of it. And that is no accident.

title: Sundstrom Steps Out Into the Midnight Sun
description: In his fifth season with the Rangers, the 23-year-old Aleksei Kovalev has a few teammates who are younger and less experienced. Occasionally, he can even offer them a bit of advice.

title: Dean Witter To Purchase A Discounter
description: Dean Witter, Discover & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Lombard Institutional Brokerage Inc., a discount securities firm that offers trading over the Internet and by toll-free telephone number. The terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

title: PLACER DOME OFFERS DEAL TO CANCEL STAKE IN HIGHLANDS
description: Canada's Placer Dome Inc. has offered to cancel its stake in the takeover target Highlands Gold Ltd. of Australia in return for Highlands' 25 percent stake in the Porgera gold mine in Papua New Guinea plus a cash settlement. The offer, in a letter to the chairman of Highlands, Clive Hildebrand, follows the rejection by the Highlands board of Placer Dome's takeover bid of 75 Australian cents a share. The bid values all of Highlands at $423 million (Australian), or $336 million (United States). A report prepared for Highlands by Baring Brothers Burrows & Company, which was published yesterday, values Highlands at 96 Australian cents to $1.14 a share.

title: Giants Purge Reeves in Meadowlands Minute
description: The divorce between Dan Reeves and the Giants was completed today. With his wife by his side and his assistant coaches watching the news conference from the back of the interview room, Reeves said a sincere goodbye to the Giants while simultaneously kicking them in the shins.

title: Can't Old Allies Get Along?
description: Thirty years ago, in the middle of the cold war, President Charles De Gaulle withdrew from NATO, prompting the United States to denounce France as irresponsible and selfish. It was a low point in French-American postwar relations.

title: U. S. JUDGE BLOCKS ENFORCING OF LAW OVER PREFERENCES
description: A Federal judge here barred the State of California today from enforcing a recent ballot initiative intended to roll back affirmative action programs in the state, a decision that will probably send the law on to a court battle that could last for years.

title: Glamour in Small Doses
description: Sometimes you don't need a new dress or outfit for a holiday party, just a new look, which can come from a change of hairdo or the addition of an accessory.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov won the European Quickplay Championship in Cap d'Agde, France, in early November, by defeating the Dutch grandmaster Loek Van Wely in the final, a mini-match. Using the Bobby Fischer clock in 30-minute games with a 20-second bonus for each move, Karpov drew two games and then won the two tie-break games of 3 minutes with a 2-second bonus for each move.

title: ARTHUR ANDERSEN CHIEF SAYS FIRM WILL NOT SPLIT IN TWO
description: The chief executive of Arthur Andersen & Company, Lawrence A. Weinbach, repeated yesterday that the firm would not split into separate accounting and consulting businesses. He had made a similar comment in July. Still, he acknowledged there had been problems. ''There are differences of view regarding whether or not there's competition between the business units, which also leads into discussions as to whether our remuneration policy is fair,'' he said. Speculation regarding a split in the firm, which is based in Chicago, has increased because the consulting business has been growing faster than than the accounting business. In addition, some consulting partners were reported to be disgruntled that some parts of the accounting business were competing with them by selling consulting services.

title: A Holiday For Victims Of Violence
description: FROM the outside, there is nothing special about the apartment house in Brooklyn, not the graffiti nor the neighbors who come around asking if any rooms are available. No, they are always told before being politely turned away by a guard. No one gets past the front door uninvited.

title: Fassel Tops List That Spans Coaching Spectrum
description: For anyone who thinks Arizona's offensive coordinator, Jim Fassel, is too soft to be a head coach, consider an incident that occurred earlier this month involving him and Cardinals quarterback Boomer Esiason.

title: Patterns
description: New Day for Parallel

title: CS Holding to Sell Elektrowatt Unit Stake
description: CS Holding of Switzerland, completing the sale of its stake in Elektrowatt A.G., said yesterday that Siemens A.G. would buy its 44.5 percent stake in Elektrowatt's building services division for about 1.1 billion Swiss francs ($822 million). CS said on Friday that it would sell its 44.5 percent in Watt A.G., the electricity unit of Elektrowatt, to a group of Swiss and German electricity companies.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH IN RESEARCH PACT WITH GENOME
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation has said it will pay the Genome Therapeutics Corporation up to $67 million in a multiyear research collaboration to develop new asthma drugs. Schering-Plough said Genome, based in Waltham, Mass., would identify genes and associated proteins for Schering-Plough in its efforts to develop new pharmaceuticals. Schering-Plough, based in Madison, N.J., will pay Genome an undisclosed up-front license fee, finance a multiyear research program, make milestone payments and pay royalties based on sales of products developed under the collaboration.

title: No Headline
description: ''One of the things I like to say at the midnight service on Christmas Eve is, 'By the way, we do this every Sunday at 11.' ''

title: Biotechnology Medications Move Closer to the Market
description: Two new biotechnology drugs moved closer to coming to market yesterday.

title: Sharon's Term
description: To the Editor:

title: City Seeks Way to Halt Casino Cruises
description: The Giuliani administration went to court yesterday to try to block the owners of a casino ship from using a Brooklyn pier, a legal maneuver intended to stop the cruises until the city can scrutinize the background of its owners.

title: Ecotourism, Environment and Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Shows It Is Young but Eager
description: Sure, Connecticut's young basketball team displayed fortitude, energy and depth tonight. But missing was the touch to put the ball through the basket.

title: Unnecessary Close-Up: Kotite in Your Face
description: Rich Kotite is a winner. You read that right. The former Jets coach whupped Miami Coach Jimmy Johnson in a peculiar game he didn't know he was playing. But before Kotite could exit with his odd triumph, ESPN failed him as miserably as his team did. When Kotite fired Kotite, or quit to himself last Friday, ESPN carried eight stingy minutes from ESPNEWS's live coverage of his news conference before returning to a ''SportsCenter'' repeat of 10-hour-old news.

title: Lawyers Also Investigating Flight 800
description: Federal investigators are not the only ones hunting for the cause of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: As Schools Face Change, Many Ask How They Fit In
description: From the highest officials in the New York City Board of Education to the parents whose children attend fifth grade in the South Bronx, everyone connected with the school system will be affected by the State Legislature's overhaul of school management last week.

title: Gingrich on Two Ethics Cases
description: Following are statements by Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, about House ethics issues raised about him and the accusations he pursued against former Speaker Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas:

title: In expanding its luxury appeal to a mass market, Tiffany tries television for the first time.
description: TIFFANY & COMPANY is advertising on television for the first time in the company's history in a tricky attempt to expand its consumer appeal without compromising its prestigious image.

title: R. A. Hendrickson, 73, Tax Lawyer and Historian
description: Robert A. Hendrickson, a New York City tax lawyer who was one of the first to draw up wills for people with homes in several countries and who wrote a two-volume biography of Alexander Hamilton, died on Sunday. He was 73 and had lived for several decades in Manhattan.

title: President Finds Rapport With Marines
description: President Clinton today told an enthusiastic crowd of more than 2,000 marines here, many with spouses and children, that they were indispensable to America's role as world leader.

title: St. Louis Bank Acquiring Rival For $1 Billion
description: Mercantile Bancorporation Inc. announced yesterday that it would acquire a rival, Roosevelt Financial Group Inc., for $1.07 billion in stock and cash. The move strengthens its position in the Midwest, but makes it a more attractive takeover target in a swiftly consolidating industry.

title: U.S. Clearance for Drug
description: Ortho-McNeil Pharmaceutical, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, said today that the Food and Drug Administration had cleared its antibiotic Floxin tablets as a sole treatment for pelvic inflammatory disease. Ortho-McNeil said pelvic inflammatory disease affects one million women a year and can lead to serious complications, including infertility. Previous treatment combined injections or intravenous medication and oral antibiotics.

title: 3 Ex-Hostages in Peru Speak Kindly of Captors
description: Three Canadians among the 225 hostages released on Sunday by Marxist guerrillas said today that they and all the captives had been treated with courtesy since the rebels took over the Japanese Ambassador's residence six days ago.

title: 7 Prisoners Get Clemency From Pataki
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today commuted the prison sentence of a 49-year-old woman convicted of killing her husband in 1985 after he had repeatedly battered her throughout their seven-year marriage.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VINCENZO LA SCOLA, an Italian tenor, will have a memorable Christmas of a different sort: he will be heard at the Vatican, at St. Patrick's Cathedral and at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Internet Traffic Jams May Have a Helpful Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoechst to Split Off Diagnostics Division
description: Hoechst A.G. of Germany said yesterday that it would operate its diagnostics division as a separate entity as part of a continuing reorganization. After Jan. 1, Hoechst's diagnostics business will be run by a new subsidiary, Behring Diagnostics, Hoechst said in a statement.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lou Eisenstein, 83, Referee in the N.B.A.
description: Lou Eisenstein, a National Basketball Association referee from the league's beginnings in 1946 until his retirement in 1976, died on Friday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83.

title: Copyright Treaties Come From a Global Reach
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Sisters, Now Into Their 90's, Are Still Going Like 60
description: For a small town, Gettysburg has always had its share of renown, as a Civil War battle site, as the backdrop for Lincoln's 266-word tribute to the ideals of America and more recently as the home of Dwight and Mamie Eisenhower.

title: NO PROGRESS SEEN IN PERUVIAN TALKS ON 140 HOSTAGES
description: After a night of joy over the release of 225 hostages, a cloud of fear hung heavy today over the Japanese Ambassador's residence here as negotiations between the Government and Marxist guerrillas failed to liberate the 140 captives who remained inside.

title: Dec. 25 in Russia: The Adoration of the Monetary
description: A 12-foot Christmas tree stands in front of Russia's most famous toy store glimmering with unsubliminal advertising. It is trimmed with huge fake boxes of Nesquik, the Nestle chocolate powder.

title: James Chester Raulston, Horticulturist, Is Dead at 56
description: Dr. James Chester Raulston, a generous-spirited giant among horticulturists who was director of the arboretum at North Carolina State University in Raleigh and devoted his life to growing and distributing new plants, died late Saturday night in a car crash just east of Asheboro, N.C. He was 56.

title: His Heart Belongs to Mommie (Dearest)
description: Out comes the lava lamp. Up go the Jimi Hendrix and ''Barbarella'' posters. And suddenly the twice-divorced, 40-ish John Henderson (Albert Brooks), who has insisted on moving into the house of his none-too-welcoming mother (Debbie Reynolds), is right back where he belongs. The same can happily be said for Mr. Brooks, whose humor thrives delightfully in this hothouse of Freudian confusion. He brings vast reserves of quarrelsome, hairsplitting hilarity to the story of a man going mano a mano with his sweet little mom.

title: T.W.A. Plans Cutbacks at Kennedy Hub
description: In an effort to stem losses from flights across the Atlantic, Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it would cut some routes and possibly hundreds of jobs at its hub at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Grace Mayer, Photography Curator, Dies at 95
description: Grace M. Mayer, a pioneering curator of photography who was instrumental in rediscovering the work of Jacob Riis and who built a major collection of prints and photographs for the Museum of the City of New York, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95.

title: Death and Taxes Joined By Computer Failure
description: THE failure of two computers in the same week should teach you something. You would also think I had learned the lesson long ago.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Christmas

title: Defense Is Knicks' Best Offense Down Stretch
description: It was fourth-quarter defense, the old-fashioned Knicks way.

title: Peace Signs (and Other Kinds): Watching Hippies Self-Destruct
description: After watching ''Message to Love: The Isle of Wight Festival,'' Murray Lerner's two-hour-plus documentary of one of the last great outdoor rock events, you may never again want to see another long-haired, glazed-eyed teen-ager flashing a peace sign and mouthing grandiose hippie platitudes.

title: Tokyo Stocks Off Sharply
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 528.75 points, or 2.69 percent, at 19,161.71. On Monday, the market was closed in observance of the Emperor's birthday.

title: Oil and Natural Gas Decline On Warmer Forecast for U.S.
description: Natural gas and oil prices retreated yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as forecasts for milder weather across much of the United States signaled that demand would be lower than originally expected.

title: As Key Allies of Gun Lobby Lose, Questions Arise About Its Power
description: Is the National Rifle Association, long imbued with the power to propel or shatter political careers like so many clay pigeons, starting to lose its aim?

title: Netanyahu's 'Realism' Is Destroying the Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: For G.I.'s, More Time Away From Home Fires
description: A year ago on Tuesday, Sgt. Steven Strait of Charlie Company led his platoon into Bosnia, celebrating Christmas in the mud while his wife back home at the American base here assembled a toy cash register for their youngest child. It was a time of uncertainty and fear of what the next year would bring them both.

title: Timing of holidays may mean more days of crowded flying.
description: MOST holiday travelers have already arrived at their destinations by today, but for many that is only half the battle. Although travelers have a break this year, with Christmas and New Year's falling in midweek -- giving some people as many as four travel days before returning to work -- airplane ''load factors,'' or occupancy rates, have been in the 80 percent range for a week. And planes and airports will continue to be crowded for much of the next two weeks.

title: From a Solo Turn on Piano, A Night of Jazz and 'Peanuts'
description: ''Rural folk piano'' is the description George Winston gives his music. The phrase was included in the program notes to his solo ''Winter Show'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night, and it raises red flags; the designation ''folk'' usually says more about who's doing the naming than what's being named. A ''folk'' version of anything connotes a grain, a tradition of memory, an individual style within a regional language.

title: G.M. Charges Schott
description: General Motors has accused MARGE SCHOTT, the Cincinnati Reds' owner, of falsifying car sales at her Chevrolet-Geo dealership.

title: Ethics Panel Pulled Punch on Gingrich 'Charity'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Daughter Is Fearful For Captive In Nigeria
description: At age 25, Wura Abiola wants to concentrate on her career in business management. But for more than two years, she has been haunted by the silence in Nigeria surrounding the fate of her father, Chief Moshood K. O. Abiola, who by most impartial accounts won a presidential election in Nigeria in June 1993 and was sent to jail a year later when he tried to claim the office.

title: 3 Strategies to Help Families in the U.S.
description: What would be needed to assure adequate, center-based care for all the families that wanted it?

title: Discipline, Not Reward
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance in Review
description: Mysterious Rituals And Bouncy Energy

title: Classy Lyrics
description: To the Editor:

title: CULBRO TO SELL $120 MILLION IN GENERAL CIGAR SHARES
description: The Culbro Corporation said yesterday that it would sell as much as $120.8 million of stock in its General Cigar subsidiary in a public offering, probably in February, as it combines its cigar holdings into a single company. The company, which makes Partagas and Macanudo cigars, also said it had bought Villazon & Company and its Honduran affiliate for $89 million, giving General Cigar the Punch and Hoyo de Monterrey cigar brands. Following the stock sale, which was disclosed in an S.E.C. filing, Culbro said it intended to spin off its nontobacco businesses, which include a nursery operation, some New England real estate and other holdings, to shareholders.

title: Personal Health
description: AMERICANS, having failed to lose weight in the fat-free-food era, are flocking back to a century-old regimen that has failed them repeatedly in the past: the high-protein, high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet currently advocated by Robert Atkins, Barry Sears and others who assert that it is carbohydrates, not fats, that are making people in this country fat.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 26 about the trial of 13 people identified as leaders or members of an organization called la Eme, or the Mexican mafia, referred incorrectly to the defendants' use of headphones. The defendants speak English and require no translations. They listen to music when the defense lawyers move to the sidebar to discuss legal issues with the judge. A member of the defense team reported the error in a letter on Dec. 1; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: A Pennsylvania township's tax abatement program persuades a company to stay.
description: THE General Instrument Corporation is building a $65 million corporate campus in this township, about 20 miles north of downtown Philadelphia, taking advantage of a tax abatement program that helped persuade the company to consolidate a divisional headquarters here.

title: U.S. Says Serb President Incited Protesters
description: Intensifying its criticism of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, the United States today accused him of organizing and inciting protesters who battled in the streets of Belgrade with demonstrators protesting against his Government.

title: Whose Lingerie Is It? A New Mideast Secret
description: Amid piles of panties headed for a Victoria's Secret near you, the veiled Palestinian women who stitch them together here say they now know that their workplace is not an Israeli factory.

title: French Trade Surplus Posted Record in October
description: The French Government said yesterday that the October trade surplus posted a record high, and a December industry survey by the national statistics office showed continued improvement in the production outlook.

title: New Spago Adjusts To Local Appetites
description: Wolfgang Puck has brought his Spago restaurant concept to the nation's Second City. The new Spago -- one of five worldwide and located near some of Chicago's better restaurants, including Topolobampo, Gordon and Brasserie Jo -- is managed by Mr. Puck's younger brother, Klaus.

title: Chilean Utility Sale Nears
description: The Power Market Developments Corporation, a unit of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, has agreed to pay $106 million for 25.6 percent of Empresas Emel S.A. of Chile. Emel owns more than 50 percent of a series of regional electricity distributors.

title: More Things in 'Hamlet' Than Are Dreamt Of In Other Adaptations
description: Kenneth Branagh's fine, robust performance as Hamlet is the bright centerpiece of his lavish new version of the play. Heading a cast so stellar that majestic Blenheim Palace plays the role of Elsinore, Mr. Branagh holds court throughout a four-hour, 70-millimeter sumptuously appointed production that doesn't often lag. This ''Hamlet,'' like Mr. Branagh's version of ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' takes a frank, try-anything approach to sustaining its entertainment value, but its gambits are most often evidence of Mr. Branagh's solid showmanship. His own performance is the best evidence of all.

title: Giants Are Quick to Line Up Coaching Candidates
description: Giants General Manager George Young said he was not going to waste any time searching for a head coach to replace Dan Reeves. He wasn't kidding. About 15 minutes after Monday's news conference to announce the firing of Reeves, Young called the Arizona owner, Bill Bidwill, to seek permission to speak to Jim Fassel, the Cardinals' offensive coordinator.

title: French Expert Backs Idea Of Flight 800 Malfunction
description: The director of the French Government agency that investigates air disasters has said he agrees with American safety investigators that a mechanical problem probably led to the explosion of Trans World Airlines flight 800.

title: Player, Father Admit Sharpening Buckle
description: MIKE CITO, a former football player at an Albuquerque, N.M., school, admitted in court Monday that the chin-strap buckle on his helmet had been sharpened by his father to the extent that it slashed five opposing players during a game Oct. 12.

title: Change and Renewal in a Heartland City
description: The year is winding down now. The holidays are on everyone's mind. In downtown Canton at the Church of the Savior (President William McKinley's church), the Rev. William Harvey has delivered his sermon on keeping Christmas holy, draping the nativity scene on the altar with Christmas clearance ads to dramatize ''how we bury Christ in a wilderness of consumerism.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Food Notes
description: Jezebel on the Upper West Side

title: Today's Battle of Stalingrad: Trying to Collect a Paycheck
description: High above the idle smokestacks of this ailing industrial city looms a huge, haunting memorial to the million Russians who died in World War II defending the city, known then as Stalingrad. But their sacrifice is also kept alive in humbler ways.

title: Miracle of Manhattitlan: A Town Transformed
description: Over the years, hundreds of townspeople have boarded up their homes, leaving this village of cactus and adobe to seek new livelihoods in and around New York City.

title: The Work Awaiting Boris Yeltsin
description: Boris Yeltsin is on the mend, but the Russian economy looks as anemic as he did before quintuple bypass surgery in November. As the frail but recovering Russian President returned to work in the Kremlin on Monday, his Government disclosed that the Russian economy contracted by 6 percent in 1996, statistical confirmation of the serious problems that cripple Russia five years after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Mr. Yeltsin will need all the energy and forceful leadership he can muster to brake the decline.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: New Chairman Elected For Thai Airways
description: Shareholders of Thai Airways International P.L.C., Thailand's national carrier, yesterday elected the Ministry of Transport and Communications permanent secretary, Mahidol Chantrangkurn, as its new chairman. He replaces Air Chief Marshal Siripong Thongyai.

title: Reflections of Advocate for Education and Arts
description: Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who wrote the legislation creating national endowments for arts and humanities and who gave his name to Pell grants, the Federal college scholarships for needy students, is retiring in January after 36 years in the Senate.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: More Apology Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Lima Slum, No Support for Hostage Takers
description: Twelve miles and a universe away from Lima, where guerrillas have taken hostages in the stately residence of the Japanese Ambassador, Felicita Fuentes Torres picked through piles of garbage today for empty cans and bottles to resell.

title: So What if It's a Turkey? It's Ours. It's Family.
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulgaria, Once a Showcase, Is Now a Health Care Wasteland
description: At the most prestigious hospital here, the Queen Jovanna, where neurosurgeons have been performing intricate brain operations, the last supplies of medicine ran out two weeks ago. There have been no clean sheets for several days because the laundry cannot afford lubricants to oil the washing machines.

title: Bombing in South Africa Kills 3 and Wounds 50
description: Two bomb blasts ripped through a shopping area in a farming town at the heart of South Africa's wine country today, killing one adult and two children and wounding at least 50 other people.

title: Home Is Where the Soccer Ball Rolls
description: Revillino Jones did not want to play soccer in America because it made his heart ache for Trinidad. But his sweet island looks gave him away. On Jones's first day at high school in Manhattan three years ago, the new coach grabbed him in the hallway and ordered him to try out for the team. Within a minute of watching the 16-year-old move with the ball, the coach knew he had found one of those ''gentleman jewels'' from other lands who could help turn a perennial loser into a champion.

title: Knicks Get in Touch With Defensive Side
description: The Knicks have talked all season about playing solid defense. Lately, that talk has become reality.

title: Some Cure. Traffic Is Worse.
description: The new high-occupancy vehicle lane that opened on the New Jersey Turnpike earlier this month was supposed to ease congestion over a 26-mile route and shave up to 10 minutes off rush-hour commuting for buses and car poolers. But because the Turnpike Authority took one of the regular lanes along a 1.3-mile stretch of road to create the restricted lane, traffic there has actually grown worse, turnpike officials said yesterday.

title: A Good Quarter and Year for U.S. Banks
description: United States banks' fourth-quarter earnings are expected to rise as much as 14 percent from last year, as banks cruised to their fifth year of record profits on increased lending and new fee-based businesses.

title: Calenergy Bid For Utility Is Victorious
description: Calenergy Inc. of the United States claimed victory today in its $:923 million, or $1.55 billion, hostile takeover offer for Northern Electric P.L.C., a British regional electricity supplier.

title: Record Orange and Grapefruit Harvests Are Expected in Florida
description: Seven years after a two-day freeze over the Christmas weekend devastated the Florida citrus crop, growers in the state are expecting their biggest crop ever, in large part because trees planted after that freeze are maturing and bearing fruit.

title: Bid for Malaysia Unit Of Bank of Nova Scotia
description: Kumpulan Fima Bhd. said yesterday that it wanted to buy control of the Malaysian operations of the Bank of Nova Scotia. Kumpulan, which was set up by the Malaysian Government in 1972, has interests in real estate, bulk storage, food processing and stock brokering. It said it had received approval from Malaysia's central bank to negotiate the purchase of a 51 percent stake in the Bank of Nova Scotia Bhd. Kumpulan did not, however, say whether the talks had begun or how much it was prepared to pay.

title: Windfall Sets Off a Blizzard of Bonuses for a Company
description: The heartening tale of how the Kingston Technology Corporation is about to bestow $100 million in year-end bonuses upon its 523 employees must begin on this disheartening note: No, they are not hiring.

title: PRIDE PETROLEUM TO SELL SOME OPERATIONS
description: Pride Petroleum Services Inc. has agreed to sell its land-based well-servicing operations in the United States to Dawson Production Services Inc. for $136 million. News of the deal pushed Dawson's stock up 14 percent, or $1.875, to $15 yesterday. Pride's shares rose 11 percent, or $2.25 cents, to close at $22.25. Pride Petroleum, based in Houston, provides well services and contract drilling. Dawson, based in San Antonio, provides gas and oil well services. Pride Petroleum said the sale was expected to generate proceeds of about $90 million, before taxes. For the year ended Dec. 31, 1995, the operations had revenue of $113.1 million and earned $7 million.

title: Snow Making Delights Skiers but Alarms Conservationists
description: Hunter Mountain Ski Bowl began the season in November with the whir of machinery pumping water at 9,000 gallons a minute for its snow-making operation.

title: Caviar Becomes Endangered Delicacy
description: JUST as holiday party givers are ordering the caviar to go with their year-ending Champagne, the World Wildlife Fund is warning that pollution and overfishing have jeopardized the future of the sturgeon in the Caspian Sea, where 90 percent of the world's caviar supply comes from.

title: Year-Round Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: The Christmas Gift of a Festive Dinner
description: IT's hard to visualize John Loring in the kitchen, and in fact, he's rarely there. But Mr. Loring, the design director of Tiffany's, is a cook of some repute. What he won't do, under any circumstances, is whip up something for himself.

title: Executive Changes
description: ENGINEERED SECURITY SYSTEMS INC., Whippany, N.J., appointed David George president.

title: A Freeholder Resigns
description: Joseph C. Parlavecchio, an Essex County freeholder since 1981, resigned yesterday after admitting that he violated the Newark school district's conflict-of-interest rules by concealing his ownership of a school building that the district leased while he was a school principal.

title: Election Is 2 Years Away, But Californians Gear Up
description: As a measure of the prestige of leading the nation's biggest, richest and most politically powerful state, candidates and would-be candidates are already maneuvering for position in the 1998 race to succeed Pete Wilson as governor of California.

title: I.R.S. Considering Easier Rules on Some Mergers
description: The Internal Revenue Service has proposed easing rules governing some tax-free mergers and acquisitions. Tax specialists said that the change would not cause a wave of new mergers, but that it would make it easier to arrange tax-free deals, which save public and private companies millions of dollars in taxes.

title: Christmas in SoHo
description: I regard the holidays as a trial for the same reason most people do: Someone I loved is gone now, and every cliched ritual of the season, from department-store windows to New Year's toasts, conspires to remind me of my loss.

title: Bond Prices End Mixed in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday in an abbreviated Christmas Eve session that saw little movement following the latest report on stores sales.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial and commodity markets in the United States, and most markets overseas, are closed today in observance of Christmas. Government offices and banks are closed, too. Markets in the United States, and many markets abroad, will reopen tomorrow.

title: Charles Bowden, Broadway Producer, Dies at 83
description: Charles Bowden, a Broadway producer who presented ''The Night of the Iguana'' and other plays by Tennessee Williams and had a long professional association with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Stuffing Corn Husks Instead of Stockings
description: THE masa, or corn flour mash, was the perfect consistency, turned to the texture of Play-Doh. Three sauces sat in bowls and blenders, ready to douse whatever needed dousing. And the corn husks, once sturdy and dry, were now appropriately softened in tin trays of water. The tamalada was ready to begin.

title: Lighting the Freedom Tree
description: Christmas trees and radi cal politics the two would seem to make improbable bedfellows. Yet proponents of two of the most divisive political movements of the mid-19th century -- those to abolish slavery and to end corporal punishment of children -- used the holiday and its symbols to further their causes. In the process, they helped shape the way Americans have celebrated Christmas ever since.

title: Child-Labor Issue Ignites a Multifaceted Youthful Crusade
description: In a skit put on by her fourth-grade class, Chloe Callahan-Flintoft played a shopper at a Disney Store who tells a surprised salesman, ''When I heard Disney was using unfair labor to make its products, I was sad because I buy a lot of their stuff.''

title: Brooklyn Trees to Be Felled To Destroy Invading Beetles
description: The whine of chain saws and wood chippers will soon fill the air in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, as hundreds of trees are cut down in the hope of eradicating a beetle that could ruin many woodlands in the Northeast if left unchecked.

title: No Garlic Benefits Seen in Heart Trial
description: THE suggestion that garlic has protective effects against heart disease has been challenged by a study in England that found that a powdered form of the clove was no better than a dummy pill in lowering cholesterol and fats in the blood.

title: Making Do With Less While Working Oneself Off the Welfare Rolls
description: Five nights a week, from midnight to 4 A.M., Diana Boyde earns $8 an hour loading boxes onto United Parcel Service trucks. Some of those boxes, she reckons, contain other people's Christmas presents.

title: Any Peace On Earth For Families At the Feast?
description: IT looked like the perfect holiday feast. The turkey was glazed to a golden brown, the dinner candles were lighted, the china was gleaming. Eighteen relatives were seated in Susan Spector's oak-furnished dining room -- when her son eyed his aunt's new boyfriend skeptically.

title: Duly Neglected but Still Fascinating
description: PEARL S. BUCK

title: Wine Talk
description: THE greeting card business has become a niche business. Even at Christmas, more and more cards are tailored for specific types: a great dad, a former wife, a favorite airedale, and so on.

title: Democrats Discover The Corporate Side
description: To the dismay of traditional Democratic allies like labor, business interests have been gaining influence with Democrats, a phenomenon that goes hand in hand with an increase in corporate donations to the party.

title: Middle Ground on Ethics
description: The Republican view of the ethics case against Speaker Newt Gingrich is that he merely violated an obscure portion of the tax code and inadvertently provided the House ethics committee with less than a complete account of the situation because he was so busy with more important matters like leading the Republican Revolution.

title: No Headline
description: ''We should be supporting them, and instead we are living off them. It is horribly shameful.''

title: Making Gulf Oysters Safer
description: SOME raw oysters have just been made safer. A new process reduces harmful pathogens to undetectable levels. These include potentially deadly Vibrio vulnificus, a toxin that is unrelated to pollution and that tends to occur in oysters from warm water, like the Gulf of Mexico. California, Florida and Louisiana require oysters from the gulf to have warning labels; some Manhattan restaurants refuse to serve them.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S., to Protect Patients, Will Curb Doctors' Bonuses

title: When Therapy Wags Its Tail
description: GLADYS SANTAROSA is in the hallway, waiting for her date with Destiny. Not for her long-anticipated ride home from St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, where she has been a patient for 13 days. She's also waiting for that. But Destiny comes first.

title: Wallace Breaks Thumb
description: Portland forward RASHEED WALLACE will undergo surgery tomorrow for a broken left thumb and will be out indefinitely.

title: 'Hansel and Gretel,' Light on the Fright
description: A television adaptation of ''Hansel and Gretel'' that was faithful to the version by the Brothers Grimm would never slip past the ratings police. To begin with, the story presents two horrific mother figures: an abusive stepmother who persuades her henpecked husband to abandon his children in the forest, and a cannibalistic witch who lures young children to her candied house.

title: Looking for Narnia
description: Anyone depressed or disgusted with life in Britain can vanish this holiday season into Yuletide past, celebrating a Victorian Christmas in a Victorian tartan nightshirt or the reproduction of a full-length Victorian nightgown. Most of these items are available at Past Times, a chain of shops that has sprouted almost overnight in 60 British cities.

title: Where Every Dancer Could Have His Day
description: Dancing was the point at Son De La Loma's show on Monday at S.O.B.'s. There wasn't that much of a crowd, and for once the dancers outnumbered the listeners, taking over the floor. And showing off steps -- everybody was watching the competition -- the dancers helped the band raise the level of intensity in the room.

title: Housing Sales Show New Life With Good Year
description: From the ashes of the late 1980's and early 1990's, the nation's residential real estate market is rising again. But don't count on another year as good as this one.

title: COMMERCE SECURITY TO BUY ELDORADO BANCORP
description: Commerce Security Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Eldorado Bancorp for $90 million in cash in a deal that will combine two banking chains in Orange County, Calif. The purchase values Eldorado at $23 a share, or a 13 percent premium on yesterday's closing price of $20.375. Eldorado, which is based in Tustin, Calif., had assets of about $390 million as of Sept. 30, while Commerce Security, which is based in Huntington Beach, Calif., had assets of $440 million. The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter of 1997, but is contingent on approval from regulators and Eldorado shareholders.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Kittles Keeps Quiet. Jordan Is Impressed.
description: The words were popping out of his mouth like candy from a Pez dispenser, a foul remark here, a prickly comment there. Allen Iverson was having his say, no matter who was on the court with him Saturday night, the Philadelphia rookie apparently unconcerned with what Michael Jordan thought of him.

title: An East River Expedition Just Before Christmas
description: The moon hung full above the Brooklyn waterfront, adding its silvery winter light to the reflected sparkling of the holiday skyline. And here and there, in eddies and backwaters, along the edges of fast-running rips and under the dock lights that ring the harbor, striped bass, the last gift of the angling season, fed on schools of frantic spearing, drawn to those same lights.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: POMEROY COMPUTER RESOURCES INC., Hebron, Ky., a professional computer service company, said it had received two contracts valued at more than $43 million over the next 18 months to provide computer networking products and services to two unidentified companies.

title: Strong Exports Slash British Trade Deficit
description: Britain's trade deficit with the rest of the world narrowed sharply in October as exports were snapped up, the Government said yesterday.

title: The Older It Is, the Newer It Seems
description: The Christmas concert presented by the Ensemble for Early Music this week at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine pointed up an interesting paradox about the troubled state of the classical music world.

title: KCS ENERGY SHARES RISE AFTER TENNESSEE GAS SETTLEMENT
description: KCS Energy Inc. shares rose 26 percent after it said it had settled all litigation with the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company, which last month won a $143.2 million jury award against the company. Financial terms were not disclosed. KCS shares rose $7.875, to $37.625, in trading of more than 9 million shares. The agreement settles a dispute in which KCS was accused of mixing propane into gas that Tennessee Gas, a unit of Tenneco Inc., was forced to buy under 17-year contracts.

title: 2 Die as Planes Collide Near San Diego Airport
description: Two men were killed and two were injured when the small planes they were flying collided over a retail, recreational and residential area around noon today.

title: A Former Role Model Has Developed a Limp
description: Maybe it's contagious. Maybe it's women's tennis that's burning out, and not just those teen tykes who play it. Or maybe the game's just suffering from a short-term case of shooting-star syndrome.

title: Pan-Asian Flavors To Perk Up Fish
description: It's easy to spot the regular diners at the Flying Fish Restaurant, Bar and Grill in Seattle. They're the ones diving into platters of Dungeness crabs, stir-fried in a wok with salt, black pepper and Sichuan pepper, ($11 a pound). The crabs come whole, and even diners in business suits end up licking their fingers.

title: For Manhattan Man, Rent Is Not in the Budget
description: Lamont McClam, a slight, 39-year-old man distinguished by a toothless, immensely winning grin, lives in a cardboard box at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street across from Trump Tower and the St. Regis Hotel.

title: South Korea to Cut Stock Supply in 1997
description: The South Korean Government will cut the amount of new stock sold next year by almost a third to help lift shares from 40-month lows, analysts said.

title: Spurs' Robinson Breaks His Foot
description: David Robinson balanced himself on crutches in the locker room and wondered about all that had gone wrong this season.

title: The Remaking of Eggnog, Popular Heavyweight Champ
description: IS there a place on today's postmodern Christmas table for eggnog? Decadent, possibly dangerous eggnog? Can eggnog be made safe for the world?

title: Bibi, Yasser & Bill
description: Israelis and Palestinians will soon finalize an accord for Israel's withdrawal from Hebron. Here's the talk President Clinton needs to have with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat after the Hebron agreement is signed.

title: INSIDE
description: View From Peru's Slums

title: Henry Henley, 75, Is Dead; Chief of Arrow Shirt's Maker
description: Henry H. Henley Jr., who as chairman and chief executive of the company that made the coveted Arrow shirt successfully steered it through the mergers and upheavals in the apparel industry in the 1980's, died yesterday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla., near West Palm Beach. He was 75.

title: U.S. PLACES LIMITS ON H.M.O. BONUSES FOR COST CUTTERS
description: The Federal Government has adopted a new policy limiting the types of bonuses that can be paid to doctors as a reward for controlling the cost of services for Medicare and Medicaid patients.

title: In Harlem, Concern Over Campaign for Borough President
description: For the last few weeks, Democrats throughout New York City have speculated on the array of candidates and potential entrants in next year's mayoral race. But in Harlem, where politics has always been more than a little lively, that race is generating nowhere near the level of passion of the campaign for Manhattan borough president.

title: Nikko to Rescue Lending Units
description: The Nikko Securities Company said today that it would inject 147.5 billion yen, or $1.3 billion, into three companies to write off bad loans and would record a net loss for the fiscal year.

title: Connecticut Man Finds E-Mail 'Date' Isn't a Girl, Isn't 13 and Has a Badge
description: A Connecticut man who investigators say propositioned a 13-year-old girl for sex over the Internet was arrested in Brooklyn on Monday as he headed to a seaside rendezvous with the girl, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Vinnie Ernst, 54, Record-Setter For Providence Basketball Team
description: Vinnie Ernst, a record-setting point guard for Providence College in the early 1960's, died on Sunday night. He was 54.

title: Man Shot Upon Return From Shopping Trip
description: A 35-year-old man returning from last-minute Christmas shopping with his wife and two teen-age children was shot in the back and the face last night outside the family's Staten Island town house, the police said.

title: Stocks Recover A Bit in Japan
description: Stocks rebounded here today, following a session on Tuesday during which they fell to their lowest levels in more than a year.

title: Madonna, Chic Pop Star, As Chic Political Star
description: In ''Evita,'' her most colossal music video, Madonna postures resplendently through the role of a pop goddess with a nation's worth of adoring fans. The basis for this spectacle is the rise of Juan Peron's fascist dictatorship in Argentina, which was not always an occasion for song and dance. But harsh reality is not permitted to interfere with this fashion show.

title: Teachers as Bullies: Norwegian's Study Finds 'Dirty Secret'
description: KATIE H. was only a second-grader when she learned a very troubling lesson. Bright and creative, she was not especially neat and tidy, and her teacher felt she had to ''stay on her back all the time.'' Because her school in Methuen, Mass., had no lunch facilities, the children ate lunch at their desks.

title: Coming of Age in 'The Nutcracker'
description: Alexandra Ansanelli: The name may not ring a bell but Peter Martins, artistic director of the New York City Ballet, gave the public a marvelous holiday surprise when he cast Ms. Ansanelli, a true prodigy, in a major debut.

title: Some Saying 'No' Sooner To Their Early Applicants
description: Some highly selective colleges and universities like those in the Ivy League that have been swamped with early applicants say they are rejecting more students outright so that the students can have a clearer picture of where they stand.

title: Salinas Denies Being Told His Brother Might Have Drug Ties
description: Former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has denied allegations that a high-ranking Mexican police commander advised him while in office of his brother Raul's possible links to drug traffickers.

title: Of Nutcrackers and Sugarplums
description: IN Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker,'' Drosselmeier is the character whose wizardry creates amazing, sometimes terrifying transformations.

title: Cup Qualifying Starts in March
description: The United States national soccer team will open its final World Cup qualifying on March 2 at Jamaica.

title: Theater in Review
description: It Could Be a One-Man Show,

title: Parents Most in Need May Have the Least Access
description: It's 10 A.M., and the parents of some 90 infants, toddlers and preschoolers in this white-collar suburb about an hour's drive southwest of Manhattan know exactly where their children are.

title: Dance in Review
description: A Dancer Who Evokes The Sculptural and Spiritual

title: F.C.C. Clears The Standard For Digital TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously today to approve the standard for the next generation of television, formally beginning the nation's transition to digital, high-definition television, the first fundamental change in television service in almost 50 years.

title: Officials, Polite but Grim, Look for Answers at Site of Texas Explosion
description: Even as well-paying factory jobs evaporated from cities in the nation's rust belt, Houston's suburbs have remained, for the most part, a working man's paradise.

title: Walter H. Weintz, 81, Pioneer in Direct Mail
description: Walter H. Weintz, a pioneer of direct mail advertising, died on Saturday in the Laurelwood nursing home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 81 and lived in Norwalk, Conn., with his wife of 60 years, the former Helen Bennett.

title: Amid New Wealth of Trade, A Humanizing Movement
description: Freeing international trade has been the flavor of the closing months of 1996. President Clinton successfully pressed his campaign for zero tariffs on Information Age technology, first at the meeting of Asian and Pacific leaders in Manila late last month, and then at the meeting of the World Trade Organization in Singapore two weeks ago.

title: Christmas in New York: A Secret Santa and a Dashing Angel
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LINDA WEIL was walking up Park Avenue with a 6-year-old and the child's mother. As they passed a dog walker with a number of four-legged charges, the little girl exclaimed, ''Look, Mom, another bouquet of dogs!''

title: America's Endangered Honeybees
description: The American wild honeybee virtually died out last winter and, in some states, 80 percent of commercial honeybee colonies died out as well. Gardeners accustomed to the familiar buzz heard instead the sound of silence. With no bees to bring pollen from plant to plant, gardeners raised fewer apples, cucumbers and zucchini, and what did grow was puny. As cold weather bears down again, bees are once again endangered. The American honeybee faces the worst threat in its history, one with potential consequences for the one-third of the national diet that relies, directly or indirectly, on honeybees for pollination.

title: A Sad Parade To Paradise In the Bronx
description: THE door to Chago's wooden shack, a tumbledown place where he sometimes slept, was slightly ajar. A candle flickered inside, illuminating the cramped space with slow-motion flares that glowed, then faded. Outside, the family garden plots lay in hibernation, awaiting next year with its promise of fragrant blossoms and fat tomatoes.

title: Devils (Reluctantly) Take a Breather
description: At the two-day break before Christmas last season, the Devils were three games below .500 and needed some time off. This season, at eight games above .500, they need anything but two days off to think about how well they are doing.

title: Algerian Islamic Group Threatens France Unless It Halts Aid
