description: The French Government said today that it had received a letter from Islamic guerrillas waging war against the Government in Algeria that threatened, the French radio said, to ''destroy'' France unless it halted all aid to its former colony and freed fundamentalist prisoners.

title: TRO LEARNING'S 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS PLUMMETED
description: TRO Learning Inc. stock tumbled 39 percent after the educational software maker said accounting issues dragged its fourth-quarter earnings way below Wall Street's expectations. TRO, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., said Monday that it earned $2.3 million, or 34 cents a share, in its fourth quarter, down sharply from the $4.4 million, or 71 cents a share, in the 1995 quarter. Analysts expected the company to earn $1.04. TRO Learning also announced that the company had not met the accounting requirements necessary to recognize revenue from a ''significant portion'' of new business signed in the fourth quarter ended in October. TRO stock closed down $6.75 at $10.50 a share on volume of more than 18 million shares.

title: Pakistan's Corruption Drive Falters, Creating Political Openings
description: Six weeks after Pakistan's President dismissed the Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, the caretaker administration appointed to root out corruption has acknowledged that the effort has been largely unavailing.

title: Huntsman to Buy Texaco Chemical Plant
description: The Huntsman Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy the last piece of Texaco Inc.'s chemical business, a Texas plant that makes gasoline additives and industrial foam, for $600 million.

title: Carroll Could Be Next To Leave the Confines Of 49er Coach Factory
description: Try as he might, Pete Carroll can't escape the talk about head coaching jobs. It's that time of the year in the National Football League, especially for successful assistants and especially for the defensive coordinator of the San Francisco 49ers.

title: China Shows New View On Mentally Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Fans Like Jordan, Hill
description: Chicago's MICHAEL JORDAN and Detroit's GRANT HILL, who have dominated the fan voting for the National Basketball Association All-Star game in recent years, are running 1-2 in balloting for this season's Eastern Conference team.

title: Suit Says New York Parking-Ticket System Is So Arbitrary It's Illegal
description: In the annals of constitutional law, many cases, indeed most cases, have greater weight and importance than All Aire Conditioning v. the City of New York.

title: $3 Million for Flood Control
description: Working against a Dec. 31 Federal deadline, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced Monday that the state will commit $3 million to a major flood control project along 3.3 miles of the Ramapo River.

title: Christmas
description: NEW YORK

title: Eileen Donovan, 81, Former Ambassador
description: Eileen R. Donovan, the United States Ambassador to Barbados from 1969 to 1974, died on Thursday in Spring Hill, Fla. She was 81 and had lived in Clearwater, Fla.

title: Holiday Retail Refrain: Better Than '95 but Not Good Enough
description: For retailers, the Christmas selling season produced a script with more twists and turns than the film ''The English Patient.'' Shoppers laughed: Merchants were forced to slash prices in the last week. And they cried: Many were unable to buy certain items that had been sold out since Thanksgiving.

title: Democrats Agree to Unite
description: Hoping to avoid a divisive and expensive gubernatorial primary, New Jersey's Democratic leaders have agreed to throw their support behind the first candidate who clearly appears headed for a June victory. Sixteen county chairmen who attended a Dec. 12 meeting supported a proposal by the state chairman, B. Thomas Byrne Jr., to poll the chairmen after the candidates are interviewed, Mr. Byrne said this week. The weight of a chairman's vote would be based on his county's turnout in the 1996 Democratic primary.

title: Wyser-Pratte Invests In 2 French Businesses
description: Wyser-Pratte & Company has taken a more than 5 percent stake in Cerus S.A., Carlo de Benedetti's French holding company, and in the insurer La France S.A., the French stock exchange authority said.

title: Imprisoned in a Life Without Love
description: ''Thieves'' (''Les Voleurs'') was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review of the film, shown at the festival under the title ''Les Voleurs'' (''Thieves''), which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 5. The film opens today at area theaters.

title: GEMSTAR TO BUY STARSIGHT IN STOCK SWAP
description: Gemstar International Group Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy Starsight Telecast Inc., another maker of television programming aids for videocassette recorders, in a stock swap valued at $273 million, or $10.23 a share. The companies also suspended their lawsuits against each other for programming technology patents, pending completion of the merger. Holders of 52 percent of Starsight's shares have approved the merger. Starsight shareholders will own about 33 percent of the combined companies, and three Starsight representatives will sit on a 10-member board. Gemstar said it would exchange 0.6062 share for each Starsight share. The transaction values Starsight at $10.23 a share based on yesterday's closing price for Gemstar. Starsight shares rose 50 cents, to close at $9.50, and Gemstar fell 37.5 cents, to $16.50 on the Nasdaq exchange.

title: Democratic Finesse
description: To the Editor:

title: Sorkin Leaving Nomura After 19 Months
description: Nomura Securities International said yesterday that Ira Lee Sorkin, who had joined the firm 19 months ago in a new position, chief legal officer, as Nomura moved into volatile businesses, was resigning.

title: No American Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: State Disbars a Lawyer
description: A lawyer charged recently with stealing more than $1 million from his clients has been permanently disbarred by the State Office of Attorney Ethics, Ocean County prosecutors said yesterday. The lawyer, Joseph A. Privetera, 62, has admitted the thefts and is working with prosecutors on a plea bargain, according to Daniel J. Carluccio, the Ocean County Prosecutor.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Recruiting

title: Administration Rejects Black English as a Second Language
description: Joining a rising chorus of criticism, the Clinton Administration today formally rejected the idea that black English, or Ebonics, is a distinct language, saying that programs based on it were ineligible for Federal support as bilingual education.

title: Business Gains With Democrats
description: Last year George Kourpias, leader of the machinists union, used the opportunity of a Labor Day celebration to talk to President Clinton about one of his union's major concerns.

title: Eating Well
description: OVER the years, readers keep raising the same questions about recipes in this column and the Plain and Simple column. And once or twice a year, I answer those that seem to be of general interest.

title: Malakhov Out 6 Weeks
description: The Montreal Canadiens said defenseman VLADIMIR MALAKHOV would be out at least six weeks after breaking his right thumb during a fight in Monday's 6-0 loss to the Ottawa Senators. Malakhov is Montreal's top-scoring defenseman this season with 3 goals and 15 assists. (Bloomberg)

title: Fraschilla Will Meet Old Friends At Garden
description: Fran Fraschilla insists there will be no sentimental feelings flowing through his body tomorrow night when St. John's meets the team he formerly coached, the Manhattan Jaspers, in the first round of the E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

title: For Holiday Leftovers, Noodles to the Rescue
description: The idea for this dish came from a recipe for pizzocheri, the Italian buckwheat pasta, with vegetables.

title: The Case Of Hodges Vs. the N.B.A.
description: ON this day especially, the notions of free speech and fair play and tolerance toward others have been historically esteemed, or at least been paid lip service.

title: She's Back, Still Coping, Still Crying

Wannabe movers and shakers pine for the days when Cabinet officers and captains of industry could not get through the day without advice from a dismal scientist. Undergraduates who once majored in economics as a stepping stone to riches at Goldman, Sachs are turning to math. Even The New Yorker has piled on, concluding in an article that economists need to be cut down a peg by abolishing their Nobel Prize.

title: Food Stamps for the Unemployed
description: The new Federal welfare law ends the guarantee that all poor people will be fed and threatens to deprive some one million poor people of the food stamps that help them survive. The law prohibits able-bodied, childless adults between the ages of 18 and 50 from collecting food stamps for more than three months in any three-year period unless they work at least 20 hours a week. There is no exemption for recipients who look for but can not find work. They are left to shift for themselves without food assistance. Their only hope lies in the fact that the law invites states to seek waivers for recipients who live in areas with high unemployment.

title: Resilience of the Blues, and the Singer

She now uses a wheelchair, having survived both a stroke and the amputation of both legs after complications from diabetes. Yet when she performed at the 92d Street Y on Monday night, she was feisty, funny and soulful, singing with gospel-charged fervor. Her hits from the 1950's and 60's testified to an unquenchable life force, still amused and delighted by the power of desire.

Last January, a ''Dateline'' crew covered a dozen births at University Hospital in Newark with a view to answering the question, where did all the fathers go? Eleven of the 12 babies were born to single mothers, 5 of them under age 18. Eight fathers were unemployed, and four were no-shows at the big moment. Six had children by more than one woman.

For home games, fans squeeze into fold-out wooden benches under a plethora of red-and-gold city championship banners, six for league and city honors in basketball.

She said that the state was spending more on health care for each inmate than for each state employee. So, in April, she dismissed the prisons' doctors and nurses and hired a private company to deliver managed care for the state's 26,000 inmates at an estimated savings of $14 million in the first year.

When she read Jerry Seinfeld, she thought Australia, not just America. And after she breezed through a manuscript about an Iowa housewife smitten by a passing photographer, she guessed Hollywood and guessed right.

Under the deal, expected to close in the spring, Commerce would pay $23 a share for all of Eldorado's 3.9 million shares outstanding. The acquisition would create a company with $850 million in assets. Shares of Eldorado closed at $22.25 yesterday, up $1.875.

title: Holidays Hinder Blood Drives

Officials at the New Jersey Blood Services in New Brunswick fear a shortage this holiday season because Christmas and New Year's Day fall in the middle of the week, hindering blood drives. A blood drive in Elizabeth yesterday collected only about half of the 30 to 35 pints received on an ordinary fourth Thursday of the month, a Red Cross official said.

The settlement ends long-running litigation between Tennessee Gas, a unit of El Paso Energy Corporation, and Tesoro over the so-called take-or-pay contract, which was to expire in January 1999. The settlement is equal to the amount Tesoro estimated it would receive in August, after Tennessee Gas lost a Texas Supreme Court decision over the disputed contract. title: Prying Open the Phone Market

That law called on the Federal Communications Commission to write rules that would allow long distance carriers and others to provide service to local phone customers who, until now, have been captive customers of the Bell companies. title: Japan's Output Drops 1.9 Percent in November
description: Japan's industrial production declined in November from October, the third time in six months that output had fallen, as production by auto and electronics makers slackened. Still, those same companies forecast that output would rise in the next few months as consumers buy big-ticket items like cars before the 2-percentage-point rise in the consumption tax on April 1, the Government said.

description: When it comes to undertaking what most sports photographers would consider technically or tactically impossible to show athletes doing what they do best, Heinz Kluetmeier's typical responses are ''I'll do it'' and ''Here it is.''

title: Henry James, Not Too Literally
description: One early poster for the film that represents this season's great meeting of the minds -- Henry James's richly perceptive ''Portrait of a Lady,'' as filtered through the acute feminist vision of Jane Campion, director of ''The Piano'' -- presents a disembodied torso in a ghostly white dress. A man's hand reaches across the corseted waist, insinuatingly ready to appropriate control or to violate the starched, forbidding costume buttoned straight up to this woman's neck.

title: Russian Shipping Line Ruled Bankrupt
description: The regional arbitration court in St. Petersburg, Russia, ruled yesterday that Baltic Shipping Lines was bankrupt and it appointed an outside manager for the troubled giant. The Baltic Shipping Lines is the only Russian naval company operating in the Baltic Sea. Baltic Shipping Lines employs about 11,000 and fully or partly owns 53 vessels as well as coastal production centers.

description: Hostage Freed in Peru

title: The Mayor's Housing Proposal
description: New York City loses about 15,000 apartments each year to abandonment, fire and creeping decrepitude -- while only 5,000 apartments are produced to replace them. Given the specter of continued population growth -- much of it fueled by impoverished immigrants -- the city must fight on several fronts to encourage new housing.

title: Natural Gas and Heating Oil Drop as Mild Weather Is Seen
description: Natural gas and heating oil prices slumped yesterday as forecasts for more mild weather across much of the United States signaled further lackluster demand.

title: Bonds Show Little Change On Slow Day
description: Treasury securities finished unchanged yesterday in quiet trading, with the European markets closed and many market participants electing to extend the Christmas holiday.

title: Sefton D. Temkin, 79, Judaic Scholar and Author
description: Sefton D. Temkin, an author and scholar of American Jewish history, died on Dec. 19 in his native Liverpool, England. He was 79 and a resident of Albany.

title: 27 Sickened by Toxic Leak
description: A spill of a chemical used in making plastic sent 12 warehouse workers, 15 firefighters and other emergency workers to hospitals yesterday with nose and lung irritation, headaches and nausea. The accident occurred at Select Cargo Services in Port Elizabeth when a forklift that was being used to move drums of ethyl methacrylate punctured three drums, causing about 75 gallons of the highly flammable liquid to spill, a company official said. The 27 people who breathed the fumes were treated and released, said Dr. Steven Marcus, medical director of the New Jersey Poison Control Center.

title: Today's Reviews
description: To accommodate added holiday movie reviews and advertising in Weekend, today's art, antiques and restaurant pages appear in section A, beginning on page 27. Home video and television are on pages B13-14.

title: Trying to Slice the National Pie and Mend Social Security, Too
description: For the last few years, the debate over the future of Social Security has been cast largely in terms of what should be done to prevent the system itself from running out of money after baby boomers start retiring early in the next century.

title: Five Are Named To a Hall of Fame
description: Five executives have been selected as the initial inductees into the Medical Advertising Hall of Fame.

description: Elf Atochem, the chemicals unit of the French oil group Elf Aquitaine, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the European adhesives and sealants operations of the British chemicals group Laporte P.L.C.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''People are happy when they eat meat,'' said my friend, looking around the room. Clearly, people were very happy at the new Brazilian restaurant Churrascaria Plataforma, although I'm not sure if it was the meat or the sheer quantity of food.

title: Canadian Hopes to Parlay 2 Theaters Into New Winner
description: While Times Square undergoes its sprucing up and re-energizing, some 190 tons of American theater history sits in wooden crates in a side-street warehouse, like pieces of a giant jigsaw puzzle waiting to be reassembled.

title: U.S. Radio Aiming At China 'Tyranny,' But Few Can Hear It
description: Three months ago, after a long debate in Congress, the United States started Radio Free Asia to ''confront tyranny'' in East Asia, in the words of its Congressional sponsors.

title: Paramount and Volvo In Cross-Promotion
description: Paramount Pictures and Volvo are teaming up for a worldwide cross-promotion for ''The Saint'' and the 1997 Volvo C70 coupe to appear in that film.

title: $25 and Under
description: In the 1960's, Milton Glaser and Jerome Snyder began an adventurous journey through the inexpensive restaurants of New York City. They wrote their reviews for The Herald Tribune and after that newspaper folded, for New York magazine. This summer I came across a collection of their old reviews called ''The Underground Gourmet,'' published 30 years ago by Simon & Schuster.

title: Montgomery Ward Selects New Leader; Creditors Wary
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation, the troubled Chicago-based retailer, named Roger Goddu, formerly with Toys ''R'' Us, as chairman and chief executive of its retail operations yesterday, replacing Bernard F. Brennan, who stepped down in October. Mr. Brennan, who owns roughly a 35 percent stake in the Chicago-based company, will remain chairman of the holding company.

description: Here are choices by the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times of New Year's Eve celebrations that were not sold out at press time. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: It's Just Like Old Times For Camby
description: Marcus Camby would repeatedly crash to the court for John Calipari, even if it was only a college practice drill. It did not matter. When a loose ball would bound before him, Camby would dive and roll his 6-foot-11-inch frame over and over on the court, as if he were on a spit.

title: United Overseas Bank Merges Malaysian Units
description: United Overseas Bank Ltd., one of Singapore's four big banks, said yesterday that it would merge its two subsidiaries in Malaysia. The bank said it planned to consolidate Chung Khiaw Bank (Malaysia) and United Overseas Bank Malaysia, creating Malaysia's 11th-largest bank with assets of 10.3 billion ringgit ($4.1 billion).

title: From a Stone, Magic: A Medium That Set The Pace in Prints
description: The 200th anniversary of Alois Senefelder's invention of lithography has not slipped by unnoticed, thanks to the New York Public Library. From its own voluminous collections, it has produced a show of no fewer than 200 early examples of this once-revolutionary print medium.

title: Public, but Independent, Schools Are Inspiring Hope and Hostility
description: In one decrepit Jersey City neighborhood, where broken drug vials crunch underfoot and the odor of burnt buildings lingers after every rainfall, community organizers say converting the chaotic elementary school to a public school run by parents, not the local school board, will reverse years of stunted learning.

title: 2 Priests Robbed by Gunmen At St. Patrick's Parish House
description: Two priests returning from Christmas dinner were robbed at gunpoint inside the parish house of St. Patrick's Cathedral on Wednesday night, the police said yesterday.

title: Whitman Selects Labor Chief
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday nominated a labor lawyer who served under Gov. Jim Florio to replace Labor Commissioner Peter J. Calderone, whom she asked to resign over a dispute earlier this month. The nominee, Melvin L. Gelade, 53, of Edison, was Governor Florio's director of employee relations and is a registered Democrat. He will work as acting commissioner pending his confirmation by the State Senate, said Jayne Rebovich, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Whitman.

title: Partners in Creation And Entertainment
description: THE Swiss artists Peter Fischli and David Weiss are among the merry pranksters of contemporary art. For proof, there's their small, capricious, often entertaining survey at the Institute of Contemporary Art here. Organized by the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, this exhibition romps through 17 years of Fischli and Weiss's sweetly irreverent sculpture, photography, video and film with little regard for sound museological procedure.

title: UConn-UMass Renewal Arrives Minus the Luster
description: In many ways, the University of Connecticut and the University of Massachusetts have been two of a kind. They are New England land-grant colleges with spacious rural campuses an hour and a half from each other. In the days when their men's basketball teams generally played modest regional schedules, they met 98 times, starting in 1904.

title: Don't Just Blame; Melt
description: To the Editor:

title: Guerrillas in Peru Release One of Six Hostage Envoys
description: Hours after a mysterious explosion rocked the besieged Japanese Ambassador's residence early today, the Marxist rebels holding more than 100 hostages released one of six captive senior diplomats, the Ambassador of Guatemala.

title: Sale of Brazilian Bank Is Blocked Again
description: The state government of Rio de Janeiro halted the planned sale yesterday of the state-controlled Banco do Estado do Rio de Janeiro S.A., officials said. The bank, known as Banerj, was to be sold for a minimum 436.7 million reals ($421.5 million).

title: Takeover in Lima Imperils the Campaign to Free American Woman
description: The takeover of the residence of Japan's Ambassador in Lima now looms as the biggest setback in the campaign to win the release of a New York woman serving a life sentence in a mountaintop maximum security prison in Peru.

title: A Founder of Japan's Opposition Bolts Party
description: Japan's main opposition party crumbled a bit more today when one of its founding members bolted to form a new party.

title: Home Video
description: Glimpses of the Music World

title: Rice Is Named Top Defensive Rookie
description: Arizona Cardinals defensive end SIMEON RICE, who tied the N.F.L. rookie record of 12 1/2 sacks set by San Diego's LESLIE O'NEAL 10 years ago, was named defensive rookie of the year yesterday. He is the first Cardinal player to win the award.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Peter W. Eccles, an international investment banker who had worked for Citicorp, misattributed a comment about the currency swap, a strategy he devised. The comment--that the swap was ''simple in name and principle but arcane and complex in execution''--was made by Phillip L. Zweig in his 1995 biography of Walter Wriston, a former chief executive of Citicorp, not by Mr. Wriston.

title: New Careers for Dancers, as the Body Begins to Know Its Years
description: Cynthia Gregory felt as if she had been traveling along a superhighway for most of her life when she sought help a few years ago from the Career Transitions for Dancers program of the Actors Fund of America. Ms. Gregory, who became the prima ballerina of American Ballet Theater, had started studying ballet at the age of 5. She began performing 10 years later, completing high school by correspondence, and danced professionally for three decades. ''I knew where I was going,'' Ms. Gregory said. Now, she found, she was afraid of what came after retirement, of allowing herself the luxury of ''getting off onto this country road, stopping here and there.''

title: Fighting a 'Hidden Epidemic'
description: Even without counting AIDS or H.I.V. infections, the United States has a higher rate of sexually transmitted diseases than any other developed country. That is the finding of a distinguished panel of health-care experts assembled by the Institute of Medicine, a branch of the National Academy of Sciences. In a recent report, the panel recommends a national public education and awareness campaign to combat what it calls a ''hidden epidemic.''

title: Avalanche Has the Stars and the Votes
description: Three members of the Stanley Cup champion Colorado Avalanche -- goaltender PATRICK ROY, center JOE SAKIC and defenseman SANDIS OZOLINSH -- were voted to the starting unit for the National Hockey League's Western Conference All-Star team.

title: Herbert Sucoff, 58, Chamber Clarinetist
description: Herbert Sucoff, a founder and director of the Sea Cliff Chamber Players on Long Island, died on Dec. 17 at North Shore University Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 58 and lived in Sea Cliff.

title: DEMOCRATS HOPED TO RAISE $7 MILLION FROM ASIANS IN U.S.
description: A White House official and a leading fund-raiser for the Democratic National Committee helped devise a strategy to raise an unprecedented $7 million from Asian-Americans partly by offering rewards to the largest donors, including special access to the White House, the committee's records show.

title: 10 Years in Jail, Without Ever a Charge
description: No one in recent memory has been in Cook County Jail longer than Odell Sheppard. No one even comes close.

title: China Sentences Tibetan on a Fulbright to 18 Years for Spying
description: China announced today that it had sentenced a Tibetan music expert to 18 years in prison, saying he returned to his native land last year as a Fulbright scholar to conduct espionage under the guise of filming traditional music and dance.

title: EUROPEAN MONITOR TELLS SERB LEADER TO HONOR ELECTION
description: Serbia was told today to reinstate the rightful winners of elections that were overturned by the Government or face further international isolation. The warning, from an international mission, elicited an initial response from the Foreign Minister that was surprisingly conciliatory.

title: Italian Monopoly Fined For Abuse of Advantage
description: Telecom Italia S.p.A., Italy's monopoly phone service provider, must pay 4 billion lire ($2.6 million) in damages to a rival, Telsystem S.p.A., for abusing its monopoly position, an appeals court ruled yesterday in Milan.

description: Lilco Merger Talks

title: Black English: Problem Is in the Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers Who Fail
description: Failing schools suffer from various maladies, but the two most common in New York City are weak principals and poor teachers. It is a deadly combination. In many cases, the principal knows he has mediocre teachers but does nothing to improve their performance. In other cases, the principal uses guile to get the teachers transferred. But that only shifts the problem to another school.

title: With No Favorite in Sight, Wild Cards Can Hope
description: The National Football League playoffs kick off this weekend with the perception that there are no clear-cut Super Bowl favorites among the 12 teams. The teams that begin play in the wild-card round are hoping that perception is reality.

title: Who Is 'Buddhist Temple'? Campaign Donor, Democratic Files Say
description: Just as the 1992 Clinton victory produced its definitive shorthand marching order -- ''It's the economy, stupid!'' -- so has the 1996 Clinton victory now produced an explanation in the same ringing meter for its forced retreat from some questionable political fund raising:

title: Harry Rains, 87, Labor Relations Lawyer
description: Harry H. Rains, a New York labor relations lawyer who represented management in the private and public sectors for nearly five decades, died on Tuesday at his home in Fort Myers, Fla. A former resident of Lattingtown Harbor, L.I., he was 87.

title: Everyone's a Tourist
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about some of the year's television commercials referred incorrectly in some editions to the company that has run commercials featuring Speed Racer, the 1960's cartoon character. It is Volkswagen, not Nissan Motor.

title: Tug of Taboos: African Genital Rite vs. U.S. Law
description: Just six months after arriving here from a Somalian refugee camp, Ahmed Guled's family has eased into the American mainstream. His children attend the Pilgrim Elementary School. They spend afternoons with Power Ranger reruns. The baby girl toddles around in a Gap T-shirt and denim mini-skirt.

title: Avoiding Stock Deals Too Good to Be True
description: A lot of investors who were expecting sugarplums have ended up with lumps of coal this year, thanks to the efforts of stock promoters who promised ''the next Microsoft'' but delivered shares of some high-flying little outfit that turned out to be a fraud.

title: Chrysler Raises Some Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation, the first auto maker to offer rebates on its 1997 models, increased prices on the vehicles today by up to $200.

title: Morris Schapiro, 93, Banker Behind Major U.S. Mergers
description: Morris A. Schapiro, an investment banker whose Wall Street savvy enabled him to arrange the mergers of several of America's largest banks, died on Monday at his apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Netanyahu Continues Talks With Palestinians
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met today with Palestinian security officials and spoke by telephone with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, capping a week of talks on an Israeli Army withdrawal from most of Hebron, on the West Bank.

title: S.E.C. Pushing Broker Scrutiny
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is coaxing securities firms to intensify their focus on broker supervision after finding that they still are not doing enough to weed out problem brokers.

title: LEXINGTON CORPORATE PROPERTIES ACQUIRES THREE SITES
description: Lexington Corporate Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust, acquired three industrial properties for a combined $14.7 million, and said it planned to acquire another for $2.86 million in January. The company also postponed a previously announced purchase of three retail properties leased to Hechinger Inc. Lexington said two of the purchased properties, in Plymouth, Mich., and Oberlin, Ohio, were acquired for $11.3 million and leased to Johnson Controls Inc. The third, in Franklin, N.C., was acquired for about $3.4 million and leased to SKF USA Inc. In January, Lexington expects to buy property in Tuscaloosa, Ala., for $2.86 million.

title: Teachers in a L.I. School Take a Closer Look at an Education Company
description: When a company briefly took over the management of the public schools in Hartford, its most vocal opponent was the teachers' union.

title: Guess: It's Nutty but Not as Old as Most
description: The Doug Elkins Dance Company calls its new offering ''Fruitcake Follies.'' That's a good overall title for the program of three pieces that the troupe has been presenting over the holiday season at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: New Fight Over Stars And Bars
description: Pvt. James Andrew Jackson Coker of Company H, 39th Georgia Infantry, was twice wounded and twice captured by Union soldiers during the Civil War. But he survived, lived out his life on the family farm and died in 1874.

title: Let's Share the Cost of Quality Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: China Reports a Surge In Foreign Investment
description: China attracted $36.9 billion in foreign investment in the first 11 months of the year, the official China Daily reported yesterday, citing the Foreign Trade Ministry. China is expected to exceed $40 billion in foreign investment for the whole year, breaking last year's record of about $38 billion.

title: Gotti Is Moved to Prison Hospital For Treatment of Infected Jaw
description: John Gotti, the former head of the Gambino crime family who is serving a life sentence for murder and racketeering, has been transferred to a Federal prison hospital for treatment of an infected jaw, a lawyer for Mr. Gotti said yesterday.

title: Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas Working Out a Merger, Sources Say
description: The boards of Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company have scheduled a meeting for tomorrow to work out a merger in which Brooklyn Union would take over Lilco's operations, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: Third Trial in Fatal Holdup
description: When Marquis Kennon goes on trial Jan. 6 for felony murder in the attempted robbery of a Franklin Township jewelry store in March 1995, the proceedings are expected to differ markedly from the previous trials of two co-defendants, prosecutors said. In those trials, defense lawyers successfully argued that the store's owner, Jeffrey Wolf, had deliberately shot and killed his wife, Brenda, during the holdup. Neither jury could reach a verdict on the felony murder charge.

title: A Whistle, A Replay And the Rangers Chalk Up Another
description: Late in last night's game at Madison Square Garden, an errant stick accidentally, but forcefully, hit the right hand of Referee Kerry Fraser. He winced and needed immediate treatment in the first aid room, but he returned quickly after the numbness went away.

title: At Funeral, Family of a Slain Officer Mourns a Double Loss
description: The funeral of a slain police officer is always a tableau of pomp and grief, and 6-year-old Ariellesf encou Davis was surrounded by both.

title: JACOR GAINS ASSETS OF THREE RADIO STATIONS
description: Jacor Communications Inc. said yesterday that it agreed to exchange the assets of its WKRQ-FM radio station in Cincinnati for the assets of three Rochester radio stations owned by the American Radio Systems Corporation. Jacor said it would receive the assets of WHAM-AM, WHTK-AM and WVOR-FM, and an option to buy WNVE-FM, also of Rochester, which is owned by Great Lakes Wireless Talking Machine L.L.C. Jacor said the agreement would allow it to divest itself of WKRQ as ordered by the Federal Justice Department. In October, American Radio Systems ended a joint sales agreement with Great Lakes, under which American Radio had the right to sell and set prices for WNVE's advertising time. The Justice Department called the agreement an illegal restraint of trade.

title: NORDSTROM LOWERS FOURTH-QUARTER ESTIMATE
description: Nordstrom Inc. said it would report lower-than-expected earnings in its fourth quarter because of slow holiday sales. The announcement came after the close of trading. Nordstrom stock, which had fallen 50 cents to $37.50, dropped $2.50, to $35, in after-hours trading. The retail chain said that sales at stores open at least a year declined moderately during the holiday season from a year ago. It attributed the drop to a shopping season with five fewer days than last year. Nordstrom was expected to earn 79 cents a share for the quarter. It earned 67 cents a share in last year's fourth quarter.

title: Blaming Holidays, Nordstrom Cuts Profit Forecast
description: Nordstrom Inc. said late yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall below Wall Street analysts' expectations because of slow sales during the holiday period.

title: Edgy Japanese Push Several Markets Down
description: As stock prices on Wall Street moved higher this week, the Japanese financial markets headed largely in the opposite direction, and the Finance Minister made comments today that appeared aimed at calming the jitters.

title: If He Can Take a Punch, Judah Could Have It All
description: Zabdiel Judah stands out at Gleason's Gym like Mikhail Baryshnikov at Chippendale's. While barrel-chested pluggers hammer at the heavy bags, Judah's deftly choreographed steps whisk him around the ring as he feints, ducks and jabs, never losing his focus or his balance. At 19, Judah has a command of boxing artistry that many fighters never grasp.

title: Smith and Knicks: Bad Blood Still Flows
description: Charles Smith has filed a grievance against the Knicks through the National Basketball Association players' union, contending that team officials and members of the medical staff withheld information about the severity of his knee injury during his tenure with the Knicks.

title: Troublemakers: Teen-agers, Tusked
description: The call came over the radio as Gus van Dyk was busy exploring the more remote stretches of this 150,000-acre park.

title: In Algeria, Oil and Islam Make a Volatile Mixture
description: Deep in this desperate country there are Americans, dozens of them, ensconced behind high walls topped with barbed wire, living in anonymous camps, pouring billions of dollars into an Algerian state racked by civil war.

title: Pataki Seeks Aid in Crash
description: Saying that the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 had cost State and local governments more than $12 million, Gov. George E. Pataki asked the Federal Government yesterday for financial aid.

title: New Technology Helps Keep Inventories Just Lean Enough
description: Just inside a receiving dock at a Bon-Ton Stores distribution center here, a clerk wields a radio-frequency device to scan the bar codes of roughly 10 percent of a shipment of kitchen gadgets. Then, instead of stacking the boxes in the warehouse, workers move them by conveyor to another truck for delivery to one of the company's 68 stores.

title: A Chance To Make A Difference
description: ON a sunny afternoon yesterday, Ray Rhodes, the Philadelphia Eagles' head coach, was putting his team through its final paces. This morning the Eagles will travel to San Francisco to meet the 49ers in the wild-card round of the National Football League playoffs tomorrow, in a game that is a combination of homecoming and exam.

title: Free Transfers to Subway For Riders of Private Buses
description: The free transfers between subways and buses that will be allowed for Metrocard users beginning next July will also apply to the private bus lines subsidized by the city, according to transit and city officials.

title: CERPROBE BUYS COMPUROUTE FOR $11 MILLION
description: The Cerprobe Corporation reported yesterday that it had acquired Compuroute Inc. and its units, including real estate assets, for about $11 million. Cerprobe said it would take a $4.6 million one-time charge related to the acquisition for purchased in-process research and development in the fourth quarter. Cerprobe said the price for Compuroute was $5.7 million in cash, the assumption of about $1 million in long-term debt and 400,000 shares of Cerprobe stock. Compuroute, a designer and fabricator of printed circuit boards and assemblies, had sales of about $7.9 million for the first nine months of 1996. Cerprobe, which makes products for testing integrated circuits and microelectronics components, reported revenues of $26 million in 1995.

title: School Prayer Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Dornan Files House Complaint To Overturn Election Result
description: Representative Robert K. Dornan, the nine-term Republican from Orange County who has maintained ever since Election Day that he is a victim of voter fraud, has now filed a formal complaint with the House of Representatives, asking that his narrow loss at the polls be overturned.

title: A 'Barber' Without The Rossini
description: Beaumarchais is going it alone these winter nights in the East Village.

title: Churches Shouldn't Complain About Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Chief Leaves the Job
description: Frank J. Wilson, the State Transportation Commissioner who became embroiled in controversy for entertaining job offers from people with close ties to companies bidding on a state contract, spent his last day on the job yesterday. John J. Haley, 45, of Hoboken, a deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was named earlier this month to succeed Mr. Wilson, who resigned last month. Mr. Haley will start work Jan. 6 as Acting Commissioner pending confirmation by the State Senate.

title: Farewell to Hong Kong's Freedom
description: Every step toward the transfer of Hong Kong back to China is a somber reminder that after the recent liberation of so many countries from Communism, a vibrant and relatively free society is soon to be swallowed up by a Communist dictatorship. The rigged selection this month by China of the future chief executive and legislature of Hong Kong make clear that political freedoms will be severely curtailed if not entirely eliminated once China assumes control on July 1, 1997. The remaining question is whether China will also crush Hong Kong's bustling economy and independent judiciary.

title: UNOCAL BEGINS BUYBACK OF UP TO $400 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Unocal Corporation said it would begin buying back as much as $400 million of its common stock. The oil company said it would pay for the buyback, which it announced earlier this month, with part of the $2.2 billion in proceeds from the sale of its refining and marketing assets. Unocal has said it has earmarked $800 million to cut its debt by 27 percent, and $1 billion for oil exploration and production in the Gulf of Mexico and Asia. The $400 million in stock would represent about 4 percent of Unocal's 250 million shares outstanding, based on the current market price. Yesterday, Unocal said it would sell its stake in an oil-refining and marketing joint venture with Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. to the state-run oil company for $250 million.

title: France to Pull Its Planes Out Of Patrols Over Northern Iraq
description: France took another step away from the United States today by announcing that it would pull out of air patrols over the internationally protected Kurdish area of northern Iraq when the nature of the allied mission changes on Jan. 1.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Pond's Ownership Is Murky
description: Mill Pond, a mile-long body of water in the Middlesex County borough of Milltown, has been choked with silt and unsightly weeds for about two decades, residents say. The only solution is to have the pond dredged, with the owner picking up at least part of the cost, borough officials said yesterday. But no one knows who the owner is. The borough hired a company last summer to do a title search and hopes to have the results next week, Councilman Peter Brucato said.

title: Dealer Group Delays Choice
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers again postponed today its announcement of a replacement for its retiring chief executive, Joseph Hardiman.

title: VIVRA STOCK FALLS ON NEWS OF FEDERAL INVESTIGATION
description: Shares of Vivra Inc. fell 5 percent yesterday after the company said Federal prosecutors in Massachusetts were investigating billing practices in its kidney-dialysis business. Vivra's partner in a former dialysis joint venture pleaded guilty in October to criminal charges that the partner billed Medicare and other Federal payment plans for unneeded tests. Vivra, which was not charged, said that it received a subpoena for information related to the dissolved partnership with Corning Inc. and to Vivra's dialysis unit. title: Not a Thing to Wear
description: Nick Kelsh declares that he sought to avoid sentimentality and ''the cult of the cute'' in his photographs of NAKED BABIES (Penguin Studio, $24.95). His intention is valid but the results wind up throwing the infant out with the bathwater in a wash of body parts. Shots of ears, rears, torsos, toes, nostrils and navels abound, objectifying the baby rather than celebrating its human spirit. Occasionally an image captures personality or an elusive moment, as in a photo of a baby boy in Zen-like contemplation of his penis or one blissfully absorbed in sucking his toes. However, most seem disconcertingly detached. In contrast, Anna Quindlen's text reflects wisely on the innocence of of babies. Whether suggesting that ''babies epitomize self before we screw it up'' or imagining birth from the infant's perspective as ''one moment floating in warm salty water. . . . only to wake suddenly in the Lincoln Tunnel at rush hour in a convertible,'' Ms. Quindlen writes with eloquent ease. Speaking as a mother -- she gives due credit to her three children, Quin, Christopher and Maria -- she asks: ''Who was it coined that old saw about God making them so cute so we will not kill them? It has particular resonance at 4 a.m.'' Leslie Chess Feller

title: Sarcastic Cheers for Rookie Turn Into Genuine Article
description: Mike Dunham looked rusty in goal, the Devils looked listless on the ice and the second home sellout crowd of the season was restless.

title: High Costs Are Blamed For the Loss Of a Mill
description: IN October, workers at the American Velvet Company in Stonington felt the tension building as the mill buzzed with rumors that the 104-year-old company might close its doors for good. Between 175 and 200 workers would lose their jobs.

title: Big Wheel
description: 1910-1996 -- People who casually leave their Rolodexes parted at Winona's, or Arnold's, or Stephanopoulos's know that power derives from access. But how many know that that same Rolodex was invented four decades ago by a meticulous Brooklyn engineer named Arnold Neustadter?

title: THE VICE PRESIDENT IN EXILE
description: 1918-1996 He sprang from obscurity in 1968 as Richard Nixon's running mate and, as Vice President, defined an era with his bombastic rhetoric. His political star sank as quickly as it had risen, however, following his 1973 resignation on corruption charges.

title: Talkin' 'Bout My Regeneration
description: WHO says rock music belongs to the young? Annual figures on ticket sales gathered by Pollstar magazine show that on America's concert stages, in arenas and coliseums, rock was ruled by its elders in 1996: performers like 55-year-old Neil Diamond, who grossed $32 million in ticket sales, and Rod Stewart, 51, who took in $29 million. These aging rockers moved into the vacuum left by that 1960's institution the Grateful Dead, who set box-office records through the 90's until Jerry Garcia's death in 1995.

title: Spain's King Honors Sephardic Rabbi for Study of Traditions
description: DURING the first part of the Middle Ages, the ancestors of Rabbi Mitchell Serels of the Magen David Sephardic Congregation here lived in Spain, enjoying what today might be called an atmosphere of multicultural diversity. They practiced Judaism and adhered to Jewish laws, but, like other Spanish Jews, they also got along well with Muslims and Christians in their country. In this so-called golden age, Rabbi Serels said, Spain's Jews were poets, religious leaders, artisans and businessmen comfortable with and an integral part of the Spanish culture, and they were largely accepted and respected by non-Jewish fellow Spaniards.

title: Strikes, Celebrations And a Lot of Brahms
description: NOW IS THE WINTER OF OUR discontent. Maybe it's just the much-heralded coming of the millennium, but a sense of crisis has been spreading through classical-music precincts in the United States and abroad. Cutbacks in music education have led some to fear for the audiences of the future, and cutbacks in public and private financing have made even the present seem perilous for many institutions.

title: Their Mission: To Make a Joyful Noise Unto the Lord
description: At rehearsal Rick Greene kept trying to coax ''a little more 'lu' '' into the hallelujahs. ''Blend, blend, blend!'' he urged as voices built into a soaring chorus of ''Let God arise and our enemies be scattered.''

title: Medical Researchers Battling 2 Emerging Tick-Borne Diseases
description: A WALK in the woods or in the high grass that borders many beaches is not the carefree experience it once was. Over the past decade, Long Islanders have risked being bitten by a deer tick and contracting Lyme disease.

title: THE HEIRESS WHO SAVED THE PEACE CORPS
description: 1936-1996 Ruppe had a habit of turning political patronage into serious missions: in eight years as Peace Corps director, she reinvigorated the organization. And for her ambassadorial work, she was awarded the Grand Cross of the Norwegian Order of Merit.

title: 1996: The Culinary Highlights
description: The chocolate brioche pudding at Blue Sky in Montclair.

title: Examples, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopes Are Moving East on 14th St.
description: As the Union Square area enjoyed a much-ballyhooed renaissance in recent years, East 14th Street remained the sorry stepsister, a bedraggled strip of low-end discounters and graffiti-scarred storefronts that has stubbornly resisted rejuvenation. But the street's fortunes are looking up these days, fueled in part by a growing real estate market and revised zoning rules that have increased its appeal to developers.

title: No Headline
description: ''Nobody in this town has ever said no to a developer. We spend tax dollars to encourage sprawl, and then it comes back to us as air pollution.''

title: The Noogie Rebellion
description: You have to watch those parenthetical asides. I toss them in occasionally, drawing on memory rather than research, and I get burned every time. In a column last month celebrating the new volume of the Dictionary of American Regional English, I wrote about the adjectival use of Indian: ''An Indian burn is inflicted by 'grasping a person's arm with both hands and twisting in opposite directions simultaneously.''' So far, so good; there are those who call this reddening of the skin a snakebite or even an arm hickey, but Indian burn is the most widely used term. Then I added, ''(In the Bronx, that's called a noogie.)''

title: Means and the Jaguars Leave the Bills Behind
description: No way that the Jacksonville Jaguars were supposed to come into Buffalo's impenetrable fortress and defeat the Bills. The Jaguars were an expansion team last season; the playoff-tested Bills were 9-0 in the post-season at Rich Stadium and had a crowd of 70,213 pulling for them.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Beavis and Butt-head Do America

title: A Preference for Sport Over the Sport Utility
description: PEOPLE who drive a lot of new cars may disagree about the merits of a particular model -- or about the future of the automobile, for that matter. But they are nearly unanimous on this: The new vehicles sold in America have never been better.

title: Justice Dept. Scrutinizes McDonnell Douglas
description: The Justice Department is investigating whether the McDonnell Douglas Corporation violated a Federal law that bars military contractors from winning sales contracts abroad by inducing American companies to buy goods from the foreign country purchasing the equipment.

title: Not Everyone Likes New Train Station
description: Regarding the shining debut of Metro-North's Cortlandt Station, as described on Sept. 8 $(''Cortlandt Welcomes New Train Station''$), not all commuters were smiling-- nor will they be.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in the Dining Out column on Dec. 15 about Doc's in New Preston referred incorrectly to James Chew and Steve Olson, two former associates of the owner. They worked with him at Typhoon Brewery in Manhattan; they have not joined Doc's.

title: Still Needed: A Cross-Island Bridge
description: THE ongoing media coverage of the trials of installing EZ-Pass on the Throgs Neck and Whitestone Bridges obscures the baseline issue concerning travel to and from Long Island: the scarcity and geographic imbalance of its bridges.

title: Lacking Barricades, France Is in a Funk
description: THERE is a new idea afoot here, being pushed hard by French leaders: France -- land of revolutions, the avant-garde, the upheavals of 1968 -- has become a ''profoundly conservative'' country deeply resistant to change.

title: Curb Your Briefcase
description: So what do people really keep in their briefcases? It can't be all documents, reports, and magazines, can it? Do you keep anything odd in your briefcase -- or have you noticed anything outrageous in a co-worker's? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Some Spots for Detroit On the Shopping List
description: PEOPLE who drive a lot of new cars may disagree about the merits of a particular model -- or about the future of the automobile, for that matter. But they are nearly unanimous on this: The new vehicles sold in America have never been better.

title: States Dispute U.S. On Welfare Money
description: Federal officials are insisting that the new welfare law requires states to follow Federal criteria even when the states are spending their own money on programs for the poor. Although the law gives the states vast new authority to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums of Federal money, many states assert that the Government is still trying to manage their programs. The states say they should be able to spend their own money to help poor people in any way they want, possibly to assist people who are cut off from Federal benefits.

title: THE CUBBY FILE
description: 1909-1996 Broccoli created one of Hollywood's most successful franchises, producing every James Bond picture through ''Goldeneye,'' except ''Casino Royale'' and ''Never Say Never Again.'' He also made ''The Trails of Oscar Wilde'' and ''Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.''

title: Giuliani Says Improvements in Education and Child Welfare Should Be Felt in 1997
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani predicted last week that in 1997 New York City residents would begin to feel the impact of recent changes in education and child welfare, just as 1996 was the year in which reductions in crime became evident.

title: The Urge To Blurt Plagues Imperfect Strangers
description: CONSIDER the scenario. The jetliner is almost ready for takeoff. Last-minute passengers eager to get seated press forward in a clumsy tangle of elbows, suit bags and wailing babies. But you are already strapped in; your luggage is stowed neatly away. A novel is open on your lap like a prayer book.

title: The Man Who Made the Faces Up
description: 1904-1996 -- Max Factor turned his father's movie-star makeup company into a mass-market enterprise. By the 1960's, Max Factor, now owned by Procter & Gamble, was the major cosmetics seller in chain drugstores.

title: With Surprising Cooperation, New Russian Budget Is Approved
description: In an unusual display of cooperation, the Communist-dominated Parliament and President Boris N. Yeltsin's Government have worked together to adopt a budget for 1997.

title: Carla Hoke and Max Miller
description: THE first thing Carla Hoke heard about Max Miller was that he never wore gray or black suits; he preferred pink ones. She was impressed.

title: Revolution as a Relic Come to Life
description: PERU has a knack for defying political waves that splash over the rest of Latin America. When right-wing military dictatorships ruled its neighbors in the 1970's, a leftist Peruvian dictator confiscated the oligarchy's sugar plantations. When other guerrillas looked to Fidel Castro in the 1980's, Peru's Shining Path embraced Mao. And as the sweet promises of democracy swept the region in the early 1990's, President Alberto K. Fujimori dissolved Congress.

title: Is New York Back?
description: YES. No. Maybe. This being New York, consensus is rare. But themes do come into focus when you listen to 27 New Yorkers, not all talking at once.

title: Military Plane to Get Place of Honor at Airport
description: AFTER months of planning and meticulous work, a restored military jet is ready to assume a prominent place on the access road to Westchester County Airport.

description: Blossom A. Peretz was sitting in her Newark office among the cluttered papers and calculations of her trade when the phone rang. It was a reporter, one of many this day, asking her what it was like to hold what could easily be the most thankless and least understood job in New Jersey government.

title: A Ripple of Neighborhood Crusades on Issues of All Kinds
description: Across Brooklyn over the last year, battles for change and preservation rippled through the borough from Red Hook to Dead Horse Bay, in strikingly grass-roots fashion.

Hoffman of Piscataway, N.J., was married yesterday to David Manning Driscoll, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Driscoll of Taunton, Mass. The Rev. description: Picasso: Faces and Figures

title: Big Events, Little Gems, Lots of Shakespeare
description: FOR ALL OF THE HYPE AND bluster attached to the year's ''event'' movies -- in which twisters ravaged Oklahoma, Madonna was ''Evita,'' aliens invaded (twice), and Tom Cruise hovered over a top-secret computer -- the year's most important films seemed to drift in quietly from someplace other than Hollywood. Many were made abroad, and even those that weren't had the feel of imported products.

title: The Large Picture Gets a Little Bit Fuzzier
description: EARLY IN 1996, A WHITE HOUSE conference ended with the promise of something new for television: an industry-created ratings system that would help parents be better monitors of their children's viewing. Late in the year, an industry group presented a system resembling the one that had been used with movies for decades, and the promise was quickly of something not so new: deep division over whether shows should be labeled only according to age appropriateness or according to levels of violence, sex and coarse language.

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: States' Authority Disputed On Use of Welfare Money
description: Federal and state welfare officials have become embroiled in an unforeseen dispute about how much power the states have over the use of their own money to help poor people under the new welfare law. The question is whether states, in spending their own money, must follow the restrictions that apply to the dollars that they receive from the Government.

description: AT the year's close, it is time to update some 1996 Our Towns columns:

title: Jaguars' Rusher Is the Means to the Bills' End
description: IT was dark and dreary, the way it usually is here when the Buffalo Bills are in the Super Bowl playoffs. But it was warm, with the temperature climbing into the low 50's. Unaccustomed as they were to the thaw in their freezer, the Bills had a home-field disadvantage.

title: Trend-Spotting: It's All the Rage
description: THIS WEEK, WITH THE COMING OF THE NEW Year, there may be a spirit of rebirth at large in the land, a sense of something new about to begin. But if so, the feeling will be all too familiar. The displacement of the old and the celebration of the new has become a year-round habit. In fact, we are always resetting our clocks, recalibrating our sense of newness, ringing out and ringing in at ever faster rates. We have created a culture founded almost entirely on trends.

title: A Policeman Who's Ready To Do Battle For the Police
description: WHO Michael Madonna, 52, of Oakland, the new president of the New Jersey Policemen's Benevolent Association, the parent group for P.B.A. locals across the state. Detective Madonna, a member of the Oakland Police Department for 31 years, was elected on Dec. 5 to succeed Frank Ginesi, who retired after two decades heading the P.B.A. While serving, he'll be paid $24,000 a year and have the use of a car, as well as his detective's salary.

title: Where the Homeless Help One Another
description: THE slogan of the New Haven Homeless Resource Center Inc. sounds inelegant and perhaps a little redundant -- ''The Homeless and Formerly Homeless helping the Homeless and Formerly Homeless to help themselves'' -- but it's accurate.

title: Ethnic Groups Inch Toward Political Mainstream, Buoying Hopes for 1997 Races
description: Even though immigrant New Yorkers sought citizenship at a record pace in 1996, it was still a bit early to expect a groundswell of electoral activism to buoy their compatriots into elected office. Still, as demographic shifts brought new rhythms to old neighborhoods, ethnic groups once on the political fringe inched toward the mainstream, and community leaders optimistically eyed the 1997 Council races.

title: Miss O'Grady, Mr. Sutterlin

Sutterlin of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Betty B. Sutterlin. The Rev. Edward Bognacki performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Roseland.

title: Just a Few More Bowls for a Familiar Voice
description: Correction Appended

title: On a Riff in Kansas City
description: ONE of the legendary jazz scenes of the 20's and 30's, Kansas City, Mo., has spent much of the time since then trying to figure out whether it is still an incubator of great jazz, or whether it even wants to be. Today, the debate seems to have been resolved in favor of a growing revival in live jazz around the city as well as an effort to recover its jazz legacy. A strong statement to that end was made two years ago when the city, along with 25 private contributors, paid $140,000 at auction in London for a white saxophone once played by Charlie Parker. It will be part of a jazz museum opening in July.

title: Fire, Storms and Foul Odors
description: Among the news items from the Bronx in 1996 were a beloved theater damaged by fire, a plastic pier damaged by Mother Nature, some new odors near a fertilizer plant and a school board member who resigned amid death threats. Here are updates on those articles.

title: The 10 Best Affordable Restaurants of 1996
description: DINERS delight in discussing their latest visits to luxurious high-profile restaurants. But most people go to these expensive, prestigious palaces only on special occasions. Yet they frequent ethnic spots, bistros, cafes, pastarias, micro breweries, taverns and barbecues on a regular basis. Restaurants that offer outstanding and sometimes unusual food without making a negative impact on the family budget have in recent years become much like second homes for many.

Singer is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Shaare Zion in Brooklyn.

description: When runners line up for the 1,500-meter race, Gabriel Mazimpaka has a disadvantage. Unlike the other runners awaiting the blast of the starter's gun, he cannot hear it. He has to use the movement of the other runners as his signal, so he begins behind.

title: Childs Saves the Knicks Another Embarrassment
description: They were marvelous one minute, mortifying the next. And when everything was falling down around them yesterday, the Knicks looked to their floor leader to glue it all back together and make life at Madison Square Garden tolerable again.

title: Young Drivers Facing New Year's Eve Alert
description: THE greeting Happy New Year comes with words of warning for young drivers this New Year's Eve. The Zero Tolerance Law, in effect since Nov. 1, lowers the acceptable level of alcohol in the blood to two-hundredths of 1 percent for drivers under 21 (six-hundredths of 1 percent is the legal limit for adults). Young drivers who have had even one beer, a glass of wine or a shot of liquor risk a six-month suspension of their license for the first offense.

title: Gas and Electric Utilities Look Ahead to Mergers
description: Unsure what will be needed to survive in an era of deregulation, more and more utilities are seeking merger partners to help them compete.

title: Mussels Steamed in Broth Chase the Chill
description: ON a recent chilly evening I sat down to a large bowl of mussels at Bambou, a Jamaican restaurant in Manhattan. When the waiter brought the dish, which was filled with plump mussels carefully arranged in concentric circles, the aroma of spices and broth was so enticing that everyone at the table began to dig in and ask for more. Chef Herb Wilson adds curry powder, coconut milk and lemon grass to the broth, a perfect foil for the briny flavor of the mussels.

title: THE TEACHER IS FATHER TO THE CHILD
description: 1897-1996 Harold Tinker went to Choate as an English master in 1923 and stayed for 39 years. The son of a car salesman, he devoted years to the study of Thomas Hardy. His most famous student, John F. Kennedy, often visited his old teacher after he was elected to Congress.

title: New Musicals, New Stages Quicken the Pulse of Broadway
description: NOT EVEN NATHAN DETROIT WOULD have bet that three smash musicals could land on Broadway in one year -- not in the waning days of the 20th century. The two exuberant new ones, ''Rent'' and ''Bring In da Noise/Bring In da Funk,'' with powerful young casts, were joined in November by a gritty, witty revival of the 1975 ''Chicago'' that tips its derbies to Bob Fosse and winks sardonically at America's news-as-entertainment culture. But the biggest surprise is that all three shows originated in the nonprofit sphere, which is expanding as commercial Broadway shrinks.

title: A Corporate Conscience Must Start at the Top
description: ASK 100 chief executives of America's largest companies whether their employees intentionally circumvent corporate policies when they consider them to be in the way, and more than 75 percent will say no. At least that was the finding of a recent Louis Harris & Associates survey for Coopers & Lybrand.

McCleery of Branford, Conn. The Rev. Nancy Charles Miller performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: Peace Means Prosperity (Sort of)
description: NOBODY in Israel would dispute that the signing of the peace agreement with the Palestinians in 1993 did marvels for the Israeli economy. Annual growth rates soared to 7 percent, countries that the Arab boycott had frightened away began trading openly with Israel, and Israeli businessmen began doing business in their own name, rather than behind some foreign front.

title: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime
description: Murder by strangers has declined more than twice as much as murder by acquaintances over four years in New York City, part of a pronounced shift in both the nature and scope of homicide in the city.

description: 1941-1996 Commerce Secretary Ron Brown was the first Cabinet member in 150 years to die on the job. An adviser to Jesse Jackson during his 1988 Presidential bid and a former head of the Democratic National Committee, he had a talent for making deals.

description: Amy Elizabeth Schmidt, a third-year law student at New York University, was married yesterday to Andrew Alston Jones, an assistant corporation counsel for the New York City Law Department. title: Anatomy of a Synthesist
description: 1920-1996 -- A graphic designer who created logos for the likes of Lawry's seasonings, AT&T; and Exxon, Saul Bass made his biggest mark in the movies. Starting in the 1950's, he turned title sequences into an art form, designing visceral, iconic images for the opening credits and posters for the films of Alfred Hitchcock, Otto Preminger and, recently, Martin Scorsese. Here, the director dissects a few of his favorite Bass images.

title: MY SPACESUIT TAILOR
description: 1897-1996 -- In 1934, Russ Colley designed a pressurized flight suit that would evolve into the suit worn by the seven Mercury astronauts (including me) during the first American space missions in the 1960's. The design of the spacesuit became a highly cooperative effort with Russ, NASA and the astronauts. We made many trips to B. F. Goodrich in Akron, where we had give-and-take sessions with Russ and worked hard to construct a suit that would allow maximum flexibility because the astronaut had to take full manual control of the spacecraft in emergencies. We decided to make a suit literally tailor-made to a fraction of an inch around every dimension of the body. Bending your elbow in a pressurized suit was extremely difficult unless the suit was tight enough to overcome the resistance. If the suit was several inches away from the skin, it would have been impossible to move. To keep us cool, Russ designed very thin long-john underwear with tiny coiled wires that would permit airflow around the whole body. He also designed airtight connections at the wrist and around the helmet, a special pressure zipper to prevent air leakage and little fingertip lights on the gloves of the suit for extra illumination during travel on the dark side of the earth. I remember that with all these special connections, it was quite a contortion to get into the suit, but it fit and it worked. When I went on my mission, I had full confidence that I was going *and* coming back. John Glenn

Their work not only traveled the continent; some of it traveled the world. With Picasso, the biggest cat of all (though some would argue the point), we saw both a show of his portraits at the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the publication of the second volume of a generally acclaimed biography by John Richardson. Mr. Richardson brings his readers up to 1917, when Picasso was 36, and he promises more to come.

title: Bang for Bucks

But airlines are balking. They say that altering the fuel tanks would be cumbersome and expensive, and the risk of such explosions is too uncertain to bother with. The cost of making sure that the atmosphere in the fuel tanks is not explosive would vary by airline. Some carriers could simply seal up their center tanks and use only the wing tanks. Others could fly with extra fuel, leaving no space for an explosive air mixture. Some use a molecular sieve that sorts oxygen from nitrogen, rendering the vapor inert.

description: Lisa R. Anthony, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Anthony of Fairburn, Ga., was married yesterday to Dr. Frank D. Curvin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Curvin of Newark. The Rev. Robert M. Franklin performed the ceremony at the Glenn Memorial United Methodist Church on the Emory University campus in Atlanta.

description: FROM THE BEAST TO THE BLONDE: On Fairy Tales and Their Tellers
