title: An Emotional Rescue From More of the Same
description: PEOPLE who drive a lot of new cars may disagree about the merits of a particular model -- or about the future of the automobile, for that matter. But they are nearly unanimous on this: The new vehicles sold in America have never been better.

title: After the Vote: Superstors' Future
description: NEW YORKERS, it seems, are ambivalent about superstores. As shoppers, they often speak of the stores' convenience and selection, even as they tell of feeling guilty for betraying their local mom and pop shops, and the megastores that have opened in the city have tended to do well. But as neighborhood residents searching for peace and quiet and congestion-free streets, they usually try to make it as difficult as possible for the retailing behemoths to open near their homes.

title: After Years of Gains, Minority Students Start Falling Behind
description: Minority students are beginning to slip further behind whites in student achievement after a long period of narrowing the gap, according to a study by a national research group.

title: A BACKSTAGE PASS TO HELL
description: 1927-1996 -- In 1953, G. David Schine toured Europe with Roy Cohn to try to rout out American Communists abroad. Discredited by the Army-McCarthy hearings, Schine worked in his family's hotel business and later went to Hollywood, serving as executive producer of ''The French Connection.'' He died in a plane crash.

title: Not Smiling About School Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: Watching the Kids, With Pizza and VCR
description: Jennifer-Toni Piserchia is just 13, but she has a date for New Year's Eve. Four or five dates, actually, and they're even younger.

title: Teague Is Mr. Big Among the Big Names
description: In a muggy interview room in the bowels of Texas Stadium, George Teague jostled his way through cameras and microphones with a genuine sense of wonder plastered on his face.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 8 about the South Beach area of Miami Beach referred incompletely to the material used in redecorating the lobby of the Hotel Astor. Some of the glasslike material used for the appearance of marble was Vitrocolor; the rest was the original material, known as Vitrolite.

title: A Single Flake, With a Multitude of Facets
description: SNOW (the word) means a six-sided crystal that grows best in extratropical cyclones where the cloud temperature is around 5 degrees. Of course, it might mean other things, especially in a snowy language.

title: Two Brothers and One Landfill Add Up to Long-Term Work
description: Dave Dougherty's friends think he has the world's most boring job. ''It's sort of a running gag,'' he said. ''I tell them I sit around and watch the grass grow.''

title: After Years of Sleaze and Decay, the Great White Way 'Suddenly' Looked White Hot
description: This was the year the glare of the Great White Way became blinding. As the Walt Disney Company and other purveyors of wholesome entertainment rushed in for a chunk of the new Times Square, the once-pervasive signs of sleaze nearly disappeared. Once a textbook case for urban decay, Times Square has become a paradigm of inner-city renewal.

title: Courtship of 2 Utilities Was On-and-Off Affair
description: Since at least the early 1980's, Brooklyn Union Gas has had a gleam in its eyes for the neighboring utility to the east, the troubled Long Island Lighting Company. But it was not until the last year that their mating rituals began to synchronize.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE PRIVATE LIVES OF THE THREE TENORS

title: Celebrities and Designers: Swatches Joined at the Seam
description: ''THANKS for giving a bunch of kids from the ghetto some new suits,'' a member of the Fugees said as the group ended its performance at an extravagant Giorgio Armani party last fall.

title: Putting Pigs in Blankets And Cheese in Puffs
description: On Jan. 1, millions of Americans will resolutely begin diets. But on Dec. 31, they will eat, drink and be merry, throwing caution and calorie counts to the wind.

title: Taking U.S. Pulse: Self-Reliance Is Back
description: RALPH WALDO EMERSON would be glad to hear what Edward B. Keller of Hastings-on-Hudson says consumer research has shown: Americans are embracing the kinds of self-reliance that Emerson wrote about more than a century ago.

title: Dierker: Talk Ends, Managing Begins
description: In his 14-year major league pitching career, Larry Dierker was a 20-game winner once, threw a no-hitter and worked in many other nerve-racking games. Never, however, was he overcome by the feeling that engulfed him earlier this off season.

title: Not So Fast
description: It has been a rough beginning for the Californians who thought they were going to lead the nation in the revolt against affirmative action.

title: Scrutinizing Kmart With a Designer's Eye
description: ASTOR PLACE, the gateway to the East Village, crowded by legends of the free-spirit world. Colorful book, clothing and record stores nearby on St. Marks Place, with colorful staffs to match. Rock clubs along the Bowery. The Public Theater, The Village Voice, the Astor Place hair salon.

title: A Restoration for Historical Society
description: The Brooklyn Historical Society's building at 128 Pierrepont Street, one of the first terra cotta structures in the country, will undergo a $5 million interior renovation and exterior restoration starting in late spring.

title: As a Dance Caught Fire, A Cold Killing
description: IT WAS A BLEAK YEAR financially for the record industry, but musically it was far from dormant. One of the biggest noises came not from the distorted guitars of alternative rock or the angry lyrics of rap but from the dance floor. By summer, the macarena had Americans of every stripe shaking and shimmying -- from the waist up -- to its infectious pulse: partyers at the beach, the women's Olympic gymnastics team and even the grounds crew at Yankee games. Not since the forbidden lambada had a dance import caused such commotion in this country.

title: '97 Budget Is in Place, but Controversy Continues
description: THE Westchester County government at last has a final 1997 budget in place, but the agitation of the last six weeks between County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and the Board of Legislators is apparently not over.

title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
description: 1914-1996 During his 50 years as a professor of economics at Columbia, William Vickrey built a reputation for devising complex theories to solve everyday problems like traffic jams and crawded subways. Vickrey, who did not separate economics from morality, was most recently concerned that a balanced budget would have negative consequences for the nation, particularly the disadvantaged.

title: Sarah M. Kozodoy And Vitali Penso
description: Sarah Naomi Kozodoy, a daughter of Ruth Lurie Kozodoy and Neal Kozodoy, both of New York, is to be married today to Hayim Vitali Penso, the son of the late Ester and Albert Penso. Rabbi Allen M. Schwartz is to perform the ceremony at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: As U.S. Giants Soar, Foreign Ones May Be Bargains
description: WITH big price tags hanging off American stocks, investors may be tempted to look overseas for more economical equities. And that temptation may be the strongest with large foreign companies, because their American counterparts have been the leaders in the long-rising United States market.

title: Smaller Can Be Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Cinematic Gold in the Dysfunctional Family
description: ANDRE TECHINE IS NOT one for self-promotion. In the world of auteur movies, where the director is often revered like a guru, this shy, ascetic-looking Frenchman does not opine on political issues, rarely appears on television and is not surrounded by a court. Fear of flying even prevents him from attending most film openings or festivals more than a train ride from here. Instead, he allows his movies to speak for him.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: I WANT TO BUY A VOWEL

title: Ever on Call
description: DR. J. PATRICK CLANCY hopes he won't have to make any house calls on New Year's Eve.

title: M*A*S*H Note
description: 'Biological father'' is a real sourball of a qualifier. At once evasive and evocative, it is an expression phrase well known to the children of post-meltdown nuclear families; saves us a big, bad mouthful of explanation. Resolutely bloodless, and having about it the astringent stink of science, it recasts Dad 1 as a lab technician. Whenever I spoke those words, I was an apple trying hard to roll myself away from the tree.

title: Why Is It Necessary To Hunt Wild Turkeys?
description: A few summers ago, a wild turkey was spotted stalking the backyards of White Plains. This huge (larger than anyone's dog), handsome bird became the neighborhood delight, and his evening appearances, in different areas of our city, were duly reported in the newspaper. He was unafraid, very receptive to bread handouts and was photographed with many of the children. Nobody would have dreamed of harming him.

title: When Revolt Was Order of the Day
description: In 1968, there were 986 homicides in New York City. No one knew it then, but 28 years would pass before the figure was below 1,000 again. Through the mists of time, 1968 might appear a halcyon year.

title: Hall to Take On Alaska School
description: The Seton Hall freshman standout Shaheen Holloway and the Pirates will play host to Alaska-Anchorage, San Francisco and Rhode Island today and tomorrow in the Seton Hall/ Meadowlands tournament at Continental Arena. Today, the Pirates (4-4) will play Division II Alaska-Anchorage (7-4) at 7 P.M. Rhode Island (5-2) will play San Francisco (4-5) in the second game at 9 P.M.

title: Trouble Spots to Avoid on the Roadways
description: A look at trouble spots you can expect to encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- from the State Department of Transportation.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Sparkling Wine

title: Shirley D. Kalb, Nathaniel Kleppel
description: Shirley Dolinsky Kalb and Nathaniel Howard Kleppel are to be married today in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin R. Sirner is to perform the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue.

title: Collins Wasn't Terrorist
description: To the Editor:

title: State of Squeeze in Lima: a Chronicle Of Terror and Clogged Toilets
description: The hostage crisis in Peru began 12 days ago, when about 20 armed members of the Tupac Amaru guerrilla movement attacked the sprawling residence of the Japanese Ambassador in Lima, the capital, and took hostage more than 500 people attending a reception there. The rebels soon freed more than 400 captives (including all the women), possibly to bring the number of hostages to a manageable level and make themselves appear humanitarian.

title: 3 Boaters Are Found Dead in the Atlantic
description: A brother and sister from East Moriches, L.I., and a friend from Germany who went sailing on Friday were found dead yesterday morning, floating in the Atlantic Ocean with their life jackets on, the police said.

title: Not His Brother's Keeper
description: A former police commander, Guillermo Gonzalez Calderoni, said in an interview last week that Raul Salinas, the brother of former President Carlos Salinas, had accepted cash payments from narcotics traffickers in exchange for promises of political help in purchasing two Mexican seaports. Mr. Gonzalez said he had relayed a message about Raul Salinas's reputed drug deals to the Mexican president in 1991.

title: GOOD SAD
description: 1911-1996 -- He was the father of bluegrass. A spectacular singer, a mandolin virtuoso and a great band leader, Monroe wrote more than 500 songs, including classics like ''Blue Moon of Kentucky.'' He influenced an array of musicians, from Elvis Presley and the Grateful Dead to Alison Krauss.

title: A Look at the Season, Happy and Sad
description: IT is time to look back at events that gladdened -- and sometimes saddened -- music lovers in Connecticut in 1996.

title: Dream Casts
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbs Will Struggle for Democracy Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: UPSTAIRS, WHERE IT'S SAFE
description: 1910-1996 -- Helen Wallenda was born into a carnival family in Germany and joined the Wallendas at 13. She became famous at 17, when she climbed to the top of their human pyramid on the high wire in 1928.

title: Disney Gets Credit; A Word Is Coined
description: What has big mouse ears, wears white gloves and ate New York?

title: Perform First, Applaud Later
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 More Hostages Released By Group of Rebels in Peru
description: Marxist rebels released the Ambassadors of the Dominican Republic and Malaysia and 18 other hostages today after a Peruvian Cabinet official entered the residence of the Japanese Ambassador in what appeared to be the first direct contact between the rebels and the Government.

title: Havens, Vast and Tiny, In Greenwich Village
description: CAFE ASEAN ++

title: A Rout Leaves Isles Reeling, but Blaming No One
description: When you lose by 7-1, as the Islanders did to the Detroit Red Wings here tonight before a sold-out Nassau Coliseum, you can usually pin the defeat on someone or something.

title: Amie Wilkinson, Benson S. Farb
description: Anne Marie Wilkinson, a daughter of Ruth E. VanDemark and Leland Wilkinson of Evanston, Ill., was married last evening to Benson Stanley Farb, the son of Mignon K. Farb and Dr. Stanley N. Farb of Jeffersonville, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Frank C. Senn, a Lutheran pastor, officiated with Rabbi Michael P. Sternfield at the University Club in Chicago.

title: Unfinished Business With Russia
description: The idea of abolishing nuclear weapons picked up some powerful support recently when a group of America's most distinguished military officers endorsed that long-term goal. One of the converts was retired Air Force Gen. Lee Butler, who directed the country's nuclear forces just a few years ago. His eloquent defense of a laudable if still unachievable idea should serve as a timely reminder that the United States and Russia have a left a good deal of arms control business unfinished in the years since the end of the cold war.

title: Peru's Growth Leaving Poor Behind
description: The Marxist guerrilla group holding 83 hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here has long sought to promote a Robin Hood image of stealing from the rich to help the poor.

title: Critic's '96 Choices: New Dining Trends
description: OUR annual inventory of dining spots indicates that this year proved an active one for the restaurant industry. More than in any recent year, 1996 displayed some interesting trends and vital signs, which diners should find exciting. Quite a few new Japanese restaurants, like Hanaka and Sushi Man, opened their doors to a delighted clientele. Some old places juiced up their kitchens and became young again; we think of Le Chateau and Dudley's. And a few recent arrivals like Equus at the Castle in Tarrytown, Koloniale in Hartsdale and Cafe Antico in Mount Kisco offer such lovely and unusual decor that the pleasure of dining begins before the food arrives.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Studs Terkel

title: Italy Braces Itself for Holy Year
description: THE Lombard invasion of northern Italy in the sixth century caused the inhabitants of towns around northern Adriatic cities to take refuge in the lagoons where Venice's graceful palazzi now stand and its quiet canals flow. So it is probably not surprising that a people so shy of hordes is upset by the prospect that the year 2000, the Holy Year the Pope has declared to celebrate the second millennium, may confront them with new waves of invaders.

title: In World Flux, a Constant: U.S. and Iran Still Foes
description: In the heart of Teheran's business district, the 27-acre compound that was once the United States Embassy sits as a little-noticed monument to the most radical time in Iran's revolution, a time when anti-American fever ran so high that young militants held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days.

title: Agony on the Upper West Side Over a Battle to Shift a Gifted Students' Program
description: At first glance, the rancor over Community School District 3's plan to move a program for gifted students from a school on West 84th Street to another five blocks north may have seemed a bit extreme. Candlelight vigils, crowded sidewalk protests, placard-waving pupils, furious letter-writing campaigns -- all for the plight of the gifted and talented?

title: Down by the River: Park Solution?
description: For more than two decades, plans for a waterfront park along the Hudson River have been derailed by political inertia, lawsuits and infighting among neighborhood groups. But for the first time in years, many battle-hardened waterfront advocates see a possible denouement emerging for the strip of collapsing piers and parking lots that now dominate the West Side shoreline.

title: Clothes That Make the Star, the Cast and the Show They're On
description: AS he maneuvers his 1971 yellow Barracuda through the hilly streets of San Francisco, Don Johnson exudes a kind of don't-mess-with-me cool that has been as carefully conceived as the color of his car, which he admits had to be repainted several times until just the right shade was achieved. In the CBS police detective drama ''Nash Bridges,'' he said he felt it was important to come up with the right look, as he did for ''Miami Vice'' in the 1980's. So Mr. Johnson, who is also the show's executive producer, and Richard van Ernst, a San Francisco costume designer, created a uniform for Nash: he wears a T-shirt under a vest (one of them always brightly colored), khaki pants or bluejeans, a blazer (often with an unusual detail like plaid shoulders) and, of course, his signature wire-rimmed sunglasses.

title: Natasha Price, Mark F. Sewell
description: Natasha de Nyse Price, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Michael Price of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Lieut. Mark Fuller Sewell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar F. Sewell Jr. of Trumbull, Conn. The Rev. Stuart A. Kenworthy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony with the Rev. John J. Castaldo, a Roman Catholic priest, at Christ Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: Thousands Attend Burial Of Protester In Belgrade
description: After a passionate speech by an Orthodox priest condemning the policies of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, friends of the first person killed in more than a month of anti-Government demonstrations buried him today in a ceremony attended by thousands of mourners.

title: Nibble, Nibble
description: Glitz and glitter, caviar and champagne are to New Year's Eve what coals are to New Castle. If, by the final day of December, your taste for traditional holiday indulgences has not been satisfied, chances are it never will. Such is the fate of any luxury that becomes routine.

title: Surrogate Consent
description: New York moved to the forefront last week in the debate over the rules that govern experiments on human beings. The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court halted at least 10 experiments by ruling them unconstitutional.

title: Housing Agency Grinch Takes On Residents' Pets
description: Every Christmas needs a grinch. John Comer is it this year in Quincy.

title: For Sports Investors, Dividends May Be Ringside Seats
description: ONE day about 30 years ago, 11-year-old Leigh Leventis finished 16th in his age group in a national bowling tournament and thought he had found his life's calling. ''I wanted to be a pro bowler,'' he said.

title: On Qualifying For an Oscar
description: In a story about Jon Robin Baitz and Ron Rifkin $(Dec. 8$), your writer wrote that the film ''The Substance of Fire'' opened in Los Angeles and in New York for ''only one week: an eligibility requirement for Academy Award consideration before the year's end.''

title: Brett Robinson, Kristina Morgan
description: Kristina Louise Morgan, a daughter of the Rev. Thomas D. Morgan of Kenner, La., and the late Diane B. Morgan, was married last evening to Dr. Brett Malcolm Robinson, a son of Dianna Robinson Stapleton of Englewood, N.J., and Philip A. Robinson of Brooklyn. The Rev. Susan M. Butler officiated at Christ the King Lutheran Church in Kenner. The bridegroom's great-uncle, the Rev. Isaac L. Lester, a Seventh-day Adventist pastor, participated in the service.

title: SHE SAW THROUGH US
description: 1906-1996 -- Her cakes has survived the suburbanization of the 50's and the fat-free restraint of the 90's. By the time she died at the age of 89, the family-owned company she helped to build into an empire had been sold several times over, the last time to CPC International as part of an $865 million deal.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER'S JOURNAL
Correction
description: A picture caption on page 55 of the Television section today about the Sugar Bowl misstates the day for the game. As the article notes, it is Thursday, not Wednesday.

title: The Hidden Meanings of 'Black English'
description: The melting pot is boiling over again, this time with a decision by the school board in Oakland, Calif., to reclassify ''ebonics,'' or black vernacular, as a distinct language. The battle is a familiar one that has raged at least since the 1960's. The issues it raises are too often polarized in a simplistic debate about whether black American speech is ''good'' West African traditionalism or just ''bad'' English.

title: White Player Gets a Chance At Black School
description: It had been only the second game of the season, last Sept. 14, but Southern University, the defending black college football champion, had lost unexpectedly for the second straight time, to Alabama State, 16-14. The players, carrying their helmets, their jerseys disheveled, walked dejectedly away from the night lights of their home field, Mumford Stadium, toward the locker room. Suddenly a man jumped out from the crowd that had assembled near the gate and confronted Southern's starting quarterback, a freshman.

title: Book Marks a Life in Broadcasting Sports
description: AS well as anyone, Bob Wolff, the Baseball Hall of Fame broadcaster, knows how much sportscasting has changed. He recently shared some insights while signing copies of his book, ''It's Not Who Won or Lost the Game -- It's How You Sold the Beer,'' at Borders Book Shop in White Plains. ''I'm a sportscaster, but nowadays I'm also an entertainer,'' Mr. Wolff said. ''That's the way of the world nowadays. I'm now in show business.''

title: BRITAIN'S BRAIN DRAIN
description: 1907-1996 Whittle got the first patents for a jet engine in 1930, at 23, but not the profits - his company was naitonalized in 1939.

title: Miss McVicker, Mr. Christensen
description: Susan Margaret McVicker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles I. McVicker of Roswell, Ga., was married yesterday to Alexander Fletcher Christensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Christensen 3d of Brooklyn. John Strachan, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Aquinas Church in Alpharetta, Ga.

title: There Is an Upside to Jets' 1-15 Disaster (as Difficult as It May Be to Believe)
description: Relax, Jets fans. Your dreams are safe for now. Nobody has turned down an offer to coach the team, not even Bill Parcells.

title: Postcards From 1996 Have a Domestic Stamp
description: FOR a roaming columnist who lives for exciting and exotic datelines, 1996 was never going to be a great year, once the Olympic delegates handed the Summer Games over to Atlanta.

title: Making Balloons Float And Confetti Fly
description: Cone hats? Top hats? Sure. Plastic or paper?

title: Tableware Designed With an Eye on Economics
description: FOUR years ago, the Newark Museum mounted a show called ''The Painted Pot,'' a survey of hand-painted ceramics. Now it's ''The Printed Pot: Fine China for Everyone,'' which traces the history of a decorating shortcut, the process of transfer printing, through about 100 pieces of tableware from the museum's collection.

title: Zoya Leporska, 78, Theater Choreographer
description: Zoya Leporska, a dancer and choreographer and a founder of Dancers Over 40, died on Dec. 16 at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: LIFE IS LONG
description: 1881-1996 Mary Electa Bidwell was supposed to be listed as the Guinness Book of World Records's oldest living American, but she died shortly before the publication's deadline. 1876-1996 Mary Thompson, who was slightly older, couldn't qualify for Guinness's title, either - as the daughter of ex-slaves, she had no birth certificate - but in 1992 she did receive the ultimate American tribute to longevity, a mention by Willard Scott on the ''Today'' show.

title: THE IMPRESARIO OF TASTE
description: 1907-1996 -- He saw his first ballet, with Anna Pavlova, in Boston in 1920, when he was 13 years old. At that time there was no American ballet to speak of. With his money and his vision, Kirstein changed that. By the 1970's, New York was the dance capital of the Western World.

title: From Atlanta To Wembley, Winners All
description: ARCHERY

title: Just the Right Touch For Frosty Reveling
description: Whimsical inexpensive hats are part of many revelers' holiday celebrations. Last year's popular Dr. Seuss ''Cat in the Hat'' style has given way to headgear reminiscent of pieces worn in the 12th and 13th centuries. The most colorful of the medieval styles are the court-jester hats with their stained-glass colors and multiple points, often ending in bells, tassels and pompons. Jester's hats, also referred to as fool's caps in the Middle Ages, now come with felt or velvet horns. Also popular this season is a revival of the Gothic stocking cap, either knitted or cut from printed fabric. Two wearers seen on Fifth Avenue knotted the ends of their stocking caps to keep from losing each other in the crowds (top right).

title: Exposing the New, And Doing It for Less
description: To the Editor:

title: To Shop, Perchance Nonstop
description: KEVIN was busier than one of Santa's elves this holiday season. Not only did he drop hundreds of dollars on presents, he also spent hours stashing them in out-of-the-way places.

title: Giants Keep Looking
description: As his search for a new head coach continues, Giants General Manager GEORGE YOUNG is scheduled to meet with ZAVEN YARALIAN, the team's defensive backs coach, tomorrow at Giants Stadium in what has all the appearances of a courtesy call. Yaralian seems to be the only assistant from DAN REEVES's staff who will be interviewed for the top spot.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Mother

title: Death and the Maid
description: ALIAS GRACE

title: Raising Medicare Standards
description: The agency that oversees Medicare and Medicaid has issued sensible rules that limit the financial penalties managed care plans can impose on doctors who exceed a plan's targets for ordering tests and procedures. Other new rules reflect a growing recognition that the Federal Health Care Financing Administration must assume responsibility for monitoring the quality of care that health plans operating under its auspices deliver to enrollees. That is a notable change of direction.

title: On Eating Disorders Among Male Athletes
description: Thank you very much for your article on the threat of anorexia and bulimia on young male athletes. Although the media has published many stories featuring the advertising, fashion, dance and movie industries voicing a concern about the over-emphasis on models and performers being ''super-thin,'' the plain truth is that nothing has changed. Yours is the first article I have seen on how participating in sports brings forth similar pressures. I see this in the exercise programs I conduct with teen-agers and young adults and on a personal level with my own college-age daughter. These kids are struggling with their self-images against a standard which requires almost starvation.

title: Role of Women in the Military Is Again Bringing Debate
description: The growing reports of rape, sexual assault and harassment involving drill sergeants at Army training bases have rekindled a fundamental debate over how far the military should integrate women into its male-dominated forces.

title: Final Peace Near, Guatemala Braces for Complications
description: This country's civil war has gone on for so long that most Guatemalans have no memory of a time when their nation was at peace. So when Remigio Gutierrez contemplates the final accord the Government and guerrillas are to sign here Sunday to end 36 years of armed conflict, he cannot help being skeptical.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED
description: We felt one hesitation in 1994 when we first set out to review notable lives that ended during the year. Would such an issue, despite our celebratory intent, merely create a somber reading experience? That doubt quickly dissipated. Recalling lives of note, often with admiration and sometimes even joy, turned out to be so satisfying then, and again last year, that the decision came easily to do it again this year.

title: INSIDE
description: Drop in Random Murders

title: 10 Years After Tax Overhaul, the Loopholes Expand
description: TEN years ago this week, the United States put into effect what political leaders hailed as a fairer tax system, wiping out shelters that many wealthy Americans used to prevent much of their income from being taxed. At the same time, maximum tax rates were lowered.

title: A Decision to Save a Lump of Terra Cotta and Brick
description: MOST people would pay to get rid of a deteriorating lump of brick and terra cotta on their roof. But the co-op corporation that owns the 1907 Hendrik Hudson apartments, at the northeast corner of 110th and Riverside Drive, is paying just to keep its lump -- and it wishes it had another one just like it.

title: Northern Vietnam's Fresh Flavors
description: ON a two-week visit to Vietnam last month, I sampled restaurants in three very different cities in the northern half of the country: Hanoi, where the narrow alleys of the old city change to broad, tree-lined avenues in the colonial quarter; Hue, the former imperial capital situated on the Perfume River, its inner citadel guarded by a series of moats; and Hoi An, now a quiet river port but once a thriving commercial center where Chinese and Japanese merchants lived side by side. In each of these cities -- and elsewhere in Vietnam -- the restaurants I tried offered simple traditional food at ridiculously low prices.

title: SHE SOUNDED LIKE GOD
description: 1936-1996 Twenty-one years after her censure of Watergate abuses electrified Congress and the nation, Jordan returned to Capitol Hill to testify on behalf of the children of illegal immigrants. To deny citizenship to those born here, she warned, ''is to derail the engine of American Liberty.''

title: In Last Decade, Innovation Is Buzzword
description: WHAT a difference a decade makes. When I began writing the Dining Out column in January 1987, tiramisu was the Island's cutting-edge dessert, portobello mushrooms and focaccia were virtually unknown and radicchio was just beginning to rear its little red head. At year's end, it is natural to look back and review the months gone by. At the end of 10 years, that reflection becomes a retrospective.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-11

title: What Child Is This?
description: CHRISTMAS PAST

title: JOYCE BY THE HUDSON
description: 1908-1996 -- Like so many great New York journalists, Mitchell was a Southerner, born in Fairmony, N.C. After working for the Herald Tribune and the World Telegram, he joined the New Yorker in 1938, and his reportage became the measure for those who followed him there.

title: G.O.P. Support for Gingrich Begins to Waver
description: The solid front of support from Republicans that Speaker Newt Gingrich has enjoyed since he admitted to ethical lapses has started to break down.

title: Get No Kick from Champagne? Try These New Year's Eve Galas
description: FIRST NIGHT NEW YORK '97 offers an alternative for those who avoid New Year's Eve festivities because of the emphasis on drinking. Over 14 hours on Tuesday, First Night offers a series of New Year's celebrations, all without alcoholic beverages.

title: 30 Years on Fire I.: Capturing Families
description: TAKING pictures of family is rarely a formal event but Peter Harrison, a graphic designer and co-founder of the design firm Pentagram in New York City, has been photographing family on Fire Island -- an extended family, of friends, relatives, visitors, surfers, you name it -- for 30 years.

title: Where Will a Town Hall's Bats Go?
description: BAT alert! About 100 little brown bats recently removed from Town Hall here are seeking places to hibernate, and town officials are advising residents to batproof their houses.

title: On 125th Street, Upbeat Era Is No Sure Thing

The most ambitious is the $56 million Harlem U.S.A. entertainment and shopping complex, planned for the south side of 125th Street between St. Nicholas Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. A Cineplex Odeon movie theater, a skating rink, an HMV record store, a Disney Store and a Gap are planned for the 275,000-square-foot glass-enclosed structure.

Among monuments in the nave to titled worthies and deceased prelates is a plaque ''In Thanksgiving for Sam Wanamaker, Actor, Director, Producer, 1919-1993, whose vision rebuilt Shakespeare's Globe Theatre on Bankside in this parish.''

description: THREE months ago, Marshall Funds of Milwaukee sent a team of executives and portfolio managers to the East Coast to kick off a multimillion-dollar national marketing and advertising campaign. Timed to coincide with the impending three-year anniversaries of several of its funds, the trip was the culmination of a three-year revamping intended to make Marshall, a bank-owned fund family, more competitive with bigger, better-known players like the Strong Funds, its Milwaukee neighbor.

title: As Power Deregulation Looms, Trepidation Mounts
description: PROPERTY managers in New York admit they are in a quandary as the state prepares to deregulate electrical utilities. Some, noting that Consolidated Edison's rates are among the highest in the nation, are rubbing their hands in delight at the prospect of being able to buy cheaper power generated outside the region.

title: A Modest Proposal, With Recipe
description: THE man at the King's supermarket butcher counter in Upper Montclair said the price was $3.99 a pound, and he had only a few Canada geese left. New Year's goose orders have to be in early, butchers say. And don't forget that with a goose, you're lucky to get four servings from a 10-pounder. So if you're planning on traditional succulent roast goose for a New Year's dinner party, figure on spending about what it costs for a pair of Broadway tickets.

title: Affordable Housing Gradually Expands

title: Fighting for the Manicure Trade, Block by Block
description: THE manicurist adroitly applied a finishing coat of polish to her customer's nails, never spilling a drop or straying out of line despite her speed. After 20 minutes of clipping cuticles, shaping edges, buffing nail surfaces and massaging the hands with cream -- taking up tools as if following the beat of a metronome -- she was done. After 10 minutes under a dryer, the nails looked perfect and the customer left the shop -- satisfied. It had cost only $8 plus tip.

title: Are Managers Counting on a Rubber Stamp?
description: INDEPENDENT directors of mutual funds have come under scrutiny for allowing fees on funds to go ever higher. But another practice that has been receiving much less attention raises the same question of whether these directors are, indeed, fulfilling their mandate to act in the interests of shareholders.

title: Adrienne Ruger, J.G. Conzelman 3d

Christian Michelsen of New York and the late James Thompson Ruger, was married last evening to James Gleason Conzelman 3d, a son of Clare Shepley Conzelman and Mr. Conzelman Jr., both of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: A Mother Shepherds Her Family Through a Search for Shelter
description: In six months of homelessness, the low point for Alicia Payton came last May, when her father died. ''I am living in a shelter,'' she says she thought. ''My dad is gone. I have to get an apartment. I have to finish school. What's going to happen next? If I have to die trying, I am going to get my kids out of this.'' Safeguarding the children has always been her top priority.

title: On the Eve Without A Chorus

Downtown the streets were lined with young singles trying to get into the two big Jewish singles events (called by their devotees matzoh-ball parties), one at Webster Hall and the other at System. Around town many sat drinking champagne before embarking on the lines for midnight Mass or simply waiting to party.

title: Aiding Humanitarian Projects in Israel
description: MARVIN M. SIROTA, who has achieved success in the drug business, is a man on a mission. He is president of the Israel Histradrut Foundation in Manhattan, a nonprofit organization that finances health, education, social service and other humanitarian projects for Jews in Israel and North America. Since its inception, the foundation has raised more than $50 million for these causes.

description: IT is the men's health issue that is discussed in jokes and whispers or often not at all. ''For some men keeping impotence a secret is more important than getting it treated and resolved,'' said Dr. Joseph Ashley, head of the Diagnostic Center for Men here.

Back when I was in college, after she had taken a frightful spill down a flight of stairs, she moved to a nearby apartment. But 433 Winthrop Road is where my grandmother lived when I was growing up. And it is where I will always remember her.

title: Shelling Out for Shreds of a Family's Mantle
description: FOR THOSE WHO SCOOPED UP THE GOLD evening bag, the large wooden humidor and the worn footstool, the Kennedy name again proved that it had lost none of its magic. For four days in April, the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis estate auction at Sotheby's in New York proved the best show in town as prices soared into the stratosphere. In the end, the thousands of pieces on the block brought in $34.5 million, roughly seven times the presale estimate. Not so curiously, some items simply stayed in the family. One of the biggest prizes, a set of golf clubs in a tattered bag that carried President Kennedy's initials, was claimed for $772,500 by Arnold Schwarzenegger, the husband of Mrs. Onassis' niece Maria Shriver.

description: Last March, The New York Times, in a series called ''The Downsizing of America,'' told the stories of Americans dealing with the changes that accompany the loss of a job in the fast-changing economy. Talks with five of them in recent weeks reveal that some who were cast from their jobs have found new ones at similar pay, while others are still struggling to re-establish themselves. All share an optimism tempered by a new sense of vulnerability.

description: WHILE many movers and shakers have already booked seats on the Concorde, reserved spots in the world's tony restaurants and secured their places on the yachts of their choice for New Year's Eve 1999, many are still in the contemplation stage. Here are what some people say they'd like to do -- or in a few cases what they will be doing -- on the eve of the new millennium. JENNIFER STEINHAUER

title: Notes from the Underground: Station Renovations Continue. Watch Your Step on the Tiles.

But even as work on other dilapidated, nonagenarian stations got under way, watchdog groups criticized the Transit Authority for construction delays and for some embarrassing glitches like installing slippery floor tiles.

title: The Requiem as Opera of Sorts, And Verdi's Isn't the Only One
description: WHETHER AFFECTING indignation or simply delighting in the outrageous comparison, pundits have long gibed at Verdi's Requiem as one of the composer's greatest operas. Yet it is a bit unfair to focus pious criticism on Verdi's setting of the Mass for the Dead, splendorous as it is. Spectacle seems an intrinsic element, or at least an invariable dramatic byproduct, of any musical requiem.

title: Torture! Carnage! Elephants!
description: Ross Leckie's first novel, HANNIBAL (Regnery, $19.95), is a lusty, full-throttle portrait of the great Carthaginian general, the scourge of the Romans in the third century B.C. and the man who made marching elephants famous. First glimpsed as an aged, scarred warrior, long defeated and awaiting capture by his enemies, Hannibal recounts his exploits as a brilliant military tactician and cold-blooded killer whose family was sworn to the destruction of Rome. Educated in Greek and Latin, he is also introduced early on to warfare and has few qualms about the savagery that goes with it. ''I have seen many crucifixions,'' he recalls somewhat wistfully. ''I have ordered many. But the first of all things is the best and the worst.'' The young Hannibal, sent to Spain to build a mercenary army to guard his country's trading routes, eventually defies the council of elders of Carthage and embarks on his daring march through Gaul and over the Alps into Italy, where his exhausted and depleted army hands the Romans several stunning -- and stunningly depicted -- defeats. Along the way, Hannibal marries Similce, the daughter of a Spanish tribal chief, whose rape and murder at the hands of Roman soldiers only increase his thirst for revenge. Mr. Leckie is least effective in explaining Hannibal's ultimate failure to capture Rome and most effective in describing the Carthaginian's revolutionary tactics. The writing in ''Hannibal'' is direct and unflinching, and even if the frequent scenes of torture and carnage threaten at times to turn the stomach, one is finally left with the powerful image of a lonely, haunted leader, stewing in his hatred and brooding obsessively about his actions: ''A battle is like lust. The frenzy passes. Consequence remains.'' Scott Veale

title: The Gumball Fiasco
description: For years it was a standard feature of many stores, banks and barber shops: a gumball machine bearing a March of Dimes seal. A child could drop in some change, turn the crank and walk away with gum.

title: He Spoke Bird

His ''Field Guide to the Birds,'' for which he painted detailed pictures of each one, has never been out of print since it was first published, in 1934.

title: Laughter and Verse
description: 1931-1996 Only George Starbuck could write a culinary verse homage to Julia Child and call it ''The Staunch Maid and the Extraterrestrial Trekkie.'' Gaunt, sexy and hollow-eyed, he composed some of the most outrageous verse of his time and, with respect to the Vietnam War, some of the most outraged. With their astounding technique, Starbuck's poems helped liberate both language and those who aspired to use it.

title: His Logo and Mine
description: 1904-1996 -- As a tennis player, Rene Lacoste won seven major titles between 1925 and 1929, including Wimbledon, the French Open and the U.S. Open. He invented a ball machine and a steel racquet, but his most revolutionary creation was a shirt with a crocodile on the chest.

title: Ghosts of Dictatorship in South Korea

Mr. Kim, the country's first democratically chosen civilian President in three decades, was elected to eliminate the remnants of dictatorship, not revive them.
