And as has been the case for the six years Ms. Cook had been on the board, the numbers painted a depressing picture when it came to black students -- declines in scores on standardized tests, increases in the percentage of black students placed in special education classes and increases in the number of suspensions and expulsions.

title: Japan Stocks Are Lower
description: Stocks were trading slightly lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks was down 7.69 points, or four-hundredths of a percent, at 19,361.35. On Friday, the Nikkei gained 77.46 points, though for the week over all the index lost 1.6 percent of its value.

title: Marijuana for the Sick
description: Voter initiatives in California and Arizona approving the use of marijuana for medical purposes are spreading alarm among many families and confronting law enforcement officials with a tough dilemma. Although the voters in those two states have clearly spoken, it is impossible for either measure to be carried out without someone violating Federal law. The Clinton Administration thus has little choice but to insist that Federal drug statutes be enforced. That response is not enough, however. Federal authorities need to address concerns that a legitimate treatment for seriously ill patients is being blocked because of broader fears of marijuana abuse.

title: Convict Escapes from Ft. Dix
description: United States Marshals are searching New Jersey and surrounding states for an inmate who escaped from his outdoor work detail at the Federal prison at Fort Dix on Friday. The inmate, Jose Orlando Travieso, was working as a landscaper when he was discovered missing, a marshal said yesterday. Mr. Travieso was five years into a 12-year sentence for cocaine and weapons possession.

title: Letter Suggests Key Military Units Support Serbian Protesters
description: A letter supposedly from military officials expressing solidarity with the anti-Government demonstrators who have gathered daily in the capital's streets for six weeks was read to cheering crowds at an opposition rally today.

title: No Headline
description: ''The North Korean statement is one that the people of the Republic of Korea can accept, because it recognizes the incident, apologizes and promises to prevent a recurrence.'' YOO CHONG HA, Foreign Minister for South Korea. $(A6:1$)

title: Apple Seeing Mixed Results From Cloning
description: Sean Anker, chief engineer for Innovative Edit, a video production company based in Indianapolis, recently decided to stay with a technology that many business people have fled: Macintosh computers. But instead of an Apple machine, he bought a Macintosh clone from the Umax Computer Corporation, a tiny start-up company based in Fremont, Calif.

title: Treasury to Sell Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and the auction of a 52-week bill on Thursday.

title: Protecting the Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigrants in New York Pressing Drive for Dual Nationality
description: Over the last several years, Dominicans, Colombians, Mexicans and others among New York City's newest and largest immigrant groups have been pressing their native countries, often successfully, for the right to retain their citizenship of birth, even after they become citizens of this country.

title: To Facilitate Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday analyzing the decrease in murders for New York City misstated the date for the most recent homicide statistics in some editions. It was Dec. 28, 1996, not 1995.

title: Ferrer Enters Primary From Center and From Bronx
description: Fernando Ferrer supports the death penalty. He would force applicants for welfare to submit to fingerprint checks. He considers late-term abortions ''barbaric.'' He does not come from Manhattan or Brooklyn. And he has issued an appeal, notable for its directness, for Hispanic voters to rally behind his mayoral campaign in a display of ethnic force.

title: Marketing campaigns go digital to cultivate cyberfriendly personas for old-line products.
description: ADVERTISERS that may not be able to walk the cyberwalk are nevertheless talking the cybertalk.

title: 'Gondoliers,' When Sullivan Won
description: There is a higher percentage of music versus spoken dialogue in ''The Gondoliers,'' Gilbert and Sullivan's last major operetta, than in any of their other works. And the best aspect of the colorful production by the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players, which opened on Friday night at Symphony Space, is that it well serves this rich, bumptious score, thanks to the animated conducting of Albert Bergeret and a vocally strong cast.

title: Burnett Units Gain 3 Accounts
description: Three overseas offices of the Leo Burnett Company have been awarded assignments with combined billings estimated at more than $20 million.

title: Both Sides in Albany See State Takeover of Lilco Debt in the Future
description: Though the corporate marriage announced today between Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company could reduce utility costs for millions of Long Island customers, it is widely agreed that more significant savings will require major action by New York State, including possibly a partial or complete takeover of the new company's electric operations.

title: The Alternate Personalities In an Author's Life and Art
description: When Margaret Atwood was in Zurich several years ago on a book-promotion tour, she had a sudden, inexplicable visitation. Looking out a window of her hotel, she thought about Grace Marks, who in 1843 at the age of 16 had been convicted of murdering her employer and his mistress. This was one of Canada's most famous criminal cases. For the author it had become something of an obsession, and in 1974 she had written a television play about Grace, based on the premise that she was guilty.

title: Say That Again?
description: To the Editor:

title: Worst Fears Are Realized With Officers' Arrests
description: The rumors started flying like bullets more than a year ago through Austin, a neighborhood of poverty and pride on Chicago's West Side. And they were ugly tales of the street, something out of one of those life-in-the-hood movies that a grandmother like Leola Spann would never allow her grandchildren to go see.

title: Chicago Dock Says Cityfront Bid Is Best
description: Chicago Dock and Canal Trust, a real estate investment trust, said last week that it had agreed to be acquired by Cityfront Center L.L.C. for $175 million, rejecting a $133 million offer from the Newsweb Corporation.

title: For Interest Groups, Battle Lines Form in Debate Over Social Security
description: With Congress and the nation gearing up for a huge debate on the future of Social Security, labor, Wall Street, corporate America and organizations of the old and the young are quietly marshaling their forces for one of the biggest lobbying battles in decades.

title: Agreement On Hebron Still Eludes Negotiators
description: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators failed to seal an agreement on Hebron today in another round of intensive bargaining, leaving only two days to resolve the issue before a self-imposed target date of New Year's Day.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Now SARAH FERGUSON, the divorced Duchess of York, is giving the coat off her back. It will go to an anonymous beneficiary of the New York Cares Coat Drive. Donors to the drive take the coats to 500 collection sites in New York and New Jersey, and the garments are then distributed through 300 agencies to needy children and adults in New York and New Jersey.

title: Looking Back Offers Insights And Updates
description: MOST newspaper articles register only momentarily, and then it's on to the next headline. But there are stories that have more than a fleeting impact, perhaps because they reveal something about the human condition. What follows is an update on those Metro Matters columns of 1996 that drew the strongest reactions.

title: Empowerment Support
description: To the Editor:

title: A Look in the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Parents Test Limits on TV Access
description: While the United States prepares to test a system of television ratings that is as simple as possible, Canadian broadcasters, after two years of experiments, have found that parents are willing to accept and use a much more complicated system if it better allows them to influence what their children watch.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND

title: Radio Station Consolidation: Good News for Owners, but What About Listeners?
description: Jerry Bell is the longtime news director of Jacor Communications' radio station KOA in Denver. He is also the news director of KTLK in that city, which Jacor acquired two years ago. And in September, when Jacor completed its purchase of two more Denver talk stations, KHOW and KBCO-AM, Mr. Bell's purview expanded even further.

title: Woman Charged With Trying to Kill Her Children
description: A 37-year-old woman was charged on Saturday with trying to kill her two young children by setting fire to their bedroom while they lay sleeping, the Suffolk County police said.

title: 'DEEP REGRET' SENT BY NORTH KOREANS
description: In an unprecedented sign of its yearning to improve relations with the rest of the world, North Korea expressed ''deep regret'' today for sending a submarine full of armed commandos into South Korean waters and for ''the tragic loss of human life,'' and promised not to do it again.

title: Game Plan for Steelers: A Two-Headed Quarterback
description: IN the darkness of the New England Patriots' offices this week, Bill Parcells and his assistant coaches will be clicking their videotape remotes more than usual in scouting the Steelers' two-headed quarterback.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Yes, the Spirit Can Give Young Criminals Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Sometimes you must ask yourself whether an opponent is doing something stupid, and you should nearly always answer yourself in the negative. An obvious situation arises when an opponent leaps majestically into a small slam contract and you hold two aces. Doubling would be foolish, because the chance is 95 percent that the bidder has one void suit and in most of the remaining 5 percent he will have two void suits.

title: What Price Success for the Toroidal Roll?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey's New Law May Let Parents Choose Schools
description: By tucking a single sentence into the 72-page school financing bill that she signed this month, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman hopes that New Jersey parents will soon be sending their children to the public schools of their choice.

title: The King Can Do No Wrong
description: For all their democratic similarities, the political societies of Britain and the United States differ in a profound respect. It is a difference that goes back to the American Revolution.

title: Guatemalans Formally End 36-Year Civil War, Central America's Longest and Deadliest
description: After 36 years of civil war that left more than 100,000 people dead and devastated this country's society, a grateful but weary Guatemala formally returned to a state of peace today with the signing of a final armistice between the Government and the leftist guerrillas who have been its traditional adversaries.

title: On Firm Turf, But Taking A Bold Step
description: When Robert B. Catell, the chairman and chief executive of Brooklyn Union Gas, looks out from his office on the 23d floor of the company's downtown Brooklyn headquarters, his vista is the borough where the utility has prospered for more than 100 years. But these days, Mr. Catell is looking far beyond Brooklyn's borders as he seeks to assure the long-term vitality of his company.

title: BOARDS AUTHORIZE A MERGER OF LILCO AND BROOKLYN GAS
description: In a deal with far-reaching political and financial implications, Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company agreed yesterday to a merger that would create a new utility and perhaps lead eventually to deep cuts in electric rates -- now the highest in the continental United States -- for 1.1 million customers on Long Island.

title: Former Suburban Police Chief Is Charged With Killing Wife
description: The Illinois State Police today charged the former police chief of this tiny suburban community with the Dec. 19 murder of his wife.

title: The Year's Memorable Films Paint the World in Light Hues and Dark
description: This year in film seemed more like two. The most memorable films of 1996 suggested parallel universes, one light and one fascinatingly dark. A mordant outlook, along with chilly detachment and often pitch-black humor, was the year's most pervasive force.

title: Red Cross Worker Wins Fame in Peru
description: Michel Minnig had only recently arrived in Peru and had not had time to finish unpacking when he was suddenly thrust into the biggest crisis in his 11 years at the Red Cross.

title: A First for the Season: Nets Win Two Straight
description: He was not the aloof, distant teammate. Shawn Bradley became a comfort -- in his own odd way -- when he cupped the rookie behind the head and pulled him in for a pat on the back.

title: Cross-Border Satellite Beams Get Mixed Reception
description: Satellites are sloppy. When they beam down television programs from outer space to home satellite dishes in the United States, they tend to spill signals all over such artificial landmarks as national borders, a bit of physics that hundreds of thousands of avid television watchers in Canada and Mexico have come to discover.

title: Note to Readers
description: The columnists are occasionally appearing out of their normal sequence because of holiday schedules.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EBERHARD MULLER, executive chef and part owner of Lutece, walked into the restaurant with PAULETTE SATUR last week and said to the staff, ''Let me introduce you to the new Mrs. Muller.''

title: A Battle of Manufacturers in Wireless Telephones
description: Lucent Technologies and Northern Telecom Ltd. are leading makers of almost everything needed to build wireless telephone networks.

title: St. John's Ends the Year With Some Momentum; Now for the Big East
description: The odds are good that St. John's will not win the Big East Conference title this season, or even finish among the top teams. What the Red Storm may be able to do, however, is force its opponents to take it seriously, something it has not always done over the last two seasons.

title: GROWING OPTIMISM FOR PEACEFUL END TO CRISIS IN PERU
description: Optimism is growing here that the hostage crisis at the Japanese Ambassador's residence can be resolved without bloodshed after a Government official and Marxist rebels met face to face on Saturday for the first time. Both sides appeared to soften their positions.

title: Welfare Recipients Need Wages, Not Workfare
description: Now that Federal law allows them to, the states can end welfare entirely for able-bodied adults. They should replace it not with workfare but with a system that pays real wages for community service work. Participants will not only move more quickly into private-sector jobs, they'll get more money. And so will their states' economies.

title: A Spreading Furor Over 'Black English'
description: When the school board in Oakland, Calif., wanted to do something about the poor performance of black students, it decided that a language barrier might be part of the problem. It endorsed the idea of using ''black English,'' the distinct language of many low-income blacks, in the classroom to reach such students.

title: T.W.A. Has Reason to Trim Atlantic Flights
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Democrat Lost Till He Won. Or Did He.
description: For the first time in Samuel M. Levine's hapless 32-year political career, his wife, Lee, did not accompany him to election night headquarters last month. ''I didn't want to be disappointed again,'' she said, ''and I didn't want to see him disappointed again.''

title: Abstractions Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Republican Urges Gingrich To Step Down
description: One of Speaker Newt Gingrich's most enthusiastic supporters today became the first Republican to announce that he would not vote for Mr. Gingrich for a second term as Speaker, saying that Mr. Gingrich's explanations for admitted ethical lapses did not ring true.

title: Woman Found Slain in Store in Queens
description: Two young women, lifelong friends who vanished early Friday after leaving a nightclub in Jamaica, Queens, were found yesterday morning locked inside a storefront about half a mile away. One had been badly beaten and the other had apparently been bludgeoned to death.

title: Ringing in Recycling
description: The onset of every new year always brings a surge of self-improvement projects for cities as well as individuals. New York will begin 1997 with a new initiative that combines mundane grit with long-term impact. The Giuliani administration will start a five-year program to close down the environmentally hazardous Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island and switch over to a combination of garbage export and recycling.

title: A High School Crowd And Loving and Longing
description: Luscious Jackson's initial appeal five years ago was as a basement project. Soulful, homemade dance music by sophisticated Manhattan women, its tentativeness betrayed musical limitations, but an attractive modesty, too. The band's second full-length album, ''Fever in Fever Out'' (Grand Royal/Capitol), ought to stretch the fragile concept to the breaking point, if for no other reason than that it has an MTV-generated audience now and can no longer hide within its own insular triangulations of nostalgia, primarily the collision of New Wave and disco in the 80's.

title: Police to Track Cabs Overcharging at New Year's
description: As revelers stumbled around the East Village last New Year's Eve, wearing garish party hats and blowing long red plastic horns, empty yellow cabs cruised up First Avenue with their off-duty lights turned on. As they approached St. Marks Place they stopped, rolled down their windows and haggled with pedestrians in a hurry to get home or hop to the next party.

title: Trial to Begin in Killing
description: Last December, Rita Gluzman learned that her estranged husband, a prominent biologist who emigrated with her from Russia, had filed for divorce. Today she is in jail in White Plains, awaiting the Jan. 6 start of her Federal trial on charges that she, with the help of a cousin, hacked her husband into 60 pieces and dumped them in the Passaic River near the electroplating company the Gluzmans owned in East Rutherford.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Liquor Industry Rise Cited by Impact
description: After 15 years of declines, shipments of cases of distilled spirits to wholesalers are expected to increase slightly in 1996, primarily because of more robust demand for higher-priced liquor brands.

title: The Perils of Victory For Nassau Democrats
description: On Jan. 1, Samuel M. Levine becomes Judge Levine -- presiding judge, the first Democrat ever to preside over Nassau's 26 county district court judges.

title: Former Social Service Worker Finds Help and Hope
description: As a caseworker for a social service agency, William D. often appeared in New York City Family Court on behalf of his clients, most of whom werethe parents and guardians of children in foster care. But when William found himself in Housing Court this year fighting eviction, he had no one to stand beside him.

title: INSIDE
description: Social Security Strategies

title: Interceptions Turn Tide As Eagles Wash Out
description: Ray Rhodes returned today to the mother ship, and found it flooded.

title: New Realities of Life In a One-Paper Town
description: When The Houston Post was shut down in April of last year, Tony Pederson, managing editor of the surviving Houston Chronicle, took dozens of calls from concerned readers of his former rival, and most were about one thing.

title: Viggo F. E. Rambusch, 97, Dean Of Church Architects, Is Dead
description: Viggo F. E. Rambusch, an architect who coordinated the decorating, lighting and furnishing of more than 1,000 churches, synagogues, theaters and other public places, died on Friday at White Plains Medical Center near his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 97.

title: People
description: * Michael F. Parkinson was named worldwide director for technology at Landor Associates, San Francisco, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Dean Fernandes, who continues at Landor as a senior consultant for interactive branding. Mr. Parkinson had been manager for information services at the consumer products division of the Walt Disney Co., Burbank, Calif.

title: Dub Reggae's Spread and a Daunting Task in Jazz
description: Glen Brown and King Tubby

title: Trade Deficit in Vietnam Climbs 80% to $4 Billion
description: Vietnam said yesterday that its trade deficit had soared by more than 80 percent, to a record $4 billion, in 1996 as its economy pulled in imports faster than it could produce goods for sale abroad. The General Statistics Office estimated the volume of exports for the year at $7.1 billion and imports at $11.1 billion, creating a trade gap much higher than 1995's $2.2 billion.

title: NCR stock is trading high, and some analysts wonder why.
description: ONE of the most disastrous corporate acquisitions in recent memory comes to a close today when AT&T spins off the NCR Corporation, just five years after its hostile takeover of the computer maker. But you would not know how painful a stretch it was from watching Wall Street.

title: That Flashing Crazy Quilt of Signs? It's Art
description: Say what you will about the transformation from porn parlors to Disney megastores, but whether Times Square has been cleaned up or sanitized, it has clearly been transformed by a spate of new billboard and light displays. At the moment, the most mesmerizing public art in New York City is this collective and expanding jumble of flashing signs, capped by the new Panasonic video screen on One Times Square, the keystone building of the neighborhood, from which the New Year's ball descends tonight.

title: New Year in Las Vegas
description: To the Editor:

title: Crazy for Conspiracies
description: Once the obsession of a dedicated but tiny band, conspiracy theories now seem to have captured a wider audience.

title: In Growth, State Ranks 34th
description: New Jersey is a leading destination for immigrants, but not for people from other states. ''More people are moving from New Jersey to other states than from other states to New Jersey,'' Thomas Espenshade, a sociology professor at Princeton University, said yesterday. Because of that trend, the state ranked only 34th among the 50 states for its rate of population growth between July 1995 and July 1996, the Census Bureau reported yesterday. New Jersey grew by 0.5 percent, or 38,000 people, during that period.

title: Back Home in Georgia, Some Gingrich Backers Have Second Thoughts
description: Over the years, in election after election, Newt Gingrich always managed to dodge the ethics grenades lobbed by his Democratic opponents, at least partly because no investigative body had ever issued findings against him.

title: E. W. BLANCH TO TAKE A CHARGE TO EARNINGS
description: E. W. Blanch Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it would take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $22.75 million, or $1.05 a share, to reorganize its wholesale insurance brokerage operations in San Antonio. The charge, which had been expected, will consist of $19.5 million to write down good will remaining from the company's 1994 acquisition of the Elton George Companies and $3.25 million as a reserve for the reorganization. Minneapolis-based Blanch had been expected to earn 38 cents a share in the fourth quarter, based on the average estimate of three analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc. Blanch primarily reinsures other companies' risks but also provides risk-management consulting and administrative services.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Malaysian Company Investing in 2 Concerns
description: Berjaya Industrial Bhd. said yesterday that it would buy controlling stakes in two companies for 664.5 million ringgit ($263.7 million) in a move to build one of Malaysia's largest diversified companies. Berjaya Industrial plans to buy 32 percent of Promet Bhd. for 350 million ringgit in cash. Promet has interests in engineering and construction.

title: I.B.M. Makes New Hard Drive
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had developed a computer hard-disk drive that can store three times as much information as the most advanced models now available.

title: Films Surprisingly Yielding Surprises
description: The most interesting thing art can do right now is thwart our expectations, sneak, push or spill past the accepted boundaries of form, genre and style. And it is the same with human relations: at their most interesting they make us question or expand the meaning of terms like parent and child, husband and wife, lover, friend or sibling; they ask for something beyond the usual rituals and pieties.

title: Tumble for Stocks of High-Price Retailers
description: The stock prices of several luxury retailers fell sharply yesterday as investors apparently feared that fourth-quarter results would be disappointing for some high-end merchants.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about a concert by Peter Schickele on Thursday at Carnegie Hall misidentified the syndicator of Mr. Schickele's radio series, ''Schickele Mix.'' It is Public Radio International, not National Public Radio.

title: TEXLON TO SELL NOTEBOOK COMPUTER UNIT TO DYNATECH
description: In an effort to focus on its core businesses, the Telxon Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Itronix Corporation notebook computer unit to the Dynatech Corporation for $65 million. Telxon, based in Akron, Ohio, said it would post a pretax gain of $35 million from the sale. Dynatech, based in Burlington, Mass., makes testing equipment for the communications industry, like equipment for testing fiber optic data lines. Separately, Telxon said it would take charges totaling $25 million in the quarter, related to job cuts, early retirements and a decreases in the value of inventories.

title: Hogs and Pork Bellies Surge; Corn and Soybeans Decline
description: Hogs and pork bellies leapt their daily trading limits yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after the Agriculture Department said the nation's hog and pig herd was smaller than expected.

title: U.S. REPORTS FOES IN KOREA WILLING TO DISCUSS PEACE
description: A day after North Korea expressed regret for sending a submarine into the South, the Clinton Administration announced today that North Korea had agreed for the first time to talk with South Korea and the United States about the possibility of negotiating a formal end to the Korean War.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For the 25th year, DICK CLARK will be the host of the New Year's Eve television broadcast in Times Square. It will be shown on ABC tonight. ''In the old days, the show was my wife, me, a cameraman, an audioman and a group like Three Dog Night, the Beach Boys or Chicago,'' said Mr. Clark, who became famous to millions of Americans with ''American Bandstand'' from 1956 to 1989. In the early days of the New Year's Eve broadcast, he would start on the street, talk to the crowd and run into 1 Times Square, take the elevator to the top floor and go to the rooftop patio. But one year, all the elevators were so full that he barely got to the roof on time.

title: UM HOLDINGS IN DEAL TO MERGE UNIT WITH CYBEX
description: UM Holdings Ltd., the parent company of Trotter Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in Cybex International Inc. Terms were not disclosed but Cybex and Trotter, both manufacturers of fitness equipment, will merge. UM Holdings, a privately held company based in Colorado Springs, will take a 50.001 percent stake in Cybex, which is based in Ronkonkoma, L.I. Current Cybex shareholders will continue to own the remaining 49.999 percent of the combined companies. The transaction is expected to be completed late in the first quarter of 1997. For the nine months ended on Sept. 30, Cybex had a loss of $788,000, on revenue of $56.9 million.

title: Reeves Gets His Chance, But Slips
description: It was the emblem. Was it new? Khalid Reeves wanted to know, hoping someone would explain to him when and why the Knicks decided to stick what amounted to a car-sized, 50-year celebratory decal on the middle of the court.

title: Russian Industry Needs Western Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Rules on Trial Dates
description: Courts have no obligation to give formal notice of a new trial date to a defendant who failed to show up when the trial was originally scheduled, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Police Say Man Killed Ex-Girlfriend and Himself
description: A 35-year-old Bronx woman was stabbed to death yesterday in her Bronx apartment, and the police said they believed she was killed by her former boyfriend, who was found hours later hanged in his Harlem apartment.

title: In Changing Times, Whither Apple?
description: IN January 1984, just before he demonstrated the new Macintosh personal computer to Apple Computer Inc.'s board of directors for the first time, Steve Jobs recited a line from the Bob Dylan song ''The Times They Are A-Changin'.''

title: Gretzky's All-Star Effort Keeps the Rangers on a Tear
description: This was a day to savor for Wayne Gretzky and Brian Leetch, who were voted to starting positions on the Eastern Conference All-Star team.

title: Banc One in Deal to Acquire Oklahoma Bank
description: The Banc One Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy the Liberty Bancorporation of Oklahoma City for $546 million in stock.

title: Virus's Similarity to Body's Proteins May Explain Autoimmune Diseases
description: FIRST the victims suffer a flu-like illness: aches, chills, headache, a fever. They gradually recover, never really knowing what hit them. But then -- perhaps right away, often much later -- their immune systems begin to attack various cells and tissues in their bodies.

title: Wuerffel Trying To Avoid Maelstrom
description: The reluctant focal point of the Sugar Bowl is sidestepping the issue that has defined the University of Florida's attempt to win its first national football championship.

title: Auto Incentives Seen From Italian Government
description: The Italian Cabinet has approved a widely expected package of incentives intended to increase car sales, the Ansa news wire reported yesterday, citing unidentified people in the Government. The incentives are intended to encourage people owning cars more than 10 years old to turn them in and acquire a new one.

title: Vatican Museums Get A New 'Ambassador'
description: The Vatican is not a place usually associated with youth. After all, Pope John Paul II is 76, and the man to whom he entrusted the care of the Vatican Museums, Carlo Pietrangeli, was 82 when he died last year.

title: Boomers' Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston Shares the Stage with Hot-Handed Rookie
description: A duel at 10 paces would have been just as dramatic.

title: Chief of Rockefeller Fund Planning to Resign in '97
description: After eight and a half years at the helm of one of the nation's largest philanthropic organizations, Peter C. Goldmark Jr. said yesterday that he planned to resign in the coming year as president of the Rockefeller Foundation to pursue as yet undetermined interests.

title: F.T.C. REVIEW TO DELAY MATTEL-TYCO TOYS MERGER
description: Mattel Inc.'s proposed acquisition of its rival Tyco Toys Inc. will be delayed by a Federal Trade Commission request for more information about the merger of the No. 1 and No. 3 toymakers, the companies said yesterday. Mattel and Tyco cannot complete the acquisition until 20 days after they have answered the F.T.C.'s questions. Mattel offered $12.50 a share, or about $755 million, for Tyco. Shares of Mattel fell $1.125, to $27.875, and Tyco slipped 12.5 cents, to $11.625. Earlier this year, Mattel's unsolicited $5.2 billion bid for Hasbro Inc., the second-largest toymaker, was withdrawn because of antitrust concerns.

title: Dutch Builder Buys Stake in Company
description: The AGIV Group, a holding company based in Frankfurt, said yesterday that it had sold its 74 percent stake in the construction company Wayss & Freytag A.G. to the Dutch builder Hollandsche Beton Groep N.V. for 300 million guilders ($172 million). The acquisition will nearly double H.B.G.'s annual sales to 10 billion guilders and increase the number of employees to 25,000 from 18,000.

title: Ring In the Old
description: Ringing out the old year on Times Square is an American rite that goes back almost a century, and although pulling it off these days is complicated by strobe lights and TV, the idea remains pristine in its simplicity. People come to 42d Street and Broadway -- or as near as they can get -- and stand in the cold, waving pompons and hopping up and down to restore circulation to the feet. At midnight the big ball drops. Everybody cheers. Music plays. Horns toot. Kisses are exchanged. Then everybody leaves.

title: Blunt Message Sets Scene for Singapore's Election
description: SINGAPORE  Residents of the Bukit Gombak public housing estate in the central part of the main island of Singapore have a powerful inducement to end their support for the opposition and vote for the candidate of the governing party in general elections Thursday.

title: More People Opting for Surgery to Treat Obesity
description: All Jerry Poole wants in the coming year is this: that a surgeon's scalpel slice his great girth open, and that his digestive organs be permanently reconfigured so that he can eat no more than will fit into a pouch the size of a small egg.

title: Rockefeller Foundation Is Losing Its President
description: After eight and a half years leading one of the nation's largest philanthropic organizations, Peter C. Goldmark Jr. said yesterday that he planned to resign from the presidency of the Rockefeller Foundation to pursue as yet undetermined interests.

title: Hispanic Settlers Transform Harding Park in Bronx
description: Pepe Mena was heading south toward the Bronx shore in his trusty car one sunny afternoon 34 years ago, just he and his wife out for a rambling drive, when he stumbled upon a neighborhood that made his heart rear up in his chest.

title: A Nation's Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns and New Year's Eve: A Lethal Mix
description: Houstonians got a message on their water bills this month. ''Don't turn some neighbor's New Year's into a nightmare,'' it said. ''Please don't celebrate by shooting a gun into the air.''

title: With Game on the Line, Hall Hits Free Throws
description: For the second straight game, Seton Hall's fate was decided at the free-throw line in the final seconds. But tonight, it came down to shots made, not missed, for the Pirates in a 72-70 victory over Rhode Island.

title: Religious Leader Describes Decision to Help Clinton After Hearing of Woes
description: The members of an international religious group chipped in $600,000 to President Clinton's legal defense fund after a major Democratic fund-raiser made a pilgrimage to its headquarters in Taiwan and described Mr. Clinton's legal problems, the group's leader said.

title: Pain Won't Keep Young Away From Green Bay
description: Steve Young will take one for the team a shot, that is.

title: Deal for Zeolite Maker
description: Corsaire Snowboard Inc. said today that it would buy a 90 percent stake in closely held Zeolite Mira for $10.8 million in cash and stock. Corsaire said it would make a down payment of $1.25 million for the Italian company, whose primary product is zeolite, a mineral that replaces phosphates in detergents. Rene Hamouth, the Corsaire president, said that Corsaire had been ''a shell company'' that was set up to buy snowboard makers but had never entered that business.

title: Straight Talk In the Debate Over Ebonics
description: HERE'S an idea sure to go nowhere fast: recognize that vast numbers of New Yorkers speak a distinct language that may be called ivonics. It is not named after the former Mrs. Trump. The word combines ivory and phonics, and applies to speech patterns of European origin that virtually define what many Americans think of as a New York accent.

title: South Returns Remains
description: In a sign of improving relations on the Korean Peninsula, the Government here today handed over to North Korea the remains of 24 infiltrators who were killed after they slipped ashore from a North Korean submarine in September.

title: Lyle Fitch, 83, Administrator Of City Under Mayor Wagner
description: Lyle C. Fitch, an authority on urban problems who served as City Administrator under Mayor Robert F. Wagner and later as president of the Institute of Public Administration, died on Saturday at the Meadow Lakes retirement community in Hightstown, N.J. He was 83.

title: Gambling With Health
description: The city's Public Advocate, Mark Green, believes that the financial incentives being offered to doctors and pharmacists to promote the use of certain prescription drugs are comparable to the payola scandals that rocked the recording industry in the late 1950's.

title: Miami's Davis Joins Giants' Coaching Derby
description: The former Giants coach Dan Reeves spent part of yesterday cleaning out his office at Giants Stadium. Around the same time, Bob Tisch, the team co-owner, met with General Manager George Young and John Mara, the executive vice president, presumably to go over the coaching candidates Young interviewed last week in the continuing effort to replace Reeves.

title: Yes, You Can Do Something About the Weather
description: AS a youth in Brooklyn, he was helpless when the lords of baseball moved his beloved Dodgers to Los Angeles -- a calamity, he jokes today, that ''precipitated the decline of American civilization.''

title: Home Resales Surged a Surprising 1.8% in November
description: Spurred by falling mortgage rates, sales of existing homes rebounded smartly in November after five straight months of declines. For the year, sales are headed for a record total of more than four million, figures compiled by the National Association of Realtors showed today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: PHILIPS UNIT TO LAY OFF 160 WORKERS IN A REVAMPING
description: The Philips Consumer Electronics Company said yesterday that it would lay off about 160 workers in the first quarter because it planned to end refurbishing operations at its television assembly plant in Greeneville, Tenn., by March 31. Philips, a unit of Philips Electronics N.V., plans to give the work to contractors. The plant employs about 1,500 people. The steps are part of a reorganization of the ailing consumer electronics division, hurt by high production costs, tough competition and a stagnant consumer-electronics market in Western Europe. Philips Consumer Electronics makes Philips Magnavox products.

title: $211.5 Million Award in Patent Lawsuit
description: Haworth Inc. said yesterday that a Federal court had awarded it $211.5 million in a patent-infringement suit against Steelcase Inc., ending a 17-year-old dispute between the two office furniture giants.

title: China's Economic Growth Eases for the Year to 9.7%
description: China's robust economy expanded at the slowest rate in five years in 1996, reflecting the Government's efforts to trim growth and push down inflation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GILLETTE CO., Boston, said its proposed purchase of Duracell International Inc., Bethel, Conn., for about $7.82 billion in stock and debt, had been approved by shareholders of both companies.

title: Hanspard to Turn Pro
description: BYRON HANSPARD, an all-America running back at Texas Tech and a Pentecostal minister, said he will pass up his senior year because the National Football League offers a bigger platform to spread his faith.

title: Outdoor Systems Plans 2 Acquisitions
description: Outdoor Systems Inc. in Phoenix, an outdoor-advertising company that has been expanding aggressively throughout the year, has agreed to two additional acquisitions.

title: Jerusalem Thoroughfare Is Designed to Provoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich to Conduct Election on Schedule
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich plans to hold the election for his job on Jan. 7 as scheduled and run as planned, regardless of whether the House ethics committee has decided how to punish him for his admitted violations of the ethics code, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: For Student Orchestra, Star Soloists And a Blend Of Legacies
description: For anyone who regularly attended Alexander Schneider's annual Christmastime concerts with the New York String Orchestra, the student ensemble he founded in 1969, the group's performances will probably always evoke a mental image of Schneider at the helm. That may seem unfair to Jaime Laredo, who has conducted the orchestra since Schneider's death in 1993. But Mr. Laredo has largely maintained the spirit of Schneider's approach, a neo-Romantic interpretive view in which warmth and depth of string tone are primary considerations. Works by the Viennese Classical composers are played with a heftiness that was common in the 1950's and is only lately coming back into fashion.

title: Groove Tube: A Virtual Year in Cathode Reality
description: Looking back on 1996 gives us a handle on what to expect in 1997.

title: Cave Explorers Are Rescued
description: More than 12 hours after they rappelled into a 100-foot vertical mine shaft in Rockaway Township, four inexperienced cave explorers were rescued early yesterday, The Associated Press reported. They tried to climb out of the shaft, but ice, water and moss made the trip back up too slick and strenuous for the explorers, Frank Wainen of Dover, and Keith Sargent, Ray Zeglin and James Comeskey, all of Randolph. The authorities were alerted Sunday night when the group failed to return. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Double Nightmare for Fichaud and Islanders
description: It was to have been Eric Fichaud's dream matchup.

title: Grandmother Is Frail, but Holds Family Together
description: Each morning at 6, Annie Nicholson, 56, pulls her frail, aching body out of bed in her small Brooklyn apartment and begins another day of cooking, cleaning, caring for two grandchildren and their stepsister and struggling to keep together a family that drugs and misfortune have threatened to tear apart.

title: Alteration of Genes in Brain Cells Shows How Mice Remember Maps
description: THE memories of a mouse may seldom rise above the mundane but it probably creates them with much the same genetic machinery as do humans in recording their sometimes more exalted thoughts. Hence two groups of biologists are celebrating a sharp new insight gained into the mechanisms by which a mouse forms memories of new environments and keeps track of where it is.

title: GRANITE CONSTRUCTION TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN TIC HOLDINGS
description: Granite Construction Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 30 percent of TIC Holdings Inc., an industrial construction company based in Steamboat Springs, Colo., for about $21 million. Granite, a heavy construction contractor, said it would acquire 10 percent of TIC this year and would make an offer to TIC's shareholders next spring for the additional 20 percent of the shares, after completion of TIC's 1996 audited financial statements. Granite, of Watsonville, Calif., said its long-term goal was to acquire a majority interest in TIC.

title: Stock Funds' Intake Slows, Then Resumes
description: Money trickled into equity mutual funds in December at the slowest pace since July, as investors took a seasonal breather from their love affair with stocks to avoid the taxable payouts that many funds make near year-end and, early in the month, to steer clear of market volatility.

title: MetroStars Go to Rio for Their New Coach
description: Carlos Alberto Parreira, who steered Brazil to its World Cup triumph in the United States two years ago and who is considered one of the world's top soccer coaches, signed a two-year contract yesterday to coach the MetroStars.

title: In South Korea, the Strikers Take a Break for New Year's
description: Trade unions suspended their five-day-old general strike today for the New Year's holidays, but they threatened to resume it with more force than ever at the beginning of next week.

title: Industrial Pollution Declines
description: New Jersey industries have reduced their emissions of pollutants and production of hazardous waste by 12 percent each year since the Pollution Prevention Act became state law in 1990, state environmental officials said yesterday.

title: Cadets Look to Cap Their Glorious Season
description: For the Auburn Tigers, the Independence Bowl today presents an uncomfortable way to end a disappointing season.

title: Bond Prices Barely Move In Slow Day
description: Treasury prices ended the last full trading session of the year little changed yesterday in thin trading.

title: HarperCollins Trade Unit Head Resigns in 'a Mutual Decision'
description: After less than a year as president and publisher of the HarperCollins trade publishing group, Jack McKeown has resigned, the company said yesterday.

title: Birds That Nest in the Grasslands Find Their Habitats Under Siege
description: THERE'S an uppie,'' Dr. Peter Vickery said as a mournful whistle washed over the Kennebunk Plains of southeastern Maine like a tendril of ocean fog. ''Uppie'' is shorthand for the upland sandpiper, a lanky shorebird with an atypical terrestrial life style for its kind: it usually gets no closer to the shore than this blueberry barren eight miles from the Atlantic coast.

title: Hoboken Loft Still Off-Limits
description: One year ago, Serena Bocchino and her family moved out of a loft in a former factory that made mercury-vapor lamps after learning that they had high levels of mercury in their urine. Since then, they and the 34 other occupants, many of them artists, have been living and working in temporary apartments and studios paid for by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency while officials determine whether they can ever return home. Last week, the agency proposed including the building among the state's sites earmarked for cleanups under the Federal Superfund program. That insures that the residents' relocation costs will be paid for at least another year, Richard Cahill, an agency spokesman, said yesterday.

title: How a Writer Tinkers, Imitates, Tailors, Shines
description: THE PRACTICE OF WRITING

title: There Is No Rest for the N.F.L.'s Weary
description: This weekend's division playoffs will match the well rested against the road warriors. The Green Bay Packers and the Denver Broncos will see if home-field advantage throughout the post-season is the best launching pad for a trip to the Super Bowl.

title: Beer Maker Is Sold To a Group of Investors
description: Pripps Ringnes A.B., the Scandinavian brewing venture owned by Orkla A.S.A. of Norway and Volvo A.B. of Sweden, said yesterday that it would sell its Hansa Bryggeri unit to a group of investors for 410 million kroner ($64 million). The sale had to be announced by yesterday to satisfy conditions established by the European Commission when the merger between Pripps and Ringnes was approved in 1995.

title: Young American Designers Make Inroads Into Japan
description: A few months ago, a dark chauffer-driven sedan pulled up to one of those unprepossessing East Village shops with dressing rooms so tiny they can double as fashion torture chambers. The driver let out his passengers, young female Japanese tourists, who spent the next half-hour at the Daryl K store trying on clothes, buying clothes, oohing and aahing.

title: Marian Shaw, Theatrical Producer, 80
description: Marian Shaw, a theatrical producer and the widow of Irwin Shaw, the novelist and playwright, died on Friday in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 80 and lived in Klosters, Switzerland, and Mougins, France.

title: Assault Charges Dropped For Low-Level Diplomats
description: To judge by the police report, the two men arrested on Sunday near West 81st Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan should have been very nervous yesterday, and perhaps a bit hung over.

title: Hull Retires Without a Ring
description: Buffalo Bills center KENT HULL retired yesterday after an 11-year career that included four straight Super Bowls.

title: U.S. Mediator Meets Netanyahu And Then Arafat in Hebron Push
description: The special American envoy to the Middle East shuttled between the Israeli and Palestinian leaders today to seal an agreement on an Israeli withdrawal from most of the West Bank city of Hebron by year's end. At the same time, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel grappled with right-wing backers increasingly incensed by the prospect of their Government's ceding most of a city they deem Jewish by birthright.

title: Clinton's Pick Declines Offer Of Party Job
description: Despite the Democrats' triumph in holding on to the White House, President Clinton has failed to enlist his first choice to be chairman of the Democratic National Committee and is now casting a wide net for someone to lead a party organization beset with debt, recriminations and investigations into its fund-raising.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the signing of a peace agreement in Guatemala located President Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen incorrectly in some copies. He was at the left, holding a peace torch with a guerrilla leader, not third from left.

title: Former Oppenheimer Trader Is Censured
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had punished a former trader at Oppenheimer & Company for concealing trading losses that cost the firm almost $900,000.

title: To Ask How Is to Ruin Magician's Magic
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban on Air Shipment of a Device
description: The Federal Government today permanently banned the shipment by passenger plane of oxygen generators, the chemical devices blamed for the Valujet crash in Florida in May.

title: A Mixed Bag On TV Ratings
description: Fox's telecast of San Francisco's victory over Philadelphia Sunday in a wild-card playoff game produced a 21.0 overnight Nielsen rating, a nine percent increase from a year ago. Of the weekend's four games, it was the only game whose rating was above 1995's. NBC's Pittsburgh-Indianapolis game on Sunday generated a 19.3 rating, down from 19.7 a year ago. ABC's Jacksonville-Buffalo game on Saturday rated a 15.3, down two percent from last year; the network's second game, Dallas's defeat of Minnesota, posted a 17.5 rating, down from 18.1 a year ago.

title: U.S.-French Relations: A History of Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: Companies Assume Some Risk to Cut Their Insurance Costs
description: Randy Whitchurch is just the kind of hard-headed business executive who is giving big insurance companies headaches these days.

title: Seat on Big Board Is Sold
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold yesterday for $1.29 million, an increase of $60,000 from the previous sale. Owning one of the 1,366 seats on the exchange is the admission ticket to trading on the world's largest stock exchange. Membership gives holders the right to trade stocks and vote at exchange meetings.

title: Retail Growth Proves Slowest In Northeast
description: Wall Street boomed, women wrapped themselves in Gucci scarves and tourists flooded New York City, floating from Niketown to Planet Hollywood in a spending daze. Yet retail sales in the Northeast appear to have lagged behind those in the rest of the country in 1996.

title: New Attention to Harsh Conditions in Peru's Prisons
description: For decades, human rights groups have spoken out against deplorable conditions inside Peru's penitentiary system, where many inmates live in cold, overcrowded cells that have no running water or toilets except for a hole in the floor.

title: Michael Bruno, 64, Economist And Israel's Banking Chief
description: Michael Bruno, a former head of Israel's central bank and a chief economist of the World Bank who was widely regarded as a leading authority on fighting inflation, died in Jerusalem on Thursday . He was 64.

title: A Calm Between the Storms Helps the Pacific Northwest
description: After the worst snowstorm in 20 years brought down roofs, knocked out power and snarled virtually all types of transportation during the busiest travel time of the year, the Pacific Northwest is now bracing for a more familiar weather problem: heavy rain.

title: Hoteliers turn to the data base in search of a new means of more effective direct-mail marketing.
description: DATA base marketing, in which companies identify potential customers and mail them promotional material, has become a popular tool among hotels, particularly upscale ones, seeking to establish or expand their guest bases.

title: Accounts
description: Tri-State Acura Dealers Advertising Association to Teletime Inc., Jericho, L.I., to handle media buying on its account, with billings estimated at $6 million to $7 million. Those duties had been handled by Media Buying Services International, New York, owned by Aegis Group P.L.C. DeVito/Verdi, New York, handles creative and marketing assignments. Acura is sold by the American Honda Motor Co.

title: Softening His Stance, Bruno Says He Will Support Rent Protections for Poor Tenants
description: Just weeks after calling for abolishing rent regulation for almost all tenants but the elderly and disabled, the Republican leader of the State Senate softened his position today, saying for the first time that he would support maintaining protections for poor renters as well.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 23 about St. Irene Chrysovalantou Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Astoria, Queens, which recently acquired a relic venerated as part of the hand of St. Irene, referred incorrectly to the disposition of a lawsuit filed by the church against two local Greek-language newspapers, which had suggested that the theft of an icon from the church in 1991 may have been a hoax. While one paper printed a retraction as part of a settlement, a judge dismissed the suit against the second paper; they did not both print retractions.

title: Q&A
description: Sun Pillars

title: Senate Leader in Albany Offers Tax Cut Plan
description: Saying the state's economy is more vibrant than it has been in years, the Republican leader of the State Senate announced a plan today to reduce business, energy and property taxes by $2.1 billion by 2001.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Big Dutch Insurer To Buy Providian Unit

title: 'Boheme,' Engine of Met Debuts
description: Probably no work in the standard repertory has provided more singers with debut opportunities at the Metropolitan Opera than ''La Boheme,'' by Puccini. Mimi and Rodolfo are touchstone parts. And the four supporting roles, while presenting few vocal challenges, offer fully formed characters to newcomers hoping to make an impact.

title: About That Lilco Debt
description: With the proposed merger of Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company, Gov. George E. Pataki has achieved the first step toward his goal of eliminating Lilco and reducing electricity rates on Long Island.

title: Sobering New Year's Party
description: As Times Square prepares to toast the New Year, the police have vowed to confront anyone drinking alcohol or getting out of hand. Page B1.

title: Categories Are Revised In Fund Spotlight Tables
description: Beginning today, the Mutual Fund Spotlight table each day will be revised to reflect a new way of categorizing funds.

title: Credit Agency Upgrades Lilco Debt
description: A top Wall Street credit-rating agency upgraded its assessment of Long Island Lighting Company debt yesterday, while assigning ''negative implications'' to Brooklyn Union Gas's credit because of its decision to pursue a merger with Lilco.

title: All Walks of Life Protesting in Belgrade
description: Aleksandra Pavlovic zipped up her down coat, adjusted her furry hat against the cold and checked her whistle, a plastic one that she and tens of thousands of other demonstrators blow daily in exuberant chorus on the streets of Belgrade.

title: Mysterious Light From Tiny Bubbles Finds Practical Uses
description: FOR 62 years physicists have marveled at the mysterious light emitted by microscopic bubbles when liquids are bombarded by blasts of high-pitched sound.

title: In the End, Pancakes Will Tell the Tale for Two Tackles
description: The tackles are eligible. One can win a national title, and someday maybe an election, while the other can win the lottery, and someday maybe a pancake house.

title: French Unemployment At 12.7% in November
description: Unemployment in France hit a record 12.7 percent in November, resuming its recent steady rise after a surprise drop in October, the Labor Ministry said yesterday. The number of unemployed rose by 20,700 last month, after a 12,000 decline in October, to reach 3.12 million after adjusting for seasonal variations, the Labor Ministry said.

title: Hong Kong Executives Buy 15% of China Financial Proxy
description: Executives of Citic Pacific Ltd., China's largest investment vehicle in Hong Kong, acquired 15.5 percent of the company today in an effort to increase its independence and growth prospects.

title: How Afghans' Stern Rulers Took Hold
description: When neighbors came to Mullah Mohammed Omar in the spring of 1994, they had a story that was shocking even by the grim standards of Afghanistan's 18-year-old civil war.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: New Year's Day

title: Chess
description: Emil Sutovskij, a 19-year-old Israeli grandmaster who emigrated from Russia in 1992, won the World Junior Championship last month. He scored 10-3 in the tournament, sponsored by the International Chess Federation and held in Medellin, Colombia, from Nov. 8 to 22. Altogether, 58 players competed in the Swiss-system event, which was for players under 21 on Jan. 1.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Among the 1,035 people on the New Year's honors list of QUEEN ELIZABETH II are the expected superstars -- and a news vendor.

title: Stocks Fall As Investors Take Profits
description: A late wave of year-end profit-taking pulled stocks lower yesterday.

title: China Rushes Cases Against Dissidents Before Shifts in Law
description: China is preparing this week to carry out a series of legal reforms hailed by some as a step toward greater rule of law and protection of individual rights. But the impending changes seem to have provoked officials around the country to speed up the prosecution and sentencing to long prison terms of political dissidents, and several Chinese scholars and Western human rights advocates say they do not expect the changes to end the abuse of police powers any time soon.

title: Air Force Computer Invaded As Hackers Forge Web Page
description: At least one computer hacker broke into the Air Force's main World Wide Web computer early Sunday morning, replacing the service's home page with obscenities and anti-Government slogans, an Air Force spokesman said yesterday.

title: Elizabeth E. Freudenheim, Freelance Writer, 70
description: Elizabeth Ege Freudenheim, a freelance writer and author who specialized in writing about crafts, textiles and the arts, died yesterday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 70.

title: Be Resolute, Mr. Clinton. Here's How.
description: President Clinton's second term officially begins on Jan. 20. But now is the time for New Year's resolutions. Here are a few suggestions, some more serious than others.

title: Current Account Deficit Soars in South Korea
description: South Korea's current account deficit soared tenfold in November as exports tumbled, driving the year's shortfall to a record high. The nation's current account deficit is likely to exceed the Government target of $22 billion this year as widespread labor strikes pummel production at steel, auto and other industrial companies. The rising deficit reflects slumping sales by computer chip manufacturers, which account for 18 percent of all exports.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Dec. 30 letter on religious programs for inmates rendered the writer's given name incorrectly. He is Robert Cohen, not Mark.

title: Let It Snow
description: Winter usually means rain, snow and such and calls for protective footwear. There are plenty of bad-weather boots that are both stylish and practical.

title: Magda Denes Is Dead at 62; Wrote of Hiding From Nazis
description: Magda Denes, a psychoanalyst who had just completed a book recounting her torment as a Jewish child hunted by the Nazis in wartime Budapest, was found dead on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 62.

title: Mesa Proclaims Innocence
description: Cleveland Indians pitcher JOSE MESA went on national television in the Dominican Republic to tell his countrymen that he is innocent of a felony charge of sexual harassment. ''I want to tell the Dominican people that I am a man of irreproachable conduct and, as a public figure who has succeeded in the United States, they want to sully my reputation,'' Mesa said in a television interview Sunday.

title: Doctors Criticize Move Against State Measures
description: In threatening doctors with sanctions if they prescribe marijuana for patients, the Clinton Administration says it is buttressing its fight against drug use by young people and countering the effects of two recently approved ballot initiatives in California and Arizona that declare marijuana legal if used for medical purposes.

title: 9 States Joining Plea To Ban TV Liquor Ads
description: Nine states have asked to join Alaska in requesting that the Federal Communications Commission prohibit television and radio stations from running commercials for distilled spirits.

title: An Upwardly Noble American Wants the Mansion
description: The only private citizen ever invited to address the Russian Parliament was Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, who spoke to it in 1994, the year he returned to his homeland after 20 years in exile.

title: Critic of Gingrich Is Warmly Praised at Home
description: Jo Ann Doyle, 42, has known Representative Michael P. Forbes since junior high school and, while she is a Republican like him, she is quick to say they do not always see eye to eye.

title: Jets Leave Coaches Twisting In Wind
description: The Jets' long slide into oblivion is taking the latest batch of assistant coaches headlong into unemployment.

title: INSIDE
description: Merger's Impact on Con Ed

title: Peru's Premier Foresees Peaceful End to the Hostage Crisis
description: In the first prediction by a Peruvian government official of a bloodless end to the captivity of 83 hostages being held by leftist guerrillas here, Prime Minister Alberto Pandolfi said today that he expected a solution that ''protects the physical well-being and lives of all of the hostages.''

title: People
description: Tony Fisher was named to the new position of senior vice president and group creative director at Deutsch Inc., New York. He has worked for agencies including Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, New York, a unit of Havas Advertising, and Ally & Gargano, New York, which closed.

title: '97 Questions For Knicks And Nets
description: AS the Knicks and the Nets say goodbye to 1996, both franchises are chasing familiar goals. The Knicks are still searching for an elusive championship. The Nets are still searching for consistency and respect.

title: Meeting for Dollars
description: The steady drumbeat of recent Democratic fund-raising disclosures does not leave much doubt that party fund-raisers were bartering meetings with President Clinton for contributions during the election campaign this year. The latest disclosures, based on documents released by the Democratic National Committee, make it urgent for Attorney General Janet Reno to abandon her now untenable position that she lacks sufficient information to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the possibility of illegal fund-raising.

title: Visions of TV Sugarplums in 1997
description: To make the new year even happier, the most creative minds in television are about to show off approaching treats to the press in Hollywood. I am staying home, but I have my dreams.

title: Patterns
description: A Return to Madison Avenue

title: If Directx Simplifies, Confusion May Result
description: YOU just want to pop a beer and a Martian or two. Instead you must answer incomprehensible questions about ''drivers that have not been certified,'' after which you discover your Windows 95 machine does not work quite the way it used to.

title: No Headline
description: ''I've seen my share of barroom brawls and drunken debauchery. It's the night of the year you never look forward to as a musician, but that's why First Night is so fantastic.''

title: What American Friend?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article yesterday about workers' protests in South Korea referred incorrectly in some editions to the status of labor unions. The law bans multiple unions in a workplace, not all unions. (In practice, this has often meant that a tame, Government-approved labor union is authorized while others are not.)

title: Humana to Trim Staff as Much as 5% as Health Care Profits Sag
description: Humana Inc., an operator of managed health care plans, said it would cut 700 to 900 jobs, or as much as 5 percent of its work force, in 1997 as it struggles to reduce costs and stem a decline in earnings.

title: In Turkey, New Accusations of Links Between Police, Politicians and Criminals
description: As a lurid political scandal continues to unfold in Turkey, President Suleyman Demirel has denied that the current Government uses death squads against its enemies and appealed for patience and restraint in the face of new disclosures.

title: BIOFIELD STOCK SOARS ON RESULTS OF PRODUCT STUDIES
description: The shares of the Biofield Corporation soared 59 percent yesterday on the strength of clinical studies supporting the company's application to sell a new system to diagnose breast cancer in the United States. Biofield said that the review of its application for Food and Drug Administration approval of the device would be expedited. Analysts predicted the system would have sales of $600 million to $800 million a year. Shares of the Atlanta-based company rose $5.25, to $14.125, in Nasdaq trading. In clinical studies of more than 1,000 women, Biofield said it found its Alexa 1000 System to be about 95 percent accurate in determining which tumors were cancerous.

title: Apartment Fire Kills Woman
description: A 49-year-old woman died and several families were left homeless after a fire spread through three apartment buildings in Jersey City yesterday afternoon, officials said. The woman, whose identity was withheld pending notification of her family, was declared dead at 6:55 P.M., apparently of smoke inhalation, said Eileen Videtti, a spokeswoman at nearby Christ Hospital. No other injuries were reported.

title: Should Old Drunken Revelries Be Forgot?
description: As New Year's Eve is the time to look back and remember what was with fondness and forgiveness, it seems fitting to consider the occasion itself. Whatever happened to that old rowdy holiday that prompted thousands of drunken tourists, thousands of drunken teen-agers and a few dozen sober pickpockets to get together for an annual revel in Times Square?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Employee of Store Where Woman Was Found Slain Is Sought in Inquiry
description: Queens detectives were searching last night for an employee of a small store in Jamaica, Queens, saying they want to question him about the death of a young woman whose body was found in the store near where a friend of hers was found badly beaten.

title: Gingrich Says Ethics Decision Won't Delay Vote for Speaker's Job
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia plans to hold the election for the Speaker's post on Jan. 7 as scheduled and run for the job as planned, regardless of whether the House Ethics Committee has decided how to punish him for his admitted violations of the Houses's ethics code, his spokesman said tonight.

title: Pataki Names Lawyer to Top Post at Environmental Agency
description: Gov. George E. Pataki promoted the top lawyer at the Department of Environmental Conservation yesterday to be its acting commissioner.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Utility Merger May Press Con Edison to Lower Power Rates
description: By creating a huge new competitor in Consolidated Edison's own backyard, the proposed merger of Brooklyn Union Gas with the Long Island Lighting Company will put new pressure on the region's largest supplier of electricity to lower rates and allow its customers to search out different energy options, analysts said.

title: Tandy Plans To Close 17 Superstores
description: The Tandy Corporation conceded yesterday that its Incredible Universe stores, a chain of superstores the size of three football fields that sell everything from computers to refrigerators to cassette tapes, were not so incredible after all and, in a bow to Wall Street, said it would shutter the unprofitable operation.
